Message: Will you be playing a game of this over the weekend?  http://bbc.in/15p9030  It may seem prehistoric nowadays, but Space Invaders, which is about to celebrate its 35th birthday, has had a huge influence on gaming and the wider world.  (Picture courtesy Getty Images)

Can your 13-year-old spell "knaidel"? This one can.  http://bbc.in/18DfTCm  Nerves of steel were needed for the live final of the US National Spelling Bee which saw two 13 year olds compete for a $30,000 prize.  (Picture courtesy AFP/Getty Images)

Learning from failure: Top tips.  http://bbc.in/18DfNun  Ever since European settlers arrived searching for new opportunities, North America has embodied a culture of independence and willingness to take risks.   (Picture courtesy Getty Images)

A US woman has been freed after spending a week in a Mexican jail fighting drug-smuggling charges.  http://bbc.in/18CZGgB  Yanira Maldonado, 42, left the jail near Nogales, Mexico and crossed into the US state of Arizona on Thursday.

Turkish police have used tear gas and water cannon against protesters occupying a park in central Istanbul.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22732139    Scores of people have suffered injuries, several of them when a wall collapsed during a police chase.

The US and Germany have called on Russia not to supply Syria's military with an advanced missile system they say could prolong the conflict there.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22734537    US Secretary of State John Kerry said the delivery of Russian weaponry would have a "profoundly negative impact" and put Israel's security at risk.    German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle urged Moscow not to hinder the chances of mooted peace talks.

Africa Beats: Zimbabwe's Mokoomba, a band from Victoria Falls, has had an extraordinary journey.  Watch them perform here: http://bbc.in/18CPq7X  In the last couple of years, they have exploded onto the world stage, and delighted audiences with their youthful exuberance, musical brilliance and slick dance routines.

Here's an update to a story we shared yesterday:  http://bbc.in/15oNoDV  A seriously ill woman who was denied an abortion by the Supreme Court of El Salvador says she will undergo a premature Caesarean section next week.  (Picture courtesy AFP/Getty Images)

450 million people globally have a mental health problem. Here's one story from India.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-22689652    This BBC News series, presented by Claudia Hammond, examines mental health care provision around the world.    (Picture courtesy Science Photo Library)
How difficult has it been for you to find a job?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22727373    Unemployment in the eurozone has reached another record high, according to official figures.

Do you see faces in hills, on Mars and in toasties?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22686500    There's a name for it apparently. Anyone who has looked at the Moon and spotted two eyes, a nose and a mouth has felt the pull of pareidolia.

Hi, it's Babita Sharma here preparing for today's Impact programme.    We're looking in detail at the governing body of world football, FIFA, which has overwhelmingly approved plans to stamp out racism.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22728162    Delegates representing more than 200 nations approved new measures including deducting qualification points from national teams if their supporters racially abuse players.     Do you think the plans will make a difference? And what are your views about tackling racism in football?    Let us know and we'll read your comments on air from 1300GMT.     See you then.

Is the Chinese President, Xi Jinping, committed to political reform? Relatives of victims of the 1989 Tiananmen killings don't think so.     Read why: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-22727940    The Tiananmen Mothers group sent an open letter to Mr Xi, accusing him of taking "giant steps backwards towards Maoist orthodoxy".

Here are a few of the (lighter) stories that have us talking in the newsroom. Which is your favourite?  - Sir Patrick Stewart discusses his first ever pizza slice http://bbc.in/18AuhLA - Cellist set to recreate BBC's first live outside broadcast http://bbc.in/18AuhLG - India's Trailblazers: The female stand-up  http://bbc.in/18AueQ3 - The lamp that tells your family you’ve fallen asleep http://bbc.in/18Aui22

The BBC’s Frank Gardner – himself a multiple gunshot wound victim – recently spent a week in the trauma unit of the Los Angeles County Hospital, where he saw several gunshot wound victims each night.  Tonight on BBC World News America we join Frank as he witnesses first-hand how people's lives are torn apart by gun crime in the violent heart of California’s largest city http://bbc.in/18zKXTm  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and keep up with our latest news and features on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/18zKVLv

This is Nik Gowing.   Our next BBC World Debate will ask: ‘Burma: What Future?’ http://bbc.in/15mnFMt  Joining our panel in Nay Pyi Taw will be the Nobel laureate and opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and Minister U Soe Thane, a key figure in the reform process.  Leave your questions for the panel in the comments section below.  Or use the hashtag #BBCDebate on Twitter.

Have you ever dreamed of living in Texas?   New figures say that half of the 10 fastest-growing cities in the US are in the state of Texas http://bbc.in/18zivBg  The BBC's Tom Geoghegan takes a look at some of the reasons behind the Lone Star State's population growth.

The Supreme Court of El Salvador, where all abortions are prohibited, has refused to allow a seriously ill pregnant woman to have an abortion, even though her foetus has almost no chance of survival.  Lawyers for the young woman - who suffers from lupus and kidney failure -  argued that continuing the pregnancy would place her life at risk.  The foetus itself is missing part or all of its brain.

Russian opposition: Sochi Winter Olympics a 'monstrous scam'.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22720228  As much as $30bn has been stolen ahead of next year's games, Russian opposition leaders say.

Does the traditional Windows 'Start' button make much of a difference? Microsoft seems to think so.. now.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22714048    Microsoft has confirmed a 'Start' button is returning to the desktop mode's taskbar of its Windows 8 operating system.

Will this end the fighting between Burma and the Kachin rebels?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22716088    The Burmese government and ethnic rebels from the Kachin Independence Organisation (KIO) have reached a seven-point ceasefire deal.    (Picture courtesy AFP/Getty Images)

The Niger Delta: Before the oil.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22487099  The BBC's Will Ross visits a Nigerian community still making a living from traditional farming and fishing, but other communities aren't as fortunate.

Syrian president says army 'has balance of power'.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22713119    The Syrian army has scored "major victories" against rebels and now holds "the balance of power" in the conflict, President Bashar al-Assad has reportedly told a Lebanese TV station.    Mr Assad is also quoted as saying Syria has received the first shipment of an advanced Russian air defence system.    (Picture courtesy of AFP/Getty Images)

500-year-old secrets revealed: Take a look what historians are calling "Britain's Pompeii".    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-22639505    The Mary Rose was the pride and joy of King Henry VIII's warship fleet before it sank in 1545.     It was raised from the seabed in 1982, but only now are we getting a real insight into what life on the Mary Rose was like.    (Illustration courtesy of the Mary Rose Trust)

Muchas gracias Bon Jovi: Should other stars follow his lead?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22712497  The US rock star has revealed that his band has waived its fee at a concert in the Spanish capital Madrid next month, given the country's economic crisis.

Woolwich murder suspect Michael Adebowale appears in court, charged with murdering the soldier Lee Rigby in south-east London on the 22nd of May.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22713349    A handcuffed Michael Adebowale, 22, confirmed his name and address as the charges were read out. A second man, Michael Adebolajo, remains under arrest in hospital.

The Chinese baby boy who was rescued from a toilet pipe is now out of hospital and in 'very good' health.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-22712895    His 22-year-old mother, who has not been named, said the baby slipped into the toilet and went down the pipe by accident as she gave birth.    The baby left with his mother's family, an official with the Pujiang propaganda department told the BBC.

The second-in-command of the Pakistani Taliban has been killed in a suspected US drone strike, a senior Taliban source told the BBC.  The Pakistani Taliban leadership has not officially confirmed the death of Waliur Rehman so far. Earlier, Pakistani security officials said a local Taliban commander was among casualties in the raid.  The strike is the first for almost six weeks.

Facebook has said it will review how it deals with "controversial, harmful and hateful" content after admitting current measures are not effective http://bbc.in/15joQfw  This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at Facebook's promise "to do better" and other news from around the world, including:  - First gay couple married in France http://bbc.in/15joQfy - Syrian women in Jordan "sexually exploited" http://bbc.in/15joQfu - More US mothers are family breadwinners http://bbc.in/15joPbC - America's wolf population http://bbc.in/15joPbA  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter - I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/15joPZg and all of our North America news can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/15joPby

What would you ask Aung San Suu Kyi? http://bbc.in/18viezb  As Burma's military leaders start opening up their country, people around the world want to know what opportunities will emerge for its people.  The BBC World Debate is heading to Burma next month and we want to hear from you. What do you want to know about the nation's future? Our panel will include Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi and U Soe Thane, a key government player in the reform process.  Leave a question in the comments section below or ask on Twitter using the #BBCDebate hashtag - we may select your question to be included in the debate.   Photo credit: Getty Images

Link Title: Canada expels envoy over expat fees
Message: Canada has ordered an Eritrean envoy to leave the country following claims he demanded contributions from expatriates to fund Eritrea's military.  Semere Ghebremariam Micael, head of the Eritrean Consulate General in Toronto, has been under investigation for the practice.

Link Title: Hunting wolves: Does the predator still need protection in US?
Message: When the Endangered Species Act was passed in the US in 1973, almost the entire grey wolf population in the American West had disappeared http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22684765  By 2012, however, the number of wolves had reached such high numbers in the Rocky Mountain states of Wyoming and Montana that officials reintroduced some hunting and trapping.  The BBC's Matt Danzico went to Wyoming and Montana to talk to ranchers, environmentalists and government officials about the ongoing debate over how humans and wolves can co-exist.  Check out the video trailer below and follow the link above to see the full story. Tell us what you think in the comments section below.

Two men are getting ready to become the first gay couple to be married in France.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22706351    The ceremony comes just days after President Francois Hollande signed the same-sex marriage bill into law.    Vincent Austin and Bruno Boileau will tie the knot in the southern city of Montpellier amid tight security.

'Attack on Red Cross office' in Afghan city of Jalalabad.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22705575    The Red Cross confirmed on its Twitter feed that "an incident" had occurred, but provided no further information.    Early reports said there had been an explosion at the building, with gunfire also heard at the scene.

Which sport should be included in the 2020 Olympics? BBC Sport takes a look at the contenders:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/22680563    The International Olympic Committee is due to announce which sports bidding for inclusion in the 2020 Games have made it onto a three-strong shortlist ahead of the final round of voting in September.    Let us know your thoughts.    (Picture courtesy Getty Images)

Should some EU countries be given more time to complete their austerity plans over others?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22704729    The European Commission has said it will allow France, Spain, Poland, Portugal, the Netherlands and Slovenia to slow the pace of austerity cuts.

Here's an update to a story we brought you on Tuesday.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-22700607  The Chinese baby that was rescued from a sewage pipe fell in accidentally, the baby's mother has said.  The mother, who has not been named, reportedly told police she unexpectedly gave birth on the toilet and that the baby slipped in to the sewer.  The baby is said to be recovering well.  (Picture courtesy of AFP/Getty Images)

Almost 68 years after World War Two ended, South Korea's "comfort women" are still waiting for a full and sincere apology.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22680705  Our correspondent has been to meet the few remaining South Korean survivors of Japan's WWII military brothels.  Read their stories.  (Picture courtesy of Getty Images)

How many miles/kilometres would you cycle every day? See if you beat this courier:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22589385    Steve Hamilton has worked every weekday bar one for the past year and a half. His speed and work ethic won him 'courier of the year' for 2012.    Take a look at his extraordinary daily routine.

The release of up to 90 Afghan prisoners would put British soldiers serving in the country at risk, according to UK Defence Secretary Philip Hammond.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22699473    British lawyers acting for eight of the men said they had been held for up to 14 months without charge in what could amount to unlawful detention.    (Picture courtesy AFP/Getty Images)

The Washington Post newspaper has reported that Chinese hackers accessed designs for more than two dozen US weapons systems http://bbc.in/15fRM8d  The compromised US designs include those for advanced Patriot missile systems called PAC-3, an Army anti-missile system known as Thaad, and the Navy's Aegis ballistic-missile defence system.

This is Katty Kay in Washington DC.   Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at how American wood pellets are being transported thousands of miles to be used in European power stations http://bbc.in/15gt9s4  The trade is driven by EU rules promoting renewable energy to combat climate change. But do these policies really help the environment?   Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter - I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/15gt9rW and all of our North America news can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/15gt9s0

One week on from a devastating tornado that killed 24 people, residents of the town of Moore in the US state of Oklahoma are still assessing the damage to their homes, schools and roads http://bbc.in/15g7XCp  Follow the link above to our interactive map of the storm's path and hear stories of survival from the people that faced the 200mph winds.

"This red alert has been issued after monitoring the activity of the volcano and seeing that it has increased seismic activity." http://bbc.in/18qPnMp  Chile and Argentina have ordered the evacuation of some 3,000 people living near the Copahue volcano in the south of their shared border.  Authorities in both countries issued a red alert - the highest possible - saying the Chilean volcano could erupt imminently.  Photo credit: AFP

Woolwich murder: Suspect discharged from hospital and arrested  on suspicion of another offence.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22695595    22-year-old Michael Adebowale is taken into custody at a south London police station, six days after the killing of British serviceman, Drummer Lee Rigby.

Police in Uganda's capital, Kampala, fire tear gas to disperse journalists protesting near the offices of a paper closed by authorities last week.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world/africa/    Two journalists were arrested and others were beaten by officers using batons, according to a BBC reporter.

A member of the Russian punk band Pussy Riot who went on hunger strike in jail last week has been taken to hospital.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22689940    Maria Alyokhina was moved to a hospital in her prison colony in the Urals town of Berezniki, the husband of one of her bandmates told the Associated Press.    The Pussy Riot trio were jailed for two years last August after being convicted of a breach of public order, motivated by religious hatred.    Picture from AFP/Getty Images.

After success in El Salvador, will a peace deal between rival gangs in Honduras help reduce the violence?    http://bbc.in/15dzsN4    We'll be looking at what impact the truce will have in Honduras, which has one of the highest rates of murder in the world.    Let us know what you think by posting your comments here or tweet us using #bbcworld.    We'll be speaking to our colleagues from BBC Mundo, in the World's Newsroom on BBC World News today, from 1500GMT.    Picture from AFP/Getty Images.

What would the world look like if continents were traced by flight paths?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/in-pictures-22657086    Michael Markieta, a transportation planner at global engineering and design firm Arup, has spent the past year developing visualisations of flight paths crossing the globe.    Can you see which city has the busiest airport?

Russia prepared to 'deter foreign intervention' in Syria:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22688894    Russia says it will go ahead with deliveries of S-300 anti-aircraft missiles to Syria.

Syria: What happens next?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22684948    EU foreign ministers agree to end the union's arms embargo on Syrian rebels as US senator John McCain arrives in the country.    Picture from AFP/Getty Images.
Take a look at Australia's harbour city covered by a thick blanket of fog. Send us your pictures and we can add them to our album.

Ever wonder how ancient Romans wore their hair? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22630813    In this week's edition of BBC News First Person we meet Janet Stephens, a stylist and 'hairdo archaeologist' from the US city of Baltimore.    Follow the link above and tell us what you think of Janet's passion for solving fashion mysteries in the comments section below.

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC.  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll hear the incredible story of Vijai Kumari and her son Kanhaiya http://bbc.in/18nPTut  Nineteen years ago, Vijai was convicted of murder - wrongfully, she claimed. She was granted bail on appeal but she did not have the 10,000 rupees ($180; £119) she needed to post bail.  Hear how her 18-year-old son, born in prison, worked to secure her freedom.  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter - I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/18nPTuv and all of our North America news can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/18nPTed

"We've seen people who now have the ability to move their fingers where they have had several years of complete paralysis." http://bbc.in/18nmr7S  Five seriously disabled stroke patients have shown small signs of recovery following the injection of stem cells into their brain.  Glasgow University's Prof Keith Muir, who is treating them, stresses it is too soon to tell whether the effect is due to the treatment they are receiving.

Link Title: Raids take digital cash firm offline
Message: Liberty Reserve - a Costa Rican-based digital currency service - has been shut down after the reported arrest of its founder.  Authorities in the Central American country said Arthur Budovsky had been taken into custody in Spain on suspicion of money laundering, following an investigation which also involved the US.

Dozens killed in Baghdad car bombings:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22682400    Car bomb attacks in and around Baghdad have killed at least thirty people.  Police and medical officials say many more were wounded in the bombings, which targeted mainly Shia districts.    There has been a recent marked rise in attacks linked to the growing political and sectarian tension.  A week ago, bombings killed seventy people in one of the bloodiest days the country has suffered for several years.    Photo courtesy of AFP/Getty Images

Free snacks, in-flight wi-fi, seat comfort: these features all factor into an air traveller’s contentment. But a new survey says a warm greeting from the plane staff goes an long way when it comes to influencing in-flight happiness. BBC Travel has the story:

German railways plan to test anti-graffiti drones:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22678580    Germany's national railway company, Deutsche Bahn, says it plans to test small drones to try to reduce the amount of graffiti being sprayed on its property.     They plan to use airborne infrared cameras to collect evidence, which could then be used to prosecute vandals.  Graffiti is reported to cost Deutsche Bahn about ten million dollars a year.

Send us your questions:    In the world's newsroom at 1600, we'll be answering your questions on Syria.    European countries are debating whether they should start arming the Syrian rebels.     Do you have any questions for our colleagues at BBC Arabic?   What do you want to know about the different rebel groups?   What about providing arms to Syria?     Post your questions here or tweet us using #bbcworld

Politicians accused in Sicily Mafia trial:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22680270    Top former Italian politicians and policemen have gone on trial alongside Mafia godfathers in Sicily.    The representatives of the state are accused of making secret deals with the gangsters in an effort to halt a series of deadly bombings in the early 1990s.  Those accused include the former interior minister, Nicola Mancino.

Cricket star Sachin Tendulkar says he will retire from the Indian Premier League tournament.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-22677848    His announcement came moments after his team Mumbai Indians won their first IPL title on Sunday night, beating the Chennai Super Kings by 23 runs.    Tendulkar, who turned 40 last month, has a huge fan base in India. He was the first cricketer to score 100 international centuries.

SYRIA CONFLICT:    European Union foreign ministers are meeting in Brussels to discuss whether to relax an arms embargo on Syria and allow weapons to be supplied to rebel forces.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22677599    Britain and France want the rules changed so they can send arms to what they call the moderate opposition but several EU countries are strongly opposed, saying it would worsen the conflict.

Link Title: Are the French really as arrogant as the surveys say?
Message: The French have a reputation for being arrogant, but a new survey says that when it comes to being haughty, it is another European country that takes the cake. BBC Travel has the story:

Our look at the news from around the world for this Sunday:  - London suspect arrested in Kenya in 2010 http://bbc.in/157Lh7l - Thousands complete last mile of Boston Marathon http://bbc.in/157LfMR - Rockets target Hezbollah in Beirut http://bbc.in/157LfMT - Brazil 'cancels' most African debt http://bbc.in/157LgQZ - Niger President warns of Libya threat http://bbc.in/157LfMP - Sonia Gandhi 'devastated' by India ambush http://bbc.in/157LgR3 - Paris knifing treated as terrorism http://bbc.in/157LgAt - Japan restarts 787 flights http://bbc.in/157LgAz - 'Open race' for top Cannes prize http://bbc.in/157Lfwv - Monaco Grand Prix as it happened http://bbc.in/157LgQR - French Open 2013 - day one LIVE http://bbc.in/157LgQV

Japan has announced fresh loans to Burma and cancelled the remainder of its debt with the country, as Tokyo seeks to boost economic ties.    The announcement came during a visit by Japanese PM Shinzo Abe to Burma, where he had talks with President Thein Sein.    Japan, a key donor to Burma, maintained trade ties with the country during its years of military rule.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22673107    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

At least three people have been wounded by a rocket strike on the southern part of the Lebanese capital Beirut.    Two rockets hit a district controlled by the Hezbollah organisation, officials and residents were quoted as saying by news agencies.    Tension has been high over the conflict in neighbouring Syria.    On Saturday, Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah promised his supporters they would prevail in Syria, where they are backing President Bashar al-Assad.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22671565

Bayern crowned Champions of Europe  Bor Dortmund 1  2 Bayern Munich  Arjen Robben's late winner exorcised the demons that have haunted him and Bayern Munich in the Champions League as they won a pulsating all-Bundesliga encounter against Borussia Dortmund.

A look at our news from around the world for this Saturday:  - Syrian town under heavy army shelling http://bbc.in/18fQVZv - Woolwich Murder sparks anti-Muslim backlash http://bbc.in/18fQVZt - Bridge collapses after US rail crash http://bbc.in/18fQTRx - Guatemala extradites ex-leader to US http://bbc.in/18fQVJb - Philippines troops clash with Abu Sayyaf - 12 dead http://bbc.in/18fQTRz - Pakistan bus fire kills 16 children http://bbc.in/18fQU7R - Tweets of the week http://bbc.in/18fQTRt

Thanks for all of your questions so far for our special BBC HARDtalk program with John Kerry. You have one more day to get in touch before we put your questions to the US Secretary of State in front of an audience of young people from all over Africa.     BBC viewers and listeners from around the world can post their question as a comment on this page. Or tweet @bbchardtalk using #hardtalk #youthconnect     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-22626891    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

"It has been in that house for 75 years. This is a virgin copy." http://bbc.in/18djIOs  A 1938 comic book featuring the debut of Superman that was discovered in the wall of an abandoned house could set a new record at auction.  Action Comics #1, currently bid at $137,000 (£88,000), had been packed in the insulation of a home in the US state of Minnesota.

Reinforcements of specially trained police are being sent to Stockholm after five nights of unprecedented rioting in the capital's suburbs.  Police officers are being sent from the cities of Gothenburg and Malmo, both of which saw rioting in recent years, a spokesman told BBC News.  It is believed the riots were sparked by the death of a man who was shot by police after he allegedly threatened to kill them with a machete.

This is Jane O'Brien in Washington DC.   Tonight on BBC World News America we take a trip to Cleveland, Ohio, to see that city's orchestra perform in a venue more suited to a cover band http://bbc.in/1508UyT  Join us as we ask why one of the world's top orchestras would perform in pub.   Check your local listings to find BBC World News America where you live and be sure to follow us on Twitter. I can be found @Trowynt http://bbc.in/1508XdR and all of our North America news and features can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/1508XdP

For the first time in history more people live in cities than the countryside http://bbc.in/14ZPREM  What does that mean for the future?   BBC Horizons takes a look at how better planning, design and architecture can help us build smarter cities.

Officials in the US state of Washington say an interstate highway bridge collapsed last night after being hit by an oversize lorry http://bbc.in/14Zy6p0  Rescue boats plucked three people out of the river 25ft (7.6m) below.  While it was not listed as structurally deficient, the bridge was deemed "functionally obsolete" by the Federal Highway Administration - meaning its design is out of date with narrow shoulders and low clearance below.  Photo credit: Getty Images

The Afrikaans rapper, Jaak, uses hip-hop to raise the consciousness of his people, whom he calls the ''brown'' underclass of Paarl in South Africa, usually referred to as people of mixed heritage.    He hopes to give the youth of his community pride in their history.     The song describes how their slave ancestors were brought to the Cape and conjures up how they lived and felt in vivid word pictures.    You can check out his music by clicking on the link below.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22635300

The wife of a soldier murdered in London has said she expected her husband to be safe in the UK.    Rebecca Rigby said her husband, Drummer Lee Rigby, had many times before walked safely down the street in Woolwich where he was attacked.    Murder suspects Michael Adebolajo and Michael Adebowale were known to MI5.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22654220    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

RAF Typhoon jets have been launched to investigate an incident involving a civilian aircraft within UK airspace, the Ministry of Defence has said.     A Pakistan International Airlines plane has been diverted from Manchester to Stansted Airport, a Manchester Airport spokesman said.    The BBC understands that the plane has now landed in Stansted.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22658979

Working out your dog's true age used to be a case of simply multiplying it by seven. But it's more complicated than that, and here's a handy calculator to do it for you.    Alternatively, you can find out how old you would be if you were a dog. You can choose to be a labrador, a spaniel, a whippet, or any one of 20 breeds. simply click on the link below    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22479412

Pakistani officials have welcomed a speech by US President Barack Obama vowing to rethink the use of drones, which have killed hundreds in Pakistan.    The foreign ministry said it appreciated that Mr Obama had acknowledged "force alone cannot make us safe" in his speech on Thursday .    However, Mr Obama also pledged to continue using drones and insisted the US was fighting a "just war".    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22653476    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

Hi - I'll be presenting Impact today at 13GMT.     What's it like to have your beloved city described as 'the gates of hell' in a novel?  Da Vinci Code author Dan Brown has upset people in the Philippines with this description of Manila in his new book, Inferno.     It's expected to be the best-selling book of the year. But that has not stopped literary critics from gleefully tearing Inferno apart.    If you're in the Philippines, or you know Manila well, tell us what you think for our Impact talking point today. Thanks, Karin    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22594345    (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

The World Health Organisation has urged countries with possible cases of novel coronavirus to share information.  The move comes after Saudi Arabia said the development of diagnostic tests had been delayed by patent rights on the NCoV virus by commercial laboratories.  Twenty-two deaths and 44 cases have been reported worldwide since 2012, the WHO says.

Ever wanted to ask US Secretary of State John Kerry a question? Well now is your chance.   BBC HARDtalk will be in Ethiopia for a special programme with Mr Kerry. He'll answer questions from a live audience of young people from all over Africa. And he'll take questions from you!   BBC viewers and listeners from around the world can get in touch by tweeting a question to @bbchardtalk using #hardtalk #youthconnect or simply click on the link below and fill in the form.   http://bbc.in/14WoNGl  (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

Is it possible to predict when a volcano is going to erupt? http://bbc.in/14W61Pk  Join us tonight on BBC World News America as we go inside a volcano to get a closer look at a European Union project hoping to do precisely that.   Check you local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/14W5YTR for our latest news and features from around North America.

"We are at war with an organisation that right now would kill as many Americans as they could if we did not stop them first."  US President Barack Obama has defended the use of drones as a "just war" of self-defence against deadly militants, and a campaign that had made America safer.  In a wide-ranging speech on a programme shrouded in secrecy, he said there must be "near certainty" that no civilians would die in such strikes.

Tornado cleanup efforts in the city of Moore in the US state of Oklahoma have been hampered by thunderstorms and hail http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22644981    The first funeral for a victim of the storm, an elementary school student, is scheduled for today.    Photo credit: BBC's Michelle Fleury in Moore, Oklahoma via http://twitter.com/BizFleury

The soldier killed in an attack on a London street has been named as Drummer Lee Rigby of the 2nd Battalion the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.    Drummer Rigby, 25, from Manchester, leaves behind a two-year-old son.    Two men are under arrest in hospital after police shot them near Woolwich Barracks on Wednesday afternoon, in the aftermath of the attack.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22644857

Thousands of mourners are attending the funeral of renowned Nigerian author Chinua Achebe in his home town in Anambra state.    His body arrived back in Nigeria on Wednesday from the US, where he died in March at the age of 82.    Chinua Achebe is widely regarded as the founding father of African literature in English.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22634418    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

A Bangladesh government report into the collapse of a multi-storey factory building, which killed more than 1,100, has uncovered a series of violations.     The report said the building had been constructed with sub-standard materials on unsuitable land.    The Rana Plaza collapse on 24 April is one of the world's worst industrial disasters and sparked global outrage.

US officials are investigating the safety of caffeine in snacks and energy drinks, worried about the "cumulative impact" of the stimulant - which is added to a growing number of products.     Is our tea and coffee-fuelled society too dependent on the world's favourite drug?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22530625

Ever wanted to ask US Secretary of State John Kerry a question? Well now is your chance.     BBC HARDtalk will be in Ethiopia for a special programme with Mr Kerry. He'll answer questions from a live audience of young people from all over Africa. And he'll take questions from you!     BBC viewers and listeners from around the world can get in touch by tweeting a question to @bbchardtalk using #hardtalk #youthconnect or simply click on the link below and fill in the form.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-22626891    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

The brutal murder of a serving soldier in Woolwich in broad daylight has shocked the country.    The prime minister has flown back early from France to lead the government's response to the suspected terrorist attack and security across London barracks has been stepped up.    But for the people who witnessed it, going about their daily lives in this corner of south east London, it will be a day they never forget.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22636231    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

Germany is the most positively viewed nation in the world in this year's annual Country Ratings Poll for the BBC World Service.     More than 26,000 people were surveyed internationally for the poll.     They were asked to rate 16 countries and the European Union on whether their influence in the world was "mainly positive" or "mainly negative".    Germany came out top, with 59% rating it positively. Iran was once again the most negatively viewed.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22624104

A way of creating more effective vaccines which could protect against a broad range of flu viruses has been reported by US researchers.  A different seasonal flu jab is produced every year as the virus is a constantly shifting target.  This study showed a single jab could protect against multiple strains.  Flu scientists said it was an important advance, but a vaccine which could defeat all flu was a long way off.

The Solar Impulse solar-powered plane has set off on the second leg of its trans-American journey http://bbc.in/185SvgE  It took off at 04:47 local time (12:47 BST) from Phoenix, Arizona on Wednesday, bound for Dallas, Texas.  The craft will also stop over in St Louis and Washington DC before heading to New York in early July.

The US attorney general has acknowledged four US citizens were killed in drone strikes since 2009 http://bbc.in/185uzdl  The US specifically targeted and killed Anwar al-Awlaki, Eric Holder wrote in a letter to the Senate judiciary panel.  Awlaki's 16-year-old son Abdulrahman, Samir Khan and Jude Mohammad were "not specifically targeted by the US".

This is Laura Trevelyan in Moore, Oklahoma. Tonight on BBC World News America we’ll take a look at the recovery operation here after Monday's tornado and meet some of the survivors http://bbc.in/185fZSS  We'll also bring you the latest news from the Woolwich 'terror' attack in London http://bbc.in/185fXdI  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and to keep up with all of our North America news @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/185fZSW  Photo credit: BBC's Vara Szajkowski in Moore, Oklahoma

Via BBC News Facebook http://bbc.in/14S6eDo  Prime Minister David Cameron says there are "strong indications" the attack in Woolwich, London, was a "terrorist incident" http://bbc.in/14S6cLF  Police were called to a machete attack in which one man, reported to be a soldier, died. Two men were shot by police and taken to hospital with injuries.  LATEST http://bbc.in/14S6eTI IN PICTURES http://bbc.in/14S6cLD WITNESS: "He pulled a gun out" http://bbc.in/14S6cLB

Keep up with our latest updates from the reported machete attack in south-east London on our live page http://bbc.in/184KatD  Eyewitness describes attack http://bbc.in/184Katp  Woolwich attack in pictures http://bbc.in/184Katx  Victim 'was soldier' http://bbc.in/184Katr  Head teacher on school 'lock down' http://bbc.in/184Katt  Johnson tweets: 'Attack in Woolwich is a sickening deluded and unforgivable act of violence' http://bbc.in/184Katz

Link Title: Man dead in suspected terror attack
Message: A man has died and two are injured after police responded to a reported machete attack in south-east London.    The British government is reported to be treating the attack as a suspected terrorist incident and the Prime Minister said it was "truly shocking".     Eyewitnesses said a man was assaulted in a Woolwich street by two individuals who were later shot by officers.

Link Title: Ai Weiwei song rages against state
Message: Chinese artist and dissident Ai Weiwei has released an expletive-ridden heavy metal music video criticising abuses of state power in China.    The track, given the English-language title Dumbass, reconstructs his 81-day detention in 2011, including what he says is an exact model of his cell.    The video shows impassive prison guards accompanying Ai as he eats, sleeps, showers and even sits on the toilet.    Ai himself sings the lyrics, few of which are fit to print.

The French parliament is debating a new road map for French universities, which includes the proposal of allowing courses to be taught in English.     For some, this amounts to a betrayal of the national language and, more specifically, of a particular way at looking at the world - for others it's just accepting the inevitable. http://bbc.in/11XBlAx

The FBI in Orlando, Florida, have shot a man they were questioning about possible links to Boston bombs suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev, US media report.    An FBI spokesman said they were responding to the incident and that the agent had shot and killed the man "while conducting official duties".    Tsarnaev died in a shootout with police days after the deadly marathon blasts. http://bbc.in/14xag4y

Rioters have lit fires and stoned emergency services in the suburbs of Stockholm for the third night in a row after a man was shot dead by police.     Incidents were reported in at least nine suburbs of the Swedish capital and police made eight arrests.    Police in the deprived, largely immigrant suburb of Husby shot a man dead last week after he reportedly threatened to kill them with a machete.

Rescue workers are combing the ruins left by the gigantic tornado that killed two dozen people, including nine children, in Oklahoma on Monday.     Officials say the search for survivors is nearly over as efforts turn towards recovery.     You can find video, maps and analysis on storm warnings and tornadoes at the BBC website. http://bbc.in/14QB2nY    (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad says he will contest the disqualification of his ally from next month's presidential poll.    Esfandiar Rahim Mashaei was excluded by the Guardian Council, which vets election candidates.    The former moderate president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani has also been excluded.    But what does this mean for one of the most critical elections in the history of the Islamic Republic?    Ros Atkins will in the world's newsroom speaking to journalists from BBC Persian.     If you have any questions you can get in touch on facebook or twitter @BBCRosAtkins.     (Photo courtesy of AFP / Getty Images)

Pakistani politician Imran Khan has been discharged from hospital two weeks after falling from a platform at an election campaign rally.     He has been fitted with a spinal brace to aid his recovery and walked out through a back exit of the Lahore hospital, avoiding waiting reporters.

This is Laura Trevelyan in Moore, Oklahoma - tonight on BBC World News America we'll bring you the latest from the rescue operations after yesterday's tornado http://bbc.in/14OlPDQ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and keep up with our latest news from Oklahoma and around North America @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/14OlPDO

The search for survivors of the gigantic tornado that tore through the US state of Oklahoma yesterday continues http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22611019  Our BBC correspondents and producers bring you this picture gallery of what they are seeing on the ground in and near the town of Moore.

Tim Cook told a US Senate committee Apple paid all the taxes it owed, complying with both the law, and the spirit of the law.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22615146    Apple has been accused by The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which has been examining "methods employed by multinational corporations to shift profits offshore", of being "among America's largest tax avoiders".     (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Imran Khan walks again after his fall at election rally:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22608024    Supporters of the Pakistani politician Imran Khan say he's been able to stand and walk for the first time since injuring his back at an election rally two weeks ago.     The former cricketer fell more than five metres from a makeshift platform.  He has now been fitted with a spinal brace, which has enabled him to walk unaided for around three hundred metres.     (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

Hi, Ros Atkins here.   I’m going to be interviewing Dan Brown later. I’m pretty sure that the majority of you will have read at least one of his books, most likely The Da Vinci Code.    Well, his new one is out. It’s called Inferno, takes its inspiration from Dante and is set in Florence. And, don’t worry, Robert Langdon features.    I’m going to have around 5 minutes, so which one question should I make sure I ask?  You can let me know here, or tweet me @BBCRosAtkins. Thanks!    (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

Ray Manzarek, founder member of the legendary 60s rock band The Doors, has died aged 74.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22604798    The keyboard player formed the band after a chance meeting with singer Jim Morrison in 1965 at Venice Beach in Los Angeles.  They found fame with hits including Riders on the Storm and Light my Fire.     Manzarek died in Germany after a long battle with cancer.

SYRIA AND ISRAEL EXCHANGE FIRE:    Israeli and Syrian forces have exchanged fire across the ceasefire line in the occupied Golan Heights.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22608489    Israel's defence forces say they returned fire after one of their military vehicles was hit by gunfire.  Syria says it destroyed an Israeli vehicle which had crossed the ceasefire line between the two countries.

TWITTER LIVE Q&A ON 50 YEARS OF THE AFRICA UNION:    At 1230gmt today George Alagiah will be answering your questions on Africa and how the continent has changed over the past 50 years.      You can tweet George @BBCAlagiah, and use the hashtags #AskBBCAlagiah and #africa2013.      For full details check out our website:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22596722

At least 37 people are reported to have been killed in the US state of Oklahoma after a huge tornado ripped through a suburb of Oklahoma City, destroying a school, sparking fires and flattening whole neighbourhoods http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22604251  Nearly 60 people were injured when the twister struck the town of Moore.  Rescuers are searching for scores of young children believed to be trapped in their wrecked school building.  In pictures: Monster tornado hits Oklahoma http://bbc.in/14KTJt8  'Entire city streets destroyed' http://bbc.in/14KTJt2  'Complete devastation' http://bbc.in/14KTIFr

A massive tornado has ripped through neighbourhoods near Oklahoma City, on the second day in a row the state has been pummelled by destructive twisters http://bbc.in/17VtYe8  The "mile-wide" storm has sparked fires and flattened homes.

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we are  speaking with Canadian astronaut (and singing sensation) Chris Hadfield http://bbc.in/14KgDkl  and asking him if he has any advice for UK astronaut Tim Peake http://bbc.in/14KgDkp as he prepares to head to the International Space Station.   Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter. I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/14KgFZn and you can keep up with all of our North America news @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/14KgDkn

The government of Venezuela is trying to import 50 million rolls of toilet paper before supermarket shelves run out of stock http://bbc.in/17V9a6m  Some economists say that the shortage of basic goods - which also include milk, butter and coffee - is a result of the socialist government's price control policies.

Despite food shortages and power cuts, people in Gaza are fighting to preserve their distinctive spicy dishes.   For more on Gazan cuisine read Yolande Knell’s report here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22560237

HOT AIR BALLOON CRASH IN TURKEY:  2 tourists have been killed and more than 20 other people injured after 2 hot-air balloons collided in Turkey.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22597878    Witnesses said that the ascending balloon was torn open as it hit the basket of another, and then plunged to the ground.

BBC WORLD NEWS IS IN AFRICA TO MARK 50 YEARS OF THE AFRICAN UNION:    What has African Union delivered to a continent in the midst of tremendous change?    VIDEO: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22592748    Today, George Alagiah is in Ethiopia, a country which has undergone rapid change registering some of the fastest growth rates in the world. He visited a shoe factory with a difference in Addis Ababa.

Can you build a new business out of an old technology? That is the question raised by BBC reporter Kate Dailey, who visited a company in Montreal that makes cassette tapes, which those of us of a certain age remember with great fondness. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22533522 Join @BBCBusiness in a live Twitter Q&A today at 1500 GMT (1100 EST). You can send us your questions via Twitter using the hashtag #BBCrunningabusiness

Hello everyone, on air today is my interview with Chen Guangcheng, the dissident who left China after dramatically taking refuge in the US Embassy in Beijing.     VIDEO: http://www.vizibee.com/video.php?video_id=676    One year on, he tells me his family back home are being 'systematically persecuted', and how he believes the Communist Party has 'privilege without responsibility'.     Do join me on Impact, Mishal

Global power in their hands but can India and China sort out their differences?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-22592770    Despite the recent flare up of a long running border dispute between China and India, the two countries have agreed on a roadmap to reach a "dynamic balance" in trade and other relations.    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Ten killed in northern Afghanistan suicide attack:    Police in Baghlan province said a man wearing a military uniform detonated a bomb vest, as he entered the municipal council's headquarters.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22594734    At least 10 people died. One of them was the head of the provincial council. He was known to take a tough stance against the Taliban.

Yahoo's board has approved a deal to buy New York-based blogging service Tumblr for $1.1bn, US media reports say.  If confirmed, it will be CEO Marissa Mayer's largest deal since taking the helm of Yahoo in July 2012.  Analysts say that by acquiring Tumblr, Yahoo would gain a larger social media presence and enhance its ability to attract younger audiences. It will also help Tumblr generate more revenue from advertisements.
A ticket holder in Florida has won the largest Powerball jackpot in US history, more than $590m, lottery officials say.
Tunisian police clash with hundreds of supporters of the radical Islamist group Ansar al-Sharia defying attempts to bar a gathering.

Link Title: El Salvador rises from the ashes
Message: Despite its reputation for gang-driven feudal battles that continue despite the actual war ending over two decades ago, a new era is dawning in El Salvador. BBC Travel takes a look at the burgeoning tourist industry in what is often called Central America's secret garden:

A guitar played by John Lennon and George Harrison in The Beatles in 1967 sells for $408,000 at auction in New York.  The custom-made instrument, built in 1966 by the VOX company, was bought by an unidentified US buyer in New York.  Harrison played I Am The Walrus on the guitar in a scene from Magical Mystery Tour in 1967. Lennon used it in a video for Hello, Goodbye later that year.
Syrian government forces surround the rebel town of Qusair with opposition activists saying at least 16 people have been killed.

David Beckham's emotional farewell: "The emotion started kicking in, it was hard to run, let alone kick a ball."   He has played his last home game for PSG before retiring.  As he left the pitch, an emotional Beckham clapped his supporters. He later lifted the Ligue 1 trophy.
FOOTBALL FANS IN SERBIA CLASH:  Police in the Serbian capital Belgrade make 104 arrests as rival fans of the city's Partizan and Red Star teams clash at a match.

Link Title: A call from the top of the world
Message: A call from the top of the world:  British explorer Daniel Hughes has reached the summit of Mount Everest in an attempt to raise £1m for the charity Comic Relief.  Daniel spoke to the BBC from the top of the world's highest mountain using his smartphone.

Link Title: China Premier Li Keqiang in India
Message: China's Premier Li Keqiang travels to India for his first foreign visit since taking office, with border tensions and trade topping the agenda.

Are you a fan of the Eurovision song contest? What is the  enduring appeal of the song contest?   Take a look at some of the images from the 58th Eurovision Song Contest held in the Swedish city of Malmo.
Pakistani politician Zahra Shahid Hussain, a senior member of Imran Khan's Movement for Justice party, has been shot dead in the city of Karachi.

Link Title: Thousands rally to oppose Italy cuts
Message: Thousands of protesters, led by trade unionists, rally in the Italian capital Rome against the policies of the new coalition government.   Wielding red flags and placards, they urged the centre-left Prime Minister, Enrico Letta, to scrap austerity measures and focus on job creation.  Public trust in his fragile coalition with the centre-right is dropping, opinion polls suggest.  The country is experiencing its longest recession in more than 40 years

Link Title: Living in: Great cities for history and ancient ruins
Message: Many travellers venture far and wide to see some of the world's greatest ancient ruins, but what is it like to actually live in the shadow of these relics? BBC travel visits the cities best known for their past:

A 25-year-old Saudi woman makes history by reaching the summit of the world's highest mountain.  Raha Moharrak, 25, not only became the first Saudi woman to attempt the climb but also the youngest Arab to make it to the top of Everest.
Russia publicly names the man it believes to be the US intelligence chief in Moscow, a breach of diplomatic protocol.
VIDEO: A would-be robber had a lucky escape after he was struck by a bus, moments after he snatched a woman's mobile phone in Bogota, Colombia.

This week the boss of one of southern Italy's most powerful mafia dynasties sensationally handed himself in to police after three years on the run - and now faces 16 years in jail. The BBC was inside the police station as it happened.
Tunisia bans the radical Islamist group Ansar al-Sharia from holding a meeting in the city of Kairouan, raising fears of possible violence.
Farmers in Japan's key tea-growing region are hoping to turn their fortunes around following the Fukushima nuclear disaster two years ago.

Link Title: Dozens injured in US train crash
Message: About 60 people have been injured, five critically, after a head-on, rush-hour collision between two commuter trains near New York, officials say.

Link Title: Is crawly cuisine the future of food?
Message: The UN is encouraging people worldwide to eat insects for the good of our health and the future of the planet. A sense of disgust about doing so remains a large barrier in many Western countries, but for two billion people across the world, eating bugs is no big deal. BBC Travel looks at the places where insects serve as tasty, low-cost, protein-filled snacks:

"We have found no two speakers that speak roughly alike." http://bbc.in/17GJ3jw  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll travel to the cities of Weimar, New Braunfels and Austin in the US state of Texas to see the efforts being made to preserve the Lone Star State's unique dialects of the German language.   Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and be sure to join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/17GJ1Iq

Link Title: Jewel theft at Cannes film festival
Message: Thieves have stolen more than a $1 million worth of jewelry from a hotel in the French riviera resort of Cannes, where the international film festival is being held.    The jewels were to have been loaned out to stars appearing at the event by the exclusive Swiss jewellers Chopard, one of the festival's sponsors.  Police say the thieves ripped a safe containing the jewelry from a wall in a room at the Novotel hotel.    Festival officials said the event's premier award, the Palme d'Or, also made by Chopard, was not among the stolen items.

Scientists say they have found a way to provide faster and more accurate early warning systems for tsunamis, like the one that hit Japan in 2011.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22572096    The researchers say that GPS technology could provide vital extra minutes before a tsunami strikes.    (Photo courtesy of AFP/JIJI Press)

NEWS JUST IN: Argentina's ex-military leader Jorge Rafael Videla died at the age of 87, according to local media.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22570888    Jorge Rafael Videla had been serving a life sentence for crimes against humanity, including torture and murder during a campaign known as the "Dirty War".    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Do you know someone who is struggling to fall pregnant? New research out of Britain might give them some hope.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-22559247    Time-lapse imaging which takes thousands of pictures of developing embryos can boost the success rate of IVF, according to scientists.    (Photo courtesy of SPL)

Do you get annoyed when tourists speak too loud or when they get in your way? What are the most annoying tourist habits?  How about when you travel abroad, do you modify your behaviour and if so how far do you go?    A Chinese official seems to think that uncivilised behaviour of some tourists was harming the country's image. He said that many were talking loudly in public places and spitting.  (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Nigeria says it is using fighter jets and helicopter gunships, in a massive assault on Islamic militants in the North East of the country.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22557727    There are reports that the government has mounted a big raid on a game reserve in Borno, where the militant group Boko Haram has several bases.    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Can disease be beautiful? http://bbc.in/14usanO  In this week's edition of BBC News Picture This we take a VERY close look at the colours and patterns found when diseases are magnified.   Take a look for yourself and use the comments section below to tell us how these images compare to  modern art.  Image courtesy of Christine Iacobuzio-Donahue and Norman Baker

David Beckham will retire from football at the end of this season http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22558393                    Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look back at his illustrious 20-year career and the reaction to the news from around the world http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/22550271  To mark the occasion - tonight we bring you this photo gallery of Beckham in the kits of all his senior level teams.

"There is beautiful imagery, there's poetry in what is happening, there is purpose in what is happening." http://bbc.in/14t2ojI  Chris Hadfield, the Canadian astronaut who built a huge social media following by tweeting about his life on the International Space Station, has made his first public appearance since returning to Earth.  Cmdr Hadfield said he is now noticing the weight of his tongue and lips and is remembering how to speak under the force of gravity.

Is Google Glass the way of the future and is it for the better? Also is there something a little bit disturbing about a product which allows you to film someone or something without anyone knowing but which at the same time will get you from A to B offering you directions along the way? Also does it make us engage with the world around us, or cut us off from it? Rory Cellan-Jones went to San Francisco to find out http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22538854

At least 15 people have been killed and dozens wounded in a suicide bomb attack on a military convoy in the Afghan capital, Kabul.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22549355    9 Afghan civilians, including 2 children were reported to have died in the blast as well as 2 US soldiers and 4 civilian contractors.    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

BREAKING NEWS: In the last few minutes, David Beckham has announced he is to retire from football.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22558393    Just a few days after winning the French league title with Paris Saint Germain, the 38-year-old says he will quit playing this summer. He joined them on a short-term contract earlier this year after previously playing for Manchester United, Real Madrid and LA Galaxy. Beckham also holds the England record for making 115 appearances as an outfield player for the national team.    Can Beckham be considered to be a footballing 'great'? Would he have a place in England's best XI?  (Photo courtesy of AFP)
Could tiny organisms help us understand the extraordinary complexity of the human brain, and how to keep our brains healthy as we get older? One person thinks so. http://bbc.in/14scSjr

Are attempts by Saudi authorities to restrict social media a losing battle?  Saudi religious police boss said that anyone using social media sites, especially Twitter "has lost this world and his afterlife".     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22543252    This follows earlier comments by Saudi Arabia's most senior Muslim cleric, who called Twitter users "fools".

'Syria Chemical Attack'  The BBC has been shown evidence of an alleged chemical attack that took place last month in the northern town of Saraqeb.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22551892    Eyewitnesses and victims say that government helicopters dropped at least 2 devices containing poisonous gas.    The BBC's Ian Pannell and cameraman Darren Conway are the first western journalists into Saraqeb where the alleged attack took place.  (Photo of Saraqeb courtesy of AFP)

Cyclone Mahasen has begun crossing Bangladesh's southern coast, as people packed into evacuation shelters.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22537615    Around 1 million people have been ordered to evacuate low-lying areas in Bangladesh and Burma, and take shelter in cyclone centres.

"I will do everything in my power to make sure nothing like this happens again." http://bbc.in/17x9xE4  US President Obama has announced that the head of the US tax agency has quit after it emerged his staff singled out conservative groups for extra scrutiny.  Mardell: Sea of troubles for President Obama http://bbc.in/17x9xE6

Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan's decision to declare a state of emergency in three states after a series of deadly attacks by Islamist militant groups http://bbc.in/17w58RO and other news from around the world, including:  - US attorney general faces hostile questioning at congressional hearing http://bbc.in/17w57gz - French economy returns to recession http://bbc.in/17w57gx - Lenin's tomb reopens to public after renovation http://bbc.in/17w58RS  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/17w570f

"Bulldozing Maya mounds for road fill is an endemic problem in Belize." http://bbc.in/17vzQdL  Police in Belize say they are investigating the destruction of a 2,300 year old Mayan temple by a construction company that used the structure as gravel for road filler.  The pyramid was on private land but under Belizean law, any pre-Hispanic ruins come under government protection.  Screenshot courtesy of News 7 Belize.

Earlier today the BBC's Lyse Doucet answered your questions about her experiences of reporting from countries such as Syria, Libya and Pakistan and her role at the BBC.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-22515474    This is an edited version of the Q&A session which is part of our Live the Story campaign.

Nigeria declares 'massive' military campaign to combat Islamist militants in the country's border territories.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22544056    A statement said the drive was aimed at "asserting the nation's territorial integrity" and "enhancing security".  (Photo courtesy of AFP)

SOLAR FLARES VIDEO:  Yesterday we showed you stunning images of flares fired off by the Sun. Now NASA has released the video (click the link below)    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22539160    These amazing close up pictures show streaks of flame erupting from the surface of the Sun. Good news is that Earth was not hit with radiation, but space weather forecasters say the solar blast did briefly disrupt high-frequency radio signals.    (Still courtesy of NASA)

Syrian government troops and rebels have clashed around a prison in the flashpoint northern city of Aleppo.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22536489    Reports suggest the rebel fighters may have tried to blow up the walls of the prison, which holds some 4,000 inmates.    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

Is writer's block just 'old nonsense'?   Do you suffer from it and if so what's the best thing to help you alleviate it?     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22521223    Virginia Wolf, Ernest Hemingway and JK Rowling have all said to have struggled with it.     Dan Brown has a unique way of busting it, by dangling upside down. He admits he uses gravity boots and even a specially made chair to let the blood and words rush to his brain.

The authorities in Bangladesh have started to evacuate hundreds of thousands of people as the country prepares for an approaching cyclone.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22541108    Similar evacuations are underway in Burma, which is also threatened. Many thousands of displaced Rohingya Muslims are seen as particularly vulnerable. But some are reluctant to leave their makeshift camps, saying they distrust the authorities.

What do you make of President Goodluck Jonathan's decision to declare a state of emergency in parts of Nigeria? With some of those areas already under the state of emergency what difference is this going to make?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22533974    At 1300GMT Ros Atkins will be speaking to our Aliyu Tanko from our Hausa service. Send us your questions.    (Screen grab courtesy of AFP)

Walmart, the world's largest retailer, has decided that it will not  sign up to a landmark plan to help improve worker safety in Bangladesh.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22535653    Instead it will conduct its own safety inspections at its 279 factories, saying that will yield faster results.    What do you think? Will the international accord of retailers mean increased safety for workers or should retailers follow Walmart's example?    (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

Taiwan is suspending hiring Filipino workers and recalling its envoy amid a row over the killing of a fisherman.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22535524    Taiwan said the move showed President Ma Ying-jeou's "strong dissatisfaction" with Manila's handling of the case.

A reminder for everyone to send in your questions for Lyse Doucet who will be doing a live Twitter Q&A about what's it like reporting a big breaking story in the field.   The Q & A will start at 1200GMT on Lyse's Twitter account @bbclysedoucet. Make sure to use the hashtag #AskBBCLyse or simply send us your questions right here on Facebook in the comments window.

Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan has declared a state of emergency in three states after a spate of deadly attacks by Islamist militant groups.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22533974    In a televised address, he said he had given the military powers to take over security in the states of Adamawa, Borno and Yobe.    Islamist group Boko Haram has been blamed for most of the violence, killing some 2,000 people since 2010.

Russia says it's going to expel an American diplomat in Moscow who it says tried to recruit one of its intelligence officers to the CIA.  Russia's Federal Security Service says it caught Ryan Fogle red handed. He was allegedly found  with spying equipment including a large sum of money a wig to disguise himself.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22529251

The Sun has unleashed the most powerful eruption - a solar flare - of 2013 so far. The solar flare - a sudden release of radiation - was associated with a huge eruption of matter. When these eruptions reach Earth, they can interfere with electronic systems in satellites and those on the ground. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22525233
Find out who are the the key figures, rivalries and competing forces in the frame to contest the Iranian presidential elections on 14 June.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22525162

The actress Angelina Jolie has revealed that she's had both her breasts removed in a double mastectomy.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22520720    She says she carries a gene that gives her a nearly 90% chance of getting breast cancer and chose to minimise the risk by undergoing the procedure.    How useful do you think Jolie's public statement, about what she has been through, is for women around the world?  (Photo courtesy of AFP/Getty Images)

The Russian security services say they have detained a US diplomat they claim is a CIA agent that they caught red-handed.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22522494    The FSB accused Ryan Fogle, a third secretary at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow, of trying to recruit a member of the Russian special services.    Fogle was reportedly arrested with a large sum of money, technical devices and written instructions for the agent he had tried to recruit.

They're described as the most disturbing images to come out of 2 years of bloody conflict in Syria.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22519770    A video has emerged on the internet that appears to show a well-known rebel commander cutting out the heart of a dead soldier and taking a bite from it. The video cannot be independently verified. It's been widely condemned.    The rebel filmed is said to be an insurgent from Homs  (Photo: Courtesy of AFP)

LIVE THE STORY: Your questions to Lyse Doucet    Click here to find out how to send your questions http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-22515474    BBC Presenter and Chief International Correspondent Lyse Doucet will be answering your questions on Wednesday 15th of May (12 - 13GMT) about her experiences of reporting in the immediate aftermath of bombings, whether in Syria, Libya or Pakistan.    Click here for the promo http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-22250340

More than 50 people are feared drowned, as one of a convoy of boats capsized off Western Burma. All of the dead are thought to be Rohingya Muslim refugees.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22520600    The boat, said to be carrying up to 200 passengers, was evacuating people ahead of Cyclone Mahasen, which is expected to hit the area later in the week.

Space station commander, Chris Hadfield, tells BBC News that those calling for a quick return of manned missions to the Moon were seeking "titillation".    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22483934    His comments were in response to suggestions that the International Space Station (ISS) served little purpose.    (Photo courtesy of NASA)

Link Title: Photos tell 'untold story' of Iraq war
Message: PHOTOJOURNALISTS ON WAR: THE UNTOLD STORY FROM IRAQ  Photographer Michael Kamber talks to the BBC about his new book in which he talks to other journalists about their eyewitness accounts of the Iraq war.

'I survived being swallowed by a hippo'    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-22509995    A man, who survived an attack by a hippopotamus, has described the terrifying moment he was swallowed by the animal.

Phillip Patterson has spent the past four years transcribing the entire King James Bible. The 788,000 words filled 2,400 pages.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22487280    He told the BBC's Matt Danzico why he began the monkish pursuit.

Italian prosecutors are seeking a 6 year sentence for former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi for paying for sex with an underage girl.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22513863    They allege he paid for sex with a 17-year-old dancer at his residence in 2010 and abused his term in office.    Mr Berlusconi, who is already embroiled in several court cases, was given a four-year sentence for tax fraud in October 2012.

Emergency workers in Bangladesh say they have ended their rescue operation, almost 3weeks after the collapse of a multi-storey building in the capital, Dhaka.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22513861    More than 1,100 people died, mostly garment workers. Politicians earlier approved a new law that strengthens garment workers' rights.  (Photo courtesy of AFP)

President Barack Obama has said reports the US tax collection agency targeted conservative groups for extra scrutiny are "outrageous".    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22515005    Groups applying for tax-exempt status with the words "Tea Party" or "patriot" in their names were singled out, the tax agency has acknowledged.

COUNTDOWN TO CANNES FILM FESTIVAL: How many yachts, limos, films, guests and performing dogs does it take to put on a film festival? With Cannes approaching, we take a walk down the famous steps of the Palais des Festivals to discover all of Cannes' secrets in facts and figures.  Find out more here: http://bbc.in/14hwoip

An astronaut who has been uploading unforgettable photographs from the International Space Station is about to return to Earth: http://bbc.in/13TiCTu    Canadian Commander Chris Hadfield has gained 800,000 Twitter followers and has recorded a version of David Bowie's Space Oddity before he flies home: http://bbc.in/15EJXNE    What do you think about his attempts to reach out to a new generation from 250 miles above us?    (Image courtesy of Chris Hadfield, NASA and CSA)

"I saw people running and some of them were collecting parts of bodies".     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22509303    At least 9 people have been killed in a car bomb explosion near a hospital in the Libyan city of Benghazi, an official has told the BBC.

More than 2 billion people around the world already supplement their diet with insects. Would you consider it?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-22508439    The UN is urging more people to eat insects in order to fight world hunger. New report suggests that eating insects improves nutrition and reduce pollution.

MASS BREAK-OUT FROM KENYA MENTAL HOSPITAL     Police in Kenya are searching for 40 mentally ill patients who escaped from a secure institution in Nairobi after overpowering their guards.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22509446    The break-out from Mathari mental hospital happened during a disturbance involving more than 70 male inmates. Some local media reports say the patients were protesting about conditions.

What is this new coronavirus and should we be concerned?     Here's our Q&A on t he new coronavirus http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-19699677    The World Health Organisation says it's likely a deadly new strain of coronavirus can be passed between people who come into close contact.     The virus is similar to SARS and can cause acute breathing problems.

Pakistan election: Why voters backed Nawaz Sharif    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22502733    It's not just that he has won an unprecedented 3rd term as prime minister. He has also survived sustained corruption allegations, periods of deep unpopularity, imprisonment, exile and being thrown out of power in a military coup.     (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

Link Title: Are people really interested in space tourism?
Message: Virgin Atlantic CEO Richard Branson recently marked a major milestone in space tourism with the first supersonic test flight of Virgin Galactic, a passenger spacecraft aiming to become the world's first commercial "spaceline" by 2014. But some say space travel will never really go mainstream.   Would you spend $200,000 for a ticket to go where few have gone before? BBC Travel asks the question:

The World Health Organization says it appears likely that the novel coronavirus can be passed between people in close contact.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22502143    This comes after the French health ministry confirmed a second man had contracted the virus in a possible case of human-to-human transmission.    Two more people in Saudi Arabia are also reported to have died from the virus, according to health officials.

Send us your questions for Linda Yueh about the Chinese economy.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22482510    On Monday, 13 May, Linda will be reporting live from China to investigate China's economic story and will be answering questions from you on her Twitter (@lindayueh) account and on the BBC World News channel and BBC Radio throughout the day.     If you'd like to ask Linda a question, fill out the form on the attached link or send a tweet using the hashtag #AskBBCLinda.    We'll publish her answers on this page later.
Georgians honour their deceased relatives by having feasts beside their graves. Damien McGuinness joined families in the Georgian capital Tbilisi to find out more about dining with the dead.

It's 40 years since the world became familiar with the word "Watergate", as televised hearings of the committee investigating Richard Nixon began. How did the name of an American hotel complex set the standard for labelling controversies?

Link Title: Syria crisis: Israel prepares for the worst
Message: Israel is stepping up its military presence in the Golan Heights as tension grows over the fighting in Syria, the BBC's Wyre Davies reports.

A $83 bill for four ice creams seems like a gross act of over-charging. But how much are we prepared to pay for one of our favourite treats?  In the heat of summer, nothing soothes quite like an ice cream - unless the price is a sore point, as it was for two British couples visiting the Spanish Steps in Rome.

Bulgarian security officials say they have seized 350,000 illegal ballot papers a day before parliamentary elections.  Parliamentary elections are under way in Bulgaria with opinion polls predicting no outright winner.  Mass protests against low living standards and widespread corruption forced the government of the centre-right Gerb party to resign in February.

The government of Taiwan has given the Philippines until Wednesday to apologise for the death of a Taiwanese fisherman whose vessel was fired on by the Philippine coastguard. It has warned the Philippines of diplomatic and economic measures if it does not respond positively.

Former Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif celebrates victory in the country's elections, as partial unofficial results suggest a big lead for his party.  Media projections based on partial results suggest a big lead for Mr Sharif's Muslim League, and he has already claimed victory.  The election should lead to the country's first transition from one elected government to another.  The turnout was huge but the poll was marred by violence.
Research suggests three-quarters of therapists have cried in a session, but should they?

Link Title: Rafsanjani to stand in Iran election
