Message: Iran ex-President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani registers for the June elections, in what could be a challenge to the country's conservative leadership.

Link Title: Deadly blasts hit Turkey border town
Message: Twin car bombs kill at least 40 people and injure 100 in the Turkish town of Reyhanli, near the Syrian border.

Socotra is an island of roughly 50,000 people located 380km off the coast of Yemen, the country to which it only technically belongs. Far removed from the political and security instability on the mainland, Socotra’s stunning microclimates, exceptional biodiversity and Candyland-like features make it an inimitable paradise. BBC Travel takes you there: http://bit.ly/10zUc2C
The US government has demanded that designs for a 3D printed gun be taken offline, citing fears over arms-control laws
Should social network ban violent video clips?  As Facebook considers censoring material on its site which depicts "graphic violence", a range of experts offer contrasting views of what it should do.
WATCH SPACEWALK LIVE:  Two astronauts from the International Space Station are preparing for an emergency spacewalk to try and fix an ammonia leak.
Egyptian security forces detain prominent youth activist Ahmed Maher on suspicion of inciting an anti-government protest in March.
VIDEO: While Saudi is closed to most foreign tourists, it is spending heavily on attracting religious visitors and locals to its cultural sites.
THERMAL INVISIBILITY CLOAK: Researchers have built and tested the first prototype of a "thermal invisibility cloak", which can hide objects from heat flow.

Foreign visitors to North Korea are allowed to attend sports matches alongside their minders. But football in this secretive republic has little in common with the passion and glamour of the Europe's major leagues.   Tim Hartley reports on the eerie silence and subdued atmosphere at a football match in Pyongyang.

Link Title: Hosni Mubarak retrial due to begin
Message: The retrial of ousted Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak on charges of complicity in the killings of protesters and corruption is due to begin.

PAKISTAN ELECTIONS LIVE: Elections are taking place amid tight security in Pakistan, in the first-ever transition of democratic power but a bomb has killed 10 people in Karachi.   Follow our live coverage from across Pakistan with continuous updates from our journalists including the Chief International correspondent Lyse Doucet.

At the start of the 20th Century, São Paulo was home to a mere 239,000 inhabitants – it now houses more than 11 million. Despite the whirlwind urban growth, or perhaps because of it, the city has become a hotbed of talented Brazilian architects, including Ruy Ohtake and Paulo Mendes da Rocha. It is their cutting edge structures that now define the city’s landscape and enhance residential life. BBC Travel visits Brazil’s largest city.

Tonight on BBC World News America we head to the new punk fashion exhibition at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art to see how that subculture's rebellious attitude influenced high fashion http://bbc.in/10xLnl7  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live.   Join the conversation @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/10xLlcY  Photo courtesy of the BBC's Ashley Semler
Find out how more information can be used to transform our lives.  Tune into BBC World News this Saturday and Sunday. http://bbc.in/10xof6r

Africa loses twice as much money through tax avoidance, secret mining deals and financial transfers as it gets from donors, ex-UN chief Kofi Annan tells the BBC.    'It was like taking food off the tables of the poor'.    So what is the solution to the African crisis?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22478994    (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)

AFRICA BEATS:   He's called "the voice of the voiceless" at home in Malawi.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22440966    Musician Peter Mawanga and his band, Amaravi Movement, ruffled feathers with their first hit 'Amakhala ku Blantyre' which suggested that the rich who come and show off in the villages may be wearing borrowed clothes.     Their music is inspired by traditional Malawian rhythms and instruments and Peter says it's high time the world was exposed to the riches of Malawian music.

VIDEO: How did a gang of cyber criminals carry out one of the biggest bank thefts in history?  They were armed, not with guns, knives and masks but with old hotel cards and laptop computers.    More than $45 million was stolen in the space of just a few hours. Our  technology correspondent Rory Cellan Jones explains how the gang did http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22477601

What would you ask someone who went on a journey that had never been done before?    Brothers Ryan and Colin Pyle went on an epic motorbike trip around China, covering 18,000km in just over 2 months.     The two brothers travelled to third lowest point on earth to the foot of Everest, taking in Tibet, the North Korean border and plenty in between.     Lucy Hockings will be speaking to the Pyle brothers on Impact programme about their adventure so we'd like to encourage you to send us your questions you'd like to ask them. We're on air in under an hour.

This is the remarkable moment when Bangladeshi rescuers pulled a survivor out the wreckage of the building that collapsed 17 days ago.    You can also take a look at the video here http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22477414    Workers said they heard a woman screaming from the debris. The BBC's correspondent at the scene says her miraculous escape has given some hope to rescuers that more people may still be found alive.

VIDEO:  The horrific price of worsening poverty in the EUs poorest country, Bulgaria.    The man on the left is Dimitar Dimitrov who had set fire to himself in protest at worsening poverty levels.    The man on the right is Boiko Borisov, Bulgaria's former PM, whose government was toppled in February after a wave of public anger at falling wages.    Bulgaria is holding elections this weekend and unsurprisingly the biggest issue weighing on voters' minds will be poverty.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22477217

NEWS JUST IN: 'Woman Found Alive in Dhaka Rubble'    Remarkable breaking news from Bangladesh, where rescue workers say they've found a survivor in the wreckage of the building that collapsed 17 days ago.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22477414    Army officials ordered workers to stop clearing the site on Friday as they tried to free a person they said might still be alive.     A soldier at the scene said rescuers found a woman in the debris and she waved her hand.

Over 1,000 people are now known to have died in the factory building collapse last month in Dhaka. It's Bangladesh's worst ever industrial disaster and the authorities are still searching for bodies.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22476774    Since the collapse, officials have closed 18 garment factories in an attempt to improve safety and assure international buyers that they meet industrial standards. The architect of the building has said it was never designed to house factories.    (Photo courtesy of AFP)

A British Olympic sailor has died after a Swedish catamaran capsized during a training session for the America's Cup in San Francisco Bay http://bbc.in/176CBSK  Andrew "Bart" Simpson - a double Olympic medallist - was one of an 11-man crew on board the Artemis Racing catamaran, the team website said.

Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the collection of more than 70 priceless paintings, including Rubens' Head of a Franciscan Monk pictured here, returning to the UK on a loan from Russia's Hermitage Museum http://bbc.in/175UroH  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live - keep up with our latest news and features by following @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/175UrVZ on Twitter.

Astonishing work has been emerging from a new generation of Egyptian street artists.   http://bbc.in/10tTcbu  Influenced by ancient culture and contemporary politics, they are delivering potent messages of protest. BBC Culture's Alastair Sooke surveys the scene and meets a major player. For much more visit the BBC Culture Facebook page.  http://bbc.in/10tTcbw

Should President Bashar al-Assad have a role in a political settlement to Syria's conflict?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22465918    US Secretary of State John Kerry said that he should have no such role.     The comments followed reports that the US was softening its insistence on Mr Assad's departure as a precondition for any deal as demanded by rebels.     (Photo courtesy of AFP)

INTERACTIVE:  Sunday 12 May 2013 will mark the 5th anniversary of the 2008 Sichuan earthquake.     Take a an interactive look at one of the largest earthquakes in human history in terms of socio-economic losses.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22398684

Nigeria attack: At least 23 policemen have been killed in an ambush by a local militia in the central Nasarawa state.    They were on their way to arrest the leader of the outlawed Ombatse "cult" when gunmen opened fire, a state spokesman told the BBC.    Ombatse means "the time has come" in the Eggon language.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22462225

"The government has systematically used arbitrary arrest and detention without charge to crush all opposition, to silence all dissent, and to punish anyone who refuses to comply with the repressive restrictions it places on people's lives".    In a new report Amnesty International says thousands of political prisoners are being held in Eritrea in "unimaginably atrocious conditions".     Since independence 20 years ago, Eritrea has been led by President Isaias Afewerki. It is a one party state.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22460836

It seems incredible yet it's true, another clothing factory in Bangladesh has been hit by tragedy, a fire that's claimed at least 8 lives. But the death toll could have been much higher - most workers had gone home for the day with the blaze took hold.     The latest disaster occurred as it emerged that 900 people were killed in the collapse of a huge garment factory complex 15 days ago.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22462405

Some news just in - Pakistan's former prime minister, Yusuf Raza Gilani, has told the BBC that one of his sons has been abducted by unidentified gunmen.     Mr Gillani said his son, Ali Haider, had been kidnapped while he was campaigning for Saturday's general election in the city of Multan in southern Punjab province.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22462410

Bangladeshi opposition deputy leader Muhammad Kamaruzzaman is sentenced to death for crimes against humanity committed during the 1971 war of independence.  The nine-month war of secession from Pakistan killed as many as 3 million people.

The owner of the house in Ohio from where three women were rescued a decade after they went missing faces four counts of kidnapping and three counts of rape, say US prosecutors http://bbc.in/170mJ44  Ariel Castro, 52, will appear in court on Thursday, but his brothers Pedro, 54, and Onil, 50, are not charged.  Our latest from Cleveland:  - Cleveland children: 'Any girl can get kidnapped' http://bbc.in/170mG8c - Gina DeJesus returns to family home http://bbc.in/170mJko - Ohio women were held with ropes and chains http://bbc.in/170mJ48

A California woman has been found guilty of first-degree murder in the shooting and stabbing death of her boyfriend in his Arizona home in 2008 http://bbc.in/1709GQ2  A jury said Jodi Arias, 32, had planned the killing of Travis Alexander, 30, a motivational speaker and salesman.  Prosecutors said Arias was manipulative and had meticulously planned the crime.

How much sleep do teenagers and children need? http://bbc.in/1703Az7  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at how sleep deprivation impacts young students and take a look at other news from around the world, including:  - Cleveland women 'repeatedly raped by captors' http://bbc.in/10qKiLV - Deaths as ship rams Genoa tower http://bbc.in/10qKg6W - US congress on arming Syria  http://bbc.in/10qKiLT - Ferguson to retire  http://bbc.in/10qKiLZ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live.

Scientists at Canada's University of Toronto have unveiled a new species of bone-headed dinosaur, which they say is the oldest in North America, and possibly the world http://bbc.in/16Zgptx  They believe Acrotholus audeti, a dog-sized plant-eater, dates back to 85 million years ago.

Link Title: Why are Indian women being attacked on social media?
Message: "Targeting me for my journalism is fine. But when it is sexist and foul-mouthed abuse which insults my gender identity I get incredibly angry."  Sagarika Ghose is a well-known face of Indian television news and also someone who has been threatened regularly with gang rape and stripping on Twitter.  So what does a top woman journalist do about such threats?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-22378366

It's the final days of campaigning in Pakistan before Saturday's general election. It's a tight race, and it was made even more unpredictable by Imran Khan's fall at a rally on Tuesday.     Doctors say he will need at least a week of rest after he fell from a platform at a rally on Tuesday.  A member of his family said he was wearing a bullet-proof vest at the time which may have saved him from more serious injury.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22446000    Still courtesy of AFP

CLEVELAND ABDUCTION:    What lies inside the run-down clapboard house where Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight are said to have spent their captivity? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22446157    Who are the 3 men suspected of abduction? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22449350

The Syrian government has blamed faulty cables for an internet blackout that has entered its second day.    Authorities blamed that incident on "terrorists", but internet experts said it was more likely that the regime had shut down the web.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22447247

SEND US YOUR VIDEO COMMENTS:    What is your reaction about the news that Sir Alex Ferguson is to retire as the manager of Manchester United?   Who will replace Ferguson at Manchester Utd?   Can Ferguson's success ever be repeated?   He is Britain's most decorated football manager but where does he rank against other world's great managers?    All you have to do is record and upload your comments by clicking on this link.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-17928844    (Still courtesy of AFP)

It was one of the world's largest robberies of diamonds.    Belgian police has now arrested 31 people over the theft of $50m of gems from a plane at Brussels airport.    The diamonds were "rough stones" being transported from Antwerp to Zurich.    Thieves were dressed as police, wore masks and were well armed.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22447516

Kurdish PKK rebels have begun leaving south-eastern Turkey for their safe havens in Iraq under a ceasefire.    "We know that they have started moving," said Selahattin Demirtas, a pro-Kurdish politician actively involved in the peace process.    More than 40,000 people have died in their 30-year fight against Turkey.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22448118

“Important to leave organisation in strongest possible shape; I believe I have done so.”     What is your reaction to this news? Who will be replacing Ferguson as the Manchester Utd manager? Can Ferguson's success ever be repeated?  He is Britain's most decorated football manager but where does he rank against other world's great managers?    Sir Alex Ferguson, the manager of Manchester United has announced he will retire. He's the man who made Manchester United one of the greatest football teams in the world.   Sir Alex won 38 trophies during his 26-years at the helm. He says it's the right time to step down, a decision he's not taken lightly.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22447018  (Still courtesy of AFP)

Brazil may be best known for the samba, but a new dance - fuelled by YouTube and social media - is emerging from the favelas http://bbc.in/16Vf4E5  Passinho, or "little step", is a hybrid of pop, funk and break-dancing combined with traditional Brazilian styles such as samba, pagode and frevo.  Get to know "Pablinho", the self-styled King of Passinho, in this week's edition of BBC News Living Online.

Police on the Colombian island of San Andres have arrested three women dressed as nuns who tried to smuggle 6kg (13lb) of cocaine under their habits http://bbc.in/16TDjm1  The fake nuns were searched after police saw them acting suspiciously.

'A golden opportunity that can't be missed.'   That's how Somalia's president Hassan Sheikh Mohamud reacted to a pledge today by Britain, China, the United States, Qatar, the EU and many others to hand over $80 million to double the size of the country's police force.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22426721

4 UN peacekeepers have been abducted by armed men while patrolling in the demilitarised area between Syria and the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22435393

NEWS JUST IN:   Pakistani politician Imran Khan has fallen off a makeshift elevator as he was being raised to the stage to address an election rally.   TV footage showed supporters carrying a bloodied and dazed Mr Khan away from the rally.  Despite falling several meters, Khan's injuries are not life-threatening.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22440518

South African traditional healers, better known as Sangomas, are frequently thought of as older, uneducated people from rural areas who wear traditional dress. They are also associated with casting bad spells on those who cross their paths. While many people still consult them, they tend to do so in secret. But all that's beginning to change. Meet Thabiso Siswana, a modern Sangoma. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22306869

Officials have praised the bravery of three women who have been found alive in a Cleveland, Ohio, home after vanishing about a decade ago http://bbc.in/16So7pg  Amanda Berry disappeared aged 16 in 2003, Gina DeJesus went missing aged 14 a year later, and Michelle Knight vanished in 2002 aged around 19.  A school bus driver and his two brothers have been arrested.

It's the moment millions of ABBA fans have been waiting over 40 years for. A museum dedicated to the Swedish pop group is being officially opened in Stockholm today by 3 of the band's original members.     The museum will feature glitzy stage costumes, life-size holograms of the group and perhaps one or two catchy songs.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22434171 (Still courtesy of AFP)

The birth of a child should be cause for celebration, but for millions of mothers and babies it's the riskiest time of their lives.    1 million babies each year, die on the day they're born, according to the charity Save the Children. It's latest 'State of the World's Mothers' report, says babies are 7 times more likely to die in the developing world.    Find out which countries have been named as the best/worst place to be a mother. Just click the link.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22430608  (Still courtesy of AFP)

US officials say North Korea has removed 2 medium-range missiles from launch sites on its east coast. The move suggests there is no longer any imminent threat of a test-launch of the weapons.     However, North Korea has issued a fresh warning to South Korea and the US that it will respond militarily to any breach of its sovereignty.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22429734    STILL: Musudan missiles were displayed during a military parade in Pyongyang last year (Courtesy of AFP)

911 call 'Help me, I'm Amanda Berry...I've been missing for 10 years.'    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22430145    They disappeared into thin air a decade ago.   Now, 3 young women (Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight) have been freed after being kidnapped and held captive in an ordinary suburban house in Cleveland Ohio in the US.    One of the women managed to attract a neighbour's attention and he helped her escape.     Three  brothers in their fifties have been arrested.    (Photos of Berry (left) and DeJesus were distributed widely after they went missing) Images courtesy of AFP

"Hopefully, music and speaking out can heal us all." http://bbc.in/16OqAkF  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll hear the story of Arn Chorn-Pond - as a child in Cambodia he was sent to a children's labour camp where he escaped death by playing his flute for the camp guards. He was later adopted by a Lutheran minister and brought to the US.  Today the musician and activist is working to showcase artists and performers from his home country in the first major Cambodian cultural festival in the US.  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and be sure to keep up with all of our news and features from the US on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/16OqAkB

A poster than can only be fully seen when looked at from a child's point of view has been used in an anti-child abuse campaign by Spain's Anar Foundation http://bbc.in/16OkEYV  The lenticular printing - a technique which means those looking at different angles see a different image -  shows a "secret" message with information about a child abuse helpline.

A controversial group in the US state of Texas has created and successfully fired the world's first gun made using 3D printer technology http://bbc.in/10jRmKf  Defense Distributed spent a year trying to create the firearm and plans to make the blueprints available online.  Anti-gun campaigners have criticised the project.

CO2 in our atmosphere is making the Arctic seas more acidic, according to a Norwegian study.     The researchers say there's likely to be major changes to sea life as a result, but they're unsure what those changes will be.     Cold water absorbs the gas more quickly, making the Arctic seas particularly susceptible.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22408341

VIDEO:  Malaysia's opposition leader is hoping to galvanise supporters and hold protest rallies after losing the general election.    Anwar Ibrahim is alleging widespread fraud saying there's evidence of irregularities in 30 constituencies.    He says he's "disgusted" at what he viewed as a "complete disrespect" of the people who had voted for reform.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22425704

VIDEO: Would you eat bugs instead of meat? Does the idea of eating insects make your skin crawl, or your stomach rumble?      Well some scientists in the Netherlands say that we should all be eating insects because they're nutritious, there are lots of them and they're cheap.    And what do they taste like? Well the BBC's John Maguire can help out with that. Just click on the link http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22423977
Beate Zschaepe in court, 6 May 13
Giulio Andreotti, one of the most prominent political figures of post-war Italy, dies aged 94, state TV says.

VIDEO:  UN investigator Carla del Ponte says there is strong evidence Syrian rebels have used sarin nerve agent but more investigation is needed.   She says testimony from victims and doctors gives rise to strong suspicions, though not proof, that opposition fighters have used the nerve gas, sarin.

Bangladeshi government has imposed a ban on mass rallies following violent clashes between police and Islamist protestors which left at least 10 people dead and more than 60 injured.     Hundreds of thousands of supporters of the group Hefajat-e Islam had gathered in the Bangladeshi capital on Sunday demanding stricter Islamic laws and the death penalty for anyone who insulted Islam.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22423815  Photo showing Bangladeshi police using a water cannon courtesy of AFP/Getty Images (05/05/2013)
3D Printer
Computer design for a a gun made by a 3D printer
A working 3D gun tested at a firing range
The gun was assembled from separate printed components made from ABS plastic - only the firing pin was made from metal

India and China pull back troops from disputed territory on their de facto Himalayan border after a three-week stand-off, Indian media reports say.  Soldiers were said to have set up camps facing each other on the ill-defined frontier in Ladakh region last month.  The two sides held a series of talks to resolve the row and the troops were withdrawn on Sunday, the reports added.  The two countries dispute several Himalayan border areas and fought a brief war in 1962.

Link Title: Malaysia PM urges unity after win
Message: Malaysia's governing coalition calls for national reconciliation after it was re-elected in the most hard-fought poll since independence.  Prime Minister Najib Razak's Barisan Nasional (BN; National Front) coalition won 133 of the 222 seats - its worst-ever poll result.  Mr Najib said there had been a worrying polarisation in voting, as many ethnic Chinese backed the opposition.

Our news from around the world for this Sunday:  - Israeli strikes on Syria 'co-ordinated with terrorists' http://bbc.in/16IhDcx - Polls close in tight Malaysian vote http://bbc.in/16IhDcv - Women die in stretch limo blaze on San Francisco bridge http://bbc.in/16IhEx3 - Evans denies rape claim as 'completely false' http://bbc.in/16IhEx1 - Deadly blast hits Mogadishu convoy http://bbc.in/16IhDcD - Anti-Jewish rally in Hungary capital http://bbc.in/16IhDcH -Alaska pupils hack class computers http://bbc.in/16IhDcB - Today's sport headlines http://bbc.in/16IhEwZ

California's Napa and Sonoma valleys have long been known as some of the best wine territory in the US. But which wineries have separated themselves from the pack when it comes to originality and quality of product? BBC Travel has the wineries that should be at the top of your to-taste list: http://bit.ly/16zi7l2

Link Title: How free are Egypt's new voices?
Message: Meet Egypt's most controversial TV star, satirist Bassem Youssef.  Two years after the 2011 revolution in Egypt, a growing number of satellite TV channels are expressing a range of views - from liberal to ultra conservative.

Does Bollywood reflect the real India?   Bollywood turned 100 on Friday. Eminent economist and Bollywood fan Lord Meghnad Desai explores whether it has reflected the life and times of a changing India.

Link Title: Malaysia to vote in close election
Message: Voting has been brisk in Malaysia in what is widely expected to be the most closely contested general election in the country's history.  PM Najib Razak's Barisan Nasional (National Front) coalition is up against Pakatan Rakyat, a three-party alliance headed by Anwar Ibrahim.  Voters are faced with returning the ruling party, in power for 56 years, or choosing an untested opposition.
Large explosions are being reported in the Syrian capital, Damascus, with state TV saying a military research centre has been attacked.

Our look at today's news from around the world:  - Syrians flee 'massacres' in Baniyas and al-Bayda http://bbc.in/16F4ocI - Major wildfires spread in California http://bbc.in/16F4ot2 - Seven Nato troops die in Afghanistan http://bbc.in/16F4lgT - Venezuela's Maduro alleges assassination plot http://bbc.in/16F4ocK - MP 'arrested over rape allegations' http://bbc.in/16F4ot0 - Hull heading back to Premier League http://bbc.in/16F4lgN - Sudan gold mine rescue called off http://bbc.in/16F4lgP - Protest in China at chemical plant Protest in China at chemical plant - Solar plane lands in Phoenix http://bbc.in/16F4ocA - A funny look at the news - 140 characters a time http://bbc.in/16F4ocE

Jet lag is often the bane of the traveller's existence: the effects of a long flight are compounded by the jolt to the system caused by switching time zones. Experts agree that strategic exposure to light is one of the most effective ways to combat this common ailment, but obeying signals from sunlight and darkness can be difficult when you're flying half way across the world. Two new online tools aim to help you reset your internal body clock. BBC Travel investigates how they work:

After Eurosceptic UKIP made major gains in local elections in England, BBC News looks at the strength of anti-establishment parties in the EU.  Europe's traditional left-right-centre pattern of parliamentary democracy is being increasingly challenged by alternative parties and protest movements.  In Greece, the once-mighty Socialist party Pasok was thrashed into third place by an anti-bailout coalition of the left, while in Italy the success of a protest movement called Five Star forced left and right into an unlikely coalition.
A long-awaited report investigating violence and human rights abuses in Kenya will recommend some prosecutions, one of its authors tells the BBC.
How villagers in Burkina Faso use themselves as bait to catch the biting flies responsible for spreading river blindness
US media reports say Israel has conducted an air strike inside Syria, as President Obama makes clear he does not foresee sending US troops there. Could this be a game changer?

A plane powered only by the Sun has set off from San Francisco on the first leg of a bid to cross the US with no fuel http://bbc.in/16AqcpR  The Solar Impulse craft will stop in Phoenix, Dallas, St Louis, Washington DC and New York in the coming weeks.  The team's plane has the same wingspan as an Airbus A340 but weighs only as much as an average car.

Link Title: Can a fear of flying be cured?
Message: One in three people suffer from aerophobia, a debilitating fear of flying that can turn business travel or a holiday into a nightmarish experience. What are the best ways to cope with a flying phobia? Author and writer's mentor Julia Cameron, who herself suffers from aerophobia, shares her tips with BBC Travel:

Can music bring peace? http://bbc.in/16AnJvt  Katty Kay will sit down with Grammy-award-winning Colombian musician Juanes on tonight's BBC World News America to discuss his efforts to promote peace through music. "We believe that if there is no intervention there will be no Biosphere Reserve in five to 10 years." http://bbc.in/109THay  Indigenous leaders say Central America's largest tropical forest is under growing threat from illegal loggers.  Nicaragua's Mayangna and Miskito people say 30,000 hectares a year are being deforested in the Bosawas Biosphere Reserve by "colonists".  They are calling on US president Barack Obama, who is visiting the region, to support their battle.

"We're going to be at Mother Nature's mercy." http://bbc.in/16zKz6B  More than 900 firefighters are battling a growing wildfire along the Pacific coast in the US state of California - one of several wildfires raging in the state. Her energy, colourful style and her soulful lyrics have made her a chart hit in her home country.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22384341

Posters expressing support for the man charged with last month's bombings at the Boston Marathon have been put up on walls in Chechnya's capital, Grozny.    They show pictures of Mr Tsarnaev and his mother, Zubeidat, and include an appeal for online donations.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22400536    The leaflet exclaims "Not Guilty!" at the top

Is it OK to laugh at Hitler? A satirical novel that follows a bemused Führer on a journey through today’s Germany is a publishing sensation. But are the Nazis a fitting subject for comedy? http://bbc.in/109fWgX

More than 900 people have been arrested in China for selling fake or tainted meat in just 3 months.     Foxes, mink and rats have all apparently been chemically treated and passed off as mutton.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22394984

100 YEARS OF INDIAN CINEMA:    Apart from Asia and the UK where else around the world is Bollywood hugely popular? Why are Indian films so popular abroad?    Although Bollywood still struggles to compete with big budget US blockbusters, box office takings last year reached $2bn dollars. Internet giant Google has changed the tagline on the front page of its Palestinian edition from "Palestinian Territories" to "Palestine".    What do you think of Google's decision to change the tagline?    The terminology is a politically contentious issue, with the final status of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem yet to be agreed.    In November 2012 the UN upgraded Palestine's status in the world body.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22395494

The Pakistani prosecutor investigating Benazir Bhutto's death has been killed in a hail of bullets as he drove to a court hearing.    Police said Chaudhry Zulfiqar Ali was ambushed as he was being driven from his Islamabad home to Rawalpindi.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22392544

More than 50,000 US service personnel have been injured in the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan http://bbc.in/107rEsp  This spring, over 400 disabled veterans gathered at a ski resort in Colorado for a week of sport and rehabilitation. BBC Newsnight's Jonathan Bell joined them there to talk to them about their injuries and the long journey to recovery.

Link Title: Why is Croatia so good at sport?
Message: Croatia excels at sports like football, basketball, tennis, water polo and handball. At the London Olympics Croatia placed 15th on a medals table weighted by population size.  Punching above its weight? It certainly looks that way. But why?   Here's one person who has the answer. Igor Stimac, the coach of the national football team says that it's because "Croats are just naturally talented".

We are pleased to announce the launch of the BBC Culture website.  If you're interested in a global view on film, fashion, art, music and more then this is the place for you. Check out the website here http://bbc.in/16tMeuf

At least 60 people have died in a gold mine collapse in Sudan.  The incident happened in a remote desert region around 200km from the North Darfur state capital El Fasher.   Rescuers are said to be using hand tools to try to reach the victims. The exact number of those missing is unclear.

Pakistan has witnessed a recent surge in violence aimed at political parties and candidates campaigning in elections due on 11 May.     But beyond the problems of security, what matters most to ordinary voters as they decide who will form their next government?     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22383246

Has the attitude towards women in Egypt changed under the rule of the Muslim Brotherhood?    The issue of sexual harassment against women is once again making headlines this time thanks to the Egypt's Information Minister. There have been protests after he made an inappropriate comment to a female journalist at a news conference.     99 % of Egyptian women admitted facing harassment in a recent UN survey.    In this special report, the BBC's Aleem Maqbool looks at the issues facing Egyptian women.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22367447

The Irish parliament is set to limit its reaction to the Magnitsky affair to a statement of concern, after Russia warned against US-style sanctions.    A motion by its joint foreign affairs committee has been redrafted to say Dublin will seek reassurances from Moscow on its respect for human rights.    Members had advocated blacklisting Russian officials linked to the death of whistle-blower Sergei Magnitsky.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22381059

Nearly 260,000 people, half of them children, died during the famine that hit Somalia from 2010 to 2012. That's according to a report by the UN food agency and the US-funded Famine Early Warning Systems Network.    The crisis was caused by a severe drought, worsened by conflict between rival groups fighting for power.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22380352

What REALLY irritates you about your work colleagues?     A survey of 2000 UK office managers claims to have identified the ultimate 'nightmare colleague'...    1. The one who turns up late for meetings.   2. The one who leaves dirty bowls and plates on their desk after lunch.  3. The one who sends you emails...even you though you sit directly across from them.  4. The one who gossips excessively about other workers and openly discuss confidential work matters.   5. The one who uses office jargon like ‘thinking outside the box’, ‘going forward’ and ‘let’s touch base.’    Let us know where you're from, what you do and what annoys you or what you really like about your colleagues.

Link Title: N Korea jails US man for 15 years
Message: He's been accused of trying to over throw the state of North Korea. But human rights activists believe his real crime may have been to take pictures of starving children.   An American tour-operator of Korean origin has been sentenced to 15 years hard labour for unspecified crimes against the state.  Kenneth Bae has been in detention for nearly 6 months, after entering the country as a tourist.

Earlier today we brought you the story of the newly discovered human bones of a 14-year-old girl that prove the first permanent British settlers in North America turned to cannibalism over their first winter in Jamestown http://bbc.in/16puGj1  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a deeper look at this story - including this three-dimension replica of the girl's face http://bbc.in/16puDUb  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live.   Keep up with our stories from around North America on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/16puGiX

The BBC’s Mishal Husain will do the first interview with Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl who survived being shot in the head by the Taliban in October. The BBC team will be filming with Malala as she visits the UN to speak about her passion for girl's education. Mishal will also be spending time at home with Malala filming daily life with this remarkable young woman who is balancing school work, and campaigning while still undergoing treatment as a result of the shooting.   The interview will air in October - a year after the Taliban tried to kill Malala - and will coincide with a similar interview conducted by Diane Sawyer of ABC, who are the BBC's partners in the USA.   The interview will be broadcast on the BBC in the UK, on BBC Urdu  and on BBC World News, the BBC’s international news channel which broadcasts to more than 350 million households around the world. It will also feature on BBC World Service and BBC.com. This will be Malala’s first major interview since the attack.  Photo Credit: Getty Images

Link Title: BBC World Service - Newsday, Which piece of music sums up Africa to you?
Message: Which piece of music sums up Africa to you?   This month sees 50 years of African unity and we've set ourselves the ambitious task of featuring 50 musicians from 50 African countries on Newsday and we're looking for your suggestions.    Post your song title, the performing artist and where they're from below.

Historians have always wondered how the first English colonists in America survived the 1609 winter of starvation in Jamestown. Now they have uncovered a dark secret from the past http://bbc.in/16o7AJn  Forensic analysis of 17th Century human remains prove that the earliest settlers resorted to cannibalism. The BBC's Jane O'Brien has this behind-the-scenes look at the unsettling evidence.

The campaign group War Child says the plight of children in Iraq is one of the most neglected crises in the world.   The reports says that 10 years on from the US-led invasion, violence is increasing, life expectancy is falling and children are falling behind in education.

How small is the 'world's smallest movie'?    Put it this way, the 90-second film can only be seen when magnified 100 million times.     How was this achieved? IBM created the movie by manipulating single atoms on a copper surface.    Click here for to see a clip from 'A Boy and His Atom' courtesy of IBM  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22364761

Satellite images have revealed that 2,275 homes were destroyed during a military raid to hunt down militant Islamists in the northern Nigerian town of Baga last month, a rights group says. Is May Day still worth celebrating? Is it still relevant?  Hundreds of millions of workers are today enjoying a holiday to mark International Labour Day. But many are also taking part in May Day action.  Click the link below to see how people from around the world are marking the International Labour Day.

VIDEO:  When Malaysia votes in its general election  it will face a simple choice - whether to give the opposition its first chance of being in government, or whether to continue backing a coalition that has been in office for more than half a century.

More than 400 people are now confirmed dead after the collapse of the building housing clothing factories in Bangladesh a week ago. 149 people are still missing.     Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets of the capital, Dhaka, in protests to mark International Workers Day. They're demanding the death penalty for the building's owners.     The European Union says it could take action to create pressure for improvements and accountability on working conditions in Bangladesh.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22364891

An enormous hurricane raging at Saturn's north pole has an eye 2,000km across and is big enough to cover the UK 12 times over.    The striking images of the storm were snapped from a height of 420.000km by the Cassini spacecraft, which arrived at Saturn in 2004.    Scientists say the hurricane's winds reach a staggering 150m/s     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22351048
US President Barack Obama restates his intention to close the prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, amid a growing hunger strike among prisoners there.  Do you agree with President Obama?

At least 13 people have been killed and many more injured after a big explosion in Syria's capital, Damascus.  A bomb is believed to have been detonated in the central district of Marjeh. Pictures from Syrian TV show a number of damaged cars and buildings following the blast.

It was an understated ceremony which looked closer to a register office wedding than a handover of power. But now, the Netherlands has a new king its first male head of state for more than a century.     King Willem Alexander took over from his mother Beatrix, just under an hour ago. They sealed the transfer of power from one generation to the next with an appearance on the balcony and a kiss from mother to son.     Thousands gathered to cheer, in Dam Square in Amsterdam. And now they'll celebrate with a 24 hour party.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22348160

Who started the punch-up on Mount Everest?    The incident had been "terrifying to watch - they nearly got killed" -an unnamed eyewitness told the AFP news agency.    More than 3,000 people have scaled Mount Everest since it was first conquered in 1953 but how many ended up getting into a fight with their Sherpa guides ?    The fight apparently broke out between 3 international climbers and their local Sherpa guides.    There are very different accounts of exactly what happened  - and who started it. Apparently things got tense around 7,500 metres up.     For the full story click the link  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22336540

China's Premier Li Keqiang has urged vigilance against a new strain of bird flu that has killed 23 people so far out of more than 100 cases that have been reported.  Experts say the virus cannot be transmitted between humans, but are worried it could mutate and potentially trigger a pandemic.  What are authorities doing to prevent the spread of bird flu? Send us your questions and Zhuang Chen from BBC Chinese service will answer them on Impact with Mishal Husain.

Syrian Prime Minister Wael al-Halaqi has survived a car bomb attack in the capital, Damascus, which has caused casualties, reports say.  The blast in western Mazzeh district targeted Mr Halaqi's convoy, state television said. There are reported to be a number of casualties.

Cranes are now being used to clear the site of the building that collapsed in Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, last week.     Rescue workers say it's unlikely they'll find any more survivors. Around 380 people are known to have died. Many are still missing.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22334240

Link Title: What will air travel look like in the year 2050?
Message: Aircraft manufacturer Airbus has released its predictions for what air travel will look like in 2050. BBC Travel has the rundown:

Link Title: Iraq unrest prompts TV channel ban
Message: Iraq suspends the licences of 10 satellite channels including al-Jazeera and imposes a ban on their operations for "promoting violence".  More than 170 people have been killed in less than a week and PM Nouri Maliki has spoken of a "wave of sectarianism" in Iraq that began abroad.  An army raid on a Sunni protest camp on Tuesday sparked widespread clashes.

Link Title: Nigeria polio: Immunising the vaccine fears
Message: Nigeria has been making some strides in the battle against the polio, which can cause lifelong paralysis, but the task has been slow and fraught with challenges as the tragic story of this year’s first polio victim exemplifies, writes the BBC’s Christine Otieno.

Link Title: New Italy government to be sworn in
Message: A new Italian government has been sworn in at the presidential Quirinal Palace in Rome.  Democratic Party Deputy Leader (PD), Enrico Letta, becomes prime minister at the head of a "grand coalition" including Silvio Berlusconi's People of Freedom party (PDL).  The swearing-in signals the end of two months of political deadlock.  Away from the ceremony, outside the PM's office, two police officers were injured by gunshots.

VIDEO:  A host of stars from film and television joined politicians and journalists at the dinner in Washington, and quite a few were singled out for special treatment.   But Mr Obama had something special in mind for his predecessor, George W Bush.

Link Title: On Ferrari patrol with the Dubai police
Message: The Dubai police force has added a Ferrari FF to it's fleet, following the recent addition of a luxury Chevrolet and Lamborghini.
Protests are held in India after an attack in a Pakistani prison leaves convicted Indian spy Sarabjit Singh in a coma.

Happy 850th birthday to Notre Dame! From the real history of Quasimodo to the pack of man-eating wolves that descended on the cathedral's square in 1450, BBC Travel has the fascinating history of this Parisian landmark:  http://bit.ly/YZYpaJ
Iraq's prime minister warns that a plague of sectarianism is threatening Arab nations, after the most widespread violence there since US troops left.

Link Title: Iceland to vote in general election
Message: Voters in Iceland are due to go to the polls in parliamentary elections expected to oust the governing centre-left coalition.

Link Title: Earth's core far hotter than thought
Message: Researchers revisit measurements to determine the temperature of the Earth's core, finding it to be 6,000C - as hot as the surface of the Sun.
VIDEO: Human cost of cheap Western clothes  The BBC's Andrew North says secret filming has revealed that child labour is used in Bangladesh to make cheap clothing for Western buyers.
Two owners of garment factories in the building that collapsed in Bangladesh are arrested, as 24 more people are rescued from the rubble.

For One Square Mile, Paddy O'Connell visits the ancient walled Croatian port of Zadar to test hopes and fears in the next country to join the European Union.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-22294290

New York police say what appears to be part of the landing gear of one of jets flown into the World Trade Center on 11 September 2001 has been found http://bbc.in/15ZxK56  The 5ft (1.52m) piece of metal, which bears a Boeing label and serial number, was wedged between two New York City buildings, police said.  It was found on Wednesday by surveyors inspecting a lower Manhattan building.

Link Title: On the Road - On the road: Alaska
Message: It's hard enough for most parents to get their children to stick to their bedtime curfews, but it is even more difficult in Barrow, Alaska, a city that gets more than 80 days of complete sunlight each year. BBC Travel takes a look at how life changes when darkness never falls: http://bit.ly/ZSadMr

Have you ever encountered a stink bug? http://bbc.in/ZSqxfW  Millions of these flying insects are emerging from hibernation and striking fear into the hearts of farmers across the US. This is Jane O'Brien in Washington, DC and tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at some of the ways science is looking to to take on these hungry (and smelly) pests. Link Title: Boston bomb suspect moved to prison
Message: "If I didn't make it, he would kill me right out” http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22308593  A 26-year-old Chinese businessman, identified only as Danny, has told the Boston Globe newspaper about how he was carjacked by the Boston bombing suspects, several days after the attack near the marathon's finish area.  Over the course of the 90-minute journey the three men discussed everyday topics such as girls, cars and smartphones before 'Danny' made his escape at a petrol station.  Other news from Boston: - Amputee: I'll dance again http://bbc.in/ZS5iep - How to interrogate a suspect http://bbc.in/ZS5gDp - Mother bitterly denounces US http://bbc.in/ZS5gTH

It has taken him 30 years to produce his first album, and almost as long to make a name for himself on the world stage.    But it is happening now for Jupiter Bokondji, 48. Last year, he was part of the ground-breaking Africa Express which took music from the continent around the UK by train.    Jupiter, and his band, Okwess International, have moved beyond the rhumba for which the Democratic Republic of Congo is so famous and are mining the rich and relatively untapped world of the country's traditional music.    Have a listen by clicking on the link below   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22267126

The Israeli military says it is to stop using artillery shells with white phosphorus to create smokescreens on the battlefield.  Rights groups condemned Israel's use of white phosphorus during the Gaza conflict because of its severely harmful effects on civilians.

What can technology do to help a global ageing population?    A demographic revolution like nothing we’ve seen before is happening right in front of our eyes. Within the next five years there will be more adults aged over 65 than there will be children aged under five, and that is the first time that’s happened in the history of mankind.     Watch BBC Horizons tomorrow at 01.30 or 08.30 GMT on BBC World News.     http://www.bbc.com/specialfeatures/horizonsbusiness/episode/ageing-populations/?autoplay=true&vid=p018622y&tab=1   (Not available in UK)

Poachers are taking advantage of instability in the Central African Republic to kill more endangered elephants, wildlife campaigners say.  8 organisations have called for action following reports of elephant meat being sold openly in markets.  Armed rebels seized power and ousted President Francois Bozize in March after a peace deal collapsed.

It's the scene of the world's worst-ever nuclear accident. In 2010 Ric Wright decided to head for the exclusion zone around the nuclear plant at Chernobyl in Ukraine to take photos of the abandoned town of Pripyat.  Once it was the home to the plant's workers and their families. The town's 49,000 inhabitants were told to leave 36 hours after the explosion on 26 April 1986.  Click on the link below for the full gallery

Grief and shock at the devastating collapse of an 8-storey building in the Bangladeshi capital Dhaka have begun to turn to rage.    Police are reported to have fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters demanding better and safer conditions for clothing industry workers.     At least 290 people are known to have died so far. And frantic rescue efforts are continuing for hundreds more still unaccounted for.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22305305

"It is extremely serious, this is a war crime" British PM David Cameron told the BBC.    His comments come after the White House, France and Israel say they had seen intelligence suggesting some use of chemical weapons. The issue is a 'red line' for the international community.     If fully verified, it could trigger some form of US-led NATO intervention, for the first time in the 2 year conflict.     What do you think the international community should do if the intelligence proves to be correct?    Please note that the video contains some disturbing images  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22305444

"We figured out this new system to live." http://bbc.in/15RUIuX  Mike Brodie began hopping trains at 17 and spent five years crisscrossing the US.   This week on Picture This, Mike tells us about his time on the railroads and shares some of the photos from his new book A Period of Juvenile Prosperity.

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has said the Boston bombing suspects planned to detonate the rest of their explosives in Times Square http://bbc.in/ZPIRGz  Mayor Bloomberg said Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect, had told the FBI he and his brother "spontaneously" decided that New York would be next.
PHOTO GALLERY:  Take a look at this selection of images from Rudolf Abraham, an award-winning photographer and writer specialising in Croatia and Eastern Europe.

US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel has said American intelligence believes "to some degree of varying confidence" that Syria has used chemical weapons http://bbc.in/15QMFP5  During a visit to the United Arab Emirates, he said it was suspected that sarin gas had been used against rebels.  Mr Hagel said the use was "small scale" and did not specify where or when.

VIDEO:     For the first time, the parents of the chief suspects in the Boston marathon bombings, have been giving a highly emotional news conference in Dagestan in southern Russia.     The mother, Zubeidat Tsarnaeva, said America had taken her sons away from her. She added that she was sure her sons Tamerlan and Dzhokhar were "not involved in anything".     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22290854

Unemployment has risen once again in Spain to another new record of more than six million, 27.2% of the workforce.  Are you in Spain? Have you been affected by unemployment? What is your reaction to the increased unemployment rate?

Female police officers in Afghanistan need dedicated facilities to help prevent sexual harassment from predatory colleagues, says Human Rights Watch.  Women - who make up 1% of the police force - are often targeted by predatory colleagues while using shared toilets.  Many facilities have peepholes or no locks, so female officers stand guard for each other, HRW said.

Australians and New Zealanders gather on Anzac day to commemorate the 98th anniversary of their soldiers landing at Gallipoli in Turkey in World War I.  For the first time, the role of indigenous aboriginal soldiers and Prisoners Of War has also been acknowledged.

"The whole building collapsed like a pancake within minutes. Most workers did not have any chance to escape"  Hundreds of desperate workers and relatives are still digging with whatever they can, to pull survivors from the wreckage of a factory which collapsed near the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka.  175 people are known to have died when the 8 storey building collapsed, but it's feared the final figure could be much higher.

A game reserve in South Africa is using a rather unusual method to conserve the local rhino population http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22284638    The reserve's owner injects the horns of the rhinos with a poison which is toxic to humans - but not rhinos - to discourage poachers.    We want to hear from you.     Do you think the owner's unique plan to combat poaching will work?

Will South America's map change? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22277407    Bolivia has said it will file a law suit against Chile at the International Court of Justice on Wednesday to reclaim access to the Pacific Ocean.    Bolivia lost access to the coastline in a 19th Century war with Chile, leaving it landlocked ever since.

Would you buy someone a "suspended" coffee?    The idea of "Suspended Coffee" is simple: When you buy yourself a coffee at a participating cafe, you also pay for a second one - which can then be claimed by someone who cannot afford it themselves.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22267613

Link Title: Suarez banned for 10 games over bite
Message: Liverpool striker Luis Suarez has been banned for 10 games by the Football Association for biting Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic.  The incident happened during Sunday's 2-2 draw between the sides.  The 26-year-old later apologised for biting the Chelsea defender and was fined by Liverpool on Monday.  Do you agree with the banning?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22278258

Link Title: The changing face of the average Aussie
Message: What does the average Australian look like to you?  Australia's population has surpassed 23 million. And as the country's numbers change, so does its image - you can forget Crocodile Dundee, for a start.  Here's Nick Byrant's report from Sydney  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22213218

Breaking- Enrico Letta is set to become Italy's new prime minister, after being asked by President Giorgio Napolitano to form a broad coalition government.    The appointment of Mr Letta, currently deputy leader of the centre-left Democratic Party, could see the end of two months of parliamentary deadlock.     An inconclusive general election in February has left the country in flux.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22278038

Many cricket fans call him the greatest batsman of his generation.  Sachin Tendulkar has broken record after record at the crease.   He's the only player to notch up a century of international centuries.  Today he celebrates his 40th birthday by playing a match.   Do you think he is a cricket legend?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-22278694

Link Title: At least 70 dead in Dhaka collapse
Message: At least 70 people have been killed and many more are feared trapped after an eight-storey building collapsed in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka.  Frantic efforts are under way to rescue those beneath the debris. At least 200 were injured by the collapse.  The army is helping with the rescue operation on the outskirts of Dhaka.  Building collapses are common in Bangladesh where many multi-storey blocks are built in violation of rules.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22275597

Does toothpaste go up your nose?  How does a space towel absorb water?  What do you eat?   What would you ask an astronaut? http://bbc.in/ZKLfP4  If you have questions like these then you may want to follow Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield, the current commander of the International Space Station, on Twitter. During his time in space he has built up a loyal fan base back on Earth thanks to his comments, photos and videos showing the more practical side of life in the cosmos.  Get to know Chris Hadfield and come up with a question of your own http://bbc.in/ZKLfP4

The Associated Press has said its Twitter account has been hacked, after the posting of a bogus post about explosions at the White House http://bbc.in/ZKBIY8  The news agency's account was suspended and it has advised all tweets should be ignored until further notice.  US markets were spooked by the tweet; the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 150 points as it was retweeted. A group calling itself the Syrian Electronic Army claimed responsibility for hijacking the accounts.

Link Title: Times Square film honour for Mandela
Message: A film installation celebrating quotes from Nelson Mandela is taking over the electronic billboards in New York as part of the Tribeca film festival.  Mandela's grandson Ndaba said it would "remind us of our humanity".  He added that his grandfather approved of The Power of Words installation.

A group of foreigners abducted on Monday by militants in eastern Afghanistan are being "well looked after", officials and the Taliban say.    Up to 11 people, thought to include eight Turks, two Russians and an Afghan were taken in Logar province after their helicopter landed in bad weather.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22261410

Graphic journalist Dan Archer uses comic strips to report on human trafficking in Nepal.    'I found comics were able to put human faces to the survivors while protecting their identities, instead of over-used images of blurry night vision cameras or, worse still, bodies with the faces blurred out'.    Take a look Dan's comic strip (click on the link below) and let us know what you think of it.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22247747

Link Title: Explosion at French embassy in Libya
Message: A car bomb has exploded at the French embassy in Tripoli.  2 French guards were wounded, with reports that one was seriously hurt.   The bomb caused extensive damage to the building and the perimeter wall. There have been similar attacks in eastern Libya - notably Benghazi, but this is tHe first of its kind in the capital.

Do you think women still have a way to go in developing leadership skills?   Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg says this remains a challenge, and the problem starts with the way little girls are perceived. Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Salehi on Canadian officials suggestion that an attack had been planned with support from al-Qaeda elements in Iran.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22263325

The Japanese PM, Shinzo Abe, has warned that Japan will use force against Chinese government ships if they attempt to land on a group of disputed islands.   It was Mr Abe's most explicit warning to China since he took power at the end of last year. Around 20 ships from both China and Japan have gathered off the islands, in the East China sea, as tension continues to build.

At least 26 people have reportedly been killed in clashes between security forces and Sunni Muslim protesters in northern Iraq. It reports that the arrests took place in Ontario and Quebec.

Link Title: Croatia: From isolation to EU membership
Message: Croatia: From isolation to EU membership  How Croatia's has gone from battered and isolated post-war state to become the EU's next new member.  "We used the process to build our own institutions and stabilise our state" Vesna Pusic, Croatia's foreign minister.

Link Title: EU states ease Syria oil embargo
Message: EU member states have agreed to ease an oil embargo on Syria to allow the purchase of crude from the opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.  Foreign ministers said they had made the decision "with a view to helping the Syrian civilian population".

LUCKY ESCAPE:  "I just feel that I've been lucky and I just think [if it was] a bigger crocodile, I maybe wouldn't have any head"  A Frenchman has managed to escape a saltwater crocodile that latched on to his head as he swam in Australia's Northern Territory.

In Senegal, traditional wrestling is more popular than football, with the champions making their fortunes and becoming national celebrities. In most of the country, the sport is only for men but in the remote, southern region of Casamance, there is a long history of female wrestling and so the national team all come from Casamance. 'To get food to eat in the town now is a problem because even the markets are burnt. We are still picking corpses of women and children in the bush and creeks.'  Residents in the northern Nigerian town of Baga say they are burying those killed in heavy fighting there between government forces and Islamist militants.   People who fled the clashes say they returned to the remote northern town to find the streets strewn with corpses.   185 people are reported to have been killed, but military officials have disputed the casualty figures, describing them as inflated.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22243834

Serbia's government has approved an EU-brokered deal with its former province of Kosovo, paving the way for progress in both sides' drive to join the EU.  The deal ushers in a normalisation of ties which have been strained since the 1999 Kosovo conflict.

The BBC has obtained video footage which shows Burmese police standing by as shops, homes and mosques are looted and burnt - and failing to intervene as Buddhist mobs, including monks, killed fleeing Muslims.    Most of the pictures were filmed by police in the town of Meiktila last month, when religious and sectarian violence broke out.     But the video will raise questions about why the European Union is planning to lift trade sanctions against Burma - it's making a decision on that today.
