UPDATE : The FBI has released photos of two suspects it wants to identify as part of the investigation into Monday's Boston Marathon bombings http://bbc.in/ZALNqH  CCTV captured the two men, one wearing a dark-coloured baseball cap and the other a white cap, near the scene.  FBI Agent Richard DesLauriers warned members of the public not to approach the two men.

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we will continue our look a the two tragedies dominating the news in the US.   We will have a report from the small town of West, Texas as it deals with the aftermath of last night's explosion at a fertiliser plant http://bbc.in/15jlSuh  We'll also return to Boston to look at today's memorial service http://bbc.in/15jlRqq and the efforts to find the bomber http://bbc.in/15jlSdU  Share your thoughts with us in the comments section below or join us on Twitter @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/15jlRqu or @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/15jlUlS   Photo credit: The BBC's Alastair Leithead in West, Texas

Link Title: Human Social Project: Cracking the real code of life
Message: What determines the age we will die? As the latest in BBC Future's World-Changing Ideas reveals, it might not be what you think:
More eyewitness accounts and analysis from the Texas fertiliser blast on BBC news.

Few objects have had such a profound impact on our lives as the humble tin can. It has lived on our shelves for 200 years, measures a few centimetres high and just millimetres thick.  How many of you have kept tins in your cupboard well beyond their expiry date?   Who has a story about a emergency shelter filled with tinned food?   Tell us your stories and we will try to put some on our Global programme from 1500GMT on Monday.
Migrant workers shot on a strawberry farm in Greece.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22198699

Link Title: Obama to visit Boston bomb ceremony
Message: President Barack Obama is due to visit Boston in the next few hours to attend a memorial service for victims of the Boston Marathon bombing. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22197194
Pakistan's Pervez Musharraf: Court orders ex-ruler's arrest http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22196101

There's been a huge explosion at a fertiliser plant in Texas.     It happened in the town of West - not far from  Waco. The authorities say a number of people have died, although it will be some time before they can give an exact figure.     The explosion happened around 8pm and reports suggest it could be heard more than 40 miles away. Eye-witnesses say a 4 block area around the factory has been devastated.     An apartment complex nearby was reduced to a skeleton, according to the Texas fire department.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22195495

More than 900 Haitian immigrants to the Brazilian state of Acre have been allowed to stay in Brazil.  A federal task force sent to Acre to deal with a rising influx of migrants issued them with residency and work permits.  Acre declared a state of emergency last week after about 1,700 arrived in the state within a fortnight.  Most of the immigrants are Haitians, but there are also Africans and Asians whose situation remains unresolved.

New research shows that Africans living outside the continent send more money home than is provided by Western aid donors.  In 2010 - the most recent year for which meaningful comparisons can be made the African diaspora remitted $51.8bn to the continent.  In the same year, according to World Bank figures, ODA to Africa was $43bn.

Scientists have designed a super-grip sticking plaster covered with microscopic needles to heal surgical wounds.  The "bed-of-needles" patch, inspired by a parasitic worm that lives in the guts of fish and clings on using its cactus-like spikes, fixes skin grafts firmly in place without the need for staples.  Its creators say the patch is three times stronger than the materials currently used for burns patients.

According to US military 7 more prisoners have joined a hunger strike at the US detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, bringing the total number to 52.  15 of the protesters are being force fed, and 3 of them are being observed in hospital.  Human rights groups say prisoners are frustrated with the military's failure to decide their future.  The US is currently holding 166 men at the facility, most without charge.

Insecurity dominates the lives of millions of Mexicans. Caught between the murderous drug cartels and absent or corrupt law enforcement, communities are taking the law into their own hands. In the state of Guerrero, a fledgling vigilante force has grown into an organisation numbering thousands. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22066082

WATCH:   This is a sneak preview of Mishal Husain's interview with the most powerful woman at Facebook, COO Sheryl Sandberg.     Just click the link http://www.vizibee.com/video.php?video_id=621    You'll be able to see the interview tomorrow on BBC World News at 1300GMT.

A letter addressed to US President Barack Obama containing a "suspicious" substance has been intercepted, officials say.  The US Secret Service said the letter was identified at a remote facility where White House post is screened.

"Bitcoin is for pure financial freedom of speech. It really changes the dynamics of how money works."    Wild swings in the recent value of Bitcoins have caused some to question whether the virtual currency is intrinsically flawed. But who would have thought one of the tech wizards behind a global currency would live in a squat?    Amir Taaki is a developer who works with a virtual currency called Bitcoin. His home and office is an abandoned Buddhist temple. The dwelling is covered in brightly painted but slowly decaying murals of Buddha, with the odd makeshift bunk bed and flotsam furniture like a couch with no pillows.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22152213

Police in Colombia have seized properties and goods worth more than $25m belonging to notorious Colombian drug lord Daniel Barrera - known as The Madman.    Among them are luxury villas, cattle ranches and restaurants and bars in the capital, Bogota, and eastern Colombia.    Police also detained four of his relatives on suspicion of money laundering.    Barrera was arrested last year in neighbouring Venezuela while he was making a call in a public phone booth.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22179894

The Red Cross in Kenya is warning people living in areas prone to landslides to move as flooding continues across country.   The Secretary General of the Red Cross in Kenya told the BBC 2 people were trapped by a landslide about 100 km west of Nairobi and villagers near the eastern town of Garissa had been marooned by high waters.   36 people have died and more than 50,000 have been displaced by the floods this month. Kenya's rainy season is between March and May but correspondents say this year's flooding is particularly severe.

Bombs that targeted the Boston Marathon on Monday may have been packed in pressure cookers, investigators say.    Images from a joint Homeland Security and FBI bulletin show the remains of a dark backpack, a detonation device and mangled pieces of metal.    Three people were killed and more than 170 injured when two bombs exploded near the finish line of Monday's race. Those who died were an eight-year-old boy, a woman aged 29 and a postgraduate student from China.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22177669

Hi, this is Ros Atkins.   Don't know if you've seen this story from India. Supreme Court judges have said that public officials are using of red lights to cut through traffic far too much and that it's promoting elitism.    Now, this isn't an issue in London where I live. We have sirens and flashing lights a lot but it's all the emergency services. It seems it's a far bigger issue in India, and I've also read about people in Russia faking blue lights just to get through the traffic.   I'm going to be reporting from the world's newsroom for Global later, and I'd be keen to hear if officials turn on the flashing lights far too quickly where you live.   You can post here, or get me across on twitter.com/BBCRosAtkiins. Thanks.

Pakistan's military has mobilised helicopters to evacuate people injured by a powerful earthquake which shook an area close to its border with Iran.    The country's National Disaster Management Authority has now confirmed that 35 Pakistanis died in the quake and that 150 were injured.     Iranian television says just one of its citizens was killed by the 7.8 magnitude earthquake.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22178765

A letter containing ricin or another poisonous substance has been posted to a US senator, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has said http://bbc.in/ZvMxgv  The letter was intended for Roger Wicker, a Republican senator representing Mississippi, Mr Reid told the Associated Press news agency.

This is Laura Trevelyan in Boston - tonight on BBC World News America we will bring you the latest from yesterday's tragedy near the Boston Marathon finish line   http://bbc.in/15dE3lf  Silent tribute planned for London run http://bbc.in/15dE3lb  Grief and defiance http://bbc.in/15dE1d5  Family tragedy unfolds in Boston  http://bbc.in/15dE3lh  Check your local listings to find BBC World News America in your area and stay up to date on our coverage from Boston @BBCNews http://bbc.in/15dE3l9

US President Barack Obama has condemned the bombings at the Boston Marathon as a "terrorist act" http://bbc.in/15dpDl7  He said the attack had been a "heinous and cowardly act", but said it was not yet known who carried out the attack and why. The FBI has said there are "no known additional threats" beyond the two bombs which went off http://bbc.in/15dpEFv  Our latest from Boston:  - FBI probes Boston Marathon 'terror' blasts http://bbc.in/15dpEpc - Few details emerge about the victims http://bbc.in/15dpDld - Blood and panic at finish line http://bbc.in/15dpDl9 - Bostonians run once again http://bbc.in/15dpDBr - US media reaction http://bbc.in/15dpDl5 - As it happened http://bbc.in/15dpEp8 - Our special report page http://bbc.in/15dpDlb  Photo Credit: The BBC's Paul Adams

Police in Bahrain have fired tear gas and clashed with students in a raid on a secondary school in the capital, Manama, reports say.  Officers stormed the Jabreya school for boys after students staged a protest demanding the release of a colleague arrested on Monday, activists say.  About 100 people have been arrested this month amid growing tension ahead of Sunday's F1 Grand Prix in Bahrain.

Europe-wide tests have found horse DNA in up to 5% of beef products.    The checks were agreed by EU member states in February following the discovery of horsemeat in frozen foods.    The European Commission says French beef had the highest levels of horsemeat, followed by Greek.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22162872

Iran has been hit by its most powerful earthquake for nearly 40 years. It was also felt in Pakistan, India and the Middle East.     Find out what eyewitnesses and BBC journalists from the region have been reporting.    Reaction from Qatar "It felt like the building was floating"    Reaction from India "A nervous TV presenter started talking about earthquake tremors having been felt in Karachi and Balochistan"    Reaction from the UAE "I got a weird feel in my ears, I could tell something was wrong. I could see people running out of buildings"    Read more here http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22165588

Link Title: UN presses world to act over Syria
Message: The heads of five major UN agencies have issued a rare joint appeal to the international community to do much more to end "cruelty and carnage" in Syria.  In a statement, the chiefs of the WHO, Unicef, Ocha, WFP and UNHCR urged political leaders to use their influence to solve the crisis.  The UN says at least 70,000 people have been killed and 1.2 million left homeless since the conflict began.

Link Title: Tunisia Ben Ali relative gets asylum
Message: Sakher El Materi, son-in-law of ousted Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali, has been granted asylum in the Seychelles, officials say.  He was arrested as he tried to enter in the island state in December 2012 and reportedly applied to stay in February.  He had fled Tunisia for Qatar after the uprising that ousted President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali in January 2011.  Months later, a court in Tunisian convicted him of corruption in absentia.

Pakistan's former military leader Pervez Musharraf has been barred from standing in general elections in May.  An election tribunal disqualified him from running in Chitral in the north-west. Earlier, he failed in an attempt to stand in three other seats.  Musharraf's lawyer says he plans to file an appeal with the Supreme Court.

Reports of a very strong earthquake in south eastern Iran.   It is the biggest earthquake in the country in the last 40 years.   The quake was felt across the Middle East and South Asia. High rise buildings swayed in Dubai and have been evacuated, and people in the Indian capital Delhi also felt buildings move.  The fault line is different from the earthquake that jolted Bushehr last week. All communications are cut and assessment teams have been sent to the stricken area.

Economic growth in sub-Saharan Africa should significantly outpace the global average over the next three years, according to the World Bank.  Higher commodities, increasing investment and a general pick-up in the world economy should all boost the continent's growth to more than 5%.  But the World Bank added that African governments had to do more to ensure that this growth reduced poverty.  Global GDP was forecast to grow by an average of 2.4% this year.

China has revealed the structure of its military units, in what state-run media describe as a first.  The army has a total of 850,000 officers, while the navy and air force have a strength of 235,000 and 398,000, China said in its defence white paper.  The paper also criticised the US's expanded military presence in the Asia Pacific, saying it had exacerbated regional tensions.  China's defence budget rose by 11.2% in 2012, exceeding $100bn

Are you in the area? Did you witness the explosions?     Investigations are underway into explosions which killed 3 people at the Boston marathon.     President Obama has said those responsible for the acts will feel the "full weight of justice".     140 spectators and competitors were injured by the blasts close to the finishing line.     The FBI now has control of what it described as a "potential terrorist inquiry". Security has been stepped up at possible vulnerable sites across the United States.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22162884
Boston Marathon explosions live text and video http://bbc.in/Zt4PyV

Two explosions near the finish line of the Boston Marathon are reported to have left people injured http://bbc.in/Zt03l1  Video and photographs show a scene of confusion, with emergency services descending on the finish line area.

Link Title: Blind drivers at the steering wheel
Message: How would you feel if a blind person pulled up next to you in a car?   Innovations in automated driving have led to speculation that blind people may be able to take to the wheel. But do they want to drive - and could it become a reality?

An appeal court in Egypt has ruled that the former President Hosni Mubarak should no longer be detained over charges related to the killing of protesters two years ago.   However because Mr Mubarak is under investigation on other charges, he will remain in custody. The appeals court accepted the two year limit on Mr Mubarak's detention without conviction had expired.

Link Title: Titanic: By the men who built it
Message: AUDIO/SLIDESHOW:  In 1920 a Titanic memorial was erected in Belfast, the birthplace of the ship, "to the imperishable memory of those gallant Belfast men who lost their lives on 15th April 1912".   Marking the anniversary of Titanic's sinking, an anonymous poem tells the story of how the ship is remembered in the the city where it was built.

Hi Ros Atkins here.  Going to be on Global later with Jon Sopel, reporting from the world's newsroom. I'm looking at story out of the UK about how, apparently, 2/3 of kids feel a pressure to cheat to win at sport.   Perhaps even more strikingly more 1/3 said they felt no remorse at winning by cheating.   Something's clearly amiss there. I wonder if you have children and how they approach sport. It'll be interesting to compare your experiences with those in the UK.   I'll work some of your comments into my report for Jon. Thanks.

Scientists in the United States have created a working kidney and successfully transplanted the organ into a rat.     It's a world first that could bring new hope to millions of people waiting for an organ donor.     The kidney in question was grown in a laboratory bio-engineered as the scientists put it and the results are said to be encouraging.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-22123386

They are being dubbed the Gauche Caviar or Cavier Left - the socialist ministers of French President François Hollande. That's after a series of revelations about their personal fortunes.   Will this bold move by the French president be enough to begin restoring his government's reputation?

Could this be the world's most expensive shirt?    An Indian man has bought the shirt with more than 3kg of gold and worth $250,000. His is an extreme case of an Indian obsession with the precious metal.    Datta Phuge's shirt only gets an outing on special occasions and he has a security guard with him wherever he travels, to protect his purchase.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21994873

Link Title: Iraq cities hit by deadly bombings
Message: Reports from Iraq are now saying that as many as 31 people were killed in a series of bomb attacks across the country on Monday morning. Around 200 people are said to have been hurt.  The attacks come as the country prepares for provincial elections on Saturday.

The result of the presidential election in Venezuela was as close as opinion polls suggested.   The Socialist, Nicolas Maduro, won a narrow victory by less than 2%.   His campaign promised to continue the policies of the late leader, Hugo Chavez, who died last month and nominated Maduro as his successor.    The defeated candidate, Henrique Capriles, has demanded a recount.
One airline has started charging passengers according to how much they weigh. BBC Travel has the argument for – and against – this controversial practice:

Link Title: Kerry in Japan amid N Korea tensions
Message: US Secretary of State John Kerry has arrived in Japan, the last stop of his four-day Asian tour which has focused on tensions on the Korean peninsula.  North Korea has recently threatened attacks against South Korea and the US, sparking alarm in the region.  After meeting China's top leaders on Saturday Mr Kerry said China was "very serious" in its pledge to help resolve tensions with North Korea, its ally.  Mr Kerry has said the US will defend itself and its allies from any attack.

How do you spot a tree that makes good violins?   Switzerland is home to some of the best violin makers in the world. But how do they know which tree will make a top quality violin?   A wander through the forest with a master tree picker gives an idea of the enormous experience and instinct required.

A Nepali television presenter has set a new world record by holding the longest-ever talk show, breaking the previous record by 10 hours.  Rabi Lamichhane, a Nepali who normally lives in the United States, stayed on air for more than 62 hours.  He interviewed politicians, journalists and celebrities on the theme "Buddha was born in Nepal", and took phone calls from viewers.

Link Title: Venice imposes short Grand Canal boat ban
Message: "This initiative is to raise awareness of the pollution and promote the use of electric or hybrid boats".  The city of Venice is imposing its first ever ban on motorboats, launches and barges on one of its main waterways on Sunday.  Almost all the usual traffic will be cleared from the Grand Canal for several hours.  The aim is to draw attention to the city's environmental problems, and help make the case for more ecologically-sound forms of water transport.

How the filming of Apocalypse Now accidentally gave rise to surfing culture in the Philippines.  When a scene from Apocalypse Now was shot on an obscure beach in the Philippines in the late 70s, little did the film-makers know they were giving birth to the country's surfing culture.

The Venezuelan opposition has made an official complaint against the government following allegations that it broke the law by continuing its electoral campaign on state television.  On the eve of the election, acting President Nicolas Maduro appeared on TV visiting the tomb of Hugo Chavez.  The opposition candidate Henrique Capriles said his opponent was "violating all the electoral norms".

Link Title: The end of Cuba's classic cars?
Message: A ride in one of Cuba's taxicabs often means a trip back in time – many vehicles on the roads are handed down through the generations. But recent economic liberalisation means that for the first time in years, residents are free to buy, sell and upgrade their cars. BBC Travel takes a seat in a classic taxicab to find out what that means for the people:

Our news from around the world for this Saturday:  - China calls for calm on North Korea http://bbc.in/Zo61DO - Mubarak judge withdraws from trial http://bbc.in/Zo60Qd - All survive after jet lands in sea off Bali Indonesia http://bbc.in/Zo60zU - What do Venezuelans want in a president? http://bbc.in/Zo60Qb - Google chief wary of mini-drones http://bbc.in/Zo61DM - Russia retaliates for US blacklist http://bbc.in/Zo61DG - A funny look at the news - 140 characters at a time http://bbc.in/Zo60Q9

The Beatles set off the surge of Western spiritual seekers to Rishikesh back in 1968, but in the decades since, this Indian city's reputation as a centre for healing and enlightenment has not waned. From the massive ashrams to the river Ganges, where candles are floated as a holy offering, BBC Travel has a snapshot of life in this deeply spiritual city:

Campaigning has ended in Venezuela ahead of this weekend's presidential election - the first vote in almost 20 years in which Hugo Chavez will not be a candidate http://bbc.in/154226r  This is Laura Trevelyan in Washington, DC and tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the election, the latest warnings to North Korea http://bbc.in/1541ZY9 , lead contamination in Nigeria http://bbc.in/1541ZY7 and a skeletal reconstruction of a 'human ancestor' http://bbc.in/154226l  Check your local listings to find BBC World News near you and join the conversation on Twitter - I can be found @LauraTrevelyan http://bbc.in/1541ZY5  and the latest from our journalists and producers in North America can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/154226p

Have beers brewed in the US suddenly become cool? http://bbc.in/Zmdqng  Not long ago the term "American beer" meant bottled lagers like Budweiser, Miller or Coors - not the "small, independent and traditional" concoctions that have become the choice of hipsters and connoisseurs at home and abroad.   The BBC’s Jon Kelly takes a look at the new American brew masters and their growing popularity.

Students in Chile have resumed protests for education reforms, with more than 100,000 people taking to the streets of the country http://bbc.in/ZlWb5e  In the capital, Santiago, riot police fired tear gas and water cannon to break up the march, after being targeted by hooded protesters.

VIDEO: Anne Frank's stepsister Eva Schloss has been describing how she survived the Auschwitz concentration camp, "The human spirit is amazing, hope is amazing - I was one of the few lucky ones".  She told BBC World's Stephen Sackur how her mother went on to marry Anne's father Otto and how he helped her to overcome her bitterness at the world.  Talking about her new memoir After Auschwitz: A Story of Heartbreak and Survival, she described how she also felt a sort of jealousy at the attention focused on her dead stepsister.

Link Title: Paris judge to rule on masks auction
Message: An auction of masks originating from a native American tribe in Arizona has begun in Paris, after a legal challenge to stop the sale failed.  Lawyers for the Hopi tribe had asked for the auction to be cancelled on the grounds that the 70 masks must have been stolen from the tribe.  It considers them sacred and blessed with divine spirits.  Auctioneers, however, say the masks had been bought and sold in the past and were legally acquired.  Take a look at some of the masks by clicking the link below.

Link Title: Burma riots gold shop owner jailed
Message: A court in Burma has sentenced three Muslims to 14 years in jail for their role in communal violence that has left more than 40 dead.  The owner of a gold shop, his wife, and an employee, were convicted of theft and assault on Thursday, reports said.  A dispute at the gold shop in Meiktila is thought to have triggered deadly clashes between Burma's Muslim and Buddhist communities.  The violence spread to other towns and led to curfews being imposed.

Wikileaks founder Julian Assange has released a database of diplomatic records by Henry Kissinger, who ran American foreign policy under two presidents.   Why does the former diplomat interest liberals like Assange?

Thousands of Malian refugees are said to be living in appalling conditions in a UN run- camp in Mauritania.   The medical charity Medecins Sans Frontieres says conditions are so bad that people who have arrived in good health are now suffering from severe malnutrition.   Some 70,000 people are now living in the remote camp in the Mauritanian desert after fleeing the violence in Mali. The charity says sanitation, water and food supplies are all inadequate. And the health of thousands of refugees is deteriorating.

The most complete view yet of a possible human ancestor uncovered in South Africa has revealed an intriguing mix of human and ape traits.    The two-million-year-old remains of several partial skeletons belonging to a previously unknown humanlike species were found in 2008 near Johannesburg.    The new analysis shows this species - Australopithecus sediba - had a human-like pelvis, hands and teeth, and a chimpanzee-like foot.    The image shows: Au. sediba is compared with a modern human (LEFT) and a chimp (RIGHT)    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22108784

Link Title: Kerry in Seoul for North Korea talks
Message: International diplomacy aimed at defusing the dangerous tensions on the Korean peninsular have stepped up a gear. US Secretary of State, John Kerry, is in South Korea on the first stop of an Asia tour that will take him on to Beijing.   The Americans are urging the Chinese to use their leverage to rein in the North Korean Government, as speculation mounts about the extent of Pyongyangs nuclear capability.   One US intelligence report says there's now "moderate confidence" the North can mount a nuclear warhead on a missile.

Each night this week thousands of people have visited Washington, DC's Tidal Basin to see the cherry blossom trees in bloom http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22083408  Walking under the trees, a gift from Japan to the US over a century ago, and predicting the day they will bloom has become a local obsession in and around the city.   BBC Washington's Pia Gadkari and Lynsea Garrison bring you this photo and video postcard from the Cherry Blossom Festival.

The Nobel Prize medal won by British scientist Francis Crick for his discovery of DNA sold for $2.27m (£1.47m) at an auction in New York today http://bbc.in/1510g5N  Professor Crick won the prize in 1962 for his discovery of the structure of the DNA molecule, making it possible to decode how living beings function.  A letter written by Crick describing his discovery sold yesterday for $5.3m (£3.45m) http://bbc.in/1510g5P

Do you recognize the three brothers in this old photo? http://bbc.in/151fesE  If you work in politics, medicine or entertainment you probably know their work.    This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC and tonight on BBC World News America we will look at the remarkable Emanuel brothers and hear how Ari, Rahm and Ezekiel each became a global leader in their field. Do they have a family secret?   We'll also take a look at news from around the world, including:  - US Senate begins gun control debate http://bbc.in/151ffNk - G8 states condemn North Korea nuclear moves http://bbc.in/151ffNg - Japan's carmakers to recall 3.4m cars http://bbc.in/151fesv - DR Congo soldiers 'ordered to rape' women http://bbc.in/151fesy  Check you local listing to find BBC World News where you live and be sure to join us on Twitter @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/151fesA or @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/151fg3A

President Obama is set to present a posthumous Medal of Honor, the highest US military award, later today to the relatives of Emil Kapaun, a Catholic priest who died at the age of 35 during the Korean War http://bbc.in/150PX1J  The Army captain from the US state of Kansas was renowned for his bravery and the care he gave his fellow soldiers while they were imprisoned in North Korea - including carrying wounded men, bathing them, stealing food for his fellow prisoners and holding secret prayer sessions.   We profiled Kapaun and the efforts to nominate him for both the Medal of Honor and Catholic sainthood last year. You can find that story by following this link http://bbc.in/150PX1H

The cost of the Cyprus bailout has been revealed to be much higher than previously thought.  The Cypriot government says it needs an extra 5.5bn euros.    It will take a total of 23bn euros to recapitalise the country's banks and buy back government bonds.    It's not clear how they'll raise the extra cash, but the sale of gold reserves has not been ruled out.

EXCLUSIVE VIDEO REPORT:   A BBC team has uncovered evidence that soldiers in the Democratic Republic of the Congo were ordered to rape women by their superior officers.    Watch the full and shocking report by clicking on the link below.     *Warning this video contains some disturbing images*    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22111752

The pop star Madonna has said she's saddened by a row over her charity work in Malawi.   She'd been accused by Malawi's President Joyce Banda, of exaggerating her charity work and  expecting special treatment during her tour of the country last week.    The singer was made to queue with other passengers at the airport, rather than being given VIP treatment.

Do you see a world where everyone will be driving electric cars?  Last week Nissan began production of the first UK-built electric car, the Leaf. The company believes that after a slow start, the time has finally come for the battery operated electric car.   Electric vehicles are seen by governments as an important part of cutting emissions and reducing global warming. After all, what comes out of the car is completely clean, but nonetheless some scientists are questioning their green credentials.

Link Title: Africans complain of discrimination in India
Message: Zubair Ahmed reports from the Indian city of Mumbai on the indiscriminate racism and constant police harassment faced by hundreds of Africans living and working in the city.  There is no official data on how many Africans live in Mumbai, but since India's economic progress gathered momentum in recent years, many have come to work in and around the city.   Unofficial estimates put their numbers at more than 5,000.

Link Title: Women seek more Western Wall rights
Message: Israeli police have detained five women while praying at the Western Wall in Jerusalem for performing religious rituals that ultra-Orthodox Jews say are reserved for men. It's the latest in a series of protests by a group called Women of the Wall who are demanding greater religious freedom for women.  Orthodox rules forbid women from taking part in a number of religious rituals at the Western Wall including the wearing of prayer shawls and reading the Torah aloud.  Should Orthodox laws be amended  allowing women a greater role in religious rituals? Or are some laws fixed and therefore cannot be changed?

Millions of Japanese cars are being recalled around the world, because of concerns over the safety of  passenger airbags.   Toyota, Honda Nissan and Mazda are recalling models made in the early years of this century. The decision follows 5 incidents in Japan and the US in which the passenger airbag burst, sending pieces of plastic flying through the air.   There are no reports of any injuries.

Scientists have gained a remarkable insight into some of the oldest dinosaur embryos ever found http://bbc.in/ZitKoN  The creatures were preserved at different stages of their development, shedding light on life inside the egg. The international team concluded that the animals would have grown extremely quickly during their incubation period.  Picture credit A. LEBLANC

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at today's immigration rally on Capitol Hill, the tensions in the Korean peninsula http://bbc.in/14YbyaX , rape in Somali camps for the displaced http://bbc.in/14Ybzfd and an unlikely graduate of the Bolshoi Ballet http://bbc.in/14YbxUH  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation in the comments section below or on Twitter @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/14YbxUB or @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/14YbyaZ  Photo credit: BBC's Richard Fenton-Smith

"Too often the Latino community is portrayed using the more stereotypical images." http://bbc.in/14XZOVZ  What does it mean to be one of the more than 50 million Latinos in the US?   In this week's edition of Altered States we look at Cotidiano, a new exhibition of images by 12 photographers of Latino descent. Their goal is to move beyond the outdated stereotypes by looking at this diverse and rapidly changing community.  Photos courtesy of Sol Aramendi - as featured in Cotidiano.

Nelson Mandela's daughters have launched a court action to oust three of his aides from companies linked to him, a local newspaper reports.  Makaziwe and Zenani Mandela allege the three have no right to be on the boards of two companies worth about $1.7m, The Star reports.

Dutch government says that it recalling 50,000 tonnes tons of meat sold as beef across Europe that may contain horsemeat.   It comes in the wake of the horsemeat scandal in Europe where the product was miss sold as beef.  The Dutch government says 370 different companies around Europe are affected.

Humans have been fascinated by the Northern Lights for centuries. But how much do you really know about them? Do you know how they are made? Or that you can also find aurora on Jupiter and Saturn... and possibly even planets outside our solar system? BBC Future reveals all. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130410-the-greatest-show-on-earth

A radical Islamist opposition group in Syria, the Nusra Front, has distanced itself from an announcement by the leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq that the two organisations were merging.    In an audio message posted on the internet, the Nusra leader, Abu Mohammad al-Joulani, said he had not been consulted about the supposed merger. But he pledged allegiance to Ayman al-Zawahiri, who replaced Osama Bin Laden as head of al-Qaeda.  The BBC's correspondent in Beirut says the Nusra Front does not want to highlight its ties with al-Qaeda in Iraq, as it is trying to win the support of Syrians in rebel-held areas and to keep the goodwill of other opposition groups.   The Nusra Front has said it was responsible for a number of suicide bombings in Syria, and it's been designated by the Americans as a terrorist organisation.

"Tax havens must be eradicated in Europe and worldwide".  French President Francois Hollande has vowed to eradicate tax havens as he pursues anti-corruption efforts in the wake of a tax fraud scandal.  He says  that French banks would be required to declare all of their subsidiaries around the world. He's also  requiring all Cabinet members to  release details of their income and assets for the first time.  Do you agree with Mr.Hollande? What would be the potential impact of eradicating tax havens around the world?

Amnesty International says that death penalty is 'becoming thing of the past'.    The report found that there was progress towards abolishing the death penalty in all regions of the world, despite a number of countries resuming executions after periods of not carrying them out.    Are you for or against the death penalty? Tell us why.

The charity Save the Children says the majority of victims of sexual violence in conflict zones - are children.   The findings are based on data and interviews from several countries including Colombia, Liberia and the Democratic Republic of Congo.  The charity says programmes to stop such violence and help children recover are chronically underfunded.

South Korea has raised its "watch-con" surveillance status amid fears the North is preparing for an imminent missile test.   It's not the first time that North Korea has tested medium range missiles during a period of tension. But sources say the difference now is that this new missile is untested, more powerful, and ready for launch.

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC and on tonight's BBC World News America we'll bring you the incredible story of Dr Larry Hergott, a cardiologist who treats both humans and apes http://bbc.in/ZLHjMH  We'll also take a look at the latest from the Korean peninsula http://bbc.in/ZLHk35 , Kenya's new president http://bbc.in/ZLHk33 and the fence set to seal the border between Yemen and Saudi Arabia http://bbc.in/ZLHk2Z  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and be sure to join the conversation on Twitter - I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/ZLHmbk and all of our North America news and features can be found @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/ZLHmbm

VIDEO:   Meet 'Petman' - a robot designed to replicate the actions of humans and help test chemical protection clothing.   Petman has been built by the Massachusetts robotics company Boston Dynamics with backing from the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

Link Title: BBC World News - Fast Track, Can you trust travel blogs?
Message: Can travel bloggers really give a balanced view when they enjoy travel for free?  Keith Wallace reports on how we are influenced by the blogs we read and asks how independent they can be when the writers are getting their trips for free from travel companies and tourist authorities

Saudi Arabia has denied reports that a court in the kingdom has ordered a punishment of paralysis for a man who caused the paralysis of a friend.  Reports of the sentence sparked widespread condemnation.  Ali al-Khawahir was 14 when he stabbed a friend in the back in the Eastern Province town of al-Ahsa. He has been in prison for 10 years.

Is "carbon aerogel" the lightest material ever made?   Scientists at Zhejiang University in China have developed an ultra-light material known as carbon aerogel. The scientists behind it claim it is the lightest material ever manufactured.  It is so light, that a slender grass known as Setaria can easily bear its weight without bending. Although the material is in a solid state, it contains many internal pores filled with air - explaining its minimal density.

Link Title: India deploys drones to save rhinos
Message: "A "milestone in wildlife protection"  India has deployed aerial drones over Kaziranga National Park in Assam state in a bid to protect endangered one-horned rhinos from poachers.  The park is home to two-thirds of the world's one-horned rhino population and also has a large number of elephants, tigers and other wildlife.  In recent months, rhinos have been killed in large numbers by poachers.

On Saturday, world powers were locked in talks with Iran to try to get it to slow down its nuclear programme. Those talks failed to find a solution, and then today, Iran said it had started production of uranium at a number of sites.   Low-grade uranium ore will be extracted at the Saghand mines and turned into purer uranium, known as yellowcake, at nearby Ardakan.  It can then be enriched - a process which the West wants Iran to curtail.

Link Title: New Kenya president to be sworn in
Message: He's the son of Kenya's founding father, one of the country's richest men and today Uhuru Kenyatta has been sworn in as Kenya's new president. Tens of thousands of people have packed into a sports stadium in Nairobi to watch the ceremony.   Dozens of African leaders and Western diplomats are also there, despite Mr Kenyatta being under indictment at the International Criminal Court.   He denies orchestrating the ethnic violence that followed elections five years ago. President Kenyatta took the oath on a bible used by his father.

It's 50 years since President Kennedy signed America's Equal Pay Act into law. It was a real attempt by lawmakers to close the pay gap between men and women.     You would be forgiven for thinking today that across America today things have dramatically changed, but you would be wrong. According to the latest figures, women on average, earn less than men in every state and region of the country.    Do women get equal pay to men in your country? If not why do you think this is still the case? Tell us where you're from and how you think equal pay could be achieved.     Still courtesy of Abbie Rowe. White House Photographs. John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum, Boston

There's been a surge in demand in China for infant formula produced abroad, because of milk safety scandals.   Following Australia and Hong Kong all of the major supermarket chains in Britain are rationing baby milk powder sales to two packs per customer, to stop people bulk-buying the product and exporting it to China.    Danone, the manufacturer of Aptamil and Cow and Gate baby milk powder, said "We would like to apologise to parents for any inconvenience caused by this limit. We know that most parents only buy one pack at a time, so we hope that the impact of this limit on UK parents will be minimal".

Will tomorrow be a better day for the yen? http://bbc.in/17nxtYR  The Japanese yen has dropped to its lowest level since 2008 against the US dollar after the central bank began the latest round of its stimulus programme.  The yen fell as low as 98.85 against the dollar, before rebounding slightly.

This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the life of Margaret Thatcher http://bbc.in/Y8N1sN and discuss her legacy in the US with former Secretary of State Colin Powell and Reagan's White House Chief of Staff, Kenneth Duberstein.   You can follow along with the world's reaction to Thatcher's passing on our live page  http://bbc.in/Y8MZ44  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area and join the conversation in the comments section below or on Twitter @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/Y8N1sJ or @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Y8N1sP

Margaret Thatcher was a very divisive figure in the UK, but not so across the Atlantic, where her popularity has endured decades after she left office.   Why did the US love her so much? http://bbc.in/Y8AVzR  Americans speak about Margaret Thatcher's legacy from the National Cherry Blossom Festival in Washington DC http://bbc.in/Y8AVzN  Obituary: Baroness Thatcher http://bbc.in/Y8AVzV  Follow our live text and video http://bbc.in/Y8AVzP

Link Title: Serbia rejects EU deal on Kosovo
Message: After months of negotiations brokered by the European Union, Serbia has rejected a deal on normalising ties with its breakaway province of Kosovo.  Kosovo unilaterally declared independence in 2008. While many countries recognise it as an independent country, Serbia does not.  The EU had given Serbia until Tuesday to relinquish its effective control over northern Kosovo in return for the start of EU membership talks.  Serbia must normalise relations with its neighbours before joining the EU.

A force of French soldiers has begun a large operation in northern Mali.   Around 1000 troops, supported by tanks, helicopters, planes and drones are combing a river valley believed to be a logistics base for Islamist militants near the city of Gao.  This is said to be the last major French-led operation before France starts reducing its military presence.  The militants have been driven out of northern cities and towns since France intervened militarily in January.

To accompany today's Running a Business feature we're asking:  How do small companies make social media work for them?  We're being joined by Roger Martin, Dean of the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto.   And we hope to also speak again with Greg and Meredith Tally whose Denver hotel features in the piece.   Please post us your questions between 11 and 1 EST

What will be the legacy of Margaret Thatcher on the international stage?    Thatcher appeared as indomitable abroad as she did at home. She worked closely with the United States in the Cold War battles against the Soviet Union, and challenged her supposed partners in Europe.    Visit our special page for further analysis, videos and radio interviews: Baroness Thatcher 1925-2013    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-22067257

Link Title: Toll rises in Cairo cathedral clash
Message: Security in Egypt has been tightened around the main Coptic Christian cathedral in Cairo following clashes between Christians and Muslims.   Two people have been killed and more than 90 wounded in the violence, which erupted at the weekend after funeral prayers for four Christians who were killed in sectarian violence. Both Christian and Muslim religious leaders have called for calm.

Link Title: Chilean poet Neruda to be exhumed
Message: He was one of South America's intellectual giants - but Chile's Nobel prize winning poet, Pablo Neruda, was also a communist and his long time aide believes that was enough to have him killed in the days after Augusto Pinochet's right wing coup in 1973.    Today a team of forensic scientists have exhumed his body to find out if he was, indeed, poisoned.    He died aged 69 just 12 days after Gen Pinochet's coup against Mr Allende.  The poet's family maintains that he died of advanced prostate cancer

The death has been announced in London of the former British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher.   She was 87, and her spokesman said she had died peacefully following a stroke.   As Britain's first woman prime minister, Margaret Thatcher transformed the British political scene when she came to power in 1979.   She became perhaps the most influential and recognisable British leader of modern times on the international stage.

Link Title: Syria's Damascus rocked by car bomb
Message: Syrian state television is reporting that at least 15 people have been killed in a car bomb attack in Damascus - and dozens of others have been wounded. The blast happened in a busy residential and commercial part of the capital.  The blast caused extensive damage and intense gunfire was heard shortly afterwards, news agency AFP reported.   Meanwhile, the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said on Monday that an inspection team is in Cyprus waiting for permission to enter Syria and investigate reports of chemical weapon attacks during the conflict.

VIDEO: "This country is a secular democracy. So each and every religion has the right to practice their religion freely and fair. But it is not fair to hurt anybody's religious feeling. Always we try to protect every religious sentiment."  These are the words of Bangladeshi PM, Sheikh Hasina, who has rejected demands by the country's Islamists for a new blasphemy law to punish those who defame Islam and the Prophet Muhammad.  Hundreds of thousands of Islamists rallied in the capital Dhaka this weekend asking for tough punishment for  those who insult Islam.   In an exclusive interview for the BBC, Ms Hasina spoke to our Bangladesh correspondent Anbarasan Ethriajan on why a new anti-blasphemy law is not required.

Link Title: Five cities where you can live large, for a little
Message: Paris, Tokyo, Singapore: these cities are so exorbitantly expensive that it's almost impossible to get ahead. But for every pricey destination, there is an urban centre that offers a comparable location and lifestyle for a fraction of the cost. BBC Travel takes a look at some of the best:

Link Title: Kerry in Turkey to boost Israel ties
Message: US Secretary of State John Kerry has arrived in Turkey, where he will hold talks expected to address relations with Israel and the conflict in Syria.  After helping broker a reconciliation between Turkey and Israel, Mr Kerry will urge them to "fully normalise" relations, US officials said.  Turkey is Mr Kerry's first stop of a 10-day trip to Europe and Asia.

The Gulf state of Qatar is hosting a two-day conference on development and reconstruction in Sudan's Darfur region.  The conference is seeking some $7.2bn (£4.7bn) in development aid aimed at making Darfur more self-dependent.  Ahead of the meeting, the UK announced it would contribute at least £33m.  Some 300,000 people are thought to have died during a decade of conflict in Darfur, according to UN estimates. As many as 1.4 million remain homeless.

Link Title: Frank Gardner's return to Saudi Arabia
Message: BBC Security Correspondent Frank Gardner finds Saudi Arabia safer than it was when he shot there nine years ago, and very slightly more tolerant of internal criticism.

The Gulf state of Qatar is hosting a two-day conference on development and reconstruction in Sudan's Darfur region.  The conference is seeking some $7.2bn in development aid aimed at making Darfur more self-dependent.  Ahead of the meeting, the UK announced it would contribute at least £33m.  Some 300,000 people are thought to have died during a decade of conflict in Darfur, according to UN estimates. As many as 1.4 million remain homeless.

The US has delayed an intercontinental ballistic missile test scheduled for next week, defence officials say.  The Minuteman 3 test was put off over concerns it could be misinterpreted by North Korea, amid fears of a conflict.  It could be postponed till May, in what correspondents say will be portrayed by Pyongyang as a victory.

A bomb in Afghanistan's southern Zabul province has killed five Americans - three soldiers and two civilians serving with the Nato-led forces - and an Afghan doctor.  The Nato-led International Security Assistance Force (Isaf) said they were killed when a suicide bomber detonated a car full of explosives.

While many know Amsterdam for its more debaucherous pleasures, residents know it offers far more than the risqué attractions it is famous for. BBC Travel takes a look at what it is like to live and work in this modern European city:

Here is our look at news from around the world for this Saturday:   - Mandela discharged from hospital  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-22052593  - Iran nuclear: positions 'still far apart'  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22050069  - Grand National 2013: Imperial Commander aims for historic win  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22049946  - Wesley Snipes released from prison  http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/22050473  - Mexico memorial for drug war victims  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-22049038  - US plays down North Korea threat  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-22048935  - Furniture 'grows like popcorn'  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22015184  - A funny look at the news - 140 characters at a time  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21977791

Islamist groups in Bangladesh are to hold a rally in the capital, Dhaka, calling for tough curbs on bloggers who insult Islam.  Thousands of activists have staged a "long march" from around the country to take part in the rally.  A 45-year-old man was killed on Friday when some activists clashed with supporters of the ruling Awami League.  Bus and river transport has been halted and groups opposed to the rally have announced a day-long shutdown

Link Title: US plays down North Korea threat
Message: US officials have played down the threat of war on the Korean peninsula, after weeks of bellicose statements from Pyongyang.  A White House spokesman said the US "would not be surprised" if North Korea launched a missile, while a top US military officer said recent threats appeared to fit a familiar pattern.  Pyongyang has threatened to attack both US and South Korean targets.  It has told foreign embassies it cannot guarantee their safety in a conflict.

Link Title: China steps up bird flu precautions
Message: China is stepping up its efforts to contain the spread of a new strain of bird flu which has killed six people in the country.  The authorities in Shanghai, where four deaths were recorded, have closed three poultry markets and banned the import of all live birds into the city.  China has now identified 16 domestic cases of the H7N9 virus.

Malala Yousufzai, the Pakistani school girl shot by the Taliban, is using a fund set up in her name to send 40 girls to school in her native Swat Valley http://bbc.in/17hW9C2  Malala has become known worldwide since the attack on a school bus in October last year. But the two school friends injured with her remain at risk at home.  Orla Guerin went to meet the girls in the Swat Valley, where their identities and location are well known.

Link Title: The rise of China’s secondary cities
Message: China’s smaller cities may not get as much tourist attention as Beijing or Shanghai, but when it comes to business travel they are becoming more prominent. From Wuhan to Chongqing, Chengdu to Hangzhou, second tier cities are emerging as hubs for both international and domestic executives. Learn more on BBC Travel:

Link Title: US economy adds 88,000 jobs in March
Message: What does this morning's jobs report tell us about the US economy? http://bbc.in/Y3fVud  This is Katty Kay in Washington, DC and tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a deeper look at the numbers and what they mean for the global economic recovery.   We'll also take a look at the North Korea's warning to foreign embassies http://bbc.in/Y3fVu5 , the deadly building collapse near Mumbai http://bbc.in/Y3fXlO and the two vacationing US music stars captivating the people of Havana http://bbc.in/Y3fVub  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and join the conversation on Twitter - you can find me @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/Y3fXlM and follow all our North America news @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Y3fVdR

North Korea has told foreign embassies in Pyongyang it cannot guarantee their safety in the event of military conflict, and asked them to consider evacuating their employees http://bbc.in/17hD82y  This comes on the same day that footage has been shown on state television of North Korean President Kim Jong-un watching military drills http://bbc.in/17hD82y  - Threats fail to impress Seoul residents http://bbc.in/17hDaHF - Mobilising the propagandists in North Korea http://bbc.in/17hD82A - North Korea's missile programme http://bbc.in/17hDaHD - Missile defences in the region http://bbc.in/17hD82C - S Korea 'deploys warships to track missiles from North' http://bbc.in/17hDarp

The number of people who have fled from the Central Africa Republic has risen to 37,000 since the start of a rebellion in December, the UN has said.  Most of the refugees have gone to the north of the Democratic Republic of Congo, others to Chad and Cameroon.  President Francois Bozize himself fled to Cameroon when the rebels captured the capital, Bangui.

Officials have rejected nomination papers for Pakistan's ex-military ruler Pervez Musharraf to stand as a candidate in forthcoming polls.  An official in eastern Kasur district made the decision after objections were filed, including charges of violating the constitution and his oath as army chief.  Gen Musharraf has the right to appeal and has also filed nomination papers in three other constituencies.  But this may affect those decisions.

Link Title: Bikers light up runway for night flight
Message: VIDEO: It's a life and death scenario familiar the world over: a mother and baby need emergency attention after complications during birth.   The problem: they're deep in the Amazon and it's night.   Solution: Locals from a small town in Peru illuminate a remote airstrip for an emergency night flight with the headlights of their motorbikes and rickshaws.

The Nigerian president, Goodluck Jonathan, has set up a panel to look into the possibility of granting an amnesty to the Islamist militant group, Boko Haram.   This follows calls from religious and political leaders in Northern Nigeria for an amnesty to end the violence.

Famine early warning systems have a good track record of predicting food shortages but are poor at triggering early action, a report has concluded.  The study said the opportunity for early action was being missed by governments and humanitarian agencies.  It said the "disconnect" was starkly apparent in Somalia where no action was taken despite 11 months of warnings.  Up to 2 million people are estimated to have died in drought-related emergencies since 1970.

At 15GMT on WHYS TV We'll be discussing your reaction to the week of news surrounding North Korea.  What do you think about what's taken place?  Do you think North Korea has been provocative?  Or is it just defending itself?  If you'd like share your views, we'd love to hear them on the show.  To get involved: visit the WHYS uploader page below and record a 30 second clip of yourself via your phone or webcam - and we'll do the rest!  We'll try our best to get them on the show, and we look forward to hearing what you have to say!

Scientists 'read dreams' using brain scans    Interpreting dreams has been important throughout the ages for predicting the future, talking with the dead, even knowing when to go to war.     These days, the sound of someone analysing what they dreamt the night before can be a bit of a nightmare - dream discussions are for many, a boring social nuisance.     But scientists in Japan say they have found a way to accurately 'read' your dreams - well with about 60% accuracy.     Using brain scans, they say they can predict images people were seeing as they entered into the early stages of sleep.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22031074

Rescuers are searching through the rubble for survivors after an unauthorised building collapsed near the Indian city of Mumbai. At least 35 people are reported to have died - including several children.   Police said a section of the seven-storey building collapsed on Thursday evening. It brought down the entire structure. The building was still being built. But it was already partly inhabited. Most victims are reported to be construction workers and their families.

Renowned American film critic Roger Ebert has died at 70 after a long battle with cancer, his newspaper the Chicago Sun-Times has reported http://bbc.in/17fAxWR  Ebert, known for his thumbs-up or down reviews on a series of television shows on films, first became a film critic for the Sun-Times in 1967.

VIDEO:  Oscar winning writer-director Oliver Stone's new book, The Untold History of the United States, and accompanying televised documentary, looks back at events that helped shape America's complex history over the 20th century.  Stone says the aim of his project is to analyse "what America has done wrong, in the hope it can change".

Police in India say a man has gone on a killing rampage with an axe, murdering 4 women and 5 children in the central state of Chhattisgarh.   The district police chief said the 35 year old man attacked his neighbours while apparently mentally disturbed after his wife left him. He was later arrested.

The hacking collective Anonymous has said it has been "hacking" and vandalising social networking profiles linked to North Korea.  The group has issued several warnings since the country's threats have intensified.  Uriminzokkiri, a news site, has been forced offline - while Twitter and Flickr accounts have been breached.  Anonymous also claimed to have accessed 15,000 usernames and passwords from a university database.

Amsterdam's most famous museum is preparing to reopen, after a decade of renovations.   The Rijksmuseum is home to the world's largest collections of works by Rembrandt.   The make-over has cost the Dutch government around 500 million dollars. The building opens to the public on the 13th of April.

The French government is under growing pressure to reveal who knew what about the tax-evading budget minister Jerome Cahuzac who admitted this week he had hidden hundred of thousands of Euros in offshore accounts.   The scandal is threatening to engulf Francois Hollande's government, with fresh allegations today that Mr Hollande's ex-treasurer, who ran his presidential campaign, is a shareholder in two off-shore companies in the Cayman Islands.

Archbishop Desmond Tutu has won the $1.6m philanthropic Templeton Prize for 2013 for "affirming life's spiritual dimension", organisers of the award say.  Organisers said he was awarded the 2013 prize for his lifelong work advancing spiritual principles such as love and forgiveness that have helped to liberate people around the world.  The former Anglican archbishop of Cape Town joins a distinguished group of 42 previous recipients.

Link Title: What is behind Burma's wave of violence?
Message: Following communal riots than killed more than 40 in Burma in March, the BBC's Jonathan Head visits the town where it all began to examine the causes of the violence.

What are the medical risks of being bald?   Men who are bald have a much higher chance of developing coronary heart disease.   That's according to researchers in Japan who studied nearly 37,000 people and found that balding men were 32% more likely to have coronary heart disease.   But it only affects people with certain patterns of hair-loss.

Link Title: US boosts defences amid Korea threat
Message: North Korea leadership has given its army the final approval to launch, what it calls, "merciless" strikes on America.   In response, the Pentagon is sending a missile defence system to the Pacific island of Guam to protect against any nuclear threat.   While few believe North Korea has rockets capable of hitting the American mainland, it is capable of targetting US military bases in the region.   And in recent weeks, has been subject to new UN sanctions for testing a long-range missile and nuclear device.

This is Laura Trevelyan in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we'll be taking a look at three difficult relationships.  Award-winning author Maya Angelou joins us to talk about her new book where she explores the challenges of reconciling with her mother.   We'll have former US Secretary of Defense William Cohen in the studio to discuss the US moving missile defence systems to Guam after North Korea's threats http://bbc.in/17dBejA   And I'll also take you along on my trip to the New York-Pennsylvania border where contrasting approaches to natural gas "fracking" have sparked a wave of "energy envy"  http://bbc.in/17dBdvZ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area and be sure to join us on Twitter - I can be found @LauraTrevelyan http://bbc.in/17dBejC and you can follow our North America stories @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/17dBdw1

Dozens of people have died in the province of Buenos Aires in Argentina after heavy rains caused flash floods http://bbc.in/17dvNku  In La Plata, between 300mm (12in) and 400mm of rain fell in a few hours. At least 35 people were killed there, said provincial governor Daniel Scioli, adding that the city "has never seen anything equal" to it.  At least another six people had died in the city of Buenos Aires on Tuesday.

The US is moving an advanced missile system to the Pacific island of Guam as a precaution following threats by North Korea, the Pentagon has said http://bbc.in/17dsPwy  The Department of Defence said it would deploy the ballistic Terminal High Altitude Area Defense System (Thaad) in the coming weeks.

Link Title: BBC World News - Fast Track, Mozambique, Turning weapons into art
Message: A peace deal in 1992 ended 16 years of civil war in Mozambique and the country has made much progress in economic development and political stability since then.  Rajan Datar went to meet one artist in Maputo whose work symbolises the change in the country.  Gonzales turns old weapons from past conflicts into art and his fans include former US President Bill Clinton.

Today is the 40th anniversary of the first mobile phone conversation.     Martin Cooper, a senior engineer at Motorola, called a rival colleague at another telecoms company and announced he was speaking from "a 'real' cellular telephone".    Today, there are more than 6 billion mobile phones in use worldwide.    Do you remember your first mobile?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22013228

A Spanish court has named King Juan's daughter, Princess Cristina, as a suspect in a corruption case involving her husband.   The case involves allegations that her husband and his former business partner funnelled about $6.4 million in public funds to companies they controlled.   Her husband, Inaki Urdangarin, denies wrongdoing and has not been charged.

BBC Future has launched a video series asking some of the greatest minds to come up with their world-changing ideas. First up is Raspberry Pi's founder Eben Upton on how technology could create a self-employed world. But what's your world-changing idea? http://www.bbc.com/future/columns/world-changing-ideas

What's it like to 'live the story' during a major news event?     Find out what it was like to report on space shuttle's final launch by sending your questions to David Shukman.    He will be doing a special Q&A at 1400GMT today.     You can post your questions right here or you can tweet it to @davidshukmanbbc using the hashtag #AskBBCDavid    Click here for more details  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21954377

INTERACTIVE: If there are 7 new social classes, which one are you?     According to new research of 160,000 people the 3 tier class system has been replaced by a 7 tier system. The survey included questions about house value, cultural activities and what jobs friends do.     Let us know which class you belong to and where you are from.     To use the class calculator just click here www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22000973

Link Title: Chad aided CAR rebels, says Bozize
Message: Ousted Central African Republic leader, Francois Bozize, has accused Chad in a BBC interview of aiding and fighting with rebels that toppled him.  Francois Bozize told the BBC it was "Chadian special forces" who led the final operation of the rebellion on the weekend of 23-24 March.  Chad, which is hosting an emergency regional summit on CAR, has not commented on the allegations.

Jane Henson, who helped design the Muppets with her former husband Jim, has died aged 78 after a long battle with cancer.  The Muppet Show made its TV debut in 1976 and has enjoyed enduring popularity.   Which Muppet Show character is your favourite?

The last crossing point from North Korea into the South has been closed.   It's the latest sign of increasing tensions between the two countries.   The move prevented hundreds of South Korean workers entering a shared industrial complex.   And comes a day after North Korea said it would restart its main nuclear facilities with the aim of strengthening its nuclear forces.  You can find out more about the Kaesong Industrial Complex in our Q&A: Just click this link http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22011178

"The US will defend and protect ourselves and... the republic of Korea" http://bbc.in/XWarl5  Secretary of State John Kerry said the US will defend itself and its "treaty ally" South Korea in the face of North Korean threats during a press conference with his South Korean counterpart Yun Byung-se in Washington, DC today.  Mr Kerry described recent rhetoric from the North Korean government as "unacceptable".  Photo courtesy of BBC's Suzanne Kianpour.
