Can social media activism really make a difference? http://bbc.in/17bv2sf  Millions of Facebook and Twitter users across the globe changed their user profile pictures last week to an equals sign to show their support for same-sex marriage. The BBC's Matt Danzico takes a look at how the picture went viral and what that means for the organization that created the campaign.

What's it like to 'live the story' during a major news event? http://bbc.in/17biAIX  Space shuttle Atlantis was launched into history when it went onto its final mission on the 8th of July 2011. Upon its return, the 30-year space shuttle programme came to a close.   BBC Science editor David Shukman will be taking your questions about covering the Shuttle missions and more in a live Twitter Q&A on Wednesday, 3 April, between 14:00 and 15:00 GMT from his Twitter account @davidshukmanbbc http://bbc.in/17biAIV  Find out more about how you can join the conversation by visiting http://bbc.in/17biAIX or leave your question for David in the comments section below.

Which world famous musician wrote there lyrics?    "I like to spend some time in Mozambique….The sunny sky is aqua blue…And all the couples dancing cheek to cheek….It's very nice to stay a week or two."     Sustainability expert Leo Johnson was always fascinated by development issues and as a young student spent several months in sub Saharan Africa. This included a brief visit to Mozambique during the country's civil war. Here he reflects on the changes after returning 20 years on.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-21945365

"The fairest way of travelling"  Samoa Air is defending its decision to charge passengers according to their weight.   Rather than paying by the seat, travellers will pay a per kilogram charge which also includes their luggage. The airline says it's the fairest way to travel.   What do you think of this? Is it fair to charge passengers according to their weight?

The Cypriot Finance Minister, Michalis Sarris, has resigned, days after his country was forced to accept tough conditions as part of an international bailout.   The deal saved Cyprus from bankruptcy and an exit from the euro.  Mr Sarris was appointed less than a month ago and had faced criticism for his handling of the negotiations with Cyprus's international creditors.    Earlier, Cyprus's president Nicos Anastasiades appointed a panel of judges to investigate the causes of the financial crisis.

Weeks after Europe was shocked by the horsemeat scandal, it seems that the mislabelling of products labelled as beef are not the only foodstuffs that don't contain what they say they do.     It turns out that fish is also affected.      Research in Britain has found that 7% of fish sold as cod and haddock in takeaways, supermarkets and restaurants was actually a different, cheaper species.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21993684

VIDEO:     Scientists have told the BBC that they expect to enter a "new realm of physics" as they begin a major upgrade the Large Hadron Collider.     Their work should double the power of what's already the most powerful particle accelerator in the World.    The BBC's was given exclusive access to the underground tunnels where the repairs are being carried out.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-22002899

Apple has apologised to its Chinese customers. The company has promised to change its policy on repair, monitor its resellers more closely and improve communication with Chinese consumers.  Apple has been under attack for around two weeks - in particular from state-backed media companies in China who accuse the company of being arrogant. But many commentators think that Apple is being singled out because it is a successful western company.

Unemployment in the Eurozone has hit a record 12%.    Official figures show more than 19m people were out of work in February.    The highest rate was 26.4% in Greece, although the most recent figure for the country was from December.

Another day, another development in the war of words between North and South Korea.     The North now says it will restart all nuclear facilities, including the reactor and uranium enrichment plant at its Yongbyon nuclear complex.     That facility has been shut since 2007, as part of an international agreement.    How potent are North Korea's threats?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21999193

Katty Kay here in Washington, DC - tonight on BBC World News America we will be speaking with Thomas Fessy in Mali about the Malian army's search for Islamist rebels in the city of Timbuktu http://bbc.in/XTyIrY  We'll also take a look at the court battle over cancer drug patents in India http://bbc.in/XTyK30 and the growing tensions on the Korean peninsula http://bbc.in/XTyIrW  Check your local listings to find BBC World News where you live and be sure to join us on Twitter - I can be found @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/XTyK2Y and you can keep up with the Washington Bureau @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/XTyIrS

"I always dreamed of getting out." http://bbc.in/179v7wL  Franky Carrillo was just 16 years old when he was convicted of murder. He spent the next 20 years in prison in the US state of California for a crime he did not commit.  Franky is now a student at Loyola Marymount University and living his dream of building a new life. Get to know Franky's story in this week's edition of Big Dreams.

Link Title: Telling the African Story: Komla Dumor at TEDxEuston
Message: Telling the 'African Story'  We wanted to share this video with you.   Here is Focus on Africa's Komla Dumor giving a highly engaging presentation at Ted Talks about some of the challenges facing the media when it comes to covering African stories.  How do you think international media could improve their coverage of Africa? What kind of stories should they cover more of?  Share your thoughts with us.

Prosecutors have said they will seek the death penalty for the man accused of killing 12 people last July at a cinema in the US state of Colorado http://bbc.in/XSVSOZ  On Friday, prosecutors rejected an offer from 25-year-old James Holmes to plead guilty in order to avoid the death penalty.

For decades, the people of Burma have had only had one newspaper on offer. That is until today.   For the first time in 50 years, the state monopoly is over. There are now 16 newspapers with licences to publish.    It's another big step in introducing democratic rights in a country where the military junta had previously oppressed political and civil freedoms.
If you made the world's gold into a cube, how long would the edges be?     Surprisingly, it would probably be no more than 50m, and possibly a lot less.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21969100

Libya's advisor to the PM has been kidnapped. The abduction took place on Sunday on the outskirts of the capital Tripoli.    There have been a series of kidnappings and security threats in the Libyan capital as the central government tries to consolidate its powers over a myriad of militias that formed after the war that toppled Colonel Gaddafi.

Link Title: 10 true stories that could be April Fools
Message: April Fools' Day is a time when mischievous fictional news stories suddenly pop up, but some turn out to be genuine.  Here is a round-up of some of this year's bizarre stories that are true, or seriously intended at least.  Let us which one is your favourite?

Officials in Tanzania say at least 30bodies have been recovered from the ruins of a tower block that was nearing completion when it collapsed on Friday.  So far only 17 people have been found alive in the building in Dar es Salaam. Most of those killed were passers-by or construction workers.   Children at a nearby playground were also among the victims.

Climate change is expanding Antarctica's sea ice, according to a scientific study in the journal Nature Geoscience.  The paradoxical phenomenon is thought to be caused by relatively cold plumes of fresh water derived from melting beneath the Antarctic ice shelves.  This melt water has a relatively low density, so it accumulates in the top layer of the ocean.  The cool surface waters then re-freeze more easily during Autumn and Winter.

Link Title: Foreign tourist raped on Rio minibus
Message: Brazil will be in the global spotlight as the next host of both the World Cup and Olympics, and ensuring public safety will be paramount.    So news that a foreign tourist has been raped and robbed on a minibus in the Brazilian city of Rio de Janeiro will put the focus on how quickly the authorities will respond to such crimes.   The woman was attacked in the presence of her boyfriend, who was handcuffed and badly beaten. Two men, including the vehicle's driver, have been arrested.

Link Title: India to rule on Novartis patent
Message: Supreme Court in India has rejected attempts by the drug maker Novartis to patent its cancer drug, Glivec.   The court rejected the plea on the grounds that the new version was only slightly different from the old.   Glivec, which is used to treat chronic myeloid leukaemia and other cancers, costs about $2,600 a month.  The generic equivalent is currently available in India for just $175.  Charities say the decision will ensure poorer patients around the world continue to get access to cheaper versions of life saving drugs.

India's annual Holi festival marks the end of winter and celebrates the upcoming spring harvest. During the Hindu festival, vividly coloured powder called gulal is thrown onto the singing and dancing crowds, making for a visually spectacular event unlike any other in the world. BBC Travel has the photos: http://bit.ly/1735762

Our news from around the world for this Sunday:  - Pope Francis delivers Easter plea for peace http://bbc.in/XQFDSG - Deadly floods hit Mauritius capital http://bbc.in/XQFE94 - Clashes in Timbuktu  http://bbc.in/XQFBdl - Third US legal official shot dead http://bbc.in/XQFE90 - Tear gas at Brazil World Cup stadium http://bbc.in/XQFBdj - Two men die of bird flu in China http://bbc.in/XQFAX5 - Coldest Easter on record for UK http://bbc.in/XQFBdp - Jordanian king swears in government http://bbc.in/XQFBdv - Cash shortage stretches to sea bed http://bbc.in/XQFDSC - A 140 character look at the funny side of news http://bbc.in/XQFDSE

Link Title: Hunting the humble hot dog in New York City
Message: Where did the modern day hot dog come from? In 1870, a Brooklyn man named Charles Feltman who began his career pushing a pie cart in the seaside neighbourhood of Coney Island had a lightbulb idea. To meet customer demands for a hot sandwich for lunch, he switched from pies to sausages and began forking them onto a roll. BBC Travel has the rest of the hot dog's juicy history:
US photographer Brian Sokol has documented what Syrians fleeing their homes have taken with them as part of a project, supported by the UNHCR, called The Most Important Thing.

Link Title: The speeches written but never given
Message: Daniel Finkelstein, of The Times, on the significance of the speeches that were written but for one reason or another were never given.

Link Title: Hopes fade for Tibet buried miners
Message: The chances of finding survivors following a landslide in Tibet that buried 83 miners are slim, Chinese media report.  Chinese media said the first body had been found - but only 36 hours after the landslip - and that the chances of finding survivors were slim.  The miners' camp, 70km (45 miles) east of Lhasa, was destroyed by thousands of tonnes of rock.  Rescuers have been hampered by freezing weather, altitude sickness and risks of further landslides.
Kenya's Supreme Court is set to announce whether it will uphold the election of Uhuru Kenyatta as president, after a challenge from rival Raila Odinga.

Link Title: N Korea in 'state of war' with South
Message: North Korea says it is entering a "state of war" with South Korea, in its latest escalation of rhetoric against its southern neighbour and the US.

When the 52 Americans held hostage inside the US embassy in Tehran were released in 1981, they agreed to not sue Iran for damages in a US court http://bbc.in/XN9uvl  See how the Oscar-winning film Argo is motivating a Senator from the US state of Georgia to seek compensation for the hostages from embargo fines.

With so many men killed in Rwanda's 1994 genocide, women have been at the forefront of the African country's recovery, taking on new business and political roles. BBC Travel has the stories of the survivors who now work as artisans, entrepreneurs and skilled workers in their quest to build a better life for themselves and future generations:

Laura Trevelyan here in Washington, DC. "Being punk is still a mode of resistance." http://bbc.in/173vNUk  As Mexico's government struggles with corruption, a lengthy drug war and economic inequality, they are seeing increased resistance from Mexico's youth.  Michael Maher reports on the youth movement in the country and its political implications.

"We may simply let the situation slip out of our control and it will slide into a spiral of a vicious circle." http://bbc.in/173mzat  Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has warned of tensions in North Korea slipping out of control, after Pyongyang said it was placing its missile units on stand-by.  KCNA, North Korea's state news agency, quoted Kim Jong-un saying the time had come to "settle accounts" with the US after its stealth bomber flights over the Korean peninsula.
As a growing economy ignites a property boom in Cambodia, the BBC's Jonathan Head speaks to the families forcefully evicted from their homes. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21973412

Just days after returning from exile former President Pervez Musharraf had his bail extended amid chaotic scenes in which a shoe was thrown at him.  It is the first time the ex-military ruler has sat before a court to defend himself against charges of conspiracy to murder and the sacking of judges.

Nelson Mandela is making "steady progress" after a second day in hospital for treatment of a lung infection, South African President Jacob Zuma says.  The office of South African President said that the 94-year-old is "in good spirits" and enjoyed a full breakfast.  Mr Mandela spent 18 days in hospital in December undergoing treatment for a lung infection and gallstones.

Link Title: Bosnia jails Serb for war crimes
Message: A former member of the Bosnian Serb paramilitary force has been jailed for 45 years.   Veselin Vlahovic was convicted of the murders of 31 people, and the rapes of at least 13 women in the Serb occupied areas of Sarajevo in 1992.   The sentence is the longest handed down so far by the Bosnian court.  He was known as the "monster of Grbavica", after the district of Sarajevo where he committed many of his crimes.

At least three people have been killed as a multi-storey building collapsed in Tanzania's commercial capital, Dar es Salaam. Dozens have been reported missing.   The building was under construction and was at least 12 storeys high. Witnesses said there were children playing nearby, and workers inside, when it fell down.

Send us your video comment on North Korea. What do you think is behind the latest threats from Pyongyang? And do they worry you?  Here's the story: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21972936. On World Have Your Say at 1500GMT, we'll speak to people in places named in North Korea's recent statements - including the US, Guam and South Korea.  If you click the link below, you can use your webcam or smartphone to send us your video comment on the story.

Link Title: Louvre is most visited venue of 2012
Message: The Louvre in Paris has topped the list of the most visited art museums of 2012, according to the Art Newspaper.  Survey found 9.7 million people visited the French institute - one million more than 2011.  New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art was the second most-visited venue, with three London museums taking the third, fourth and fifth spots.  The most popular exhibition of the year was a show of Dutch Old Masters at Tokyo's Metropolitan Art Museum.  Which is your favourite art museum and why?

"He is in good hands." http://bbc.in/170Vzsa  South African President Jacob Zuma says Nelson Mandela is responding well to hospital treatment, in an interview with the BBC.   Referring to Mr Mandela by his clan name Madiba, President Zuma said the country "must not panic".

AUDIO/VISUAL SLIDESHOW:    Find out how a lack of Arctic summer sea ice may put the future of polar bears at risk.    Jenny Ross, an American photographer and conservationist - and Andrew Derocher, professor of biological sciences, spoke to the BBC about how climate change is putting the future of polar bears in peril.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21941646

21 medical staff in Bahrain have won their appeal against convictions linked to anti-government protests.    They had been found guilty last November of misdemeanours after treating protesters injured by police clearing a landmark in the capital.  The acquittals were welcomed by observers.  "A year after their trial started, two years after the alleged incidents, these medics have finally been vindicated after being mistreated or tortured in custody," Brian Dooley of Human Rights First told the BBC.

At least 12people have been killed and 20 injured in a mortar attack on Damascus University.  Shells are reported to have struck the university cafeteria. TV pictures show broken glass and blood on the floor.    The rebel Free Syrian Army says it's stepped up an assault on the Syrian capital, after getting fresh supplies of weapons. They say the most intense clashes are in the north east of Damascus.

INTERACTIVE VIDEO:    Use our interactive to find out more about a major breakthrough in science. A team of British scientists have developed a synthetic vaccine which is safer than ones that use live infectious viruses.     Want to find out more? Just click the link below and let our medical correspondent Fergus Walsh explain it all.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-21927454

Banks in Cyprus have re-opened after being closed for almost two weeks.    Billions of euros are reported to have been brought into the country to meet the expected demand for cash. But it's still not business as usual - with strict controls on how much money customers can take out - as well as limits on credit card transactions, and transfers abroad.    The controls will be in place for seven days, but they are likely to last for months.    Meanwhile, take a look at the moment when Tim Willcox found himself in a tense situation on the streets of Nicosia. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21963462

What is your reaction to the news that Oscar Pistorius will be allowed to travel after successfully challenging the terms of his bail?  His lawyers argued that the Olympic and Paralympics star should be allowed to return to his home and to travel.  Mr Pistorius also sought an end to supervision by a probation officer and compulsory drug and alcohol testing.

The government of South Africa says that the former President, Nelson Mandela, has been admitted to hospital with a recurrence of a lung infection.   A statement said Mr Mandela was admitted shortly before midnight local time.   Last December, Mr Mandela , who is 94, spent 18 days in hospital undergoing treatment for a lung infection and gallstones.

Link Title: Cyprus banks to reopen on Thursday
Message: From 0500 GMT we'll be live in Cyprus where banks are due to reopen at midday local time for the first time in nearly two weeks following a controversial bailout deal. But the crisis isn't over - customers will face strict capital controls to prevent a run on the banks. Do you think Cypriots have been unfairly treated? Has the Cypriot financial crisis rocked your trust in banks? Let us know what you think.
The word "ungoogleable" has been removed from a list of new Swedish words after a trademark spat. But what does it mean?

The International Committee of the Red Cross says it is urgently sending a doctor to Guantanamo Bay because of a growing hunger strike among detainees.  A Pentagon spokesman says 31 of 166 detainees are now on hunger strike.  The inmates - many of whom are being held without charge - are angry at the US failure to resolve their fate.

Hi it's Babita here. Has your internet speed slowed down? Slow network speeds are being blamed on what security experts are describing as the biggest cyber attack of its kind in history. Should we be worried and is cyber warfare now the biggest threat to our security? Let us know what you think. That's our top story on Newsday with me and Rico Hizon from 2300GMT on BBC World News. See you on-air.

Take a look at our picture gallery as India celebrates Holi, the festival of colours.   The festival comes at the end of the winter season and marks the beginning of spring.   The biggest celebrations take place in the temples of Vrindavan, a town in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, where, according to legend, the Hindu god Krishna played Holi with his consort Radha.
Hundreds of thousands of electric bikes are sold in Germany and Holland every year, so why have they failed to catch on in the UK?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21786511

Link Title: Q&A: Same-sex marriage in the US
Message: Coming up on World News America:  We'll have the latest as the US Supreme Court reviews whether to strike down a law denying federal benefits to same-sex couples  Check out our Q and A for background information http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21943292  Jonathan Head reports on an extraordinary day in Burma where Aung San Suu Kyi not only attended the country's military parade  she was in the front row. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21950145  And don't miss our report from Berlin as a historic part of the wall section has been removed  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21952436

Billions of locusts are threatening to cause severe food shortages on Madagascar, in the Indian Ocean.     The United Nations food agency says half the island has been infested by huge swarms. It says a three year campaign was needed to control the insects.     More than half the population of 22 million people is at risk.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21955740

We live in an increasingly crowded world - and the traditional boundaries between man and beast are beginning to break down.  It's as true in the forests of Africa as it is in the majestic Rocky Mountains of America -- where communities in Colorado have reported an increase in contact with Black Bears.  A team of researchers have been assigned to track the animals - and the BBC's Paul Adams met up with them. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21890034 All photos by Robert Brown

We've all received unsolicited messages on our private email accounts, we're all regularly advised to keep our private data secure and we've all been warned about so-called phishing scams.    As computers assist us, or even control, more and more aspects of our lives the security surrounding the internet has become even more important.    Now a skirmish between an anti-spam company and a firm it accuses of hosting spamming websites has sparked what experts say is the biggest cyber-attack in history.    It's thought to have been so extreme that it slowed down the internet - you may even have noticed.

The future of the banking industry in Cyprus remains up in the air.   Its second largest bank, Laiki Bank, is set to close whilst the head of the island's largest lender, the Bank of Cyprus, was sacked on Wednesday.  The government is scrambling to open the banks on Thursday after a two week shutdown.

It's really not what you want to happen just 3 years before you host the Olympic Games.  The city of Rio has been forced to close the stadium which will host Athletics at the 2016 Games. Authorities say the roof is unstable and needs to be fixed urgently.    With the upcoming World Cup and the success of London 2012 is Brazil under pressure to be ready in time and deliver?

Link Title: Suu Kyi attends Burma army parade
Message: The Burmese opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, has attended an annual military parade for the first time.   It's yet another sign of her improved ties with the army, since being freed from house arrest. She was seated in the front row as the commander in chief said the military would continue to play a leading role in national politics.   The army is helping police try to contain spreading sectarian violence, which has seen Muslim communities attacked by crowds of Buddhists.

Banks in the country have been shut for more than a week as a controversial bailout was negotiated, which will see depositors take losses.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21940060

Link Title: Indian state bars S Lanka cricketers
Message: The chief minister of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu says she won't allow forthcoming premier league cricket matches to be played there if they involve Sri Lankan players or officials.   In an open letter to India's prime minister, Ms Jayalalitha said the people of Tamil Nadu had been "shocked and angered" by allegations of human rights abuses committed by the Sri Lankan government against the island's Tamil population.   The move comes after weeks of protest in Tamil Nadu against the Sri Lankan authorities.

AUDIO/VISUAL SLIDESHOW:    For more than a decade, US sociologist Cathy Greenblat has been travelling the world studying the treatments offered to people with dementia. Her mother and two of her grandparents all developed the disease - and she wanted to understand more about the condition.    In her book - Love, Loss and Laughter - she tells positive stories of ageing, dementia and end-of-life treatment, across seven countries. Take a look at some of her touching images here, as she explains what she discovered.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-21862859

The Syrian opposition has been given the country's seat at the Arab League summit in Qatar.   The opposition leader, Moaz-al-Khatib, has used the opportunity to call for more international support for the rebels, including US patriot missiles for the north of the country.

In the world's newsroom today we'll be talking about Saudi Arabia's threat to ban Skype, WhatsApp and other encrypted messenger services.   The telecommunications regulator wants to be able to monitor these apps but Saudis have said this will inhibit their communications. Several years ago Saudi Arabia also tried to ban Blackberry's messaging service.  Are you in Saudi Arabia?  Do you use any of these messaging services?  What do you think of this story? Italy's highest criminal court has overturned the acquittal of Amanda Knox and ordered a retrial.   She and her former boyfriend Rafaelle Sollecito served four years in prison for the murder of their flatmate, a British student, Meredith Kercher. The pair were freed in 2011.

"I was a little girl dreaming about space and becoming an astronaut - in the developing world where space was not even part of the lexicon." http://bbc.in/XCEeyU  Born in Colombia and raised in Argentina, Adriana Ocampo always knew she was going to work in space exploration. Looking up into the stars, her dog by her side, she found inspiration. Today she manages Nasa's New Frontiers division, which handles the Juno mission to Jupiter and the New Horizons mission to Pluto.  Get to know Adriana's story in this week's edition of Big Dreams.

Prosecutors in Italy are considering whether to re-try an American woman and her former boyfriend, for the murder of an English student in Perugia.  Prosecutors are arguing that the acquittal of Miss Knox and her former boyfriend Raffaele Sollecito on appeal in October 2011 was flawed.  The pair spent four years in jail for the murder of the 21-year-old student in Perugia in November 2007.  They have both always denied any involvement in the murder.

The man who established and once commanded the rebel Free Syrian Army (FSA) has been badly wounded by an explosion in Deir al-Zour province.  Col Riad al-Asaad had to have a leg amputated after the blast in the town of Mayadeen on Sunday, the FSA said.  Some reports said a bomb exploded near his car; others that a rocket hit it.

British journalist Paul Fauvet came to Mozambique in 1980 just as the country was plunged into a civil war.   He has witnessed every key event since. Here he describes the transformation of his adopted country from revolutionary Marxist state to embracing the market and the exploitation of its resource riches.

At the start of our 'What If' series we challenged the creative types out there to come up with a visualisation of the future both an image and an animation.     We now have our two winners.     Marina Koleva from Bulgaria won the animation competition and  Leonel David Mendes from Portugal won the image competition.    You can see the winning animation as well as some of the other entries by clicking the the link below.    http://bit.ly/whatifresults

The EU has suspended most of the sanctions it imposed on dozens of people close to Robert Mugabe, the president of Zimbabwe, after the country approved a new constitution curbing the president's powers.   The EU said it would lift travel bans and asset freezes imposed on 81 people and 8 organisations.   President Mugabe remains on the sanctions list.  The EU said the referendum had been peaceful, successful and credible.

Mosques have been ransacked and houses destroyed in Burma in the latest outbreak of violence against the Muslim minority.   About 300 people are reported to have attacked a mosque in the town of Oh The Kone, about 80km from Rangoon.  President Thein Sein, opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and the speaker of parliament's lower house on Sunday issued a joint declaration in the face of the deadly communal violence.

Link Title: Deal reached in Cyprus bailout talks
Message: A 10 billion euro bailout deal has been agreed saving the country's banking system from collapse, but almost certainly plunging Cyprus into a deep recession with thousands searching for work.    It's the price Cypriots have been forced to pay for staying in the Euro but is it a price they will come to regret?

Link Title: Vettel apologises to Webber for pass
Message: F1 racing driver Sebastian Vettel has said sorry to his team-mate Mark Webber for ignoring team orders not to overtake him.   The reigning world champion won the Malaysian Grand Prix after ignoring radio instructions not to pass his colleague.   Do you think Vettel should have ignored Red Bull's instructions not overtake, and should teams tell their drivers when they can and cannot challenge for a higher spot?

Link Title: US set for Bagram prison handover
Message: The United States has handed over to Afghanistan the only prison in the country still under American control.    The handover ceremony took place at Bagram prison (now the Parwan detention centre) which has been at the centre of a number of prisoner abuse allegations.

More than 30 years after being stripped, bound and paraded through countless Vietnamese villages, Pete Peterson returned to the country as America's ambassador. While there, he shook the hands of his captors - and began a mission to save the lives of the young by teaching them to swim http://bbc.in/XAenHO  Get to know Pete Peterson and his mission in this story from BBC World Service's William Kremer.

Link Title: A voyage to the bottom of the sea
Message: Only two people have ever been to the deepest spot in the ocean, the Mariana Trench, but if a team of submarine specialists have their way, it could soon become a travel destination like no other. BBC Travel hops aboard a high-tech vessel to take a deep dive into this fledgling form of adventure tourism:
Argentina identifies the remains of a body that washed ashore in Uruguay in 1976 as a "disappeared" victim of that era.
Adam Gopnik considers how an 18th Century chess robot - the mechanical Turk - was more than just an elaborate hoax.

Fighting has broken out again in the Central African Republic's capital, with unconfirmed reports suggesting rebels have taken the vacated palace of President Francois Bozize.  After an overnight lull, gunfire and explosions were reported on Sunday.  Seleka rebels claimed to have seized the president's palace, AFP reported.  The fighters, who have been involved in an on-off rebellion since December, accuse the president of failing to honour a peace deal.

Former Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf has arrived back in Pakistan, ending four years of self-imposed exile and defying death threats.  A protection detail of heavily armed commandos met him after his plane from Dubai touched down in Karachi airport. A mass rally in the city was cancelled.  General Musharraf plans to lead his party in the May general election.

Link Title: Russian exile Berezovsky dies in UK
Message: Exiled Russian tycoon and former Kremlin power-broker Boris Berezovsky has been found dead at his home outside London. A police investigation has been launched into the death of the 67-year-old - a wanted man in Russia, and an opponent of President Vladimir Putin.  A former Kremlin power-broker whose fortunes declined under Mr Putin, Mr Berezovsky emigrated to the UK in 2000.  Thames Valley Police said the death, at a property in Ascot, Berkshire, was being treated as unexplained.

Here is our snapshot of today's news from around the world:  - France confirms death of Islamist commander http://bbc.in/16PzSLK - 'Significant progress' in Cyprus http://bbc.in/16PzSLE - Pope Francis meets his predecessor http://bbc.in/16PzPPU - Obama visits ancient ruins of Petra http://bbc.in/16PzPPY - Snow causes UK travel and power disruption http://bbc.in/16PzT20 - Charges over Brazil nightclub fire http://bbc.in/16PzQ6o - Abu Sayyaf release Australia hostage http://bbc.in/16PzQ6k - BP to buy back $8bn in shares http://bbc.in/16PzSLC - Advert turns air into drinking water http://bbc.in/16PzPQ2 - A funny & 140 character look at this week's news http://bbc.in/16PzPQ0
Visitors to developing countries often want to do something about the poverty they're exposed to. But the mere act of travelling can make a difference. BBC Travel explains how:

Link Title: Cyprus MPs in key bailout talks
Message: MPs in Cyprus have voted to restructure the island's banks - one of several measures to ease a financial crisis that has hit eurozone confidence.  They have also approved a "national solidarity fund" and capital controls to prevent a bank run.  Cyprus needs to raise 5.8bn euros to qualify for a 10bn-euro bailout.  Efforts continue to reach consensus on key issues such as levies on bank deposits before Monday's deadline.

Link Title: The influence of writer Chinua Achebe
Message: "Every African schoolchild basically grew up with Chinua Achebe, every schoolchild read 'Things Fall Apart'" says Bilkisu Labaran, from the BBC's Focus on Africa programme.  What was the influence of the Nigerian writer who was called by many the founding father of African literature in English?   What are some of the memorable quotes from his work you'll always remember?

Has prosperity in Indonesia trickled down?   Indonesia's minimum wage has gone up by 40% in many parts of the country thanks to pressure from increasingly aggressive unions, but businesses say they can't cope.

Link Title: Love letters and kindness may improve mental health
Message: Can love letters to strangers be good for your mental health?  Is being kind to others good for your mental health?  A study published in the journal Emotion reports that performing acts of kindness may help people with social anxiety to feel more positive.

Pakistan's former military ruler Gen Pervez Musharraf is finally coming home in time to stand in elections, due in May.  He left the country in late 2008 and has since been living in self-imposed exile in London.  With arrest warrants issued against him in at least two murder cases, and given his rather dismal electoral prospects, many ask why he is returning at all?

In a report released earlier this month, the World Economic Forum ranked 140 countries in order of their hospitality towards international travellers. A numerical value was assigned to each country, with Iceland claiming the title of 'most welcoming' with a ranking of 6.8 out of 7. BBC Travel has a slideshow of the 10 countries that made it to the top – some of which may surprise you:

US President Barack Obama's Middle East trip headed to Jordan today http://bbc.in/XvSgSU (Photo courtesy of BBC North America editor Mark Mardell)  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at Obama's trip and other news from around the world, including:  - Cyprus crisis: Pressure grows over bailout http://bbc.in/XvSgSO - Burma refugees die in Thailand camp fire http://bbc.in/XvSgSQ - Iraq war: How the year US troops served shaped their fight http://bbc.in/XvSgSS - 50 years since Beatles first album  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/XvSjy1

Katty Kay here in Washington, DC – tonight on BBC World News America we’ll be looking at the 50th anniversary of the release of Please Please Me, the Beatles’ first album http://bbc.in/XvuOFo  We want to hear from you.   What is your favourite song by the Liverpudlian quartet?

At the end of President Obama's trip to Israel, the Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has apologised to Turkey for the loss of life incurred when Israeli troops stormed a Turkish aid ship three years ago.  Turkey and Israel have agreed to normalise relations.

VIDEO:    Could a folding car solve parking problems?    As part of the BBC's What If? season, Theo Leggett has been looking at high-tech solutions to traffic problems, including a car that folds itself to fit in a smaller space.    Click here for the video  http://bit.ly/foldingcar

INTERACTIVE:    How the language of conflict and diplomacy has changed in the 10 years since the Iraq invasion.    What was a "brutal regime" in 2003 became a "sovereign government" by 2004 and a US "partner" by 2011, all embedded in an underlying rhetoric of terms such as "terror", "freedom" and "democracy".    The BBC analysed more than 100 US government statements on Iraq and extracted key phrases that shaped the way the conflict was reported.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21897379

The authorities in Nigeria say that the acclaimed writer Chinua Achebe has died.     Chinua Achebe who was born in 1930 has been called the founding father of African literature in English.     He is most famous for his ground breaking first novel 'Things Fall Apart', which dealt with the impact of colonialism in Africa.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21898664

SEND US YOUR VIDEO COMMENTS:  As Cypriot politicians face a momentous choice, which could determine whether their country goes bust we’re want to hear from you about the ongoing situation on the island.   Are you worried about what is happening there?  Do you have money invested in Cyprus?  What’s your take on the situation?   Just click on the link and join the discussion on World Have Your Say programme at 1500GMT  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-17928844

Link Title: State of emergency in Burmese town
Message: The Burmese authorities have declared a state of emergency in Meiktila and three other townships in central Burma.   The announcement comes after three days of sectarian violence between Buddhists and Muslims in which at least 20 people have been killed.   The president's office said the move would enable the military to restore order in the town of Meiktila where rioting began on Wednesday.

Link Title: China leader Xi begins Russia visit
Message: Xi Jinping has arrived in Russia on the first stop of his maiden overseas tour as president of China.  Mr Xi is set to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin, with the two likely to discuss energy and investment deals.  Speaking ahead of the visit, Mr Xi said the two countries were "most important strategic partners" who spoke a "common language".  He will also visit Tanzania, South Africa and the Republic of Congo on his tour, which continues until 30 March.

Residents of Mumbai, India's thriving commercial capital, are enjoying one of the first public art festivals the city has ever hosted: the Focus Photography Festival. In addition to shows at several Mumbai art galleries, the festival also includes talks and workshops - with events for children as well as aspiring photographers - to bring photography to a wider audience.  See more pictures from the festival here http://bbc.in/16MdhQ2  Photo courtesy of the BBC's Pia Gadkari

BBC News North America editor Mark Mardell sent us this photo earlier today of US President Obama arriving in Ramallah to meet with Mahmoud Abbas http://bbc.in/XsXFtP  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a closer look at Obama's trip and other news from around the world, including:  - The economy in Cyprus http://bbc.in/XsXHlx - Turkey's Kurds: PKK chief calls for ceasefire http://bbc.in/XsXFtT - Maps detail Universe's ancient light http://bbc.in/XsXHlt - Picture This: Bringing Mulligan Home http://bbc.in/XsXFtV  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/XsXFtR

Driverless robotic cars might seem like something from TV and films, but research is under way to see what potential uses they may have.     Click here and check out a car that sees pedestrians and tells them when they can cross the road.    http://bit.ly/carrobot

This image is a map of the oldest light we've ever seen - thought to be the after-glow from the Big Bang billions of years ago.    The European Space Agency released the image today taken from a satellite launched 4 years ago to explore the origins of our universe.    Click the link and find out what it tells us  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21866464

Congress has comfortably passed a large spending bill to keep the US government running until the end of September and avert a temporary shutdown http://bbc.in/16LAaTS  President Barack Obama must now sign the bill, which was passed by a bipartisan vote of 318-109. The bill keeps in place a pay freeze for federal employees.

SEND US YOUR QUESTIONS:    There is still time left for you to send questions to Laura Trevelyan  about her experience of working during Hurricane Sandy, and other major news events.     This is all part of our 'Live the Story' series.    Laura will start answering your questions on her Twitter page @LauraTrevelyan from 1800GMT today.    Tweet your question using the #AskBBCLaura    For more details click this link  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21756202

President Obama has said the Palestinians and Israelis need to restart direct peace talks, despite their disagreements.  At a joint news conference with the Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah, Mr. Obama said Israeli settlement activity did not advance the cause of peace, but that such obstacles should not be an excuse to do nothing.   The Palestinians have made a freeze on Israeli settlements a precondition for restarting talks a stance that Mr Obama once supported.

Link Title: Kurd rebel leader calls Turkey truce
Message: He promised an historic announcement and he did not disappoint.   The leader of Turkey's Kurdish rebels, Abdullah Ocalan, has called a ceasefire, following three decades of fighting.    Ocalan is in a Turkish jail serving a life sentence. The announcement was read out on his behalf at a celebration of the Kurdish new year in Diyarbakir.   It puts an end to a conflict which has claimed more than 40,000 lives in three decades.

VIDEO:   Heading to a supermarket is usually pretty uneventful. But for one man in Australia - his trip was quite the opposite.   He's being hailed as a hero after he resuscitated a two year old girl who had a seizure at the checkout.

Link Title: Gillard survives as Rudd shuns vote
Message: The Australian Prime Minister, Julia Gillard has faced down a revolt within her own Labor Party over her leadership.   In a dramatic day in Australian politics, she called a snap leadership ballot after being challenged to do so by one of her own senior cabinet ministers, Simon Crean.  But in the end no-one stood against her.    Mr Crean said he feared the Labor Party was heading for defeat in a general election in September this year and announced his support for Ms Gillard's rival - the former prime minister Kevin Rudd.    Mr Rudd said he was sticking to a pledge not to seek a return unless he enjoyed the overwhelming backing of colleagues.

Hi it's Babita. On Newsday we're live in Australia where Prime Minister Julia Gillard is expected to make a landmark apology to hundreds of thousands of women who had their babies taken from them after birth and never saw them again.  The babies were forcibly removed from the women, who were mostly unmarried and in their teens. The practice known as 'forced adoptions' lasted over several decades from the 1950's to the 1970's. Will an apology now, after 50 years, make a difference? What do you think?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21872919

Hi it's Babita here: On Newsday we're live in Australia where Prime Minister Julia Gillard is expected to make a landmark apology to hundreds of thousands of women who had their babies taken from them after birth and never saw them again.  The babies were forcibly removed from the women, who were mostly unmarried and in their teens. The practice known as 'forced adoptions' lasted over several decades from the 1950's to the 1970's. Will an apology now, after 50 years, make a difference? What do you think?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21872919
Did the Voyager-1 spacecraft really leave our Solar System? http://bbc.in/XqmxCF  The BBC's Jonathan Amos takes a closer look at the debate.

The president of Cyprus will on Thursday present political leaders with a "Plan B" for funding the country's controversial bailout, state TV says http://bbc.in/16K78nq  Earlier it was announced that banks, which have been shut all week to prevent mass withdrawals, would stay closed until Tuesday.

Actor Harrison Ford joins us tonight on BBC World News America to discuss global conservation. We'll also take a look at US President Obama's trip to Israel http://bbc.in/Xqgf63 the continuing financial crisis in Cyprus http://bbc.in/XqgcXX and the UK is getting closer to three-person IVF http://bbc.in/XqgcXZ  Check you local listings to find BBC World News where you live.   Be sure to join Laura Trevelyan http://bbc.in/Xqgf65 tomorrow at 14:00 EDT (18:00 GMT) for a live Twitter Q&A about covering major news events http://bbc.in/XqgcXV

"A two-year study found 80 percent of US Marines killed might have lived with better torso protection." http://bbc.in/16JTelm  Throughout the war in Iraq the American military faced an enemy whose ability to adapt tactics and weapons proved increasingly deadly. Ten years on from the start of the war we look at how military equipment was enhanced and upgraded in this data visualization video.

Link Title: Live the story: Your questions to Laura Trevelyan
Message: The BBC's Laura Trevelyan reported from New York when Hurricane Sandy battered the city with six metre waves and 130kph winds.   In the first of our 'Live the Story' live Twitter Q & A sessions, Laura will be answering your questions about her experience of working during the super storm, and other major news events.  Tweet your question using the hashtag #AskBBCLaura, she'll be replying at 1800GMT on Thursday 21 March

Link Title: Three-person IVF moves closer in UK
Message: The UK could become the first country to allow babies to be created from three parents.   Tiny amounts of DNA from a third parent would be used to prevent children from being born with potentially fatal diseases.   The government regulator says there is no evidence that this form of IVF is unsafe but are there more important ethical issues?

Fancy a camera that looks like this? The concept came about after BBC Future challenged British design firm Conran to reimagine the digital camera. Find out how it works - and what inspired the designer - here: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130318-radical-camera-goes-back-in-time

The BBC's chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, is in Jerusalem covering Barack Obama's first visit to Israel as US President.   In between lives reports she sent us this behind the scenes look at how the team broadcasts from the field.

Ten years after the US-led invasion of Iraq - how much has changed? We look at the numbers behind the country that is still emerging from conflict. From violence to fridges, electricity production to internet access, we take a look at the direction Iraq is going in. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21752819

Coral reefs cover less than 0.1% of the planet but are home to a quarter of all marine species. And as this video from BBC Future shows, there's perhaps more to them than meets the eye. These colourful ecosystems could be the key to the future of medicine. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130319-underwater-pharmacies

The home of the head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, has been raided by French police.   Investigators are searching for evidence relating to her role in awarding financial compensation to businessman Bernard Tapie in 2008.  Mr Tapie was awarded 400m euros by an arbitration panel - Ms Lagarde denies that she abused her authority when she was French finance minister.

Link Title: UK Budget 2013: George Osborne delivers statement
Message: The UK is one of the world's biggest economies, and, despite not being in the eurozone, it's still being rocked by problems with growth and its credit rating.   Today, Chancellor George Osborne (Britain's finance minister) is delivering his budget speech, setting out what tough decisions the government will take and how they'll affect the UK, Europe and beyond.   The BBC has in depth coverage online, with a live streaming of the speech and up to date analysis.

After a bitter dispute between Nato and the Afghan government a deal has been done on withdrawing US special forces from Wardak province.  The troops and their Afghan counterparts have been accused of murder and intimidation in the area.  The agreement comes as tense negotiations are under way on the withdrawal of all Nato forces by 2014.

It's footage that's shocked many Egyptians - a huge mob in the delta region of Gharbiya lynching, beating and hanging two suspected criminals.  The father of one of the victims said he was powerless to stop the mob as they beat his son to death.  Is this a sign that law and order is still out of control after Egypt's revolution?

Link Title: Voices from Solitary: A Sentence Worse Than Death
Message: Hi, Ros Atkins here.   William Blake is serving a life sentence for murder in New York State and has now spent over 25 years in solitary confinement .   In 1987 he killed a deputy while trying to escape custody. He's written an essay about his experience that has been shared many thousands of times in recent days. It received an Honourable Mention in the Yale Law Journal's Prison Law Writing Contest.   Regardless of your view of solitary, it demands your attention. He says he's received a sentence worse than death.   I wonder if you think he deserves it?  I'll read some of your comments when we discuss this on Global later. (You can also reach me @BBCRosAtkins.)

South Korean officials are investigating a suspected cyber-attack. Computer networks at broadcasters and banks have been paralysed. Staff at three TV stations said their computers crashed and could not be restarted - with screens simply displaying an error message. There's no evidence yet of who or what might be responsible - but initial speculation centres on a hacking attack by North Korea.

"The first time we tried to take the image [of Tintina], it saturated the detector, because we had no idea we'd have something so bright." http://bbc.in/XnWVGn  A rock - dubbed "Tintina" - crushed under the Nasa Curiosity Mars rover's wheels has dazzled mission scientists with its brilliant white colouring.  BBC News Science editor Paul Rincon looks at what this could mean for our understanding of the Red Planet.

Pakistani schoolgirl Malala Yousafzai, who was shot in the head by the Taliban after campaigning for girls' rights to education, has attended her first day at school in the UK http://bbc.in/XnWsUR  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll catch up with Malala and look at other news from around the world, including:  - Baghdad hit by deadly blasts on invasion anniversary http://bbc.in/XnWsUH - Cyprus drops tax plan for small savers http://bbc.in/XnWsUP - Obama set to travel to Middle East  http://bbc.in/XnWsUN -  Bowie album scores first number one in 20 years http://bbc.in/XnWuMi  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/XnWuMn

How well do you know your friends on Facebook? http://bbc.in/16HsVfu  Social media friends are often little more than online acquaintances - Ty Morin from the US state of Connecticut is looking to change that. The photographer has started travelling around the US and beyond to meet all 788 of his Facebook friends face to face and take a photo of each of them.  Get to know Ty in this week's edition of Living Online http://bbc.in/16HsVfu and tell us what you think of his project in the comments section below.

The ICC has welcomed Bosco Ntaganda's surrender to stand trial. Washington says it's consulting with Rwanda and other governments on how to get him to the Hague but, Rwanda's justice minister says it's a matter between the United States and General Ntaganda.   Known as "The Terminator", Gen Ntaganda surrendered on Monday to the US embassy in Rwanda after 7 years on the run.  He denies committing atrocities during the long-running conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The Syrian government and rebel fighters have accused each other of using chemical weapons in a rocket attack in the province of Aleppo.    The Syrian state news agency says 25 people were killed. State television has shown what it says are people suffering the effects of inhaling poison gas.  The rebels have blamed the government.    The head of the international chemical weapons watchdog says there's no independent confirmation of chemical weapons being used in Syria.

With general elections approaching next year India's politicians are increasingly feeling the pressure to get cyber-savvy.    Out of 150 million internet users in India there are 65 million using Facebook and Twitter has an estimated 35 million accounts.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21831185

Seven service personnel have died in an explosion at a military ammunition storage facility in the US state of Nevada, says a Marine Corps spokesman http://bbc.in/16GIEvg  Several others were injured in Monday night's blast during a Marine training exercise at the Hawthorne Army Depot. The injured have been transported to local hospitals for treatment, said the spokesman.

Hi, Ros Atkins here.   Now I'd like to think that those of us who present on BBC World News get along well, but one thing that can cause the occasional amicable difference of opinion is studio temperature. This was especially an issue at our old home in TV Centre where the studio seemed to swing between a sauna and a walk in freezer.   It seems this issue of temperature at work isn't just our pre-occupation. Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer at Facebook, has revealed that Mark Zuckerberg likes to keep the temperature low - like 15 degrees Celsius low! No wonder he wears a hoody all the time.   I'm interested to know how this plays out where you work. You can comment here on get me at twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins. Speak to you on Global later.

Today in the world’s newsroom we’ll be talking to colleagues from the Russian service about the situation in Cyprus.   We’ll also be hearing from the Swahili service about Democratic Republic of Congo war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda handing himself in, but first at 1300 we want to put your questions on Iraq to Edgard Jallad from the BBC’s Arabic service.   What do you want to know about what’s happening there? Post your comments below and don’t forget to let us know where you are.

Link Title: Baghdad hit by deadly car bombs
Message: 10 years on from the start of the US-led invasion of Iraq and a reminder today of the tension and violence that remains.   Car bombs, gunfire and explosions ripped through the capital Baghdad during morning rush hour leaving at least 50 people dead.   The attacks come a decade after the campaign that toppled Saddam Hussein.

Hundreds of thousands of people gather at St Peter's Square in Vatican City for the inauguration Mass that marks the official start of Pope Francis' papacy.  You can watch it live by clicking the link below from 0815gmt

"Now is the time for the Iranian government to take immediate and meaningful steps to reduce tensions and work toward an enduring, long-term settlement of the nuclear issue." http://bbc.in/XlJ6bw  US President Barack Obama has offered Iran a "practical solution" if it truly seeks peaceful nuclear capabilities rather than weapons in a message marking the Persian new year, Nowruz.  Mr Obama urged Iran to take "immediate and meaningful steps" to reduce tension with the international community.

Imagine if you lived in a place so remote that it takes five days of travel by boat to reach the nearest town http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21806193  Now imagine moving to New York City.   On this week's edition of Big Dreams we meet Nilson Tuwe Huni Kui, the son of the traditional chief of the Huni Kiu Kaxinawa tribes in Brazil, as he lives his dream of studying documentary film in the Big Apple, sharing his culture and telling the world about the problems facing his people. Join us tonight on BBC World News America and get to know Nilson http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21806193

Argentina's President says she has asked for the Pope's help in the Falklands dispute.  Christina Fernandez de Kirchner, who's had a difficult relationship with her former Archbishop of Buenos Aires over same sex marriage, asked the new Pope to promote dialogue between her country and the UK.   In a referendum held a week ago, people in the Falkland Islands voted overwhelmingly in favour of remaining a UK overseas territory.  There's been no word yet on how the Pope responded to the appeal.

Link Title: Iraq: The Spies Who Fooled the World
Message: Intelligence from highly-placed sources suggesting that Saddam Hussein did not have weapons of mass destruction was available before the 2003 invasion of Iraq according Panorama programme has learned.  Gen Sir Mike Jackson, then head of the British Army, says, "what appeared to be gold in terms of intelligence turned out to be fool's gold, because it looked like gold, but it wasn't".

Link Title: What if everyone had a car?
Message: There are more than a billion cars in the world today - and in another 40 years there could be four times that.   It's a staggering prospect - especially if you live in a part of the world where there's already traffic gridlock.   As part of our 'What If' season looking at the future, correspondent Theo Leggett and the BBC's team of graphic designers have been looking at how new technology might be able to help.  Have a look at this:

Hi, Ros Atkins here.   If you thought Wales v England rugby game at the weekend was a mismatch, you ain't seen nothing yet. On today's Global, I'm going to be taking on Magnus Carlsen, rated by some as the greatest chess player ever.     For the record, I played in a few Cubs tournaments when I was 10 (cubs being the younger version of the Scouts).     To be frank, I'm looking for some help, in fact quite a lot of it.   The item will probably be 5 minutes long, so I need some aggressive openings if I'm to make any headway. If you're a keen chess player, your tips please!     You can leave them there or get me over at twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins. Wish me luck.

The news that all bank accounts in Cyprus will face a tax of up to 10% has been met with shock and anger, and its not just Cypriots who are affected, half of the accounts affected are held by foreigners, many of them Russian.  Below you can read our analysis of the international bailout negotiated for Cyprus and its controversial levy on bank deposits.

Link Title: Deadly car bomb in Somali capital
Message: Reports from Somalia say at least 10 people have been killed in a car bomb in the capital Mogadishu in what appears to be one of the worst attacks in recent months.    Witnesses on the scene say a minibus and several road side shops were caught in the blast.

At least four people have been killed and 29 injured in a suspected suicide attack on a court and prison complex in the Pakistani city of Peshawar.  Two attackers were intercepted by police - one was killed in crossfire and the other blew himself up near a crowded courtroom, police said.  It is unclear if the target was the court or the jail next door.

One of France's best-known criminal lawyers, Olivier Metzner, has been found dead.  His body was found floating off his private island in Brittany.  A note was found at his home and an investigation has been opened, with police treating the case as suicide.  He made his name in a series of high-profile cases, defending the rogue trader Jerome Kerviel, former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, and Vivendi chief Jean-Marie Messier.

Link Title: Hovering leprechaun on St Patrick's Day
Message: VIDEO:   Find out how millions of people around the world are celebrating St Patrick's Day.  70 iconic world landmarks are turning green in honour of the patron saint of Ireland.

Fried food might be bad for your waistline, but it's proving good for the environment in one way: Dutch airline KLM has started using an eco-friendly fuel mix of 25% cooking oil and 75% jet fuel on some transatlantic flights between New York and Amsterdam. The leftover oil comes from restaurants in the southern US state of Louisiana, where it is used to fry up cracklins, catfish and other Cajun treats before being refined at a plant near Baton Rouge and trucked to New York to fuel the flights. BBC Travel has the full story on this advance in eco-tourism:

Five men have confessed in India to gang-raping a Swiss woman as she camped with her husband in the central state of Madhya Pradesh, police say.  The couple were camping at a village in Datia district on Friday during a cycling trip when they were attacked by a group of men.  The assailants overpowered the husband before gang-raping his wife and they were robbed of their valuables.

The Iraq war was long, bloody and unpopular. For 10 years, movie and television directors have struggled to portray the men and women who fought the battles. How have the war films of our time evolved?

"No-one will be able to harm democracy in future," were the words by Pakistan's PM Raja Pervez Ashraf.   He has hailed as "a victory" for democracy the completion of a full term by an elected government for the first time in the country's history.  An interim government will now be installed until the next election, which is expected to be held in May.  Since Pakistan was founded in 1947, government were often overthrown in coups, toppled by political infighting or end in assassinations or murders.

Link Title: World records boost for Middle East
Message: Dubai boasts the world's tallest tower, the world's largest indoor ski slope and will soon be home to the world's biggest Ferris wheel.  But besides landmark buildings there has also been a boom in Middle East record attempts - something that has prompted Guinness World Records to open an office there.  Many are being attempted by companies - but why bother? And to be a record breaker, is dedication really all you need? Or are deep pockets a necessity too?

Link Title: Shock in Cyprus over bailout levy
Message: People in Cyprus reacted with shock to news of a one-off levy of up to 10% on savings as part of the 10bn-euro bailout agreed in Brussels.  Savers could be seen queuing at cash machines amid resentment at the charge.  The deal reached with euro partners and the IMF marks a radical departure from previous international aid packages.  President Nicos Anastasiades defended it as a "painful" step, taken to avoid a disorderly bankruptcy.

From a town in Florida that caters to the off-season circus community to a Shanghai suburb that's a dead ringer for an English village, BBC Travel has rounded up the world's most unusual towns. Take a look at them here:
Kenyan Prime Minister Raila Odinga files an appeal against his narrow election defeat in the presidential election, accusing election officials of fraud.
