Link Title: Phages may be key in bacteria battle
Message: Are bacteria-munching viruses the answer to antibiotic resistance?   At the Eliava Institute in Tbilisi, Georgia, patients are treated for all kinds of bacterial infections with viruses called phages. Phage therapy is common in countries of the former USSR.   In most places in the world antibiotics are given for these infections. But now that more and more bacteria have become dangerously resistant to antibiotics, will phage therapy catch on worldwide?

In Argentina's capital city of Buenos Aires, one only needs to gaze skyward for a history lesson. The many Europeans who immigrated here in the late 1800s fused Baroque, Art Nouveau and Beaux Arts styles to create an eclectic, cosmopolitan and unique architectural landscape. But a lack of awareness coupled with a tumultuous economic and political history means few efforts have been made to preserve the city's architecture. BBC Travel has the story on the people and groups committed to changing that:

On tonight's BBC World News America we'll travel to Iceland to meet teams of wounded soldiers as they train to participate in a race across Antarctica http://bbc.in/Xdsse8  We'll also look at other news from around the world, including:  - Arming Syria's rebels http://bbc.in/Xdst1P -  US plans to beef up missile defences http://bbc.in/Xdsse0 - Vatican denies Dirty War allegations http://bbc.in/Xdst1J - 'Black Death pit' unearthed http://bbc.in/Xdsti7 - Get to know Davy ... Davy Crockett  http://bbc.in/Xdst1L  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Xdssea

The Pentagon is expected to announce plans to boost missile defences on the US West Coast to counter the threat from North Korea http://bbc.in/16xEJ47  The US plans to add 14 interceptors, which can shoot down missiles in flight, to those already in place in California and Alaska, officials say.

Link Title: Viewpoint: Violent backdrop for crucial Pakistan elections
Message: Pakistan is gearing up for the most critical elections in its history amid an orgy of killings, writes journalist and author Ahmed Rashid.  An average of 10 to 20 people a day are being killed in the major cities - Karachi, Quetta, Lahore and Peshawar - as the country is gripped by violence. On a bad day as many as 100 people can be killed by suicide or car bombs.

Now it's two years since the Syrian revolution began, mirroring the uprisings that swept across North Africa earlier.   The protests not only produced memorable images of revolt, they also inspired an explosion of revolutionary rap that introduced local hiphop artists to the world.   Now those Middle Eastern and African rappers have taken their show on the road packing out a New York concert hall even though they weren't rapping in English - take a look.

New research in France suggests that treating the virus which causes AIDS very early can provide what's called a "functional cure" for some people.   Until now, patients with HIV have been warned that they'll need to take medication for the rest of their lives.   But now it seems that around one in ten patients who get treatment early enough, can eventually give up their medication, without the virus returning.

A Zimbabwean politician,Sten Zvorwadza, has been attacked in the capital, Harare, during the last day of campaigning before a referendum on a new constitution.   It's the first vote in the country since the violent elections of 2008. And, it could pave the way for the 89 year old president Robert Mugabe, to remain in power for another ten years.

VIDEO:  Entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley are increasingly choosing to live communally in 'start-up houses' where you can get connections and access to workshops and investors.  Alastair Leithead visited the Blackbox Mansion in Silicon Valley for What If?, our special series looking into the future.  http://bit.ly/livingtech

He started his career as a manual labourer and is now in charge of the world's second largest economy.     Li Keqiang has been named China's new premier. But his meteoric rise to power has not been without controversy.     As provincial governor of Henan his tenure was marked by a series of incidents that earned him a reputation for "bad luck".     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-21796641

Are historical films accurate?  Last month's Oscars saw historical films do particularly well - Lincoln, Argo and Zero Dark Thirty are all based on true stories.   Directors will argue there has to be some poetic licence to sell their films but many would disagree.   Best Picture winner Argo was widely criticised over its portrayal of British inaction in the 1979 Iran hostage crisis. And this week Iran expressed its anger with the film's representation of events, reportedly mounting a legal case against Hollywood.   What do you think? Should directors be obligated to keep to historical accuracy or should they be given 'licence to sell their film'?  Let us know and we'll put some of your comments to our guests on GMT programme at 1230gmt  Is Lincoln historically accurate? http://www.huffingtonpost.com/quora/how-historically-accurate_b_2198656.html

Join BBC Middle East editor Jeremy Bowen today for a live Twitter chat.    Jeremy will take your questions about the current situation in Syria, the impact both the conflict and the UN Security Council sanctions have had, and what the future is for both the Assad regime and the people of Syria.    He will answer your questions directly from his Twitter account @BowenBBC today between 12:00 and 13:00 GMT.     Tweet your question using the #AskBBCJeremy    For full details of how to participate please click the link below.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21773676

A new and controversial frontier in mining is opening up as a British firm joins a growing rush to exploit minerals in the depths of the oceans http://bbc.in/16vf77X  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at the environmental concerns and other news from around the world, including:  - Pope Francis speaks to the Church on first full day http://bbc.in/16vf77T - Xi Jinping named president of China http://bbc.in/16vf5gc - LHC cements Higgs boson identification http://bbc.in/16vf5wC - Rappers and the Arab Spring  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/16vf5gg

"Google's rise is a mirror to Apple's decline." http://bbc.in/16v7K03  Seismic shifts are taking place in how investors view two of the biggest names in technology. While Apple has given little away about where its future profits will come from -  the Google camp appears to be brimming with ideas for products that could turn into money-spinners in years to come.    We want to hear from you. What do you expect the future to look like for these two companies?

Happy Birthday, Sir Michael Caine.  One of Britain's most respected actors was born 80 years ago today http://bbc.in/XaGKw9  Talking Movies brings together some of Sir Michael's observations and reflections on a career that has included more than 100 films, two Oscars and widespread acclaim from fans and critics around the world.

Link Title: SA concern over girls' high HIV rate
Message: At least 28% of South African schoolgirls are HIV positive compared to 4% of boys because "sugar daddies" exploit them, the health minister has said.  Aaron Motsoaledi said 94,000 schoolgirls also fell pregnant in 2011, and 77,000 had abortions at state facilities, The Sowetan newspaper reports.  About 10% of South Africans are living with HIV, official statistics show.  South Africa has run the world's largest anti-retroviral (ARV) programme since President Jacob Zuma appointed him health minister in 2009.

Link Title: BBC World News announcing white smoke!
Message: Pope Francis is well into his first full day as leader of the world's 1.2bn Catholics.   The first Latin American Pontiff ever is leading cardinals in mass at the Sistine Chapel. Catholics will be paying close attention to the sermon which may provide insight into Pope Francis' priorities for the Catholic church.  Relive the moment when Jon Sopel announced that white smoke was coming out of chimney above the Sistine Chapel http://www.vizibee.com/?video_id=567  Pope Francis celebrates Mass in Romehttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21786224  In pictures: Pope Francis's first day at work http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21789029  BBC News website readers reaction http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21784082

Physicists at the Large Hadron Collider in Switzerland say there's strong evidence that the subatomic particle they detected last summer IS a Higgs Boson.     It's sometimes referred to as the God Particle and until now, its existence has been purely theoretical. The elusive particle would explain why matter has mass - a cornerstone of physics.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21785205

Have you ever wondered what is it like to report on a major news event?     In order to bring you closer to the heart of BBC News reporting, over the next several weeks, our journalist will be explaining what it was like for them to 'Live The Story'.     The BBC's New York correspondent Laura Trevelyan has reported on Hurricane Sandy, 2012 Newtown school shooting in Connecticut and the Haiti earthquake in 2010. She will be explaining what were some of the main challenges she faced while trying to get to the heart of the story.    For a preview take a look at this clip. Just click http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-21600986

Why are Nepalis still waiting for justice, more than six years after the end of their country's brutal civil war? Joanna Jolly finds out why the scars from the conflict are still raw despite attempts by both sides to bury the past. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-21759384

Israel finally has a government, 2 months after the country's elections in January.   Likud, the party of Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu, says that after weeks of negotiations it's now forming a coalition with 3 smaller centrist and right-wing parties.   The new government is expected to take office early next week.

Link Title: Xi Jinping set for China presidency
Message: China's once in a decade handover of power is nearly complete.   Country's parliament, which only meets once a year, has now formally confirmed Xi Jinping as President.   Mr Xi assumes the leadership of a nation that is growing wealthier but more vocal in its anger at issues such as rising inequality, environmental damage and food safety.   He was already leader of the Communist Party.

Link Title: Khmer Rouge chief Ieng Sary dies
Message: Former senior Khmer Rouge leader Ieng Sary has died.  The 87-year-old was on trial for genocide committed under the 1975-79 Maoist regime at the time of his death.  He and three co-defendants were accused of leading a campaign of mass murder in which up to two million people died.

Link Title: Science behind the Vatican’s smoke signal explained
Message: How does the Vatican generate the white and black smoke it uses to signal decisions in the Papal election?   Look at the recipes used to signal the announcement of a new Pope, and you’ll find they are essentially making smoke bombs.

Coming up on World News America:    - The latest from the Vatican on the papal conclave http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21758339    - Wyre Davies reports from Syria as a report by Save the Children highlights the scale of the issue facing Syrians affected by the conflict. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21766971    - A report from the Atacama desert as the ALMA telescope is switched on. Its expected to peer deeper into space than ever before. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21774448

Argentina's Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio, a Jesuit, is announced as the Roman Catholic Church's new Pope, to be named Francis I.     He is the first pope to hail from from the Americas and the first from outside Europe in over a thousand years.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21777494

Parkinson's disease affects coordination, makes movement slower and less controlled, and gives sufferers difficulties with balance and walking.     So you might think that ballet would be last thing to which patients are suited to?     But now the weekly Dance for Parkinson's classes are being run by the English National Ballet as expressive art forms might offer new hope.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-21682196
BREAKING: White smoke is emerging from the Sistine Chapel chimney in Rome, indicating a new pope has been chosen   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21758339

Scientists in Tanzania have turned an iPhone into an amateur microscope to check schoolchildren for intestinal worms.  They attached an $8 ball lens to the handset camera lens, and used a cheap torch and double-sided tape to create an improvised microscope.  Pictures were then taken of stool samples placed on lab slides, wrapped in cellophane and taped to the phone.  They were studied for the presence of eggs, the main symptom of the parasites.

Link Title: Deadly shootings in upstate New York
Message: Four people have been shot dead in two shootings in two villages in upstate New York, US police say.  Schools in the region are on lockdown as the police hunt for a suspect, local media report.  Two other people were wounded in the shootings which took place in the villages of Herkimer and Mohawk.

Cardinals from all over the world are behind closed doors in the Sistine chapel to select one from among them. So far we have had only black smoke indicating that their ballots had been inconclusive http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21758339. We wanted to show you what goes on behind the scenes during such a major news event. Many of our journalists have been sharing their photos with us in this gallery.

Link Title: Battle for the R G Mugabe fashion label
Message: The firm behind a fashion label showing the signature of Robert Mugabe is at the centre of a dispute over the brand with the Zimbabwe president's own party as the country heads towards elections, writes the BBC's Brian Hungwe.

Hi, Ros here getting ready for Global (I'll be in London, Jon Sopel's in Rome for all the latest on the conclave).   Now, I've a few questions for you.  1) Is it rude to ignore voice-mails, or just out-of-date to leave them?  2) Is it lazy and even impolite to asking someone for information you can easily get from a web search?  3) Do we need to send emails saying 'thanks'?   Inspired by this great Nick Bilton article, and the huge response to it, I'm going to be discussing digital etiquette at around 1545GMT (give or take, depending on what happens in Vatican City).  TBH, I'm shocked by question number 3. I send loads of them! Please leave comments here or get me on twitter @BBCRosAtkins. Please don't be offended if I can't respond to all of them...

Nigeria's government has pardoned a key ally of President Jonathan Goodluck Jonathan who was convicted of stealing millions of dollars.  Opposition activists said the decision is a major blow to efforts to curb corruption in Nigeria.  Ex-Bayelsa state Governor Diepreye Alamieyeseigha was released in 2007, two days after receiving a two-year sentence.

Link Title: Five killed in Kashmir gun attack
Message: At least five paramilitary soldiers are killed as gunmen open fire on security forces near a school in Srinagar in Indian-administered Kashmir, police say.

The BBC's Joan Soley recently travelled with Chuck Hagel, the new US Secretary of Defense, on his first foreign trip as head of the Pentagon. Here are some of her photos from the trip http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21722383

Cardinals of the Catholic Church did not elect a new pope on their first day in the Vatican conclave. Black smoke rising from a chimney above the Sistine Chapel indicated that their ballot had been inconclusive http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21764446 The BBC's Michael Hirst spent the day St Peter's Square taking in the scene and meeting people from around the world who are waiting to see who will be the next leader of the Catholic church. He shares some of his photos with us in this photo gallery. Be sure to follow Michael on Twitter throughout the conclave http://Twitter.com/hirstmike

"We have found a habitable environment that is so benign and supportive of life, that probably if this water was around and you had been there, you would have been able to drink it" http://bbc.in/16pzfZ4  Nasa's Curiosity rover has made another discovery on Mars - after studying a powdered sample drilled from a fine-grained rock, scientists say the stone was likely formed in or altered by water.
Can Barcelona avoid Champions League exit?   Andres Iniesta says they must treat their game with AC Milan like a final if they are to progress.

Link Title: SA dragging case police denied bail
Message: A South African court has refused to give bail to 9 policemen charged with the murder of a Mozambican taxi driver who was dragged behind a police van.  The incident, recorded on video by a bystander, caused widespread revulsion.  President Jacob Zuma called it "horrific" and "unacceptable" while police chief Riah Phiyega ordered the suspension of the accused officers.

This picture of BBC video editor Jehad Mashhrawi cradling the corpse of his baby son Omar became one of the most heartbreaking images of last November's short war in Gaza.   At the time human rights groups blamed the deaths on an Israeli air strike but now a UN Agency says his home may have been hit by a misfired Palestinian rocket.   Mr. Mashhrawi has dismissed the UN findings as "rubbish".

A leading US expert on missile defence has raised serious doubts about the success rate of Israel's Iron Dome  system during last year's Gaza conflict.  The success of the Iron Dome was one of the most significant military aspects of Israel's brief campaign.   The Iron Dome missile defence system - built by the Israeli company, Rafael, but largely funded by the US - was rushed into service to defend against the Palestinian missile threat.

Papal Conclave is due to get underway in a few hours time. For complete coverage of the process to elect the new Pope make sure to visit our special page http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21701046    Also, a historic palazzo in Rome that houses a key Vatican department is also the home of what claims to be the "the number one gay sauna in Italy". http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21753860    Find out about 10 lesser-known facts about the conclave http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21514787

Here's the kind of referendum result you very rarely hear these days. 1,500 votes to 3.   Just 3 people, somewhere on the Falklands Islands voted against keeping their status as a British overseas territory.   Argentina has long claimed the South Atlantic islands, which it calls the Malvinas as its own.  UK Prime Minister David Cameron has called on Argentina to respect the wishes of Falkland Islanders to remain a British overseas territory.

Today on Impact we discuss different parenting methods - inspired by the manual  'French Parents Don't Give in'.     Its advice includes showing your children you have a life apart from them, keeping them out of your bedroom at night, and not hot-housing them academically.     What do you think? Mishal

What are some of the weird and wonderful things you 'like' on Facebook? What does it say about?    Well, it turns out that what you choose to "like" on Facebook says more about you than you might think. Researchers at Cambridge University have used algorithms to predict many different personal details with a high level of accuracy (click the link for more).    But the researchers warned that the digital profiles people are creating also threaten privacy.    Are you worried that your details are being used in an underhand way?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-21699305

A woman has been jailed for 10 years for laundering about $860m in Hong Kong.  Lam Meiling, 61, made almost 40,000 bank transfers between 2002 and 2005.  She said the money came from a factory owner from her hometown in Dongguan, and that her job was to transfer the money to other factory owners in mainland China.  She was arrested in 2008 after two of her bank accounts were investigated.

Can a business be too successful? http://bbc.in/16nhGJb  The BBC's Kate Dailey looks at a San Francisco-based fashion label that struggled to fill orders after being featured in a popular US web magazine.   Would their new customers wait for "the greatest hoodie ever made"?

"You just try not to panic and hope there's some luck with you." http://bbc.in/16nfIs6  Climber and safety consultant Mark Roberts, 47, was wearing a head camera while climbing Snowdon in Wales - he lost his grip and fell 100ft (30m) down a gully. Ride along with Mark's fall in this video.   He was airlifted to hospital with ankle injuries but was not seriously hurt.

A court has blocked a ban on the sale of large sugary drinks - including soda - from restaurants in New York City, a day before the law was to take effect http://bbc.in/16mFP2o  Judge Milton Tingling ruled that the measure was "arbitrary and capricious", after industry groups sued the city.

Jonathan Kathrein was surfing on the California coast when he was attacked by a great white shark. The high school student battled to free his leg from the 12ft fish's jaws as it dragged him underwater http://bbc.in/X07K1d  Today, Mr Kathrein is fighting to save the same fish that nearly took his life.  In this week's edition of Big Dreams we meet Mr Kathrein and learn about  the threat to sharks around the world.

Thousands of South Korean and US troops are taking part in joint military exercises, against a background of rising tensions with North Korea.     The exercises take place every year, but this time the situation with North Korea is especially difficult.     Last week, Pyongyang said it would tear up the armistice which ended the Korean War 60 years ago.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21737859

When the BBC discovered evidence of a massacre at a village just outside the central Syrian city of Homs in January, those on both sides of the conflict blamed each other for the atrocity. What really happened? Click on the link to find out what the BBC team found and what military and forensic experts have discovered from the satellite imagery and video footage. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21291714

Link Title: Why the world’s most enduring designs always evolve
Message: BBC Future begins a new four-week series called Imagineering - where top designers rethink everyday objects. To set the scene, Jonathan Glancey looks at how great design always evolves, and the firm which set the tone for many of Apple's designs presents a smart mask that maps air pollution.  http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130307-smart-mask-maps-polluted-streets

South African athlete Oscar Pistorius, accused of killing his girlfriend, may be "on the verge of suicide", a close family friend has told the BBC.  The sportsman was a "broken man" after rising legal costs forced him to sell his belongings, Mike Azzie said.  Mr Pistorius, who is on trial for shooting model Reeva Steenkamp at his home last month, denies the charges of premeditated murder, saying he mistook her for an intruder.

CONCLAVE VIRTUAL GUIDE -Step inside the virtual Sistine Chapel to find out how the next Pope is elected.     The decision will be taken behind closed doors in a chapel swept for electronic bugs. By tradition the news will be transmitted by smoke signal, from a special stove.     The conclave of cardinals starts on Tuesday when they will begin the process of electing the next leader of the world's 1.2 billion Catholics.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21631398

The man accused of leading the gang rape of a student on a Delhi bus has been found dead in his prison cell.  Ram Singh was a bus driver. The student was allegedly lured onto his bus with a friend, before being subjected to a horrific attack. The brutality of the case triggered outrage and mass protests across India.   Police say Ram Singh hanged himself. But his parents refuse to believe it. They say their son was assaulted in prison. A post-mortem examination will be held later on Monday.

Link Title: The winter treasures of Russia's Lake Baikal
Message: Russia's Lake Baikal is the deepest in the world – it has a volume more than all five of the North American Great Lakes combined. Due to geological activity, the lake's floor drops a little every year - and the water is so clear you can often see object 40m beneath the surface. See photos of the lake – and the stunning wildlife it supports – on BBC Travel:

Link Title: Hiking in the landslide capital of the world
Message: Thanks to its lush scenery and challenging trails, Taiwan's Yushan National Park is immensely popular with hikers. But due to the country’s high rates of tectonic uplift, weak rocks, steep slopes, frequent earthquakes and extreme rainfall, this region is extremely prone to landslides. BBC Travel talks to one of the park rangers who knows this terrain intimately - and makes it his job to evaluate whether it's safe for travellers to tread here:

Scientists think they've figured out how much ice is in Antarctica.  A detailed analysis of 50 years of data reveals more:  http://bbc.in/16ewwBx  If it was all converted to liquid water, it would be enough to raise the height of the world's oceans by 58 metres (193 feet).

For some unhappy couples, the process of divorcing can seem to drag on interminably. Not so in the Netherlands, where a chain of "divorce hotels" offer splitting pairs the chance to check in married - and check out, three days later, as singles. BBC Travel has the full story on this novel concept:

Roman Catholic cardinals will begin electing a new pope on Tuesday 12 March, according to a statement released in Rome http://bbc.in/16ed0oQ  The announcement came after 115 cardinals gathered at the Vatican for talks and prayers.

‘Changing Fortunes’, our TV and online series, continues this weekend.    To be wealthy is to be mobile. And with so many international super wealthy now able to move around the globe at will, certain destinations are proving a magnet.     The super wealthy are becoming more and more transient, drawn to global megacities such as London and New York. We ask new London residents like Zhu Mingming why.     The episode analyses the attraction of London, fast becoming the number one city for the itinerant mega-rich, and its up-and-coming rivals such as Miami.    Watch ‘Wealth Without Borders’, the latest episode of Changing Fortunes this weekend on TV and online:    http://www.bbc.com/changingfortunes

It was originally intended to be a state funeral but as world leaders gather to pay their respects to Hugo Chavez a change of plan.     Nicolas Maduro, the man who'll later be sworn in as acting president, announced the Venezuelan people 'would always have Mr Chavez' and instead of being buried the Socialist leader would be embalmed "like Lenin and Mao Zedong" and placed on public display.     Cuba's Raul Castro is just one of many leaders to salute the late President. He's joined by more than 30 heads of state including Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21709922

For latest news from Latin America make sure to follow our colleagues at BBC Mundo.   At present they have the latest news and pictures from Caracas as Venezuela prepares for the funeral of Hugo Chavez.

Stargazers are in a state of high excitement as they track a comet heading for a close encounter with our own planet.     The comet, elegantly called -- C 2011 L4 Pan-Starrs -- should be visible with binoculars or a telescope in the northern hemisphere tonight.     In upcoming days it should be visible to the naked eye.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21701641

She's been the first lady of Afghanistan for a decade. But in a rare interview for International Women's Day, with the BBC, Zinat  Karzai, has defended her low public profile, citing security constraints and Afghan cultural sensitivities.   Mrs Karzai is a qualified doctor who's been dubbed the invisible first lady. Yet women make up more than 27% of both the lower and upper houses of the Afghan Parliament, doing better than Britain, France, and the United States.   So what are these cultural sensitivities?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21699353

Would everything be better if women ruled the world?    How different would the world be if women dominated the top positions of global power?      Dee Dee Myers was the first female White House Press Secretary and has seen the workings of the political machine from the inside.     She’s been talking to former US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, former Irish president Mary Robinson, IMF Chief Christine Lagarde and the United States Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano about how the world would change if more women follow in their footsteps of power.     http://bit.ly/womenwhatif

It's not quite counting grains of sand in the Sahara but it’s still one heck of a challenge. Scientists think they've calculated how much ice there is in the Antarctic. The British Antarctic Survey has concluded there's more than was previously thought and that makes it more vulnerable to rising temperatures. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21692423

India is still an extremely conservative country, where women are often afraid to discuss their sexuality in the open.   But for the past 10 years, one play has been trying to challenge those taboos.   The Indian version of the worldwide show, the Vagina Monologues discusses issues such as a woman's sexuality - and even rape.   But it's still banned in a number of cities and doesn't have a sponsor.

Link Title: N Korea ends peace pacts with South
Message: China has called for 'calm and restraint' after North Korea threatened nuclear war.   The world's most secretive and isolated state has said it's scrapping all non-aggression pacts with its neighbour South Korea, closing its crisis hotline with Seoul and shutting their shared border crossing.   That's in response to a fresh round of United Nations sanctions, passed by unanimous vote, punishing North Korea for carrying out a third nuclear test.

SEND US YOUR VIDEO COMMENT  As Venezuela prepares for the funeral of Hugo Chavez, do you think he will leave a lasting impact on the world?  Click the link below to upload your video comment with your webcam or smartphone and tell us how you'll remember him.  World Have Your Say will be part of the BBC's coverage of the funeral from 1500GMT.

"We want to avoid temptation and everything like that... What the eyes see and what the flesh wants, that is what we want to avoid." http://bbc.in/16ctBsZ  North America is home to many religious communities, one of which - Canada's Hutterites - believe that living communally and separately from what they refer to as "the world" will secure them a place in heaven. A film crew was allowed to observe them at close quarters for four months.

What do Brazil's Catholics want in a new pope? http://bbc.in/16c8ya9  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the church in the world's most populous Catholic country and other news from around the world, including:  - UN backs new North Korea sanctions http://bbc.in/16c8ya3 - Katty Kay in Venezuela  http://bbc.in/16c8AP6 -  Berlusconi convicted over wiretap http://bbc.in/16c8ya5 - Moon mining race under way http://bbc.in/16c8AP8  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/16c8ya1

What are your thoughts on Facebook's new look? http://bbc.in/16bRoJA  Facebook has revamped its design, making its website look more like its Android and iOS mobile apps. The refresh also introduces topic-specific alternatives to its news feed.

AUDIO SLIDESHOW: How a war photographer captured life in Iraq     To mark 10 years since the start of the Iraq War take we have put together some of the most thought-provoking and powerful images taken by photographer Sean Smith who documented events in Iraq since 2003.    He witnessed the "shock and awe" bombing of Baghdad, watched Iraqi families flee their homes in the hunt for insurgents, and saw US soldiers killed on patrol by improvised explosive device blasts.     Take a look here and have a listen as Sean explains the stories behind the photographs.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21683264

The UN Security Council has unanimously approved fresh sanctions against North Korea in response to Pyongyang's nuclear test last month http://bbc.in/WMNobP  The resolution is targeting North Korean diplomats, cash transfers and access to luxury goods.

Space exploration has long been about reaching far off destinations but now there is a race to exploit new frontiers by mining their minerals.     Google has offered a $20m prize to the first privately-funded company who can land a robot on the moon, explore the surface by moving at least 500m and send high definition video back to earth by 2015.     Alastair Leithead visited the test laboratory of Moon Express, one of 25 companies vying to win the prize.      Do you think the earth could benefit if we could exploit the moon’s resources?     http://bit.ly/moonvideo

Four days after voting ended Kenya is no closer to selecting its new Prime Minister. Now one of the countries most senior politicians has called for an end to the count, claiming it "lacks integrity".  Prime Minister Raila Odinga's running mate Kalonzo Musyoka has said, "We have evidence the results we have received have been doctored."  The latest figures indicate Mr Odinga's rival Uhuru Kenyatta has maintained his lead with about 53% of the vote.

Are you celebrating World Book Day? How will you mark the occasion? Every year thousands of parents have to help with a costume for their child for World Book Day. Send us photos of characters your children have chosen to dressed up as – just click the link http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21687507

The former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi has been sentenced to one year in prison over the publication of a wiretapped conversation.  Mr Berlusconi was alleged to have pressed to have it published in order to damage a political rival. He is expected to appeal against the sentence.

VIDEO:   Russia's President Vladimir Putin has come under political pressure from a predecessor, former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.   In an interview with the BBC Mr. Gorbachev called on Putin "not to be afraid of his own people". He also  denounced new laws passed in Russia as an "attack on citizens' rights".  Recent changes include fines for organising unsanctioned protests and restrictions on websites.

In 1981, when the Cold War was at its peak, a group of women set up camp at an airbase in the south of England in protest at America's plans to store a nuclear weapon there.   The Greenham Common camp remained in place for more than two decades. At its peak 70,000 women from across the country - and the world - joined the protest, blocking entrances to the base, forming human chains around the site and cutting through its perimeter fences.  A day before the International Women’s Day do you think enough is being done to remember and acknowledge the experiences and achievements of women through history?

To his family, 39-year-old Theo Ionides was an unremarkable Royal Navy volunteer relegated to technical duties during World War II and safely tucked away from the front line http://bbc.in/169buUM  In reality he was part of a secret crack team of commandos recruited by James Bond creator Ian Fleming.  This is his story http://bbc.in/169buUM

The number of Syrian refugees who have fled the conflict has reached a million, the UN has said http://bbc.in/1693Qdd  The UN High Commissioner for Refugees said the number of people seeking haven in neighbouring countries had jumped since the beginning of the year.  Half of the refugees were children, most of them under 11 and often traumatised by their experiences.
The era of drone wars is already upon us but the era of robot wars could be fast approaching.     Would it be ethical to fight wars with killer robots?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21576376

Link Title: UN chides Israel over child arrests
Message: The United Nations children's agency, UNICEF, says the ill-treatment of children in Israeli military detention appears to be widespread, systematic and institutionalised.    In a new report the agency said children were subjected to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment while in Israeli custody.  It acknowledged Israel had made some "positive changes" in its treatment of young detainees in recent years.  Israel said it would "work hard" to adopt the report's recommendations.

Snow has started falling outside the Washington Bureau of BBC News - the mid Atlantic region of the US is expecting a large accumulation over the course of today http://bbc.in/WJvEOs  The same storm snowstorm has already dumped up to 12 inches (30cm) on parts the US Midwest and cancelled 1,100 flights http://bbc.in/WJvGWG  Is it snowing where you are?
SEND US YOUR VIDEO COMMENT:  Are you mourning Hugo Chavez?   How will you remember the Venezuelan President?   Click the link to upload a video with your webcam or smartphone.

There are still big problems with the counting of votes in Kenya's elections.     Officials in Nairobi are again appealing for patience as people wait for results from Monday's vote. The count has been hampered by severe hitches with the electronic voting system.     Officials have reverted to a manual count with ballot papers being driven hundreds of kilometres to the counting centre in Nairobi.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21682269

The charismatic president who led Venezuela for 14 years is being remembered around the world today - some revere him as a champion of the poor and the socialist cause - others see him as an autocrat who squandered Venezuela's oil rich economy.     In pictures: Mourning for Chavez http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21680581    A divided and divisive legacy? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-16610581    Future of Bolivarian dream? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21682064

"Syria is spiralling towards disaster" and "a milestone in human tragedy".   This is the warning from the United Nations' High Commissioner for Refugees to news that the number of Syrians displaced by fighting in their country has now reached one million and continues to rise fast.   The rate at which people are fleeing the civil war - mostly to neighbouring countries - has increased since the start of the year. Half are children under the age of eleven.

Venezuela's President Hugo Chavez has died, his vice-president has announced http://bbc.in/WHuwea  An emotional Nicolas Maduro made the announcement on Tuesday evening, flanked by leading Venezuelan political and military leaders.  Video: Venezuela's President Hugo Chavez dies http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20912436  Live Text: Venezuela President Hugo Chavez dies http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21679372

Do video games belong in a museum? http://bbc.in/WHdEUW  PacMan, Tetris, SimCity and 11 other video games made their debut at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City this week. They are just the initial batch acquired by MoMA, which hopes to acquire 40 in the next few years.  But not everyone thinks these works belong in the same building as Munch and Monet.  Follow the link above - then tell us what you think in the comments section below.

New York's Dow Jones share index set a new all-time high on Tuesday, while London's FTSE 100 closed at it highest level in five years http://bbc.in/WH5n3p  The rallies mean the stock markets are returning to levels not seen since before the global financial crisis. The Dow is currently at 14,277.19 - exceeding the previous record intra-day high of 14,198, set in October 2007.

Ikea has withdrawn a type of almond cake from its restaurants after two samples were found to be contaminated by faecal bacteria.  Traces of the coliform bacteria were found in batches of the cake that went through Ikea's health checks. The cake came from a Swedish supplier.  The cake has been withdrawn from 23 countries; the UK and Ireland are not affected, said the furniture company.  None of the infected batches had gone on sale, Ikea said.

Europe might still be in the middle of a recession, but that has not stopped some of the world’s top car makers from unveiling some far from budget vehicles at the Geneva Motor Show.  Ferrari, McLaren, Bentley and Rolls-Royce are all showing off new models, with many of them priced in excess of a million euros.  Although these luxury brands seem confident they will find buyers, sales of cars bought by ordinary motorists across Europe are plummeting.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21381911

How should Russians and Georgians remember Joseph Stalin?  On the 60th anniversary of the death of Soviet supreme ruler Joseph Stalin there is still controversy over how to view his legacy.  See how Georgian's remember Stalin: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21656615

Link Title: Gaza race cancelled over women ban
Message: This year's Gaza marathon has been cancelled after the Hamas authorities said women would not be able to take part.   Last year about a hundred runners took part, including a handful of women.   The race is organised by the UN and raises funds for its projects - next month's event would have been the third of its kind.

After what many called a historic day, 11 million votes were cast and now Kenyans are waiting to see who their new president will be. With a third of votes counted Deputy PM Uhuru Kenyatta is in the lead with 54% while his main rival, the Prime Minister Raila Odinga, has 41%  There were extraordinary scenes outside polling stations with long lines of people waiting to vote, and while most did so peacefully, small pockets of violence left at least 19 people dead. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21665108

Is the Champions League match between Manchester United and Real Madrid the biggest game in world football?  Real boss Jose Mourinho certainly thinks so.  Yesterday he said that 'The world will stop to watch'.   Do you agree? We want to hear from you WHY this game is such a big deal.  Tell us where you're from and who you will be supporting. We will use some of your comments on BBC World News TV.

The governor of Raqqa, a northern province in Syria, has been captured by the rebels - according to activists.    The amateur video (see still below) appears to show Hassan Jalili and another senior ruling party official seated among jubilant armed fighters.    The takeover of Raqqa would mark a major gain for the rebels in their two-year fight against the regime.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21666913

Link Title: What does the future hold for China?
Message: This only happens once every ten years. It is the change of leadership in China. 3000 members of the country's parliament are witnessing the final act in the handover of power.    The outgoing Premier, Wen Jiabao, has given one of his last speeches. He promised a new emphasis on people's well-being, to include major efforts to tackle corruption and pollution. Now, the incoming President, Xi Jin Ping, has to present his outline of China's future direction.

"Don't flip out: I just flipped over to my B-side computer while the team looks into an A-side memory issue." http://bbc.in/WEVpzi  Nasa's Mars rover Curiosity let the public know on its Twitter feed @MarsCuriosity http://bbc.in/WEVpzk that it is recuperating in"safe mode" after a computer glitch caused by corrupted files. The robot, which is analysing rock samples on the Red Planet, is now running from a back-up computer.

BBC News Washington producer Suzanne Kianpour is travelling with John Kerry on his first trip abroad as US Secretary of State http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21649025 Each day she'll bring us photos and behind-the-scenes stories from the trip in a travelogue that we'll run here on our Facebook accounts. Here are her reports from Paris and Rome.

Link Title: Big Dreams - tonight on BBC World News America
Message: How hard would you work to live your dream? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21596072  Jonah Eaton wants to cross the Atlantic in a wooden boat - but his first goal is to build the craft.   Get to know Jonah and hear how this project has kept him very busy for the last eight years. Be part of a BBC World Service Programme with MIT's Joi Ito:  Joi Ito is one of the great pioneers of openness on the internet. He claims it will be “the pillar of democracy for the 21st Century”. But with Egypt’s so-called Facebook revolution in jeopardy and world-wide anxieties that the web is being used by governments to spy on their citizens, is this optimism misplaced? In a special live BBC World Service programme from Boston, Razia Iqbal introduces Joi Ito to listeners world-wide and an audience at MIT’s Media Lab in Boston, USA.   Join them at MIT Media Lab 12:40pm on Thursday March 14th for What If…We Could All Talk to Joi Ito? All tickets are FREE, there is a maximum of four per person, and tickets are released on a first-come first-served basis.  The event finishes at 2pm.  Click here for tickets and please specify number:  JoiItotickets@bbc.co.uk

Iraqi officials say at least 40 Syrians and 7 Iraqis have been killed by gunmen in the Iraqi province of Anbar.   They said the Syrians' convoy was ambushed and attacked with mortar rounds and automatic weapons.   The  Syrian victims were government soldiers and employees who were being escorted back to the Syrian border.

Approximately 3,000 people have fled the latest militant infighting in Khyber. They are now fighting a frustrating battle to secure government help for food and shelter. The BBC's M Ilyas Khan talks to the families forced into desperate escapes from Pakistan's Tirah valley. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21585297

Do shops sell to us by stealth?  As customers demand more than just a low price, and with increasing competition, we take a look how some retailers are choosing to offer free information and services instead of relying just on hard sell. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21371039

Germany says it will not allow Bulgaria or Romania to join the EU's passport-free Schengen zone if the issue is put to a vote in the EU on Thursday.  "If Romania and Bulgaria insist on a vote, the attempt will fail because of a German veto," German Interior Minister Hans-Peter Friedrich said.  Both countries must take further steps to prevent migrants abusing the system, he told Germany's Spiegel news website.  The two countries have sought Schengen entry since joining the EU in 2007.

In the early hours of last Monday morning a wanted, 27 year old man was brought into a Police station in the north of the country. But it's the manner of his delivery to police which has caught our attention. The police have confirmed that he was brought to them by someone wearing a full Batman outfit. The caped crusader's victim was later charged with a number of offences including handling stolen goods. But the identity of the man in the batman costume remains a mystery.  The city in question is Bradford and most definitely not Gotham City. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-21654930

Ros Atkins will be reporting from around the world’s newsroom on a number of stories today including this one about a 2 year-old child in Mississippi who has apparently be cured of the virus that causes AIDS.   While the scientists are still cautious - it could be a major breakthrough.   If you’ve any questions you’d like to ask Ros, please post them here, or find Ros at twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins.

A day of mourning is being observed in Pakistan's biggest city, Karachi, after a deadly bomb attack there on Sunday.  At least 45 people were killed in the powerful blast in a Shia-dominated area of the city. Schools and businesses closed in the city on Monday and a strike was called in protest at the attack. No-one has yet claimed responsibility for the explosion.

Thousands of Kenyans have been queuing since before dawn to cast their votes in the general election.   Security is tight, as 99,000 police officers and thousands of observers have been deployed across the country.   While voting this morning has been peaceful, at least 12 people are now reported dead in two separate attacks near the coastal city of Mombasa. The attacks have been blamed on a separatist movement, the MRC  In pictures: Kenyan elections http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21651666  Elections Q and A: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21478869  Mapping the elections : Interactive graphics http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21592589

An estimated 1.2 million children are victims of child trafficking each year, and the travel industry - which criminals use to move and enslave their victims - is increasingly involved in trying to do something to stop it. See the hotels and airlines determined to combat child trafficking and abuse on BBC Travel:

Link Title: Getting the right hat for chilly Calcutta
Message: "One elderly gentleman was trying to speak, but his mouth was covered by a scarf and, anyway, his friend could not hear anything as he had huge ear muffs on."  Record low temperatures of 9C (48F) have forced people in Calcutta to wear whatever they need to keep warm: http://bbc.in/VoVFpU  (No, 9C is not cold if you live in Moscow or New York or Toronto or Aberdeen)  What is the coldest temperature you have ever experienced?  Via BBC News Facebook http://www.facebook.com/bbcnews

Firefighters in Poland say a small dog probably saved the life of a 3 year old who went missing from her home overnight in freezing temperatures.  The child, Julia, vanished on Friday and was found lying in marshes several kilometres from her house on Saturday morning, with the dog by her side.  She is now in hospital in western Poland, suffering from frostbite after temperatures fell to -5C (23F).  Firefighter Grzegorz Szymanski said the dog kept the child warm enough to live.

Former President Hosni Mubarak will face retrial on 13 April over the deaths of protesters, Egypt's appeals court has decided, state media say.  He faces charges of conspiring to kill protesters during the 2011 revolt that forced him from power, and corruption.  A retrial was ordered in January after a court accepted his appeal against the life sentence he had been serving since his conviction last June.  Mr Mubarak, 84, is currently in a military hospital. About 850 people were killed in the 2011 crackdown.

Singapore is a nearly inevitable stop for anyone doing business in Southeast Asia. But in recent years, the city has successfully shed its image as “Singabore” – a bland stopover – thanks in part to two gigantic and hugely popular government-controlled casino resorts. BBC Travel has the story on Singapore's vibrant new scene:

As Kenyan voters prepare to go to the polls on 4 March BBC News has spoken to Kenyans across the country about their expectations of the upcoming poll and what challenges they think the new government and president will face.

A deadly form of skin cancer is able to avoid attack from the body's immune system, UK researchers have found.  A potential test could work out which patients are likely to respond to treatment, the Journal of Clinical Investigation reports.

By the time India's Maha Kumbh Mela comes to a close on 10 March, authorities estimate some 100 million pilgrims will have cleansed their sins in the holy waters at the confluence of the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers in Allahabad. BBC Travel has photos from this extraordinary holy event:

Link Title: No deal in sight on US budget cuts
Message: Congress has adjourned for the weekend and a blame-game is raging in Washington http://bbc.in/Wwc2NE  Budget cuts worth $85bn (£56bn), originally passed in an effort to push the US Congress to strike a budget deal, are due to become law by the end of Friday.  Hope for a deal to stop the cuts, known as the sequester, appear extremely slim.  Who will the 'sequester' budget cuts hurt? http://bbc.in/Wwc2NK  What are the 'sequester' budget cuts http://bbc.in/Wwc2NG  Katty Kay takes your sequester questions http://bbc.in/Wwc2NC

As part of our on-going series Changing Fortunes we meet the world's youngest millionaires.     Older people have always been richer than younger ones – but what has changed is the disparity between the generations. Here, West and East are diverging sharply. What does this mean for the future?    In this episode we profile Suhas Gopinath, CEO and Chairman of Globals Inc, who despite still living with his parents has managed to carve out a highly successful and profitable career.    Other CEOs profiled in the series are Si Shen (Co-founder of Papaya Mobile) and Ashish Thakkar (Founder of Mara Group)    For more details about when you will be able to see the next programme please click the link provided.     http://www.bbc.com/specialfeatures/changingfortunes/  (only works outside the UK)

There have been violent protests in the Indian capital Delhi after a minor girl was allegedly sexually assaulted inside a school.   The seven-year-old is being treated in a city hospital.   It comes even as parliament witnessed an angry debate over another alleged rape in the state of Maharashtra.   Sexual assaults on women has become a major issue in India after a young woman died in Delhi last year after being brutally gang raped.

Have you ever resigned from your job or have you ever been sacked? Is there ever a right way to resign or be sacked?    Andrew Mason - the boss of of the voucher company Groupon - has stepped down. Well, by his own admission, technically he was fired.    In a memo (attached below) to staff he wrote:  "I've decided that I'd like to spend more time with my family. Just kidding - I was fired today."    Let us know and we'll use some of your comments at 1330GMT on Impact.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21625280

8 South African police officers have been suspended over shocking video images of a suspect being handcuffed to the back of a police van and dragged down the street.   The man, who later died in police custody,  was a taxi driver who'd been accused of parking illegally.   South Africa's  police chief, Ria Phiyega, described the  police's behaviour as callous and unacceptable.    South Africa's police force was already under intense scrutiny after officers shot dead 34 striking miners last August.  Its credibility was also dented when it emerged that the lead detective in the murder case against athlete Oscar Pistorius was himself accused of attempted murder.

Or do you think it could cause more problems than it solves? We'll discuss on World Have Your Say at 1500GMT - send us your views with your webcam or smartphone by clicking the link below.

As commuters rode the New York City subway in the 1940s, their eyes were drawn to posters of pretty young women.  Miss Subways, a beauty contest run by the New York Subways Advertising Company, featured the fresh visages of young women who lived and worked in New York. It lasted for more than three decades, ending in 1976 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21583380  In this week's edition of Picture This, we take a look at where these women went after the subways.

Link Title: Kiwis on drugs: a blueprint for the future?
Message: New Zealand is proposing a new type of drugs policy.  Psychoactive Substances Bill is aimed at tackling the influx of new such substances by licensing the importation, manufacturing and sale of all new psychoactive products.  Rather than trying to ban every new drug that turns up, the legislation shifts responsibility to the manufacturer and the retailer.   Will the rest of the world follow its lead and will the policy prove to be successful?

The BBC’s Gabriel Gatehouse asks how much of a threat separatists will pose to the government that will take power after the elections. Are land and ethnicity the real fault-lines, or are there other factors at play? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/21578446

How will the automatic spending cuts in the US impact you?    Will the cuts harm the already weak US economy?    Is a last-minute deal still possible? http://bbc.in/Z2FOLy    Join BBC World News America presenter Katty Kay for a live Twitter chat today between 14:30 and 15:30 EST (19:30 and 20:30 GMT) on her Twitter account @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/Z2FNaq    Be a part of the conversation by Tweeting a question with the hashtag #AskBBCKatty or by leaving a question in the comments section below.    Find out more here http://bbc.in/Z2FOLy

Argentina has approved an agreement with Iran to set up an international truth commission to investigate the bombing of a Jewish centre in Buenos Aires in 1994.    The attack left more than 80 people dead. Courts in Argentina have blamed Iran for the bombing, Iran denies any involvement.  Argentina has one of the biggest Jewish communities in the Americas.

Link Title: Parents film girl, 8, driving at speed
Message: VIDEO:  " I'm a an 8 year old kid and I can drive"  Video footage of an eight-year-old girl driving her family's car at 100 km/h on an icy Russian road has led to a police investigation.  The video was posted on the internet by the girl's parents who have been criticized for being irresponsible.  What do you think?

Link Title: US 'to step up' help to Syria rebels
Message: The United States is offering its deepest involvement in the Syria conflict.   Now,for the first time, the United States will be giving financial assistance to the rebels and providing food and medical supplies for their campaign but not weapons.   The new US Secretary of State John Kerry made the offer at meetings in Rome with key figures from the Syrian opposition.

Link Title: Man 'dragged by SA police van' dies
Message: A disturbing video has emerged from South Africa showing a police suspect being tied to the back of a van and dragged along the road. The country's police watchdog is investigating the fatal incident.  The man, believed to be a taxi driver from Mozambique, was allegedly accused of parking his vehicle incorrectly.   Other reports suggest he may have tried to disarm a police officer. South Africa's Indepedent Police Investigative Directorate say they're shocked by the footage, which shows the man bundled towards a police van and then tied to the back of the vehicle which drives away. The man later died in custody.

5000 people have lost their lives in a bloody conflict in Thailand over the past decade but now both sides are trying to find a resolution.   The Thai government and a Muslim rebel group have just signed a deal, brokered by Malaysia, which will lead to peace talks.  It's the first time the Thai authorities have recognised the rebels and the prime ministers of Thailand and Malaysia are publicly backing the agreement.

Hi - it's Babita here on Impact today.     We're discussing banker's bonuses. For the first time in EU history, bankers face a legal cap on bonuses from next year following an agreement in Brussels.     The deal is designed to prevent another banking crisis. But bankers in the City of London say a cap could drive business to countries outside the EU.     What do you think? Is this good or bad news for banking? Let us know and I'll read out some of your thoughts during the programme.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21608938

A second Islamist political leader has been sentenced to death in Bangladesh, for war crimes committed more than 40 years ago.    Delwar Hossain Sayeedi is Vice President  of the Jamaat-e-Islami party.   He's been found guilty of mass murder and torture, during Bangladesh's war of independence from Pakistan in 1971. His supporters say the trial is politically motivated.

Link Title: Smog and haze engulf China's capital
Message: Air quality in China's capital, Beijing, once again hits serious levels, with locals urged to stay indoors amid thick smog and a sandstorm.  Beijing's environment agency blamed large amounts of dust blowing in on strong winds from Inner Mongolia, and urged people to stay indoors.

Milking cows is a messy, menial and low-paid job that few workers in the US want to do http://bbc.in/15RlYZ2  For years, dairy farmers have relied on immigrants. But visa restrictions and a crackdown on undocumented workers have forced the farmers to look elsewhere to get the task done.   See how robotic milking machines are changing the landscape of dairy farms in New York State.

A team led by millionaire and former space tourist Dennis Tito plans to send a "tested couple" to Mars and back in a privately funded mission http://bbc.in/Z0bgKe  Mr Tito will join Katty Kay tonight on BBC World News America to discuss the mission and their plans for reaching for the red planet. We'll also take a look at other news from around the world, including:  - Pope recalls joy and 'choppy waters' http://bbc.in/Z0beC5 - Egypt suspends Luxor balloon flights  http://bbc.in/Z0bgtY - Syria and the US  http://bbc.in/Z0bgtW - Reeva Steenkamp's best friend speaks out http://bbc.in/Z0beCf - Would you board Titanic II?  http://bbc.in/Z0belN  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Z0bgKc

Last September we profiled Brandon Stanton and his Humans of New York photo blog for our Living Online video series http://bbc.in/15QM1PW  Brandon is making headline news around the world today after fashion label DKNY apologised and agreed to pay $25,000 to a Brooklyn charity for using hundreds of his photos in a Bangkok shop window display without his permission http://bbc.in/15QM1Q0

Dreadlocks have grown in the popularity in South Africa, so popular is the twisted hair that it has now spiralled into crime, with people being robbed of their hair. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21498878

Iran says talks with world powers in Kazakhstan to try to resolve its nuclear crisis were a "positive step".  The EU's chief delegate said she hoped Iran was "looking positively" at proposals presented at the talks.  International powers suspect Iran of seeking to develop nuclear weapons - a charge Iran strongly denies.

Pakistan's army Chief of Staff, Gen Ashfaq Pervez Kayani, has said that the army has no intention of interfering with upcoming parliamentary elections.  He said it was his "dream" that fair elections would take place on time.  Polls due in May would mark the first time a civilian government has completed its term and transferred power to another elected assembly.

The best-selling French writer, wartime resistance fighter, and Holocaust survivor, Stephane Hessel, has died at the age of 95.   Three years ago he published the essay 'Time for Outrage', which sold millions of copies and helped inspire the Occupy Wall Street movement and anti-capitalist protest groups in other countries.

Link Title: Bahrain police acquitted in death cases
Message: A court in Bahrain has acquitted two policemen charged in the shooting death of a protester.  The decision on Tuesday came just two days after a court confirmed the acquittal of two other policemen in the deaths of protesters in February 2011.  The rulings threaten to fuel more unrest in the kingdom.

Have you ever lied to your doctor?  There's an interesting story today about the gap between alcohol sales in England and what people say about their drinking.   BBC Healthcheck presenter Dr Ayan Panja will be with me with his own stories of patients being less than truthful.   So - confess! Mishal

At least 19 people have been killed and many more have been injured in a fire that swept through an illegal market in the eastern Indian city of Calcutta.  Police officials say the fire began in a paper and plastic market in the crowded Sealdah area of the city. Several people were also seriously burnt in the blaze.  Officials say the number of dead could rise as more are thought to be trapped in the rubble. The fire has been contained and rescue operations are ongoing.

How do you train to be a celebrity's nanny?    A spoonful of sugar may have done the trick for Mary Poppins. But these days, a nanny for the rich and famous needs more worldly skills. Like defensive driving to avoid the paparazzi, and martial arts to protect against kidnapper.    Some of Britain's most traditional nannies - those trained at the famous Norland College - are learning new skill with modern techniques for celebrity clients.    Did you hire nannies yourselves? Or, perhaps, did you have nannies when you were a child? What were your experiences?    Let us know and we'll use some of your comments on GMT programme at 1230GMT    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21598420
WATCH LIVE NOW: A special BBC programme as Pope Benedict XVI holds his final general audience at St Peter's Square in the Vatican before his resignation on Thursday.

Where did the meteor that hit central Russia come from? http://bbc.in/YXmb7q  A team of astronomers from Colombia have used amateur video footage to plot the meteor's trajectory through Earth's atmosphere and then reconstruct its orbit around the Sun.

BBC News Washington producer Suzanne Kianpour is travelling with John Kerry on his first trip abroad as US Secretary of State http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21569993         Each day she'll bring us photos and behind-the-scenes stories from the trip in a travelogue that we'll run here on our Facebook accounts.          Here are her reports from London & Berlin:             LONDON Our day in London was dominated by discussions of Syria. We watched Secretary Kerry seemingly speak directly to the Syrian opposition from his podium at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office – he cited his new role as a "ripe" moment -"We understand the Syrian people want to see results and I would say to Al-Khatib so do we," he said. About an hour later, a senior State Department official informed us that the secretary had personally called Syrian Opposition Coalition president Moaz Al-Khatib to ask him to come to Rome. Shortly after that reports came in that al-Khatib had told the Italian government the boycott was over. Kerry has barely started his new job and has hit the ground running quite fast.                 BERLIN  Secretary Kerry joked with embassy staff that he refreshed his German language skills on the flight over with Rosetta Stone and told stories from his time in Germany as a child. During several of today's events he spoke about how at age 12 he took his diplomatic passport and went over to East Berlin. Later in the day Kerry sat down with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov at the Adlon Hotel, known to many as the location of Michael Jackson's baby-dangling incident and the shooting location of the British film Unknown. As a crowd gathered outside waiting to catch a glimpse of the motorcade, the hotel security staff joked with me, "they have no idea who's in here."

"It is unconventional material for a musical... that's sort of the stuff that we love" http://bbc.in/15O8ayv  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll speak with South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone about the launch of the West End run of their award-winning musical The Book of Mormon and take a look at news from around the world, including:   - Egypt balloon crash: Two Britons and UK resident die http://bbc.in/15O8aON - Markets react to Italy's election stalemate http://bbc.in/15O8blN - US Sequester, the view from Virginia http://bbc.in/15O8aOL - Iran nuclear crisis: 'Useful' talks in Kazakhstan http://bbc.in/15O8aOP  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/15O8blQ

The dangers of texting while driving are well documented - but police in Jamaica are facing a different threat posed by mobile phone use http://bbc.in/15NUhjJ  Motorists on the Caribbean island are using their phones to alert large numbers of people when they see police roadblocks. These roadblocks are credited with helping police catch gang members and criminals carrying guns.  We want to hear from you:  Is it possible to regulate the use of messenger services?

Link Title: Fespaco: How free are African artists?
Message: Fespaco, Africa's premiere film festival, is taking place in Burkina Faso this week, amid debate about artistic freedom on the continent.  The BBC explores whether Africa's artists are still subject to tight censorship or are they free to explore their ideas through books, paintings and films.  What do you think?

A "manifesto" left by an al-Qaeda group in Mali warned other militant groups there against implementing Islamic law too quickly and predicted Western intervention.  The document, published by a French newspaper, is said to contain advice by the head of al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), Abdel Malek Droukdel.  It criticises militants in Mali for implementing Islamic law too quickly and predicts France's intervention.

AUDIO/VISUAL SLIDESHOW:    Are you intrigued how data continues to increasingly define us?     Just think about the information we share on the web, to that collected by the numerous companies with whom we interact with.     Photojournalist Rick Smolan wanted to find out how data was transforming the world so, as part of the BBC News - What If? season, we've put together this slideshow to look at his global snapshots.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-21535739

Link Title: SA study: Donkey meat sold as beef
Message: While Europe is in the midst of a scandal about horsemeat passing off as beef, food scandals are also cropping up elsewhere in the world.  In South Africa donkey, water buffalo and goat meat have been sold as burgers and sausages.  A study published by the local Stellenbosch University found that 99 of 139 samples contained species not declared in the product label.

Do you have problems with sleeping?   Scientists now have evidence that sleepless nights can seriously affect your daily health.  Researchers at England's University of Surrey found that getting less than 6 hours sleep a night can attack your immune system and alter more than 700 genes.

In Rome the word "ungovernable" seems to capture the state of the country's politics after elections in which no party or coalition emerged with an outright majority.   Former PM Silvio Berlusconi did almost as well as Pier Luigi Bersani's centre-left party in the lower house, but no-one has control of the Senate, and you need control of both to govern.   But it's the maverick and former comedian Beppe Grillo who's stolen the limelight winning a quarter of the vote and effectively throwing a political grenade into the proceedings.

The US-based lobby group, Human Rights Watch, has accused the Sri Lankan security forces of using rape and other forms of sexual violence against ethnic minority Tamil detainees suspected of involvement with the defeated Tamil Tiger separatists.  It says the practice has continued to be widespread after the end of the civil war four years ago. But the Sri Lankan government has called the allegations "fabricated".

British, French and Japanese nationals are reported to be among 19 tourists killed in a hot air balloon crash near the southern Egyptian city of Luxor.  The balloon was flying at 1,000 ft (300m) when it caught fire and exploded, plunging onto fields west of Luxor, officials said.  Two people, including the balloon's pilot, reportedly survived the crash.  Luxor lies on the banks of the River Nile and is home to some of Egypt's most famous pharaonic-era ruins.

Sir Ranulph Fiennes has pulled out of an expedition across Antarctica in winter because of severe frostbite http://bbc.in/YSQoVn  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at his journey and other news from around the world, including:   - Britain's Cardinal O'Brien resigns as Archbishop http://bbc.in/YSQoVp - Syria: children living underground http://bbc.in/YSQpZn - Kerry's first trip  http://bbc.in/YSQoVt - Italy still waiting for poll results  http://bbc.in/YSQoVr  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area. BBC News Washington producer Suzanne Kianpour is travelling with John Kerry on his first trip abroad as US Secretary of State http://bbc.in/15KDBK2  Each day she'll bring us photos and behind-the-scenes stories from the trip in a travelogue that we'll run here on our Facebook accounts.   Here is her first entry:  "Secretary of State John Kerry embarked on his first foreign trip in his new role bright and early yesterday morning, with press corps in tow. After having drawn for seats (there are a few business class like seats on what is jokingly called Air Force 2.5 - the rest very much coach) - the mood on the plane was almost like the first day of school.  New faces, new guy in charge - we set out for London. Secretary Kerry, dressed uncharacteristically casually for those used to seeing him in a suit on Capitol Hill, made a few appearances in the packed press section at the back of the plane. Towering over us, the 6'4" secretary shared some laughs and seemed at ease. While he is not likely to travel as much as Secretary Clinton, Kerry has an intense itinerary ahead of him this week - nine cities spanning Europe and the Middle East over 11 days."  Secretary Kerry and Suzanne have arrived in Berlin. We'll update you on the trip here tomorrow.

Link Title: BBC Big Dream - Board Game Designer
Message: Do you have a hobby that is actually your dream job? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21481991  On this week's edition of our video series Big Dreams we meet David Fox, a secondary school maths teacher, as he takes eight different board games that he has designed to the American International Toy Fair.  Will his dream of being a game designer come true?  Check out our trailer below and follow the link above to see David's story.

Fragments of an ancient continent are buried beneath the floor of the Indian Ocean, a study suggests.    Researchers have found evidence for a landmass that would have existed between 2,000 and 85 million years ago.    The strip of land, which scientists have called Mauritia, eventually fragmented and vanished beneath the waves as the modern world started to take shape.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21551149

A BBC investigation has uncovered corruption and child abuse among the ranks of the Afghan police force.     Travelling with US marines in Helmand Province, the team found that young boys were being sexually abused at a police station and many officers were also involved in corruption.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21547542

VIDEO:    Nokia has broadened its flagship Lumia range, offering less expensive models of its Microsoft Windows mobile phone.    Chief Executive Stephen Elop told the BBC's technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones that he was confident the devices could boost the manufacturer's popularity to third place in the smartphone market.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-21575350

Russia's Chelyabinsk region is gripped by a kind of meteor fever, with thousands combing through fields trying to find meteorite fragments.  Near the villages of Deputatsky and Pervomaysky, an hour's drive from Chebarkul city, whole families of meteorite hunters are hard at work.  The meteorite passed over the area before reportedly crashing into the Chebarkul lake, and the snowy fields are covered with human footprints http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21554326

It seems that with every day that passes there is another twist in Europe's horsemenat scandal.   Today, it's the turn of Swedish furniture giant Ikea.    Frozen meatballs destined for the food halls of their stores in the Czech Republic were found to contain horsemeat.  The discovery comes as European Union agriculture ministers meet in Brussels for talks widely expected to focus on the growing horsemeat scandal.

Britain's most senior Roman Catholic cleric, Cardinal Keith O'Brien, is stepping down as Archbishop.  Cardinal O'Brien's decision follows allegations of inappropriate behaviour towards priests dating back to the 1980s, claims he contests.   The case will once again draw attention to the sex abuse scandals that have dogged the Church and, threaten to overshadow the process of finding a new pope.

Link Title: LIFE OF PI - TAIWAN - CINDY SUI - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Lots of Oscars talk on Impact today, including the Taiwan connection of Life of Pi. It's not just about Ang Lee - the movie was also largely financed and made in Taiwan.   So could it now help to promote Taiwanese culture, in the face of a continuing Chinese effort at peaceful reunification?   Taiwan's Culture Minister Lung Yingtai is my live guest. Mishal     The BBC's Taiwan correspondent Cindy Sui explains how the Taiwanese government helped Mr. Lee in making the Life Of Pi

Link Title: Italy votes in key general election
Message: Italians are voting in the second and final day of a general election that's been dominated by the country's faltering economy.  The outcome is far from clear. Pier Luigi Bersani's centre-left bloc is believed to have a narrow lead over Silvio Berlusconi's alliance.    But victory for an unstable coalition or one prepared to ditch painful economic reforms could spell trouble ahead for the single currency.

Link Title: Park sworn in as S Korea president
Message: Park Geun-hye promised a tough stance on national security and an era of economic revival as she was sworn in as South Korea's president.  Ms Park, who defeated liberal rival Moon Jae-in in December's general election, took the oath of office in front of tens of thousands of people.  North Korea's recent nuclear test posed a "challenge to the survival" of the Korean people, she said.

Link Title: Business travel gets a female touch
Message: Motivated by a desire for safety and a recognition that women increasingly travel for business, female-only hotel amenities and transportation options are cropping up all over the world. For example, one hotel in Houston, Texas, offers a women-only floor with features including yoga mats, jewellery boxes and a make-up kit. Does this hole in a wall make you angry? http://bbc.in/YIyHYw  This wall in north London used to feature a piece of artwork by the celebrated street artist Banksy - but earlier this week the work was cut out from the side of a discount store and shipped to an art auctioneer in Miami.    The auction house says the piece was acquired legally - locals are still upset.

Link Title: How credit card-friendly is your next destination?
Message: “How much cash should I bring with me?” It’s a common question from travellers, made more complicated by the fact that some places are decidedly more likely to accept credit cards than others. From New York City, where many restaurants are still cash-only, to Korea, which is one of the most credit card-friendly nations in the world, BBC Travel has your guide to how you should expect to pay:

‘Changing Fortunes’, our TV and online series, continues today. We look at three extraordinary women who have beaten the odds to make their fortunes and see what they have put back into the community?
