Link Title: The babies who nap in sub-zero temperatures
Message: Would you put your baby or toddler outside in the freezing cold for their lunchtime nap?   Most Nordic parents wouldn't give it a second thought. For them it's part of their daily routine.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21537988

Global stock markets have fallen after some members of the US central bank suggested its stimulus measures may be increasing the "risks of future economic and financial imbalances" http://bbc.in/15z6Qzk  The comments came in minutes of the Federal Reserve's last meeting, where the Fed said it had left its monthly $85bn bond-buying plan in place.

We want to hear from you -  Will Google glasses become as common as the iPod?  What features are you hoping to see?
It is just 100 seconds long and it has been getting a lot of attention!    We catch up with the director of the shortest film ever nominated for an Oscar.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21516368

Oscar Pistorius bail hearing - latest developments:  - Police have not found anything inconsistent with how the star athlete described his shooting of his girlfriend. - Prosecutors say a witness can testify to hearing "non-stop talking, like shouting'' between 2 a.m. and 3 a.m. before the predawn shooting on Valentine's Day. - Under cross-examination, police detective acknowledges the witness who allegedly overheard argument, was 600 meters from Pistorius' house.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21514428  For the latest developments go to bbc.com/news

Hi it's Babita here,    Coming up on Impact, we're discussing the dangers of skin whitening products and why this billion dollar industry is thriving in Asia. What do you think?     Send us your comments and we'll put your views to the former model Tuey Mach and our medical expert Dr Ayan Panja.     That's all coming up on Impact from 1300GMT.

Aaron Swartz was many things - a brilliant young technologist, an entrepreneur, and an advocate for internet freedom http://bbc.in/Yy8dJ4  But according to the United States government, he was also a criminal.  Has his death made him an internet 'martyr'?

While Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl shot by the Taliban for campaigning for girls education, continues to recover in the UK - many Pakistani school children are defying the Taliban every day by attending classes in areas where schools are being bombed http://bbc.in/15sWC3n  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll visit one of these school and take a look at other news from around the world, including:  -  Pistorius 'thought he was firing at intruder' http://bbc.in/15sWC3h - Tunisia's PM resigns http://bbc.in/15sWC3j - Diamond robbery in Brussels http://bbc.in/15sWC3l - China military unit 'behind prolific hacking' http://bbc.in/15sWDEs  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area. Nasa ground controllers have lost contact with the International Space Station because of a computer problem http://bbc.in/Yxr3jH  Flight controllers in Houston were updating software on board the ISS's flight computers this afternoon (GMT) when one of the station's data relay systems broke down. The ISS has been able to make contact intermittently via Russian ground stations.

Armed robbers have made off with a "gigantic" haul of diamonds after a rapid raid at Brussels Airport http://bbc.in/15sAaHv  Disguised as police, they broke through a fence on Monday evening and broke into the cargo of a Swiss-bound plane to take the gems, estimated to be worth $50m (£32m; 37m euros).

Guitarist Tomoyasu Hotei has been hugely successful in Japan and his music has been used in films such as Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill.    He explained to the BBC that the quieter life in London allows him to play to smaller audiences and fulfil his dream.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21510249

Have you ever dreamt of quitting your cushy job and starting a new life halfway around the world to follow your passion?     Jessica Fox, a Nasa employee in Los Angeles, decided one day to move to Scotland to live in a used bookshop.     Would you throw it all away to follow your dream?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21472543
Oscar Pistorius 'thought he was firing at intruder'.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21503370

As if Australians weren't already disappointed with a poor medal haul from swimmers at the London 2012 Olympics - now a damning review slams a "toxic" team culture, that led to bullying and misuse of prescription drugs.    Is there too much pressure to perform in a sports mad nation like Australia?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21501881

Reeva Steenkamp's family are holding a private service in Port Elizabeth as boyfriend and South African athletics star, Oscar Pistorius, faces bail hearing in Pretoria.  Prosecutors tell court, Pistorius shot his girlfriend through a bathroom door.    BBC World News has the latest.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21502687

US security firm claims Chinese military unit is behind large scale hacking network.    They claim to have tracked the hackers to a building in Shanghai and say the People's Liberation Army "is also located in precisely the same area".    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-21502088

One of the giants of ocean science, the Alvin deep-submersible, is almost ready to get back in the water after a $41m (£26.5m) upgrade http://bbc.in/YucUDK  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at how the 49-year-old vehicle is getting ready for more missions and deeper voyages. Check out this clip of Jessica flying a plane and hear more about her story in this week's edition of Big Dreams http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21377627

British Prime Minister David Cameron has assured Indian students there is no limit on the amount of visas being given to study in the UK - so long as they have an English language qualification and a place to study.  Cameron is on a 3-day tour to improve business and trade ties with India.  He also announced Britain will introduce a same-day visa service for Indian businessmen, wanting to invest there. How important do you think this trade link is between the UK and India? Is it a relationship in which both countries can mutually benefit? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-21495635

Should soft drinks should be heavily taxed and junk food adverts banned?  In the UK - that's what some doctors suggest is a radical overhaul needed to take action against obesity.   Is this going too far and should people be responsible for their own actions or is advertising providing too much temptation?  Tell us what the situation is in your country and if there are other proven solutions, to curb the problem.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-21478314

Are you interested in running your own business? Link Title: Stranded cruise ship nears US coast
Message: It's been called "the cruise from hell" and now it  is finally over.   More than 3,000 passengers on board the Carnival Triumph have disembarked after the cruise ship was pulled into the port of Mobile Alabama by a flotilla of tugboats.   The ship had been powerless for five days - disabled by an engine-room fire that led to a sanitation breakdown, food shortages and foul smells.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21465387

Link Title: The awkwardness of the Skype job interview
Message: Have you ever done an interview via webcam?  Is it trickier than being interviewed in person?  In the US more than six out of 10 HR managers now use video to interview job applicants, according to a survey.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-2133471

Link Title: Air Asia X launches child-free seating
Message: A new service from Air Asia X promises travellers the option of a child-free zone – seven rows of seating devoid of anyone under 12 years old. But does banning children from a certain section of the aeroplane actually result in a more pleasant and peaceful journey? BBC Travel has the full story:

Conscious and smiling: the first pictures of Venezuela's Hugo Chavez have been released, since his latest cancer surgery in December.  The 58-year-old is shown lying in bed, reading a newspaper, with his two daughters at his side.  Mr Chavez has not been seen in public since he went to Havana for surgery last year.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-2147691

44 % of Taiwan's adults are overweight and so are a 1/4 of the children.     For the past two years, more than a million Taiwanese have lost 2.2 million kgs on an ambitious nationwide weightloss programme.     It all represents a remarkably successful government healthcare programme to help the population lose weight.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21441916

A chunk of space rock the size of an Olympic swimming pool will skim past Planet Earth in a few hours' time.     You'll be relieved to hear that scientists say the giant lump will not crash into us.     It will pass over directly over the eastern Indian Ocean, making for the best viewing in Eastern Europe, Asia and Australia. Its closest approach will be 19:25 GMT.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21442863

Upload your video comment: what next for the Catholic Church after Pope Benedict? On World Have Your Say at 1500GMT, we'll bring together a group of Catholics to discuss the future. What do they want from the next Pope? Is change needed in the church? If it is - who should decide on how it changes? Join the conversation by sending us your video via the link below.

The South African Paralympic champion Oscar Pistorius has been formally charged with murder.     He broke down in tears as the charge was read to him in a courthouse in Pretoria.     A magistrate has ruled that he can stay in custody in a police house rather than the local prison.      Pistorius was arrested after his girlfriend, 29 year old Reeva Steenkamp was found shot dead at his home.     His Defence lawyer described him as being in 'an extremely traumatized state of mind'     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21467359

A meteor has crashed in Russia, injuring at least 400 people.    A fireball was seen streaking through the sky above the city of Yekaterinburg, in central Russia. followed by loud bangs.    The shockwave blew out windows and rocked buildings.    Most of those hurt suffered minor cuts and bruises but some received head injuries.    The meteor is believed to have landed in a lake near Chebarkul, a town in the neighbouring Chelyabinsk region.    Elena Gorshkova sent BBC News this image of the meteor above Yekaterinburg.     Did you see the meteor or feel the shockwave? Please let us know and we may use your comments during our programmes.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21468116
On this Valentine's Day, we bring you a different kind of love story http://bbc.in/15gst7t

Why do we love art? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21377626    Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at the science behind our emotional reaction to artwork and look at news from around the world, including:     - Pistorius faces murder charge  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21459240  - Arrests in horsemeat investigation  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21466074  - American and US Airways to merge  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21454925  - Cruise ship limps to US coast  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21465387  - Love and dating - online  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21448715    Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area. A processing plant in the South of France - whose meat ended up on the shelves of Tesco and Aldi as well as in some Findus products - has been accused by the French government of knowingly selling horsemeat labelled as beef.  Ministers claim the firm called Spanghero - has been engaged in "fraud"  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21464052

At least 19 people have been killed in a series of attacks in north-west Pakistan, officials say.  Seven were reported dead in a blast at a police checkpoint in the Hangu district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.  Meanwhile, at least six people were killed in a bomb attack on an anti-Taliban tribe in the Orakzai region.  In another incident, six suicide bombers died in an attack on a police station in the town of Bannu.

It's Valentine's Day.    In Pakistan matchmaking shows have been popular for years with many couples choosing to seek romance and future partners under the full gaze of television cameras.    However, televised weddings are still a controversial subject in a society where choosing partners has traditionally been the responsibility of family elders.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21451436

All 27 members of the European Union have been told to carry out random tests on processed beef, to see whether it contains traces of horsemeat.     They'll also be told to check for Bute -- that's a veterinary drug which is used for race-horses but can be harmful to humans.     The British government  has said traces of the drug have been found in three British horse carcases which entered the food chain in France.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21456388

The South African sporting icon Oscar Pistorius is facing a murder charge, following the death of his girlfriend.   30 year old Reeva Steenkamp was found shot dead at his home in Pretoria.   Oscar Pistorius is due to appear in court on Friday.    Here's our report on some of the online reaction to the news.

Women's safety is a hot topic in India at the moment.  One popular service in Delhi is Cabs for Women by Women. It's a ladies only taxi company in the Indian capital Delhi.  In India, as elsewhere, it takes months of training to become a taxi driver

How much would you pay for a fake Facebook girlfriend?    This BBC report looks into the growing business of hiring a partner for your social media profiles.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-21446368

A teenage boy in the Gulf state of Bahrain has been shot dead during protests to mark the second anniversary of a failed uprising.   Anti-government demonstrators have set up road blocks and clashed with members of the security forces.  Opposition groups have called for a general strike.  Meanwhile, Amnesty International has called for the release of what it calls Bahrain's "prisoners of conscience".  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21450053

The South African sporting legend Oscar Pistorius is facing a murder charge, following a fatal shooting at his home near Pretoria.   Police were called to his home in the early hours of the morning.  The victim is widely reported to be his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp.  The precise circumstances surrounding the incident are unclear. Reports say he may have mistaken her for a burglar.

Police say they have found a body in a burnt-out cabin where murder suspect Christopher Dorner is believed to have made his deadly last stand http://bbc.in/Yeah8Q  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at the manhunt and firefight in this in this California town and take a look at other news from around the globe, including:  - Pope Benedict' last public Mass http://bbc.in/Yeaf0Y - Obama takes State of the Union message on tour http://bbc.in/Yeah8T - Can a railway unite Nigeria?  http://bbc.in/Yeaf0Q - Kate photos: Chi says photos 'not scandalous' http://bbc.in/YeagSA  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Yeaf0W  Photo courtesy of BBC's Regan Morris http://bbc.in/Yeaf0S

Is Hollywood finding southern comfort in New Orleans? http://bbc.in/Ye0XSC  We take a look at the places, the talent and the business perks that are helping turn the Crescent City into the third largest centre for film production in the US.   With two Louisiana films up for a total of nine awards at this year's Oscars - is this the start of a new frontier in filmmaking?

What do you think is the future of mobile? BBC Future is investigating this in a five-part series, the first of which asks a fundamental question: Do we have enough bandwidth to meet the exploding demands for mobile data? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130212-mobiles-signal-dawning-crisis

Link Title: EU and US launch free-trade talks
Message: The European Union and the US will begin formal talks on a free-trade agreement, paving the way for the biggest trade deal in history.  European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso made the announcement following President Barack Obama's State of the Union address.  A deal would bring down trading barriers between the two biggest economies in the world.  EU-US trade is worth around $613bn a year.

At least 10 civilians, mostly women and children, have been killed in a Nato air strike in Kunar province in Afghanistan, local officials say.  At least three Taliban commanders were also said to have died in the attack.  The Nato-led Isaf force said it was aware of the reports of civilian deaths and was "looking into the circumstances" of the incident.

BBC Future's latest Power of Nature video looks at the Sundarbans, the largest mangrove forest in the world. This vast tract acts as nature's bioshield, protecting the Bay of Bengal from cyclones and other extremes, but its very existence is under threat. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130212-sundarbans-natures-bioshield

The railway linking the economic powerhouse of Lagos and the conflict-hit north of Nigeria has reopened after more than 10 years. The BBC's Will Ross made the 31-hour train journey and asks whether the train line can help unite this divided country. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21364541

Health officials in the UK believe they have the strongest evidence yet that a new respiratory illness similar to the deadly Sars virus can spread from person to person.  Cases of the infection may come from contact with animals. However, if the virus can spread between people it poses a much more serious threat.  However, officials say the threat to the whole population remains very low.

Link Title: The Pope's inbox: Priorities for next pontiff
Message: Pope Benedict XVI has thanked the public for their "love and prayers", as he makes his first public appearance since announcing his resignation.  He said he resigned "for the good of the Church", aware of his own declining spiritual and physical strength.  Pope Benedict XVI's successor will take the helm at a difficult time for the Catholic Church.  Here are some of the major issues facing the next Pope once he is elected. Are there other issues you think should take higher priority?  Managing the Vatican Equality laws Sex abuse The role of women Interfaith tensions Smaller congregations, fewer priests

Before a television audience of millions, US President Barack Obama will address both houses of the US Congress in the annual State of the Union speech tonight http://bbc.in/15aqWzv  Join us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/15aqWzx for live commentary, photos and key lines from the speech.  Photo courtesy of BBC's Suzanne Kianpour

A man believed to be a former Los Angeles police officer accused of three murders has been involved in a shoot-out with police, reports say http://bbc.in/159WZj7  The fugitive exchanged shots with officers in California's Big Bear Lake region, according to the Los Angeles Times.  Two officers are reported to have been wounded by gunfire.  Join us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://Twitter.com/bbcnewsus as this story develops.

Outgoing Pentagon chief Leon Panetta has said North Korean military ambitions are a "serious threat" to the US http://bbc.in/YaQcQR  Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll look at the reactions to the nation's nuclear test and other news from around the world, including:   - The latest on Pope Benedict XVI's health & resignation http://bbc.in/YaQcR1 - Obama prepares for State of the Union  http://bbc.in/YaQcQV - Horsemeat row: Slaughterhouse raided http://bbc.in/YaQcQY - The power of presidential words  http://bbc.in/YaQg37  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation about tonight's State of the Union on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/YaQg3c

Two French charity workers have been sentenced to 2 years in prison for illegally trying to fly around 100 African children from Chad to France in 2007.   Eric Breteau, who founded Zoe's Ark, and his colleague Emilie Lelouch had not appeared at the court in Paris until the verdict, and were immediately arrested.   The children were said to have been orphans from Darfur in Sudan, but turned out to be mainly from Chad and with families of their own.

VIDEO:  She came, she heard, she translated. The resignation of the Pope came out of the blue yesterday and also in Latin.   The news was broken by one of five journalists in the room when he made his announcement .  Giovanna Chirri, who works for the Italian news agency Ansa, used her knowledge of Latin to tell the world of the Pope's resignation.

Syrian rebels have captured a military air base near the northern city of Aleppo, activists say.  Fighters took control of al-Jarrah base after days of clashes there with security forces, reports said.  The reported capture comes a day after rebels in the north-east overran Syria biggest hydro-electric dam, delivering a strategic blow to the government.

VIDEO:   How much would you spend on a mobile phone?   If the answer is $10.000 dollars then this phone is for you.    Luxury mobile phone company Vertu is launching its latest handset and that's about how much some of the more basic models will cost.   it will use the Android operating system and it will come with a titanium casing, crystal encrusted screen and its very own personal concierge service.  Speaking to the BBC's Aaron Heslehurst, Vertu's chief executive Perry Oosting denied the handset was simply "a showpiece".

Natasha Harris from New Zealand, who died three years ago after a cardiac arrest, drank up to 10 litres of the Coca-Cola each day.  Now a coroner has said that drinking large quantities of fizzy drink was a "substantial factor" in her death.  Ms. Harris drank twice the recommended safe limit of caffeine and more than 11 times the recommended sugar intake.  Coca-Cola had argued that it could not be proved its product had contributed to Ms Harris' death.

Two Nigerian journalists have been arrested over the killing of 9 female polio vaccinators in northern Kano state on Friday, police have said.  Some Muslim leaders in northern Nigeria believe polio vaccinations cause infertility among women.  They see it as a Western conspiracy to reduce the Muslim population.

Link Title: How to upload a video to World Have Your Say
Message: VIDEO COMMENTS: A day after Pope Benedict XVI called time on his evangelical mission, questions about where the next pope should come from are beginning to intensify.  Many in Italy are calling for the next pope to come from the Apennines. But there are many others who think that he should come from Asia, Africa or Latin America.  What do you think? Is it important where the next Pope comes from? Should his age be taken into consideration?  This is your opportunity to let us know what you think. Just upload your video comment (click on the link below and follow the instructions)and we'll do the rest.  Some of your comments will be used throughout the day.

North Korea says it has successfully carried out its third underground nuclear test, a move that has drawn international condemnation.  Pyongyang said the test involved a "miniaturised" device and was carried out in a "perfect manner".  The confirmation came three hours after seismic activity was detected at North Korea's nuclear test site.  US President Barack Obama called for "swift" and "credible" international action in response.

Seismic activity has been detected in North Korea, the US and South Korea say, in what could be a sign of a widely anticipated nuclear test http://bbc.in/157KULv  The US Geological Survey said it had detected a tremor with a 4.9 magnitude.

What does it take to fix the US economy?   Bill Marriott, Executive Chairman and Chairman of the Board of Marriott International, joins Katty Kay tonight on BBC World News America to discuss the US economy ahead of the first State of the Union address of President Obama's second term.   We'll also look at other news from around the world, including:  - Pope Benedict XVI to resign citing poor health http://bbc.in/Y7nAYR - Horsemeat scandal continues  http://bbc.in/Y7nAb8 - Do you have Big Dreams?  http://bbc.in/Y7nAYH  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/Y7nAYN

Link Title: Pope resigns: Cardinal Peter Turkson on succession
Message: Is it time for a non-European to be the Pope? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21417062  Ghanaian Cardinal Peter Turkson has been suggested as a possible candidate, but he told the BBC choosing a Pope based on statistics was not how it should be done.  "It doesn't go by representation... those type of considerations tend to muddy the water."

What is your dream? http://bbc.in/156RzW4  Introducing Big Dreams - our new series looking at people who set incredible goals and go after them . This week we meet Jason Lewis who set out at the age of 26 to circumnavigate the world using only human power.   Hear about the challenges and discoveries on his 13 year journey http://bbc.in/156RzW4 and share your big dream in the comments section below.

Our live Twitter Q&A session with North America editor Mark Mardell ( http://bbc.in/Y6UTew )has been postponed until after the US State of the Union.   We apologise for the delay and we look forward to tweeting with you soon.

Tunisian President Moncef Marzouki's party has reversed its decision to withdraw from the Islamist-led government, an official has said.  The secular CPR party said it would stay in the coalition for another week to give talks a chance, he said.  The CPR had earlier threatened to quit the government if two Islamist ministers were not replaced.  Tunisia's political crisis has deepened since last week's killing of opposition politician Chokri Belaid.

It's a big day for the BBC in Pakistan today - we are broadcasting a new TV service, Sairbeen, for the first time. It will be broadcast by Express News in Pakistan.    BBC Urdu will bring the very best of BBC global news as well as an insight and analysis of Pakistan's news together into one programme.     Issues not normally discussed in the local media will also be featured on the programme.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2013/bbcurdutvsairbeen.html

Two daughters of Iranian opposition leader Mir Hossein Mousavi have been arrested after security forces raided their homes in the capital, Tehran.  It comes almost two years after their parents were put under house arrest.  Mr Mousavi, a leader of the Green Movement, lost to Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in the 2009 presidential election.

Do you have a question about tomorrow's US State of the Union address? http://bbc.in/Y6d0kF    Join BBC North America Editor Mark Mardell today between 14:00 EST and 15:00 EST (19:00 GMT and 20:00 GMT) on his Twitter feed @BBCMarkMardell http://bbc.in/Y6d2Jv to find out more about the challenges Obama will face in his second term during a live Q&A session.     Find out more about how you can join the conversation http://bbc.in/Y6d0kF or ask your question in the comments section below.

Link Title: How to upload a video to World Have Your Say

Tell us what you thought of Benedict XVI papacy?  How does he compare to John Paul II?  Which part of the world do you think the next Pope should come from?  Just click on the link below and Ros Atkins will explain exactly how to upload your video comments.

Government troops in Mali are carrying out house-to-house searches in the northern city of Gao after running battles with Islamist rebels.    The rebels launched a surprise attack on Sunday, using wooden boats to cross the Niger River on Gao's outskirts, before pushing into the heart of the city.     French and Malian soldiers say they're in control of Gao after fighting the rebels.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21408339

French ministers are to hold talks with key players in the meat industry as the horsemeat scandal widens to up to 16 countries.  Seven French supermarket chains have withdrawn frozen beef meals made by Findus and Comigel.  The move followed the discovery that foods sold in Europe and the UK labelled as beef contained horsemeat.  The scandal has already had an impact on distributors in the UK, France, Sweden, Ireland and Romania.  Food products in a further 11 EU countries may be affected, it is feared.

In a shock announcement on Monday the Vatican said Pope Benedict XVI would resign as head of the Catholic Church on 28 February.     The reasons are not yet clear. He has faced considerable challenges in his career.    For latest updates go to our Live Page http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21409149    You can also see the full profile of Pope Benedict XVI by clicking  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11141340

The Pope is to resign at the end of this month in an entirely unexpected development, reports from the Vatican say.  The 85-year-old became Pope Benedict XVI in April 2005 following the death of Pope John Paul II.  At 78, Benedict XVI was one of the oldest new popes in history when he was elected.   The last Pope to resign willingly was  Celestine V in 1294 .  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21411304

The head of the Kumbh Mela organising committee in India, world's largest religious festival, has resigned a day after a stampede killed at least 36 people at the train station in the northern city of Allahabad.    Azam Khan said "Though the incident took place outside the Kumbh Mela premises, I take moral responsibility and resign as the in-charge of the Kumbh".    Most of the victims are said to be women.     Some 30 million Hindu pilgrims have been bathing where the rivers Ganga and Jamuna meet.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-21406879

With US authorities scrapping full-body scanners at security checkpoints, many wonder what the next advances in airport security will look like. See one potential “checkpoint of the future” on BBC Travel:

The outgoing commander of Nato forces in Afghanistan has said the alliance is on the road to winning the war.  Gen John Allen, who handed over to Gen Joseph Dunford on Sunday, said troops had gone "a long way" towards winning a counter-insurgency.  Gen Allen is set to be nominated as the alliance's supreme commander in Europe.

Here is a look at news and features from around the world for this Sunday:  - LAPD makes offer to fugitive suspect http://bbc.in/153rS95 - UK Horsemeat scandal: Focus switches to Romania http://bbc.in/153rS8Z - Tunisia party 'to leave government' http://bbc.in/153rS93 - Five dead on Canaries cruise ship http://bbc.in/153rR50 - Chinese 'ping-pong diplomacy' player dies http://bbc.in/153rS8V - 'Penguin-cam' gets up close and personal http://bbc.in/153rS8R - Is this the most beautiful railway station in the world? http://bbc.in/153rS8T

Link Title: In pictures: Lunar New Year celebrations
Message: PHOTO GALLERY:  Millions of people are celebrating Lunar New Year, also known as Chinese New Year, the most important annual holiday in much of Asia.  The new year began in China at midnight, with firework displays and family gatherings.  It marked the opening of the year of the snake, taking over from the dragon.  The snake has a mixed reputation in China. It's associated with wisdom, beauty and intelligence but also pride and anger.

Nasa's Curiosity Mars rover has finally drilled deep enough into a rock to acquire a powdered sample for analysis.  The fine grey material from the 6cm-hole will be sieved and inspected before being delivered to the robot's onboard labs in the coming days.  It will represent a historic first in planetary exploration - never before has the interior of a rock on another world been probed in such a way.  The US space agency said the drilling was an immense achievement. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21399857

Link Title: Kumbh Mela set for holiest day
Message: It's billed as the largest religious gathering on earth.   The Kumbh Mela - or Pitcher Festival - is taking place in northern India and tens of millions of pilgrims have converged on Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh to take part in it.   They'll bathe in the Ganges and Yamuna rivers, a practice Hindus believe cleanses them of their sins.  Are you taking part? Let us know   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-21395425

Here is our snapshot of this weekend's news from around the world:   - Blizzard paralyses north-east US and Atlantic Canada http://bbc.in/151ytAB - Chinese Year of Snake celebrations in Asia http://bbc.in/151yvZj - Tunisian PM pledges new government http://bbc.in/151ytAF - German minister quits over 'plagiarism' http://bbc.in/151yvIX - Horsemeat scandal: 'Tougher testing' ordered http://bbc.in/151yvZf - Rio street party draws 'more than 1.5m' http://bbc.in/151ytAD - Deadly rocket attack on Iranian exile camp in Iraq http://bbc.in/151ytkm - Delacroix painting defaced  http://bbc.in/151yvZh - A funny look at the world of news - 140 characters at a time http://bbc.in/151ytAH

Link Title: New life in Krakow's Jewish quarter
Message: After World War II, the Krakow neighbourhood of Kazimierz fell into neglect. Tourists visited only to see the place that Steven Spielberg used as a backdrop for the epic war movie Schindler’s List. But today, Kazimierz is experiencing a surprising cultural revival. BBC Travel explores the resurgence of a neighbourhood once thought of as “frozen in time”:

Do you have a big dream?   Join us on http://www.BBCNews.com on Monday 11 February 2013 for a new video series looking at people who dream big and go after their goals.   This week we'll meet Jason Lewis and hear about his thirteen year journey circling the world using only human power.   Check out the trailer below and join us on Monday for the full story.

Members of Tunisia's governing Islamist party, Ennahda, have called for a rally, a day after huge crowds attended a murdered opposition leader's funeral.  A post on the group's Facebook page urged people to gather at 14:00 (13:00 GMT) on Habib Bourguiba Avenue in the centre of the capital, Tunis.  The rally would defend the legitimacy of the National Constituent Assembly and fight against violence, it added.  Opposition supporters have blamed Ennahda for the death of Chokri Belaid.

Imagine spending more than 24 hours sitting on the hard seat of a smelly, slow-moving train, surrounded by crowds of people and unable to sleep.    The pain of travelling home for Chinese New Year is an annual rite of passage for millions in China.     Not to worry - this year China's eager entrepreneurs are rushing to solve travellers' problems with a variety of wacky solutions sold on the country's main shopping site, Taobao.com.    For more gadgets click here  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-21334002

‘Changing Fortunes’, our new TV and online series, continues today. The series examines the new patterns of wealth formed by our globalised world economy.    In today’s episode, the programme explores how China’s insatiable appetite for resources and the impact this has had on the prices for raw material has produced a boom for commodity rich countries such as Brazil, Russia and Africa. We meet the millionaires and billionaires who have benefitted, and pose the question: can they avoid the commodities curse?    Watch ‘Sitting on a Goldmine’, the latest episode of Changing Fortunes this weekend on TV and online:    http://www.bbc.com/specialfeatures/changingfortunes/episodes/sitting-on-a-goldmine/

Hadiya Pendleton, a 15-year-old girl who performed at President Obama's inauguration days before being shot dead in a Chicago city park, will be buried today.  Tonight on BBC World News America, Steve Kingstone speaks with Hadiya's parents about gun violence and their hopes for change.   In other news from around the world:  - Tunisia mourns http://bbc.in/XXD29V - EU leaders agree to 3% budget cut http://bbc.in/XXD0if - Earliest placental mammal ancestor pinpointed http://bbc.in/XXD0yD - Afghan youth orchestra on escaping their old lives http://bbc.in/XXD29R  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/XXD29P

The hunt for a fired Los Angeles policeman accused of a shooting rampage has moved to a snowy mountain range 80 miles (128km) east of the city http://bbc.in/14Ytlxp  Search teams combed Big Bear Lake for Christopher Dorner, 33, after his torched truck was found by a ski area - the huge manhunt now spans California, Nevada, Arizona and northern Mexico.  Protection teams are guarding 40 individuals who are believed to be targets http://bbc.in/14Ytlxj

Now if you're wondering where we humans came from take a look at the image below.    Scientists say it's the earliest ancestor of most mammals living today.     An artist's impression of course, but it's the result of an international effort mapping out thousands of physical traits and genetic clues to trace the lineage of all the mammals known as placental.     And this little furry creature, apparently, was an insect-eater.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21350900

The flurries are falling around the US north-east, which is braced for a "potentially historic" storm that could see up to 3ft (91cm) of snow in some areas http://bbc.in/14Y7pST  Power cuts and transport chaos are expected as blizzards from the Great Lakes descend on parts of New England.  The US forecast from BBC Weather http://bbc.in/14Y7o1k

Link Title: Will we ever… simulate the human brain?
Message: A billion-dollar project claims it will recreate the human brain in just 10 years. But detractors say it is impossible. Who do you think is right? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130207-will-we-ever-simulate-the-brain

Link Title: Yemen blames Iran after weapons haul
Message: Yemen's president has called on Iran to stop backing armed groups in his country after coastguards seized a ship carrying missiles and rockets.  Abd-Rabbu Mansour Hadi's message came amid speculation the weapons originated in the Iran.  Tehran has denied any connection to the weapons; Yemen has asked the UN Security Council to investigate.  The Sanaa government fears Iran is working with separatists and rebels in the south to destabilise the country.

WATCH:   The Bolshoi Ballet has been in the spotlight recently but not because of its dancing.    Three weeks ago the company's artistic director was injured in an acid attack. And today the plot has thickened.   One of the companies principle dancers, Nikolai Tsiskaridze, has accused the management of carrying out a campaign to discredit him.   He's now calling on the Russian government to sack the theatre's entire management.

On World Have Your Say at 15GMT, we'll look at the situation in Tunisia following  the assassination of opposition leader Chokri Belaid.   Thousands of mourners have gathered in the Tunisian capital, Tunis, ahead of his funeral.   We'll speak to Tunisians both inside and outside the country about the state of post-revolution Tunisia.

Link Title: China: 200m on the move for New Year
Message: In China itself, hundreds of millions of people, equal to the population of Brazil, are on the move to celebrate the new year with their families this weekend.  Will you be celebrating the Chinese New Year?   If so tell us how you plan to celebrate it and what you hope for the new year.

Air Asia says it will offer baby-free "quiet zones" on its flights so that adults can get some peace and quiet. But it will come at  a price.    Sound like a good idea to you?   Would you pay extra to be in the "quiet zone"?    Have you ever been on a flight with children running down the isles or with screaming babies?    Should all planes and trains follow suit, or do adults need to learn to live with child passengers?    Send us your comments and we'll share some of them on Impact with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19728508

A suicide bomber has blown himself up in the northern Mali town of Gao - the country's first such case, sources say.  The attacker approached a group of soldiers on a motorbike before detonating an explosive belt, injuring one of them, a Malian officer told AFP.  Gao is the most populous city in northern Mali, which was captured by Islamist militants last year.
Lecturer Berny Sebe argues that the murder of opposition politician Chokri Belaid in Tunisia shows that hardline religious politics is gaining ground.  Do you agree ?

Nasa's Mars rover Curiosity has turned its drill in rock for the first time http://bbc.in/14WrY24  Soon, Curiosity will be commanded to drill up to 5cm into rock to obtain a powdered sample that can be delivered to the vehicle's onboard labs.

"Of course he knows what he is doing - we trained him." http://bbc.in/14W7Ehc  Police in Los Angeles, California have launched a huge manhunt for Christopher Dorner, a sacked officer and former US Navy reservist, who is suspected of killing three people, including a former colleague http://bbc.in/14W7E0W  Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck says the situation is "extremely worrisome and scary, especially to the police officers involved".

Do you eat lunch at your desk? http://bbc.in/14VVWDt  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at the 54% of office workers that dine in front of a computer and take a look at other news from around the world, including:  - Brennan grilled on drones http://bbc.in/14VVWDx - Crisis in Tunisia deepens http://bbc.in/14VVUeK - 'Widespread' doping in Australia http://bbc.in/14VVWTN - Michelle Rhee on education in America  http://bbc.in/14VVUeE  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/14VVUeI

Is education a social issue or an economic issue?   Michelle Rhee, the former chancellor of the Washington, DC public school system, stopped by the BBC News Washington Bureau today to discuss her new book and the state of education in the US.   Check out this clip from her visit and tell us what you think in the comments section below.   Join us tonight on BBC World News America for the complete interview.

AUDIO/VISUAL:   The extinction of an animal species always brings finality, but in the wake of the demise of species other creatures can prosper. More than 99% of the species which once roamed our planet no longer exist, yet a rich range of plants and animals survived.    In a new exhibition - Extinction: Not the end of the world? - the Natural History Museum in London explores how extinction can have a long-lasting effect on other creatures, and looks at those animals facing an uncertain future in the 21st Century. Take a look with exhibition developer Alex Fairhead.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21351017

Child sex abuse victims in India are dismissed, ignored and mistreated.   That's the conclusion of a damning new report by the pressure group Human Rights Watch.   It's accused India of failing to tackle the issue especially in its state run care home and schools.

Tunisia's political crisis is deepening after the assassination of a leading opposition leader earlier this week.  The killing of anti-Islamist politician Chokri Belaid sparked violent protests. The prime minister then announced plans for a new, technocratic government.  But the ruling Islamist party Ennahda rejected the move, saying Hamadi Jebali "did not ask the opinion of his party".

Link Title: Boyfriends for hire to beat China's wedding pressure
Message: "I'm almost 30 but I'm still single."  "I'm under lots of pressure. My sisters and my relatives all ask me why I'm not married. When they call me, I'm scared to pick up the phone."   The Chinese women are turning to "boyfriend renting" websites to avoid family demands about marriage.  The pressure for singles to settle increases around Chinese New Year celebrations.

Link Title: Iran rebuffs direct US nuclear talks
Message: Iran's supreme leader has dismissed a US offer of one-to-one talks on Tehran's nuclear programme.  Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a speech posted online that the US was proposing talks while "pointing a gun at Iran".  On Saturday, US Vice-President Joe Biden suggested direct talks, separate to the wider international discussions due to take place later this month.  But the US widened sanctions on Iran on Wednesday, aiming to tighten a squeeze on Tehran's ability to spend oil cash.

Australian sports fans are furious from the findings of a government investigation, which has found widespread use of banned drugs across a range of professional sports.   The year-long study by the Australian Crime Commission concluded that the doping was facilitated by sports scientists, coaches and medical staff and that some illegal drugs were distributed by organised crime.   In response to the report Sports Minister Kate Lundy said  "If you want to cheat, we will catch you, if you want to fix a match, we will catch you".  We want to hear from you.   After the Lance Armstrong doping scandal and now this do you feel cheated?    Do you have faith in sports today?  In general is there too much pressure on winning at all costs?  We'll use some of your comments on our GMT and Impact programmes.

Do you miss the excitement of London 2012? Good news - we are just one year away from the opening of the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia http://bbc.in/14SMLUh  The BBC's Daniel Sandford takes a look at how the host region is being transformed by the most expensive games ever http://bbc.in/14SMLUf

What will the elimination of Saturday mail service mean for consumers?   The US Postal Service plans to end Saturday delivery of first-class mail by August, in its latest cost-cutting drive http://bbc.in/14SvhHw  The move would save about $2bn (£1.3bn) a year, according to the agency.

Campaigners in India say tens of thousands of women are having unnecessary hysterectomies, after being targeted by doctors looking to cash in on their vulnerability. Some of the women were told they would get cancer if they didn't have the operation. The BBC's Jill McGivering went to Rajasthan to meet some of the women http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21297606

How do the sands of the Sahara give life thousands of miles away in the Amazon jungle? Find out in BBC Future's latest episode of the Power of Nature: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130205-sahara-life-giving-sands

Angry protests have broken out in Tunisia after the opposition leader was assassinated.  Shokri Belaid was shot twice in the head and the neck outside his home in Tunis.  Mr Belaid was a prominent secularist and a critic of the moderate Islamist party which leads the government.

The CIA has been operating a secret airbase for unmanned drones in Saudi Arabia for the past two years.    The US media had known of its existence, but hadn't reported it until now.  The base was set up to hunt for Al Qaeda members in Yemen.  Senior US government officials had said they were concerned the disclosure would damage counter-terrorism efforts.

For all you sports fans around the world we're pleased to announce the BBC's new global sports app.    You'll be able to keep up-to-date with the sports you love on your mobile devices.      The app will include all the latest scores, stats, schedules and standings, as well as expert commentary from BBC journalists around the world.    At the moment it's available on iPhone and iPod touch devices, with an Android version to follow soon.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/21352245

Hello, it's Mishal.  Among our talking points on Impact today - religious faith, or the lack of it.   Have a look at the '10 Virtues' video below, published as a 'Manifesto for Atheists'.   If this is enough to lead a good life? Or do we still need religion?  We'll use your thoughts as part of our discussion at 1330 GMT.

Security guards have seized a man who tried to hit Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad with a shoe as he visited a mosque in the Egyptian capital Cairo.   The shoe did not appear to hit Mr Ahmadinejad, but the president made a hasty retreat.   Video of the incident shows a man shouting "coward" as he strikes out.  It is not clear what the motive was - some reports suggested it was against Iran's support for Syria's government.  Showing the sole of a shoe is a grave insult in the Arab world.

Austrian Felix Baumgartner fell even faster during his historic skydive from the edge of space last October than was originally thought http://bbc.in/11S107w  Analysis has revealed that the daredevil attained a speed of 1,357.6km/h (843.6mph) when he leapt from his stratospheric balloon.

Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny has apologised for the stigma and conditions suffered by women who were inmates of the Magdalene laundries http://bbc.in/11HP4tA  On tonight's BBC World News America we'll look at the apology and other news from around the world, including:  - The case for drones killing Americans http://bbc.in/11HP4JY - The latest from Mali http://bbc.in/11HP4K4 - Gay marriage in the UK  http://bbc.in/11HP2BZ - Ahmadinejad visits Egypt http://bbc.in/11HP4K0 - The king in the car park revealed  http://bbc.in/11HP2Sm - Restoring the memories of Sandy victims http://bbc.in/11HP4K8  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/11HP4tF

Artificial organs ... synthetic blood ... functioning limbs ...  How far can prosthetists get in rebuilding a human being? http://bbc.in/11R6mzO  Check out this £500,000 human-like machine on display at the Science Museum in London and see how different technologies designed to help physically handicapped people can work together.

President Barack Obama has urged the people of Kenya, where his father was born, to avoid violence and intimidation in next month's elections.     He posted a message on YouTube, which begins with a greeting in Swahili in which he said that the polls were a chance for Kenyans to unite and show they were not just members of tribes or ethnic groups, but a proud nation.    Kenya's disputed presidential election in 2007 descended into violence in which more than 1,000 were killed.    Kenyans head to the polls on 4 March.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21341868

Bulgaria has accused the Lebanese militant movement Hezbollah of being behind a bomb attack that killed 5 Israeli tourists in Burgas last year.  Interior Minister Tsvetan Tsvetanov said: "There is data showing the financing and connection between Hezbollah and the two suspects."  An official investigation has found an Australian and a Canadian to be among the three suspects behind the bus bombing.   The conclusions could pave the way for the European Union to brand Hezbollah a terrorist organisation. Hezbollah has denied being involved in the attack.

Link Title: African Cup of Nations heats up
Message: VIDEO:  As African Cup of Nations enters the semi-final stages the BBC's Peter Okwoche has been to Durban's beach zone to find out what Mali fans think of their upcoming match against Nigeria.  The snag, well Peter's from Nigeria which hopefully won't damage the BBC's reputation for impartiality ... too much.  He's also a very brave man.  When Peter wants to do something - well he dives in....literally. You must see this video.

Link Title: First witness for Delhi rape trial
Message: An Indian man who was beaten while his female friend was raped and tortured on a bus, has given evidence in her murder trial - this is the case that has gripped India for weeks.   The witness arrived in a wheelchair to the Delhi court where five men stand accused.   A sixth defendant is being tried separately in a juvenile court. All of the defendants are pleading not guilty.

There has been widespread anger, over recent months, in China over officials using fake identities to buy multiple properties.    However, this case seems to top them all.    Zhao Haibin, a former local police chief, allegedly bought a total of 192 houses with fake identity papers.    State media reports that Mr Zhao has admitted having another ID, but says he only managed flats owned by his brother.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-21333133

Hello, it's Mishal.     Impact goes on air just as British MPs debate gay marriage.     Wherever you are, we'd like to know your views (please no swearing or using derogatory terms) - take a look at the map below which shows which parts of the world have moved in this direction.     We'll be discussing from 1300 GMT today.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21321731

Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has become the first Iranian president to visit Egypt since the Islamic revolution in 1979.  "I will try to pave the ground for developing co-operation between Iran and Egypt," Mr Ahmadinejad was quoted as saying by Iran's state news agency, Irna, before leaving Tehran.

Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has become the first Iranian president to visit Egypt since the Islamic revolution in 1979.  "I will try to pave the ground for developing co-operation between Iran and Egypt," Mr Ahmadinejad was quoted as saying by Iran's state news agency, Irna, before leaving Tehran.

What can rocks on Mars tell us about the universe?  Curiosity, Nasa's Mars rover, has used its drill system for the first time http://bbc.in/11LFhy4  The drill bit can be seen touching the ground in this photo from the US space agency. While other rovers have been able to "scrub" rocks, Curiosity is the first to carry the capability to drill inside them.

Police in the US state of Alabama have killed a hostage-taker who kept a five-year-old boy in a storm shelter for nearly a week, US media report http://bbc.in/11D9YtJ  The boy is reported to be alive.

"My mission is the same - to help people. And I will do that." http://bbc.in/11KUHT2  Malala Yousafzai, the schoolgirl who was shot and wounded by the Taliban in Pakistan after campaigning for womens' rights, says she has been given a 'second life'.  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll speak to Malala and look at other news from around the world, including:  - Afghanistan and Pakistan aim for peace http://bbc.in/11KUHTb - Match-fixing & The Champions League http://bbc.in/11KUG1w - The king and the car park http://bbc.in/11KUHCH  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/11KUG1m

How would you react if your child's video message to his grandparents became a web sensation? http://bbc.in/11Cmn1a  Join the BBC's Mishal Husain as she meets Dylan Hall, the boy in Wales who has become a star in Thailand with his version of the alphabet song, and his father.

Link Title: Should people be off on Fridays?
Message: The Gambia has shortened the work week, making Friday a day of rest.   President Jammeh wants the extra rest day to "allow Gambians to devote more time to prayers, social activities and agriculture".  We want to hear from you:  Do you think this is the perfect pattern for a working week?  Tell us where you're writing from and how many hours a week do you work in your job?  If you worked a four day week what would you do with the extra day?

The leaders of Afghanistan and Pakistan have said they will try to achieve a peace settlement for Afghanistan within six months.   Their joint pledge came at talks hosted by the British PM, David Cameron, just outside London.   The two leaders said they'd achieved an unprecedented level of co-operation, in the talks which focused on how to secure peace across the Afghan-Pakistan border.

VIDEO:   The 15 year old Pakistani girl who was shot by the Taliban has been speaking for the first time on camera about what happened.     She says that she is "getting better, day by day''.  Malala Yousufzai was known in Pakistan as a campaigner for girls' education. She was shot at point blank range on her school bus and eventually flown to the UK for specialist medical treatment.

The Mars rover Curiosity has used its drill system for the first time.  The robot's tool bit hammered briefly, without rotation, into a flat slab of rock on the floor of Gale Crater, the huge bowl where it landed last August. Although previous rovers have scrubbed the surface of rocks, Curiosity is the first to carry the capability to drill inside them.  US space agency (Nasa) engineers are taking a step-by-step approach to the procedure. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21312821

Europol, the pan-European police organisation, say they have unearthed what they are calling football match fixing on a scale not seen before.   The scam involves millions of dollars in bribes, hundreds of games affected and a crime syndicate based in Asia.   Results in some of the most high profile matches, including the Champions League, are now suspect.

Hi, Ros Atkins here.  I'm going to visiting the BBC Vietnamese Service during Impact later to talk about the attached story.   It concerns 22 people in Vietnam who've been jailed between 10 years and life on subversion charges.   There's a lot of interest in this, but also a lot of questions about who they are, and the laws and politics behind their prosecution.   I'll be joined by a colleague at the Vietnamese Service who can answer any questions you have, and we'll get you as many as answers as possible.   Please post your questions here or send them to me  http://www.twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins.   The item scheduled for 1340GMT though these things can shift. Speak to you later.

French warplanes have carried out air strikes in Mali's far north as they try to strengthen their hold on the former rebel  town of Kidal.  30 French jets targeted Islamist militants' training and communication centres around Tessalit  a mountainous area near the Algerian border.  There have been fears that the rebels could use mountain bases to re-group and launch a new offensive.

Tokyo has emerged from the dark days following the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, re-asserting its position as a hotspot for Asian business travel. You can see proof of this in the skyline, which has a slew of recently-opened luxury hotels and high-end restaurants. BBC Travel has your guide to the best of each:

The White House tweets a picture of Barack Obama skeet-shooting - seemingly to settle a row about whether the president had fired a gun before.    Mr Obama recently told the The New Republic magazine: "Up at Camp David, we do skeet shooting all the time."    The photo, dated 4 August 2012, shows Mr Obama standing in jeans, polo shirt, sunglasses and earphones, aiming a rifle that has a smoking barrel.    He is due in Minneapolis on Monday to discuss his gun-control proposals.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21309245

Iran has unveiled a new home-made combat aircraft, which officials say can evade radar.  The single-seat Qaher F313 (Dominant F313) is the latest design produced by Iran's military since it launched the Azarakhsh (Lightning), in 2007.  President Mahmoud Ahmedinejad said it had "almost all the positive features" of the world's most sophisticated jets.  He said the "development of the Iranian nation's military power is... for deterrence and defensive purposes".
Is the Chinese government restricting Tibetan travel? A new report claims Tibetans are not being reissued passports - further heightening tensions in this region. BBC Travel has the full story:

Wealth is changing hands and crossing continents.     Changing Fortunes, our new TV and online series starting today, explores how the phenomenal speed of Chinese and Indian economic growth means that before mid-century these economies are expected to become the world’s largest.     Watch Changing Fortunes ‘From East To West’ on TV and online   today.    http://www.bbc.com/specialfeatures/changingfortunes/episodes/east-to-west/ (Not available in the UK)
Five men plead not guilty to the rape and murder of a student in a Delhi bus in December, in a case which caused outrage across India.

A quarter of a million Twitter users have had their accounts hacked in the latest of a string of high-profile internet security breaches.  Affected users have had passwords invalidated and have been sent emails informing them.  Mr Lord said the attack "was not the work of amateurs".  He said it appeared similar to recent attacks on the New York Times and others.  The US newspaper reported this week that their computer systems had been breached by China-based hackers

Russian President Vladimir Putin will lead tributes marking 70 years since the Battle of Stalingrad, seen as a turning point of World War II.  The city of Stalingrad, which was renamed Volgograd in 1961, will regain its wartime name for the event, following a council decision.  Around one million people are thought to have died in the battle, as Soviet troops defeated the Germans.  It is considered one of the major turning points of World War II.
South Africa's Shaheed Ebrahim, owner of the Escape to the Cape tour company, won his country's 2011/2012 Emerging Tourism Entrepreneur of the Year award. How did he outsmart the competition?

Ed Koch was known for speaking his mind and taking on the critics but but after a decade of leading the Big Apple in the 1980s he is also remembered for saving the city from near financial ruin.   Koch died today at the age of 88 from congestive heart failure and the tributes have been pouring in.

A Japanese pop star has shaved her head and offered a filmed apology after breaking her management firm's rules by spending a night with her boyfriend.  A sobbing Minami Minegishi apologised to her fans and said she did not want to leave the band AKB48, in the video seen by millions on YouTube.  The production company behind AKB48 said Minegishi, 20, had failed to abide by its cardinal rule - no dating.  But fans have defended her, saying she is entitled to a normal life.

VIDEO:  It is one of the most recognisable buildings in Miami.   But only a few people know that behind its walls, hides one of the world's largest data centres which redirects most of the digital information that comes from Latin America.  BBC Mundo's Thomas Sparrow visited the centre and and found out why Florida became the ideal location for this modern hub of digital communication.

From student activist to globetrotting stateswoman. Has her political journey come to an end or is there more to come?    BBC state department correspondent, Kim Ghattas finds out.    http://bbc.in/TlbwEV    And you can watch "Our World - Hillary: America's Diplomat in Chief" on BBC World News/Cable TV at 20.30GMT (1530EST/1230PST) today.

We are fascinated by the rich as never before.   Changing Fortunes, our new TV and online series starting on Saturday 2nd of February, examines the new patterns of wealth formed by our globalised world economy.   We look at the key trends and travel to meet some of the innovators, entrepreneurs and business successes whose stories offer us a window into the rapidly changing nature of wealth today.   Watch the TV ad below and tune in to Changing Fortunes tomorrow on TV and online.

It was a massive, deadly explosion that destroyed part of a bridge and sent cars plummeting 30 metres to the ground.   At least 9 people are dead in central China after a truckload of fireworks exploded.   Rescuers in Henan province are still desperately searching for survivors.

An Indian court has ruled that Bollywood superstar Salman Khan should face a charge of culpable homicide for a hit-and-run incident 10 years ago.  In September 2002, he allegedly drove his car into a bakery in Mumbai city, killing a street sleeper.  The actor is currently being tried for the lesser offence of "death caused by negligence". He could face 10 years in prison for the more serious charge.  He denies the charges and has said he will challenge the latest order.

Link Title: Analysis: Strike adds complexity to tense region
Message: On WHYS TV today:   This week, WHYS had the chance to ask Hillary Clinton questions during her global town hall debate.   Tune in at 1500GMT to hear what she had to say. We'll also discuss the continuing crisis in Syria  after this week's attack by Israeli fighter jets and more killings in Aleppo.

Link Title: Explosion at US embassy in Turkey
Message: There's been an explosion in front of the U.S. Embassy in the Turkish capital of Ankara killing two people and wounding one other.  Ankara's Governor has said that initial investigations suggest a suicide bomber is behind the attack with other officials calling it a suspected terrorist attack.   The bomb appears to have exploded inside the security checkpoint at the entrance to the embassy.   The US Ambassador to Turkey has said that one of those killed was a Turkish member of staff. It appears the other person reported killed is the bomber.

VIDEO REPORT: Australia's Great Barrier Reef is considered one of the world's natural wonders.   Now the government there is taking steps to beef up its protection of the coral reef try to prevent it losing its UN World Heritage status.    The UN's cultural body, UNESCO raised concerns about the reef last year when it sent a team to Queensland to investigate the likely impact of expanded port development and shipping along the coast.

The search for survivors of an explosion at an office complex in Mexico City continued through the night. Rescue workers with sniffer dogs searched through the debris left by the blast at the headquarters of the state oil company, Pemex.   At least 25 people were killed, more than a hundred were hurt.  The company is trying to establish what caused the explosion in a building right next to the its skyscraper. The area was especially busy when it happened because Pemex staff were changing shifts at the time.

"I didn't choose violence I chose to do politics in a country where politics involves violence" http://bbc.in/11lcyoc  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll meet the Dutch woman who went to Colombia as a language student and ended up fighting for the FARC.   We'll also look at other news from around the world, including:  - The latest on Israel's airstrike on Syria  http://bbc.in/11lcyEz - Mali's militants 'in disarray' http://bbc.in/11lcAfN - Hagel's hearing gets heated  http://bbc.in/11lcAfP - New York Times 'hit by hackers from China' http://bbc.in/11lcyog - Beckham and Beyonce have big days  http://bbc.in/11lcAfG  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/11lcyoa

The White House has warned Syria not to transfer weapons to Hezbollah in neighbouring Lebanon http://bbc.in/11kYhba  The warning came amid contradictory claims of an Israeli strike in Syria.  Israel has maintained silence about the incident, but Syria has made a formal complaint to the UN.

Artist Kelvin Okafor, whose accurate drawings are often mistaken for photographs, visited us here at BBC World News today and took the chance to sketch Focus on Africa host Komla Dumor. The 27-year old graduate of Middlesex University has been generating buzz in galleries and online for his portraits. Take a look at his work and tell us what you think http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-21234214

For thousands of Pakistani women being chosen as a bride for a man living in the UK is a dream come true, the chance to begin a family in a country that offers far greater opportunities than they would find at home. But for many that dream has turned into a nightmare.    A growing number of these women are claiming they've been forcibly separated from their children in the UK and left abandoned in Pakistan by their British husbands.   That's according to lawyers, foreign office officials and charities.

Link Title: Mali conflict: Timbuktu celebrates end of Islamist rule
Message: The French defence minister said that three weeks of French air strikes has left Islamist rebels in northern Mali scattered and in disarray.    Jean-Yves Le Drian said that some have fled the country, while others had made a tactical withdrawal to mountainous areas.  One of the towns they were driven from is the ancient trading city of Timbuktu where most people are once more enjoying life, following the end of militant Islamist rule.

Link Title: Beckham set to complete PSG move
Message: The rumours have been flying for months but finally, it seems, one of the most famous faces  in world football,  David Beckham is about to sign for a new club - Paris St Germain in France.   The former England football captain, who's 37, is having a medical today, and all being  well, he's expected  to  begin training with the club in the next fortnight. Beckham has been without a club since he left LA Galaxy in December .

VIDEO:  It's 70 years since the commander of the German forces at Stalingrad surrendered to the Soviet army. This weekend the city, since renamed Volgograd, will commemorate the event.  One of the turning points of World War II, the Battle of Stalingrad is still regarded as one of the most brutal ever fought.   As many as a million soldiers are believed to have died in 6 months of intense urban warfare.     BBC's Moscow correspondent Daniel Sandford has been talking to some of the survivors.

United Nations report says Israeli settlements in the occupied territories violate the rights of Palestinians.  The report, by three UN human rights experts, claims settlements are systematically driving Palestinians off the land, and subjecting them to discrimination and intimidation on a daily basis.   Israel does not accept the findings, saying the report "will only hamper efforts to find a sustainable solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict".

Syria says its airspace was violated by Israeli jets that carried out a direct and targeted attack on a military research centre.  Russia has come to Syria's backing - saying the raid, if confirmed, would be an unprovoked violation of Syrian sovereignty and the UN Charter.  But diplomats and security officials in the region say the air strike was actually on an arms convoy destined for Hezbollah in nearby Lebanon, underlining Israeli fears that Syrian missiles and chemical weapons could end up across the border and in the hands of the Hezbollah militants.

Hackers from China have "persistently" infiltrated the New York Times for the last four months, the US paper says.  It said the attacks coincided with its report into claims that the family of Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao had amassed a multi-billion dollar fortune.  The hackers used methods which have been "associated with the Chinese military" to target the emails of the report's writer, the paper said.

Do chain stores change the culture of a neighbourhood? http://bbc.in/11gZgck  On this week's edition of Altered States we meet residents of New York City's Lower East Side who are banding together to stop a 7-Eleven convenience store from opening in their community.

Surgeons are to operate on the skull of Pakistani teenager, Malala Yousufzai, who was shot in the head by the Taliban for promoting girls' education http://bbc.in/11gnhjP   Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll take a closer look at  Malala's surgery and other news from around the world, including:  - Israeli 'air strike on convoy on Syria-Lebanon border' http://bbc.in/11gnhjL - Giffords pleads for gun control http://bbc.in/11gnfs7 - Blackberry - reinvented http://bbc.in/11gnhjJ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/11gnfs9

"You must act. Be bold. Be courageous. Americans are counting on you." http://bbc.in/11fVPTi  Wounded former Representative Gabrielle Giffords has implored the US Congress to curb gun violence, at the first hearing on the issue this year on Capitol Hill. The Arizona Democrat, who was shot in the head in a 2011 attack that killed six people, said too many children were dying in shootings.  But the National Rifle Association told the Senate judiciary committee that gun control was not the answer.  Video: 'You must act' http://bbc.in/11fVRKX  Video: NRA says gun owners not to blame http://bbc.in/11fVQ9C  US guns in numbers http://bbc.in/11fVRKV  Would more guns save lives? http://bbc.in/11fVS1b  Sales up for US gun shops http://bbc.in/11fVPTk

A suspected tornado has reportedly overturned cars on a major highway and damaged buildings with people inside in the US state of Georgia http://bbc.in/11g6sRn  The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports there have been numerous emergency calls of trauma and injuries. Twisters also tore through Mississippi, Indiana and Tennessee on Wednesday, killing at least one person.

Link Title: SA tycoon donates half his wealth
Message: South Africa's richest man Patrice Motsepe announced that his family will contribute at least half of his $2.65 billion fortune to improve the lives of the poor  Mr. Motsepe said he was inspired to make this contribution by Bill and Melinda Gates as well as Warren Buffet who are part of the Giving Pledge which encourages billionaires to give the majority of their wealth to charitable causes.   Mr. Motsepe is Executive Chair of African Rainbow Minerals and has made much of his money from the mining sector.

INTERACTIVE:  Here in the UK you can't get away from stories about the rising cost of fuel. It's such a controversial topic that the Office of Fair Trading published a review today into whether reductions in crude oil prices were being passed on to people at the pump.     The conclusion is that they are being passed on and that the fuel market is competitive despite public mistrust. But across the world the fuel we put in our cars is pretty much the same, however the prices are not.     How much do you pay on fuel and how does it compare with what people are paying in other countries?     Find out by trying our online calculator by clicking on the link below    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21238363

Zimbabwe's Finance Minister Tendai Biti has said that the country only had $217 left in its public account last week after paying civil servants.  However, he said that the following day some $30m of revenue had been paid in.  Mr Biti told the BBC he made the revelation in order to emphasise that the government was unable to finance elections, not that it was insolvent.

We have only explored around 5% of our oceans and have already documented around a quarter of a million unique species. But before we have explored the other 95% we are starting to destroy parts of this valuable habitat. Find out why in the second part of the Power of Nature series over at BBC Future: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130129-blue-heart-of-the-planet (Picture courtesy of Science Photo Library)

VIDEO:   The writer Sir Salman Rushdie has criticised the Indian government's handling of the aftermath of the gang rape in Delhi.  Mr Rushdie, who is in India to promote his latest film, told the BBC young people needed to demand change.  He said women, particularly mothers who raise their sons in a certain way, had to take responsibility too.

A Dutch court has ordered Shell's Nigerian subsidiary to pay damages to one farmer, because it didn't do enough to prevent oil leakage.     But it rejected four other claims against Shell, in a landmark case brought by Friends of the Earth and Nigerian farmers from the Niger Delta region.     The farmers had accused the oil giant of poisoning fish ponds and farmland with leaking pipelines.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21258653

Link Title: Cameron to visit Algeria for talks
Message: Hi, Ros Atkins here.   David Cameron is going to be in Algeria later. It's the first visit by a British PM since Algerian independence, and of course the timing is related In Amenas hostage crisis.   I'll be joining Lucy in Impact live from the world's newsroom to take a detailed look at the political, economic and social status quo in Algeria.   If you have a specific question about Algeria you'd like to ask the colleagues I'll be with, please post it here. I'll do my best to use as many as time allows. Speak to you later on.  (you're also welcome to tweet questions to twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins).

Germany's biggest health insurer, Barmer,  has said there had been a big rise in the number of children in Germany diagnosed with Attention Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder, ADHD, and this was increasingly being treated with drugs.     They have said that "effective parenting might be a better option" and that pills "should not be the first choice".     ADHD prevalence has grown significantly throughout the world in the last two decades.    What is your opinion?     Do you think there is a danger of creating a generation of children who are dependent on pills to keep them under control?   Or do you believe that pills are more effective?

Link Title: South Korea set for space launch
Message: South Korea has launched a rocket in its 3rd attempt to place a satellite in space from its own soil.  Live television broadcasts showed the 140-tonne Korea Space  Launch Vehicle blasting off and clearing the launch pad at the Naro Space Center on the south coast.   It now gains entry to an elite global space club that includes Asian powers China, India and Japan.

"I just want to get the most out of these arms, and just as goals come up, knock them down and take it absolutely as far as I can" http://bbc.in/11a7fTK  The first US soldier to survive losing four limbs in Iraq has said he is looking forward to swimming and driving after having a double arm transplant at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland  His surgeon says it will take more than year to know how fully Mr Marrocco will be able to use the new arms.

"I counted on just one video, about 48 bodies" http://bbc.in/119SSig  The bodies of dozens of young men, all apparently summarily executed, have been found in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo, rebels and activists say.  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll look at this gruesome discovery on the banks of the Quwaiq river and other news from around the world, including:  - UK military personnel sent to West Africa http://bbc.in/119SPDa - Obama makes immigration reform push http://bbc.in/119SSia - The Who on playing Quadrophenia http://bbc.in/119SSic  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/119SPDg

"It was sheer horror. The emergency exits did not work, and then I lost my friend in the confusion. Then a girl died in my arms. I felt her heart stop beating." http://bbc.in/11aZcKY  Brazilian police have arrested four people in connection with a fire at a nightclub that killed 231 people in the southern city of Santa Maria on Sunday. A co-owner of the Kiss nightclub handed himself in to police on Monday afternoon for questioning.

Link Title: Bitter end to Spain's bumper olive years
Message: If you like to cook with olive oil, you might want to consider stocking up.    Spain is by far the biggest producer in the world, but olive farmers are saying that this year's crop is down by a massive 80 percent.   That could mean there's not enough olive oil to go around and that could mean higher prices.

In an unprecedented step, Israel has become the first country to refuse to attend a review by the United Nations Human Rights Council, prompting concern that its work could be undermined.
