"After a series of votes and statements and incidents we have decided to suspend our working relations with that body," Israeli foreign ministry spokesman Yigal Palmor told the Financial Times.  Israel claims the council is biased against it but many UN member states have sharply criticised Israel's actions, pointing out that the review process is universal, and all countries are expected to take part.

VIDEO: One of the big holes for Google maps has been North Korea - that is until now.    Eagle eyed watchers of the secretive state have noticed some more controversial details, including the inclusion of some of the countries infamous gulags, said to be home to over 150,000 inmates.     Google's chariman visited North Korea a few weeks ago and encouraged the nation to open itself up online.     Could this be the start?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21226623

Activists in Syria say they have found the bodies of 59 men in a river-bed in Aleppo.  A video posted online, that can't be independently verified, shows the bodies of the men many with their hands bound.   The video appears to have been filmed in the Bustan al-Qasr region of Aleppo that has been hotly contested since last July.

Would you like to win a laptop worth almost $4000? Are you a budding animator or illustrator? Do you know any?     If the answer is yes then you should make sure to enter our global competition as part of 'What If' season.     The BBC is looking into the future, finding out what it holds for health, education, transport and even love.     What does the future look like to you? We want to know and we want you to share your vision of the world.     For all the information on how to enter just click here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21069026

France's politicians are defending the health of its economy after Labour Minister Michel Sapin described the state as "totally bankrupt".  Finance Minister Pierre Moscovici said later that Mr Sapin's comments were not "appropriate".  "France is a truly solvent country, France is a truly credible country," Mr Moscovici added.  President Francois Hollande has promised to reduce its deficit to below 3% of output this year from 4.5%.

Link Title: Dutch queen to abdicate for son
Message: People in the Netherlands are digesting the news that their Queen Beatrix is to abdicate,  after 33 years on the throne.    The eldest of her three sons, Crown-Prince Willem-Alexander will succeed her at the end of April.    In a television address, Queen Beatrix described her time as monarch as 'beautiful years'.  She turns 75 on Thursday.  Queen Beatrix is following recent tradition by abdicating, as her mother and grandmother did before her.   What do you think about the way that the Dutch royal family hands of the throne by abdicating?    Is it a good time for Queen Beatrix to abdicate?  Does it, and if so in which way, affect other royal families around the world?

10 endangered pygmy elephants have been found dead in a reserve in Malaysia, with officials saying they may have been poisoned.  The animals, which had all suffered internal bleeding, were found near each other over the space of three weeks.  In one instance, a three-month-old calf was found alongside the body of its mother, apparently trying to wake her.  Sabah Environmental Minister Masidi Manjun said it was "a sad day for conservation and Sabah".

Australia is battling flooding in two states, as rescue teams worked to evacuate people from inundated areas.    In Queensland, more than 1,000 people were plucked to safety in the city of Bundaberg as the Burnett River burst its banks, flooding 2,000 homes.    In New South Wales there are concerns that the Clarence River, at a record high, could flood the city of Grafton.    Tropical Cyclone Oswald, which triggered the flooding, is now heading out to sea south of Sydney.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21231199

Link Title: Dutch queen to abdicate for son
Message: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands has announced she is abdicating in favour of her eldest son Prince Willem-Alexander.   Speaking on television, Queen Beatrix said Prince Willem-Alexander would become king on April 30th. The Queen, who will celebrate her seventy-fifth birthday later this week, has been on the throne since nineteen-eighty.   Last year she suffered a personal tragedy after her middle son Prince Johan Friso was hit by an avalanche during a holiday in Austria. He's been in a coma since the accident.  [This is a re-post after a previous version gave the wrong date of abdication, for which apologies]

Link Title: The family feuds sparked by booming Indian land values
Message: The dramatic rise in the value of land in India has resulted in a growing number of families of Indian origin returning from the UK to cash in on their inheritances.   But many discover that the land is either sold, occupied or disputed - resulting in bitter feuds and lengthy legal battles.

Brazil nightclub fire: What happened?    Brazil has declared three days of national mourning after 231 people were killed in the deadliest fire the country has seen in five decades.    The blaze at Kiss nightclub in the southern city of Santa Maria reportedly started after a member of a band used pyrotechnics on stage.    Here is what we know so far about what happened.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21196209

Is it a sign of strength or a sign of desperation?   Egyptian President Mohammad Morsi has imposed a month long state of emergency and a curfew in three cities after a fifth day of violence.    His opponents, who've been invited to talks later today, say what's happening is a return to the strong arm tactics of dictatorship.    Two years since the great uprising many Egyptians say they are still waiting for the new dawn they were promised.

Hello - our Impact discussion today focuses on a controversial new book that says China is engaged in 'a silent conquest of our planet' and questions the huge loans it makes to the developing world, especially Africa.     The authors believe it's the elite rather than local communities who benefit from the investment.      What do you think?   Mishal

In Brazil's southern city of Santa Maria families of those who died in a nightclub fire have come to identify the bodies of their loved ones.    233 people died in the inferno - started, it's thought, when a rock band let off fireworks.   Though the focus is on grieving there are many questions for the authorities.  Not least whether the safety culture is fit for a country due to host the Olympics is less than four years.

Now what does it take to be British?   If you're a new immigrant - the questions you'll face in a UK Citizenship test have been revamped with - what the guide calls - a focus on the events and people who have made Britain great.  The UK Immigration minister Mark Harper said: "The new book rightly focuses on values and principles at the heart of being British. Instead of telling people how to claim benefits it encourages participation in British life."  So if you plan to take the test you can expect to be tested on figures from Queen Elizabeth the first to Margaret Thatcher. And culturally your knowledge will range from William Shakespeare to the Rolling Stones.   For questions please click on the link below. In the meantime let us know what you think.  What do you make of the new revamped version? Are the questions more relevant?  Do you think that questions are too easy?

French-led troops in Mali have taken control of the airport in the key northern city of Timbuktu, French military officials say.  The troops encountered no resistance as they headed towards the city, a senior officer with the Malian army told AFP news agency.  French and Malian troops have been pushing north in their offensive against Islamist rebels.

From Germany’s Black Forest where the Grimm brothers set their dark fairy tales to the Mexican island wilderness where trees are strung with dismembered dolls, BBC Travel visits the forests that make haunted houses look tame by comparison:
The BBC's Jorn Madslien joins top level finance professionals and industrialists for a game of fantasy investment in Davos.

Countries ranked “the best ethical destinations” were rated by social welfare, environmental protection and human rights. Costa Rica, Ghana, Samoa and Uruguay made the top 10 list – BBC Travel has the rest here:

Here is our look at this weekend's news from around the world: - Egypt : Death sentences spark violence http://bbc.in/10PlBIU - Anonymous hacks US agency http://bbc.in/10PlBJ0 - French-led soldiers in control of airport in Mali http://bbc.in/10PlBIY - Australian Open: Azarenka beats Li Na http://bbc.in/10PlDkf - Afghanistan: Suicide attack strikes market http://bbc.in/10PlBJ4 - Prison riot in Venezuela turns deadly http://bbc.in/10PlDk5 - UK: Protests against hospital closure  http://bbc.in/10PlBJ6 - The funny side of US news http://bbc.in/10PlDAx

It is almost a year since government forces in Syria began a sustained assault on the strategic city of Homs to drive out opposition fighters http://bbc.in/10TQjWj  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll join Lyse Doucet as she returns to the city. We'll also look at other news from around the world, including:  - Egypt opposition in clashes on revolution anniversary http://bbc.in/10TQmRW -  Apple, Samsung and the smartphone dogfight http://bbc.in/10TQkcA  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10TQn8e

"We feel our revolution has been stolen" http://bbc.in/10KCuVc  Egyptian opposition supporters are protesting across the country on the second anniversary of the uprising that swept Hosni Mubarak from power.

Herod the Great? The biblical figure is best known as a tyrant who butchered the male children of Bethlehem in an attempt to prevent the birth of Jesus, but he was also a visionary respected for his ambitious building projects. More than two millennia later, Herod remains a divisive figure: an upcoming Israeli exhibit examining his life has been met by Palestinian protest. BBC Travel investigates: http://bit.ly/11TRNQo

Police have blocked major roads and are using tear gas and stun grenades against anti-government protesters in the Bahraini capital, Manama.  Protesters had responded to a call by opposition parties to march in the city.  Hundreds of youths had taken to the streets of the old market district of Manama, chanting "no dialogue with killers", an opposition source said.

The origins of HIV can be traced back millions rather than tens of thousands of years, research suggests.  A genetic study shows HIV-like viruses arose in African monkeys and apes 5 million to 12 million years ago.  HIV affects 34 million people worldwide.

Traffic gridlock has paralysed Athens as Greek commuters struggle to work by car, amid a public transport strike.  Early on Friday police stormed a metro train depot, breaking up a workers' sit-in. Police sealed off the entrance.  Other transport workers have joined the striking metro workers in solidarity and a big rally is expected shortly.  The conservative-led government used an emergency law to threaten the strikers with arrest unless they resumed work. The row is over a planned pay cut.

A mother in the northern Indian state of Rajasthan has been arrested for allegedly selling her daughter for 650,000 rupees ($12,000).  The mother said she sold the girl to raise money to repay a fine of 450,000 rupees ($8,383) imposed on her by the village council, police said.  Police say the girl was sold a month ago, but the crime came to light when she tried to run away from the couple.

I'm holding a copy of a new book - "Raising Girls" by Steve Biddulph.. he's the man who wrote the best-selling book - "Raising Boys" many years ago.     You would not believe the discussion it has provoked, on the train on the way into work and now in the newsroom.     People’s questions and concerns seem urgent - Why are girls growing up so fast? What do I do about body-image, bullying, eating disorders, sex?     We're talking to Steve on Impact today and I'd love to hear your thoughts and also get a sense of whether the issues are the same the world over.     So, please get in touch and see you soon.. Lucy

Demonstrators are gathering in Cairo's Tahrir Square ahead of the second anniversary of the uprising that led to the ousting Hosni Mubarak from power.   It's been a tumultuous two years for Egypt which has seen political tensions, mass street protests and a deepening economic crisis.   Demonstrators accuse their President, Mohammed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, of betraying the goals of the revolution. And they're demanding radical changes to Egypt's new constitution.   Are you in Egypt? Do you plan to mark the second anniversary of the uprising? Will you be attending any rallies? If so, we would like to hear from you.

Link Title: Click here to upload your video comment or question on North Korea
Message: Upload a video comment: is it time for North Korea to be taken more seriously? Pyongyang has threatened "physical counter-measures" against South Korea if it participates in UN sanctions. On Thursday, North Korea announced a third nuclear test, aimed at its "arch-enemy", the United States. Are you worried about North Korea? Or do you believe these are empty threats? We'll use your videos as part of our discussion on World Have Your Say at 1500GMT.

Traditional Scottish haggis is banned in the US http://bbc.in/10EueWV  So, how do fans of the dish in America soothe their cravings for oatmeal and sheep's innards?   What possible substitute can they find for a Burns Night gathering?   The BBC's Jon Kelly takes a look at the debate over the delicacy.

Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the crumbling tower blocks in Alexandria, Egypt and why construction standards are difficult to enforce http://bbc.in/10P2xza  In other news from around the world:   - US to allow women in frontline combat http://bbc.in/10P2vrb - North Korea 'plans nuclear test' http://bbc.in/10P2vr7 - British, German and Dutch nationals urged to leave Benghazi http://bbc.in/10P2vr5 - Dolphin asks for rescue http://bbc.in/10P2xzn - Refugee crisis in Jordan 'critical' http://bbc.in/10P2xzf  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.  Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10P2vr3

Obama piggy banks? A first family t-shirt? Political condoms?   On Inauguration day, we hit the National Mall in Washington, DC to look for some of the unique and oddball souvenirs people will be bringing back home.   Which is your favourite?  See our story from Inauguration Day 2013 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21133210  Produced by the BBC's Taylor Brown

One of the Islamist groups fighting in northern Mali has split and wants dialogue, a statement from the breakaway faction says.  Islamic Movement for Azawad said it was splitting from Ansar Dine, and "rejects all forms of extremism and terrorism".  France sent troops to Mali earlier this month to halt a militant advance.  It said al-Qaeda linked Islamists - some of whom were foreigners - threatened to turn Mali into a "terrorist state".

The UN refugee council (UNHCR) said on Wednesday that more than 26,500 Syrian refugees had crossed into Jordan since 1 January, putting a considerable strain on resources.  A UN official told the BBC that up to 3,000 were arriving every day and at least 50,000 were waiting to cross.  Jordan has already warned that if there is a mass influx of refugees it will close the border with Syria.

The UN is launching an inquiry into the impact on civilians of drone strikes and other targeted killings.    The inquiry will study the impact of drone strikes in five places.    Twenty-five attacks will be examined - in Pakistan, Afghanistan, Yemen, the Palestinian territories and Somalia.    There is a need for "accountability and reparation where things have gone badly wrong", the British lawyer heading the investigation told journalists.    What are your thoughts on using drones in military strikes?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21176279

The government of North Korea has issued a chilling warning claiming its nuclear weapons are designed to reach America.    Whether that's credible or not it's certainly the most provocative statement to come since Kim Jong-un came to power.   And it's not just rhetoric in what's being referred to as a new phase in its struggle with the historic enemy North Korea  says it's planning a third nuclear test.

Link Title: US to end ban on women in combat
Message: US Defence Secretary Leon Panetta is lifting the military's ban on women serving in combat.   The move could open more than 230,000 combat roles to women, from front-line roles to elite commando postings.   Women comprise 14% of America's 1.4 million active military personnel.  What are your thoughts on this decision?   Some argue that the move will cause enormous complications in the infantry battalions that fight the enemy with deliberate offensive action under fire.   Others argue that women are already in combat and that this move is about recognising their service.  We'll use some of your comments during the GMT programme with George Alagiah at 1200GMT.

Construction has started in Kenya on "Africa's Silicon Savannah" http://bbc.in/10Jul88  The $14.5bn (£9.1bn) project, intended to be an IT business hub, will take 20 years to build. Despite Kenya's usually divisive politics, the project has the backing of all political parties.

A commission set up to suggest reforms to India's rape laws after last month's gang rape of a student has called for faster trials.    The panel, led by former chief justice JS Verma, also called for longer sentences but not the death penalty.    India's law minister said the report would get "government attention" soon.    Justice Verma said his three-member commission had received 80,000 responses from India and abroad on how to reform rape laws.     Below are the recommendations of the report submitted to the home ministry.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-21156283

Hello from the World Debate team at the World Economic Forum in Davos. We’re preparing for the recording of a special edition http://bbc.in/10IE270  Two years after the Arab Spring, Nik Gowing will be asking if democracy is winning. With him, Turkey’s Foreign Minister, Ahmet Davutoglu, and the Egyptian opposition leader, Amr Moussa.   Join the conversation and leave a question in the comments section below.

Our colleagues at BBC Future have just launched a new video series called Power of Nature, which uncovers the hidden forces behind the planet’s treasures. First up is the Himalayas, the vast mountain range that has profoundly shaped the cultures of South Asia and holds the gift of life for billions of people. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20130122-himalayas-water-towers-of-asia

Glaciers in the tropical Andes have shrunk by an average of 30-50% since the 1970s, according to a study.  The glaciers, which provide fresh water for tens of millions in South America, are retreating at their fastest rate in the past 300 years.  The study included data on about half of all Andean glaciers and blamed the melting on an average temperature rise of 0.7C from 1950-1994.

A study in China and the US confirms what all parents already know - we lie to our children!   What is the long term impact of lying to our kids and does it really effect family relationships as our children get older?   Join me in the Worlds Newsroom as we discuss all of this and Mishal and I share a few lies of our own...(eg. If you don't come right now, I'll leave you behind!").    And send us the most common lie you tell to your kids using the video uploader ( http://bbcwhysupload.cs.streamuk.com/ ), we'll try to get some on air.   See you soon, Lucy

The high turnout among the middle classes in the Israeli elections has transformed the outcome.   A new centre left party led by a television presenter with no previous experience in politics came second. Yair Lapid's slogan throughout the campaign was "Where's the money?" and yesterday it seemed Israeli voters want him to answer that question.   Today, coalition talks are set to begin after general election results predicted right-wing and centre-left blocs tied on 60 seats each.  President Shimon Peres is expected to ask Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to attempt to form a new government.

Hello - it's Mishal.     I've already had a huge response on Twitter asking for your thoughts on how women are portrayed in Indian film - after the rape case, should Bollywood be more responsible?     It's our Impact discussion with actress Nandita Das (featured below) and filmmaker Sharmeen Obaid Chinoy.

A pair of glasses dubbed a "privacy visor" has been developed to thwart hidden cameras using facial-recognition software http://bbc.in/10G1aD0  The glasses are equipped with a near-infrared light source, which confuses the software without affecting vision.

Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the the biggest ever exhibition of the work of French artist Manet http://bbc.in/10F7SsY that is set to open at London's Royal Academy this week and other news from around the world, including:  - Israel's election  http://bbc.in/10F7U3U - The latest from Mali  http://bbc.in/10F7St2 -  Death sentence for Briton in Bali  http://bbc.in/10F7U3Y - Roe v Wade ruling turns 40  http://bbc.in/10F7SsQ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10F7U3S

BREAKING NEWS: A college in the US state of Texas is on lockdown amid reports of several people injured in a shooting http://bbc.in/10EN9ph  Jed Young, a spokesman for Lone Star College in the north of Houston, said two students had been wounded in cross-fire.

Link Title: Lost indigenous language revived in Australia
Message: Find out how an indigenous language, once thought of as dead in Australia, is now coming back to life thanks to the dedication of researchers and the vision of 19th Century German missionaries.   The Kaurna language once thrived and was spoken by the original inhabitants of Adelaide.   But it began to disappear from daily use in South Australia as early as the 1860s.

Do you have questions about yesterday's US inauguration? http://bbc.in/10oBWEl  Do you wonder what challenges Obama will face in his second term?   BBC Washington Correspondent and World News America host Katty Kay will take your questions in a live Twitter Q&A today between 1400 EST and 1500 EST (1900 GMT and 2000 GMT).   Follow along on Twitter @KattyKayBBC http://bbc.in/10oBWEp  Tweet your questions with the hashtag #AskKattyBBC or ask in the comments section below.   Photo courtesy of the BBC's Tushar Dayal

Scores of Russians are to be flown home after fleeing the violence in Syria - but Russia insists it is not the start of a mass evacuation.  Buses carrying the Russians have crossed the Lebanese border heading for Beirut airport, Lebanese media reported on Tuesday.  Moscow has been one of President Bashar al-Assad's closest allies during the conflict in Syria.  But it has admitted making contingency plans for a possible future evacuation.

Germany and France are to propose closer economic and financial ties between eurozone countries, to help avoid another financial crisis.   The proposal was made in Berlin by the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, and the French President, Francois Hollande.   Both leaders are marking the fiftieth anniversary of the Elysee Treaty, which sealed the two countries' reconciliation after the Second World War.

Link Title: Election quandary for Israel's Arab citizens
Message: ANALYSIS:  Israel's elections pose a quandary for its Arab citizens, a large but marginalised part of the population.  Some argue that participating in elections might be viewed as an endorsement of the existence of Israel - others that voting is the only way to exercise influence over how the state behaves and where it spends it money.

Link Title: Harry: 'Take a life to save a life'
Message: Hello, it's Mishal.   In the world's newsroom we are wondering today what you think of the Prince Harry interview we have been running.   After working in Afghanistan he has spoken of killing Taliban and said to save a life - it is sometimes necessary to take a life.   Your comments will form part of our live discussion today

The Philippines says it will challenge Chinese territorial claims in the South China Sea in a UN court.  Foreign Secretary Albert del Rosario said the decision came after Manila had exhausted "almost all political and diplomatic avenues" to resolve the maritime dispute with Beijing.  He said he hoped arbitration would help bring a "durable solution" to the row.  Tensions between the two have been high since a stand-off at the Scarborough Shoal - which both claim - last year.

A gamma ray burst, the most powerful explosion known in the Universe, may have hit the Earth in the 8th Century http://bbc.in/10AC48s  In 2012 researchers found evidence that our planet had been struck by a blast of radiation during the Middle Ages, but there was debate over what kind of cosmic event could have caused this.

Couldn’t make it to Washington, DC for Inauguration Day?   Our producers, hosts, correspondents and social media friends took a lot of photos from around the city today. Here is a small taste of what we saw and some of the people we met http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21133210

Couldn’t make it to Washington, DC for Inauguration Day?   Our producers, hosts, correspondents and social media friends took a lot of photos from around the city today. Here is a small taste of what we saw and some of the people we met http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-21133210

Algeria's Prime Minister has said 37 foreigners of eight nationalities and one Algerian worker were killed during the hostage crisis at a gas plant http://bbc.in/10zFSXM  Among the dead are citizens of France, the United Kingdom, Norway, Malaysia, the Philippines, the United States, Japan and Romania.  Algerian state media says that 685 Algerian workers at the plant had escaped, with reports that militants told them they were only targeting non-Muslims.

Link Title: Jazz, the sound of soft power
Message: Qatar has spent billions bringing the world to the tiny gulf kingdom. Major universities have set up campuses here while international think tanks have opened up offices.   Finding a jazz band at a luxury hotel isn't surprising but in this part of the world, the music faces criticism from religious scholars.

Barack Obama has arrived at the US Capitol, where he is soon to take the oath of office for his second term as president. Follow live http://bbc.in/10yZgUJ  Hundreds of thousands of supporters have gathered to see Mr Obama, 51, be sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts.  Join the conversation @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10yZfjB

French and Malian troops have seized the key Malian towns of Diabaly and Douentza from militant Islamists, the French defence minister has said.  French warplanes have bombed suspected Islamist positions around both towns since France launched a military operation in Mali on 11 January.  A column of French and Malian troops entered Diabaly, said an AFP news agency reporter with the soldiers.

Reports from Eritrea say a group of about 200 soldiers backed by tanks have surrounded the ministry of information in the capital, Asmara.    State TV has also reportedly been taken off air in what some have described as a coup attempt.    The city is said to be calm with no shots having been fired.    Eritrea's government has been criticised by human rights activists as one of the world's most repressive and closed countries.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21127529

Hundreds of thousands of people have started gathering on Washington, DC's National Mall as Barack Obama is set to be publicly sworn in for his second term as US president later today http://bbc.in/10ya2KY    Keep up with everything happening in Washington on our LIVE page http://bbc.in/10ya19O or by following @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10ya2L0 on Twitter.    In DC? Watching at home?  Share your Inauguration photos with us http://bbc.in/10ya1q8    VIDEO: Obama 'officially' sworn in for second term yesterday http://bbc.in/10ya19S    Inaugural poet on explaining US in a verse http://bbc.in/10ya2KW    Inauguration Day: Unclear strategy for Obama's legacy http://bbc.in/10ya1qa

Link Title: Inside the life of Kim Dotcom
Message: VIDEO: Meet the controversial internet tycoon better known as Kim Dotcom.  He has launched a new file-sharing business just a year after he was forced to close a similar website.  His previous venture Megaupload.com accounted for more than 4% of the world's internet traffic, but authorities in the United States claim the site facilitated massive online piracy.

He is young, wealthy and is taking this Israeli election by storm as leader of the Jewish Home party.   "I alone, among the parties represented here, am against a Palestinian State in Judea and Samaria. Such a state would mean 200 years of heartache for Israel and the Palestinians. I know they have their ambitions but, as for a Palestinian state, I am against it."  Loved by aspirational right-wing voters, Naftali Bennett is a dot-com millionaire whose forthright views have drained support away from Mr Netanyahu's ruling Likud Party and given political pundits and journalists plenty to talk about.

Link Title: In pictures: Behind Kachin rebel lines
Message: On the Worlds Newsroom we're discussing the latest developments in Kachin in Burma.   Friday's ceasefire has already been broken - Burmese forces have launched an attack on a Kachin military post.  How strong is the Kachin army? What do the Kachin people want? What are the prospects for peace?  Send us your questions and I'll put them live to Tin Htar Swe, the editor of our Burmese service at 1345 GMT. See you soon, Lucy (Hockings)

President Barack Obama will today be inaugurated for his second term at the White House.  We'd like to give you an opportunity to write a few words as ' a letter to Obama'.  Tell us where you are writing from.  Which key issues would you like him to address at home and abroad?   What has he failed to address in his first term?  Please keep your messages concise.  We'll try to broadcast as many of your 'letters' on our programmes throughout the day.

Link Title: Delhi rape case to get under way
Message: The  trial of five men for the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old woman has just got underway in Delhi. A sixth suspect, who claims he is 17, will be heard by a separate juvenile court.   It's a case that has shocked India and triggered a wider debate about the treatment of women. It's being heard by a special fast-track court. If convicted, the men could face the death penalty.   However, the lawyer representing Ram Singh, said the intense media attention in the capital could lead to an unfair trial.  "We are sure we will not get justice in Delhi"

Link Title: India hosts the world’s biggest gathering
Message: Hindus the world over are making the pilgrimage to Allahabad, where the world’s largest gathering – the Maha Kumbh Mela – is taking place over the next two months. Initial reports suggest more than 100 million people will visit the city to bathe where the Ganges, Yamuna, and mythical Sarasvati Rivers meet. Here’s what you need to know about the most holy Hindu pilgrimage in 144 years:

US President Barack Obama, seen here sprucing up a school as part of a National Day of Service on Saturday, is due to be officially sworn in for his second term as US president in a small ceremony at the White House http://bbc.in/10utjNk  The public ceremony with pomp and circumstance will follow a day later.   Will you be in Washington? Watching from home? Share your photos and stories with us on Twitter with the hashtag #BBCDC  Find out more http://bbc.in/10utlon

The United Nations says torture in Afghan prisons continues to be widespread despite its recommendations in a similar report in 2011.  More than half of the 635 detainees interviewed by UN investigators said they had been ill-treated or tortured.  The Afghan government says the claims are exaggerated, the BBC's Quentin Sommerville in Kabul says.  Nato's force in Afghanistan, Isaf, has suspended the transfer of detainees to facilities named in the report.

Three Brazilian teenagers have been killed and three other people injured after gunmen opened fire during the rehearsal of a samba school in the eastern state of Minas Gerais.  Four men on motorbikes shot at members of the Sao Geraldo samba school practising for next month's carnival in the city of Sao Joao Del Rei.  Police officials said they believed the attack was gang-related.  However, they said it was not clear if those killed were the intended targets.  The victims were between 14 and 19 years old.

The Burmese army has launched an attack on a strategic hilltop held by rebel Kachin forces in the north of the country, breaking a ceasefire announced by the government.  Burmese troops shelled a Kachin base just a few kilometres from their headquarters in Laiza, on the Chinese border.  It was hit by sustained mortar and artillery fire, and hundreds of Burmese troops could be seen crawling through the trees up the slopes, says the BBC's Jonathan Head, who is in the area.  He says if the base falls, there are few defences left to prevent the fall of Laiza, should the Burmese military decide to take it.

US President Barack Obama has blamed "terrorists" for the death of at least 23 hostages at a besieged desert gas facility in Algeria.  A four-day siege at the In Amenas site was ended on Saturday by an army raid.  At least five Britons, five Norwegians and 10 Japanese are dead or missing, while Algeria said its troops had killed all 32 hostage-takers.

A man put a gun to the head of the leader of Bulgaria's ethnic Turkish party during a televised conference http://bbc.in/10rHhiU  Ahmed Dogan, leader of the Movement for Rights and Freedoms (MRF) was unharmed and the unidentified man was wrestled to the ground by security guards.

Cancelled flights and bumped passengers are an unfortunate fact of travelling by air. But some airlines are worse offenders than others. Wall Street Journal has ranked the best and worst airlines – how does your favourite carrier stack up? Learn more on BBC Travel:

This weekend's latest news from around the world: - Captors and hostages die in Alegeria http://bbc.in/109OaAz - Live: Algeria crisis http://bbc.in/109O9g5 - Armstrong & Oprah: cyclist questions punishment http://bbc.in/109OaAG - Stranded passengers at Heathrow http://bbc.in/109OaAB - Nepal to cap wildlife growth http://bbc.in/109O9g9 - NHS prescribing self-help books http://bbc.in/109OaAL - Climbers missing after avalanche http://bbc.in/109OaAx - The week in tweets  http://bbc.in/109O9g7  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.
Eleven hostage-takers are killed as Algerian troops launch a final raid on the gas plant where foreign workers were being held captive, local media report.

VIDEO:    Mishal Husain takes you behind the scenes for a rare glimpse into how IMPACT programme is put together, from the morning editorial meeting to the make-up room, the studio and the gallery.    Just click the link below.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-21088767

VIDEO:   A Cairo cafe is being described as Egypt’s first ‘Islamic café’ after setting up separate gender areas and dissuading unmarried couples from visiting.  The idea is to cater for the needs of customers who would like to have a conservative place to hang out but some believe it's a sign of a divided society.

Link Title: Algeria siege goes into fourth day
Message: Militants holding a group of foreign workers hostage at a gas plant in Algeria are reported to be holed up in a workshop at the remote site, surrounded by Algerian special forces.  The state-run APS news agency says 12 Algerian and foreign workers have died since rescue efforts began on Thursday.  The militants are armed with rocket launchers and machine guns, APS says.  They say they are holding seven hostages: three Belgians, two Americans, one Briton and one Japanese.

More than 140 countries have agreed on a set of legally binding measures to curb mercury pollution, at UN talks.  Delegates in Geneva approved measures to control the use of the highly toxic metal in order to reduce the amount of mercury released into the environment.  Mercury can produce a range of adverse human health effects, including permanent damage to the nervous system.  The UN recently published data that showed mercury emissions were rising in a number of developing nations.  The deal was agreed after all-night talks.

The Fermi space telescope has seen hints of evidence for "dark matter" in high-energy gamma rays seen at the galaxy's centre - the material makes up some 85% of the Universe's mass http://bbc.in/10nLYdD  Proving its existence, and learning something about what it is, has been a holy grail for astrophysicists since the 1930s.

On Monday we'll be bringing you live coverage of the US presidential inauguration from this perch on Washington, DC's Pennsylvania Avenue http://bbc.in/10ndMyB  Join us tonight on BBC World News America for the latest from the siege in Algeria http://bbc.in/10ndMij massacre near Homs, Syria http://bbc.in/10ndOGO Lance Armstrong's confession to Oprah http://bbc.in/10ndOGU and the acid attack on the artistic director of Russia's Bolshoi Theatre http://bbc.in/10ndOGW  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/10ndOGS

The former mayor of New Orleans Ray Nagin has been charged on 21 counts including wire fraud, bribery, filing false tax returns and money laundering http://bbc.in/10mEqb3  Nagin was mayor from 2002-10. He came to national attention in 2005 when Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans.

Three years after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, the prime minister of the country calls it one of the “safest destinations... in all of Latin America” for travellers. But the US stands by a travel advisory warning travellers of violent crime in the area, including murder and kidnapping. BBC Travel investigates whether Haiti really is safe for travellers to visit:

Link Title: Brazil drought stokes worries over energy shortages
Message: Brazil's government insists that a severe drought will not lead to power rationing but analysts say the country's energy system is stretched to near capacity.  Recent rains have helped ease the problem and the government insists there will not be any shortages.  Brazil's hydroelectric dams, which generate 67% of the country's power, have seen water levels dip to near critical levels.

The BBC sees evidence of a massacre in a village near the Syrian city of Homs, where locals say at least 100 people were killed.   Reports of the massacre emerged on Thursday from opposition activists, but these were not possible to confirm.  Syrian army soldiers told the BBC team that all the bodies had already been taken away. Our Chief International Correspondent Lyse Doucet found a scene of a vicious murder reporting "three charred bodies lay sprawled just inside one house. A trail of blood stained the cement".

Few in the west have heard of Swami Vivekananda, who was born 150 years ago this week. Yet this Bengali intellectual, still revered in India, introduced many people to yoga and meditation.   BBC's Emily Buchanan explains her connection to one of India's most influential spiritual teachers - Swami Vivekananda.

The artistic director of Russia's Bolshoi Theatre, Sergei Filin, is being treated in a Moscow hospital for severe burns to his face after a masked man threw acid in his face, police say.  The attack happened late on Thursday as Mr Filin, an award-winning ballet star, was walking home in central Moscow.  Doctors are now fighting to save his eyesight and Interfax news agency says he will be sent to a clinic abroad.  A Bolshoi spokesman said Mr Filin, 42, had suffered months of threats.

The fate of dozens of international hostages being held by Al Qaeda linked militants remains mired in confusion.    The hostage crisis is being played out in and around the sprawling In Amenas gas production facility - seen here in a satellite image - which was attacked by gunmen on Wednesday.     Yesterday Algerian forces launched an assault, apparently triggered by an effort by the hostage takers to leave the compound.     Reports in recent hours have spoken of many casualties but the picture remains chaotic.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21071378

Link Title: Click here to record & upload your video comment
Message: Upload your video comment on Lance Armstrong using a webcam or smartphone. The American cyclist has admitted that he used performance-enhancing drugs during his career, after years of denials. Has the interview with Oprah Winfrey changed your opinion of Lance Armstrong? If he was a hero to you - is he still? We'll use your videos on World Have Your Say at 1500GMT.

As Lance Armstrong ended years of denials by admitting he used performance-enhancing drugs during all seven of his Tour de France wins we ask what should happen now to him and within the sport of cycling itself?  Even though he said "I view this situation as one big lie I repeated a lot of times", Armstrong denied it was "sport's biggest doping programme", saying "it was smart, but it was conservative, risk averse".

Link Title: Sydney bakes in hottest day ever
Message: The Australian city of Sydney is experiencing its hottest day on record, with temperatures reaching nearly 46C.  A temperature of 45.8C was recorded at Observatory Hill in the city at 14:55 local time (01:55 GMT).  Some areas in the wider Sydney region were even hotter, with the town of Penrith, to the west, registering a temperature of 46.5C.  Firefighters are still battling dozens of wildfires sparked by the intense heat in New South Wales and Victoria.

Hi, this is Nik Gowing.   I’ll be at the World Economic Forum in Davos next Thursday for a special edition of the BBC World Debate http://bbc.in/103tZ7l  I’ll be asking: ‘Is Democracy Winning?’ – not only in North Africa and the Middle East, two years after the Arab Spring, but across the world.   Joining me will be:  - Ahmet Davutoglu, Turkish Foreign Minister - Amr Moussa, Egyptian opposition leader  - Navi Pillay, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights.  I want to hear your thoughts.   Join the conversation and leave your questions here for our panel.

Has Barack Obama lived up to Martin Luther King Jr's dream? http://bbc.in/10iDMvc  On this week's edition of Picture This we meet author Clayborne Carson, who was among the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators that marched on Washington in August of 1963, and discuss how he sees King's legacy and whether America's first black president has brought the US any closer to fulfilling the "dream" of equality.

Will Lance Armstrong admit to doping?   His interview with Oprah Winfrey airs tonight at 21:00 EST (02:00 GMT) - the same day in which the IOC asked Armstrong to return the bronze medal he won at the 2000 Sydney games http://bbc.in/102F1cZ  Join us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/102EZ4Z & @BBCSport http://bbc.in/102F1cX and share your reaction to his answers.  What questions does Lance Armstrong need to answer? http://bbc.in/102EZln

Tens of thousands of Kurds have attended the funerals in Diyarbakir, Turkey, of three female Kurdish activists shot dead in Paris last week.  Crowds chanted as the coffins of the PKK (Kurdistan Workers' Party) members Sakine Cansiz, Fidan Dogan and Leyla Saylemez were carried through the city streets to a parade ground where the funerals were held.  There was tight security at the event.  No-one has been arrested for the crime and the motive is unclear.

Link Title: A new era in news is beginning
Message: Hello it's Babita here,  In our new home at BBC Broadcasting House, we're bringing together the expertise of journalists who broadcast BBC World News in languages around the globe.   Take a look at the video and see how we do it.

The trial of five men accused of the gang rape and murder of a student on a bus in Delhi has been transferred to a fast track court.    The 23 year-old woman died from her injuries after the attack, which sparked nationwide protests.   The fast-track case is now expected to begin on Monday, although one of the defence lawyers is arguing for it to be heard elsewhere, because his client is worried that he won't get a fair hearing in Delhi.

A number of hostages have escaped the Islamist militants who took them captive at a gas facility in eastern Algeria, media and officials say.    Details of the escape and the numbers involved remain unclear, but some 30-40 Algerians and 15-25 foreign nationals were reported to have escaped.    The militants earlier said they were holding 41 foreign nationals.    A siege is ongoing, with Algerian soldiers surrounding the facility near In Amenas.      For a Q&A on the hostage crisis click http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21056884

It's a lucky strike for one Australian amateur prospector who has found a massive gold nugget.     The nugget itself weighs a whopping 5.5kg and it's value has been estimated at more than $315,000.    The unidentified man was quoted saying "A finding like this gives people hope. It's my dream to find something like that, and I've been prospecting for more than two decades".      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21055206

Link Title: First Nigerian troops due in Mali
Message: Hi, Ros Atkins here.   I'm wondering if you have questions on the situation in Mali that I can help get answers to.   I'll be reporting live from the BBC's French for Africa service later on BBC World News, and if you post issues you'd like me to raise here on our FB page, when I report into Mishal's programme later, I'll find people who can address them.   You're welcome to ask about part of the conflict, and I promise I'll check through every question you leave here. Thanks and talk to you later.

A few weeks have passed since Christmas and now is probably  a safe time to start thinking what to do with unwanted presents like jumpers or useless gadgets given to you by a distant relative.     The old saying goes 'one man's trash is another man's treasure' so we want to hear what one should do with an unwanted gift?     Do you swap it, give it to charity, sell it or just hide it?     Tell us about some of the unwanted presents you have received and what you ended up doing with them.    Your comments might be used on GMT programme with George Alagiah at 1230GMT

"The police confirmed that 20 children had been shot and the room erupted. And I remember I started shaking - and I just couldn't stop for the life of me" http://bbc.in/ZZ9N6A  The parents of a British-born boy killed in the Sandy Hook school shooting have said they plan to stay in Newtown despite the death of their son. Six-year-old Dylan Hockley was one of 20 children who lost their lives when Adam Lanza opened fire at the Connecticut primary school in December.  The BBC's Steve Kingstone speaks with the Hockley family.

Which city moves the slowest? http://bbc.in/ZYG79z  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the final part in our series on global gridlock as Beijing faces off against Mumbai.   In other news from around the globe:  - Obama takes on guns  http://bbc.in/ZYG79N - Lyse Doucet in Syria  http://bbc.in/ZYG79B - French 'fighting Islamists in Diabaly' http://bbc.in/ZYG79H - London helicopter crash  http://bbc.in/ZYG79D - Japan grounds the Drealiner http://bbc.in/ZYG3H2  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/ZYG6Tl

US President Obama has unveiled the most sweeping gun control proposals in two decades. He called for a ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines and wider background checks on gun buyers http://bbc.in/ZYy6Sf  The Democratic president also signed 23 executive actions, which do not require congressional approval.  Mark Mardell: President Obama's next campaign http://bbc.in/ZYy9gH  VIDEO: 'Congress must act soon'  http://bbc.in/ZYy6S8  Guns in numbers http://bbc.in/ZYy9gN  Newtown parents recall attack http://bbc.in/ZYy9gF  Special report: US gun debate http://bbc.in/ZYy90q

More than 20 people have been killed in near-simultaneous car bomb blasts in the Syrian city of Idlib that's according to government officials and activists.  The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said security vehicles, buildings and a checkpoint had been targeted, and that most of the dead were state forces.  But the government said the blasts had hit city squares, killing civilians.  Rebel forces control much of the countryside around Idlib, but government forces hold the city.

Former Barcelona boss Pep Guardiola has a new job in Germany.  He's to take over as Bayern Munich manager when current boss Jupp Heynckes retires at the end of the season.   The 41-year-ol has signed a three-year contract to June 2016. Pep Guardiola has been on a season-long sabbatical since leaving the Nou Camp in May last year, after winning 14 trophies, two of them Champions League titles.

Link Title: Pussy Riot jail plea turned down
Message: A Russian court has rejected a plea to release one of the jailed members of the punk protest group Pussy Riot.    She had asked the judge to let her serve the rest of her two-year sentence when her five year-old son grows up.   Maria Alyokina was arrested last year after her band interrupted a cathedral service in Moscow with an anti-Putin song.

Link Title: Behind the scenes at Yugoslavia trials
Message: VIDEO:  It's two decades now since the former Yugoslavia ripped itself apart in a vicious and bloody civil war. The fighting has long since ended, but the consequences live on.   After being on the run for several years, two of the highest profile Bosnian Serb leaders, the former military commander Ratko Mladic and one-time president Radovan Karadzic, were finally captured. They're currently on trial for war crimes in the Hague,  the first war crimes court established since Nuremberg.  Today though we can show you what happens behind the scenes  at the court as the BBC is the first broadcaster ever to be allowed access to the entire building.

Algerian security officials say one person has been killed and several foreigners abducted in an attack on a gas facility at In Amenas in the east of the country.    Islamist militants allied to Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb say they carried out the attack.    They claim to have seized six people. Their nationalities are unclear.    The oil giant BP says a gas field it runs in partnership with Norwegians and Algerians was attacked.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21042659

Hello, it's Mishal.   Do you really know what's in your food?   Do you trust what's written on the packaging?  There's a story below about horse and pig DNA being found in beef products.   Is this just a reality in an era of mass produced food?   We discuss on Impact

Link Title: Obama to unveil gun control plan
Message: Gun control is an issue which has sharply divided opinion in the United States, especially since the Connecticut school shooting a month ago.  After intense national pressure from the White House, some of the toughest ever restrictions in the US have been signed into law in the state of New York. Governor Andrew Cuomo said they will keep guns out of the reach of criminals and the mentally ill.   In a few hours President Obama will announce new plans for tighter national gun laws. It is the result of his urgent initiative after the murder of 20 children and 6 teaching staff at Sandy Hook school.   We want to hear from you, do want stricter gun laws?   Do you want to see the establishment of a federal standard for background checks for people buying guns at gun shows?   Should current laws on gun ownership remain as they are?

"I think the most important questions and the answers that people around the world have been waiting to hear were answered”  Tonight on BBC World News Americas we'll look at the reaction to the first details out about Oprah Winfrey's interview with cyclist Lance Armstrong http://bbc.in/107Mnkg and other news from around the world, including:  - Dozens killed by Aleppo university blasts http://bbc.in/107MkVJ - Joe Biden to make gun-control recommendations http://bbc.in/107Mnke - African elephant poaching http://bbc.in/107Mnk8 - Gridlocked: Paris vs Lagos  http://bbc.in/107MlbX  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/107MkVH

What is Hillary Clinton's legacy?    What will be John Kerry's biggest challenges?   The BBC's Kim Ghattas takes your foreign policy questions on Twitter.  Ask a question in the comments section below or visit http://bbc.in/107d74j for more information

Link Title: GRAPHENE REVOLUTION - GLOBAL WITH JON SOPEL - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO:  Stronger than diamond, more conductive than copper and more flexible than rubber. A miracle material that might once have been resigned to science fiction is fast becoming science fact.  From paper thick electronic screens to aiding drug delivery there seems to be very little graphene can't do but can graphene possibly live up to the hype?  Jon Sopel was joined by John Lettow, President of Vorbeck Materials (one of the first companies to launch a graphene based product) and by the BBC's Science Editor, David Shukman  For more on graphene click here - http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-21014297

Troops from a regional West African force will be in Mali within days to help a French intervention against Islamist rebels, Nigeria says.  The force's commander, Gen Shehu Abdulkadir, confirmed the move to the BBC as West African military commanders met in Mali's capital, Bamako.  France has almost 800 troops in Mali, and another 1,700 involved elsewhere.  It began its intervention last Friday with the aim of halting the Islamists' advance south.

The Kenyan government has warned that an alarming increase in poaching is pushing the African elephant towards extinction.   Five years ago, close to 7,000kg of ivory were seized worldwide. In 2011 the amount seized was five times higher. So where is all this African ivory heading?   Well, most goes to ports in Malaysia, the Philippines, Hong Kong and Vietnam.  From these ports though, much of the ivory goes to China - that's where the big market is. The 28,000kg of ivory seized in China between 2009 and 2011 was more than anywhere else in the world.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-21018429

Link Title: ASIA PACIFIC - WHY IT MATTERS? MISHAL HUSAIN - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIRTUAL REALITY GUIDE: South China Sea is an area now often in the headlines because of territorial disputes in Asia.  With a third of the world's shipping passing through its waters, the area is strategically vital  The region's fishermen are often the ones who see these disputes up close.   These issues are also increasingly on the radar of the United States, with President Obama making the importance of the region clear.   Mishal Husain takes you to the Pacific Ocean in our new virtual reality studio and explains what the issues are around the South China Sea and why the Asia Pacific matters to President Obama.

Link Title: Which cities have the worst traffic?
Message: Hello, it's Mishal.   If you haven't seen it already, here's a glimpse of our 'Gridlocked World' video series where we challenge correspondents in different cities to see how far they can get in an hour of rush hour traffic.   We're also visiting Paris, Lagos, Beijing and Mumbai - but wherever you are, share your traffic chaos stories with us today on Impact.   How long is your average journey to work? Are there too many vehicles on the roads? Let us know and we'll use some of your comments during our programme.

It's been widely reported that cyclist Lance Armstrong has admitted to doping in a pre-recorded interview with Oprah Winfrey.  Armstrong was last year stripped of his seven Tour De France titles after a finding by the US Anti Doping Agency was backed up by the sports governing body. Tour De France organisers then had his name removed from the roll of honour.   The 41 year old also delivered an apology to around 100 staff at his LIVESTRONG charity.

Pakistan's Supreme Court has ordered the arrest of Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf.  He's wanted in connection with a corruption case known as the rental power case. It was initiated against him before the start of his tenure as Prime Minister and is connected to his days as Water and Power Minister.   Mr Ashraf denies accepting bribes.

The first day of India's vast Kumbh Mela festival has ended, with officials estimating that eight million people took to the waters at the confluence of the Ganges and Yamuna rivers http://bbc.in/103Hski  The bathing was held under tight security with more than 30,000 police deployed at the grounds in Allahabad.  Hindus believe a festival dip at Sangam - where the rivers meet - will cleanse sins and help bring salvation. The event, every 12 years, is billed as the biggest gathering on Earth.

How bad is traffic in your city? http://bbc.in/ZQnQey  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll compare traffic in Los Angeles and Moscow and take a look at other news from around the world, including:  - Mali's Islamists seize town  http://bbc.in/ZQnQew - Weather makes Syria more challenging http://bbc.in/ZQnNQ1 - A report from San Diego  - US / Pakistan relations  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the discussion on Twitter by following @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/ZQnNQ3

Lance Armstrong has apologised to the staff at his Livestrong Foundation, amid reports that the US cyclist may admit doping in a TV interview http://bbc.in/ZQaY8f  Armstrong made the apology during private conversations in Austin, Texas, a foundation spokeswoman said.  His interview with Oprah Winfrey is due to be aired on Thursday.

What is Hillary Clinton's legacy?  What challenges will John Kerry face?  What will be the biggest foreign policy stories in 2013? http://bbc.in/102rua3  The BBC State Department correspondent Kim Ghattas will answer your questions in a live Twitter Q&A on Tuesday 15 January 2013 between 14:00 EST and 15:00 EST (20:00 GMT and 21:00 GMT)  Do you have a question?   Follow this link to find out more http://bbc.in/102rua3 or ask in the comments section below.

The Middle East faces a staggering humanitarian disaster as a result of the  war in Syria - that's the stark warning from International Rescue Committee - an aid agency with considerable experience in war zones.  It says a lack of concerted global action is costing lives. Reports of kidnapping, torture and rape have already forced some six hundred thousand Syrians across the border to neighbouring Jordan, Turkey, Iraq and Lebanon.  Lyse Doucet has spent time with refugees surviving  a wintry Bekaa Valley in Lebanon http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21007519
Behind the scenes -  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-20947831

A major cyber-attack that may have been stealing confidential documents since 2007 has been discovered by Russian researchers.  Kaspersky Labs told the BBC the malware targeted government institutions such as embassies, nuclear research centres and oil and gas institutes.  It was designed to steal encrypted files - and was even able to recover files that had been deleted.  One expert described the attack find as "very significant".

Chinese media have reacted strongly to dangerous levels of pollution recorded in many northern cities in recent days.  Over the week, a dense smog had been gathering over Beijing and some 30 other cities in northern and eastern China, with visibility down to 100m in some places.  In the capital, Beijing, at the weekend, air pollution soared past levels considered hazardous by the World Health Organization.  The official People's Daily said the smog was a "suffocating siege" which had to be urgently addressed.  The state-run China Daily said the country had to learn to balance development with quality of life.

Link Title: SYRIA - FAISAL MAKDAD INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO:   The BBC's Chief International Correspondent Lyse Doucet has been exclusively talking to the Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal Makdad on the ongoing crisis in his country. Mr Makdad believes President Bashar al Assad should still remain in power.

It's billed as the world's biggest religious festival as millions of Hindu pilgrims gather in the Indian city of Allahabad for the Kumbh Mela.    Before daybreak thousands jumped into the freezing waters at the point where the Ganges and Yamuna rivers meet, believing their sins were being washed away.    The Kumbh Mela takes place every 12 years in Allahabad but there are similar events across India every three years.    To find out what's it like being there click on http://bbc.in/ZZE21U    To use our interactive map and explore the site click on http://bbc.in/ZZE4Ha

Link Title: GUIDED TOUR OF NEW HOME FOR BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Hello everyone, it's Mishal.   It's a big day for us as we launch 'The World's Newsroom' and our new-look programmes.   There's a guided tour in the video below but we also welcome your thoughts on what you see. So please be a part of it - and leave us your comments. Thank you  For more click on www.bbc.com/worldsnewsroom
Who will win at tonight's Golden Globes? http://bbc.in/ZMXIBt  Follow @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/ZMXIBp on Twitter for the latest from our team on the red carpet.

Hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets of Paris over plans to give gay couples in France the right to marry and adopt children.  France's Socialist government is planning to change the law this year.  But the demonstrators, backed by the Catholic Church and the right-wing opposition, argue it would undermine an essential building block of society.  The organisers put the number of marchers at 800,000, with demonstrators pouring into Paris by train and bus, carrying placards that read, "We don't want your law, Francois" and "Don't touch my civil code".
Air pollution levels in the Chinese capital Beijing are at hazardous levels for the third day running, with dense smog continuing to shroud the city amid freezing winter temperatures.

This week BBC Travel brings you a shopaholic's guide to Doha, where you can wander a labyrinthine souq, take in some of the glitziest shopping malls known to man and explore hip boutiques from local designers. This is one of our favourites -- Villaggio, a Venetian-themed shopping extravaganza with its Las Vegas-style indoor gondola rides. Have you been? http://bit.ly/VU9qck

The French military has kept up its bombing of militant targets in Mali for a third day, as part of an offensive to drive back Islamists.  France's decision to intervene so soon took many by surprise.  A UN-backed international force had not been expected to deploy in the west African state until the autumn.  But last week the Islamists, who already control large swathes of the north, pushed further south, capturing the strategically important town of Konna.  French President Francois Hollande said France and Europe would be threatened by the creation of a "terrorist state".

Police in India have arrested six men after they allegedly gang-raped a woman on a bus, just weeks after a similar attack shocked the nation.    The latest assault is said to have taken place in the northern state of Punjab. The police are searching for a seventh suspected attacker.    Last month, a 23-year-old student died of her injuries after the being raped in the capital Delhi.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21003279

Aaron Swartz, a celebrated internet freedom activist and early developer of the website Reddit, has died at 26.  The activist and programmer took his life in his New York apartment, a relative and the state medical examiner said. His body was found on Friday.  Mr Swartz began computer programming as a child, and at 14 co-authored an early version of the RSS specification.  After leaving Reddit, Mr Swartz became an advocate of internet freedom, and was facing hacking charges at the time of his death.

US journalist Paul Salopek is going to spend the next seven years walking from Ethiopia to the tip of South America, retracing the journey of early humans out of Africa and around the world.    Along the way he will be writing articles, shooting video and tweeting.    Salopek will take some 30 million footsteps during this journey, which he calls "the long walk into our becoming". So there is a lot of potential for blisters.    But he insists he is not doing this as some kind of extreme sport - he will be thinking hard, en route, about human evolution.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20902355

A court in Egypt has ordered a retrial for ex-President Hosni Mubarak after accepting an appeal against his life sentence over the deaths of protesters.  Mubarak, 84, was overthrown last year after mass street protests in the capital Cairo and other cities, and jailed in June.  His former Interior Minister, Habib al-Adly, was also granted a retrial.  The two men are likely to remain in custody, however, because of separate investigations into their affairs.  Mubarak ruled Egypt for almost 30 years, surviving six assassination attempts, before last year's revolt.

The jungles, high plains and mountain ranges of South America are full of secrets, and the search for the ancient civilisations which inhabited them continually throws up surprises.    In a new television series for BBC 4, Lost Kingdoms of South America, archaeologist and Americas curator at the British Museum Dr Jago Cooper explores mountain citadels and sprawling stone ruins to learn about the peoples who lived in them long before the arrival of the Incas and Spanish conquistadors.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20975815

Air pollution in the Chinese capital Beijing has reached levels judged as hazardous to human health.   Readings from both official and unofficial monitoring stations suggested that Saturday's pollution has soared past danger levels outlined by the World Health Organization.  The air tastes of coal dust and car fumes, two of the main sources of pollution, says a BBC correspondent.

Here is our brief look at what is making news around the world this weekend:  - Mali and France 'push back Islamists' http://bbc.in/13psh3J - Porn producers sue to overturn condom law http://bbc.in/13psh3T - Rebels 'take control of Syria airbase' http://bbc.in/13psh3N - Raid on paedophile ring in Argentina http://bbc.in/13psh3P - Heseltine attacks Cameron on EU http://bbc.in/13psgwN - Florida's snake hunting contest http://bbc.in/13psh3L - Karzai meets with Obama  http://bbc.in/13psgwH - Our look at CES 2013 http://bbc.in/13psgwP - Dreamliner review ordered http://bbc.in/13psh3F - Our funny look at the news - in 140 characters or less http://bbc.in/13psgwL

Why is Haiti no better off despite the massive global earthquake relief effort? http://bbc.in/V1OzFH  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll meet author Jonathan Katz, the only full-time American reporter stationed in Haiti when the earthquake hit, and hear about his book, "The Big Truck That Went By: How The World Came to Save Haiti and Left Behind a Disaster," and take a look at other news from around the world, including:   - US plans to leave Afghanistan  http://bbc.in/V1OySn  - Savile scandal: Report reveals decades of abuse  http://bbc.in/V1OySj  - Dreamliner's nightmares  http://bbc.in/V1OwKf  - Kate's portrait http://bbc.in/V1OzFJ  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation with @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/V1OySl

Link Title: A PREVIEW - THE NEW HOME OF BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: On Monday 14 January we'll proudly introduce you to the new home for BBC World News - we'll look sharper and more dynamic than ever before in high-definition and virtual reality studios.   Take a sneak peek at The World's Newsroom in the video below.

US President Barack Obama and Afghan leader Hamid Karzai have discussed the possibility of keeping a US military force in Afghanistan beyond 2014 http://bbc.in/V1z9By  Watch live: Barack Obama and Hamid Karzai joint news conference at White House http://bbc.in/V1z94v

This week BBC Travel visited Mumbai, where life means learning to appreciate the daily tumult and epic traffic, while enjoying life in the most cosmopolitan city on the subcontinent. Here's what you need to know about living in India's largest city: http://bit.ly/VPKkvA

Link Title: Saudi king names women to council
Message: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah appoints women to a fifth of the seats in the previously all-male consultative Shura Council.  Two decrees reconstituted the council, which advises the government on new legislation, for a new four-year term - and stated that women should always hold at least a fifth of its 150 seats.  The king took the decisions following consultations with religious leaders.

France is ready to stop Islamist militants who control northern Mali, the French president says, following a plea for help by his Malian counterpart.  However, President Francois Hollande said France would only act under UN authorisation.  Armed groups, some linked to al-Qaeda, took control of the region in April 2012.

The first official painting of the Duchess of Cambridge has been unveiled.   It was painted by the artist Paul Emsley and took several months using a technique of building thin layers of oil and glazes on canvas.  Sunday Times Art Critic Waldemar Januszczak said the he was "disappointed" by the portrait because the Duchess' "eyes don't sparkle". What's your opinion of the painting?

A new study has found that children growing up under China's one-child policy are less trusting, risk-averse and pessimistic.   Did you grow up in a one-child family? Or did you have lots of siblings? How did it affect you?

Rebels are reported to have taken control of a strategic military airbase in north-western Syria after weeks of fierce fighting with government forces.  Opposition activists said the Free Syrian Army was in full control of Taftanaz airport. Videos purportedly showed fighters inside the facility.  Meanwhile, top US and Russian officials will later attend talks in Geneva with the UN envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi.

Coming up on GMT today, how a teacher at a high school in California averted a serious shooting incident.  It comes just four weeks after a gunman killed 26 pupils and staff at the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut.  That incident provoked a nationwide debate about gun laws in the US.   What do you think? Should teachers be armed?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20975608

California rocket builder SpaceX says it expects to start launching humans into orbit in its Dragon capsule in 2015 http://bbc.in/UZAkRY  While these first flights would carry the company's own test pilots - not US space agency (Nasa) astronauts - Nasa is trying to seed an indigenous commercial market in crew transport services.  SpaceX is not alone - Boeing and the Sierra Nevada Corporation also have plans to compete in this emerging commercial market.  We want to hear from you.  Tell us what you think about Nasa's plans to purchase crew services from these companies .  Is the future of space travel in private hands?

Will it be Lincoln's last days?  Or the story behind the Canadian Caper?  Perhaps it will be the iconic stage musical adapted for the silver screen?   Which Best Picture nominee will win it all on 24 February?  http://bbc.in/13lLROh  Tonight on BBC World News Americas we'll take a look at the Oscar nominations and other news from around the world, including:  - Three Kurdish women activists found dead in Paris http://bbc.in/13lLROd - Rape in South Africa  http://bbc.in/13lLOSP   - Joe Biden to make gun-control recommendations http://bbc.in/13lLQKf - Up to 50% of global food 'is wasted' http://bbc.in/13lLQKj  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation by following @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/13lLQKd

A gunman has shot two people at a high school in California, police have said http://bbc.in/13lvEJ9  One victim suffered a "major injury" and was taken to hospital in an air ambulance, officers said.  The other victim suffered a "minor injury" in the shooting at Taft Union High School, about 80 miles (120km) north of Los Angeles.

It only stopped at seven stations, there were complaints about noise and a lack of seats, and passengers were -- according to reports of the time  'subjected to the unpleasantness of smoke.'     But the first ever train to grace the London Underground was, nevertheless, a great success and it was the start of a subway system that carries over a billion passengers a year and today celebrates its 150th anniversary.     Take a look at how underground map has evolved over time.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-20943525

The ancient Greek goddess Europa is featured on the new five-euro note, which the European Central Bank is poised to unveil.  It is only the second series of euro banknotes since the single currency's launch on 1 January 1999.  The "Europa" series notes will be phased in over several years, starting with the five-euro note in May.  The euro was formally launched on 1 January 1999 but did not enter circulation until 2002.

Zimbabwe has failed to make the key reforms needed to ensure a free and fair presidential election later this year, a Human Rights Watch report says.  This has provoked fears of a replay of the violence surrounding the 2008 poll, the US-based rights group says.  It said time was running out for the unity government to implement legal and institutional reforms, including a new constitution.  President Robert Mugabe has sweeping powers under current laws.

The bodies of 3 Kurdish women, said to include a founding member of the Kurdistan Worker's Party, have been found in central Paris in what police believe was an execution style killing.   The victims are thought be Turkish-born Kurdish activists shot at point blank range in Information Centre of Kurdistan.   Three shell casings were found next to the bodies. The French Interior Minister Manuel Valls has arrived at the site where large numbers of the Kurdish community have gathered.   Police believe the killings were politically motivated and a murder investigation has been launched.

The makers of the famous board game Monopoly have launched an online vote to decide the fate of one of the playing pieces used in the game.      At the moment Monopoly sets have a racing car, a battleship, a small dog, an iron, a top hat, a shoe, a thimble and a wheelbarrow to identify players.    Possible replacements include a cat, a diamond ring, a guitar, a robot and a helicopter.     Which pieces would you get rid of? What would you replace it with and why?

As much as half the world's food gets thrown away before it ever reaches a human mouth. That is the staggering finding of a report from the UK's Institution of Mechanical Engineers.     They said the waste was being caused by poor storage, strict sell-by dates, bulk offers and consumer fussiness.    The report said that between 30% and 50% of the four billion tonnes of food produced around the world each year went to waste.    It suggested that half the food bought in Europe and the US was thrown away.    What it is the case where you are and what can be done to stop it?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20968076

Link Title: A PREVIEW - THE NEW HOME OF BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO:  Take a sneak preview of the new home for BBC World News.   On screen from Monday 14 January, BBC World News will look sharper and more dynamic than ever before complete with high-definition and virtual reality studios.   It will provide you with the most engaging viewing experience yet.

Link Title: Delhi rape suspects due in court
Message: The five men accused with the gang rape and murder of a 23 year old medical student have made a short second appearance in court in Delhi today.  The case has not yet been transferred to a fast track court for trial.The lawyer who intends to represent three of the accused has said the men were tortured and coerced into admitting the crime.

A 300m-wide asteroid is making a close pass of Earth ...  But there is no need to worry - "close" is a safe distance of about 14 million km http://bbc.in/13ju0Yl  Get to know Apophis - named after the Egyptian demon of destruction and darkness - and see why it has been put on a watch list by scientists.

What film are you picking to win?   US civil war drama, Lincoln has led this year's Baftas with 10 nominations including best film and best actor for Daniel Day-Lewis http://bbc.in/13jfCiJ  The other best film contenders are Argo, Les Miserables, Life of Pi, and Zero Dark Thirty.  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the Baftas announcement and what it could mean for tomorrow's Oscar nominations. We'll also take a look at news from the world, including: - Iranians released in Syria http://bbc.in/13jfCiH - Cooler weather helps Australia http://bbc.in/13jfCiL - Fixing the US economy http://bbc.in/13jfCiF  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/13jfC2r

President Barack Obama is "determined" to curb gun violence, US Vice-President Joe Biden has said, opening high-profile talks on the issue http://bbc.in/UWWS5E  Mr Biden, leading the White House effort on gun control policy, said the president could use executive orders. The moves come after a deadly shooting in Connecticut saw 27 people killed, including 20 schoolchildren.  We want to hear what you think -  What changes are you expecting to gun policy in the US?

Last year the BBC took a look at the use of "booth babes" as a marketing tool at the Consumer Electronics Show http://bbc.in/UWMVFv  We've gone back to Las Vegas to see if things have changed and how people are reacting to the tactic http://bbc.in/UWMWJn  Take a look at both reports and tell us what you think.   Is their presence degrading to women?

Link Title: SA wine region hit by violence
Message: South Africa's police have fired rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse striking farm workers in the wine-producing Western Cape region.  The workers barricaded roads and threw stones at police in De Doorns town, a top grape-producing area, local media reported.  The strikers, who pick and pack fruit, are demanding their daily wage be more than doubled to about $17.  South Africa has been hit by a series of wildcat strikes since last year.

In what's being called the first major prisoner swap, 48 Iranians held hostage by rebel fighters in Syria since August have been freed.  The rebels claimed the Iranians had been assisting the Syrian military, but Iran insisted they were Shia pilgrims. A Turkish charity said they were released in exchange for more than 2000 prisoners held by the Syrian authorities.

India says one of two soldiers killed in an alleged cross-border attack by Pakistan troops in the disputed territory of Kashmir was beheaded.
