India has summoned Pakistan's top diplomat in New Delhi to formally complain about the attack. Pakistan has rejected allegations that it killed any Indian soldiers.   Kashmir continues to be claimed by both India and Pakistan. Control remains divided between them, which is marked by a Line of Control. The countries have fought two wars over Kashmir. A cease-fire between the two rivals has largely held for a decade.

Link Title: LAKHDAR BRAHIMI INTERVIEW BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Lakhdar Brahimi, the UN-Arab League envoy for the Syrian crisis, has described President Bashar Al-Assad's recent rare public speech as a lost opportunity for peace.   Speaking exclusively to BBC's Lyse Doucet he was responding to the President's speech on Sunday where he outlined what he described as a new initiative.  It included dialogue, a national reconciliation conference and the formation of a government to oversee new elections.   Mr Brahimi began by answering whether president Assad's speech made his job more difficult.

Link Title: World Have Your Say: Letters To Obama
Message: Inauguration day for President Barack Obama's second term at the White House is fast approaching, so we'd like to give you an opportunity to film your ''letter to Obama' .  Which key issues would you like him to address at home and abroad?   What would you do if you were President of the United States?  We'll try to broadcast as many of your videos as we can on World News as the inauguration date draws closer.  For all the details of how to record and send your message just click on the link below.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-17928844

PHOTOS: The temperatures have fallen, for the moment,  but there are still up to 30 fires raging out of control in eastern Australia.   In New South Wales four regions are classed as 'catastrophic' and fires are also burning in Victoria and Tasmania. And the forecast is for a return to searing heat.    Take a look at some of the most dramatic pictures from across the country.

Will we ever find another planet just like Earth? http://bbc.in/UUNH5J  Astronomers say that one in six stars hosts an Earth-sized planet in a close orbit - suggesting a total of 17 billion such planets in our galaxy.  The result comes from an analysis of planet candidates gathered by Nasa's Kepler space observatory."

Is Afghanistan ready for US troops to leave? http://bbc.in/UUx8a3  Afghan President Karzai has arrived in the US and is due to meet with US President Obama on Friday - the role of US troops in Afghanistan's towns and villages is sure to be a topic of conversation.   Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the upcoming meeting and other news from around the world, including:  - Australia's fires http://bbc.in/UUx8a7 - Tensions in Belfast http://bbc.in/UUx7mB - 17 Billion earth-sized planets http://bbc.in/UUx7mL - Gadgets and gizmos at CES 2012 http://bbc.in/UUx8a9  Check your local listings to find BBC World news where you live.   Join the conversation on Twitter by following @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/UUx7mD

When Cesar Kuriyama saved up enough money to quit his advertising job at the age of 30, he planned to take a year off to travel and spend time with family  http://bbc.in/13gA0Bh  To document the year, Kuriyama filmed one second of video every day. After editing the clips into a single video, Kuriyama had not only a record of daily life, but a new perspective on how he lived day to day.  Now he plans to do it for the rest of his life.  He's even developed a smartphone application which allows others to create their own "one second" videos http://bbc.in/13gA0Bh

A former US congresswoman who survived a gunshot wound to her head during a mass shooting has launched a campaign against gun violence.  Gabrielle Giffords' Americans for Responsible Solutions initiative aims to raise money for gun control efforts.  A school shooting in December that killed 20 children and six adults has fuelled debate over gun violence.
David Bowie has released a new single after a decade.   The track 'Where Are We Now ' will be followed by a new album later this year.  Have a listen and let us know what you think?

Astronomers say that one in six stars hosts an Earth-sized planet in a close orbit - suggesting a total of 17 billion such planets in our galaxy.  The result comes from an analysis of planet candidates gathered by Nasa's Kepler space observatory.  The Kepler scientists also announced 461 new planet candidates, bringing the satellites' total haul to 2,740.

Link Title: Heat and wind fan Australia fires
Message: High winds and record temperatures have fanned fires in south-east Australia, as the prime minister warned of a "very dangerous day".   More than 100 fires have already been reported in New South Wales, with residents in some areas urged to leave.  An uncontrolled fire is burning by the Tasman peninsula, near areas already hit by blazes over the weekend.

How will crews cope on a mission to Mars? http://bbc.in/13etpap  Results from the Mars500 project, a simulated mission to Mars, shows that some of the crew experienced isolation and mild depression.  For much of the time, the men had only limited contact with the outside world. Their simulated spaceship had no windows, and the protocols demanded their communications endured a similar time lag to that encountered by real messages as they travel the vast distance between Earth and Mars.

Journalists at Southern Weekly, a major Chinese newspaper, have gone on strike in a rare protest against censorship http://bbc.in/13enNwV  Will these protests bring about more press freedom in China?   Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at China's reaction to the strike and other news from around the world, including:   - Obama's Pentagon and CIA nominees  http://bbc.in/13enNwQ  - Delhi gang rape suspects charged http://bbc.in/13enL87  - Belfast situation 'tense'  http://bbc.in/13enL8e  - Fires in Tasmania  http://bbc.in/13enL8c  - Bank of America to settle claims http://bbc.in/13enNwT  - South Africa's unlikely opera singer http://bbc.in/13enNwX  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/13enNwN

The music was alien to him and the language incomprehensible, but for Mthetho Maphoyi, the chance discovery of a CD of opera music led to a life-changing experience http://bbc.in/13e9bxl   His love of the music and the kindness of strangers such as pianist Derk Blaise has opened up a whole new world to the boy from the Western Cape township in South Africa.
Digital caves are a revelation for tourists - and offer respite for ancient historical sites. Jane O'Brien explores how 3-d recreations can be even better than the real thing.

Bahrain's highest appeal court has upheld the sentences of 13 activists for their part in anti-government protests in 2011.  This was their last possible chance of getting their convictions overturned, the men's defence lawyers said.  Some of the activists received life sentences after being convicted of plotting to overthrow the state.  Bahrain has been wracked by unrest since pro-democracy demonstrations began in February 2011.

Find out why the inhabitants of a small Greek island live on average 10 years longer than the rest of western Europe.    Included is an amazing story about the 98 year old Stamatis Moraitis who, while living in the US in the 1960s, was diagnosed with terminal lung cancer.    He returned home to Ikaria to be buried with his parents but  45 years on and Stamatis still lives happily on his beloved island.    He even went back to the US in hope of telling his doctors about his good health.    "A few years ago I went back to the US and tried to find my doctors. But I couldn't find them. They were all dead."    And what does he attribute his good health to?    "It's the wine. It's pure, nothing added. The wine they make commercially has preservatives. That's no good. But this wine we make ourselves is pure."      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20898379

INTERACTIVE:    Settled by civilisations spanning some five millennia, Gaza has been built layer-upon-layer since the Bronze Age.    As each era ended, its people left behind remnants of their times - churches, monasteries, palaces and mosques, as well as thousands of precious artefacts.    While traces of its rich past remain, the race to preserve what is left beneath the surface of this battle-scarred land is fraught with problems.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20853440

Almost a hundred editorial staff at one of China's most respected newspapers are striking over Communist censorship.  The journalists from 'Southern Weekly' have called for the local propaganda chief's resignation, after the paper's New Year's message, was re-written as a Communist party tribute.  A crowd of supporters has also reportedly gathered outside the paper's offices in Guangzhou.

Link Title: Five Delhi rape suspects in court
Message: It's a case that has sparked outrage and protests across India. Five men accused of the gang-rape and murder of a female student on a bus in Delhi are appearing in court for the first time.   The men arrived at the court not long after reports emerged of another gang rape also in the Delhi area..   The case itself has been temporarily adjourned after chaotic scenes in the courtroom. The judge has ordered a closed hearing.  The case is expected to be transferred to a new fast-track court for trial.

Syrian President Bashar al-Assad has delivered a rare TV address, denouncing his opponents as "enemies of God and puppets of the West" http://bbc.in/13bS3IO  He lamented the suffering of the people in the civil war, saying a "black cloud" of pain engulfed every corner.

From Queensland to Tasmania, local Australian artisans are creating unique handcrafted items which make great souvenirs for the discerning traveller. BBC Travel takes a look at some of the best: http://bit.ly/133LNna

Here is our brief look at today's news from around the world:  - 'Five dead' in plane crash near Grenoble http://bbc.in/UNfXaD -  Tuna fetches $1.7m http://bbc.in/UNfVQ3 - Sudanese leaders to meet in Ethiopia  http://bbc.in/UNfVPQ - Loyalists attack police in east Belfast  http://bbc.in/UNfXax - 'World's fattest man' sheds 46 stone  http://bbc.in/UNfVPW - US Senator guilty of drink-driving  http://bbc.in/UNfXqR - Cat 'arrested' for jail break-in  http://bbc.in/UNfXaB - A funny look at the world of news in 140 characters or less  http://bbc.in/UNfXaz  Enjoy the weekend & check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.

High self-esteem can often be regarded as a good thing.  And new research suggests increasing numbers of US university students think they're something special, in terms of their ability, drive and skills.  Would you label yourself as gifted? Or do you feel it would be arrogant to do so?  http://bbc.in/138XqbA

Do you consider yoga a competitive sport? http://bbc.in/138M87a  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll meet author Benjamin Lorr and hear his story of how yoga changed his body and perspective. We'll also look at other news from around the world, including:   - Malala leaves hospital http://bbc.in/138M876 - Chavez battles infection http://bbc.in/138M6MD - A crazy week for the US economy http://bbc.in/138M87c - Drilling rig runs aground off Alaska http://bbc.in/138M6MH - Will you be listening to these California sisters in 2013? http://bbc.in/138M87g  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation with @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/138M874

After breaking for the holidays, Nasa's Curiosity rover is very close to drilling into its first Martian rock, with the set-up operation likely to begin next week http://bbc.in/138xZ9Y  All of Curiosity's instruments have been commissioned. The drill is the only tool that has yet to be deployed.  Its hammer action will enable the device to retrieve powdered samples from up to 5cm inside the rock, which can then passed to the rover's onboard laboratories for analysis.

Health authorities in the UK have begun an inquiry after a woman died just two days after eating Christmas lunch in a London pub.    30 others have fallen ill. Dangerous bacteria was found in samples taken from the affected diners.

Lying within the Arctic Circle, northern Norway’s Lofoten Archipelago is a hauntingly dramatic landscape full of beautiful harbour scenery, jagged peaks and a vibrant fishing history. BBC Travel takes you there: http://bit.ly/VD5gFy

A rare protest against censorship in China ... Journalists at a leading Chinese newspaper have demanded the resignation of a senior Communist party official.   Former staff at the Southern Weekly want the official to quit after he changed an editorial into a Communist Party tribute.   The row has opened up the debate about freedom of speech and constitutional reforms in China

Two gum trees made famous by one of Australia's most renowned indigenous artists have been burnt to the ground.  It's suspected the fire was started deliberately. The trees had been due to be added to a national heritage register.

Does confidence really breed success?     US research suggests that more and more American university students think they are something special. High self-esteem is generally regarded as a good thing. But could too much of it actually make you less successful?     Check out the analysis here --> http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20756247
Thousands of Palestinians have gathered to mark 48 years of Fatah. It's the first Fatah rally held in the Gaza Strip since Hamas took power in the region in 2007.

The Pakistani schoolgirl, who survived a gun attack by the Taliban, has been discharged from hospital in the UK.   Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head because she'd campaigned for education for girls. She'll undergo major reconstructive surgery in a few weeks' time.

Did this dark lump of rock found in the Moroccan desert come from Mars? http://bbc.in/UJNlis  The texture and chemistry set it apart from all previous objects picked up off the surface of Earth but are known to exist on the Red Planet.  What can we learn about our neighbouring planet from this small rock?

Indian authorities have charged five men with the kidnap, gang rape and murder of a woman in Delhi last month http://bbc.in/136HVAT  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the charges and what they mean for women in India. We'll also take a look at other news from around the world, including:  - Drone attack kills militant http://bbc.in/136HVAP - Depardieu now Russian http://bbc.in/136HTJn - Cattle rustling in Texas http://bbc.in/136HTJp  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/136HVAR

Where next for the French actor, Gerard Depardieu? He's been awarded Russian citizenship by President Putin.   Depardieu has threatened to give up his French passport in protest at planned tax rises on the rich by the Socialist government there.

Link Title: US town bans small water bottles
Message: Feeling thirsty? A town in the US state of Massachusetts has banned the sale of bottled water in units smaller than a litre. The idea is to reduce waste and encourage tap water use. Will it work?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20895902
One of the best known pieces of dietary advice is to eat five portions of fruit and vegetables a day. But where did it originate?

Link Title: Delhi rape suspects to be charged
Message: Five men in India have been formally charged with the kidnap, gang-rape and murder of a woman on a Delhi bus last month.  The 23-year-old medical student died from the injuries she sustained during the attack.

There are reports that a Pakistani militant commander, Mullah Nazir, has been killed in a US drone attack.   Security officials say at least five other militants were killed in the missile attack in South Waziristan, near the Afghan border.

What can stolen cows tell us about the US economy? http://bbc.in/UGWZlZ  The BBC's Paul Adams takes a look at the unique crime of cattle rustling, a staple of many a western movie, and introduces us to the team of rangers on the case.

Can two pensioners from Lincolnshire get this WWII Lancaster bomber flying again? http://bbc.in/UGN8fP  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll meet the Panton brothers and hear why they are so passionate about restoring this rare plane. We'll also take a look at other news from around the world, including: - What happened to the Fukushima 50? http://bbc.in/UGN9QT - Pakistan's polio worker killings http://bbc.in/UGN7Zt - US dodges the "fiscal cliff" http://bbc.in/UGN8fL - UN says 60,000 dead in Syria http://bbc.in/UGN8fR  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/UGN9QN for the latest from our producers and correspondents working in North America.

"There is no reason for me at the moment to believe anything they tell me." - Chris Christie, Governor of New Jersey  http://bbc.in/UGy2XA  The US House of Representatives will not vote on a $60bn (£37bn) super-storm Sandy aid package today and lawmakers from the US states of New York and New Jersey are angry.   The Senate approved a bill last week. A spokesman for Speaker Boehner said he was committed to passing a bill in January, but it will need to be reintroduced.  Representative Peter King, a New York Republican, told reporters. "It's wrong and I'm saying that as a member of the Republican Party." http://bbc.in/UGy2XA

The United Nations says the number of people killed in Syria since the start of the uprising there almost 2 years ago has reached at least 60,000.  A study commissioned by UN human rights commissioner Navi Pillay collated data from different sources, and concluded that there had been 59,648 deaths until November 2012.  Ms Pillay said the figure would now have risen above 60,000 and described the bloodshed as "truly shocking".  Syrian opposition groups had previously estimated 45,000 people killed.

It is considered to be one of the most valuable collections of modern art ever assembled but few have ever explored its riches.    The art, which includes about 300 pieces by Pablo Picasso worth bout $900m, is kept in the Geneva free port art storage site.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20696126

Rebel forces in the Central African Republic say they have halted their offensive on the capital, Bangui, and will take part in peace talks.  The announcement from the Seleka rebels comes as the country's neighbours say they are sending in extra troops.  Gabon deployed 120 troops on Tuesday and Cameroon was expected to send a similar number, the CAR's defence minister told the BBC.

AUDIO SLIDESHOW:    Take a look at stunning imagery of African wildlife as Sir David Attenborough spent four years exploring the whole continent, uncovering an astonishing array of previously unknown places, bizarre new creatures and extraordinary behaviours.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/in-pictures-20811945

Several people have been killed by an air strike on a petrol station in the outskirts of the Syrian capital, Damascus, say activists.    Witnesses said dozens of people had been killed or wounded in the attack on the Nawras station in Mleiha district. There is no confirmation.    Unverified video footage posted online showed charred bodies and vehicles.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20890108

Link Title: Call for law to mark Delhi victim
Message: India's junior Education Minister Shashi Tharoor has called for the Delhi gang-rape victim to be named so she can honoured in a revised anti-rape law.  Meanwhile, thousands of women have taken part in a rally in the Indian capital, Delhi, to protest against the recent gang rape of a 23-year-old medical student.  Police are expected to charge five of six suspects with murder on Thursday.  If convicted, they could face the death penalty, which is rarely carried out in India.

Link Title: Woman trapped in shop at New Year
Message: While most people celebrated New Year with parties and fireworks one pensioner in northern France spent the night alone in a locked supermarket.  The 73-year-old woman felt faint at the store in Roubaix and went to the toilet. But when she came out later she found the shop deserted and locked up.  French media say she set off the alarm repeatedly and spent the night wandering the aisles, but nobody came.  A member of staff found her safe but exhausted on Tuesday morning

VIDEO: Military aircraft have been targeting rebel areas in Burma's northern Kachin state over the last five days, video obtained by the BBC shows.  The footage, shot by the humanitarian group Free Burma Rangers, shows attack helicopters firing on the ground and jets flying close to the trenches of the rebel Kachin Independence Army.  A government official said the army had not informed them of any air attacks.  Fighting with the Kachin rebels resumed in 2011, after a 17-year truce.

ope Benedict XVI has condemned "unregulated capitalism" for contributing to world tension, in a new year address to worshippers.  The Pope also thanked the world's peacemakers and said humanity had "an innate vocation for peace".  The Roman Catholic Church leader spoke at a Mass in the Vatican, then greeted a crowd outside St Peter's Basilica.  He deplored "hotbeds of tension and conflict caused by growing instances of inequality between rich and poor".

France's President Francois Hollande says he still plans to raise the top rate of income tax after his 75% plan was struck down on technical grounds.  In a national address on New Year's Eve, he said the law would be redesigned, adding, "we will still ask more of those who have the most".  However, he did not mention the 75% figure, leading some to speculate that the move would be watered down.  The president also promised "all efforts" towards cutting unemployment.

Fierce clashes have erupted near the international airport in Syria's second city of Aleppo.   The rebels have been targeting the airport to limit the movement of government forces.   The state news agency reports that the Syrian army have been clearing surrounding areas after what it describes as clashes with armed terrorist groups.

New laws being introduced in the Netherlands mean people who visit so-called coffee shops that sell cannabis will have to provide ID and an official document confirming they live in the country.   But several cities, including Amsterdam, may try to delay their full implementation because they do not want to miss out on income from non-Dutch tourists.

A team of scientists have said they believe an old gourd contains the blood of French King Louis XVI.  The monarch was killed by guillotine by French revolutionaries more than 200 years ago, on 21 January 1793.  The scientists said the DNA is very similar to genetic material from what is believed to be the mummified head of an earlier French king, AFP reports.  After Louis XIV's beheading many spectators were reported to have dipped their handkerchiefs in his blood.

South Africa is marketed to the world as Mandela's rainbow nation, where everyone is proud of their race and heritage.     But for some black South Africans there is such a thing as being too black.     As a result millions of Africans are using harmful creams to bleach their skins despite the many dangers associated with the products.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20444798

At least 60 people have been crushed to death and more than 200 injured during new year festivities in Ivory Coast's main city Abidjan, officials say.  The incident occurred in the early hours of Tuesday near a stadium in the central Plateau area of the city where a fireworks display was held.  The cause of the stampede is not yet clear. It occurred as people were heading home after the event.  Most of the dead are believed to be children aged between eight and 15.  The death toll is expected to rise.

Since the overthrow of Muammar Gaddafi, Libyans have begun a love affair with ice cream. Never before has the decadent Italian influence on Libya been more visible.  Before the revolution, there were only a handful of ice cream shops, known as gelaterias, in the capital, Tripoli. Since the uprising, gelato shops have been opening up in almost every busy street - with names such as Buenissimo, Limona and GilatiItalia. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20850246
BBC World News would like to wish you all a Happy New Year!  Take a look at how people around the world have celebrated the beginning of 2013.

Link Title: N Korea's Kim in rare TV speech
Message: The North Korean leader has delivered a new year's message on state TV, the first such broadcast for 19 years.  Kim Jong-un, in power since 2011, spoke of the need to improve the economy and also to reunify the Koreas, warning that confrontation only led to war.  The speech came less than a month after the conservative Park Geun-hye was elected president of South Korea.  In 1994, Mr Kim's grandfather, Kim Il-sung, spoke on radio and TV. His son, Kim Jong-il rarely spoke in public.
Pictures from around the world as festivities get under way to welcome in 2013.

Pakistan frees the former justice minister of the Afghan Taliban, Mullah Turabi, as part of moves to encourage a peace process, an official says.  Afghan officials have been in talks with Pakistani counterparts to try to free certain Taliban prisoners in order to push forward a peace process.  Pakistan released 13 Afghan Taliban members in November.  However, the former Afghan Taliban number two, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, remains in Pakistani custody.

Link Title: What if we jump over the US fiscal cliff?
Message: After almost two years, a game of fiscal chicken between President Barack Obama and Republicans in Congress is reaching its final moments.  That so-called "fiscal cliff" is approaching fast and still no deal has been made.  What are the various scenarios for what could happen next?

Bagpipes are usually associated with Scotland which is the worlds largest maker of the instrument.     BUT which country is right behind the Scotland?    Find out by clicking on the link    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20876096

India has scaled back New Year celebrations, as it mourned the death of a woman whose gang rape on a bus a fortnight ago sparked public outrage.  The army has cancelled all official celebrations as have the states of Punjab and Haryana.  The president of the governing Congress party, Sonia Gandhi, also said she would not be celebrating.  Meanwhile, protests continued on Monday in the capital, Delhi, where the 23-year-old medical student was assaulted.
What might 2013 bring?   BBC correspondents make their predictions on the big stories and the names to watch.

For decades, Libya appeared to be starved of talent. The entertainment industry is still virtually non-existent.     But since the uprising Libya's musicians - including heavy metal bands - and artists are enjoying the creative freedom.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20874795

Link Title: Chinese couple turn 100 on same day
Message: VIDEO: A village in China has been marking a very special occasion with a married couple celebrating their 100th birthdays on the same day.  Shi Sifan and his wife Liu Yaogu were both born on 28 December 1912. The couple have four children and have spent 78 years together.

A group of about 450 Rohingya Muslims from Burma have arrived on Malaysia's Langkawi island after a two-week boat journey, officials say.    It is believed to be one of the largest groups of Rohingya migrants to have arrived in Malaysia this year.    One man is reported to have drowned trying to swim ashore. The others have been taken to a detention centre.    Many Rohingyas have fled Burma's Rakhine state as deadly clashes flared earlier this year.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20873678

Modern Vienna is the cultural and political heart of Austria and a world-class city with a soft spot for the finer things in life. BBC Travel tells you what you need to know about living in this Central European city.
Images of prominent events in 2012 in India, including the deaths of some of the country's leading arts figures and politicians.

France's constitutional council has struck down a top income tax rate of 75% introduced by Socialist President Francois Hollande.  Raising taxes for those earning more than 1m euros has been a flagship policy for Mr Hollande.  The policy angered France's business community and prompted some wealthy citizens to say they would emigrate.  Mr Hollande's government said it would rework the tax, due to take effect in 2013, to meet the council's complaints

Link Title: Delhi calm plea after rape death
Message: Thousands of people have staged peaceful protests in India's capital, Delhi, following the death of a woman who was gang-raped in the city.  The 23-year old woman, who has not been identified, died early on Saturday at a hospital in Singapore, where she had been taken for specialist treatment.  The attack on 16 December triggered violent public protests in India.  Six men who had been arrested in connection with the rape have now also been charged with murder.
Articles about Facebook, cul-de-sacs, adult video actresses, One Direction and the @ symbol are among some of 2012's most clicked Wikipedia pages. For more click below.

A Florida fossils dealer has admitted smuggling dinosaur bones into the US, including those of a 70-million-year-old Tyrannosaurus bataar from Mongolia.  A court in New York heard that Eric Prokopi sold the skeleton at auction in May for more than $1m

The 1982 invasion of the Falkland Islands by Argentina took the then prime minister Margaret Thatcher by surprise, newly released archive papers show.  The then-prime minister only saw it was likely after getting "raw intelligence" two days before the Argentines landed.  Papers released under the 30-year rule show Mrs Thatcher was acutely worried about retaking the islands.
The Daily Meal has unveiled its list of the 101 best restaurants in Europe, featuring eateries in 26 countries and 70 cities. BBC Travel investigates:

Link Title: US evacuates its embassy in CAR
Message: The US says it has evacuated its embassy in the Central African Republic as rebels threaten to advance towards the capital, Bangui.  The state department said it had not broken off diplomatic ties with the government but warned US citizens not to travel to CAR during the unrest.  Earlier, CAR President Francois Bozize appealed to the US and France to help block the rebel advance.  The UN has said it is evacuating its non-essential staff from the country.

A female student gang-raped on a bus in India's capital Delhi has "taken a turn for the worse" at a Singapore hospital, doctors say.  The 23-year-old arrived in Singapore on Thursday after undergoing three operations in a Delhi hospital.  "Her vital signs are deteriorating with signs of severe organ failure," hospital chief executive Kelvin Loh said in a statement.  Doctors had earlier described the woman as "fighting for her life"

Former Italian Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, is rounding out the year with a divorce, and he has reportedly agreed to pay his ex-wife almost four million dollars a MONTH as part of their settlement.   Veronica Lario, with whom Mr Berlusconi has three children, filed for divorce 3 years ago. She accused him of having relationships with young women.   Mr. Berlusconi will keep the family home which is worth around $100 million. Forbes Magazine has estimated Mr. Berlusconi is worth around $6 billion.
PICTURE GALLERY:    Take a look at 2012's stunning imagery from on high     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20214931

VIDEO:  Many of the hundreds of thousands of migrants who enter Greece are Muslim, yet Athens remains the only EU capital without an official mosque.  Now there are plans to build one next year but, as Mark Lowen reports, the near-bankrupt country may find it hard to deliver.
PICTURE GALLERY:   Take a look at some of the pictures that made the headlines in 2012

China has tightened its rules on internet usage to enforce a previous requirement that users fully identify themselves to service providers.  The move is part of a package of measures which state-run Xinhua news agency said would protect personal information.  But critics believe the government is trying to limit freedom of speech.  The announcement will be seen as evidence China's new leadership is targeting the internet as a threat.

An Indian woman whose gang rape on a public bus in Delhi earlier this month caused national outrage is fighting for her life.   Doctors treating her at a hospital in Singapore say she is on life support and that she has suffered brain injuries.   In India, political leaders are responding to calls for justice - and for changes in the laws in India to better protect women against sexual assault.

The US appears to be heading over the "fiscal cliff", with prospects dim for a deal to avoid tax rises and spending cuts, the US Senate leader says.  Speaking on the Senate floor, Democrat Harry Reid said there did not seem to be enough time to craft a deal before Monday night's end-of-year deadline.  Senators and President Barack Obama have returned to Washington, while the House of Representatives is in recess.  Analysts say heading over the "cliff" could tip the US into recession.

Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has sacked Health Minister Marziyeh Vahid Dastjerdi, the sole woman in his cabinet, state television reports.  Ms Dastjerdi was also the first woman minister in the 30-year history of the Islamic republic.  While no reason has been given, the dismissal is being linked to her call for drug price rises to fight shortages caused by international sanctions.  Mr Ahmadinejad rejected her comments, saying her budget needs had been met.

So many men were murdered during Rwanda's 1994 genocide that the women were left to pick up the pieces... but it has not been an easy task.    This is a fascinating look into how women helped rebuild Rwanda after the genocide.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20727127

AUDIO SLIDESHOW:  From the first man on the Moon, to the man whose followers became known as the Moonies - and from Dallas's JR Ewing to the puppeteer behind Sesame Street's Count von Count - the past 12 months have seen the passing of many well-known figures.    At the end of another year, spend a few minutes looking back at some of the faces - no longer with us - who made their mark on the international stage.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20743959

A British mission to find life in the hidden waters of an Antarctic lake has been suspended.   Scientists had been attempting to break through to Lake Ellsworth -- some two miles under the ice -- but they've been thwarted by a series of technical difficulties.

Every year the Magazine selects a group of men and women to be its Faces of the Year.    It's not an award. This is not a definitive list of the most important or influential people. It's not based on people's achievements, their popularity or their contribution to society.    It is not about people like Barack Obama, or the Pope, who make the news every year, but those whose fame is really something of the last 12 months.    Here are three women who made headlines in 2012: Reporter Marie Colvin, activist Malala Yousafzai, and boxer Nicola Adams.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20696239

Link Title: Tea workers burn boss to death
Message: Hundreds of tea plantation workers in North-East India have set fire to their boss's bungalow, burning him and his wife to death.  Angry workers surrounded the manager's bungalow at Kunapathar in Tinsukia, Assam state. They torched the building and two vehicles.    Police say the incident happened after the management asked some workers to leave their accommodation.

From a new species of animals to mysterious new planets to the Higgs-like boson, scientists were kept busy with new discoveries in 2012. Here's BBC Future's gallery of the most stunning findings over the past 12 months. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121219-2012-the-year-in-discoveries

Large crowds of Pakistan People's Party (PPP) supporters are gathering to mark the 5th anniversary of the murder of ex-PM Benazir Bhutto.  Ms Bhutto died in a gun and bomb attack during her 2007 election campaign.  Hundreds of thousands of people have set up camp near the Bhutto family's ancestral home in Sindh province.  Benazir Bhutto son is launching his political career today. Bilawal Bhutto Zardari is to set out his vision for the first time in front of thousands of supporters at the family seat in the province of Sindh.

What are your memories of the programmes created by Gerry Anderson? Send them to us and presenter Peter Dobbie will read out a selection in the next couple of hours http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-oxfordshire-20845407

http://www.bbc.co.uk/neAn explosion in a warehouse has sparked a major fire in Lagos, Nigeria's largest city and commercial capital.  Witnesses said fireworks were stored in the warehouse in the busy market area of Lagos Island, and the blaze quickly spread to other buildings.  The blast reportedly shook windows of homes several miles away and a thick cloud of smoke could be seen rising over the island.  It was not immediately clear if there were any fatalities.
BBC's Christian Fraser takes a close look at the celebrations for the 850th anniversary of Notre Dame cathedral in Paris.
Merry Christmas from the team on duty at BBC World News!

South Africa's first black President Nelson Mandela will spend Christmas in hospital, a government statement has said.  Mr Mandela, 94, was admitted to hospital two weeks ago and has been treated for a lung infection and gallstones.  There is growing concern in South Africa about his health.

Christians around the world are celebrating Christmas, which marks the birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem.  In the city itself, Christmas Eve Mass was celebrated at the 1,700-year-old Church of the Nativity, on the spot where it is believed Jesus was born.  Meanwhile in the Vatican, Pope Benedict XVI held the traditional Mass at St Peter's Basilica.  He urged Christians to "find time and room for God in their fast-paced lives".  The Pope prayed that Israelis and Palestinians would be able to live their lives in peace. He also prayed for peace in Lebanon, Syria and Iraq.  How are you celebrating Christmas? Send your pictures and videos to yourpics@bbc.co.uk

Link Title: India PM appeals for Delhi calm
Message: Indian PM Manmohan Singh has appealed for calm in the capital, Delhi, following violent protests over the gang rape of a woman.  Mr Singh said his government would "make all possible efforts to ensure security and safety to all women".  More than 100 people were hurt in clashes at the weekend - police say at least 60 officers were injured.  The rape, which happened on a bus in Delhi and left the woman in a critical condition, has caused outrage in India.

It might seem churlish to dissect such an enduring image of Christmas as the star of Bethlehem, but a quiet astronomical debate has been bubbling away for decades. Could some real cosmic event have drawn "three wise men" on a journey to find a newborn king?     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20730828

"Not a single mausoleum will remain in Timbuktu," Abou Dardar, a leader of the Islamist group Ansar Dine.  Islamists in Mali have begun destroying remaining mausoleums in the historic city of Timbuktu, an Islamist leader and a tourism official said.  Islamists in control of northern Mali began earlier this year to pull down shrines that they consider idolatrous.

Many sites in this world are considered strange – but only a few garner the status of being completely surreal, as if from a different planet. BBC Travel visits six of the most otherworldly sites on Earth, including The Wave, a 62ft-wide and 85ft-long sandstone rock formation in Arizona that gets its name from the swirling, undulating lines that traverse the ground, caused by wind erosion. What places would add to this bizarre list?

Egypt's main opposition has demanded an inquiry into the referendum on the draft constitution, citing fraud.  The National Salvation Front urged the election commission to investigate the "irregularities".  Initial unofficial results indicate a "Yes" vote for a document which President Mohammed Morsi says will safeguard democracy.  The opposition says the constitution favours Islamists, and the referendum has highlighted bitter divisions.  The result is expected to be officially announced on Monday.

Record-breaking India batsman Sachin Tendulkar has retired from one-day international cricket.  In a statement, the 39-year-old said:  "I feel blessed to have fulfilled the dream of being part of a World Cup-winning Indian team."   The 'Little Master' made his one-day debut in 1989 and collected 463 caps.  He excelled in the 50-over format and became the world's top run-scorer with 18,426 at an average of 44.83, including a record 49 centuries.

Egyptians appear to have approved a controversial new constitution in a referendum, unofficial and preliminary results indicate.  Results reported by state media suggest that some 63% of voters backed the charter over two rounds of polling.  Critics say the document, which has triggered mass protests, betrays the revolution that toppled Hosni Mubarak.  President Mohammed Morsi's mainly Islamist supporters say it will secure democracy and encourage stability.

What do the "fiscal cliff" debates mean for markets around the world? http://bbc.in/12EY9kD  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the debate and other news from around the world, including:  - NRA reacts to Newtown http://bbc.in/12EY9kH - Kerry nominated http://bbc.in/12EYaVB - Understanding the DC network - We're still here http://bbc.in/12EYaVF  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.  Join the conversation by following @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/12EY9kB

"Good guys with guns stop bad guys with guns" http://bbc.in/UdFOIr  Shortly after the US observed a national moment of silence for the 26 victims of the school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut , the National Rifle Association (NRA) called for armed security at schools http://bbc.in/UdFOIp  Wayne LaPierre, chief executive of the NRA, criticised politicians who had "exploited" the tragedy in Newtown for "political gain," called for a national database of the mentally ill and blamed violent video games and films for portraying murder as a "way of life".  Where do you stand on the NRA's call for armed security in US schools?

Are you worried about your flights being delayed or cancelled this holiday season? BBC Travel brings you the pocket-sized guides to flyers’ rights, which will help you decode what compensation you might be owed. http://bit.ly/TGOYMh

US President Barack Obama is to nominate John Kerry to be his next secretary of state, US media report http://bbc.in/12EqOWR  Mr Kerry would replace Hillary Clinton at the head of the state department, the media quoted senior administration officials as saying.  Mr Kerry ran as Democratic presidential candidate in 2004 and is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Many women in the world are struggling to make their mark in male dominated societies. One organisation is trying to do something about that. The Barefoot College in India trains women from poor backgrounds to become solar engineers.     This weekend, BBC World News is showing Solar Mamas, a film which focuses on two women from Jordan going through that training - and the struggle they face  when they return home.       You can watch a clip  by clicking here or you can see the full programme on BBC World News at 0910 GMT or 2010 GMT on Saturday, December 22.  Or go to bbcworldnews.com/tvschedule to find out what time you can tune in where you live.  Let us know what you think about this film.     The film is part of a global cross media event called Why Poverty? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-20316363

French actress Catherine Deneuve has defended fellow movie star Gerard Depardieu over his move to Belgium in a row about tax exiles  Depardieu has criticised the Socialist government for its new 75% wealth tax.  Next year, the top rate of income tax in France is due to become 75% on earnings above 1m euros ($1.3m). Belgium's highest tax rate is currently 50%.  French Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault has condemned Depardieu's decision as "shabby".  Do those earning millions have the responsibility to stay in their home country and contribute with their tax payments?   Or is it perfectly reasonable for them to seek countries where tax rates are lower?

Link Title: Many dead in Kenya coast violence
Message: Police say at least 39 people have been killed and dozens more wounded in a fresh outbreak of violence in the Tana Delta region of southern Kenya.   A village was attacked at dawn by people with machetes and houses were set on fire. Many of the victims are believed to be from the Orma tribe, which has had frequent clashes with Pakomo farmers over access to land and water.

Link Title: Russian MPs back US adoptions ban
Message: Russian MPs have approved a ban on Americans adopting Russian children.  The bill also proposes to ban US-funded non-governmental organisations that do any political work in Russia.  It is a response to the US Magnitsky Act, which blacklists Russian alleged human rights violators. Sergei Magnitsky, an anti-corruption lawyer, died in a Russian jail in 2009.

Fans and celebrities have paid tribute to Indian sitar maestro Ravi Shankar at a memorial near his home in California.  Former Beatle George Harrison's widow spoke at the event and tributes from singer Peter Gabriel and film director Martin Scorsese were read out.  Shankar died in a US hospital aged 92, after failing to recover from surgery earlier this month.  He gained widespread international recognition through his association with The Beatles.  George Harrison once called Shankar "the godfather of world music".

The Republican-led US House is set to vote on a package of spending cuts and tax rises party leaders say will keep the US away from the "fiscal cliff". The vote comes as talks with the White House appear to have stalled, with President Barack Obama seeking a lower threshold http://bbc.in/12D5PUi  More on the "fiscal cliff":   - Theatrics at the cliff edge http://bbc.in/12D5QI6  - Q&A: The US fiscal cliff http://bbc.in/12D5QI4  - What is the US fiscal cliff? http://bbc.in/12D5QYk  - Who first called it a 'fiscal cliff'? http://bbc.in/12D5PUk

I've heard there was a secret chord That David played, and it pleased the Lord But you don't really care for music, do you?   Do you remember the first time you heard these lyrics? http://bbc.in/UbDBwZ  On tonight's BBC World News America we'll look at how Leonard Cohen's song started as a rejected pop tune and became a modern hymn" http://bbc.in/UbDBwZ and look at other news from around the world, including:  - House Republicans vote on Plan B http://bbc.in/UbDEcc - Latest on Benghazi attack http://bbc.in/UbDBx3 - The dangers of rubber bullets - It's the end of the world ... not really http://bbc.in/UbDBx1  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/UbDEc8 for the latest from our staff and correspondents working in North America.

At least three people have died as the first major snowstorm of the season crosses the US Midwest. Blizzard conditions and as much as 1ft (30cm) of snow are expected from Kansas to Wisconsin, with the Rocky Mountains already blanketed http://bbc.in/12CGfyW  As Christmas approaches, we take a look at the two large low pressure systems bringing strong winds, rain and snow to our Facebook friends in the US http://bbc.in/12CGfyY

Poland is Europe's least multicultural society, but could be on the cusp of becoming a destination for a new wave of migrants.  "I feel proud that Poland is a destination country for economic migrants. We understand them perfectly because, up until now, we have been the economic migrants." Poland's Minister for Foreigners.  Paul Henley meets the migrants heading to Poland, attracted by its thriving economy.

Link Title: Putin backs ban on US adoptions
Message: Russian President Vladimir Putin has defended a ban on Americans adopting Russian children, which has been proposed by the Russian parliament.  He said the bill, a response to the US Magnitsky Act which bars entry to Russian alleged human rights violators, was "appropriate".  Russian officials, he said, were not allowed to sit in on US cases involving the mistreatment of Russian children.

Link Title: Mayan apocalypse: End of the world, or a new beginning?
Message: Here on Impact we really hope this isn't our last edition.   We hope the Mayan calendar's predictions aren't correct and Friday 21st December ISN'T the end of the world - but if it were, how would you spend your final 24 hours?   Would you go to your favourite restaurant? Perhaps visit your favourite landmark? Or simply spend it with your loved ones?   I'm presenting Impact today at 13gmt and we'll be discussing this - please do get in touch to tell us what you'd do. Thanks, Karin.

The case of a woman who was raped in Delhi has caused outrage across India.   The victim was returning from the cinema on Sunday night when she was gang raped and beaten by six attackers.   Both GMT and Impact programmes would like to hear your thoughts on this story.  If you're in India what has the reaction been where you are and also tell us how women are treated day to day?   Do current laws need changing?  Has the government responded adequately?   We will use some of your comments in both of our programmes at 1200GMT and 1300GMT

Police in China have carried out further arrests of members of a doomsday cult for spreading rumours about the imminent end of the world, state media say.  Almost 1,000 members of Christian group Almighty God have now been detained.  State media terms Almighty God an "evil cult" - the same description it applies to the banned Falun Gong group.  The sect predicts Friday will usher in three days of darkness and has urged its members to overthrow communism.

In March 2012, a BBC report found a deep economic and social divide in the middle of the city of St Louis. Census data showed major differences in household income, property values and educational attainment depending on which side of Delmar Boulevard one lived http://bbc.in/12B3Hg0  The story quickly went viral in the city, cited by major publications, TV stations, public radio, and shared thousands of times on social networks.  See how the story sparked discussions among residents and civic leaders about what could be done next to bridge Delmar Boulevard http://bbc.in/12B3IjY

"Christmas won't be so happy for me this year, because I'm only happy when I'm with you. God grant that we can spend next year's Christmas together again." http://bbc.in/12AOuLJ  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll hear the story of a German soldiers' letters from Jersey that have been delivered 71 years late http://bbc.in/12AOuLJ  We'll also take a look at other news from around the globe, including:  - UBS fined $1.5bn for Libor rigging http://bbc.in/12AOuLL - Killings disrupt polio campaign http://bbc.in/12AOtHK - Time Magazine's Person of the Year.  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/12AOuLH for news and features from our staff working in North America.

Park Geun-hye, the daughter of former dictator Park Chung-hee, has defeated her liberal rival Moon Jae-in in the race to be the next President of South Korea http://bbc.in/12Axaqp  Votes are still being counted, but Mr Moon has admitted defeat. Turnout was high in a poll dominated by economic and social welfare issues.  Ms Park has said her victory will help the country's economy recover.

"The fact that we can't prevent every act of violence doesn't mean we can't steadily reduce the violence." http://bbc.in/12ArAnN  US President Barack Obama has called for "concrete proposals" on gun control by the end of January, saying "words need to lead to action".  Vice-President Joe Biden is set to lead an exploration of options after a mass school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut killed 26 children and teachers at a primary school.
Astronomers trawling through a mess of stellar data discover that Tau Ceti, our nearest single Sun-like star, hosts five planets - one in its "habitable zone".

Two polio vaccination workers have been killed in north-western Pakistan in the latest of a spate of deadly attacks.  The shootings in the Peshawar region left a vaccination supervisor and her driver dead, and injured a volunteer.  The deaths brought to eight the number of health workers killed in this week's anti-polio drive. The three-day drive is now over.  No group has claimed responsibility, but the Taliban have issued threats against the UN's anti-polio efforts.

The outpouring of anger in India is continuing over the gang rape of a young woman on a bus on Sunday.   Now police have used water cannon to break up demonstrations in Delhi. Protestors gathered in front of the residence of Delhi's chief minister, demanding more be done to protect women.   The Indian Government have promised to put more police on the streets. The woman remains in a critical condition.

'Thank you and we are listening' is the title of a blog posted by Instagram's co-founder Kevin Systrom.  it comes after widespread anger from social media users about the company's alleged plan to sell its users' photos to advertisers.  Facebook's photo-sharing site Instagram has today denied it plans to sell its users' photos to advertisers.   In a blog, Kevin Systrom said Instagram's Terms of Use would be changed to clarify this and he insisted that Instagram did not claim ownership rights of users' photos.

The UN is appealing for $1.5bn to fund relief efforts for those affected by the conflict in Syria.  Officials said $1bn was needed to meet the needs of the one million people expected to have fled to across Syria's borders in the next 6 months.  More than 525,000 Syrians have already crossed into neighbouring countries.  The UN is also seeking $519.6m to provide aid to the further four million people displaced inside Syria, almost double the previous estimate.  In total, the UN estimates that 25% of Syria's population now need humanitarian relief.

Hi, I'm presenting Impact today at 13gmt.   We'd like your thoughts on this story: Every year, vessels from the US-based conservation group Sea Shepherd follow the Japanese whaling fleet south to try and disrupt its activities in the Southern Ocean.    Now a US court has ordered Sea Shepherd to stay at least 500 yards away from Japan's whalers.   It banned the group from "physically attacking any vessel" and from "navigating in a manner" likely to endanger their "safe navigation".   We'd be grateful for your comment for our show today.   Thanks, Karin

Link Title: Polls show tight South Korea race
Message: An exit poll by three main television stations gives Park Geun-hye of the ruling Saenuri Party a very slim lead in South Korea's tight presidential race.  Combined figures from the networks released after polls closed gave her 50.1% of the vote over left-leaning rival Moon Jae-in's 48.9%.  But another poll by another television station put Mr Moon in the lead.  Formal results are expected late on Wednesday or in the early hours of Thursday.

Five female Pakistani polio vaccination workers have been fatally shot in a string of co-ordinated attacks http://bbc.in/U775MD  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take look at the attacks and other news from around the world, including:   - Obama supports assault weapons ban after Newtown tragedy http://bbc.in/U775MB - Gang rape of a young female student in India sparks outrage http://bbc.in/U775Mx - The artist behind the term "electronic superhighway" http://bbc.in/U778b4 - Satellites slam into Moon http://bbc.in/U777UN  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Join the conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/U777UK with news and features from our producers and correspondents working in North America.

Is it the diversity? The urban landscape? Culture? Great pizza? http://bbc.in/12yqEAq  New York City's start-up scene is booming, creating more than 10,000 jobs in the city over the past five years.   But is "Silicon Alley" really a credible rival to the California high tech corridor? http://bbc.in/12yqEAq

US President Barack Obama wants to reinstate an assault weapons ban in the wake of the mass killings in Newtown, Connecticut, his spokesman says http://bbc.in/12ykcJz  Jay Carney said the president was "actively supportive" of a Democratic senator's plan to introduce a bill on the first day of the next Congress.

Coming next week on BBC World – Kirsty Lang meets Led Zeppelin’s Jimmy Page for a fireside chat about his music, past and present.      Last month we brought you some highlights of the interview – now on Christmas Day we’ll have the full conversation.

VIDEO:    The phrase "field of gold" has taken on a quite literal meaning in the English county of Staffordshire.     Almost 100 new pieces of gold and silver have been discovered by archeologists in the same Staffordshire field at Hammerwich where 3,500 pieces were found in 2009.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20771067

The vice-president of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR) has been detained, the organisation has said.  Sayed Yousif al-Muhafdha was arrested at a protest on Monday in the capital, Manama, which commemorated the killing of two Bahrainis in 1994, it added.  Prosecutors ordered that Mr Muhafdha be held for a week pending an investigation into an accusation he broadcast false information on Twitter.  Last week, a court rejected an appeal by the BCHR's president, Nabeel Rajab.

Link Title: Instagram wants right to sell photos
Message: If you're an Instagram user you might be interested to read this.  Facebook's photo-sharing site Instagram has updated its privacy policy giving it the right to sell users' photos to advertisers without notification.   A notice updating the privacy policy on the Instagram site said:  "We may share your information as well as information from tools like cookies, log files, and device identifiers and location data with organisations that help us provide the service to you... (and) third-party advertising partners."  How do you feel of these changes?   Will you continue to use Instagram? Is it ethically a wise move and what impact will it have on Facebook's reputation?

Hello, it's Mishal.   Among our stories on Impact today - how some fans of the Russian football club Zenit St Petersburg are insisting that keeping the squad white is an 'important tradition'.  So, after years of anti-racism campaigning in football, is any progress being made?

Link Title: S Africa's ANC votes for leader
Message: South Africa's President Jacob Zuma has been re-elected as head of the ruling African National Congress.   Mr Zuma comfortably saw off a leadership challenge from his own deputy, Kgalema Motlanthe. He received an overwhelming majority of votes cast by some 4,000 delegates at the party's Mangaung conference.  Mr Motlanthe has been replaced by anti-apartheid era hero Cyril Ramaphosa as deputy president.

How would you cope if a tragedy hit your hometown? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20752695    On tonight's BBC World News America we'll meet a man returning home to Newtown, Connecticut after Friday's tragic shootings http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20754114    Family grieves for teacher http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20761177    'I could see shooter's feet' http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20758764    Will Newtown prompt changes in gun laws? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20760350

The first of 12 stadiums being built or extensively renovated for the 2014 World Cup has been inaugurated in Brazil. The Castelao Arena, with a capacity of some 65,000, was renovated at a cost of $250m (£155m).  Football's world governing body, Fifa, had repeatedly expressed concern over World Cup delays. But in recent weeks, Fifa officials have sounded more upbeat, saying that they expect all 12 stadiums to be ready on time.

The first funerals are being held for victims of Friday's shootings at a primary school in the US state of Connecticut http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20754114    Noah Pozner and Jack Pinto, both aged six, were the first of those killed at Sandy Hook school to be buried.    - "I could see shooter's feet" http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20758764  - The US & guns by the numbers http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20759139  - Obama: 'These tragedies must end' http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20751625  - Mark Mardell:Obama's pledge http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20752342    Photo Credit: Ben Tornquist, BBC World News America

"Unprecedented performance" and a "remarkable achievement"   That is what experts are saying about the US study in which brain implants were used to allow a paralysed woman to control a robotic arm with her thoughts.  Jan Scheuermann, who is 53 and paralysed from the neck down, was able to deftly grasp and move a variety of objects just like a normal arm.

Hi, Ros here. I'm prepping for the 1800 bulletin, but also playing close attention to the BBC African Footballer of the Year announcement. That's at 1650GMT - not long at all.     And this is a serious trophy. Not just because of the prestige that comes with it. It's also very very heavy. Here's a photo I took of Alex Jakana and Peter Okwoche from Focus on Africa using a trolley to get it onto set! Nice work chaps. Thanks.     Hear the announcement at bbcworldservice.com, and full coverage from Focus at 1730GMT on BBC World News TV. I know who I want to win but we'll see...

Link Title: Neither side can win - Syria VP
Message: Syrian Vice-President Farouq al-Sharaa tells a Lebanese newspaper neither the government's forces nor the rebels can win the 21-month-old conflict.  Mr Sharaa told Lebanese newspaper al-Akhbar that the situation was worsening and a "historic settlement" was needed.  He said neither the opposition nor the security forces could bring about a decisive end to the ongoing violence.  Do you agree with Mr. Sharaa's thoughts?

The official inquiry into a huge fire which killed 111 workers at a Bangladesh garment factory last month, has found that it was an act of sabotage.  The inquiry decided there was no possibility that the fire, which gutted the Tazreen factory, could have been caused by an electric short circuit.  It is recommending that the owner of the factory, in an industrial district of the capital, Dhaka, should face murder charges for gross negligence.

The financial crisis in Greece has hit hard and all sectors have been affected not least sport.     As funding for amateur football has been slashed, two local teams in central Greece have resorted to unusual sponsorship to make ends meet.    One team approached a funeral parlour and the other has found a sponsor whose business is actually thriving, a luxury brothel.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20732325

A 23-year-old Indian student has been allegedly gang-raped inside a private bus in the capital, Delhi, police say.  The woman was travelling with a male friend on Sunday night when they were attacked. They were brutally beaten, stripped and thrown out of the vehicle.  Both have been admitted to hospital. The condition of the woman is reported to be "critical".  Delhi is often called the "rape capital of India" - police recorded more than 550 cases in the city last year.

The Connecticut school shootings have re-opened the debate over the America's gun laws as long-term supporters of reform have issued calls for tighter controls.    But what impact, if any, will this tragic event have on the nation's gun laws?    Also what role does the media have in reporting on such events? Many have criticized the media for paying too much attention on the killer and not enough on the victims.    Do let us know what you think and we'll use some of your comments on our Impact programme at 1300GMT.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20752342

Link Title: N Koreans mark Kim Jong-il death
Message: North Korea has held a ceremony to mark a year since the death of Kim Jong-il, days after the country's successful rocket launch.  New leader Kim Jong-un and his wife paid their respects at the memorial hall in Pyongyang which houses the late leader's body.  Scientists who worked on last week's long-range rocket launch also attended, state television said.  Kim Jong-il died on 17 December 2011; his death was announced two days later.

US President Barack Obama has arrived in the Connecticut community devastated by the shootings at an elementary school http://bbc.in/12urUo9  LIVE: President Obama visits Newtown http://bbc.in/12urUo5  Twenty children and six women died in Friday's assault on Sandy Hook school in Newtown by a lone gunman who then took his own life.

Link Title: Breaking the glass ceiling of trekking
Message: This week BBC Travel looked into the trekking industry in Nepal. It may still be a male-dominated business, but three sisters are slowly chipping away at the gender gap. Since 1998, the aptly named 3 Sisters Adventure Trekking has been offering women-focused trips with female guides and porters, and last month this work earned them a 2012 Responsible Tourism Award.

Link Title: Four great Christmas markets outside Germany
Message: This week BBC looked into the tradition of Christmas markets in Germany, and how these authentic and charming festive fairs can now also be enjoyed in the United States, Japan, France and England:

All 20 children who died in a shooting at a primary school in Connecticut were aged between six and seven , according to an official list of the dead http://bbc.in/12tylYA  The state's chief medical examiner said the gunman used a rifle as his main weapon, and all the victims appeared to have been shot several times.  US President Obama will visit the small town of Newtown, Connecticut tonight.  - 'Emilie lit up the room' http://bbc.in/12tyjQu  -Will Newtown shootings change the US gun debate? http://bbc.in/12tylYG  - Teacher who lied to protect children http://bbc.in/12tyjQo  In other news from around the world:  - Venezuelans to go the polls http://bbc.in/12tyjQs  - Damascus refugee camp 'attacked' http://bbc.in/12tylYE  - Body of 'Kate nurse' arrives in India http://bbc.in/12tyjQq  - Boris: Don't sneer at Starbucks http://bbc.in/12tyjQw

The United States remains in shock after a mass shooting left 28 people in Connecticut dead, including 20 children http://bbc.in/12rp6Z0  More details are starting to emerge about the carnage, which also claimed the lives of seven adults and the suspected gunman.  - Profile of suspect http://bbc.in/12rp6YR  - As it happened http://bbc.in/12rp6YP  - What does it mean for Obama? http://bbc.in/12rp4jJ  - Our latest from Connecticut http://bbc.in/12rp4jF  - 'Worst thing ever seen' http://bbc.in/12rp4jH  In other news from around the world:   - Mandela undergoes operation http://bbc.in/12rp6YV  - Russian opposition leaders arrested http://bbc.in/12rp4jL  - Casablanca piano sold http://bbc.in/12rp6YT  - Japan set for election http://bbc.in/12rp6YL

The US flag over the White House is flying at half-mast tonight to honour the victims of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in the US state of Connecticut  http://bbc.in/U10fct  Twenty children and six adults have been killed in the shooting attack, according to police.  Continue to follow our live page for updates from Connecticut http://bbc.in/U10fsI
Follow this link for our live page reporting on the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown in the US state of Connecticut http://bbc.in/UMw9EI

As many as 27 people have been killed, including many children, in a shooting attack at a primary school in the US state of Connecticut, US media say http://bbc.in/U0p3kE  At least a dozen children are among the dead at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, the Associated Press reported.  Earlier, the gunman was reported to have been killed and at least three people were taken to hospital.  A news conference is imminent and the state Governor Dannell Malloy is on his way.   Updated information available on http://bbc.in/U0p3Bn

The festive lights, ice skating and holiday windows may make New York City magical in December, but it’s not all fun and games if you have shopping to do. If you’re pounding the pavement with a list that has you stumped, try these one-of-a-kind outlets for gifts with a New York twist so you can get on with making the most of your holiday. BBC Travel shows you how.

It appears the US space agency, NASA, has been having trouble identifying Mount Everest.     It posted a picture on its website, taken from outer space, claiming it was a photo of the world's tallest peak.     But a Nepalese expert spotted the error - the photo was actually of a mountain in India.    Photo: Everest straddles the border of China and Nepal    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20714990

Police are responding to reports of a shooting at a primary school in Newtown, Connecticut, local media have reported http://bbc.in/U05d9h  Schools across the district are on lock-down as a preventive measure, the school superintendent's office said.

The Israeli FM, Avigdor Lieberman is resigning, a day after being charged with fraud and breach of trust.   Mr Lieberman said he wanted to clear his name without delay. Although a more serious case of corruption against him has been closed, there've been allegations that companies under   Mr Lieberman's control received huge payments from foreign businessmen.

After weeks of protests and bloody clashes supporters and opponents of President Morsi in Egypt are holding their final rallies on the eve of the first vote on the controversial draft constitution.     In the past few days there have been violent clashes in what is seemingly the biggest crisis since President Hosni Mubarak was toppled nearly two years ago.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20726474

Who do you think should control the internet? Governments? United Nations officials? Or nobody at all?     It is a question that's been the subject of fierce debate between 193 countries for the last two weeks in Dubai.     China, Russia and some Gulf and African states want to see more UN power over the internet and a reduction in what they see as Western dominance.      But a bloc led by the US and including the UK and Canada has refused  - saying it could play into the hands of authoritarian regimes.    Let us know what you think and we'll use some of your comments on the Impact programme with Tim Wilcox at 1300GMT    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-20723878

The mother of Nigeria's Finance Minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has been released by her kidnappers, the Delta state governor tells the BBC.  Kamene Okonjo, an 82-year-old retired professor, was seized from her home in southern Nigeria on Sunday.  It is not clear if Mrs Okonjo was held for political or financial gain.

A man wielding a knife has gone on a rampage at a school in central China, stabbing 22 young children and 1 adult.     State media said the children were attacked as they arrived at a primary school in Henan province.     This is the latest in a string of attacks on children in China in recent years.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-20723910

UN Ambassador Susan Rice has withdrawn her name for consideration to succeed Hillary Clinton as US secretary of state, the White House says http://bbc.in/UHTg3m  Ms Rice has been at the centre of Republican criticism over the Obama administration response to a deadly attack on a US consulate in Libya.

Link Title: Bahrain tensions a trigger for Gulf turmoil
Message: The Crown Prince of Bahrain has made a renewed appeal for dialogue to end the country's political impasse. Two years on from the start of the Arab Uprising, the Gulf Kingdom still suffers violent unrest.   Jeremy Bowen reports from, Bahrain, a barometer for the Gulf, where increasing sectarian tensions are stoking concerns about wider Shia-Sunni rivalry in the region.

Link Title: Why Poverty? - Education Education - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: In China, education is seen as a way out of poverty.  But not all students can go to state subsidised universities.  Instead, they go to private colleges - some of which charge exorbitant fees to students, often from poor rural families, for a low standard of teaching.    This weekend, BBC World News is showing Education, Education, a film which highlights how young hopes in China are being exploited.     You can watch a clip  by clicking here or you can see the full programme on BBC World News at 0210 GMT or 1510 GMT on Sunday, December 16.    We’d like to know what you think about this film. The film is part of a global cross media event called Why Poverty? and you can find out more about that at  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-20316363

A Russian official has said for the first time that the Syrian government may be defeated by opposition forces.  Nato's Secretary General, Anders Fogh Rasmussen said in the last hour that Syria's government is 'close to collapse'.  He said it was "only a matter of time" before Bashar al Assad's regime fell, and that it should immediately put in place steps for a transition.   Meanwhile, inside Syria, one aid agency has made an urgent plea to be allowed to help the residents of Deir ez-Zor, in the east of the country.  Medecins sans Frontieres say the city is being hit by shells and bombs every day, making it almost impossible to evacuate the wounded. MSF now want a daily ceasefire so they can be allowed to safely evacuate those affected.

Fake photos flood the web, like this one of a shark swimming down a flooded street after Hurricane Irene. Are they just harmless fun, or do they change the way you remember events and influence your view of the world? BBC Future investigates. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121213-fake-pictures-make-real-memories

I'll be on air soon with Impact at 1300gmt.      Today - after Google's chairman says he's proud of the steps it has taken to cut is tax bill in the UK (it paid just £6 million in corporation tax on £2.5billion in UK sales last year) - do you think giant companies should pay more tax than they're legally obliged to?     Or are they simply doing what they're legally entitled to do?     We'd love to hear your thoughts. Thanks, Karin

Link Title: FMR THAI PM ABHISIT INTERVIEW ON BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Former Thai PM Abhisit Vejjajiva has been charged with murder over the death of a taxi driver shot by soldiers during political violence.  Mr Abhisit was prime minister when thousands of protesters took to the streets in 2010 demanding his government step down.  He gave orders allowing troops to use live ammunition on protesters, who had shut down parts of Bangkok.  He denies the charge, which supporters say is politically motivated.  You can watch the interview with Mr Abhisit when he  joined Mishal Husain on the Impact programme earlier this week.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20707765

What does this look like to you? http://bbc.in/TVaG1b  Parade route? Municipal garden? Beautification project?   Would you believe this row of flower pots is a spot along the border between the US and Canada?   Join us as we visit Derby Line, Vermont and Stanstead, Quebec to see how fears about terrorism, smuggling and illegal immigration have led to increased security - and the potential for huge fines for residents that dare cross the flower pots.

Link Title: UDINESE LONE FAN ARRIGO BROVEDANI INTERVIEW - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: WATCH:  He is the football fan who has been making headlines all over the world. Why?   Because he was the only supporter to show up and watch his beloved Udinese play an away game at Genoa.  Arrigo Brovedani is a wine merchant who found himself alone in the visitors' section.  But in true good spirit Sampdoria stewards gave him coffee and home fans invited him for a drink after the match.  He spoke to BBC's Karin Giannone about his experience.

A report from the world's biggest conservation group WWF says that Illegal wildlife trade is 'threatening national security'.  Report highlights a "new wave" of organised wildlife crime by armed groups operating across borders.  It says funds from trafficking are being used to finance civil conflicts.  The study comes as Malaysian officials captured about 20 tonnes of ivory in one of the biggest seizures ever made.
VIDEO:  Meet Chen Siyuan, an ambidextrous translator from Handan in China's northern Hebei province, who has a remarkable ability to write with both hands, at the SAME time.

Pope Benedict XVI has sent his first much-anticipated Twitter message using his personal account.  The Pope was shown pressing a button on an iPad tablet at the Vatican.  The message read: "Dear friends, I am pleased to get in touch with you through Twitter. Thank you for your generous response. I bless all of you from my heart."

Students at a school in the US state of Vermont have been finding out what life is like without the technological advantages of a modern life.     They were asked to live and interact without mobile phones and with limited internet for a few months.     Interestingly %75 of them said afterwards they would use the internet a little or a lot less upon their return home.    Would you be able to live without internet and mobile phones? Do you think children are introduced to such technologies at a too early age?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20649022

Egypt's referendum on a controversial draft constitution has begun in embassies abroad, days before the vote is due to take place at home.  But with many judges refusing to oversee the process, it is unclear whether the vote will take place on one day or continue the next week.  The opposition has called for the entire referendum to be scrapped.

President Barack Obama has said the US now formally recognises Syria's main opposition coalition as "the legitimate representative" of its Syrian people.  Mr Obama told ABC News that the National Coalition was now inclusive, reflective and representative enough for Washington to take this "big step".  Mr Obama warned that the US would not support extremist elements within the opposition coalition.  The UK, France, Turkey and Gulf states have already given their recognition.  Does international recognition of the opposition mean a likely fall of the Assad government?

The government of North Korea has defied international warnings and fired a long-range rocket.     The country's leaders, in Pyongyang insist it was part of a peaceful mission to put a satellite into orbit.     The US and its allies say it's a disguised ballistic missile test that violates UN resolutions.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20690338
