Musician Ravi Shankar has died at the age of 92. The sitar maestro had a strong influence on many bands including The Beatles. George Harrison once called Shankar "the godfather of world music". Did you ever see him play? Have you met him? What are your memories of him?

A gunman has opened fire at a shopping mall near the city of Portland in the US state of Oregon, killing two people and himself http://bbc.in/TTkf0y  One other person was seriously injured at the Clackamas Shopping Center and taken to hospital, Lt James Rhodes of Clackamas County Police said. Officials say the gunman killed himself after the shooting spree. Police who arrived at the scene did not fire.

North Korea has launched a long-range rocket, according to reports in South Korea and Japan http://bbc.in/UznLZb  North Korea says it plans to put a satellite into space but the US believes it is actually testing missile technology banned under UN resolutions.

What could teenagers accomplish if they didn't spend so much of their time on Facebook and Twitter? http://bbc.in/TSGRy2  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll visit a school in the US state of Vermont that is changing friendships from digital to actual. Check you local listing to find BBC World News in your area for this and other stories from around the world, including:  - HSBC's 'stunning failures over oversight' http://bbc.in/TSGOT2 - Morsi supporters and opponents rally http://bbc.in/TSGRhM -  Jeremy Bowen in Syria http://bbc.in/TSGRy5 - Mandela's health http://bbc.in/TSGOT4 - Russian volcano erupts http://bbc.in/TSGOT8  Join the conversation by following us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/TSGRhK

A pig processing plant in northern Chile that provoked months of protests by local people over the stench is to close indefinitely, its owner says http://bbc.in/TSwOZO  In May, authorities ordered the plant closed and 500,000 pigs removed, as residents blocked access to the site http://bbc.in/TSwMRQ  Operations resumed recently, provoking renewed demonstrations.

What does the X-37B do? http://bbc.in/TSoJ7C  A notoriously mysterious military spaceplane operated by the US Air Force is expected to launch for the third time from Florida on Tuesday.  The reusable, unmanned craft is designed to operate in Earth orbit for extended periods; its prior missions in 2010 and 2011 lasted 224 and 469 days. The US government has been resolutely quiet about its precise purpose, and would not confirm a launch time.

Huge crowds have gathered in Cairo for rival rallies ahead of Saturday's referendum. Hundreds of troops are guarding the presidential palace but the BBC's George Alagiah says opposition protesters have managed to get into the presidential compound.   Pro-Morsi demonstrators have also been gathering in the city. Muslim brotherhood spokesman Mahmoud Ghozlan told state-owned al-Ahram newspaper that there was no plan to head for the presidential palace.   There are fears there could be more violence if rival groups of protesters come face to face

Link Title: BBC News - It will take a 'baby elephant' to knock over this bike
Message: WATCH: The motorbike that balances itself. Using technology found on the International Space Station and the Hubble Space Telescope, its designers say it would take a baby elephant to push it over. Would you give it a try?

On the Hub at 1600GMT, Asian countries have taken the top places in global school rankings for maths, science and reading. Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea were top in this global education league. Why do you think Asian children are coming out top of the class?

TAKE A LOOK at the special section on our website about the Arab Uprisings, two years on from protests beginning in Tunisia and then spreading to Egypt and elsewhere. There's analysis from our correspondents in the region and special reports on life in places like Damascus.

South Africa's first black President Nelson Mandela is being treated for a lung infection, the president's office has said, in its first announcement since Mr Mandela was taken to hospital on Saturday. Presidential spokesman Mac Maharaj said he is responding well to treatment.

Asia will wield more global power than the US and Europe combined by 2030, a forecast from the US intelligence community has found.  Within two decades China will overtake the US as the world's largest economy, the report adds.  It also warns of slower growth and falling living standards in advanced nations with ageing populations.

"They're laughing and mocking just like they did Noah. But the flood still came, and Jesus is still coming." http://bbc.in/TQ8AiU  Meet the pastor in the US state of Maryland spending millions of dollars to rebuild Noah's Ark, to scale, on the edge of an interstate highway.  Will Richard Greene live to see the finished project?

It has been nearly two years since the Arab Spring began http://bbc.in/TQ2W0h  How has the region changed?   Tonight on BBC World News America we'll begin our week-long look at the impact of the uprisings and other news from around the world, including:  - Australian presenters 'gutted and heartbroken' http://bbc.in/TQ2UFR - Strauss-Kahn settlement with maid http://bbc.in/TQ2W0f -  Mandela 'doing well' http://bbc.in/TQ2W0j - A look at Zero Dark Thirty http://bbc.in/TQ2UFN  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/TQ2W0d for the latest news and features from our staff and correspondents working in North America.

Former International Monetary Fund chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn has signed a settlement with a hotel maid who accused him of sexual assault http://bbc.in/UtiOBj  The incident was widely seen as having ruined Mr Strauss-Kahn's chance of becoming the Socialist presidential candidate in his native France.

Link Title: ONE POUND FISH MAN ON BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: He is the unlikely star singing about cheap fresh fish in an East London market.  The video of him performing has been seen by millions on the internet and believe it or not he has now bagged himself a record deal too.  Meet Shahid Nazir the One Pound Fish Man

Link Title: Interview: The Nobel prizes in the 21st century
Message: The 2012 Nobel Prize winners pick up their awards today, so BBC Future caught up with the head of the Nobel Foundation to discuss the future of the prizes – including the infamous three-person rule, the lack of female winners, and why it might be relying on hedge funds to restore its prize money. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121210-the-nobel-prizes-in-the-21st-cent

Link Title: Chavez heads to Cuba for surgery
Message: The Venezuelan president, Hugo Chavez, has arrived in Cuba for his fourth cancer operation. Earlier, he spoke openly for the first time about handing over to a possible successor, the vice-president Nicolas Maduro.

Nigeria's police have launched a manhunt for the kidnappers of Finance Minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala's mother, a spokesman has said.  Kamene Okonjo, a professor, was seized from her home in Delta State on Sunday.  A finance ministry spokesman said Mrs Okonjo-Iweala had been threatened recently but did not know whether this was linked to the kidnapping.  Nigeria is one of the worst countries in the world for kidnapping, where it is a lucrative criminal enterprise.

Italian stocks have fallen sharply, reacting to news that Prime Minister Mario Monti plans to resign and former premier Silvio Berlusconi is to run for office again.  The main Italian stock index fell 3.1%.  Other indexes throughout Europe were also lower, with banks the worst hit among shares.  Mr Monti became the leader of a technocrat government in 2011 after investors became worried about Italy's economic health.

Link Title: FMR THAI PM ABHISIT INTERVIEW ON BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW:  Former Thai PM Abhisit Vejjajiva and his deputy are the first officials to face charges over the shooting death of a taxi driver in 2010 during rival demonstrations between the red shirts and the yellow shirts.  Mr. Abhisit joined Mishal Husain for an exclusive interview. He began by explaining what he was likely to tell the hearing which begins on Thursday.

VIDEO: It's been nearly two years since the Arab Uprising began in  Tunisia and swept across countries into the Middle East.   The BBC's Lyse Doucet, has been back to Tunisia to see how life has changed. She's gained rare access to one of the grand palaces of the deposed President, Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.

Lionel Messi is undoubtedly a proven goal scoring machine and now he has also set a new record for most goals scored in a calendar year.   Messi scored an incredible 86 goals beating Gerd Mueller's tally of 85 - set in 1972.  The argument of whether he can be considered as the best player of all time continues. Do you think that Messi is better than either Maradona or Pele?

Hello, it's Mishal. We'll be using the Twitter hashtag #bbcimpact while we are on air today (1300-1430 GMT) and using it to discuss today's talking point - do you have sympathy for the Australian DJs who made the hoax call to the Duchess of Cambridge's hospital?   Join the debate ahead of time - or live

The former South African President, Nelson Mandela, has spent a second night in hospital in Pretoria.     Mr Mandela, who's 94, has been having tests for an unspecified medical condition, said to be age-related. On Sunday he was visited by President Jacob Zuma who said he was looking well after a restful night.    He is revered at home and around the world for leading the struggle against white-minority rule before becoming South Africa's first black president in 1994    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20662446
This week BBC Travel looked into Africa’s business hotel boom, where high-end accommodations are sprouting up buoyed by travellers flocking to the continent’s rich stores of natural resources.

South Africa's former president Nelson Mandela spends the night in hospital after being admitted to undergo tests, officials say.  The 94-year-old was admitted to hospital on Saturday to undergo tests.  South Africans have been waiting for word on Mr Mandela's condition amid messages of hope for a speedy recovery
Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi has annulled a decree that gave him expanded powers but a constitutional referendum will go ahead, officials say.

A weekend Facebook update of news from around the world:  - Italian PM Monti plans to resign http://bbc.in/UlDjji - Brazil says goodbye to Niemeyer http://bbc.in/UlDjQ9 - UN climate talks extend Kyoto Protocol http://bbc.in/UlDjQ5 - Mandela in hospital 'for tests' http://bbc.in/UlDjjg - A funny look at the world of news - in 140 characters or less http://bbc.in/UlDjQd

"Government is too inefficient to make the costs come down to make another Moon landing economic. It will be an entrepreneurial effort” http://bbc.in/STsesb  On the 40th anniversary of Apollo 17, Nasa's last manned mission to the Moon, one of the last men to set foot on the Moon has said that private enterprise will be the driving force for a return to the lunar surface.  Harrison Schmitt told the BBC that governments are "too inefficient" to send humans back to the Moon.  Do you agree with Schmitt?

Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, told the BBC's Katty Kay that the US had a duty "to try to remove uncertainty and doubt as quickly as possible" when it comes to the Fiscal Cliff debate http://bbc.in/STj2UE  Do you agree with Ms Lagarde?  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at Katty's interview with Lagarde and other news from around the world, including:  - Hoax call nurse found dead http://bbc.in/STj278 - Protesters clash with army in Cairo http://bbc.in/STj52y -  Jeremy Bowen in Damascus http://bbc.in/STj2UG - Mapping the Blitz http://bbc.in/STj2UA  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/STj274 for the latest news and features from our staff and correspondents working in North America

The US Supreme Court has announced it is to hear arguments on whether gay marriage is legal under the US Constitution http://bbc.in/STddXh  The court will hear challenges to the Defense of Marriage Act (Doma), which defines marriage as between a man and a woman, and California's Proposition 8.

Link Title: Part V: Dispensing Comfort - Providing Morphine for Pain Relief in...
Message: The final part of the cancer in the developing world series from our colleagues at PRI's The World -  Modern cancer care involves more than the latest surgical techniques and chemotherapy drugs; it also offers freedom from pain. Yet basic palliative care, in the form of morphine, is almost nonexistent for many patients in developing countries. What is being done to bring them pain relief?

A five-year old British girl has had pioneering surgery to repair a large gap in her spine using bone taken from her legs.    Missing bones in her spine meant her upper body weight was unsupported and her inner organs were being crushed.    The lifesaving surgery came at the cost of her lower legs, which she had always been unable to move.    It's only the second time this kind of an operation has been performed.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-20426413

Link Title: Korean food goes high-end in Seoul
Message: This week BBC Travel visited Seoul, where a group of imaginative young chefs is taking the city’s high-end Korean food scene in unexpected directions, pairing 21st-century cooking techniques with traditional flavours.

VIDEO:  An interactive Blitz map showing every bomb dropped on London during World War II has been created   More than 20,000 people were killed and 1.4m made homeless: "It seems astonishing that London survived," said the map's creator

Link Title: The man who lives inside a sewer
Message: A Colombian man has been living inside a sewer in the city of Medellin, in Colombia, for over 20 years. He transformed an abandoned sewer into a home, complete with bed, TV and stove.   Although Miguel Restrepo is legally homeless and could be forced out of the sewer by local authorities at any minute, he describes the cramped space he shares with his wife and dog as a great place to live.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20643956

Ghanaians are choosing a new president and parliament. It's expected to be a tight race between the two main Presidential candidates in a campaign dominated by how to spend the country's new found oil wealth.  Long queues have been reported at polling stations across Ghana. In some places, voting was delayed by a few hours, but otherwise it appeared to be progressing smoothly and peacefully.

Egyptian opposition leaders have rejected calls by President Mohammed Morsi to enter a national dialogue.  Mr Morsi, under fire for issuing a decree that gives him sweeping new powers, had invited all major political factions to a meeting on Saturday.  But the opposition said the president had offered little in terms of concessions, criticising his refusal to delay a constitutional referendum.

Would you return over $500k if you found it on a bus?  That is exactly what an Austrian bus driver did after he found the money at the back of his vehicle.  The sum represented the entire life savings of an elderly lady.  Earlier that day she had withdrawn the money from her bank before accidentally leaving it on the bus.  You'll be pleased to hear that the police eventually managed to track down the 77-year-old who got her money back.

Link Title: Hamas chief set for Gaza visit
Message: The exiled leader of the Palestinian group Hamas, Khaled Meshaal, has arrived in the Gaza Strip.   The visit marks the 25th anniversary of the founding of Hamas, which controls Gaza.   This is the first time Mr Meshaal has set foot on Palestinian land for forty-five years. He went into exile in after the 1967 Six Day War.  Hamas spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri said in a statement that Mr Meshaal's visit was "a fruit of the victory of the resistance over the occupation".

A one-metre-high tsunami has hit Japan's northeast coast. The wave was recorded in Ishinomaki, a city in Miyagi prefecture.    The tsunami was triggered by a powerful earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.3.     The quake was felt as far away as Tokyo. There have been no reports of serious damage or casualties.       http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20638696

Link Title: Part IV: The Infectious Connection - Scientists Study Viruses and...
Message: Our colleagues at PRI's The World continue their look at cancer in the developing world -  Cancer can be triggered by infectious diseases, especially in impoverished parts of the world. Scientists in the U.S. and Africa are working to unravel how viruses and bacteria cause malignancies. By breaking that cycle, they hope to prevent tumors from forming in the first place.

VIDEO:  Find out how Mali's musicians are fighting back for their cultural freedom.   Mali was always well known for its vibrant culture and music.   Well, that's changed ever since Islamist radicals took over northern Mali earlier this year. They have imposed Sharia law in major towns with strict new codes governing social life including banning music.   Dozens of musicians have had to flee south where singing hasn't been made a crime. The BBC's Thomas Fessy reports from the capital Bamako.

Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer, who designed some of the 20th Century's most famous modernist buildings, has died just before his 105th birthday.  He rose to international fame as the architect of the main government buildings in the futuristic Brazilian capital, Brasilia, inaugurated in 1960.  He also worked with Swiss-born modernist architect Le Corbusier on the UN building in New York. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20621265

Nobel laureates and Chinese activists have called for the release of jailed Chinese Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo in two separate letters to Xi Jinping.  The 134 Nobel laureates asked the new Communist Party head to release Liu, who has been jailed since 2009.  A group of Chinese activists and writers also signed a letter urging Liu's release from inciting subversion.

When was the last time you took a day off work?  Well spare a thought for Baljit Singh Rana, a police sub-inspector in Delhi, who hasn't taken a day off from work for 14 years.   According to records he has been at the office every single day not even taking leave for the weddings of his three children. But his family say he is a caring father and husband who has never ignored his family responsibilities.

The Egyptian army deploys tanks outside the presidential palace in Cairo after clashes between supporters and opponents of President Morsi left 5 dead.  The BBC's Jon Leyne in Cairo says the violence, which opposition leaders accused Mr Morsi's Islamist Muslim Brotherhood movement of organising, was ominously reminiscent of the tactics used by former President Hosni Mubarak during the revolution.  Are you taking part in the protest against President Morsi, or do you support him? Send us your thoughts

Hope amid the heartbreak in the Philippines as rescuers search for hundreds still missing after Typhoon Bopha.    More than 300 people have died and hundreds more are missing in the wake of Typhoon Bopha, which cut a swathe of devastation across the southern Philippines.    People were killed in eight provinces but eastern Mindanao was worst-hit.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20621441

Fewer than one in three Latinos backed Mitt Romney in the recent US presidential election http://bbc.in/QHX20J  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at what Hispanic Republicans think of the party and other news from around world, including:  - Clashes in Cairo amid constitution row http://bbc.in/QHX1d2 - Typhoon death toll rises in Philippines http://bbc.in/QHX1d8 - What happens next in Afghanistan http://bbc.in/QHX20F - Remembering Dave Brubeck http://bbc.in/QHX20H  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/QHX1d0 on Twitter for the latest news and features from our producers and correspondents working in North America.
Meet Monty - a giant schnauzer in New Zealand who is learning to drive http://bbc.in/SNB1vJ  The canine driving school aims to show the public how intelligent rescue dogs can be... Are you convinced?

"Gamification" - taking the rules of video games and applying them to dull office work or how we exercise is billed as the next big thing. But is there really anything in it? BBC Future finds out. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121204-can-gaming-transform-your-life

Pioneering jazz pianist and composer Dave Brubeck has died, aged 91 http://bbc.in/QHCPbp  The musician, whose recordings included Take Five and Blue Rondo a la Turk, died on Wednesday morning in hospital in Connecticut.  Brubeck, who played with the likes of Duke Ellington and Ella Fitzgerald would have turned 92 on Thursday.

Rival protesters have clashed outside the presidential palace in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, as unrest grows over a controversial draft constitution.  Stones were thrown and supporters of President Mohamed Morsi dismantled tents set up by anti-Morsi protesters.  Vice President Mahmoud Mekki has said a referendum on the draft will go ahead on 15 December despite the unrest.  But he indicated that changes could be made after the vote, saying the "door for dialogue" remained open.  He urged critics of the draft document to put their concerns in writing for future discussion.

A bomb blast and a shoot-out between Islamists and troops from the semi-autonomous Puntland region have left 31 people dead or wounded, officials say.    Fighters from the al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabab group attacked a military base and planted a roadside bomb, the officials said.    Al-Shabab fighters have reportedly moved to Puntland in recent months.    http://bbc.in/QHlkYx

NASA has announced it's to send a new robot vehicle to Mars in 2020.     It will be based on the Curiosity Rover, which landed on the Red Planet in August.     Eventually it's hoped that the robots will pave the way for a manned mission to Mars.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20603689

The global survey of corruption that has found that Greece is perceived as having the most corrupt public sector in the EU.   Other struggling Eurozone economies including Portugal, Ireland and Italy have also slipped down the Transparency International index .

One of our most shared stories online today is the research on falling sperm count among French men.     It's still said to be within normal range, but are you concerned about how our fertility may be changing?     We discuss on Impact. Mishal       http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-20593467

The Philippines is taking a battering as a typhoon sweeps across the country. More than 230 people have been killed and thousands have been left homeless.    Typhonn Bopha is the strongest to hit the Philippines this year. The Compostela Valley province is one of the worst affected areas. Many people have been evacuated ahead of the storm, which is now over the western island of Palawan.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20604423

Chinese telecoms giant Huawei has hit back at US politicians who labelled it a security threat http://bbc.in/QFEw8Z  A senior executive told the BBC that Huawei should not be treated unfairly just because it was Chinese. In October the United States House Intelligence Committee warned US companies against dealing with Huawei and another Chinese telecoms firm, ZTE.  Tell us what you think in the comments section below.

Not too long ago ...   In a galaxy not very far away ...   Star Wars fans took to the web to crowd-source the construction of a full scale Millennium Falcon http://bbc.in/SKgRCG  Meet some of the people bringing model makers, fans, designers and engineers from around the world together to recreate the "fastest hunk of junk in the galaxy" in the US state of Tennessee.  Would you plan a visit to the completed model? http://bbc.in/SKgRCG

Nato has approved the deployment of Patriot anti-missile batteries along Turkey's border with Syria http://bbc.in/SK8AP4  The long-expected move emerged from a meeting of Nato foreign ministers in Brussels, and amid growing fears that Syria could use chemical weapons.
IN PICTURES: Typhoon Bopha has killed dozens in the Philippines and caused widespread damage to the southern island of Mindanao.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20599491

Link Title: Nato warns Syria on chemical arms
Message: BREAKING: Nato has approved the deployment of Patriot anti-missile batteries along Turkey's border with Syria.
What was earth like 2.7 billion years ago? Fossils from ancient raindrops could provide some answers
Police reportedly fire teargas during clashes with protesters as thousands gather near the presidential palace in the Egyptian capital Cairo   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20600920

How does happiness change with age? Is it safe to assume that as children we are carefree, then go through miserable teenage years, then regain happiness when we settle, only to get grumpy again with old age?! A neuroscientist at University College, London believes this is wrong. Find out why ...     Http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20591893

Link Title: Nato warns Syria on chemical arms
Message: After months of tension on the border between Turkey and Syria, Patriot missiles could be deployed to counter any threat to Turkey. And there's a warning to Syria on chemical weapons.

Link Title: Second day in hospital for Kate
Message: The Duchess of Cambridge is spending a second day in hospital as she receives treatment for severe morning sickness

Link Title: Presenter Yalda Hakim to join BBC World News
Message: One of Australia's brightest young journalists, Yalda Hakim, is joining the BBC World News team.
BBC World News has a new presenter! Yalda Hakim is joining the team as a presenter and correspondent for a new current affairs programme.

Link Title: Psy explains his name to the BBC
Message: VIDEO:  The global hit Gangnam Style, by the Korean pop star Psy, is officially the world's most watched video on YouTube.   It's closing in on 900 million views.  The 34 year pop legend - whose real name is Park Jae-Sang has been passing through Singapore on yet another whirlwind tour.   And while he was there he spoke to BBC's Rico Hizon and explained what was the inspiration for the hit and why he chose to call himself Psy.

Link Title: UN to pull out staff from Syria
Message: The United Nations says it is pulling "all non-essential international staff" out of Syria as the situation around the capital Damascus deteriorates.  As many as 25 out of 100 international staff could leave this week, the UN news agency Irin reports.  All field trips outside the capital are being halted temporarily as staff were at "increased risk" from indiscriminate shooting and clashes by both sides.  Eight UN staff have been killed since the conflict started, Irin reports.

Link Title: Iran's HIV/Aids sufferers struggle for survival
Message: As Iran's economy has faltered and the cost of living has skyrocketed, Iranians living with HIV/Aids are struggling more than before for survival, reports Roxana Saberi.

The Duchess of Cambridge is expecting a baby, St James's Palace has announced.  Members of the royal family and the duchess's family, the Middletons, are said to be delighted.   A spokesman said the Duchess has been admitted to King Edward VII Hospital in central London with very acute morning sickness and is expected to stay for several days.   Catherine and William were married at Westminster Abbey in April 2011.

Link Title: D-Day looms for South Africa's Jacob Zuma
Message: South Africa's governing African National Congress (ANC) is preparing for a leadership contest which could decide whether it will reinforce the cliche of Africa's well-documented post-colonial failures or break away from a dark past into a bright future for Africa's largest economy.

Hi Ros here prepping for the 1500 bulletin (after Mishal on Impact).     We'll run a story on the 20 birthday of the text message (it was 'Merry Christmas' if you're wondering).     What interesting is that it was far from certain they were going to be a hit. Actually in places like America, they're not as popular as say Africa and Europe. So why is that sometimes a text is so much better than a call? And do you still text as much as ever.     If you could let me know and I'll work some of your comments into the story on air. You can get me here or across on twitter @BBCRosAtkins. Thanks!

Link Title: Putin to discuss Syria in Turkey
Message: Russian President Vladimir Putin is to meet Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan to discuss the Syrian conflict, which has strained bilateral relations.  Moscow is a key ally of Syria, while Ankara is backing the rebels trying to oust Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.  In October, Turkey intercepted a Syria-bound plane which it said had Russian-made defence equipment - a claim rejected by both Moscow and Damascus.  The talks in Istanbul are also expected to focus on energy issues.

US researchers say they have developed a new type of lighting that could replace fluorescent bulbs.    The new source is made from layers of plastic and is said to be more efficient while producing a better quality of flicker-free light.    The scientists behind it say they believe the first units will be produced in 2013.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20553143    Still courtesy of Wake Forest University

Will you be joining the Pope on Twitter?     Benedict XVI has just become the latest leader to reach out this way, and his followers are growing by the minute.     Is this a Vatican PR exercise or a new way to guide the faithful? Mishal

Israeli settlement plans in a strategically sensitive area of occupied land near East Jerusalem would deal "an almost fatal blow" to peace hopes, UN head Ban Ki-moon has warned.    In further development the UK has also warned Israel of a "strong reaction" if it carries out plans to expand settlement building in the occupied Palestinian territories.    What do you think of the Israeli settlements and Ban Ki-moon's comments?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20576201

The Japanese government has ordered emergency inspections of road tunnels across the country following a deadly roof collapse west of Tokyo.  Nine people were confirmed dead after concrete panels collapsed and started a fire in the Sasago tunnel, 80km from the capital on Sunday.  An inquiry into the Sasago collapse has also been launched.  Officials from the highway operator suggested that metal rods securing the concrete panels may have loosened.

Link Title: Abbas cheered on return from UN
Message: Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas gets a hero's welcome in the West Bank, after his successful move to upgrade the Palestinians' status at the UN.
Pictures of the rescue effort following the collapse of the Sasago tunnel in Japan, which has trapped cars and left several people missing.

Link Title: Managing e-mail while on the road
Message: This week BBC Travel looked into how to best manage email while on the road, testing several new apps and websites that screen your e-mail messages for you.

Link Title: Mexico's Pena Nieto set for power
Message: Mexico's incoming president, Enrique Pena Nieto, names a 20-member cabinet hours before his inauguration.
Supporters of Egypt's President Morsi are to hold a mass rally to back his new powers and the drafting of a constitution opponents say is too Islamist.
Tens of thousands of opposition supporters in Kuwait City call for a boycott of Saturday's election in  a row over changes to voting rules.

Make sure you tune into BBC World News at 1900 GMT.    Zeinab Badawi will be interviewing Wikileaks founder Julian Assange directly from his refuge at the Ecuadorian embassy.    What would you ask him?

Link Title: Calls for release of Qatari poet
Message: Human rights groups have urged Qatar to free a poet detained last year for what they say was peaceful criticism.  Mohammed al-Ajami is reported to be facing a secret trial on charges of "inciting to overthrow the ruling system" and "insulting the emir".  The case against him is said to be based on a poem he wrote in 2010 which criticises Sheikh Hamad Al Thani.  But activists believe the authorities were angered by a 2011 poem he wrote about authoritarian rule in the region.
This week BBC Travel visited Jordan, following in the footsteps of explorer Louis Burckhardt to unveil the secrets of Petra.

Brazil's economy slowed unexpectedly in the third quarter, new data suggests.  Latin America's biggest country clocked just 0.6% growth in the three months to September versus the previous quarter, half the rate expected by analysts.  Growth for 2012 now looks set to be closer to 1%, compared with 2.7% last year and 7.5% in 2010

VIDEO:  For the second day in a row New Yorkers have been demonstrating acts of goodwill.  Yesterday we reported about a NY police officer who bought a pair of $100 boots for a homeless man.  Today we can report about a NY businessman acting as a 'Secret Santa'. He's been giving away $100 bills to victims of superstorm Sandy in New York and New Jersey.

Link Title: What's wrong with Indian cricket's spin bowlers?
Message: Suresh Menon, Editor of Wisden India Cricketers' Almanack, tries to find out what has happened to India's spinners.

Hi, Ros here getting ready for World Have Your Say at the top of the hour.   We'll be getting your reaction to the change in Palestine's status at the UN.   In the second half we'll turn to Egypt and the increasing tension around the new constitution.   There are all sorts of ways you can reach us: here, across on the WHYS facebook page, on twitter @bbc_whys or @bbcrosatkins, pls text, phone and google+. So no excuses... Speak to you in a bit.

Link Title: LEILA SHAHID INTV - PALESTINE UN STATUS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Leila Shahid is a Palestinian Authority representative in Brussels and she joined the GMT programme to discuss Palestine's new status at the United Nations.

Link Title: DORE GOLD INTV - PALESTINE UN STATUS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Former Israeli Ambassador to the UN joined GMT programme to discuss Palestinian Authority being granted observer status at the United Nations.

An American company has developed a technique that they say can make bread stay mould-free for 60 days.    The bread is zapped in a sophisticated microwave array which kills the spores that cause the problem.    They claim it could significantly reduce the amount of wasted bread.    The technique can also be used with a wide range of foods including fresh turkey and many fruits and vegetables.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20540758

Link Title: Former Indian PM IK Gujral dies
Message: Former Indian prime minister Inder Kumar Gujral has died after a long illness in a hospital near the capital, Delhi, aged 92.   He became India's 12th prime minister, heading a United Front coalition government in 1997.  During his 11-month tenure, he worked at improving India's frosty relationship with archrival Pakistan.  Mr Gujral was also known for his strategic vision of India's role in its neighbourhood.

The UN General Assembly has voted overwhelmingly to recognise Palestine as a non-member observer state - a move strongly opposed by Israel and the US.  Israel says the UN's vote to recognise Palestine as a non-member observer state, has pushed the peace process "backwards".  The UN vote assembly voted 138 to 9 in favour, with 41 nations abstaining.  The major breakthrough for Palestinians is they can now take part in U-N debates. But it also gives Palestine the potential to join bodies like the International Criminal Court and accuse Israel of war crimes.

The Islamist-dominated assembly writing a new Egyptian constitution has convened to vote on the final draft.  In one of its first steps, the constituent assembly voted to keep sharia, or Islamic law, as the main source of legislation.  It came after the constitutional court said it would rule on Sunday whether to dissolve the assembly.  Egypt's judiciary is in a stand-off with President Mohammed Morsi after he granted himself sweeping new powers.

Rwandan support for rebels in neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo may be more widespread than previously believed, the BBC has found.    Two ex-rebel fighters told the BBC they were offered money from Rwanda to set up a new front further south.    Rwanda has previously backed armed groups in eastern DR Congo. The M23, who like Rwanda's leaders are mostly ethnic Tutsis, has also denied it is funded by Rwanda.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20542846

The internet and mobile phone systems have been cut off in Syria, a monitoring firm has said.  The Syrian government has previously cut off access during major operations.  Renesys, a US-based firm which tracks internet connectivity worldwide, said on its blog: "In the global routing table, all 84 of Syria's IP address blocks have become unreachable."  According to its systems, access was disconnected at 12:26pm local time (10:26 GMT).

A French court has cleared Continental Airlines of responsibility for the Air France Concorde crash that killed 113 people 12 years ago.   The ruling reverses a court decision against Continental two years ago. Maintenance mistakes by its mechanics did not make it legally responsible.

After a decade of legal wrangling and spending $4.5bn, this year Shell Oil was given permission to begin exploratory drilling off the coast of Alaska.     But many in the local Inuit community are concerned it could have a devastating impact on one of their main sources of food - the bowhead whale.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20310752

A UN tribunal has cleared Kosovo's former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj of war crimes from the 1998-99 conflict, after a retrial in The Hague.  Mr Haradinaj, a rebel commander during the war, was accused of overseeing a campaign of torture and murder against Serbs and suspected collaborators.  But four years after the last acquittal the UN court ruled again that the prosecution had not proved the case.  Serbian officials reacted angrily, denouncing the UN tribunal.

International police forces uncover a Romanian syndicate allegedly behind what officials say is Australia's biggest ever credit card fraud.  Seven people in Romania were charged with data theft from 30,000 Australian credit cards, police in Australia say.   The computer systems of 100 small businesses in Australia were hacked, according to federal police.   They say that data was used to make fraudulent transactions around the world worth more than $30m (£18.8m).

"We were raised to be quiet and let the man talk first. I don't do that anymore. And they don't like it." http://bbc.in/Qrdgex  In the Dominican Republic domestic violence rates are high, women are less educated and more likely to be out of work. Those who do have jobs earn much less than men.   Women in the Dominican diaspora in the US, though, enjoy much better economic conditions. There has been a major shift in attitudes too, with the traditional machismo culture also being challenged by women who often moved to the US ahead of their families.  Meet two of the women that are changing their culture http://bbc.in/Qrdgex

Is there life on the icy moons of our Solar System? http://bbc.in/QqVBnh  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the Antarctic lake that might be able to tell us more about our galaxy and other news from around the world, including:  - Syria's refugees http://bbc.in/QqVBDz - Egypt's courts launch anti-Mursi strike action http://bbc.in/QqVBnd - BP banned by EPA http://bbc.in/QqVBDv  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/QqVBn9 on Twitter for the latest news and features from our producers and correspondents working in North America.

"The UK is keen on striking the right diplomatic balance” - Manuel Hassassian, Palestinian ambassador to the UK http://bbc.in/QqNDdC  Foreign Secretary William Hague has said UK may abstain in a key vote on upgraded diplomatic status at the UN for Palestinians. Hague said the UK would not oppose moves to recognise the Palestinians as a "non-member observer state". But he would need assurances that the Palestinians would seek negotiations with Israel "without pre-conditions".  Palestinian diplomats said they had rejected the "unrealistic" demands http://bbc.in/QqNDdC

Link Title: X-37B: Secrets of the US military spaceplane
Message: As the US Air Force prepares for the third launch of its mysterious X-37B spaceplane, BBC Future looks at what is known about this classified project. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121123-secrets-of-us-military-spaceplane

On the Hub at 1600GMT, we'll be talking to Mohiuddin Khan Alamgir, Bangladesh's home minister, about factory working conditions. There has been growing anger among factory workers after a fire killed more than 100 people there. We'll also be talking to Kalpona Akter, director of the Bangladesh Centre for Worker Solidarity and has been interviewing survivors of the fire. What do you want to ask them?

The largest trial of crimes committed during the so-called 'Dirty War' between 1976 and 1983 begins today in Argentina. 68 former officials face 800 charges of kidnap, torture and murder.   Tens of thousands of Argentines were kidnapped and killed by the military junta. Many victims were killed during "death flights", their bodies dropped into the Atlantic Ocean. For the first time in Argentina, the pilots of those "death flights" are on trial.   The trial is expected to hear from around 900 witnesses and last up to 2 years.

The "Kate-effect" is taking hold in France. The craze for British style weddings has been increasing since the Royal Wedding last year. Demand is growing for multi tiered wedding cakes rather than the traditional croquembouche and also for bridesmaids -- who are increasingly finding a place in French ceremonies.

Link Title: Tobacco firms told to admit lying
Message: Hi, Mishal here with Impact at 1300GMT. As tobacco companies face a US ruling about their past activity, Impact has the global picture on smoking. Should Asian countries be trying harder to warn people about the dangers?

At least 34 people have been killed and many injured in two car bomb attacks in the Jaramana district of Damascus. The Syrian state media agency said terrorists were responsible for the attacks. No group has claimed responsibility.

Hobbit mania erupted in New Zealand's capital for the world premiere of Peter Jackson's new trilogy.  The first of the three movies - prequels to the Lord of the Rings trilogy - was shown at Wellington's Embassy Theatre on Wednesday evening.  Stars flew in for the event, which saw Wellington rebranded as "the Middle of Middle Earth".  Tens of thousands of fans - some in costume - gathered around the theatre for the screening.

Are you in Egypt?  Are you taking part in the protests? http://bbc.in/SrzRpv  Tens of thousands of people have held protests in Cairo against Egyptian President Mohammed Mursi, who last week granted himself sweeping new powers http://bbc.in/SrzRpt  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the protests and other news from around the world, including:  - Was Arafat poisoned? http://bbc.in/SrzRpx - Fraud at Kabul Bank http://bbc.in/SrzSK4 - US-Mexico relations - Seventy years of Jimi Hendrix   Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area  Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter http://bbc.in/SrzSK2 for the latest news and features from our staff and correspondents working in North America.

The destruction of the Amazon rainforest has reached its lowest level since monitoring began 24 years ago.   The Brazilian government says it's because of its action taken against offenders. Official figures showed the rate of deforestation fell 27% in the year to July compared with the previous 12 months.   Even so, an area nearly 6 times the size of New York City has been lost in a year.

Seven years ago Isabelle Dinoire, became the first-ever person to have a face transplant.     In a rare interview, she describes how she copes with the stares, and her yearning to meet the family of the woman whose face became her own.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20493572

Link Title: France to back Palestinian UN bid
Message: France has confirmed it intends to vote for Palestinian non-member status at the United Nations later this week.  The Palestinians are asking the UN General Assembly to upgrade their status from permanent observer to a "non-member observer state".  The vote is due to take place later this week.

Link Title: Sao Paulo accused on human rights
Message: Authorities in Brazil's Sao Paulo state are failing to provide security or justice for victims of human rights violations, Amnesty International says.  It says reports of police involvement in revenge killings have not been investigated properly for "many years".  The claim comes amid a wave of violence in which more than 90 police officers have died this year. In October alone 571 civilians were killed.

Ever since Neil Armstrong set foot on the Moon's surface in 1969 space suit technology has continued to evolve.    Modern space suits are designed to protect astronauts from extreme temperatures, speeding particles, solar radiation and the hard vacuum of space.    We have an interactive guide to help you understand more about space suit technology in the 21st Century.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20433089

A report in The New York Times says a leaked copy of an audit of Afghanistan's disgraced Kabul Bank suggests highly organised fraud.  When the Bank's assets were seized two years ago, the vast majority of its loans - almost nine hundred million dollars - were reportedly made to just 19 people and companies.   One of President Hamid Karzai's brothers, Mahmoud, is said to be a beneficiary. He denies any wrongdoing.

The remains of Yasser Arafat have been exhumed as part of an investigation into how the Palestinian leader died.  Swiss, French and Russian experts were given samples to establish whether his death in Paris in 2004 at the age of 75 was the result of poisoning before the tomb was resealed.  France began a murder inquiry in August after Swiss experts found radioactive polonium-210 on his personal effects.  Arafat's medical records say he had a stroke resulting from a blood disorder.

In the image below you can see parents in South Korea, praying for their children's exam results.    A new study has revealed a global league of education systems.    Finland leads the world and is followed by  South Korea and Hong Kong.     The bottom 5 feature the emerging economies of Mexico, Brazil and Indonesia.    So what do the top ranked countries do that other countries don't?   What is the education culture in your country?   Are teachers highly respected?   How much emphasis is placed on play time?      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-20498356

Bangladesh is observing a day of mourning for the more than 100 victims of a clothing factory fire on Saturday.  The country's three-million workers in the industry were given a day's holiday.  Meanwhile, police continued to hunt for the owner of the factory who they want to question about alleged violations of building regulations.

Song Byeok was once the official state propaganda artist of North Korea. He created paintings and posters celebrating the country's revered leaders Kim Jong-Il and Kim Il-Sung http://bbc.in/Qmkn7Y  After losing his family to famine and a botched attempt to leave the country - he was sent to a prison camp. He managed to escape in 2002 to South Korea. There he turned his artistic skills against the regime in his homeland.  Get to know Song Byeok in this week's edition of First Person http://bbc.in/Qmkn7Y

Can science help bring peace to the Middle East? http://bbc.in/Spird4  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the particle accelerator that is bringing together scientists from countries usually openly hostile to each other and news from around the world, including:  - Presidential power in Egypt http://bbc.in/SpipSu - Syria crisis: Despair of refugees in Atma camp http://bbc.in/Spird6 - The GOP and the Fiscal Cliff http://bbc.in/SpipSs  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest news and features from our producers and correspondents working in North America.

Did any of your teachers drive a Lamborghini? http://bbc.in/SpbPLF  Meet some of Hong Kong's A-list "tutor kings" and "tutor queens" - the celebrity instructors giving pupils a chance to improve mediocre grades.

A couple drowned and their 16-year-old son is missing after trying to save their dog from being swept into the ocean off the coast of the US state of California  http://bbc.in/Sp1DTr  The dog chased a stick into the surf in Big Lagoon and was pulled out to sea by 10ft-high waves (3m), the Associated Press reported. The boy and his parents followed.   The dog swam to shore on its own.

Activists in Syria say a government jet has dropped a cluster bomb on a playground, leaving 10 children dead.  Video posted on the internet showed children's bodies on the ground with their mothers grieving over them.  The children were killed when a MiG fighter bombed a playground in the village of Deir al-Asafir, east of Damascus, opposition activists said.

Holy smoke - the Popemobile that ferried Pope John Paul II through the thousands of people who thronged to see him in Ireland in 1979 - is up for hire.    The little yellow van that set a million faithful hearts aflutter has had a 60,000 euro makeover.    There are now 14 new seats as well as the original straight-backed chair with cushion as used by Pope John Paul II.    The popemobile is up for hire from 250 euros an hour.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20495148

Link Title: Egypt's Mursi to meet top judges
Message: Egyptian President Mohammed Mursi is set to meet senior judges to try to ease a mounting crisis over the extent of his powers.  Justice Minister Ahmed Mekky said he believed a resolution would be found.  The president said earlier he was committed to finding "common ground" with other parties.

Nelson Mandela's former prison on Robben Island is not a place you'd associate with the finer things in life.     But the discovery of grape vines still growing in his old prison courtyard has inspired an unlikely rescue mission.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20465704

Can science bring a new diplomacy to the Middle East?   Today we take you inside the remarkable Sesame project in Jordan, bringing together scientists from countries as diverse as Iran, Israel, Turkey, Cyprus and Pakistan.   On Impact - a report from our Science Editor and a live interview with the man who hopes science builds trust in a troubled region. Mishal

Separatist parties in Spain's richest region, Catalonia, have won a majority in elections and promised to push for what amounts to a referendum on independence.   The governing CiU lost seats in the regional parliament, but another pro-separatist party, the Republican Left, made big gains.   After these results how likely are we to see a referendum on the independence?

The Israeli Defence Minister, Ehud Barak, has announced he will quit politics after the general election next January.  It brings an end to a long career in Israel's military and political establishment.  How much will his departure change the party political landscape in Israel?
Have you seen New York City's abandoned City Hall subway station? BBC Travel uncovers five other NYC oddities that you may not have known about.

Shares on Egypt's stock market plunged almost 10% on Sunday, days after President Mohammed Mursi granted himself sweeping new powers.  Protests against the president's decision have continued in Cairo, while the Muslim Brotherhood is planning rallies backing him later.  Trading was suspended for 30 minutes as shares slumped in the first session since the president's announcement.  But the slide continued as soon as share dealing resumed.

VIDEO REPORT: The French village of Bugarach is preparing for an influx of mystical groups who are convinced they will escape the end of the world in 2012.  Rumours have been circulating since 2010 that the village of Bugarach, with a population of 200, will provide shelter from an impending Armageddon.  This is expected to be on 21 December 2012, the end of a 5,125-year-long cycle in the ancient Maya calendar.

The death toll from a fire in a clothes factory in Bangladesh has leapt to at least 120, officials say, as bodies are found in the charred building on Sunday.  The blaze broke out late on Saturday in the multi-floor Tazreen Fashion factory in the Ashulia district on the outskirts of the capital Dhaka.  Some people died after jumping from the building to escape the flames.   It is unclear what caused the fire, which started on the ground floor trapping many victims in the factory.

Members of Venezuela's National Guard find half a million dollars in cash buried on the shores of the river Meta in the west of the country.  It was hidden in plastic bags on the banks of the river Meta along with a rifle and 1kg (2.2lb) of cocaine.  Counter-narcotics officers said the money belonged to an international drug trafficking gang which also stored fuel and small aircraft in a camp nearby.   They said the camp was used to smuggle drugs from Colombia to Central America.
Egypt's top judges accuse President Mursi of staging an "unprecedented attack" on the judiciary, after giving himself sweeping new powers.

Link Title: DR Congo crisis talks under way
Message: Four African heads of state begin talks to resolve the crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where M23 rebels have seized the city of Goma.

Actor Larry Hagman, who dominated TV schedules in his role as JR Ewing in 1980s soap opera Dallas, has died at the age of 81.  Hagman, who had suffered from cancer and cirrhosis of the liver, died in hospital on Friday afternoon

The body of Palestinian leader is to be exhumed on Tuesday, Palestinian officials announce, for tests to find on whether he died of poisoning.  Arafat's medical records say he had suffered a stroke, but France began a murder inquiry in August after Swiss experts found radioactive polonium-210 on his personal effects.  His tomb, in Ramallah in the West Bank, was sealed off earlier this month

Japan's era of shoguns and samurai is long over, but the country does have one, or maybe two, surviving ninjas.     Experts in the dark arts of espionage and silent assassination, ninjas passed skills from father to son - but today's say they will be the last.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20135674

Link Title: EU budget talks end without deal
Message: After hours of wrangling the European Union budget talks have ended without agreement.  The 27 member states were trying to agree funding for 2014 to 2020 but there have been deep divisions on whether there should be cuts or increases in spending.
This week, BBC Travel explores Madagascar's labyrinth of stone, a limestone formation that shelters some of the world’s most diverse wildlife.

Link Title: Road built around house in China
Message: An elderly Chinese couple, that refused to abandon their home to make way for a highway, have found themselves living in the middle of the road.   While all their neighbours have moved out, the Luo's - in their sixties - have refused to go until they receive US $40000 in compensation from the local government.

What's in a name? Well quite a lot it seems if you are Felipe Calderon, President of Mexico.   He is trying to change the official name of his country from the United Mexican States to simply Mexico.   His reasoning is that the term 'United States' is too closely associated with Mexico's more powerful neighbour to the north.

The 50th Anniversary 4K Restoration of LAWRENCE OF ARABIA is in UK cinemas from 23 November and will roll out worldwide this winter.     The 4K Digitally Restored version of David Lean’s Director’s Cut had its World Premiere at Cannes 2012 and was also shown at Edinburgh, London and Bologna Festivals this year.    What do you make of digitally restored movies? Should it be done or should it be appreciated for what it is in its original form?    Still courtesy of “Park Circus/Sony Pictures”.

Hi Ros here from World Have Your Say. We'll be on at the usual time today (15GMT) and as you'd expect we'll be reflecting on the Israel Hamas ceasefire.   I know that conversations around this subject can easily become a debate about history, so let me ask you a favour.   We're focusing on what, if anything, each side achieved from this week-long conflict and from the terms of the ceasefire.   I'm keen to hear your views on that particular subject, and if could address those issues I'd be grateful.   We'll look at your comments of course, but you can also message us through http://www.facebook.com/worldhaveyoursay, or you can get me across on twitter @BBCRosAtkins. I'll speak to you in a couple of hours.

Supporters and opponents of President Mursi are out on the streets of Cairo a day after he gave himself sweeping new powers.   Supporters of his Islamist movement say the move was necessary in order to get rid of the last vestiges of the Mubarak era.   But critics say he's made himself completely unaccountable.  What do you think of President Mohammed Mursi's decree?

Top code-breakers at one of Britain's intelligence agencies, GCHQ, say they have failed to decipher a message found attached to the leg of a dead World War II pigeon.     The strip of paper contains 27 groups of 5 letters which code-breakers have failed to crack despite trying for several weeks.    We wanted to pose a challenge to all of you.     Can you do better than the British intelligence agencies and crack the code? Do send us your suggestions.

Israeli soldiers kill a Palestinian man close to the Gaza-Israel border, say Palestinian officials - the first killing since Wednesday's ceasefire.  The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) confirmed only that it had fired "warning shots" after seeing a group walking towards the border fence.  Earlier, Israel said it had arrested several people over a bus bomb in Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

Facebook is set to remove the ability for users to vote on changes to its data privacy policy, in a move that has angered campaigners.  In an email to all members, Facebook said it wanted a "more meaningful" way for users to give feedback.  The site has also proposed combining information across its other services, such as photo-sharing app Instagram.  Facebook said a vote into the changes could take place, but more than 300m users would need to participate.

A South Pacific island, shown on marine charts and world maps as well as on Google Earth and Google Maps has been  'proven not to exist'.    The supposedly sizeable strip of land, named Sandy Island on Google maps, was positioned midway between Australia and French-governed New Caledonia.    But when scientists from the University of Sydney went to the area, they found only the blue ocean of the Coral Sea.    The phantom island has featured in publications for at least a decade.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20442487

Link Title: War crimes warrant for Mrs Gbagbo
Message: The International Criminal Court has issued an arrest warrant for Simone Gbagbo, the wife of Ivory Coast's ex-President Laurent Gbagbo.  She is wanted for alleged crimes against humanity committed in the wake of disputed presidential elections in 2010.  Her husband is already awaiting trial at the court in The Hague on four charges of crimes against humanity.  Some 3,000 people died in the unrest after he refused to accept defeat.

The former French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, is being questioned by a judge in Bordeaux about his connections to France's richest woman, the L'Oreal heiress Liliane Bettencourt.   It's alleged he accepted illegal party donations to finance his 2007 presidential campaign, something Mr Sarkozy has repeatedly denied.

The cream of the crop from Africa's world footballers has been nominated for the BBC's African Footballer of the Year.    Who do you think deserves to win?    The winner will be decided by you the football fans. You have until December 13th to cast your vote.    Click on the link below for further details    http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20432605

Link Title: Gaza conflict: Reaction to the ceasefire
Message: A ceasefire agreed on Wednesday between Israel and Hamas has largely held overnight.   A number of rockets were fired towards southern Israel from Gaza in the first few hours, but Israel did not respond and appears not to be regarding this as a breach of the ceasefire.   Israel says it arrested what it described as 55 terror operatives in the West Bank overnight.  People in Israel and Gaza have been giving us their reaction to the news to the ceasefire.

Link Title: EU budget summit to test stamina
Message: EU leaders gathering in Brussels are to seek a deal on the bloc's seven-year budget, with many calling for cuts as they rein in spending nationally.  Countries that rely heavily on EU funding, including Poland and its ex-communist neighbours, want current spending levels maintained or raised.  The UK and some other net contributors say cuts have to be made. At stake are 973bn euros ($1,245bn).

Astronomers have obtained an important first look at the dwarf planet Makemake - finding it has no atmosphere http://bbc.in/Qb5dlY  One of five such dwarfs in our Solar System including former planet Pluto, Makemake had until now eluded study.

In March this year El Salvador's most violent gangs - the Mara Salvatrucha and the 18th Street gang - agreed on a truce http://bbc.in/QaXx2S  The agreement was negotiated in a series of secret meetings with both gangs' leaders in El Salvador's prisons.  Can the peace last?

A senior Hamas negotiator has told the BBC that they have agreed to a ceasefire with Israel to end a week of violence in which nearly 160 people have died http://bbc.in/Sevu0E  It is expected to come into effect at 19:00 GMT (21:00 local time)

Link Title: Chelsea set to announce new boss
Message: Ros here. I'm hosting the 18GMT bulletin. If you're a football fan, you've probably already seen that Roberto Di Matteo was relieved of his duties as Chelsea manager earlier. We're all busy speculating about who might take over and thought you'd probably like to join in.   So two questions: who will get the job? And who deserves the job? You can either comment here or get me across on twitter @BBCRosAtkins.

Link Title: Bolivia shuts down for census day
Message: Bolivia is holding its first census in 11 years. The government has imposed a curfew ordering people to stay in their homes for the day. Those who aren't at home on Wednesday face a fine. Alcohol consumption has also been banned for the day. President Morales says the census needs to be accurate for the benefit of future generations.

Link Title: The race to stop a global killer
Message: A deadly fungus is sweeping the world killing off hundreds of amphibian species. Researchers have now teamed up to work out how to stop it, but can they succeed? BBC Future investigates. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121121-the-race-to-stop-a-global-killer

Rebel fighters in the Democratic Republic of Congo have threatened to march to the capital, Kinshasa, after capturing the eastern city of Goma. M23 rebel commander Lt Col Vianney Kazarama told a crowd in Goma that they were ready to "liberate" the country.     The UN Security Council has strongly condemned Goma's seizure and called for sanctions against the rebels.     Congolese affairs analyst,  Theodore Trefon, explains why this latest violence in Goma matters: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20415534

Swedish researchers say that being muscular as a teenager could help you live longer. The study tracked more than a million teenage boys for 24 years and found those with low muscle strength were at increased risk of early death.   But Professor Stephen Evans says while there is good evidence exercise is beneficial for health, the study did not show doing more exercise would necessarily prolong your life.
A bomb on a bus in Tel Aviv has injured at least 10 people in what police are calling a "terrorist attack". The incident happened as Israel continues its strikes on Gaza.
Pakistani national Mohammad Ajmal Amir Kasab, the sole surviving gunman from the 2008 Mumbai attacks, has been executed in an Indian prison.

Did "Superstorm" Sandy give the Occupy movement a new mission? http://bbc.in/ScsTV3  The BBC's Kate Dailey and David Botti take a look at how the group has become one of the leading providers of storm relief for beleaguered areas in the US states of New York and New Jersey still suffering the effects of the storm.

Egyptian and Palestinian officials say a ceasefire is set to be announced in the Gaza conflict http://bbc.in/Scn9uA  Egypt's President Mohammed Mursi said he expected Israel to end air strikes late on Tuesday. A Hamas official also told the BBC a truce was imminent.  Israel has not confirmed this, but has put plans for a land invasion on hold.

What makes us intelligent? And does Google and Wikipedia make this better or worse? As BBC Future explains, studies have revealed that our minds are made up just as much by the people and tools around us as they are by the brain cells inside our skull. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121120-what-makes-us-intelligent

Link Title: Fewer new HIV cases in children
Message: The UN's latest assessment of global cases of HIV/Aids shows there has been a further drop in new infections among children.  There were 330,000 new infections in children last year - the figure is 24% lower than in 2009.  But the report by UNAids also warns "significant additional effort is required" if broader targets to tackle HIV/Aids are to be achieved by 2015.
We examine some of the consequences of moves to legalise marijuana in two US states.   What do you think? Should marijuana be legalized elsewhere and if so under which conditions?

Britain has recognised the new coalition of opposition groups as the sole legitimate representative of the Syrian people, becoming the second western country to do so.   The Foreign Secretary, William Hague, called the formation of the group a major breakthrough, and said London would provide increased support to it. The coalition will receive  from Britain communications equipment but there was no mention of any military aid.   So far the Gulf States, Turkey and France have recognised the opposition as the sole representative of the Syrian people.

Israel says it has put plans for a ground operation in Gaza on hold as talks continue in Egypt to try to secure a truce.     The UN Secretary General, Ban Ki Moon, has been in Cairo as part of diplomatic efforts to stop the fighting.    Overnight, there were further Israeli air strikes on Gaza while Palestinian groups launched a handful of missiles into southern Israel.    This is the latest on casualties in Gaza:  medical staff say at least 115 Palestinians  have been killed and another 800 injured since the bombardment began.    On the Israeli side: 3 people have been killed in the last seven days and police say that 61 rockets have been fired from Gaza  into Israel so far today.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20394242

Humans are not the only ones to experience midlife crisis.   Chimpanzees and orangutans may also experience it just like us.  That is according to an international team of researchers who found that well-being was high in youth, fell to a low in midlife and rose again in old age, similar to the "U-shape curve" of happiness in humans.  The study brought together experts such as psychologists, primatologists and economists.

A BBC correspondent has seen what seems to be a column of rebel fighters entering central Goma, the main city in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.  He saw them exchange small arms fire with the Congolese army.  UN peacekeepers have denied M23 rebel claims that they are in control of the airport.  Tens of thousands of people have fled recent fighting, which has led to fears of a resumption of the DR Congo war, in which some five million people died.
Islamist rebel groups in the Syrian city of Aleppo say they reject the new Western-backed opposition coalition, and seek to establish an "Islamist state".

Hamas officials say at least 105 people have died in the Gaza Strip in six days of violence. Israeli forces continue a bombardment they say aims to stop rocket attacks into Israel. Monday's fatalities include a commander of the Islamic Jihad militant group http://bbc.in/Q683sq  More than 100 rockets were fired on Israel by militants on Monday, but no casualties were reported.   - As it happened: 19 November http://bbc.in/Q683sk - What is Israel's military strategy? http://bbc.in/Q683IM - Israel targets Hamas homes http://bbc.in/Q683IE - In pictures http://bbc.in/Q680wC - Q&A: Israel-Gaza violence http://bbc.in/Q683II

Were you in London for the Olympic Games?  What advice would you give to Rio? http://bbc.in/Q5Xm9d  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at the visit to Rio by London 2012 organizers and other news from around the world, including:  - The latest from Gaza http://bbc.in/Q5XntL - Obama visits Burma http://bbc.in/Q5XntO - Nose cells restore ability to walk in  paralysed dogs http://bbc.in/Q5Xm9b  Check your local listings to find BBC World News America in your area.   Follow us on Twitter http://bbc.in/Q5Xm99 for the latest news and features from our correspondents working in North America.

"Ariane 5 has no chance" http://bbc.in/QTNSPz  Is there a new space race brewing?   Elon Musk, chief executive of California's SpaceX, has warned Europe it must replace its Ariane 5 rocket if it wants to keep up with his company's lower production costs.

Scores of Kenyan troops go on the rampage, beating residents of the eastern town of Garissa, after three soldiers are shot dead by unknown gunmen.  A reporter in Garissa, near the Somali border, has told the BBC that the soldiers ordered people to evacuate a mosque before assaulting them.  The three soldiers were part of the African Union mission in Somalia.  They were killed as they were fixing a puncture on their truck, the army says.

At least 14 people have been killed and many injured in a crush at a religious ceremony in Bihar, northern India.  Many of the dead are feared to be women and children.  Police say the accident happened following the collapse of a makeshift bamboo bridge on the banks of river Ganges where Hindu devotees were offering prayers to the setting sun as part of the annual Chhath ritual.  In the ensuing panic, the victims were crushed to death.

Colombia's left-wing Farc rebels have declared a unilateral two-month ceasefire as they start peace talks with government negotiators.  The first face-to-face meeting is aimed at ending five decades of conflict in which some 600,000 people have died.  The chief government negotiator, Humberto de la Calle, said it was a defining moment. Do you think the truce will last?

Link Title: Gaza deaths mount in Israel raids
Message: At least 25 people have died in the Gaza Strip as Israeli forces kept up air strikes they say are aimed at stopping rocket attacks into Israel.  Fewer rockets have been launched, but some have hit southern Israeli towns.  94 Palestinians and 3 Israelis have died since Wednesday. They include 9 members of a Gaza family apparently killed by mistake.  Efforts to secure a ceasefire continue, with a senior Egyptian official saying there are "encouraging signs"

History is being made in South East Asia today as Barack Obama became the first US President to visit Burma and Cambodia.   It was a whirlwind trip to Rangoon, with the President trying to strike a balance between praising the governments recent reforms and warning against the danger of ethnic violence.  In a speech at Rangoon University, he urged Burmese people to accept Muslim Rohingyas after recent violence.
BBC journalists in both Israel and Gaza send in their photos of the stories they're covering

International charity Save the Children has warned 200,000 Syrian refugee children are at serious risk from freezing temperatures, as winter sets in the Middle East.  Many families have fled across the borders to Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon.  More than two million are displaced inside Syria, as fighting between government forces and rebels continues.  Save the Children says many are living without proper shelter and clothing and may not survive the harsh conditions.
People from Gaza and Israel share their experiences as the Israeli military and militants in Gaza continue to trade fire.

Link Title: A day to break toilet taboos
Message: Have you ever participated in any World Toilet Day events? BBC Travel details how you can take part on Monday.

This weekend on Horizons it’s all about biofuels: Adam’s in Brazil looking at how to extract the most from sugar cane, and Saima will be in San Francisco looking at third generation biofuels made from single-celled plants or algae. Tune in on Sunday at 1430 and 2030 GMT. Or watch anytime online:  http://www.horizonsbusiness.com/episode/biofuels/
As the Gaza conflict enters a fifth day, Israel warns it is ready to "significantly expand" its operation.   Follow it live: http://bbc.in/SDUIEi  In pictures: http://bbc.in/SDUHAc

Link Title: Obama in landmark SE Asia visit
Message: Barack Obama has begun a tour of South East Asia, which will include a historic visit to Burma.  Mr Obama landed in Thailand's capital Bangkok on his first foreign trip after his re-election as president.  On Monday he will become the first US president to visit Burma, which has been praised in the West for freeing hundreds of political prisoners and holding its first contested election.

Link Title: Israel pounds Gaza for fifth day
Message: Israel has been shelling Gaza from the sea and air on the fifth day of its bombardment of the coastal territory.  Two media buildings were hit, including one housing offices of Hamas TV as well as Britain's Sky and ITN. Several Palestinian journalists were injured.   The Israeli army said eight rockets had been fired from Gaza since midnight, three of which hit Israeli territory.  Israel says it still wants to hit hundreds of Gaza targets as it seeks to stop rockets being fired into Israel.

Fifty children aged four to six years old and the driver of the school bus they were on were killed when their vehicle was hit by a train in central Egypt on Saturday.  The transport minister resigned in the wake of the crash near Manfalut, 350km south of Cairo.   The provincial governor said the man in charge of the crossing was asleep and had been arrested.   Egyptian roads and railways have a poor safety record.   An estimated 8,000 people die in car accidents each year in the country

One of India's most controversial politicians, Bal Thackeray has died at the age of 86.  He founded the Shiv Sena party with the aims of halting the spread of Islam and keeping South Indian migrants out of Maharashtra state.  Our correspondent in Mumbai told us the city is at a standstill on Saturday night as supporters amass outside Thackeray's home.

Link Title: Israel air strikes hit Hamas HQ
Message: Israel has targeted the headquarters of Hamas leaders and other key facilities in Gaza, on the fourth day of Israeli air strikes in the territory.  Prime Minister Ismail Haniya's office, which Egypt's PM had visited on Friday, was among the buildings destroyed.  At least 39 Palestinians and three Israelis have died since Israel killed Hamas's military chief on Wednesday.

Link Title: Israel and Hamas in Twitter war
Message: Israel Defense Forces and Hamas are engaged in battle on a new front: Twitter.  Both are live-tweeting events, almost in real time.   How much does this truly influence public opinion?   Do you find it acceptable or do you think it's a surprising use of social media?
This week, BBC Travel visits the World Elephant Polo Tournament, held every November in Nepal’s Chitwan National Park. Have you ever seen a polo match played by elephants?

South African police have arrested a man who they say swallowed 220 polished diamonds in an attempt to smuggle them out of the country.    The man was arrested at Johannesburg airport and a body scan showed that he had ingested $2.3m worth of the stones.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20330080

Link Title: The ordeal of a Moscow 'shop slave'
Message: An Uzbek woman says she was kept as a slave for 10 years in Moscow.  She told our correspondent, Daniel Sandford, the story of her ordeal, which saw her give birth twice in captivity.

Hi, Ros here from World Have Your Say. We're on air in an hour (1500GMT) on BBC World News.   Needless to say, we'll be speaking to Gazans and Israelis about the impact the escalating conflict is having on their lives.   If you are directly affected and would like to take part, please either post here, or get me on http://twitter.com/BBCRosAtkins and I'll pass your details onto the team.   While inevitably we'll discuss the rights and wrongs of what's happening, we're particularly concerned to understand the experiences of those in the areas where missiles and rockets are landing. Speak to you shortly.

Syrian opposition leaders are due in London for talks over the conflict in the country with the UK's Foreign Secretary William Hague.  Before meeting opposition leaders in London, Mr Hague said the UK wanted to recognise them as the legitimate voice of the people at "an early stage".  But he said he must be sure they had "genuine support" throughout Syria and were committed to a democratic future.

ON IMPACT with Karin Giannone: Apart from the main headlines we'll also be talking about the rumours that David Beckham is considering making a short-term move to play in Australia.  He has denied any such rumours but we want to hear from you.  How would David Beckham benefit from playing in Australia? Players like Alessandro Del Piero and Emile Heskey already play for Australian clubs, are we going to see more star players in  Australia ?  Let us know what you think and we may use some of your comments during our programme.

A war crimes court in The Hague has overturned the convictions of two Croatian generals charged with atrocities against Serbs in the 1990s.  Appeals judges at tribunal for the former Yugoslavia ordered the release of Ante Gotovina and Mladen Markac.  In 2011 they were sentenced to 24 years and 18 years respectively over the killing of ethnic Serbs in an offensive to retake Croatia's Krajina region.

Link Title: Egypt PM arrives for Gaza mission
Message: Egypt's Prime Minister, Hisham Qandil, has condemned Israeli attacks on Gaza as a "disaster" during his visit to show solidarity with the Palestinian people.  He said, "What I am witnessing in Gaza is a disaster and I can't keep quiet. The Israeli aggression must stop."  A truce, proposed for the Egyptian Prime Minister's visit, has been broken by both sides  At least 20 Palestinians and three Israelis have been killed since Israel began its offensive on Wednesday.  Keep up to date with the very latest with the BBC's correspondents on the ground.
