Jon Donnison in Gaza is @JonDonnison Paul Danahar in Gaza is @pdanahar Wyre Davis in Gaza is @WyreDavies Yolande Knell in Ashkelon is @YolandeKnell Katya Adler in Jerusalem  is @katyaadler   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20353223

The odds are stacked against young people in Kenya. Three-quarters of those under 35 do not have jobs. Poverty and poor education have left 1.3 million youths unemployed - and studies suggest women are five times more likely to struggle to find work than men.    Susan Kayongo, 18, has benefited from a scheme - the Girls Empowerment Micro-franchise project - run by the International Rescue Committee in Nairobi.    It is hoped this will become a blueprint to help thousands of young unemployed Kenyan women.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20300644
Aside from cricket, India is not known for its sporting success , so how are major global sports trying to tap into the Indian market?

Three people have been killed as rockets fired from Gaza struck southern Israel, amid escalating violence.  They died when a four-storey building in the town of Kiryat Malachi was hit.   Hundreds of rockets were fired into Israel by militants in Gaza, and Israel carried out numerous air strikes as cross-border violence soared in recent weeks.

Link Title: BP to get record criminal fine
Message: The BBC has learned that the oil giant BP is to face the biggest criminal penalty in US history - at least three billion dollars - over the Deepwater Horizon oil disaster in 2010.   The explosion and fire aboard the rig killed eleven workers and set off a spill which polluted large areas of the southern coast of the United States.

VIDEO:    A BBC journalist whose baby was killed by shrapnel in Gaza has been speaking about his son's death.    In this video Jihad Misharawi tells us how his 11-month-old son Omar died after shrapnel hit the family home.    Violence has been escalating across Gaza and southern Israel following the Israeli killing of Hamas' military chief on Wednesday, as Jon Donnison explains.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20340810

For up to date analysis of the latest developments on events  in Gaza and Israel make sure you follow our correspondents on Twitter:    Jon Donnison in Gaza is @JonDonnison  Paul Danahar in Gaza is @pdanahar  Yolande Knell in Israel is @YolandeKnell  and Paul Adams in Washington DC is @BBCPaulAdams    For further analysis on how Palestinian and Israeli firepower compare to one another click on this link.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20343180

France is to push for a discussion on supplying Syrian rebels with "defensive arms" ahead of talks in Paris and London.  The BBC's Christian Fraser says the West has been reluctant to back the armed struggle but the mood music in France and the UK has been changing.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20340664

Link Title: PROF. FAWAZ GERGEZ INTV BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO:  As media attention in the Middle East focuses on Gaza, Professor Fawaz Gerges, from the London School of Economics, joined us on BBC World News to discuss the implications and consequences of the recent escalation in violence from both sides.  'Israel must stop the siege of Palestinians in Gaza and Hamas must stop firing rockets against Israeli citizens' - Professor Fawaz Gerges.

Could Jose Mujica be the world's poorest President?     He lives in a on a ramshackle farm and gives away most of his pay.     Laundry is strung outside the house. The water comes from a well in a yard, overgrown with weeds.     Can you guess which country he runs?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20243493

There were no real surprises as China's new leaders were named, at the end of the Communist Party congress.   Vice President Xi Jinping will succeed President Hu Jintao as head of the ruling Communist Party. He said China must continue reforming and warned that the party had to tackle corruption and be more in touch with the people.  Take a look as we profile China's new Politburo Standing Committee - the group who will lead the country for the next decade.

"I can never be the person that I was before these things happened. I'm still suffering from depression, I am still suffering from nightmares." http://bbc.in/QHrx7K  In June 2009, a woman was shot dead in a demonstration in Tehran. Neda Agha-Soltan became the face of the Iranian protest movement - except that it was not her face to begin with, but the face of university teacher Neda Soltani.   Neda Soltani shares her disturbing story of mistaken identity with us http://bbc.in/QHrx7K

A top Hamas military leader was killed in Gaza City today, as the Israeli military began retaliation efforts against a recent spike in rocket attacks on Israel from the Gaza Strip. Israeli officials described Ahmed Said Khalil al-Jabari - Hamas's top military commander - as having "a lot of blood on his hands" http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20328579  Tonight on BBC World News America, we'll discuss the renewed violence in Gaza and other news from around the world, including:  - Austerity strikes sweep much of Europe http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20320993  - President Obama's first press-conference since reelction http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20333066  - Controversy surrounds a proposed new bio-security facility in Kansas http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20318386  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS by clicking on the link below.

Link Title: JIMMY PAGE INTV PROMO - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: *Please note the change in date from our earlier post*  VIDEO:  Led Zeppelin head to Washington next month to receive the prestigious Kennedy Center Honors, in the presence of President Obama.   Guitarist Jimmy Page tells Kirsty Lang why the award is so important to him.   You'll be able to watch the interview on BBC World News on Friday 16 Nov

Where can you build the world's largest animal disease lab? http://bbc.in/Sp4oCr  After an exhaustive search for a location to replace New York's Plum Island - The National Bio and Agro defence facility (NBAF) is set to be built in the town of Manhattan in the US state of Kansas.   Residents of this small city have raised concerns about the suitability of the site - including the risk of tornadoes and the health of local livestock.

Link Title: JIMMY PAGE INTV PROMO - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO:  Led Zeppelin head to Washington next month to receive the prestigious Kennedy Centre Honours, in the presence of President Obama.    Guitarist Jimmy Page tells Kirsty Lang why the award is so important to him.    You'll be able to watch the interview in full on BBC World News on Thursday 16 Nov from 2230GMT

Many of you will be familiar with the “10,000 hours rule", made popular by the writer Malcolm Gladwell, which states that 10,000 hours of practice is what it takes to be the best in your field. Is it true? No, says one person on BBC Future, and he should know - he's the psychologist whose research formed the basis of the idea. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121114-gladwells-10000-hour-rule-myth

The death of a woman who was 17 weeks pregnant is the subject of two investigations at University Hospital Galway in the Republic of Ireland.  The husband of a pregnant woman who died in an Irish hospital has said he has no doubt she would be alive if she had been allowed an abortion.  Savita Halappanavar's family said she asked several times for her pregnancy to be terminated because she had severe back pain and was miscarrying.  Her husband told the BBC that it was refused because there was a foetal heartbeat.

Hamas says the head of its military wing, Ahmed Jabari, has been killed in an Israeli air strike.  Israel said it had targeted Ahmed al-Jabari because of what it called his decade-long terrorist activity.  He is the most senior Hamas official to be killed since an Israeli offensive in Gaza four years ago.  Witnesses say Jabari was traveling in his vehicle in Gaza City when his car exploded. There are reports his deputy has also been killed.

Link Title: ISRAEL PROPOSES 'TOPPLING' ABBAS REPORT - WYRE DAVIES - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: ANALYSIS:  Reports from Israel say that the Foreign ministry has proposed "toppling" Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas IF a Palestinian bid for state observer status at the UN is approved later this month.   A draft document, expected to be approved by the foreign minister Avigdor Lieberman, says that "any other option would mean admitting the failure of the Israeli leadership."  The chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, told the BBC that the Palestinian Authority took Israel's threats seriously and that it did not rule out any attempt on Israel's part to hurt the president.  BBC's Wyre Davies spoke to GMT about possible implications of any such action by Israel.

Astronomers have spotted a "rogue planet" wandering the cosmos without a star to orbit 100 light-years away.    The proximity of the new rogue planet, dubbed CFBDSIR2149-0403, has allowed astronomers to guess its age: a comparatively young 50-120 million years old.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20309762

Should companies be forced to promote more women to the boardroom?     The EU says there is a severe gender gap in boardrooms at big businesses, it's planned to fix this with a controversial directive that many people, including women, have criticised.    The European Commission wants companies to have women in at least 40% of their non-executive board positions at major listed companies by the year 2020.

Millions of people across Europe are joining protests against austerity measures imposed by governments trying to cut public debt.     In Spain and Portugal, strikes have hit public transport systems hard with more than 600 flights cancelled in Spain alone.    Strikes have been called in Spain, Greece, Portugal and Italy, with other protests planned in Belgium, Germany, France, the UK and some eastern EU states.     Wednesday's action has been called for by the European Trade Union Confederation, which issued a statement saying "Austerity is a total dead end, and must be abandoned."    Do you agree that it is time to abandon austerity measures?     Should affected countries consider leaving the Euro?

Do you still use internet cafes? http://bbc.in/QFdMX7  Many internet cafes have permanently shut their doors as wireless technology continues to grow. Are these outlets ultimately destined for the dustbin of history?  Join us as we visit a cafe that has rebooted its business plan to stay relevant in the mobile age.

A physician from Edinburgh is set to run seven ultra marathons on seven continents in seven days in an attempt to promote health and raise more than £10,000 for charity http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20317720    Tonight on BBC World News America we'll meet Andrew Murray and hear about his upcoming runs. We'll also take a look at news from around the world, including:     - Gen John Allen's emails with Petraeus' mistress http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20317071      - UN 'failed Sri Lanka civilians' http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-20317718    - Japan and China square off in the East China Sea http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20307141    Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area    Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://twitter.com/bbcnewsus

Afghanistan commander Gen John Allen is being probed amid reports he sent thousands of "inappropriate" emails to Jill Kelley, the same Florida socialite involved in the downfall of CIA Director David Petraeus http://bbc.in/SkF1l5  - Petraeus 'shared no classified information' http://bbc.in/SkF1kZ - Who is Gen Allen? http://bbc.in/SkF1l1 - Who are the women? http://bbc.in/SkEYWy - FBI search Paula Broadwell's home http://bbc.in/SkF14J

France has become the first European nation to recognise Syria's opposition coalition as the sole legitimate representative of the Syrian people http://bbc.in/SkjTvn  The move was announced by President Francois Hollande at a televised news conference in Paris.

The United Nations failed in its mandate to protect civilians in the last months of Sri Lanka's bloody civil war, according to a leaked draft of a highly critical internal UN report.     A penultimate draft leaked to the BBC, said events in Sri Lanka leading up to the end of the war in May 2009 mark a 'grave failure' of the UN and 'should not happen again'.     Human rights groups estimate that as many of 40,000 civilians were killed during that period and tens of thousands are still 'missing', making it one of the worst atrocities of recent decades.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20308610

A Canadian man who was believed to have been in a vegetative state for more than a decade, has been able to tell scientists that he is not in any pain.     Scott Routlay who suffered a serious head injury when he was involved in a car accident, was asked questions while having his brain activity scanned.    It's the first time that a previously non-responsive severely brain damaged patient has been able to respond regarding their care.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-20268044

The process of exhuming the body of the late Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat has begun in Ramallah.  Reports say stones and concrete at his mausoleum are being removed, and surrounding roads have been been closed.   It comes after a television documentary by Al Jazeera, earlier this year, claimed Mr Arafat may have been poisoned by the radioactive element Polonium 210.   He died in a French military hospital in 2004.

A new commuter train has been launched in Kenya's capital, Nairobi - the first of its kind since independence in 1963.    The train will run between the city centre and the suburb of Syokimau, where Kenya has built its first railway station in more than 80 years.    The service is intended to ease traffic congestion in Nairobi, one of the fastest-growing African cities with a population of about three million.    President Mwai Kibaki was the first commuter on the new train.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20310767

Link Title: In pictures: India prepares for Diwali
Message: PHOTOS: The Hindu festival - Diwali - is being celebrated across India and around the world.    Festivities take place over a number of days, but today - considered the most auspicious - is the main focus of family traditions.

There's been a new twist to the scandal engulfing the American military's top brass.   On Friday, General David Petraeus resigned as boss of the CIA after it was revealed he'd been having an extra-marital affair.   Now a close colleague from the US military, General John Allen, has been drawn into the scandal after what are being called "inappropriate communications" with a woman linked to the affair.   He's denied any wrongdoing but his application for a top NATO job has been put on hold.

Hi, I'm presenting Impact today and we'd really like to hear your thoughts on this:     An etiquette guide for movie-goers has been put together after a poll revealed more than half of film fans get annoyed by people talking in the cinema.    Other common gripes include people rustling their popcorn and loudly slurping drinks and people putting their feet on the chairs.     What annoys you most about other cinema-goers' behaviour? Do you complain to them, or just stay quiet?   If you have any stories about what's ruined a film for you, please share them with us.   Thanks for getting in touch, Karin

Link Title: Aung San Suu Kyi on India visit
Message: Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi makes her first visit to India in nearly 40 years, a return to the country where she studied.  She will meet Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, tour parliament and deliver a public lecture.  Ms Suu Kyi will also visit the college in Delhi she attended in the 1960s, when her mother was Burmese ambassador.  The visit comes two years after elections in Burma that formally ended military rule.
Palestinian leaders in the West Bank will ask the UN to admit Palestine as a "non-member observer state" by the end of the month, officials say.

Would you go swimming in the streets of Venice? http://bbc.in/QC3wiw  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll take a look at the flooding in Italy and other news from around the world, including:  - Tensions grow between Israel & Syria http://bbc.in/QC3uHu - Petraeus' affair fallout http://bbc.in/QC3wis - New BBC head vows to 'get a grip' http://bbc.in/QC3wiy - Tower of London keys stolen http://bbc.in/QC3uHs  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Be sure to follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/QC3wiu for the latest news and features from our correspondents and producers working in North America.

"Furious would be an understatement" http://bbc.in/SgeghE  Retired Army Col Steve Boylan, a former Petraeus spokesman, has told ABC News that Gen Petraeus' wife Holly was "not exactly pleased" by the revelation of the former CIA Director's affair.   Boylan interview http://bbc.in/SgedT6  Who are the women? http://bbc.in/SgedT2  Who is David Petraeus? http://bbc.in/SgedT8  John Simpson: A huge loss for US http://bbc.in/SgeghI  In Pictures: Petraeus' career http://bbc.in/SgeghC

Early next month, Led Zeppelin will be receiving the prestigious Kennedy Center Honor in Washington.  So we thought we'd send our own Kirsty Lang to have a fireside chat with their guitarist, Jimmy Page.  In the interview, which we'll air later this week, Jimmy reveals the music chat he plans to have with President Obama.  If you were in Jimmy's boots what music question would you ask the President?

Is world peace possible? Psychologist and cognitive scientist Steven Pinker tells BBC Future that it's possible - we may be predisposed to being violent but we are also predisposed to be peaceful. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121109-is-world-peace-possible

Israel's military says its tanks have scored 'direct hits' on Syrian artillery units after Syrian mortar shells landed near an Israeli army post.  It comes a day after Israel fired warning shots after it said a Syrian shell hit another of its army posts on the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.  The episode is the most serious between the two countries since the Arab-Israeli war of 1973.  Israel captured the Golan Heights from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.

Link Title: BBC INVESTIGATION - TIM DAVIE INTERVIEW - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: The Acting Director General of the BBC, Tim Davie, has vowed to 'get a grip' of the current crisis engulfing the corporation - and deal with it. (see the video clip below)    On Monday, two senior executives have stepped aside from their jobs in News following the resignation on Saturday of the former Director General George Entwistle.  The crisis developed after two separate reports on child sex abuse, one of which was shown on domestic television wrongly implicating a senior British political figure.  Take a look at the profiles of the key news executives at the BBC and all the background on the crisis here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20286888

Link Title: China warns Dalai Lama on Tibet
Message: China has criticised Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, over comments he reportedly made on a spate of self-immolations by ethnic Tibetans.  Speaking in Japan, the Dalai Lama was quoted saying China was not "seriously" looking at the causes of the protests and focusing on blaming him instead.  China's foreign ministry accused him of "glorifying" the self-immolations.  Nearly 70 Tibetans have set themselves alight since 2011 in what activists say are protests against Beijing's rule.

Syrian opposition groups have agreed to form a united front in their struggle against President Bashar al-Assad.  The new coalition has elected a leader, Moaz al-Khatib, is a moderate Islamist cleric who fled Syria earlier this year.   The new grouping is expected to establish an interim government and a military council to co-ordinate the armed struggle in Syria.

Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard has announced a national inquiry into how institutions have reacted to child sex abuse allegations.   She made the announcement after a senior policeman claimed that the Catholic Church in the Hunter Valley of New South Wales, destroyed evidence of abuse and conspired to disrupt police investigations.
Images of the heavy floods that have hit the Italian city of Venice, turning St Mark's Square into an outdoor swimming pool.

West African regional leaders agree to deploy more than 3,000 soldiers to Mali to retake the north from Islamist extremists.   At a summit of Ecowas, the group's chairman said it was ready to use force to "dismantle terrorist and transnational criminal networks".  The soldiers would be provided mainly by Nigeria, Niger and Burkina Faso.  Islamist groups and Tuareg rebels took control of the north after Mali's president was overthrown in March.

Bulgarian archaeologists have unearthed ancient golden artefacts during excavation works in the north of the country.   The findings include golden rings, female figurines and 100 gold buttons. They are thought to date back to the late 4th or early 3rd century BC.

Link Title: Analysis: Petraeus a huge loss for US
Message: The US has lost one of its most admired public servants, writes the BBC's John Simpson of General David Petraeus, who has left his role as head of the CIA after an extra-marital affair.

In 2004, in South Africa, a magic show arrived in one of Cape Town's townships Khayelitsha.   It was a day that Olawetu Dyantyi, then a 10-year-old boy, would never forget.   He went home and taught himself how to juggle using stones.   He progressed onto golf balls. And once he had mastered the art he took the hour long journey to Cape Town's College of Magic.   Focus on Africa's Nomsa Maseko went there to meet him

A strong earthquake has rocked central Burma, with at least 12 people feared dead and dozens more injured.    The 6.8-magnitude quake struck some 120km (70 miles) north of the second-largest city of Mandalay, at a depth of 10km, the US Geological Survey said.    Burma's local media say a bridge under construction collapsed in the town of Shwebo, closest to the epicentre.    In Mandalay, terrified residents dashed out of their homes for safety, fearing more tremors    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20285901

Israeli forces say they have fired warning shots into Syria after a mortar round fired from Syria exploded in the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.  It is the first time that Israel has fired on Syrian forces since the Middle East war of 1973.  The latest incident comes days after Israeli troops were put on high alert after a vehicle was hit by Syrian fire in the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.  The two countries are formally at war and a UN force patrols the buffer zone.

The BBC's director general, George Entwistle, resigns in the wake of Newsnight child abuse broadcast.  In a statement given outside New Broadcasting House, Mr Entwistle said: "I have decided that the honourable thing to do is to step down."  Earlier, Mr Entwistle said the Newsnight report, which wrongly implicated ex-senior Tory Lord McAlpine should never have been broadcast.  Mr Entwistle took up the post of director general on 17 September.

A global "day of action" for girls' education is under way, declared in the name of Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl shot by the Taliban last month.   She is now in the UK and is said to be doing well in hospital.   However, back in Pakistan, there are conspiracy theories and fears surrounding the attack.   Aleem Maqbool reports from Pakistan

Will humans one day all be cyborgs - enhancing our "feeble" brains with advanced technology that will give us access to all of human knowledge in an instant? Ray Kurzweil thinks so, he tells BBC Future why. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121108-will-men-and-machines-merge

"He looked straight at me, I don't think he smiled" http://bbc.in/RqerbY  Edgar Feuchtwanger, was a five year old Jewish boy growing up in an affluent Munich suburb when Hitler moved to his neighbourhood http://bbc.in/RqerbY   He speaks with Mike Lanchin from the BBC World Service about how his life changed on 9 November 1938, when the onslaught against German Jews began in earnest.
In the last two years, Seville’s architectural heritage has come under siege. BBC Travel takes at look at how the city is preserving more than 1,300 years of history. Have you been to Seville?
The Director of the US Central Intelligence Agency, David Petraeus, has admitted to an extramarital affair and submitted his resignation to US President Obama http://bbc.in/TQkw3A

We hope they don't forget the WiFi password http://bbc.in/RphTne  An astronaut on the International Space Station (ISS) has used the interplanetary internet  to send commands to a robot on Earth http://bbc.in/RphTne  The experimental technology could be a future way to communicate with astronauts on Mars.   Photo courtesy of Nasa http://bbc.in/RphTnc

Link Title: Ferran Adria: From kitchens to computers
Message: Ever since one of the world's top restaurants, El Bulli closed it's doors in July, many foodies have been wondering what would it's founder do next.   Well  Ferran Adria's latest project is an online culinary bible of modern cuisine, the "world's first culinary Wiki".   It will be better known as Bulli-Pedia.

Tens of thousands of people around the world have signed an online petition calling for the Pakistani schoolgirl shot in the head by the Taliban to be nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.  Malala's father said she was "humbled" by the support from around the world.  Doctors in the UK, where she is being treated, say she is making progress.  Malala, 15, is widely known as a campaigner for girls' education in Pakistan.

Thousands of people have marched through the streets of Argentina's capital, in one of the largest protests against the policies of President Fernandez.  Opposition activists used social networks to mobilise the march, which they said was one of the biggest anti-government protests in a decade.  Those gathered said they were angry at rising inflation, high levels of crime and high-profile corruption cases.  President Fernandez was re-elected by a landslide to a second term in 2011.

Link Title: SOUTH KOREA TOILET MUSEUM - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: It's something none of us can escape and now there's a museum devoted to it - the world's first toilet theme-park has opened in South Korea.  It's the world's first toilet theme park and it celebrates the history and art of  humanity's most ubiquitous activity. Lucy Williamson gives us a tour.

The opposition in Syria has been criticised for being ineffective and deeply divided.   They are meeting right now in Doha to try and rectify that in the hope that it will lead to billions of dollars of international support.  The biggest opposition bloc, the Syrian National Council, is holding talks on forming a single 60-member leadership group which would be recognised as the sole legitimate representative of the Syrian people.

AUDIO SLIDE SHOW:    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-20236912    The annual Palestinian olive harvest is an important cultural and economic event. Nearly half the agricultural land in the Palestinian territories is planted with eight million olive trees - and there are about 80,000 farmers, most of whom operate on a small-scale basis.    But many have difficulty accessing their olive groves, because they are located close to Jewish settlements or the barrier that Israel is building in and around the West Bank. Israeli soldiers are deployed in some areas during the harvests to try to prevent clashes with settlers.    Take a look at how olive harvesting in the West Bank is a real family affair - as the fruit is picked and turned into oil.

WATCH: The so-called 'First Lady of Formula 1', Sauber CEO Monisha Kaltenborn, is the latest guest on our interview show 'Mishal Husain Meets'.     See it at these times on BBC World News:    GMT:   Friday 2030,  Saturday 1130 & 1630   Sunday 2230.    Click on the link to see some highlights    http://vimeo.com/52849310

SPECIAL REPORT:   Many of you have been urging us to provide more reports on the continuing ethnic conflict in Burma between Buddhists and minority Muslim Rohingyas.  On IMPACT we'll have a special report (click on the attachment) from villages in Burma's Rakhine state which have been destroyed by violence in recent weeks.   What happened appears to go beyond simply ethnic clashes - evidence has emerged of security forces' complicity in the violence.  We want to hear from you.   Do you think there has been a lack of moral leadership from Burma's politicians and leaders?  Even Burma's opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi remains non-committed by saying that tolerance and the rule of law are crucial to ending the ethnic violence in Rakhine State.

HSBC's operating practices are coming under fire once again. According to a UK newspaper, the bank is investigating allegations of money laundering.   Tax authorities have reportedly obtained bank account details from branches in Jersey, where criminals are allegedly holding funds.  HSBC said that it is conducting an investigation but the bank has NOT been contacted by the British tax authorities at this time.

Jared Lee Loughner has been sentenced to life in prison without parole for the January 2011 shootings in Tucson, Arizona that killed six and critically injured US Representative Gabrielle Giffords http://bbc.in/Rm3Fnb   Ms Giffords, who was shot in the head, attended the hearing with her husband, Mark Kelly.

After more than 50 years of loyal service, the US Navy tells BBC Future it is ready to replace its pods of highly trained sea mammals with cheaper robots. So what will become of its mine-clearing dolphins? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121108-final-dive-for-us-navy-dolphins

Astronomers have spotted another candidate for a potentially habitable planet - and it is not too far away.  The star HD 40307 was known to host three planets, all of them too near to support liquid water.  But research has found three more - among them a "super-Earth" seven times our planet's mass, in the habitable zone where liquid water can exist.  Many more observations will be needed to confirm any other similarities.

Guatemalan rescuers are searching wrecked buildings for survivors of Wednesday's earthquake, which devastated some towns on the Pacific coast.    The 7.4-magnitude tremor, the most powerful to hit Guatemala since 1976, left at least 48 people dead, many more injured and thousands without power.    Dozens of homes were destroyed in the worst affected region of San Marcos, near the border with Mexico.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20256454

Prime Minister David Cameron is trialling a specially-designed mobile app that displays live data about day-to-day government affairs to aid decision-making.   The app will also let him know what Brits think of him and his government.

At least four people set themselves on fire in ethnic Tibetan parts of China on Wednesday, a rights group and media reports say.  Three teenage monks set themselves alight in Aba county in Sichuan province, where many self-immolations have taken place in recent months.  One of the boys died and the other two were taken to hospital.  Later the same day a 23-year-old woman died after setting herself on fire in Qinghai province.  More than 60 Tibetans have set themselves on fire since early 2011, in what rights group say are acts of protest against Beijing's rule.

In Britain, The Bishop of Durham, Justin Welby, has been chosen as the next spiritual leader of the Anglican church.  A former oil executive, the Bishop is known for his opposition to gay marriage and his support for women clergy.  Bishop Welby became a bishop only a year ago when he took up the Church of England's fourth most senior post.

The Red Cross says it's struggling to cope with the aid crisis in Syria.   The head of the international aid agency said the humanitarian situation in the country is getting worse despite the scope of the operation increasing, with an unknown number of people not getting the aid they need.

It's all change in China - the process of a once-in-a-decade power transfer in the world's most populous country has begun - the Congress of the governing communist party has started.  So what's going to happen over the next week?   We'll have full coverage, graphics and in depth analysis as China prepares fora new generation of leaders. Click on the link below for much more.

Thirty-nine people have been killed and many more are missing after a 7.4-magnitude quake hit off the Guatemala's Pacific coast, the president has said. Otto Perez Molina declared a national alert and advised people to evacuate tall buildings as a precaution http://bbc.in/RjktuU  Officials said landslides had buried roads and it would take 24 hours to restore links to the quake-hit area.

Now that the US has chosen a leader for the next four years - will the world's attention turn to China's Communist Party congress? http://bbc.in/TLAX16  Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll look at the event that will see a new set of leaders unveiled and wrap up our coverage of the US presidential race http://bbc.in/TLAZ9a   Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.   Be sure to follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/TLAZ96 for the latest from our correspondents and producers working in North America.

Do you still have questions about last night's US presidential race? http://bbc.in/Ri63eJ  BBC Washington Correspondent Katty Kay will be answering some of them via her Twitter account @KattyKayBBC from 20:00 GMT till 21:00 GMT (15:00 EST till 16:00 EST).  You can leave questions for Katty by posting a comment below this post.  Or tweet your question using the hashtag #AskKattyBBC

A Kenyan woman, who gave birth to twins on the day Barack Obama was re-elected, has named them after the President and his Republican rival Mitt Romney. Twenty year old Millicent Owuor delivered the twins at a hospital in Western Kenya, near Mr Obama's ancestral home village of Kogelo, where celebrations have been continuing. She posed for photographers holding her two new-borns.

Would you travel on an electric plane, asks BBC Future? Check out some of the radical ideas that designers are putting forward for the future of air travel: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121106-radical-planes-take-shape

Bahrain's government revokes the citizenship of 31 opposition activists, including two former members of parliament, for "undermining state security".  Those affected include Jawad and Jalal Fairuz, former MPs for the leading Shia movement, al-Wifaq, and Ali Mushaimaa, son of al-Haq's imprisoned leader.  Last week, the government banned all public gatherings and rallies.
PHOTOS: Previously unseen photographs form the basis of a new exhibition at Somerset House in London featuring the work of French photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson.

Within 15 years, experts predict that we will have small devices capable of recording our entire life experience as a continuous video feed - a life log that we can reference when our own memory fails.   But should we fear rather than embrace some medical advances?   Experts outline the challenge posed by the rapidly developing medical field of human enhancement.

A multi-storey department store collapses in Ghana's capital, Accra, with many people believed to be trapped in the rubble.   Rescue efforts are under way, with reports that least three people have been killed.  The BBC's Sammy Darko, who is at the scene of the Melcom store collapse, says he has seen one person rescued.  Ghana's President John Dramani Mahama said he has suspended his electoral campaign for next month's poll.
BBC Chinese's Weiliang Nie explains about the Chinese Party Congress meeting, and the man widely expected to become the country's new leader.

President Francois Hollande's cabinet is to consider a bill giving gay couples in France the right to get married and adopt children.  France already allows civil unions between same-sex couples, but it was a campaign pledge of President Francois Hollande to extend their rights.  He is now facing tough opposition to the idea.  This is one the most divisive issues he has encountered since he was elected in May.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20224677

What does it take to deliver the US presidential race to the world? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20233064  Here is a behind-the-scenes look at election night in the BBC Washington Bureau.   Thank you for joining us online, on TV, on the radio and on social media.   Obama defeats Romney to win re-election http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20233064  In pictures: US elects a president http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20230194  Crowd 'go wild' at Obama victory rally http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20231024  Romney admits defeat and congratulates Obama http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20234161
BREAKING NEWS: US President Barack Obama officially wins re-election http://bbc.in/TJCYLp

We're bringing you the election results live from the BBC newsroom in Washington DC. While our correspondents are out in the field, our team in the bureau is non-stop reporting, fact-checking, broadcasting, bringing you all the developments live throughout election night.   http://bbc.in/STW2Eh

The polls are starting to close in the eastern US and we have our first results of the evening - Indiana and Kentucky go for Romney, Vermont goes for Obama.   The first swing state to close their polls is Virginia. Follow along on our live page for up to the minute results from across the US  http://bbc.in/Rf786T  US election: Stage set for Obama - win or lose http://bbc.in/Rf75Ih

As US voters take to the polls - crews are getting the stages ready in Boston and Chicago http://bbc.in/RevQ7y  Are you in the US today? Tell us about your voting experience in the comments section below.   Follow all of the action from across the US on our live page http://bbc.in/RevNIM  Why can't they vote by mobile or email? http://bbc.in/RevQ7A  Romney casts his vote http://bbc.in/RevQnS  Obama thanks American people http://bbc.in/RevQnO  In pictures: The US votes http://bbc.in/RevNso  Join the #election2012 conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/RevNsm

Link Title: Two million hit by Nigeria floods
Message: More than two million Nigerians have been forced from their homes by this year's floods, which have left 363 people dead, officials say.  The worst floods in five decades have affected many areas of the country - especially near the River Niger.  The BBC's Will Ross in Lagos says waters are now receding but there are fears over food supplies as some farmers saw all their crops destroyed.

Do you recognize these two young baseball players?     You're looking at a young Obama in Hawaii and a six year old Mitt in Detroit.    For more click on the link below as we take a look at Obama and Romney through the years.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20075984

Link Title: UN to send emergency aid to Cuba
Message: The UN's World Food Programme is to send emergency food supplies to Cuba and also appeals for funds to help Haiti in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.    It was "the worst catastrophe in 50 years in Santiago de Cuba," WFP spokeswoman Elisabeth Byrs said.  The WFP is also appealing for $20m to help some 425,000 Haitians affected by the storm.  Sandy caused widespread damage to infrastructure, crops and livestock in both Haiti and Cuba.

British Prime Minister David Cameron says he would back offering President Bashar al-Assad safe passage out of Syria if it ended the bloodshed there.  Mr Cameron said the international community should consider anything "to get that man out of the country".  He also told al-Arabiya TV he would favour Mr Assad "facing the full force of international law and justice".  Amnesty International criticised Mr Cameron for "talking about immunity deals for President Assad".

VIDEO: Recent protests across cities on the West Bank against rising fuel and food prices have sometimes turned violent.  Many people blame obstacles put in place by the Israeli authorities.  Despite the problems some Palestinians are trying to do more to boost their own economy, and create more jobs.

The first banknotes featuring the face of anti-apartheid icon Nelson Mandela go into circulation in South Africa.  They are the first South African notes to bear the image of a black person - they replace notes with wild animals and rural and industrial scenes.  President Jacob Zuma says the banknotes were a "humble gesture" to express South Africa's "deep gratitude".  Mr Mandela, 94, is one of the world's best loved figures after spending 27 years in prison for fighting apartheid.

As polls open in the US Presidential Elections hundreds of millions of Americans will vote today for their next leader.    You can follow all the latest developments with tweets and videos from our reporters in various battlegrounds across the country by going to our Live Page (just click the link below).    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20009190

South African police have been accused of planting weapons near the bodies of workers killed during strikes at the Marikana platinum mine.  Photographs taken by police suggested large knives had been placed near the bodies after they had been shot, a lawyer told an inquest into the deaths.  Thirty-four miners died when police opened fire at striking miners in August, leading to widespread shock.  The police say they were acting in self-defence.

Link Title: Beijing ramps up security ahead of Party congress
Message: With China's once-in-a-decade leadership change happening in Beijing, the BBC's Beijing bureau reports on how security is tight in the capital.

Could these be the votes that decide the race for the White House? http://bbc.in/TGR2Fo  The BBC's Rajesh Mirchandani got a peek at some of the early ballots ready for counting in El Paso County, Colorado.   Follow all of the action from the last day of the 2012 presidential race on our live page http://bbc.in/TGR148  In pictures: Final day http://bbc.in/TGR2VG  Obama makes final push http://bbc.in/TGR146  Romney supporters 'hopeful' of victory http://bbc.in/TGR0NO  The race reaches a Welsh corner of Ohio http://bbc.in/TGR2Fs

While most of the nation is preparing to go to the polls, the US presidential race is being overshadowed in much of New York and New Jersey by the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy http://bbc.in/TGyvsG    Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll look at the clean up and at the campaigns http://bbc.in/TGyvsE    Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area.     Be sure to follow us @BBCNewsUS tomorrow for live tweeting coverage of the 2012 race for the White House http://bbc.in/TGyvsC

One day to go!  http://bbc.in/TGb7eO The BBC's Washington newsroom is almost ready - are you?   Follow all of the action on our live page as Obama and Romney travel the US on the last day of campaigning http://bbc.in/TGb7eU  The meal is now served - the last day of our 2012 election 'Daily Diet' http://bbc.in/TGb7eS  Is this a battle for America's soul? http://bbc.in/TGb8Q1  The final day: In pictures http://bbc.in/TGb8PZ  Jonny Dymond on the trail with Mitt Romney http://bbc.in/TGb8Q3

Link Title: SERBIA - THE SECOND MEETING - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: A remarkable friendship between the pilot of a US Stealth Fighter and the air defence commander who shot him down is being celebrated in Serbia.   Dale Zelko has been in the country for premieres of The Second Meeting .   That is a  documentary about his relationship with the commander Zoltan Dani.   The two men hope their story and new comradeship will promote peace and tolerance.

Can the 'American Dream' be reversed in India?    America's Silicon Valley has always been a hub for some of the brightest and best Indian immigrants to start businesses. Now, in a reversal, more people from the US are moving to the sub-continent with their ideas.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-20201666

A couple arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of killing their 15-year-old daughter using acid say they carried out the attack because she looked at a boy.   The girl's father told the BBC that they feared she would bring dishonour on their family. Her mother said it was her "destiny" to die that way.  The couple were arrested in Pakistani-administered Kashmir last week.  The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan reported 943 women were killed in honour killings last year.  That represented an increase of more than 100 from 2010.

An international training institute to teach online tactics for human rights campaigners is being set up in the Italian city of Florence.    The first students, starting in the new year, will be drawn from human rights activists around the world - with the aim of arming them with the latest tools for digital dissent.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20085559

Laos gives the go-ahead to build a massive dam on the lower Mekong river, despite opposition from neighbouring countries and environmentalists.  A formal ceremony marking the start of full construction at Xayaburi would be held on Wednesday, the government said.  Countries downstream from the $3.5bn dam fear it will affect fish stocks and the livelihoods of millions.

We wanted to remind everyone that you can follow  the US presidential elections as well as the rest of the global news agenda in any of BBC’s 27 languages.    To do so simply click on the link below.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/languages/index.shtml

Hello everyone, it's Mishal.   On Impact today, special coverage of two very different leadership processes - the US election and the Communist Party's transition to new leaders in China.   Have a look at our analysis of China's influence below - but which outcome do you think matters more?

A gas blast at a mine in New Zealand that killed 29 workers was preventable, an investigation has found, with multiple warnings ignored.  Health and safety systems at the Pike River mine were inadequate, and reports of excessive methane levels were "not heeded".  A drive for production "before the mine was ready" created the circumstances for the tragedy, the report found.  The mining disaster in 2010 was New Zealand's worst in almost a century.
What does it mean to be an American? http://bbc.in/U9LPbe  With the presidential race only hours away - we take a look at the demographics that define the US.

The 2012 US presidential race is almost over - and as we get ready for the final stretch http://bbc.in/Urkhsk we invite you to take a look back at five moments from US elections past that we have pulled out of the BBC vaults http://bbc.in/Urkhsi  Tell us what you think of the issues, the presenters and characters.

Link Title: World Have Your Say live from Boston
Message: TAKE A LOOK: At 0010GMT/2010EDT World Have Your Say will be live from the Old South Meeting House in Boston where we'll be joined by an audience of 400 people asking is America working and looking ahead to the US presidential election on Tuesday. If you have a question or comment post it here. Don't forget to let us know where you are.

Where does all of the US campaign money come from? And where does it all go? http://bbc.in/RwBV0g  The US presidential campaign will be the most expensive in history – an estimated $2.5bn (£1.5) when it’s all said and done.  We’ve put together a three-minute explainer which tells you all you need to know http://bbc.in/RwBV0g

Fuel shortages and difficulties in restoring power are hampering efforts to restore normality to parts of the US north-east in the wake of Storm Sandy http://bbc.in/YxpxPh  Fights broke out at petrol stations in New York and New Jersey, and power suppliers warned some areas might not have electricity until 11 November http://bbc.in/YxpuTP  Anger is also rising in New York's Staten Island, with some residents saying they had been forgotten http://bbc.in/YxpwuO

Link Title: New York City Marathon goes ahead
Message: The New York City Marathon will go ahead as planned this weekend, despite the damage caused by Superstorm Sandy. Do you think it should be going ahead? Are you running? What is your cause? Let us know and send your pictures or videos of you and New York to yourpics@bbc.co.uk or text them to 61124 (UK) or +44 7624 800 100 (international)

Coming up on Impact with Karin Giannone. Better than expected jobs figures in the United States - just four days ahead of the election. How do the numbers change the campaign? We're live in the key battleground of Cleveland, Ohio to find out. Plus, increased tension on the Japanese island of Okinawa as a US airman is accused of assaulting a young boy. Join Karin at 1300 GMT.

WATCH: A new series of 'Mishal Husain Meets' makes its debut today, with the lineup of Asian personalities beginning with Chinese actress and Jackie Chan favourite Zhang Jingchu. Mishal's guests will also include Sauber Formula 1 boss Monisha Kaltenborn, TV celebrity Chef Wan, entrepreneur Sandiaga Uno, pop diva Anggun and India's breakthrough Olympic gold medallist Abhinav Bindra. Catch it on air at these times GMT: Friday 13.30 & 23.30, Saturday 11.30, Sunday 17.30 and 22.30

A petition seeking to recognise the 1984 anti-Sikh violence in India as "genocide" is tabled in the Australian parliament.  The petition was moved by MP Warren Enstch on Thursday.  As long as the violence "continues to be referred to as 'anti-Sikh riots' there can be no closure for the Sikh community", he said in the petition.  Nearly 3,000 Sikhs were killed after the assassination of then PM Indira Gandhi by her two Sikh bodyguards.

Will the Latino vote decide the US presidential race? http://bbc.in/SfCwRq  There are more than 50 million Latinos in the US - making them the nation's largest minority group - and both parties are working hard to win them over.   We take a closer a look at the numbers behind the growing power and influence of the Latino vote.

Link Title: SANDY - JACOB'S STORY - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: 70 people have lost their lives since Superstorm Sandy hit the USA's eastern coast.   One of those was a young New Yorker, Jacob Vogelman.   The BBC's Matthew Danzico went to meet his mother, who was at her home, with her surviving sons.

Plans to exclude tourists from special cafés in Amsterdam where people can smoke cannabis have been dropped.   The city's local authority had planned to give locals a pass to allow them in while keeping foreigners out.    The city's mayor said the proposal would have lead to a rise in crime.  Was this decision inevitable in the current economic climate?

The latest in this week's series of special reports from around China, exploring the many challenges that its next generation of leaders will have to address.   Tackling the growing gap between rich and poor is one of the most urgent tasks facing the country's new leaders.  Damian Grammaticas reports from one of China's most impoverished provinces.

Link Title: World Have Your Say: The US Election Debate
Message: What would you like to ask US voters?  On Friday at 8.10pm EDT (Saturday 0010GMT), World Have Your Say will be live from Boston with an audience of Americans to debate the issues of the Presidential election – and you can take part.   Click the link to record your question on video and we can put it directly to our audience.   Some of the things we know people want to talk about include China, Iran, Israel, Syria, Libya, the US & democracy, how America’s economy affects you, the death of Osama bin Laden. Whatever you want to raise, upload your video now.   You can also email videos to whysvideo@bbc.co.uk  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-radio-and-tv-17928844

Hi, I'll be presenting Impact today at 13gmt.     We're going to be discussing the pitfalls of believing everything you see on social media - after recent hoax tweets and spoof pictures during #Sandy like the one below.     We'd love to hear your thoughts about the good and the bad side of social media. Thanks  Karin

Argentina's Congress has approved a law to lower the voting age to 16, in a move that will take effect for key mid-term elections next year.  President Cristina Fernandez has courted the youth vote and critics say the change is designed to boost her party's chances in the 2013 polls.  Voting is obligatory in Argentina for people aged 18 to 70, but will be optional for those aged 16 and 17.   Is this a about widening of political participation or a strategic move prior top next years elections?  Should someone aged between 16 and 17 be allowed to vote?

Nigeria's army has fuelled unrest by committing widespread abuses in its campaign against Islamist group Boko Haram, Amnesty International says.  The rights group says in a report that abuses include extrajudicial killings, enforced disappearance and torture.  A spokesman from the Nigerian army rejected the accusations, saying soldiers always operate within the law.  Boko Haram campaigns for an Islamic state and has been blamed for the deaths of hundreds of people this year.

Rescue operations are on in India's southern city of Chennai to find five missing sailors on board an oil tanker that ran aground following a cyclone.   Coast guard helicopters and boats are combing the sea for sailors from the Pratibha Cauvery.  One of the crew members drowned after a boat carrying him and others capsized near Chennai, in Tamil Nadu state.  Seven people were killed when Cyclone Nilam struck the south-eastern coast with winds of up to 100km/h (60mph).  More than 100,000 people have been evacuated.

Link Title: Drive through New York City after Hurricane Sandy
Message: BBC Video Journalist Matt Danzico took a drive around a quiet Manhattan the day after Hurricane Sandy. He brought a camera along for the ride.   New York devastation mapped http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20131303  Sandy map overview http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20154479  Sandy: New Jersey devastation before and after http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20154472  In Pictures: The recovery http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20150725

New York continues to clean up after Hurricane Sandy - gridlocked streets have made navigating the city difficult today http://bbc.in/PmEAd7  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at storm damage in New York and New Jersey http://bbc.in/PmEClw  Check your local listings to find BBC World News America in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/PmEClu

Why are some US voters being asked to show photo identification and proof of citizenship for the first time? http://bbc.in/RswrQU  Will you be able to register on election day?   The BBC's Franz Strasser takes a look at the numbers behind voting registration in the US and who is most likely to be impacted by the new stricter rules.

Archaeologists in Bulgaria say that have uncovered the oldest prehistoric town found to date in Europe.  The walled fortified settlement, near the modern town of Provadia, is thought to have been an important centre for salt production.  Archaeologists believe that the town was home to some 350 people and dates back to between 4700 and 4200 BC.  That is about 1,500 years before the start of ancient Greek civilisation.

About 120 people - many of them Rohingya Muslims from Burma - are missing after their boat capsized in the Bay of Bengal, Bangladeshi police say.  More than 20,000 Muslims have been displaced by fighting which erupted in Rakhine state 10 days ago.  At least 80 people have died in the violence and thousands of homes have been burnt down.  Clashes in Rakhine in western Burma earlier this year uprooted more than 70,000 Rohingya.

The south-eastern coast of India has been hit by Cyclone Nilam, with wind speeds reaching 100km/h.  Nearly 4,000 people have been evacuated to escape the storm which is buffeting the city of Chennai. Several trees have been uprooted, but so far there have been no injuries.  At least 4,000 people in displacement camps in nearby Sri Lanka have been affected by flooding.  As it heads west, Cyclone Nilam is now hitting the Indian states of Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh, and the town of Pondicherry.

The latest in this week's series of special reports from around China, exploring the diverse challenges that its next generation of leaders will have to address.   Maintaining the prosperity that many Chinese have experienced will be a key challenge and nowhere is the boom more in evidence than Shanghai - but our correspondent John Sudworth has also been exploring the resentment its wealth can cause.

Nasa's Curiosity rover has found soil on Mars to be similar to Hawaii's after sifting and scanning its first sample on the Red Planet.     The robot's CheMin instrument shook out fine particles of soil and fired X-rays at them to determine their composition.    These sandy samples should give clues about Mars' recent geological history.    As had been theorised, much of the sample is made of weathered "basaltic" materials of volcanic origin, like that seen on the islands of Hawaii.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20151789

Are you or have you been affected by storm Sandy?     What is the situation in your area?     Are you expecting the storm to head your way? How are you preparing?     BBC World News would like to invite you to send us your video diaries of your experiences.     Show us how your lives have been affected. Please begin the video with your name and your location.    To upload your video diaries please use the following    http://upload.news.bbc.cs.streamuk.com/

Bananas could replace staples such as maize and rice in parts of the world affected by climate change.   A report commissioned by the UN committee on Food Security predicts that production of foods, such as maize, rice and even potatoes, will decrease in many developing countries.   It says bananas might make a suitable replacement.

Link Title: Disney buys firm behind Star Wars
Message: Hello everyone, it's Mishal. In my house, the prospect of new Star Wars movies has generated much excitement.   What do you think?  Could the Jedis end up as a James Bond style franchise or is it best to leave the films to age gracefully?   Send us your thoughts for Impact's live discussion with film critic Jason Solomons

Opium growing has increased in Burma - the world's second largest grower - for a sixth year running, a United Nations report says.   The UN Office on Drugs and Crime said land used for opium had risen by 17% this year, from nearly 40,000 hectares to 51,000 hectares.  Burma is the second largest opium grower in the world after Afghanistan.

The clean up continues in New York http://bbc.in/TUvirs  Tonight on BBC World News America we'll look at Sandy's path of destruction, where the storm is heading next and how it could impact the race for the White House http://bbc.in/TUvhno  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/TUvhni  Photo courtesy of Rondell Meeks in Brooklyn, New York

What would you do if you were the US president? http://bbc.in/T1VX1a  That's the question posed by Lori Korchek and Mike Bade to thousands of citizens across the US who have taken a seat behind their travelling desk http://bbc.in/T1VX1a  Photo Courtesy of America for President

The back-up generator at New York University's Langone Medical Center failed last night during Hurricane Sandy - patients had to be carried down as many as 15 flights of stairs to ambulances waiting outside so they could be taken to other hospitals in the city http://bbc.in/T1C0HK  The BBC spoke to hospital staff involved in the evacuation.

Would anyone really eat this cake? It is from BBC Future's gallery of the best science and technology photographs from the last month - including Felix Baumgartner, images (real and fake) from Hurricane Sandy, and this gruesome cake being sold in a museum during the Halloween period. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121030-octobers-best-images

Fabrice Muamba has inspired many people across the world ever since he made an amazing recovery from suffering a heart attack during a game against Tottenham in March 2012.    Well 7 months on and Fabrice has since gotten married and has an autobiography on the way.    We are delighted to announce that Fabrice will be joining Dan Walker on Football Focus.     You’ll be able to see it on BBC World TV at 2030GMT on Friday 2nd of November and on Saturday the 3rd at 0810 GMT.    If you would like to ask Fabrice a question make sure you send it by 1430GMT on Friday 2nd of November and will try to get him to answer as many as possible. You can also tweet @mrdanwalker.

As the clean up begins - our live page coverage of Hurricane Sandy continues http://bbc.in/T0V0pI  This photo from the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey http://bbc.in/T0V09k shows flood waters rushing in to the Hoboken, New Jersey PATH train station through an elevator shaft.  Mapping the devastation in New York City http://bbc.in/T0UYy4   Your Hurricane Sandy stories http://bbc.in/T0V09o  US markets to remain closed http://bbc.in/T0UYy0  NYC's power surge explosions http://bbc.in/T0V0pE  The morning after http://bbc.in/T0V09m  Early estimates are saying Sandy will cause $10bn to $20bn (£6bn-£12bn) in damages. How did they get that number? http://bbc.in/T0V0pC

Link Title: EHUD BARAK INTERVIEW - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: INTERIVEW:   The Israeli Defence Minister, Ehud Barak, is in London for talks with British senior defence officials and Foreign Secretary William Hague.   He joined George Alagiah on GMT programme to talk about the Middle East crisis and Iran's nuclear ambitions.

Bahrain's interior ministry has announced a ban on all protests and gatherings amid escalating clashes between police and anti-government demonstrators.  Interior Minister Sheikh Rashid Al Khalifah said "repeated abuse" of the rights to freedom of speech and expression could no longer be accepted.  Protests would be permitted only once security and stability were sufficient to maintain national unity, he added.  Demonstrations were last banned during the three-month state of emergency King Hamad declared in March 2011.

The east coast of the United States is waking up today to the reality of Superstorm Sandy which has caused a trail of devastation.     Sandy had already led to the loss of 60 lives in the Caribbean before it moved north into the United States - its ended up being one of the worst storms ever to hit the US.    Here's what the storm would look like if its centre were over western Europe.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20123703

Have a look at the image below - one of those causing outrage in China after scandals involving violence by teachers in schools.     In another case, a boy was picked up by his ears.     Is it time to act decisively on corporal punishment in schools? Mishal

A popular Somali poet and songwriter, who was critical of Islamist fighters and wrote songs urging people to join the police, has been killed in Mogadishu.  He was shot by unknown gunmen near his home on Monday evening.  Mr Awale wrote and acted in radio plays critical of the militant group, al-Shabab, who he accused of misleading people in the name of Islam.  The National Union of Somali Journalists says he had received death threats because of his work and songs calling for people to join the police.

The Swiss bank UBS is cutting 10,000 job worldwide as it slims down its investment banking activities.  The jobs will go over the next three years, and amount to 16% of its current workforce of 64,000.  UBS lost 39bn Swiss francs $42bn during the financial crisis and had to be bailed out by the Swiss authorities.  UBS chief executive Sergio Ermotti said: "This decision has been a difficult one, particularly in a business such as ours that is all about its people.

Tonight on BBC World News America, we are watching Sandy http://bbc.in/TQI1vf - Laura Trevelyan reports from New York http://bbc.in/TQI0aE - Katty Kay speaks with DC's mayor http://bbc.in/TQI1vb - What does the storm mean for Obama & Romney? http://bbc.in/TQI0aA  Follow our live page for the latest information http://bbc.in/TQI1vf  And follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/TQI1eX

An Iranian naval task force has docked in Sudan, carrying with it a "message of peace and security to neighbouring countries", Iranian state media report http://bbc.in/TQqPpM  The vessels, which include a corvette and freighter, set sail from Iran last month, the Irna news agency said. Their arrival comes six days after explosions destroyed an arms factory in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum.

The first-ever commuter train service in Tanzania's commercial capital, Dar es Salaam, is launched to ease congestion on roads.     The trains will run on two routes, mostly during peak hour.    It is the first phase of a government scheme to improve the transport network in Dar es Salaam.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20122900

We asked to see your photos as Hurricane Sandy comes to shore on the East coast of the United States http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20121729 Here is a small sample of what you are seeing out there http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20121435 Are you in Sandy's path? Share your story in the comments section below and be sure to follow our online live page http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20121635

Link Title: Egypt's Copts to vote for Pope
Message: A council of Coptic Christians in Egypt is set to vote for a successor to Pope Shenouda III, who died in March.  Two bishops and three monks are short-listed to become the 118th head of the region's largest Christian minority.  The individual chosen will become the new Coptic Pope who will be enthroned in a ceremony on 18 November.

Two of the world's six major publishers have agreed to merge, in the face of the growing challenge of digital books.     The UK publisher Pearson will combine its Penguin book publishing business with German owned Random House.     The new venture, to be called Penguin Random House, would corner an estimated quarter of the market for English language book sales.     When the deal completes next year, Pearson will have a 47% stake and Bertelsmann, the owner of Random House, will own the rest.    Will this deal help bolster their negotiating strength with companies like Amazon?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20120485

How do you build the world's fastest supercomputer? Check out BBC Future's exclusive, behind the scenes look at Titan - a machine capable of 20 quadrillion calculations every second, and which has been unveiled today: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121026-a-supercomputing-titan

VIDEO:  Next week, China's ruling Communist Party will begin its once in a decade leadership change.   The most populous country on earth has seen great changes since the current leaders were appointed ten years ago.   To find out just how great the BBC is taking a trip across China and our correspondent Martin Patience is starting at the Great Wall.

International observers say Ukraine's election was a backward step for democracy, marred by "the abuse of power and the excessive role of money".  The statement from the regional security body OSCE came as early results pointed to a win for President Viktor Yanukovych's Party of Regions.  A major opposition leader, Yulia Tymoshenko, remains in jail.

Hello - we have a special live page today where you can track the latest on Hurricane Sandy, which is affecting travel far beyond the east coast of the US.     If you're affected, let us know how. Mishal & the Impact team    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20121635

A Greek journalist has been arrested after publishing a list of about 2,000 Greeks who hold accounts with the HSBC bank in Switzerland.  Kostas Vaxevanis has been charged with breach of privacy.  Mr Vaxevanis says the list he published is the same one that was given by the then French finance minister Christine Lagarde to her Greek counterpart.  Some of those named, said to include many prominent Greeks, are suspected of using the accounts for tax evasion.

A space capsule has returned to Earth, ending the first commercially contracted re-supply mission to the International Space Station (ISS).    The capsule was sent by the California-based company SpaceX, the first of 12 missions it will perform for US space agency Nasa.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20118963
The US East coast braces for the arrival of Hurricane Sandy http://bbc.in/TNWR5J  New York City transit suspended http://bbc.in/TNWTdU  What does Sandy mean for Obama & Romney? http://bbc.in/TNWTdQ
A 7.7 magnitude earthquake has rocked islands off Canada's western coastline, being widely felt in parts of British Columbia, but prompting no immediate reports of damage http://bbc.in/SN4DbD

The eastern seaboard of the US is preparing for the arrival of Hurricane Sandy http://bbc.in/THDhbs  Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll look at the path of the deadly storm and other news from around the world, including:  - Berlusconi sentenced for tax fraud http://bbc.in/THDj2S - The end of Syria's truce? http://bbc.in/THDk6Q - An update from the Romney campaign http://bbc.in/THDj2Z - A look at the cartoonists that take on the candidates http://bbc.in/THDj2V  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/THDhbo

Big bird, big hair and larger than life personalities http://bbc.in/THqCVM  Every US presidential race has generated a wealth of commentary, criticisms and caricatures - and 2012 is no exception.  Meet two of the cartoonists that are translating soundbites and stump speeches into the drawings that get everyone else talking http://bbc.in/THqCVM

Russian leftwing opposition leader Sergei Udaltsov has been charged with plotting mass disorder, and faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted.  Mr Udaltsov says he has not committed a crime and says the accusations against him, first aired in a documentary on Russia's NTV channel, are politically motivated.  Activists say the charges are an attempt by Putin to suppress dissent. What do you think?

Why have Apple's gadgets become so popular, asks BBC Future? Is it all part of a shift in technology that has gradually moved away from an emphasis on utility to today’s holy trinity of look, feel and lifestyle? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121026-apples-fashionable-seduction
This week BBC Travel visited Russia, where the hotel scene is getting a makeover and new air routes are opening up across the country in advance of the 2014 Winter Olympics and Grand Prix.

Link Title: Who, what, why: What's it like to be imprisoned in the Vatican?
Message: What's it like to be imprisoned in the Vatican?  Paolo Gabriele, Pope Benedict's former butler, begins an 18-month prison sentence today inside the Vatican walls, after being found guilty by a Vatican City court of stealing sensitive documents from the Pope's desk.   The BBC's David Willey looks at what life will be like for the only prisoner inside the world's smallest sovereign state.
A court in Milan has convicted the former Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, of tax evasion and sentenced him to four years in jail. Mr Berlusconi is expected to appeal the verdict.

A temporary ceasefire has come into effect in Syria between the army and rebel fighters, but there are already reports of violations in several areas.   The unmonitored four-day truce is intended to last throughout the Muslim festival of Eid, and give humanitarian workers an opportunity to help those in need.  Despite reports of clashes in some areas, correspondents say that violence in other parts has fallen - for now.  So will the truce hold?

How does language change and evolve? For several decades linguists have puzzled over this question, but now they have a powerful new tool in their hands: Twitter. A new study shows how you can track language changes over time in a remarkably simple way - see how slang expressions and emoticons like "bruh" and -__-" spread through tweets. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121025-language-lessons-from-twitter

Link Title: US paper blocked over Wen Jiabao
Message: The New York Times says its website has been blocked in China after the newspaper published a report saying Premier Wen Jiabao's relatives have accumulated billions of dollars.   China has condemned the report as a "smear".   Bloomberg's website is still being blocked after a similar expose of the family wealth of the man tipped to be China's next leader, Xi Jinping, in June.   So how potentially damaging is this report for Mr Wen and the ruling party?

One of the oldest Mayan tombs ever found is uncovered in western Guatemala - along with a necklace depicting a vulture-headed human figure, say experts.  Located at a temple site in Retalhuleu province, the grave is thought to be that of an ancient ruler or religious leader who lived some 2,000 years ago.  Carbon-dating indicated the tomb had been built between 700 and 400 BC, said government archaeologist Miguel Orrego.  A rich array of jade jewels, including a necklace depicting a vulture-headed human figure, were found.

US President Obama is set to cast his vote soon in his hometown of Chicago, Illinois http://bbc.in/TE2wLL  Mr Obama will be the first US president to vote early and he is not alone - 6.5 million Americans have already voted, nearly two weeks before election day http://bbc.in/TE2zqU  Can early voting change the outcome of the race?  Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll take a look at early voting and other news from around the globe, including:  - Syria's ceasefire http://bbc.in/TE2zHa - Hurricane Sandy strikes Jamaica and Cuba - the Bahamas bracing for hit http://bbc.in/TE2zqW - MPs warn that Afghanistan may never be 'viable state' http://bbc.in/TE2wLH  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/TE2zqR

At least 56 people have been killed and hundreds of homes torched since Sunday as clashes spread in Burma's Rakhine state   Several were killed overnight as violence erupted despite a night-time curfew in at least two towns.  The latest clashes are the first serious outburst of violence since June when a state of emergency was declared in Rakhine after 90 people were killed.  But tensions remained high between ethnic Rakhine Buddhists and Muslims.

With less than two weeks to go until the US presidential elections, our BBC Washington correspondent Katty Kay is holding a live Twitter Q&A at 19:00 GMT (15:00 EST).    You can send in your questions or take part in the discussion by using the Twitter hashtag #AskKattyBBC or tweeting @KattyKayBBC.    You can also send us questions via the BBC News account on Google+ or by using the BBC website page below.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20047835

Link Title: SA agrees gold miners pay deal
Message: South African unions and gold-mining companies have agreed a deal aimed at bringing thousands of striking employees back to work.  The strikes have slashed production and cost the industry millions of dollars.  Will this deal finally bring an end to a long-running bitter dispute?

One of India's most popular comedians Jaspal Bhatti has died in a road crash in Jalandhar city in Punjab state.  The comedian was hugely popular in the 1980s and 1990s when he did hit television shows like the Flop Show and Ulta Pulta (Upside Down).  We'd like to hear from you, what are your memories of him? Why was he so popular?   We'll use some of your comments on The Hub with Nik Gowing at 1600GMT

Link Title: The end for keyboard and mice?
Message: Apple's iPhone and its rivals may have introduced touchscreens to the masses, but now a raft of technologies promise to change the way we interact with computers forever. So, is the keyboard and mouse on its way out? BBC Future looks at ideas at the bleeding edge of human-computer interaction. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121023-the-end-for-keyboard-and-mice

Caribbean islanders in the Bahamas are bracing themselves for the arrival of Hurricane Sandy after it brought death and destruction to Cuba and Jamaica.     The storm has caused winds of up to 180-kilometres an hour and waves 9-metres high. Two people are known to have died so far.     If you are in the area affected by the hurricane you can send us your pictures to yourpics@bbc.co.uk or follow this link to upload a short video. http://bbcwhysupload.cs.streamuk.com/        http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20078215
The UN has already backed the Eid ceasefire in Syria but will the government and rebel groups uphold the truce?

Link Title: Tokyo governor to form new party
Message: Tokyo's outspoken governor Shintaro Ishihara says he is resigning to form a new national political party, ahead of expected general elections in Japan.  The 80-year-old, serving his fourth term as governor, is known for making provocative comments.  Earlier this year, he sparked off a row when he said he would use public money to buy a group of islands at the centre of a dispute between China and Japan.

A ceasefire between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza appears to be holding after it came into effect at midnight local time.     Egyptian officials mediated the truce following several days of violence.

The European Space Agency (ESA) has outlined the basic design for a robotic probe that could be dispatched to the Moon's south pole in 2018 http://bbc.in/SvDhq6  Is this the first step towards a manned ESA mission to the moon?

Will 'Walmart moms' decide who wins the US presidential race? http://bbc.in/TAsdNf  Both Obama and Romney are aggressively courting women voters - but how are their messages registering with swing state mothers?   The BBC went to Colorado to meet Rebecca and Catherine and find out what matters to them.

This lake, in Bamiyan province in Afghanistan, is part of the country's first-ever national park. It attracts thousands of local visitors every year. The government hopes foreign tourists will start to visit too. Read more about it here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20038511

Microsoft launches its first tablet in the UK on Friday. It runs their latest operating system, Windows 8. It's Microsoft's first entry into the tablet market and early reviews have been mixed. The device itself is being praised but some critics are saying there's simply not enough software available.   What do you think? Are you going to be one of the first to get this new tablet? If you're an Apple lover, will this make you switch to Microsoft? If you're already a fan of Windows, are you excited about the new turn its taking?

Link Title: Millions gather in Mecca for Hajj
