Message: This week marks the annual celebration of the Hajj pilgrimage and the beginning of Eid. Thousands of people have already gathered in Mecca. If you are taking part in the pilgrimage this year or you're in Mecca on Mount Arafat day, we'd love to hear from you. Send us your pictures to yourpics@bbc.co.uk or follow this link to record a short video of yourself telling us about your experience: http://bbcwhysupload.cs.streamuk.com/

TAKE A LOOK: How should the Antarctic be protected? This week delegates from 27 different countries and organisations are meeting in Hobart in Australia to discuss its future. They hope to reach an agreement on the best way to preserve this unique but vulnerable area. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20066845

Lakhdar Brahimi, the UN envoy to Syria, says President Bashar al Assad's government has agreed to a ceasefire during the Islamic holiday of Eid al-Adha. The government will make a final decision on Thursday. Mr Brahimi hopes the lull in fighting will provide an opportunity to discuss a longer lasting ceasefire.

Hello its Mishal here with Impact at 13GMT. As the Jimmy Savile abuse scandal in Britain leads to more victims coming forward, we look at shocking figures from elsewhere. In India - 53% of young people questioned in a recent survey said they had suffered sexual abuse. Why do so many suffer in silence?

Link Title: Why mum went on strike at home
Message: Canadian Mom Jessica Stilwell went on strike recently to teach her kids a lesson. Her blog talking about how the strike was going became a hit with parents around the world. What do you think? Tell us your stories about parenting. What advice would you give to Jessica?

Today the German Chancellor Angela Merkel will unveil a monument in Berlin commemorating the Roma victims of the Nazi holocaust. The memorial will be in the Tiergarten park, near the Reichstag, the German parliament building. Experts say between 220,000 and 500,000 Roma were killed during World War II.

8500 South African miners have been sent letters of dismissal after failing to return to work. Gold Fields mining company issued a final ultimatum to employees after it secured a court order ruling the strike illegal. Last week, 11000 miners heeded the ultimatum and returned to work.

NOC, a nine year old beluga whale, can make sounds very close to human speech. Researchers in the US discovered NOC's ability. While dolphins have been taught to mimic the pattern and durations of sounds in human speech, this is the first time any animal has spontaneously tried such mimicry. Listen to NOC here.

Link Title: BBC News - Hardtalk - Star Trek's William Shatner: I have no ego
Message: WATCH: Actor William Shatner talks to Hardtalk about his time as Captain Kirk in Star Trek. He says he didn't know about his co-starts bad feelings towards him until years later.   For the full interview watch Hardtalk on BBC World at 1530GMT

Link Title: Qatar emir in landmark Gaza trip
Message: Qatar's emir has become the first head of state to visit the Gaza Strip since Hamas came to power there in 2007. Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani has pledged $400m for building in Gaza. Qatar is one of Hamas' main benefactors since the group fell out with Syria and Iran.

Link Title: Winning votes in the social media age
Message: WATCH: The BBC's Matt Danzico looks at how both US presidential candidates are using social media as part of their campaign strategy and asks why it is so important. Will social media decide the US presidential election?

LIVE: On BBC World Service radio, watch our special broadcast on the future of China.   Guests in Beijing, Shenzhen, Chicago, Nairobi and London are talking to a global audience about the future of China's economy, social issues, foreign relations, the power of the internet among other things.   What would you like to ask them? What do you think of China? If you are Chinese, how would you define yourself and your country? What do you imagine the future of China to be?

Link Title: Why so many old pianos are dumped
Message: More and more pianos are ending up on the scrap heap. When once it was a 'must have' item, some experts say they are becoming less culturally relevant. What do you think? Do you have a piano in your house? Would you like one?

Link Title: MPs to quiz BBC chief over Savile
Message: Today the Director General of the BBC has been seen around the world answering hard hitting questions from MPs about allegations of sexual abuse by a former BBC presenter. Jimmy Savile was a household name in Britain until his death last year – the allegations against him date back over 40 years. On Impact today we’ll be looking at the painful journey of the victims who are finally being heard.

TAKE A LOOK: This gallery of photos shows scenes from Lebanon over the last couple of days. Violent clashes have been taking place following the killing of a senior security official on Friday. The worst clashes took place in Tripoli, in the north of the country, where at least 3 people died.

Link Title: BBC News at 2012 US presidential foreign policy debate - Boca Raton
Message: US President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger Mitt Romney have battled over national security, in the third and final presidential debate. The rivals tangled over the Arab Spring, Iran, China's rise and more in a feisty 90-minute head-to-head http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20025893  But did Romney show that he is ready for the "3AM phone call" made famous by Hillary Clinton's campaign in 2008?   We asked Obama campaign staffers Jim Messina and Jennifer Psaki as well as Republican US Senators Rob Portman and Marco Rubio   http://youtu.be/mf9mqyVqFG4

BBC News is in the city of Boca Raton in the US state of Florida for the final debate of the 2012 US presidential race http://bbc.in/TtZSIh  Follow all of the action on our live page http://bbc.in/TtZSIl and join our live-tweeting conversation on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/TtZSIf

Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are set to meet at Lynn University in Boca Raton, Florida tonight for the third and final debate ahead of 6 November's presidential election - this time, they will be focusing on foreign policy http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20025893    Join us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for live tweeting from the debate http://twitter.com/bbcnewsus

Link Title: BASEBALL IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA
Message: It had long been suspected but new evidence indicates that the outbreak of cholera which started in Haiti two years ago - was 'most likely' started by United Nations peacekeepers.    Research has found that the strain of the disease in Haiti is identical to that common in Nepal, where the UN troops were from.   The UN now faces massive compensation claims from victims.   At 1800GMT Zeinab Badawi will be speaking to David Darg who has directed a documentary about the cholera epidemic in Haiti, called Baseball in the time of Cholera about a young baseball player in Haiti.   What are the possible implications of the new research?

Link Title: Verdict due in Italy quake case
Message: Six Italian scientists and an ex-government official have been sentenced to six years in prison over the 2009 deadly earthquake in L'Aquila.  A regional court found them guilty of multiple manslaughter.  Prosecutors said the defendants gave a falsely reassuring statement before the quake, while the defence maintained there was no way to predict major quakes.  The 6.3 magnitude quake devastated the city and killed 309 people.

The world's oldest undeciphered writing system, which has so far defied attempts to uncover its 5,000-year-old secrets, could be about to be decoded by Oxford University academics.    This international research project is already casting light on a lost bronze age middle eastern society where enslaved workers lived on rations close to the starvation level.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-19964786

Link Title: BBC World Have Your Say UGC Upload
Message: What do you think the future of China looks like?   Tomorrow at 11GMT on World Have Your Say on World Service radio, we'll be hosting a live debate with BBC Chinese talking to people in London, China, the US, Brazil and Kenya; we'd also like to hear from you.  If you have comments or questions for our Chinese audience, go to our video uploader, record your comments and we'll try to use them on the programme.

Lance Armstrong has been stripped of his seven Tour de France titles by cycling's governing body the UCI.  The International Cycling Union has accepted the findings of the United States Anti-Doping Agency's (Usada) investigation into Armstrong.  UCI president Pat McQuaid said: "Lance Armstrong has no place in cycling. He deserves to be forgotten."  McQuaid added Armstrong had been stripped of all results since 1 August, 1998 and banned for life for doping.

Hello Facebookers - Mishal here with Impact today. Criticism of the Bo Xilai case has emerged today from what you might consider an unusual quarter - a group of leftists including former Communist Party officials. Full details are below - we're discussing on air at 9pm Beijing time.

VIDEO: Rising numbers of people of Indian origin born in the West are moving "back" to the country their parents left decades ago.   With India's economy growing faster than America or Britain's, the BBC's Rajini Vaidyanathan has been speaking to some of the new wave of "reverse migrants" who are seeking opportunities as well as a cultural connection.

Link Title: Verdict due in Italy quake case
Message: A verdict is due in the trial of six Italian scientists and an ex-government official charged with manslaughter over the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake.  The 6.3 magnitude quake devastated the city and killed 309 people.  Prosecutors allege the defendants gave a falsely reassuring statement before the quake after studying hundreds of tremors that had shaken the city.  The defence has argued that there is no way to predict major earthquakes even in a seismically active area.

One of India's veteran film-makers, Yash Chopra, dies aged 80, days after being admitted to hospital with dengue fever.  Over five decades, Chopra, dubbed the King of Romance, gave Bollywood some of its biggest blockbusters.   His film studios Yash Raj Films helped establish some of Indian cinema's biggest names, including Amitabh Bachchan and Shah Rukh Khan.  In his tribute, Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh described Chopra as an "icon of Indian cinema".

Link Title: The sounds of Egypt's blind orchestra
Message: Cairo's Egyptian Blind Girls Chamber Orchestra has been called "a thing of light and hope."

Thousands of Lebanese attend the funeral of security chief Wissam al-Hassan, who was killed on Friday, amid renewed calls for the PM to resign.  The protesters threw stones at the building, as police fired tear gas.  The scenes came after the opposition renewed a call for the PM to resign over the attack which killed one of Mr Hassan's bodyguards and a woman nearby.

Link Title: Best of the web: Planets, pandemics and power
Message: Want to know what makes Google, Google? Take a look inside its top secret data centre in our round-up of this week's best stories: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121019-planets-pandemics-and-power

On Sunday, the Catholic Church will canonize its first ever Native American saint, Kateri Tekakwitha. Sometimes known as Lily of the Mohawks, she died more than 300 years ago, but is thought by some to have performed a miracle as recently as 2006 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19996957
What's your favourite James Bond moment? Upload your videos to http://upload.news.bbc.cs.streamuk.com/ or email them to yourpics@bbc.co.uk

Link Title: Your James Bond moment in video
Message: The name's Bond... James Bond. As 007 celebrates his 50th anniversary, we want to hear your favourite Bond moment, one-liner or song. All villains, Bond girls, secret agents and signature songs welcome.

Link Title: America’s best neighbourhoods for authentic ethnic food
Message: This week BBC Travel looked at America’s best neighbourhoods for authentic ethnic food, where you can eat your way around the world without leaving the US.

NASA's Curiosity rover has ingested its first Martian soil sample. Our Science Correspondent Jonathan Amos explains why this pinch of dust is significant. http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-20003236
A senior Lebanese intelligence official was among those killed in a car bomb attack in central Beirut.   http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-20008827
Images from Lebanon's capital Beirut, where at least eight people have been killed in a huge car-bomb explosion
There has been a large explosion in the Lebanese capital, Beirut. At least 8 killed and 78 injured.

Link Title: The hidden rules that shape human progress
Message: Are there hidden rules that shape all human progress? Could there be a Moore's Law for everything? BBC Future explains. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121018-hidden-rules-of-human-progress

Tensions between China and Japan over disputed islands are mounting. China is reportedly conducting more naval exercises in the East China Sea. Japan has defended its decision to purchase the islands. We have an exclusive interview with Japan's Foreign Minister     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20001044
US President Barack Obama and Republican rival Mitt Romney see the funny side as they poke fun at themselves and each other at a fundraiser.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20000056

Link Title: EU in deal on bank supervision
Message: EU leaders have moved a step closer to setting up a single banking union. They've agreed to phase in a body to monitor banks in countries that use the euro. The plan will start sometime next year.   Will it work?

Kenya's ambitious Vision 2030 plan hopes to bring the country into the future http://bbc.in/RKns1r - projects include the expanded use of geothermal power, sponsoring an international sports academy and building a new tech hub popularly referred to as Konza City (see photo).   But will corruption kill off these plans?   Economist James Shikwati takes a deeper look http://bbc.in/RKns1r

Can we really predict the results of the US presidential race? http://bbc.in/RXNcok  Has an abundance of data made us too confident in our capabilities?   Nate Silver from the New York Times takes a look at statistics in his new book The Signal and the Noise and offers us a by-the-numbers look at this year's presidential campaign season.

Google has threatened to exclude French media sites from search results if France goes ahead with plans to make search engines to pay for content.  In a letter sent to several ministerial offices, Google said such a law "would threaten its very existence".  French newspaper publishers have been pushing for the law, saying it is unfair that Google receives advertising revenue from searches for news.  Should search engines be made to pay for content?

Negotiators from the Colombian government and left-wing Farc rebels set the stage for their first direct talks for a decade, addressing reporters in Norway.  After almost 50 years of conflict, the two sides launched the peace process at a hotel in Norway, with negotiations expected to last months.  Colombia's negotiator said both sides agreed on the need for social change.  Farc delegation head Ivan Marquez said they came "with an olive branch" but peace did not mean "arms go quiet".

TAKE A LOOK: The photograph is called "Bubble Jetting Emperors" and it has earned Paul Nicklen one of the world's top photo awards.    The Canadian braved the extreme cold of Antarctica and attack by leopard seals to shoot emperor penguins as they prepare to blast their way through a hole in the ice has earned    His picture won the Underwater Worlds category and the overall title in this year's Veolia Environnement Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition.        http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/19980616

It' the end of an era.   Newsweek, the 80-year-old US current affairs magazine, is to become an online-only publication, ending its print edition.  The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines.  Newsweek merged with the internet news group the Daily Beast two years ago.  The Daily Beast's founder, Tina Brown, said its site now had more than 15 million unique visitors a month, a 70% increase on last year.  She said in a statement: "Exiting print is an extremely difficult moment for all of us who love the romance of print and the unique weekly camaraderie of those hectic hours before the close on Friday night.

The head of Saudi Arabia's religious police has said there is a pressing need to employ more women in the force.  Abdul Latif Abdul Aziz al-Sheikh said he hoped a recruitment drive would take place soon.  Saudi's religious police enforce the kingdom's strict Islamic laws, including dress and prayer times.  Correspondents say the introduction of women could be a sign of the king's cautiously reformist agenda.

Hello everyone, among our talking points on Impact today is the BBC survey below on the cost of a football habit.     English clubs are ever more popular around the world but for fans, it comes at a price. Is it worth it?    We'd also like to hear how much it costs where you are to go to a football match. Mishal     http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19981001

Are there cracks in the Germany-France love-in that’s anchored the Eurozone? We’ll be discussing that ahead of today’s EU summit.    A woman’s right to choose – the rally crying for feminism tested in Northern Ireland as Marie Stopes opens the first private abortion clinic in Belfast. That and lots more on GMT with me, George Alagiah.

Link Title: EU summit to focus on euro crisis
Message: EU states are sharply divided over plans for banking union as their leaders gather in Brussels for a two-day summit.  The aim is to agree first on joint banking supervision, with the European Central Bank playing the lead role.  But the UK - the EU's main financial centre - wants safeguards to protect the powers of the Bank of England.  It and the other nine non-euro states are also concerned about voting rights in the proposed banking union.  Do you think that Euro summits actually work and achieve their aims?

The United States has welcomed the decision by the Cuban government to abolish the requirement for exit permits http://bbc.in/Tcqai6  Highly-qualified professionals such as doctors will still continue to face travel controls.  What does this change in policy mean for the future of Cuba?

Link Title: Top Tamil Tiger now a 'free man'
Message: The Sri Lankan authorities say that the senior most surviving Tamil Tiger leader, Selvarasa Pathmanathan - also known as known as "KP" - is a free man.  They say there are no longer plans to lay any charges against him.  Media Centre for National Security head Lakshman Hulugalle told the BBC there was "no case" against Mr Pathmanathan.

Astronomers have found the nearest planet outside our Solar System, circling one of the stars of Alpha Centauri just four light-years away.    The planet has at minimum the same mass as Earth, but circles its star far closer than Mercury orbits our Sun.    It is therefore outside the "habitable zone" denoting the possibility of life, as the researchers report in Nature.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19959531

Lance Armstrong is stepping down as chairman of his Livestrong charity to help it limit the damage from the doping scandal.  Nike have also severed ties with Lance Armstrong by releasing this statement:  "Due to the seemingly insurmountable evidence that Lance Armstrong participated in doping and misled Nike for more than a decade, it is with great sadness that we have terminated our contract with him.   Nike does not condone the use of illegal performance enhancing drugs in any manner.   Nike plans to continue support of the Livestrong initiatives created to unite, inspire and empower people affected by cancer."

Link Title: Rwanda leads DRC rebels, says UN
Message: UN experts say Rwanda's defence minister is effectively commanding the M23 rebellion in the neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo.  The confidential report, leaked to Reuters agency, says Uganda is also backing the M23 rebels, who have been fighting the DRC's army since April.  The document builds on a UN report published in June which accused Rwanda of supporting the insurgents.  Rwanda and Uganda strenuously deny supporting the rebellion.

Link Title: BBC - Newsbeat - Amanda Todd: Tributes pour in for cyber bullying victim
Message: Tributes from across the world are being paid to a 15-year-old girl from Canada who killed herself after being bullied online.  A memorial for Amanda Todd was held overnight in British Columbia, five days after she was found dead.  It comes just five weeks after she uploaded a video to YouTube describing years of bullying that she said drove her to drugs and alcohol.

Link Title: Ugly scenes mar England U21 win
Message: Players from England's under 21 team say they were racially abused by fans during a bad tempered game against Serbia on Tuesday.   The Football Association has complained to European football's governing body, UEFA. Members of the team also alleged they were pelted with stones, coins and seats.   There mass brawl erupted between opposing players and coaches at the final whistle after England won the Euro 2013 play-off 1-0.  What do you think UEFA should do?  Financial punishment or ban from international football? How bad is racism in football?

Link Title: Cambodia set for week of mourning
Message: Cambodia is preparing for the return of the body of former King Norodom Sihanouk, who died in China on Monday.  His body is due to arrive in Phnom Penh later on Wednesday, marking the start of a week of official mourning.  As many as 100,000 people are expected to line the route the coffin will take from the airport to the royal palace.  Grieving Cambodians wore black ribbons and flags flew at half-mast after news broke that the 89-year-old had died of a heart attack in Beijing.

Link Title: BBC News at Presidential Debates: Spinning the Town Hall
Message: Both Obama and Romney are trying to appeal to undecided voters - but did tonight's bickering put them off? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19965927  We went to the spin room and asked Obama supporters Governor Deval Patrick and Obama Campaign Manager Jim Messina as well as Republicans John Sununu and Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell.  What do you think?   http://youtu.be/3g9Y-Sy-PlI

Link Title: BBC News at 2012 Presidential Town Hall Debate
Message: With 90 minutes to go before the second presidential debate of the 2012 campaign http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19965927 - we asked Obama surrogate Democratic Governor Martin O'Malley of Maryland and Romney surrogate Republican Congressman Peter King of New York the three things their candidates need to do in tonight's debate.  Here is what they told us.   Join us tonight on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for live tweeting coverage of the town hall debate http://www.twitter.com/bbcnewsus  http://youtu.be/ray7x2vKSxs

Join us tonight from the campus of Hofstra University in Hempstead, New York for the second debate of the 2012 US race for president http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19965927 Follow our live page from http://www.bbcnews.com and our live tweeting @BBCNewsUS http://twitter.com/bbcnewsus

Creativity is often part of a mental illness, with writers particularly susceptible, according to a study of more than a million people.  Writers had a higher risk of anxiety and bipolar disorders, schizophrenia, unipolar depression, and substance abuse, the Swedish researchers at the Karolinska Institute found.  They were almost twice as likely as the general population to kill themselves.  The dancers and photographers were also more likely to have bipolar disorder.

Link Title: Obama team bullish on next debate
Message: US President Barack Obama's team says he will make a "strong" comeback in Tuesday's debate rematch with Republican Mitt Romney.  Is tonight's debate in New York "do-or-die" for Obama?  You can stay up to date with the latest news from the debate from our team on the ground by following @BBCNewsUS on Twitter.

Link Title: WORLD FOOD DAY - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: The past 12 months has seen drought in the United States, poor rainfall in Russia and South America and a dry monsoon in India and all of these have a major impact on the world's most important food crops and  consequently what we eat.  It's World Food Day today - a day dedicated to raising awareness of the problems facing the global supply of food.   The BBC's Mark Lowen and Will Grant have been finding out how food prices are being effected Greece and Mexico.

Link Title: Clinton takes blame for US deaths
Message: US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton takes responsibility for the deaths of four Americans in Libya, ahead of the US presidential debate.   Mrs Clinton said ensuring the safety of US diplomatic staff overseas was her job, not that of the White House.  US Republicans have strongly criticised President Barack Obama over the attack.

Egypt's football association has postponed the start of the domestic season indefinitely. The decision was made because of a violent stadium riot at Cairo club Al Ahly in February. 74 people died. When the Egypt Football Association tried to start the new season in September, hundreds of Al Ahly fans attacked the body's headquarters, calling for justice for those killed in February.

TAKE A LOOK: Two amateur astronomers have discovered a new planet. Its skies are lit up by four suns. It's the first time that such a system has been identified. The planet, located about 5,000 light years from Earth, has been dubbed PH1 in honour of Planet Hunters, the astronomy website that helped the discovery happen. On Impact at 1300GMT we'll be talking to Dr Chris Lintott, the astronomer who runs Planet Hunters. What would you like to ask him?

VIDEO: Jose Andre Montago Baina is seven years old, he's blind, and he's become known as a prodigious jazz musician. His talent has been attracting attention from around the world. Take a look at him playing.

Two of Bollywood's top stars - Saif Ali Khan and Kareena Kapoor - have got married in the Indian city of Mumbai.  The hugely popular stars, dubbed Saifeena by the paparazzi, are known as Bollywood's "first couple".

The former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic has denied charges of war crimes, at his trial in The Hague.  Mr Karadzic has opened his defence and is representing himself against 10 charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity during the war in the 1990s.   He told the court he did everything he could to avoid war and described himself as a mild man with a great capacity to understand others.  The single genocide charge against him relates to the deaths of more than 7,000 Bosniak (Bosnian Muslim) men and boys in Srebrenica in 1995. It was the worst atrocity in Europe since the end of World War II.

Francesco Schettino, the Captain of the Costa Concordia cruise ship, has made his first appearance at an inquiry into the disaster http://bbc.in/T5PjuE  The court will determine whether Schettino and others should be put on trial.  Tonight on BBC World News America - we'll look at the inquiry in Italy and other news from around the globe, including:  - Malala Yousafzai arrives in the UK for treatment http://bbc.in/T5Pgzg - The dangers of arming Syria's rebels  - Why are ex-convicts in the US barred from voting? http://bbc.in/T5Pgzc  Check your local listings to find BBC World News in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/T5Pia4

As Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are hunkered down with advisers ahead of Tuesday's debate in Hempstead, New York http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19954883 our election poll tracker reveals that the race looks to be getting tighter http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19415745  Mark Mardell, our North America editor, looks at why tomorrow night could be Obama's do-or-die debate http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19956631  The BBC's Daily Diet for 15 October - a tasty helping of US politics http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19952070  Get to know your battlegrounds http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-17306282#Battleground%20states

Felix Baumgartner may have captivated the world with his record-setting jump through the sound barrier http://bbc.in/T5pMSn  But he is not the first person to take on a daring feat in the name of science. Meet some of the people who hiked, explored, flew and rode to the extremes to help all of us better understand our world http://bbc.in/T5pNFS

BBC World News TV is the first broadcaster to air the 'Class Dismissed - the Death of Female Education,’ original 2009 documentary by the New York Times journalist Adam Ellick on Malala Yousafzai.    The documentary which brought Malala to the world's attention follows her struggle to keep up her education amid Taliban attempts to close all girls’ schools in the area.        You will be able to watch the film on Tuesday 16th October 2012 at 03.30 GMT; 08.30 GMT and 15.30 GMT.

Burma's president has blocked a global Islamic body from opening an office to help Muslims involved in recent communal violence in the west of Burma.  A statement on the president's website said such an office was not in accordance with the people's wishes.  Thousands of monks have joined protests against the Organisation of Islamic Conference's plans to open an office.  Tensions in western Rakhine state have been high after deadly clashes between Muslims and Rakhine Buddhists.

Link Title: Eight ways China is changing your world
Message: As China's ruling communist party meets from 8 November to rubber-stamp sweeping leadership changes, the BBC's Angus Foster explains why the country's influence now reaches so many aspects of our lives.

Link Title: Africa leader prize to be awarded
Message: There is no winner this year for the world's most valuable individual prize - the Mo Ibrahim prize for good governance in Africa.  The $5m prize is supposed to be awarded each year to a democratically elected leader who governed well, raised living standards and then voluntarily left office.  The panel said no candidate had met all of the criteria - as in 2009 and 2010.

Link Title: Envoy appeals to Iran over Syria
Message: UN envoy Lakhdar Brahimi has appealed for Iranian help to implement a ceasefire in Syria over the upcoming Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha.  Following a visit to Tehran, Mr Brahimi said such a ceasefire could "allow a political process to develop".

Hello it's Mishal with Impact.     We are still fascinated by Felix Baumgartner - as are many of you, judging by the interest we have had in the story in the last 24 hours.     Today we ask what his feat means for science and our understanding of what happens to the human body in space.     Take a look at our interactive guide to his suit - and we'll have our Science Correspondent standing by to answer your questions at 1430 GMT.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19943590

Italian experts are due to reveal the data from the black box of the Costa Concordia cruise ship which capsized after hitting rocks near an island in January killing 32 people.    A judge will then decide whether there should be a criminal trial against the ship's captain, Francesco Schettino, who is accused of causing a shipwreck, manslaughter and abandoning ship before all passengers were evacuated.     In the popular tradition of the sea, a ship's captain is expected to stay until all the passengers have been safely evacuated but is a ship's captain legally required to be the last one off?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16611371

The Philippines is set to sign a peace plan with the country's largest Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front.  The framework deal follows long negotiations aimed at ending a 40-year conflict that has cost an estimated 120,000 lives.

SKYDIVE VIDEO: Felix Baumgartner is the new world record holder for the highest ever skydive. Here is another opportunity to see the jump.  The 43-year-old daredevil now holds the record for the highest ever manned balloon flight, and is waiting to discover whether or not he has broken the sound barrier.  Opening his parachute after 4m15s, he missed out on the record for the longest freefall - 4m36s, set by Joe Kittinger in 1960.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19943132

Austrian Felix Baumgartner has broken the record for the highest ever skydive by jumping out of a balloon 39km above New Mexico.  The 43-year-old was hoping also to break the sound barrier during his descent - although that mark awaits confirmation.  It took 10 minutes for him to reach the desert surface below.  Only the last few thousand feet were negotiated by parachute.  Baumgartner's efforts have finally toppled records that have stood for more than 50 years.

Link Title: Police surge into Rio drug slums
Message: Hundreds of Brazilian police officers backed by armoured cars and helicopters have moved to take control of two Rio de Janeiro slums notorious for drugs.  Some 1,500 police and commandos took part in the operation in the northern favelas of Jacarezinho and Manguinhos. The no-go areas are known as centres for the trafficking of crack cocaine.

Link Title: LA trees hold up shuttle journey
Message: The final journey of the retired US space shuttle Endeavour through Los Angeles aboard a giant trolley has been delayed by trees along the route.

Turkish civilian planes are no longer allowed to fly over Syria, Damascus has said, amid growing tensions between the two neighbouring countries.  This comes just days after Turkey intercepted a Syrian-bound plane, claiming it carried Russian-made munitions for the Syrian army.

A crucial Africa Cup of Nations football match between Senegal and Ivory Coast has been abandoned after fans rioted at a stadium in Dakar.  Home fans started fires in the stands and threw objects on the pitch as Senegal were losing 2-0, a result which would have eliminated the team.   Ivorian fans jumped down on the pitch to escape the violence.
Zambia, Ghana, Mali and Nigeria are among the first teams to qualify from a dramatic weekend of 2013 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers.
When the deal that averted disaster in 1962 was signed, there were 100 other nuclear weapons in the hands of Cuba, sparking a frantic Soviet mission to recover them.

Colombia's president has apologised to indigenous communities in the Amazon for deaths and destruction caused by the rubber boom around 100 years ago.  Backed by Colombia's government, a Peruvian firm tapped rubber from 1912 to 1929 near La Chorrera in the south.   Up 100,000 people were killed and communities devastated, according to indigenous leaders.

Link Title: Shuttle rolls into history in LA
Message: The decommissioned American space shuttle, Endeavour, is making its final journey -- through the streets of Los Angeles to its permanent home at the California Science Centre.   Trees have been cut down, power lines have been moved and traffic signals removed to allow the shuttle to pass through the streets.

The UN Security Council has adopted a resolution paving the way for military intervention in Mali to retake the north from Islamist extremists.   The resolution requests a detailed plan for such an operation from African organisations within 45 days.
Tour de France director Christian Prudhomme says there should be "no winner" of Lance Armstrong's seven titles.  Do you agree?
This week BBC Travel looked at the equation of dual citizenship and whether becoming a passport holder in two countries might be easier than you thought.
VIDEO: The BBC's Ian Pannell visits a hospital in Aleppo overwhelmed with trauma victims of Syria's civil war, where doctors work under fire to keep people alive.

Link Title: Best of the web: From Nobel acclaim to ignoble acts
Message: Every Friday BBC Future lists their pick of the week's most interesting and thought-provoking articles. This week: The heart-breaking story behind a rare brain disease; the mind-boggling science behind the Physics Nobel prize, and how to make your online passwords security-proof. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121012-from-nobel-praise-to-ignoble-acts

A group of Egyptian judges has criticised President Mohammed Mursi's attempt to remove the country's top prosecutor as a "farce".  The president said he was reassigning prosecutor-general Abdel Maguid Mahmoud, regarded as a figure from the era of ousted President Hosni Mubarak, as Vatican envoy.  But Mr Mahmoud has said he will not go.  Amid the controversy, supporters and opponents of President Mursi clashed in Cairo's Tahrir Square on Friday.

Link Title: BBC World Have Your Say UGC Upload
Message: On BBC World at 1500GMT, we'll be talking about the decision to award the Nobel Peace Prize to the EU. Some of you say it's a brave decision and will help to remind people of the EU's real meaning. Others have called it a farce, particularly considering the current economic crisis in Europe. Does the EU deserve the prize?    Also, Pakistan is marking a day of prayer for 14 year old Malala Yousafzai. We'll be discussing your reaction to what has happened to the young activist.    Get in touch by posting below or if you want to record a short video of yourself, click on the link to use our video uploader. Don't forget to let us know where you are.

The Botswana High Court has overturned a customary law which prevented women from inheriting the family home.  The judge ruled that the law contravened the constitution, which guarantees equality for men and women.  Correspondents say traditions which stop women from inheriting property exist in many African societies.  Do such traditions exist where you live?   What do you think of such traditions, should they remain or is it time for a change?

The first rock examined up close by Nasa's Mars rover proved to be a little more interesting than expected.    The pyramidal object, nicknamed "Jake Matijevic" after a recently passed mission engineer, had a composition not seen on the planet before.     Scientists have likened it to some unusual but well known rocks on Earth.    These form from relatively water-rich magmas that have cooled slowly at raised pressures.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19923118

Link Title: Day of prayer for Pakistani girl
Message: Pakistan calls for Friday to be observed as a "day of prayer" for the recovery of a 14-year-old girl shot in the head by Taliban gunmen.  Malala Yousafzai was transferred to a military hospital in Rawalpindi on Thursday. Doctors say her progress over the next few days will be "critical."  The Taliban said they would target the girls' education activist again, accusing her of "promoting secularism".  But the shooting has prompted outrage and protests across Pakistan.

Link Title: Nobel Peace Prize awarded to EU
Message: This year's Nobel Peace Prize has being awarded to the the European Union.   The decision by the five-member panel, led by Council of Europe Secretary-General, Thorbjoern Jagland,  was unanimous.   The EU won the Nobel Peace Prize for 6 decades of advancement of peace, reconciliation and human rights in Europe.  What do you think of the decision?   Considering the current economic climate do you think that the decision is well timed?

PICTURE GALLERY: Ceremonies have been taking place in Indonesia and Australia to mark the 10th anniversary of the Bali bombings.   More than 200 people were killed.   The Indonesian Foreign Minister said the attack was nothing less than an assault on humanity.

Link Title: BBC News: Was the US vice-presidential debate too aggressive?
Message: US vice-presidential candidates Joe Biden and Paul Ryan have clashed sharply in their only debate, as polls show a tightening campaign http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19912954   But was the debate too aggressive to appeal to undecided voters?   We headed to the spin room and spoke to Former Ohio Governor Ted Strickland, US Senators Rand Paul, Mitch McConnell and Dick Durbin

We are live from Danville, Kentucky and Washington, DC covering the one and only vice-presidential debate between Democrat Joe Biden and Republican Paul Ryan http://bbc.in/SUQ9KV  Join the conversation by following our live page http://bbc.in/SUQbCi   And follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/SUQbCg for colour commentary from our producers and correspondents

Hello from the World Debate team in Tokyo http://bbc.in/RAmK3O We’re preparing for the recording of a special edition of the World Debate tomorrow at the IMF Annual Meetings.   Nik Gowing will be joined by the IMF Managing Director, Christine Lagarde, and the Finance Minister of Germany, Wolfgang Schauble, to discuss what should be done to rescue the global economy.  Are harsh austerity measures doing too much harm and destroying any prospect of the growth so desperately needed?   When central banks pump in cash, does it really stimulate the economy?  If you want to put a question to our panel, please leave it here. And don’t forget to watch the Debate Saturday at 09:10 and 21:10 GMT and Sunday at 02:10 and 15:10 GMT on BBC World News http://bbc.in/RAmK3O

BBC News is in Kentucky as US vice-presidential candidates Joe Biden and Paul Ryan are set to meet in their only debate. Here is a sneak peek behind the scenes at Centre College in the small town of Danville http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19912954 And be sure to join us tonight on Twitter @BBCNewsUs to follow all of the action from the debate http://twitter.com/bbcnewsus

Link Title: JOHN MCCAIN ON US FOREIGN POLICY - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: INTERVIEW: John McCain, the Republican senator for Arizona and former US presidential candidate, joined Lyse Doucet to talk about the US foreign policy and his support for direct intervention in Syria.

The Syrian-bound plane forced to land in Turkey was carrying Russian-made munitions, Turkey's Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said.  The plane, coming from Moscow, was intercepted by Turkish jets on Wednesday and forced to land in Ankara.  Mr Erdogan said the arms on board were destined for Syrian's defence ministry.  Syria and Russia have reacted angrily to the incident, denying allegations of illegal cargo and accusing Turkey of putting lives in danger.

Unemployment in Greece hit a record 25% in July, government figures show, with youth unemployment reaching more than 54%.  Greece's statistical authority said 1.26 million Greeks were jobless in July, with more than 1,000 jobs lost every day over the past year.  With austerity cuts continuing and Greece likely to enter another year of recession, the level may rise further.  The worst-affected 15-24 age group, however, includes those in education.

A woman in south-west France who received a telephone bill of nearly 12tn euros has had the real amount she owed waived - after the company admitted its mistake.  Solenne San Jose, from Pessac outside Bordeaux, said she received a huge shock when she opened the bill for 11,721,000,000,000,000 euros.  This is nearly 6,000 times France's annual economic output.

A 14-year-old Pakistani girl shot in the head by Taliban gunmen is being transferred to a new military hospital with better facilities, officials say.  Malala Yousafzai, in critical condition two days after being attacked in the north-western Swat Valley, left Peshawar by helicopter for Rawalpindi.  The Taliban, who accuse the young activist of "promoting secularism", have said they will target her again.

Link Title: Armstrong is a legend - Sky rider
Message: The news of Lance Armstrong being labelled a serial cheat  by the American anti-doping agency has been dominating the news.  His supporters have been quick to jump to his defence and his critics we quick to condemn him.  But away from sport Lance Armstrong's charity, Livestrong,  has raised almost half a billion dollars for cancer charities over the last 15 years.  So how do you think today's damning report will affect donations?  Armstrong maintains his innocence so will people think twice before continuing to donate funds to his charity?  Tell us what you think

Link Title: International Day of the Girl Child - 11 October
Message: Today is the first International Day of the Girl Child. The United Nations is highlighting efforts to end child marriage, a fundamental human rights violation that impacts all aspects of a girl’s life.  Every year, an estimated 10 million girls worldwide are married before they reach 18 years of age.  Child marriages take place in every region of the world and cut across cultures, religions, and ethnicities.  We want to hear from you. What is the situation like where you live? Does child marriage still occur frequently?  How close is your country in eradicating child marriages and can it ever be achieved.

Lawyers for the oil giant Shell are in court in the Netherlands facing accusations that the company has polluted villages in Nigeria.   Farmers from the Niger Delta say leaks from Shell's pipelines have ruined crops and fish farms. They want the company to pay compensation.   Shell says half the leaks in the region were caused by sabotage and that they were unable to clean them up due to insecurity.   It is the first time a Dutch multinational is being put on trial in a civil court at home in connection with damage caused abroad.  Shell insists it has been unable to clean up the spills due to insecurity.

As a cyclist, Lance Armstrong could have been described as the 'most sophisticated, professionalised and successful' racer of all time.   Instead that is the exact phrase being used to characterise the extent to which he cheated - according to the US Anti-Doping Agency.   The agency took evidence from 11 of his old teammates and say he supplied banned drugs to other riders, pressured them into participating and threatened to get them removed from the team if they refused.   Lance Armstrong denies the allegations but is not contesting them. He was tested 60 times by the anti-doping authorities and never failed a test.  What do you think will be the impact on cycling and wider world of sports? As he has never failed a doping test can and should he be stripped off his titles? Let us know what you think.

Higher food prices is always bad news for consumers. And today farmers in the UK are saying that the price of the weekly shopping basket WILL rise following their worst wheat harvest in years. A wet summer means wheat yields have fallen by 15%. And the problem's not limited to the UK. World supplies have also been hit by drought in the US - and a heatwave in Russia. Add to that rising fuel prices - which make it more expensive to work the land and transport produce - the global price of wheat has gone up 30% in the last year.  We want to hear from you about food prices in your country. How much do you pay for milk, bread, eggs? Are prices rising? What difference is that making to your lives?

Link Title: Global call on mental health care
Message: Hi all, Karin Giannone with you for the Hub at 16GMT. What now for Malala Yousafzai and her fight for girls' education, after the Taleban attack? And with nearly half a billion people in the world thought to be suffering from a mental illness - how much of a priority should governments make the treatment of mental health disorders?

Link Title: Turkey steps up warning to Syria
Message: Turkey's top military commander has warned Syria that it will respond with greater force if it continues its cross-border shelling. On Monday, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said that the cross-border shelling between Turkey and Syria was "extremely dangerous". Turkey's Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said Turkey has no intention of starting a war with Syria but that it will defend its territory.

Link Title: BBC NEWS | South Asia | Diary of a Pakistani schoolgirl
Message: Hello everyone, it's Mishal back on Impact. The diary below is how we first came to know of Malala Yousafzai - the young Pakistani whose activism began when the Taliban targeted girls schools like hers. We'll be speaking to colleagues at BBC Urdu for the latest on her story

Link Title: BBC man tries Paul Ryan P90X workout
Message: VIDEO: Republican vice presidential candidate Paul Ryan is well known for keeping fit. He reportedly takes on the gruelling P90X workout every morning. Our reporter Jamie Coomarasamy got a taste of keeping in shape the Paul Ryan way on a recent visit to Wisconsin.

ON AIR at 1100: George Alagiah is here with GMT. We'll be looking at how the Red Cross in Spain is trying to help the thousands of people pushed into poverty by Spain's economic crisis. Take a look at this graphic and read our Q&A to find out more. http://bbc.in/JWFqLd    Wherever you are, if you have been affected by the economic crisis, you can share your stories with us here.

Surgeons in Pakistan say they have removed a bullet from a 14-year-old girl who was shot in the head by Taliban gunmen.  Malala Yousafzai, a campaigner for girls' rights, is reported to be in a stable condition after the operation.  Gunmen attacked Miss Yousafzai and two other girls as they walked from school on Tuesday, sparking condemnation from politicians, activists and the public.

On World Mental Health Day (10 October), the World Health Organization is calling for an end to the stigmatization of depression and other mental disorders and for better access to treatment for all people who need it.  BBC World will have comprehensive coverage throughout the day talking to experts and sufferers from Paris, San Paolo and Delhi.    We want to hear from you:  If a member of your family was depressed would you know how to help them get treatment?    Is there a stigma attached to depression in your country?  Which aspect of mental health do you think that we should be addressing?

German Chancellor Angela Merkel visited Greece today. While she pledged her country's continuing support - angry protests raged in Athens http://bbc.in/RusBHP  What message does Merkel's visit send about Greece's continued membership in the eurozone?  We'll look at the Chancellor's visits tonight on BBC World News America along with other news and features from around the world, including:  - Outcry over attack on young activist in Pakistan http://bbc.in/RusBHL - Jerry Sandusky sentenced http://bbc.in/RusAUu - Meningitis outbreak grows http://bbc.in/RusBaI - Meet the first White House videographer http://bbc.in/RusBaL Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/RusAUm

Hi, this is Nik Gowing from the IMF Annual Meetings in Tokyo.   The BBC is recording a special edition of The World Debate http://bbc.in/SMx9OH this Friday the 12th of October. We’ll be asking: ‘Rescuing the global economy: what next?’  Joining us on our panel: - Christine Lagarde, the Head of the IMF - Wolfgang Schauble, German Finance Minister,  - Raghu Rajan,  newly appointed Chief Economic Adviser of the Indian government -  Peter Orszag, formerly President’s Obama Budget Director and now at Citigroup  We want to hear your thoughts on why the economic recovery is so disappointing four years after the financial crash and what you’d ask our panel.   Please leave your questions in the comments section below and visit http://bbc.in/SMx9OH to learn more about The World Debate

TAKE A LOOK: On Monday Mexican authorities announced that the leader of the notorious Los Zetas drug cartel,  Heriberto Lazcano, was killed in a shootout with marines. Now state officials say his body has been stolen from the morgue it was being stored in. Since 2006, the drugs war in Mexico has been responsible for an estimated 50,000 deaths. To find out more about its impact take a look at this Q&A  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-10681249

VIDEO: Satellite images are playing an increasingly important role in rescue efforts after natural or man made disasters. Have a listen to our audio slideshow where Dr Alice Bunn from the UK Space Agency explains exactly how they are being used to save lives.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19826963

14 year old, Malala Yousafzai, a vocal campaigner for women's rights, was shot on her way home from school in the Swat Valley. The Taliban has claimed responsibility.   Malala is a well known activist who first appeared in international media when she was 11 talking about life under the Taliban. Our correspondent in Islamabad says there has been huge shock at the attack.

Link Title: Nobel Prizes: Is there a secret formula to winning one?
Message: Could your sex, age, whether or not you are married... or even whether you have a beard help determine your chances of winning a Nobel Prize? Check out BBC Future's graphic to find out if there is a secret recipe to winning one of these prestigious prizes: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121008-winning-formula-for-nobel-prizes
Tune in to BBC World News in about an hour's time to find out whether skydiver Felix Baumgartner in successful in his attempt to break the speed of sound.

TAKE A LOOK: Skydiver Felix Baumgartner is attempting to break the speed of sound by jumping out a balloon at more than 120,000ft  above Roswell, New Mexico. The jump will take place in around two hours time. We'll keep you updated with how Felix gets on. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19860249

At 11GMT George Alagiah will be on GMT talking about German Chancellor Angela Merkel's visit to Athens today. Security for the visit is extremely high - around 7000 police officers have been deployed and public gatherings have been banned in certain parts of the city.   Are you in Greece? What do you think about Angela Merkel's visit?  Our Europe editor Gavin Hewitt examines the complicated relationship between Germany and Greece.

Link Title: 'A far cry from the Maiduguri I grew up in'
Message: 30 civilians have been killed in continuing violence in the Nigerian city of Maidiguri. The city has been under siege by the Islamist group Boko Haram and violence between the army and Boko Haram has caused many deaths. BBC Hausa's Jimeh Saleh is from Maidiguri. Here he talks about how his home has changed.

The global economic recovery is weakening as government policies have failed to restore confidence, the International Monetary Fund has said. It added that the risk of further deterioration in the economic outlook was "considerable" and had increased.The IMF downgraded its estimate for global growth in 2013 to 3.6% from the 3.9% it forecast in July.

"It's ordinary things that become surreal through the lens of the White House." After volunteering for the Obama campaign in 2008 - Arun Chaudhary became the first official US presidential videographer. Take a look at a few photos from Arun’s time at the White House and follow the link below to hear his take on some of "the mundane aspects" of presidential life http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19767164

Tonight on BBC World News America on PBS - Laura Trevelyan sits down with author Salman Rushdie to talk about anti-Western sentiment.   We'll also be taking a look at other news from around the world - including:  - Life inside Aleppo http://bbc.in/SJmFzo - Romney challenges Obama on foreign policy http://bbc.in/SJmFzm - Chavez secures a fourth term http://bbc.in/SJmDHZ - Defacing Rothko http://bbc.in/SJmDYd  Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/SJmFj4

What does it take to jump from 23 miles up? http://bbc.in/Rr5spQ  At some point in the coming days, Austrian daredevil Felix Baumgartner intends to leap out of a capsule and into a near vacuum as he descends 120,000ft to earth. If he is successful, Baumgartner will pass the previous skydiving world record by some 18,000ft and become the first human to break the sound barrier unaided by a vehicle.

Link Title: MITT ROMNEY ON US FOREIGN POLICY - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: It's less than a month to go until the US presidential election and today the Republican candidate, Mitt Romney has been outlining his foreign policy agenda in a major speech at the Virginia Military Institute.   Mr Romney said President Obama was failing to lead in response to events in the Middle East, including the killing of American embassy staff in Libya last month.  What do you think of Romney's comments?

Link Title: Stem cell experts win Nobel prize
Message: Two pioneers of stem cell research have shared the Nobel prize for medicine or physiology.  John Gurdon from the UK and Shinya Yamanaka from Japan were awarded the prize for changing adult cells into stem cells, which can become any other type of cell in the body.  Prof Gurdon used a gut sample to clone frogs and Prof Yamanaka altered genes to reprogramme cells.  The Nobel committee said they had "revolutionised" science.  How important do you think Nobel prize is in the 21st Century?

TAKE A LOOK: A mural by US artist Mark Rothko housed at London's Tate Modern has been vandalised by a man claiming to be commenting on contemporary art.  The man who did it tells the BBC he didn't do anything wrong.   Do you agree?  It is the latest act of art vandalism, stretching back to 455 AD when the Vandals invaded Rome, destroyed numerous artworks, and became forever associated with the wilful defacement of art.  Here are some other works that have been defaced in recent years.

VIDEO: Cameras recorded the moment the truck carrying liquified natural gas exploded after overturning on Saturday on a highway in Hunan province.   5 people - including 3 firefighters have been killed in a tanker explosion in China.  24 hours later, the Chinese news agency said it was still burning. 50 people needed to be rescued from their vehicles.

Today on Impact we look at the row engulfing two Chinese telecoms giants in the USA.   One of them - Huawei - is a hi-tech leader, involved in everything from mobile phones in Africa to your wifi laptop dongle.   We assess whether these are legitimate security fears or just hype about competition from China. Mishal

VIDEO: Take a look at these amazing images as the first commercial rocket takes off for the International Space Station with food, clothes and equipment.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19867358

Venezuela's President Hugo Chavez has won his bid for another six years in power. But what can he do to revive the country's struggling economy?  The votes have been counted, the result is clear. On 10 January next year, Mr Chavez will be inaugurated for another term as Venezuela's president.  But his economic strategy is running into trouble. The nation is beset by crumbling infrastructure, an overvalued currency and underperforming industry.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez has won a fourth term in office after defeating opposition leader Henrique Capriles.Mr Chavez won 54% of the vote, the country's electoral council announced.  Noisy celebrations among Chavez supporters erupted across the capital Caracas following the result.Turnout was more than 80% and voting was extended beyond the official closing time at some polling stations which still had long queues.

Hi its Babita here.  We on-air live from London and Singapore for Newsday. Voting is coming to a close in Venezeula where people have been queuing to cast their votes in the most tightly contested presidential elections for fourteen years. We'll have the latest from Caracas on the battle between the President Hugo Chavez and his rival Henrique Capriles. Join us for Newsday on BBC World News 00GMT/08SGT

Link Title: Campaigning for the rights of cats
Message: The Gastronomic Festival of the Cat happens every September in La Quebrada, Peru, but this year it comes as animal rights activists step up their efforts to change attitudes.  "God created cats!" read one placard. "Murderers!" shouted a chorus of animal-rights activists.   Even a stray yellow dog seemed to be barking in support of cats. He was wagging his tail with great excitement.

Voters in Venezuela prepare to go to the polls in what is predicted to be the country's most tightly contested presidential election in a decade.  Left-wing incumbent Hugo Chavez, first elected in 1998, is being challenged by opposition leader Henrique Capriles.  Mr Chavez wants to continue what he calls his socialist revolution while Mr Capriles has promised to restore economic growth.  Almost 19 million Venezuelans are eligible to vote in the election.

Link Title: Why Spain's greatest football match matters to Palestinians
Message: Barcelona is the football team of choice for Palestinians, but many are bewildered by a row between Hamas and Israel about the attendance of former hostage Gilad Shalit at El Clasico, the match against Real Madrid, says the BBC's Jon Donnison.

Link Title: Khan protest heads to tribal belt
Message: A motorcade protest against US drone strikes in Pakistan, led by former cricket star Imran Khan, heads for the country's restive tribal regions.  The "march" by thousands of protesters left the northwestern town of Dera Ismail Khan on Sunday morning.  The authorities say the protesters will not be allowed into the region as they will be at risk of attack by militants

"When I saw their bodies in pieces, my heart wanted revenge... it's all I want” http://bbc.in/SzAznF  Under President Barack Obama there has been a six-fold increase in US drone attacks. The BBC's Orla Guerin looks at the impact of these precision strikes on life in the Pakistani tribal region of North Waziristan.

Is it possible to enjoy the absurd action sequences in our favourite films without adult reason spoiling the fun? http://bbc.in/SzpgMp  More than thirty years after Raiders of the Lost Ark first appeared on cinema screens -the film is set for UK release on Blu-Ray next week- the BBC's Daniel Nasaw takes a look some of the more outlandish scenes.  Photo courtesy of and used with the permission of Paramount Pictures

Link Title: Best of the web: Brains, internet pains and automobiles
Message: Why are we not all driving electric cars? Find out in BBC Future’s round-up of the best of the web

This week BBC Travel looked at Los Angeles’ hidden architectural delights. Nestled between the city’s skyscrapers are spectacular buildings of structural and artistic note, ranging from Art Deco to Spanish Mission – you just have to know where to look.

Link Title: ELECTRIC CARS - GOOD OR BAD? - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Electric cars are the future - clean, green and better for the environment.   That's what we've come to think but new research from Norway's University of Science and Technology suggests it's not always the case.   Scientists say that when wider environmental impacts, such as the production of electricity are considered, conventional petrol and diesel cars CAN be cleaner.   One of the reports authors, Professor Anders Hammer Stromman, joined Peter Dobbie on BBC World News from Trondheim.

The world's biggest platinum producer, Anglo American Platinum, fires 12,000 striking South African miners after a protracted strike over wages.  The firm said the miners had failed to attend disciplinary hearings and had been dismissed in their absence.    South Africa's mining sector has been hit by a wave of wildcat strikes, during which a number of miners and mine officials have been killed.

Link Title: BBC News - Today - Imran Khan: I would order US drone shoot-downs
Message: Audio Interview with Imran Khan:  The Pakistani politician Imran Khan has said that he would authorise the shooting down of US drones over his country if he became its head of government, as they violate Pakistan's sovereignty.  Mr Khan, a former international cricketer who now leads the Tehreek-e-Insaf party, told Today presenter John Humphrys that the drone strikes are "so counterproductive", kill many innocent people and that the relatives of casualties often "go join the militants".

The Syrian city of Homs has been subjected to the most severe bombardment  in five months amid continuing violence across the country, activists report.  Aircraft and artillery targeted the neighbourhood of Khaldiya, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said.

A protest rally involving tens of thousands of Jordanians is underway in the capital, Amman. If follows the decision by King Abdullah on Thursday to dissolve Parliament and call elections.   As other countries in the Middle East went through revolution during the Arab Spring,  Jordan has remained relatively stable, although calls for reform have become louder.

So James Bond is celebrating his birthday today. It's exactly 50 years since the first film 'Dr. No' was released in cinemas.   Agent 007 has become the hero of one of the most influential movie series ever.  We want to hear from you. Are you a fan? What is the enduring appeal of 007?   Or on the other hand do you think it's time for James Bond to put away his Walter PPK?  Let us know and we'll use your comments on GMT with David Eades at 1100GMT

Astronomers in Australia are officially starting up a key part of the world's biggest radio telescope tasked with surveying outer space and probing the origins of stars and galaxies.  The Australian Square Kilometre Array Pathfinder in Western Australia's outback has 36 antennas with a diameter of 12m  each.  The US $155m telescope is expected to capture radio images.
The BBC's Focus on Africa TV programme has uncovered a number of abuses in a mental health institution in the Ghanaian capital, Accra http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19836287
Behind the scenes at with the BBC at the Denver Presidential debate

Link Title: How Love Me Do inspired a generation
Message: Coming up on Impact. After deaths near the border, Turkey hits targets inside Syria - for the first time. Despite calls for restraint, the government in Ankara gets approval from parliament to authorise cross-border military operations. And, "Love me do" - how 2 chords, 3 words and 4 men changed pop music forever. That's all coming up on Impact 1400 BST.

Link Title: Key moments: First US presidential debate
Message: Today on GMT with David Eades at 1200 GMT. With an audience of 50 million to impress, has Romney gained ground on Obama in the first of the televised presidential debates? Plus, We've loved them ever since, can you believe it's 50 years since the Beatles released their first single?

Link Title: BBC News: Mile High Spin in Denver
Message: What were the best moments for Obama and Romney at the first presidential debate? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19825146  We spoke to Romney-backers Rudy Giuliani and Orrin Hatch as well as Obama staffers Jim Messina and David Axelrod in "Spin Alley."   http://youtu.be/Wz4B4ehiBVc
Join us on our live page http://bbc.in/SrcSxK and follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS http://bbc.in/SrcUG1 for our coverage of tonight's US presidential debate from Denver, Colorado

Turkish artillery has fired on positions inside Syria after shells from Syria killed five people in a southern Turkish border town http://bbc.in/SqQu7T  A woman and her three children were among those killed earlier when the shells, apparently fired by Syrian government forces, hit Akcakale. Turkey's response marks the first time it has fired into Syria during the 18-month-long uprising against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

We are in Denver, Colorado for the first debate of the 2012 US presidential race http://bbc.in/SqyNoS  Join us tonight on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest from our team on the ground in Colorado and our American correspondents http://bbc.in/SqyNoM  Mark Mardell, the BBC's North America editor asks: Do the US presidential debates matter? http://bbc.in/SqyPgm How do you prepare for a presidential debate? http://bbc.in/SqyNoI Do you think you can predict the electoral college? http://bbc.in/SqyP02 Obama and Romney square off - at a NYC prep schoool? http://bbc.in/SqyP06

Link Title: India beat SA but exit World T20
Message: Today on The Hub with Nik Gowing. Frustrations in Iran lead to clashes. The President and government try to allay fears about a national currency with increasingly less value. Plus, the fury against India's cricket captain after the Indian cricket team wins, but has to bow out of the World Twenty20. That and more on The Hub.

Link Title: Will we ever… travel faster than the speed of light?
Message: It is a favourite of science fiction... but could we ever travel faster than the speed of light? Jennifer Ouellette discovers that although we would need to bend the laws of physics, this hasn't stopped physicists from throwing in the towel on the idea. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20121003-can-we-travel-faster-than-light

Hello, on Impact we discuss the shocking pictures from Aleppo today - the Syrian government is blaming opposition car bombs for the devastation caused by a series of explosions but the nature of the damage does raise other questions. Join us as we piece together the latest information at 1400 BST. Mishal

Coming up on GMT with David Eades. Obama versus Romney. The race for the White House heats up ahead of the first Presidential debate. Plus, Hamas accused of a litany of atrocities in their treatment of detainees in Gaza - we hear from a victim and from Hamas. Join David at 1200 GMT BST.

UK engineers are developing a system to harpoon rogue or redundant satellites and pull them out of the sky http://bbc.in/Smhh5g  Do you think it will work?   Tonight on BBC World News America on PBS we'll look at this technology and other news from around the globe, including:  - Iran's currency losing value http://bbc.in/Smhjdd - The state of the US economy from the streets of Chicago  - JP Morgan Chase sued for $20bn http://bbc.in/Smhjdj - Keepsakes & commercials from the campaign trail http://bbc.in/Smhjdf  Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/Smhh5e

Ever wanted to travel to Robinson Crusoe's island? http://bbc.in/Rayh9Y  Join us on a visit to the real island that inspired the novel - even though it bears little resemblance to its fictional counterpart.

Do you have a beloved piece of American political memorabilia? http://bbc.in/Sm12oO  Meet people from the Museum of the Moving Image and the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History who are preserving and digitising campaign adverts and keepsakes for future generations in this week's edition of Living Online.

Yesterday we asked you if new voter ID rules in various US states would keep people like Elbert and Albert Green from the polls http://bbc.in/Rag6B1  Today, a judge in Pennsylvania has stopped new ID requirements for voters from taking effect before November's presidential election http://bbc.in/Rag4t7  What does this mean for the candidates?

President Mikheil Saakashvili has admitted his party has lost Georgia's parliamentary election, in a live TV announcement.  He said the Georgian Dream bloc of his main rival, billionaire tycoon Bidzina Ivanishvili, had won Monday's election.  Victory for Mr Ivanishvili means the first democratic transfer of power in Georgia's post-Soviet history.

Link Title: Life on the real Robinson Crusoe Island
Message: Think of the island on which Robinson Crusoe is shipwrecked in Daniel Defoe's famous book and you're likely to think of a sun-drenched Caribbean idyll with sandy beaches and palm trees.   But the island that supposedly inspired the book is nothing like that. It's in the Pacific, nearly 700km off the coast of Chile, and is frequently shrouded in mist.

Turning air into liquid may offer a solution to one of the great challenges in engineering - how to store energy.  The Institution of Mechanical Engineers says liquid air can compete with batteries and hydrogen to store excess energy generated from renewables.

More than half of Australia's Great Barrier Reef has disappeared in the past 27 years, according to a new study by scientists.  Various factors, including cyclones, coral bleaching and the Crown of Thorns starfish, have been blamed.

A collision between two passenger boats off Hong Kong has left dozens of people dead.  One of the boats was carrying more than 120 people to a fireworks display when it half-sank following a collision.  A large-scale air and sea search for survivors is still continuing.

Will new voter ID laws keep US voters from the polls? http://bbc.in/R7SJrM  Fourteen US states have introduced voter ID laws designed to prevent fraud in November's elections. Critics claim the restrictions will keep people from the polls, especially poor and minority voters. The BBC's Kate Dailey visited a driving licence office in Philadelphia to take a closer look at the process of getting identification in Pennsylvania.   Are you confused about the US presidential race?  Here are the five things you need to know http://bbc.in/R7SM73

Link Title: FLYBOARD IN ACTION - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Now, If you don't know yet what a Flyboard is, you're going to want to take a look at these pictures.   It's a combination between a jet ski and a jet pack and here it is at a demonstration in Australia. The Flyboard is attached to a jetski by a hose that pumps water to keep it aloft and riders use their feet to control the direction and their hands to keep it stable.   If you want one, a flyboard is a snip at around $12000.

Huge traffic jams have failed to dampen the mid-Autumn Festival in China.  Around 85 million travellers were estimated to have taken advantage of levies on many toll roads being lifted for the first time at the start of the eight-day national holiday, known as the Golden Week.  The festival has been celebrated since the early Tang Dynasty and symbolises good harvest.

Link Title: Iran rial hits record dollar low
Message: In The Hub with Nik Gowing: Iran's currency is reported to have fallen to a record low against the dollar. Also, the attack on the American consulate in Libya fuels debate during the US presidential election campaign. Join us at 1700 BST.

Link Title: 'Still at war' 50 years after ending campus segregation
Message: In 1962 James Meredith enrolled as the first African American student at the segregated University of Mississippi.  White students and anti-desegregation supporters protested against his enrolment by rioting on the Oxford campus.   Fifty years on he tells the BBC why he still feels "at war against a system of white supremacy".

The world needs to do more to prepare for the impact of a rapidly ageing population, the UN has warned - particularly in developing countries.   Within 10 years the number of people aged over 60 will pass one billion, a report by the UN Population Fund said.

Link Title: South Korean rapper tops UK chart
Message: One of the leading figures in the Korean music industry joins us live on Impact today to talk K-Pop - is 'Gangnam Style' starting a trend or will we look back and see it's success as just a momentary breakthrough into Western charts. Are you a fan? Mishal

Guns used by US gangsters Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow, who died in a hail of police bullets in 1934, have sold at auction for $504,000.  The guns were part of the RR Auction, entitled American Gangsters, Outlaws and Lawmen, taking place in the US state of New Hampshire on Sunday.
Filming on-air trails for the series with Executive Producer Sarah Macdonald

The Mishal Husain Meets team has been filming in Singapore, with a new studio look for Series 2 of the interview show. You'll be able to see it on air from 3rd November, with the lineup of Asian personalities as follows: Sauber Motorsport CEO Monisha Kaltenborn, singer Anggun, TV celebrity Chef Wan, businessman Sandiaga Uno and award-winning Chinese actress Zhang Jingchu.

Islamist militants in Somalia say they have withdrawn from their southern stronghold of Kismayo, following an African Union (AU) military attack http://bbc.in/PMKYZ3  Kenyan and Somali forces launched a beach assault on al-Shabab's last major bastion on Friday but encountered fierce resistance.

Join us tonight on BBC World News America on PBS - coming to you from São Paulo, Brazil http://bbc.in/PLlV8J  Katty Kay will look at the challenges facing the education system in Brazil as it tries to keep pace with the growth of their economy. And we'll meet a surfer making waves in the nation's fashion scene.   Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/PLlT0G

Link Title: Bo Xilai accused of China crimes
Message: Top Chinese politician Bo Xilai has been expelled from the Communist Party and will face justice, state media say.  Mr Bo, the ex-Communist Party leader in the city of Chongqing, is accused of abuse of power and corruption.

World leaders at the General Assembly have criticised the UN for its lack of decisive action to resolve the Syrian conflict.  BBC World will look back over the comments made at the General Assembly this week and quiz our Middle East Editor Jeremy Bowen.  Do you feel the UN is suffering from paralysis as the humanitarian crisis continues to deteriorate in Syria? What would you like to ask our Middle East Editor about the role of the UN in the conflict so far?

Link Title: War risk worth taking for Syria safe zones, says Turkey
Message: The United Nation's failure to agree a way to deal with the worsening civil war in Syria has dominated the diplomatic week at the General Assembly in New York.   Turkey's Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu has called for the establishment of safe zones in northern Syria  He tells the BBC that the risk is worth taking to get humanitarian access to the huge numbers of displaced people.

Link Title: Nineteen die in Nepal plane crash
Message: Coming up on GMT with Naga Munchetty: The last major stronghold of Islamist militants in Somalia is stormed by government troops. Also a plane heading for the Everest region crashes in Nepal's capital, killing everyone on board. Join us at 1200 BST.

African Union forces have launched a beach assault and taken control of parts of Kismayo, the last major Islamist militant bastion in southern Somalia, Kenya's military says.  The port city has been a stronghold of the al-Qaeda-aligned group al-Shabab.

The Civil War Battle of Antietam was one of the bloodiest days in American history, with 23,000 dead, wounded or missing in a matter of hours. One hundred fifty years later, a group gathered to remember the battle - by re-enacting it. The BBC's Daniel Nasaw joined them http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19638398

Link Title: Should there be child-free zones on planes?
Message: An airline says it will offer baby-free "quiet zones" on its flights. Should all planes and trains follow suit, or do adults need to learn to live with child passengers?

Link Title: Dalai Lama hopeful of Chinese change
