Message: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, says he hopes for a new Chinese approach to Tibet when new leaders are appointed in Beijing.  The Tibetan exile movement meets at its headquarters in Dharamsala in India to discuss its future strategy, amid mounting anxiety at the number of Tibetans setting themselves on fire in protest at China's continued control.

A well-known Hong Kong billionaire has offered $65m to any man able to woo and marry his lesbian daughter.  Property and shipping tycoon Cecil Chao publicly promised the "marriage bounty" after reports emerged that his daughter had wed her long-term girlfriend.  On Impact today Lucy Hockings speaks to his daughter to find out what she thinks about her father's plan.

Spain is due to set out its austerity budget for 2013 later, against a backdrop of a deteriorating economy and 25% unemployment rate.  Madrid is expected to outline 39bn euros worth of savings, tax rises, and structural reforms.  It comes amid further protests this week, and growing expectations that Spain will seek a bailout from its eurozone partners.
What is the middle in "middle class"?  How many jobs did Obama create?  Who are Romney's 47%?   We crunch the numbers behind the US presidential race http://bbc.in/OVT0Sc

Later this week we'll be bringing you BBC World News America from Sao Paulo, Brazil. Today Katty Kay visited a school looking at whether the country's education system can keep up with economic growth or if it threatens to hold the nation back.     Tell us what you think -   How can the country best prepare its students for the future?     Tonight on BBC World News America on PBS we'll look at news from around the globe, including:   - Rape as a weapon in Syria's conflict  - Morsi at the UN General Assembly  - Protests on the streets of Greece  - JK Rowling's latest work    Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area     Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://twitter.com/bbcnewsus

The growth of the Hispanic population in California could reach a new milestone as early as 2013, an analysis of Census data shows http://bbc.in/OVuiSc  By next year, immigrants and their descendants from Central and South America could become the biggest ethnic group in the country's most populous state - surpassing whites for the first time. But Hispanics still trail other ethnic groups in important aspects of society.   The BBC’s Franz Strasser went to Southern California to hear from experts about where the Hispanic community stands today.

Check out this extraordinary view of the Universe taken by the Hubble Space Telescope.    Called the eXtreme Deep Field, the picture captures a mass of galaxies stretching back almost to the time when the first stars began to shine.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19728375
3D printers that create artificial limbs, cheap drugs and replacement organs could radically change medicine in the developing world. But can this technology deliver? BBC Future investigates.

You might think that winning the lottery happens only once in the lifetime but a family from Norway has already had a HAT-TRICK of national lottery wins.   Last week, 19-year-old Tord became the latest member of the Oksnes family to hit the jackpot meaning that in the last six years they have won a total of more than $3.9 million.
Former ANC Youth leader Julius Malema has vowed to clear his name after being charged in court with money laundering.  Does the case have implications for the ANC's reputation?

Coming up on GMT with George Alagiah - We'll be live from Athens as thousands of workers have walked out in the first general strike since the country's coalition government was formed.  Also BBC's Fergal Keane has a special report about allegations of sexual violence, including rape, taking place within Syria's government detention centres.   For all that and more join us on BBC World News at 1100GMT

Link Title: Viewpoint: Manmohan Singh has stayed on too long
Message: As Indian PM Manmohan Singh turns 80, writer and historian Ramachandra Guha says he should have retired after his first term.   Do you agree?

Trade unions in Greece have begun the first general strike since the country's conservative-led coalition government came to power in June.  The 24-hour walkout is to protest at new planned spending cuts of more than 11.5bn euros.  The savings are a pre-condition to Greece receiving its next tranche of bailout funds, without which the country could face bankruptcy in weeks.

China's Premier Wen Jiabao says the nation's first aircraft carrier has "a mighty and deep significance" and is "a cause for patriotic passion" http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-19710040    But how does the the 300m (990ft) Liaoning -named after the province where it was refitted - compare to carriers from the US, France and UK?     What does the craft say to the world about Beijing's maritime ambitions?
A group of British UFO-watchers is celebrating 50 years of searching for spacecraft in the sky.     What keeps them looking for extra-terrestrial life?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19702652
Next time you complain about being stuck in traffic, spare a thought for the drivers in Brazil's biggest city, which has some of the worst congestion problems in the world.

Link Title: Viewpoint: Are Africa's women on the rise?
Message: The past 12 months have seen a series of notable successes for African women - with two Nobel Peace prizes, a second president and the first female head of the African Union Commission.   For the BBC's Africa Debate programme, Malawian women's rights campaigner Jessie Kabwila asks if Africa's women are on the rise.

Link Title: UNGA BAN KI MOON - ISRAEL/PALESTINE CONFLICT - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: The United Nations General Assembly has opened in New York with leaders from around the world in attendance.  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon highlighted the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, saying the door may be closing "for good" on a two-state solution, as the continued growth of Jewish settlements undercuts peace.

On Impact with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT - We'll have the latest as talks aimed at diffusing tensions between China and Japan over disputed islands make little progress. And we'll also bring you President Obama's address to the UN General Assembly where he's expected to take a tough line on Iran's nuclear programme. For all that and more join lucy on Impact.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19709355

VIDEO: The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have dramatically increased the number of troops who are now suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. In the US where 300,000 troops are estimated to be affected, the military is ploughing millions into developing ways of helping more veterans cope when returning home from long deployments. Alastair Leithead visited the US military tele-health technology lab in Washington State.

This summer was full of feel-good stories about sporting success at the Olympics and Paralympics, and the celebrations of the Queen's Jubilee - but that feels like a distant memory now it seems we're back to financial problems and political scandals.       A new publication called 'The Positive' plans to fight back by covering mostly happy headlines and good news stories.     So, is there too much negativity in the press?   Is it the job of the press to balance out positive and negative stories?   What's the happiest news story you've seen in the press today / this week?  Is there a natural negativity to the "news"?    Let us know what you think and we'll use some of your comments on GMT with George Alagiah.
INTERACTIVE: A guide to Camp Bastion, a sprawling, well-fortified British base in the desert in southern Afghanistan, which is home to almost 30,000 military personnel and civilians.

Link Title: IMAGES OF FAMILIES IN CHINA - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: PHOTO MONTAGE:  Take a look at these images of families in China. The photographer persuaded people to empty their houses and pose with all their worldly possessions.   Huang Qing-jun spent nearly a decade travelling to remote parts of the country for the project. The results show the enormous social change that has come in a generation.

Link Title: How threatening is the new coronavirus?
Message: A new respiratory illness similar to the Sars virus that spread globally in 2003 and killed hundreds of people has been identified in a man who is being treated in Britain.  Here we take a look this new virus and examine how concerned should we be about it?

VIDEO: While many of the casualties in the Syrian conflict are civilians, the region of Latakia in the west of the country is seeing more of its men die on the government's side.  The area is a stronghold for President Assad's minority Alawite Muslim sect, and as rebels claim further victories against government troops funerals in the region are becoming more frequent.  Lyse Doucet, who was granted official access to the area, reports from the village of Addalia.

There is controversy in Germany over an attempt by the Catholic church to keep its members paying a church tax that give a very substantial income to the Vatican.   Germany - and it is not the only country to do so - has a system by which those officially registered as belonging to certain churches levies a substantial tax that goes to that church.   But, many Catholics have decided to deregister and opt out of the tax - prompting the church to decree that they can't get a religious burial or take holy communion.  Let us know what you think.

7 civilians have been shot dead by Kenyan troops advancing towards the al-Shabab stronghold of Kismayo, a Somali army spokesman tells the BBC.  The Kenyans are part of the pro-government African Union mission in Somalia, which says it is investigating the incident.  The alleged shooting happened about 50km from Kismayo, the largest city still in militant hands.
VISIONS OF INDIA: Two exhibitions, organized by Delhi-based arts organization Tasveer, showcase the work of some of the world’s best photographers on India.

The technology firm Foxconn,  has confirmed that 40 people were injured in a fight at one of its manufacturing sites in China.  Foxconn supplies products to many of the world's electronic giants, including Apple. It's previously been criticised for its working conditions, after a spate of suicides among staff.   This time, it says a personal dispute among workers in a dormitory like this at its plant at Tiyuan escalated into a fight involving 2000 workers.

The US state department has condemned a Pakistani minister's offer of $100,000 for the death of the American maker of an anti-Islam film.  It said the step was "inflammatory and inappropriate".  Railways Minister Ghulam Ahmad Bilour made the offer after a wave of protests against the film across Pakistan and the wider Muslim world.

Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident and Nobel Peace Prize winner, spent most of the past two decades under house arrest in Rangoon, thousands of miles from her husband and children in the UK. She talks to the BBC about the human effect on her and her family.

The interim Libyan leader, Mohammed Magarief, has vowed to disband all illegal militias in the aftermath of the US ambassador's death this month.  All camps and militias not under the authority of the government would be dissolved and no unauthorised checkpoints allowed, he said.  But the militias that emerged during the fight to topple Muammar Gaddafi last year still remain a powerful force.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19690210

Link Title: Viewpoint: Should we send humans to Mars?
Message: Dr Alexander Kumar - who has been overwintering at Concordia Station, Antarctica - asks whether we should send people to the Red Planet given our poor record managing this one.  Much like the interior of Antarctica, Mars remains inhospitable.

Link Title: Dutch party invite ends in riot
Message: A party invitation which went viral on Facebook ended in rioting and injury after thousands of revellers descended on a small town in the Netherlands.   Haren had been braced for trouble all week after what should have been an invite to a small-scale celebration was passed on to 30,000 people.  The girl whose 16th birthday was being celebrated had not set her Facebook event to "private".

The militia suspected of killing the US ambassador to Libya nearly two weeks ago has been driven out of its base in the eastern city of Benghazi.  Police and protesters stormed the HQ of the Islamist group Ansar al-Sharia.  The attack on the US consulate was triggered by an amateur video made in the US which mocks Islam.

US space shuttle Endeavour is making a flypast of California landmarks today as it heads to retirement at a Los Angeles museum http://bbc.in/Pvg6Mk  The 75-ton ship has already passed San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge and throngs of people are camped out in Griffith Observatory waiting for it to pass by the Hollywood Sign.    In this Nasa photo, taken this morning, Endeavour is flying over Rosamond Dry Lake just east of the town of Rosamond, California.

US space shuttle Endeavour is making a flypast of California landmarks today as it heads to retirement at a Los Angeles museum http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19677972     The 75-ton ship has already passed San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge and throngs of people are camped out in Griffith Observatory waiting for it to pass by the Hollywood Sign http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19681711    In this Nasa photo, taken this morning, Endeavour is flying over Rosamond Dry Lake just east of the town of Rosamond, California.

Link Title: Is this Europe's most under-rated city?
Message: Is there a new Belgrade emerging? The city now boasts music festivals, nightclubs, pedestrianised streets and designer boutiques - What's your view as Serbia prepares to rejoin the European mainstream?

Two cinema buildings have been attacked and ransacked in the northern Pakistani city of Peshawar during fresh protests over an anti-Islam amateur film produced in the US.  Although the Pakistan government called for peaceful protests during a "special day of love" for the Prophet Muhammed, clashes were being reported across the country.

On GMT today with Naga Munchetty: The Pakistani government urges demonstrators against a reportedly anti-Islamic film to reject violence. Also the members of a breakaway Amish group who are facing prison terms for hair and beard-cutting attacks on fellow members of their community. Join us 1200 BST

The last of 33,000 extra US soldiers sent to Afghanistan by President Barack Obama more than three years ago have left the country, the Pentagon says.  They were deployed with the aim of pushing back the Taliban and allowing Afghan government forces time to take over the security of their own country.

Canada for president? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19594334    Meet two comedians trying to convince Americans to choose a real outsider as the next US president: the entire country of Canada.     The BBC recently joined them during a "campaign stop" in New York City where they explained why they think the US has much to learn from its neighbour to the north.

Nasa's Curiosity rover has now driven 289m (950ft) since its landing on the Red Planet some six weeks ago http://bbc.in/OHfDtD  The vehicle has about 200m still left to cover to get to a location dubbed Glenelg.   Have you been following Curiosity's progress? http://bbc.in/OHfFle  What do you hope we find on Mars?

Miners in South Africa are returning to work at the Marikana platinum complex, which was the scene of violent protests.  Striking miners reached an agreement with owners Lonmin on Tuesday. It will see their salaries rise by up to 22%. But is this the end of South Africa's industrial unrest?

Fireflies dancing beneath the stars, the last transit of Venus for 105 years and giant swirling galaxies deep in space.  Take a look at some of the awe-inspiring images taken from the 2012 Astronomy Photographer of the Year competition.

The appearance on YouTube of an anti-Islam film produced in the US has sparked protests and attacks across parts of the Middle East, Africa and Asia, in which more than 28 people have died.  The furore has prompted debate about balancing freedom of speech with freedom of religion.  Should self-censorship and regulation be imposed in order to appease the sensitivities of religious groups?

A team of doctors has flown out to Afghanistan after a British servicewoman gave birth to a boy having not realised she was pregnant.  So-called denied, or undetected, pregnancies are rare but in some cases women do not show a bump and continue to have periods for the duration of the pregnancy.

Opposition parties and trade unions in India are staging a day-long strike over plans to open the country's retail sector to global supermarket chains.  Workers blocked railway tracks in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar states, and the opposition strongholds of Calcutta and Bangalore were virtually shut down.

The health of Alaska's economy and people is intertwined with the health of its king salmon - Alaskans depend on the species for both commerce and food. When this year's king salmon season yielded one of the lowest returns on record, officials clamped down on fishing statewide. The slow season has devastated the state's commercial businesses and tourism - and has even left some user groups without enough food this winter http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19349265

China's leader-in-waiting has said Japan should "rein in its behaviour" and stop undermining Chinese sovereignty, state media have reported.  His comments follow days of sometimes violent anti-Japanese protests in China over a chain of disputed islands in the East China Sea.

An ancient scrap of papyrus makes explicit reference to Jesus having a wife, according to a renowned expert in Christian history.   Harvard divinity professor Karen King believes the provocative find could spark debate over the role of women within Christianity.  But the announcement has sparked scepticism from some theologians.

There has been further heavy fighting in the Syrian capital, Damascus, and the northern city of Aleppo.  Activists said government forces were closing in on Hajar al-Aswad, a southern suburb of Damascus, and the situation for residents was desperate.  Earlier, Amnesty International warned that indiscriminate air and artillery strikes were causing a dramatic rise in civilian casualties in Idlib and Hama.

Link Title: How adult adoptions bolster family firms
Message: On Impact with Karin Giannone: The man likely to be China's next leader meets the US Defence Secretary to discuss relations between the two superpowers. Also, why so many families in Japan are adopting men in their 20s and 30s. Join us at 1400 BST.

Link Title: Suu Kyi seeks easing of sanctions
Message: Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who is visiting the US, has said she supports further easing of sanctions against Burma's government.  She made the comments after talks with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.  Western sanctions against Burma have already been loosened since the new government began enacting a series of political and social reforms.

"It once was a small step... now it's six big wheels"    http://bbc.in/OCNFPJ Meet the team of social media gurus behind the irreverent Twitter account @MarsCuriosity and see how they attract people with playful humour in the name of science.  Does social media engagement get you excited about science?

Coming up on The Hub: NATO-led forces in Afghanistan are sharply scaling back joint operations with the Afghan army. Will this measure stop the recent surge in so-called "green-on-blue" attacks? And a French court blocks the future publication of topless photos of the Duchess of Cambridge. Join Nik Gowing at 1700 BST.

On Impact with Lucy Hockings: Asia's two biggest economies at loggerheads over disputed islands in the East China sea. We'll assess how damaging the protests are to China-Japan relations and what the economic cost might be.  Join us at 14BST.

Middle age starts much later than previously thought, according to a new survey of people over the age of fifty.   Although seven out of ten early 50-somethings in the UK defined themselves as middle-aged, a sizeable minority, nearly one in five, thought middle age did not begin until after the age of 60.   So is middle age really a state of mind?
Nato restricts operations with Afghan forces following a string of deadly attacks on its personnel by rogue Afghan security forces.

Journalist and author Bob Woodward will be joining us tonight on BBC World News America on PBS. Mr. Woodward will discuss the role of foreign policy in the upcoming presidential election.  We'll also take a look at news from around the world - including:  - The aerial assault on Syria's largest city http://bbc.in/OAOk46 - Tensions between China and Japan http://bbc.in/OAOj0b -  Royals seek to ban Closer images http://bbc.in/OAOj0d - Exploring Antarctica in Winter http://bbc.in/OAOk48  Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsUS for the latest breaking news and feature stories from our staff and correspondents working in North America http://bbc.in/OAOk42

"Why is the whole world watching and doing nothing? The dead are laying in the streets” - FSA commander   http://bbc.in/OAHeww  The BBC's Paul Wood is in Aleppo, Syria's largest city, as aerial attacks continue to destroy the city.
Burma's government releases more than 500 prisoners, raising hopes that political detainees may be among them.

On The Hub with Nik Gowing: Deepening anger in the Arab world over the amateur video made in the United States, which mocks Islam. Also, the British explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes is to lead the first team on foot across Antarctica during the southern winter. Join us at at 1700 BST.
More protests against an anti-Islam film made in the US erupt around the Muslim world, after Hezbollah's leader urged followers not to stay silent.

Hello - After Canon and Panasonic, Uniqlo is the latest Japanese brand to reveal how its operations in China are being affected by widespread anti-Japan fervour. Anger over a long-running territorial dispute seems to be rising, so is it all now getting out of hand? We discuss on Impact. Mishal

BBC Middle East editor Jeremy Bowen, on a reporting trip to Libya, Egypt and Lebanon, will answer your questions in a live Twitter Q&A on Monday 17 September.  He'll take questions on the current unrest caused by a US-made film that mocks Islam, the death of the US ambassador to Libya and three others in an attack on the Benghazi consulate, and tension between Israel and Iran, as well as what it's like to be a reporter covering the region.
A Russian Soyuz space capsule successfully lands in Kazakhstan with its three-man crew after they spent 123 days at the International Space Station.

Dozens, and possibly hundreds, of gay men have been killed in Iraq since the US invasion, according to a 2009 report by Human Rights Watch http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19557895  Iraq's Human Rights Ministry says it cannot help gay people because they are not considered a minority in Iraq. A spokesman for Prime Minister Nouri Maliki denies any organised persecution and says gay Iraqis should "live their lives a normal way".  The trailer below is a short introduction to the third video in the series. Follow the link above for the full report  Join the conversation on Twitter with the hashtag #GayInIraq  http://youtu.be/pIOxtrFaB3M

Friday prayers  - and a fourth day running of violence and protest across the Muslim World. The fury that the film ridiculing the Prophet Mohamed has sparked has led to attacks on other Western embassies  - including the British and German missions in Sudan. Also, More on the Palace fury as topless pictures of the Duchess of Cambridge are published in France. Join Tim Willcox 1700 BST.

Coming up on Impact. Protesters storm the British and German embassies in Sudan - over a film deemed to be offensive to Muslims. The German Embassy is on fire. Plus, Violent protests against the anti-Muslim film continue outside the US Embassy in the Egyptian capital Cairo. Join Lucy Hockings at 1400 BST for the latest.

Coming up on GMT. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are considering taking legal action after topless photos of Kate are published in France. Plus, The Pope arrives in Lebanon for his first visit there for fifteen years and he brings a message of peace. Join Zeinab Badawi at 1200 BST.

Mexican officials say marines have captured a man believed to be one of the country's most wanted drug lords, Jorge Eduardo Costilla Sanchez http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-19582382    Mr Costilla, a suspected Gulf cartel leader, was detained in the northern state of Tamaulipas, they said. His capture follows the arrest last week of the suspected head of a rival Gulf faction, Mario Cardenas Guillen. Link Title: Dangers of being a US diplomat
Message: Coming up on The Hub with Lyse Doucet. Angry protests spread across a number of Muslim countries against a film said to mock the prophet Mohammad. And, a sharp fall in the number of children under five dying across the world - that's according to the UN children's agency UNICEF. Join Lyse at 1700 BST.

Protests against an anti-Islam film made in the US are spreading across the Middle East and North Africa http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19584734  This comes after Tuesday's attack on the US Consulate office in Benghazi where the US ambassador to Libya was killed.   In Yemen, demonstrators briefly stormed the grounds of the US embassy in Sanaa and burned the US flag, but were driven back by security forces.  In Egypt, 70 people were injured in protests, the health ministry said. Protests were also reported in Morocco, Sudan and Tunisia.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are currently on their Diamond Jubilee tour of South East Asia and the South Pacific. Do you live in the region? How do you feel about the royal visit? Are the Royal Family relevant in your part of the world? Let us know and we will look at some of your comments today on Impact with Lucy Hockings, 1400 BST.

Link Title: Cash thrown from car in US chase
Message: Coming up on GMT with David Eades. Anti-American outrage spreading across the Middle East as another Embassy is attacked. The US compound in Yemen's capital the latest target as a film about the Prophet Mohammed provokes further violence. Plus, Money for nothing, as a bank robbery becomes a free for all in this American getaway chase. Join David 1200 BST.

The firing of the biggest rocket in Britain for some 20 years will take place next month at the Aerohub, Newquay Cornwall Airport http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15460965    The hybrid rocket is being developed for the Bloodhound SuperSonic Car, which will attempt to reach 1,000mph (1,610Km/h) in 2014. Message: In post-occupation Iraq being gay, or even looking gay, can be a death sentence http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19557895  A BBC investigation has found that law enforcement agencies are involved in ongoing, systematic and organised violence against gay people, while the government refuses to acknowledge it. Hello - as I write this the death toll from the factory fire in Karachi is rising, making it Pakistan's worst industrial disaster in recent times. The reports are horrifying - some victims suffocated, others were burned alive. Stay with the BBC as we bring you the latest. Mishal

Coming up on GMT with David Eades. America's Ambassador to Libya is killed in an attack on the US consulate in the city of Benghazi. Officials say his death came in violent protests against a film said to be offensive to the Prophet Mohammed. Plus, Germany's Constitutional Court says there's nothing to stop the country taking part in the Euro Bailout Fund. Join David 1200 BST.

How do you become a social media and web sensation?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19548517    Meet the man behind the Humans of New York photo blog and hear how his photography project made him an unlikely celebrity on the streets of the city.

How do you think the world has changed since the 9/11 attacks? We'll be discussing that on Impact as the 11th anniversary is commemorated in the United States. Many of us can remember exactly where we were when we heard the news that day, so do share your thoughts. Mishal

Coming up on GMT with Daivd Eades. The balance sheet from Beijing - Premier Wen lists China's extraordinary economic progress during his time in office. Finally, Andy Murray wins his first Grand Slam final and the first by a British male tennis player for 76 years. That's at 1200 BST.

Around 80 new words have been added to the Collins online dictionary. Some of the new additions, such as "blootered" and "frenemy", have been added after thousands of suggestions from the public were considered. What would you have suggested?

"I'll do it for one summer... Now, here we are 22 years later." http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19516220  While sports stadiums around the world get more and more high tech with each passing year - Fenway Park, the longtime home of Major League Baseball's Boston Red Sox, still relies on a manual scoreboard which is operated inside a 37ft (11.2m) high wall called the "Green Monster".  Meet the score keeper who has been clattering metal numbers in there for 22 years.

And UK Political corrrespondent, Naomi Grimley, assess what to expect as Britain's politicians return to work after the summer break.
African leaders gather in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa for the funeral of long-serving PM Meles Zenawi, who died suddenly in August
An imam is held in Pakistan accused of planting burnt pages of the Koran on a Christian girl who has been detained on charges of blasphemy.

US songwriter Hal David, who wrote dozens of hits with collaborator Burt Bacharach, has died at the age of 91. The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers said he had died in Los Angeles from complications from a stroke.

Link Title: Egypt TV chief's plot trial opens
Message: An Egyptian TV station owner and presenter has denied calling for the murder of President Mohammed Mursi.  "I merely criticised President Mursi," Tawfiq Ukasha told judges at the start of his trial in the capital, Cairo.  Mr Ukasha's al-Faraeen channel was ordered off the air last month after a programme critical of Mr Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood that backs him.

Italian Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini has described the Roman Catholic Church as being "200 years behind" the times.  The cardinal died on Friday, aged 85.  Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera has published his last interview, recorded in August, in which he said: "The Church is tired... our prayer rooms are empty."   Martini, once tipped as a future pope, urged the Church to recognise its errors and to embark on a radical path of change, beginning with the Pope  Do you agree with Cardinal Martini's comments?

Thousands of people could be at risk from a deadly virus in California's Yosemite National Park that has already claimed two lives, officials say. Four other cases of Hantavirus, a rare lung disease, have been reported.

Thousands of people could be at risk from a deadly virus in California's Yosemite National Park that has already claimed two lives, officials say. Four other cases of Hantavirus, a rare lung disease, have been reported.
This week, BBC Travel examined how the strange, harsh frozen continent of Antarctica can sustain such varied forms of life. Have you ever dreamed of visiting Antarctica?

VIDEO: Could this be Australia's best Paralympian ever?   The Olympics sought to 'Inspire a Generation', but the Paralympics is all about changing perceptions.  According to Australian Paralympian Matthew Cowdrey, helping to change stereotypes is perhaps his greatest achievement.

A 7.6-magnitude earthquake has struck off the eastern Philippine island of Samar, causing tsunami evacuations and power cuts.    The regional tsunami warnings have now been lifted.    The earthquake struck at a depth of 33km (20 miles) at 20:47 local time (12:47 GMT), the US Geological Survey said.    The quake was said to be long and violent, with some roads and bridges reported to be damaged.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19435229

Mexico's presidential runner-up Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has refused to recognise a court ruling upholding July's election and called for a mass demonstration.  The left-winger said the country's highest electoral tribunal made an illegitimate decision.  Mr Lopez Obrador had accused winner Enrique Pena Nieto of using illicit money to buy votes and media coverage.  But the tribunal ruled that he had not produced enough evidence of wrongdoing.

In a secluded section of Raleigh, North Carolina live 16 carefully selected canine recruits for a high-priority US military project. Their mission: to detect and neutralise roadside bombs – the leading killer of US troops in Afghanistan. BBC Future takes an exclusive look at the high-priority military project to see how it plans to create a better bomb dog. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120829-upgrading-the-dogs-of-war

Link Title: Syria: The story of the conflict
Message: INTERACTIVE: Take a look at our interactive guide to how anti-government protests in Syria led to a bloody internal conflict in which thousands have lost their lives.

South Africa's justice minister has demanded an explanation after 270 miners were charged with the murder of their colleagues who were shot by police.  The decision had "induced a sense of shock, panic and confusion" among South Africans, Jeff Radebe said.  State prosecutors charged the miners under the apartheid-era "common purpose" doctrine.  The decision has already been condemned by constitutional lawyers.

Chelsea Football Club owner Roman Abramovich wins a legal battle with exiled Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky.  Mr Berezovsky, 65, claimed to have been a business partner of Mr Abramovich, 45, and accused him of a breach of trust and breach of contract.  He said he was intimidated into selling shares in Russian oil company Sibneft for a "fraction of their true worth" and claimed more than £3bn in damages.  But the London Commercial Court judge Mrs Justice Gloster ruled against him.

A Chinese dissident convicted of subversion charges with the help of evidence provided by US internet giant Yahoo is released from jail.  Wang Xiaoning was freed early on Friday morning, his wife, Yu Ling, told the BBC by telephone.  Mr Wang, who was detained in 2002, served his 10-year sentence in a Beijing jail.  Yahoo drew widespread criticism for providing information linking him to emails and political writings.

Link Title: Tokyo court deals win for Samsung
Message: A court in Tokyo has ruled that Samsung Electronics did not infringe on patents held by Apple, a victory for the South Korean company.  The patent was related to transferring media content between devices.  It comes after Samsung lost a key patent case in the US last week and was ordered to pay more than $1bn in damages.  .

Mitt Romney has pledged "to restore the promise of America" as he accepted the Republican presidential nomination at the party's convention in Florida.  - Mitt Romney vows to restore America's promise http://bbc.in/PRfPoy - Clint Eastwood: 'We own this country' http://bbc.in/PRfRg8 - Convention-goers talk praise George W Bush's legacy http://bbc.in/PRfRga

Take a look at some of our photos from the convention and join us tonight on your local PBS broadcaster. Message: "They're not an entrenched base for any party. No party can take it for granted." http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19426565  As Senator Marco Rubio, the Republican party's most prominent Hispanic figure, gets set to introduce Mitt Romney tonight - we meet two Mexican-American men trying to change the perception of the Hispanic voter.   We also took to the convention floor to ask:  What can the Republican Party do to appeal to Hispanic voters?   Tell us what you think in the comment section below. http://youtu.be/eMsFvkeiWN4

The London 2012 Paralympic Games kicked off with an opening ceremony that starred Professor Stephen Hawking, veteran actor Sir Ian McKellen and a double amputee war veteran who rode a zip wire into the Olympic Stadium.  So what did commentators and pundits from across the world make of the show?   Did it match up to the recent opening of its sister Games?   Did you watch the opening ceremony? What did you make of it?

Link Title: UNIVERSITY VISA BAN - LMU STUDENT INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: A London university has been banned from teaching students from outside the EU after being found in violation of immigration rules, raising the risk of deportation for 2,000 of its undergraduates.  Mishal Husain was joined on Impact by Ashiqur Rahman, an undergraduate computer science student at the London Metropolitan University, who came to study here from Bangladesh.

An attack by gold miners on a group of Yanomami tribespeople in Venezuela has left up to 80 people dead, according to campaign groups.  The attack is reported to have taken place last month in the remote Irotatheri community, close to the border with Brazil.  The miners allegedly set fire to a communal house, with witnesses reporting finding burnt bodies.  The Yanomami have previously complained of miners encroaching on their lands.

Some 270 South Africans arrested during recent protests at the Marikana mine will be charged with the murder of 34 of their colleagues shot dead by police.  A prosecuting authority spokesman told the BBC that 270 workers would be tried under the "common purpose" doctrine.  Police have not been charged because a commission of inquiry would investigate their actions, the spokesman said.

Comments by Egypt's president Mohamed Mursi, in which he hit out at the "oppressive" Syrian regime at a summit in Iran, sparked a walkout by the Syrian delegation.  Mohammed Mursi, making the first visit to Iran by an Egyptian leader since 1979, said the movement had an "ethical duty" to support the uprising.

Hello - imagine being an overseas student in the UK and suddenly finding yourself at risk of deportation because of a government ruling against  your university.   That's the situation at London Metropolitan University right now, after evidence that some students had no valid visas, and there were insufficient checks on English proficiency and turning up for class.   The full story is below but let us know what you think for our discussion on Impact. Mishal

Link Title: India bag found in French Alps
Message: A bag carrying diplomatic mail from India is found after 46 years on Mont Blanc in the French Alps, close to where an Air India plane crashed in 1966.  The jute bag was recovered by a mountain rescue worker and his neighbour after some tourists spotted it on a glacier last week.  The Air India plane flying from Mumbai to New York crashed in January 1966.  All 117 people on board died.
A first-hand account of the May 2011 raid that killed Osama Bin Laden by an ex-US Navy Seal contradicts the official story, the Associated Press claims.
Hats have long been a feature of Republican National Conventions. The 2012 gathering in Tampa is no different.

In northern Florida, agricultural and independent-minded families tend to vote Republican, and pass that on down through the generations http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19402386  We spoke to three generations of one family to find out what concerns Republican voters have going into the election.  Inside the halls of the convention we asked: Are the American people willing to make the sacrifices the Republicans are asking for in Tampa?  Tell us what you think.   http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cPVYOb6pDnY

Dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed in New Orleans as Hurricane Isaac lashes the city and a nearby levee breaks http://bbc.in/POnOCV  New Orleans flood defences struggling to stop flood http://bbc.in/POnOTj Isaac as seen from the International Space Station http://bbc.in/POnOTd

Link Title: Should India abolish the death penalty?
Message: OPINION: The Indian Supreme Court has upheld the death sentence for the only surviving gunman involved in the attacks in Mumbai in 2008.   But is it time for India to abolish the death penalty?  Critics of capital punishment say, there's no evidence to show that the death penalty deters crime.  Two-thirds of the world's countries have done away with the death penalty in law or in practice.  Last year, according to Amnesty International, death sentences were imposed in 63 countries, but only 21 countries actually carried out executions.

VIDEO: NASA’s Curiosity rover is a multi-talented piece of technology - as well as taking pretty impressive snaps of Mars, it's also something of a DJ.    Is there anything it can't do?     For its latest trick, Curiosity has broadcast the singer Will.I.Am's song 'Reach for the Stars' on the red planet and beamed it back to earth -- for the listening pleasure of an audience of NASA engineers and local students.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19407396

The President of Senegal wants to abolish the country's senate and use the money to pay for the flood relief. Could this decision damage the nation's democracy? Is this the best option to help the victims of the flood ? Post your comments below

Afghan President Hamid Karzai removes intelligence chief Rahmatullah Nabil amid reports of an imminent cabinet reshuffle.  Mr Karzai's office said a decision had been taken to limit the term of the office to two years.  However, there are reports that Mr Karzai was unhappy with the agency's performance in combating the militant Taliban movement.

In April, the country marked the 18th anniversary of the first multi-racial elections that heralded the birth of the "rainbow nation".      Goodman Lepota, an 18-year-old black student, tells the BBC that some young South Africans, or "born frees", are using apartheid as an excuse for underachieving and they should move on.    Does race still matter in South Africa?    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19345289

Hello everyone, I'm back in the newsroom today for the first time since the Olympics, just as the opening ceremony of the Paralympics approaches.   The movement is growing in strength, with over 4000 athletes competing in London - but how much does their success affect attitudes to disability in their home countries? We debate on Impact. Mishal

In a rare interview with Syrian television, President Bashar Assad has vowed that his forces will win what he describes as a global war against his country.   Al-Assad has also rejected a proposal that people displaced by the conflict should be sheltered in a humanitarian buffer zone inside Syria.  The UNHCR said 5,000 refugees were now arriving at the Turkish border every day, compared to about 500 earlier this month.

Hurricane Isaac has made landfall in southern Louisiana. It's lashing coastal areas with winds of up to 130 kilometres an hour and has sent floodwaters surging.     New Orleans is braced for Isaac, exactly seven years after Hurricane Katrina. President Obama has warned residents in the hurricane's path not to "tempt fate" and to heed evacuation warnings.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19407265

Link Title: 10 things you need to know about the Paralympics
Message: After the success of the London Olympics there's unprecedented excitement about the Paralympics.   But what are the differences between the two sets of Games?

"This is the sport for the digital generation."  http://bbc.in/OI2ME7  In an age where digital technology rules all - are pro video-game players a new form of athlete?  Join us as we visit a Major League Gaming competition in the US state of North Carolina where participants compete for a $200,000 (£127,000) prize.

Link Title: BBC News - Can the Republican Party close the gender gap?
Message: Can Mitt Romney close the gender gap? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19403603  The BBC talked to female voters in Tampa, Florida, site of the Republican National Convention, about what they're thinking ahead of the election. We also asked attendees at the convention.   Tell us what you think.   http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=54vk8BOvwc8&feature=youtu.be
France opens a murder inquiry into the death of Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, French media report, after his widow alleges he was poisoned.

VIDEO: More than 4000 Paralympic athletes have begun arriving in London ahead of Wednesday's opening ceremony.  Among them are many who have been injured in conflicts around the world.   There's one athlete from Afghanistan, a country where thousands of civilians are hurt in attacks and land mines each year. Aleem Maqbool in Kabul profiles the Afghan power-lifter paralympian.

9 US troops are disciplined for incinerating scores of Korans and for urinating on the bodies of dead Taliban soldiers in Afghanistan.  They will not face criminal prosecution over the incident, which sparked rioting that claimed at least 30 lives and saw two US troops shot dead.  The investigation said there was no malicious intent to disrespect Islam.
Riots break out for a second day in the Kenyan coastal city of Mombasa, as police fire teargas to dispese protesters who loot shops to protest at the killing of a Muslim cleric.

Link Title: Virginity cream sparks Indian sex debate
Message: An Indian company has launched what it claims is the country's first vagina tightening cream, saying it will make women feel "like a virgin" again.   The company, which is selling the product for around $44USD,  says it is about empowering women, but critics say it is doing the opposite.  What do you think? Is this about the empowerment of women or is it, as some critics argue, a reinforcement of the widely held view in India that pre-marital sex is something to be frowned upon, a taboo which is even seen as sinful by some?

NASA's mobile robot "Curiosity" has beamed back more astonishing images from Mars. One of the images sent back by the rover is this 360-degree view of the landing site including the highest part of a nearby mountain called Mount Sharp http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19396270

Young people who smoke cannabis run the risk of a significant and irreversible reduction in their IQ, according to one of the largest studies ever carried out.  The findings come from a study of around 1,000 people in New Zealand.  An international team found those who started using cannabis below the age of 18 - while their brains were still developing - suffered a drop in IQ.

Link Title: Corrie case verdict due in Israel
Message: The family of an American woman,  Rachel Corrie, crushed to death by an Israeli bulldozer, have lost a civil claim for damages against the Israeli Ministry of Defence.     They described the Israeli investigation as a "well-heeled system" to protect the military at the cost of civilians.  The bulldozer driver has said he didn't see 23-year-old Rachel Corrie, a pro-Palestinian activist who opposed the military's demolition of Palestinian homes.   An Israeli court found the country's Ministry of Defence was not liable for her death in Gaza in 2003.   The judge said the 23-year-old's death was a "regrettable accident" and that the state was not responsible.

Two Tibetan teenagers have died after setting themselves on fire in Sichuan province, activists and US media said.  It happened outside the Kirti Monastery in Aba county, where many of the self-immolations have taken place.  This brings the number of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to 51, the group added.  The BBC is unable to verify this figure. Foreign media are banned from the region, making reports hard to confirm. Chinese state media have confirmed some of the self-immolations but not all.

US Republicans have opened their national convention as they prepare to formally nominate Mitt Romney as Barack Obama's White House challenger.  But the convention in Tampa, Florida was immediately adjourned until Tuesday amid concern over Tropical Storm Isaac http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19391003

Egyptian leader Mohammed Mursi has appointed a Christian intellectual, a female university professor and two Islamists as presidential assistants.  Samir Murqus, a liberal Coptic writer, was named assistant for democratic transition, officials announced.  Pakinam al-Sharkawi, who teaches political sciences at Cairo University, will be in charge of political affairs.

Link Title: Dog walks again with artificial legs
Message: VIDEO STORY: A dog in Mexico has been given a new lease of life after receiving prosthetic legs.   It is claimed that the dog, named Lemon Pie, had his paws cut off by members of a criminal gang.  He was found in a rubbish bin in the city of Fresnillo.

Link Title: Why is Europe avoiding the F-word?
Message: European leaders who think closer integration will fix the euro crisis rarely use the word "federalism" - why is it so embarrassing?

A Kenyan radical Islamist cleric accused of supporting Somalia's al-Shabab militants is killed in a drive-by shooting in Mombasa.  Aboud Rogo Mohammed was on US and UN sanction lists for allegedly supporting Somalia's al-Shabab militants.  According to a UN report, he had helped al-Shabab obtain funding and new recruits. He was also facing charges of plotting attacks in Mombasa.

Women in Togo have called a week-long sex strike, starting on Monday, to demand the president's resignation.  The ban has been called by opposition coalition Let's Save Togo, which groups together nine civil society groups and seven opposition parties and movements.  Opposition leader Isabelle Ameganvi said that sex could be a "weapon of the battle" to achieve political change.  The coalition wants President Faure Gnassingbe, whose family has held power for decades, to stand down.

Shares in Samsung Electronics have suffered their biggest one-day fall in almost four years, after a US jury found the technology giant copied designs from rival Apple.  The South Korean company's shares fell 7% in Seoul trading, the most since October 2008.  The company was ordered to pay $1.05bn in damages to Apple, in one of the most significant rulings in a global intellectual property battle.
Images from the Dominican Republic and Haiti, which bracing for the arrival of powerful Tropical Storm Isaac.

Syrian opposition activists say scores of bodies have been found in a town near the capital Damascus, accusing government troops of "massacre".  Many of those killed in the town of Darayya were victims of execution-style killings, the activists said.  According to unconfirmed reports, 200 bodies were discovered in houses and basement shelters.  Without commenting on the activists' claim, Syrian state TV said Darayya was being "cleansed of terrorist remnants".

Link Title: Tributes flood in for Neil Armstrong
Message: Politicians, leading scientists and fellow astronauts are among those who have paid tribute to the first man on the moon, Neil Armstrong, who has died at the age of 82.

US astronaut Neil Armstrong, the first man on the Moon, has died aged 82.  A statement from his family says he died from complications from heart surgery he had earlier this month.  He set foot on the Moon on 20 July 1969, famously describing the event as "one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind".  US President Barack Obama said Amstrong was "among the greatest of American heroes - not just of his time, but of all time".US astronaut Neil Armstrong, the first man on the Moon, has died aged 82.

A shrine in the Libyan capital Tripoli venerating a Sufi Muslim saint has been partly destroyed - the latest in a series of attacks blamed on ultra-conservative Salafi Islamists.  Residents of Tripoli said men with bulldozers attacked the shrine on Saturday, unimpeded by police.  The attack came a day after hardliners were accused of damaging the tomb of a Sufi scholar in the city of Zlitan  Hardline Salafists regard the shrines as idolatrous.

Haiti and the Dominican Republic brace for a battering as Tropical Storm Isaac is fast approaching the island of Hispaniola.   Aid groups warn that some 400,000 Haitians still living in makeshift camps after the deadly earthquake of 2010 are extremely vulnerable.  Storm warnings are also in place for neighbouring Dominican Republic, as well as Cuba and parts of Florida.

A US jury has said Samsung should pay Apple more than $1bn in damages in an intellectual property row.  The jury decided several Samsung devices had infringed iPhone-maker Apple's software and design patents, but rejected counter-claims by Samsung.  Apple will now seek import bans on several of its rival's products. Samsung has said it will appeal.  Correspondents say the ruling is one of the most significant in a global battle over patents and intellectual property.

A jury has ruled that Samsung should pay Apple $1.05bn (£665m) in damages in an intellectual property lawsuit in the US.   It said that several of Samsung's devices had infringed Apple's software and design patents.  The jury rejected Samsung's claims that several of its patents had been breached and awarded it no damages.
Tropical Storm Isaac's projected path across the Caribbean sparks sanitation and housing concerns in Haiti http://bbc.in/PD1vjf

This year a team from Africa is competing in the Little League World Series of Baseball for the first time http://bbc.in/PCT084  Meet the retired American businessman that brought the game to Uganda.   Do you think the sport, known as the American pastime, will have a future in Africa?

Link Title: The return of China’s wild panda
Message: This week, BBC Travel reports on how bamboo is regrowing in China’s Sichuan province, luring the wild panda back to its spiritual home.

Link Title: Carried by soldiers, no score-keepers at 1960 Paralympics
Message: The first Paralympic Games in Rome in 1960 was a disorganised and undignified affair, symptomatic of attitudes in the 1950s and 60s. Soldiers carried competitors to and from the athletes' village, and score-keeping was haphazard.    Britain's first gold medallist at the 1960 Paralympics, Margaret Maughan, tells the BBC's Peter White about her experience of the Games, a rudimentary affair symptomatic of attitudes in the 1950s and 1960s.
BBC World News Interview with Ecuador's President Rafael Correa

The African Union has asked Gambia's leader to renounce plans to execute all death row prisoners next month - announced in a speech to celebrate Eid.  A Gambian pressure group says many of the 47 death row inmates are political prisoners or have faced unfair trials.  According to Amnesty International, no executions have been carried out in The Gambia for 27 years.  The death penalty was abolished when former President Dawda Jawara was in power but reinstated in 1995 shortly after Mr Jammeh seized power in a military coup.

The United Nations refugee agency says that more than 200,000 Syrian refugees have fled to neighbouring countries as the conflict has intensified.  The UNHCR said the figure was already more than its projection of 185,000 for the end of this year.  About 30,000 arrived in Turkey, Iraq, Lebanon and Jordan in the past week.

Anders Behring Breivik, who killed 77 people in two attacks in Norway last year, is sane and must serve his sentence in prison, a court has ruled.   He insisted he was sane and refused to plead guilty, seeking to justify his attacks by saying they were necessary to stop the "Islamisation" of Norway.  Prosecutors had called for him to be considered insane.  Do you agree with the ruling?

New research suggests we hear meaningless business jargon in the workplace at least ten times a day.     The most common phrases - according to the study by "Wonga" - include "it's a no-brainer", "at the end of the day" and "touch base".     Almost 1 in 5 office workers admit to using the clichés to impress colleagues and even improve their chances of promotion.     It appears Britain has been taken over by clichés - but do you unsuspectingly use it too?    Why do we have the need to use clichés?    Who are the worst culprits for using such jargon?    We're keen to hear what you think. Stephen Sackur will be reading out some of the comments on our GMT programme at 1100GMT

Link Title: Apple and Samsung get Korea ban
Message: A South Korean court rules that Apple and Samsung both infringed each other's patents on mobile devices.  The court imposed a limited ban on national sales of products by both companies covered by the ruling.  It ruled that US-based Apple had infringed two patents held by Samsung, while the Korean firm had violated one of Apple's patents.   The sales ban will apply to Apple's iPhone 3GS, iPhone 4 and its tablets the iPad and iPad 2.

The Sun has become the first British newspaper to publish the photos of a naked Prince Harry taken in Las Vegas.  Owner News International said it was making the move despite warnings from the Royal Family's lawyers that it would be an invasion of his privacy.  The Sun said the images were widely available around the world, its readers had a right to see them and freedom of the press was being tested.

Link Title: Ex-Seal pens Bin Laden raid book
Message: A former member of the US Navy Seal team that killed Osama Bin Laden is to release a first-hand account of the raid, amid criticism of White House leaks.  US military officials say the Pentagon has not reviewed the book - part of normal protocol to ensure no secret information has been disclosed.  The book, No Easy Day, is due out on 11 September and will be published under the pseudonym Mark Owen.   What is the benefit is such details being released?  Should they be released at all or is it in the public's interest?

Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, son of former leader Muammar Gaddafi, will go on trial in Libya in September, a prosecution spokesman says.  Saif al-Islam, 40, will face trial in the town of Zintan, where he has been held since his capture last year.  The International Criminal Court, which has issued a warrant for crimes against humanity, says it is aware of the news but has not been contacted by Libya.

The most senior US Catholic cardinal is to give a benediction at the Republican National Convention next week in Florida when Mitt Romney accepts the party's presidential nomination.  Cardinal Timothy Dolan will give prayers at the televised event, Mr Romney said in an interview.  The cardinal is suing President Barack Obama over his health care plans.  But the cardinal's office says the appearance will not be an endorsement for Mr Romney.

Jordan has pulled three of its athletes facing sexual assault charges out of the London 2012 Paralympic Games.   The three athletes were arrested on Monday in Northern Ireland, where Jordan's Paralympic squad is training before the games open next week.  The three men, two of whom compete in wheelchairs, are all members of the Jordanian Paralympics power-lifting team.

Link Title: Ensuring Olympic legacy does not turn to lethargy
Message: A new TV channel dedicated to minority sports is set to be launched in the UK, capitalising on the huge interest they generated during the London Olympics.   "London Legacy TV" will cover sports such as taekwondo, swimming, fencing and handball, which get little airtime between Olympic Games every four years.  Do you think there is enough appetite for this channel to succeed? Will this channel be a success?  Would you watch it?   Which minority sports would you be interested in watching and why?   Do you think there is a lack of variety of different sports made available to viewers?  Let us know what you think and we'll use some of your answers on GMT with David Eades on BBC World News TV at 1100GMT

Link Title: SA memorials for Lonmin mine dead
Message: Memorials are to be held across South Africa for the 34 miners killed during clashes with police at Lonmin's Marikana platinum mine.

The US space agency's (Nasa) Curiosity rover has finally begun to roll. The Mars robot, which landed on the Red Planet two weeks ago, turned its six wheels briefly on Wednesday to satisfy engineers that its locomotion system was in full working order.  Curiosity is a sophisticated mobile science laboratory. It has been built to drive at least 20km across the Martian landscape to investigate whether the planet ever had the conditions necessary for life.  Wednesday's drive saw the rover roll forward 4.5m, turn clockwise on the spot for about 120 degrees, and then reverse up 2.5m.

Link Title: US West Nile virus outbreak grows
Message: The US is in the midst of one of the largest outbreaks of West Nile virus it has ever seen.  The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) confirms there have been nearly four times as many cases in 2012 as are usually reported this early in the year. Forty-one Americans have died from the mosquito-borne virus so far.

California votes to approve America's first bullet train even though the state is already billions of dollars in debt http://bbc.in/OwI0XX  Will high-speed rail change California's car culture?  Tonight on BBC World News America on PBS, we'll look at the proposed multi-billion dollar railway and other news from around the world, including: - Lebanon: Syrian unrest spills into Tripoli - Forbes' 100 most powerful women - Eurozone in crisis - An American 15-year-old pioneers a new test for pancreatic cancer  Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter

Link Title: India clamps down on social media
Message: Unlike?  Indian authorities are cracking on social networking sites claiming they are being used to send threatening messages and pictures to migrant workers. This follows clashes between tribes in the north-east state of Assam last month.  The Indian government threatened legal action if the social networks did not remove "inflammatory" content. Facebook and Google have already removed featuring hate speech. Twitter has failed to respond.  Is this censorship?

The gap between the rich and the poor is widening in Latin America, according to a study by the United Nations Agency on Human Settlements.  The report by the UN Agency for Human Settlements says that the richest 20% of the population on average earn 20 times more than the poorest 20%.  According to the study, Guatemala is the country with the widest disparity, and Venezuela the most equitable one.  The survey says the region is the world's most urbanised, with eight out of 10 people living in cities.

Spouses of heart attack victims have an increased risk of depression and anxiety, even if their partner survives, Danish research suggests.   The study found that in the year after losing a spouse to a heart attack, partners were three times more likely to start taking anti-depressants.  Even if their partner survived, the use of anti-depressants still increased by 17%, compared with the year before.

Link Title: Autism: Banking on new brain donors
Message: Earlier this year a faulty freezer destroyed one third of the largest collection of donated brains in the world, setting back the field of autism research by up to a decade. So what do you do when you have lost the irreplaceable, asks BBC Future?

At least 48 people have been killed in ethnic clashes in south-eastern Kenya, officials say.    The clashes in Tana River district, Coast Province, took place late on Tuesday between the Orma and Pokomo groups, the region's police chief said.    The clash is the worst since post-election violence rocked the country after disputed polls four years ago.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19343995

Link Title: BBC - Newsbeat - Naked pictures of Prince Harry appear on the internet
Message: Pictures showing Prince Harry naked in a Las Vegas hotel room have been published on the internet by a US website.  St James's Palace has confirmed that it is Prince Harry in the photos but is making no further comment about the images.  Many people have been commenting on social networks about Prince Harry's latest escapade.   What do you think?   How much will these photos damage the reputation of the royal family?   Should Prince Harry as the third in line to the British throne, be expected to behave in a more responsible way?  Or is this good for the image of the monarchy which many see to be too distant from the ordinary people in Britain?  Let us know and we'll use some of your comments on our Impact program with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT

Nasa's Curiosity rover is set to take its first test drive with a short spin to check out its systems.    It will then begin exploring a crater scientists believe could reveal what the Red Planet was like billions of years ago.    Curiosity is considered to be the most advanced mission sent to another planet so could it change the way we think about the Red Planet?     Was Mars some 4 billion years ago that much different than Earth?

Greece's Prime Minister, Antonis Samaras, has called for more time to implement tough spending cuts and reforms, ahead of talks on its bailout.  At issue is whether Greece has done enough to receive its next 31.5bn-euro bailout payment.  Do you think that the European leaders should fully support Greece or is it time for Greece to leave the Eurozone?

In Jesus's lifetime, the whole population of the Holy Land may have been descended from King David.   So how many generations does it take before we are all related to each other, asks evolutionary biologist Dr Yan Wong.
There are now more Indians in Australia than Chinese and British, but can migrants from the sub-continent forever resist the lure of their homeland? The BBC's Phil Mercer reports from Sydney

Link Title: Character trumps policy for older voters
Message: What matters to older voters in the US?   BBC News continues its year-long series in Levittown, Pennsylvania by visiting the senior citizens in a town that once represented the "American dream."  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19289231

Presidential hopeful Mitt Romney has joined other Republicans in calling for Congressman Todd Akin to drop out of the US Senate race in Missouri http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19335083  Mr Akin announced today that he would not be quitting the race - calling the response to his comments as a "little bit of an over-reaction"  Do you agree with Romney's request?   Tonight on BBC World News America on PBS, we'll look at Todd Akin's decision and other news from around the world, including:  - The death of long-time Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi  - The Curiosity rover is ready to explore more of Mars - The booming trade in an old Silk Road town - New arrivals at a zoo in Cuba  Check your local listings for broadcast times in your area  Follow @BBCNewsUS on Twitter

Canadian police have identified a woman whose body parts were found scattered around the Toronto area last week.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-19338592  Guang Hua Liu, 41, a single mother of three, was last seen by friends who dropped her off at work on 10 August. Police found her head, foot and two hands in a nearby river last Thursday, and then calves, a thigh and an arm in a creek over the weekend.

"A similar fate may await the inner planets in our solar system, when the Sun becomes a red giant and expands all the way out to Earth's orbit some five billion years from now" http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19332091    A US-Polish-Spanish team of astronomers have found evidence for a planet being devoured by its star.   Do you think earth will meet the same fate in five billion years?

Russia has warned against unilateral action in Syria after the US said it might intervene militarily if Damascus used chemical weapons on the rebels.  Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said there should be no outside interference and countries should "strictly adhere to the norms of international law".  On Monday, President Barack Obama said the deployment of chemical weapons represented a "red line" for the US.

Link Title: How many intelligent alien civilisations exist?
Message: Are we alone? It is a question that has occupied mankind for centuries. But how many alien worlds could there possibly be in our galaxy? Or the Universe? Have a play with BBC Future's interactive graphic to find out.

Link Title: REACTION TO TODD AKIN RAPE COMMENTS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: The US Republican Congressman who made controversial remarks about rape is resisting pressure to end his bid for the Senate.  Congressman Todd Akin was defending his opposition to abortion when he said that women's bodies could prevent pregnancy in cases of what he called 'legitimate' rape.   Erin Matson, the Vice President of the National Organisation for Women, joined David Eades on BBC World TV to discuss comments made by the Congressman.

Link Title: Teen invents cancer test using web
Message: US high schooler Jack Andraka invents advanced pancreatic cancer test using search engines and free online science papers.   The test is 168 times faster and more than 1,000 times less expensive than the gold standard in the field.

Maruti Suzuki's plant in India's Haryana state has reopened, after a month-long lock-out following clashes between staff and the management.  However, only 300 staff are expected to resume work and the factory will operate at a reduced capacity.  According to estimates, Maruti suffered a loss of up to 800m Indian rupees ($14.4m) per day during the lock-out.

Link Title: In pictures: 2012 National Geographic Traveler Photo Contest winners
Message: PHOTO GALLERY: A photograph of a Kyrgyz woman and her daughter in a remote region of Afghanistan has won the 24th annual National Geographic Traveler Photo Contest.

At least three people are killed and 25 hurt in clashes in the Lebanese city of Tripoli between opponents and supporters of Syria's president.  Exchanges of gunfire continued through the night, involving the Sunni Muslim district of Bab al-Tabbana and the Alawite district of Jabal Muhsin.  Tensions over Syria have triggered clashes in Tripoli since February. In early June, 15 people were killed.

Link Title: The man pushing himself across Africa
Message: Wheelchair user Zack Kimotho is attempting to raise nearly £2m to build a Spinal Injury Rehabilitation Unit in Nairobi - the first in East Africa.   To do this he is pushing himself across Africa - from the Kenyan capital to South Africa, where the nearest Spinal Unit is.   Have you ever raised money for a good cause?   What challenge did you set for yourself in order to raise the donations?

Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has died at the age of 57, state media say, after weeks of illness.  A government spokesman said Mr Meles had died in a hospital abroad - but did not say exactly where or give details of his ailment.  Mr Meles took power as the leader of rebels that ousted communist leader Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1991  Former BBC Ethiopia correspondent Elizabeth Blunt looks back at the life of Meles Zenawi, Ethiopia's former prime minister.
PICTURES: The festival of Eid al-Fitr is being celebrated across the Muslim world, marking the end of the holy fasting month of Ramadan.

On the Hub with Nik Gowing at 1600GMT - We will be live from the Indian state of Assam where hundreds of thousands of Muslims are marking the festival of Eid inside heavily guarded relief camps.  And, Chinese court give a suspended death sentence for the wife of the disgraced Chinese politician Bo Xilai - but has the Communist party put the scandal to rest?   For all that and more join us on BBC World News TV

Some of the workers whose protests over pay at a mine in South Africa led to the shooting of dozens of their colleagues have gone back to work. Do you think they have made the right decision?  Remember to tell us which country you are commenting from.We will have some of your views on Focus on Africa on TV tonight at 1730GMT.KD
NEWSDAY

Somalia's first formal parliament in more than 20 years is to be sworn in the capital, Mogadishu, marking an end to an eight-year transitional period.  After choosing a Speaker, the MPs' main task will be to elect a new president - a vote expected within a week or two.  Outgoing moderate Islamist President Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed, in power since 2009, is regarded as a favourite.  Other strong candidates include Prime Minister Abdiweli Mohamed Ali and former parliamentary speaker Sharif Hassan Sheikh Aden.

Muslims are predicted to make up almost one in three of the world's population by 2025, and increasing numbers of well-heeled, well-educated Muslims are already seeking out goods and services that meet their needs - not only at home, but also when they travel.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19295861

The Burmese government announces it is ending censorship of the country's media, the latest in a series of political reforms.   But does the end of the law necessarily mean the end of the censorship altogether?
A deadline approaches for striking workers at a South African mine where police shot dead 34 miners last week. The mine's owners have given them an ultimatum: return to work or face dismissal.
Joseph Kony's sister has spoken to the media for the first time about living with one of the world's most wanted men.

Hollywood film-maker Tony Scott, famous for movies including Top Gun, dies after jumping from a bridge in Los Angeles, authorities say.  British-born Scott, brother of Alien director Ridley, shot to fame in the 1980s with a string of action films.  The 68-year-old's blockbuster hits included Crimson Tide, Days of Thunder and Beverly Hills Cop II.

The achievements of Team GB at the Olympics have led to a wave of criticism of footballers. They've been lambasted for being overpaid, arrogant underachievers. But why do some people hate footballers so much?

A 62-year-old woman attempts to become the first person to swim from Cuba to the US without a shark cage.  Diana Nyad has already been stung several times by jellyfish but is continuing her 166km (103 mile) journey, team members said.  She left the Cuban capital, Havana, on Saturday afternoon and is aiming to reach Florida on Tuesday.  She is relying on an electronic shield as a shark deterrent.
Anti-Japanese protests take place in cities across China after Japanese nationalists raised their country's flag on disputed islands.
Julian Assange urges the US to end its "witch-hunt" on Wikileaks, in his first public statement since entering Ecuador's London embassy in June.

Link Title: South African orphan sees his work in Museum of Modern Art
Message: Tshepo "Tuki" was orphaned as a young boy. Growing up poor in Makuleke village in rural South Africa, he always dreamed of one day visiting the US.  That dream came true this summer when the 16-year-old was invited to New York City to see a piece of his artwork on display at the Museum of Modern Art.  His "wire car," a common toy in Makuleke village made from recycled material, is part of an exhibit called "Century of the Child," which runs through November 5th.

A French swimmer who lost all his limbs in an electrocution accident completes a swim to link five continents, by crossing part of the Bering Strait.   Using tailor-made flippers, Philippe Croizon finished his quest by crossing between the US island of Little Diomede and Great Diomede in Russia, joining Asia and the Americas.  The 44-year-old has swum three other straits since May.
China praises Japan's "wise" decision to free 14 activists who sailed to a group of islands claimed by both countries, in a commentary in state media.

Burma sets up a commission to investigate recent violence between Muslims and Buddhists, a move welcomed by the UN.  The move was announced by President Thein Sein, who earlier rejected UN calls for an independent inquiry.  The clashes between Rakhine Buddhists and Rohingya Muslims also displaced thousands of people.  The UN welcomed the inquiry, saying it could make "important contributions" to restoring peace.

South African President Jacob Zuma has announced an inquiry into violence at a mine in the north-east of the country, calling the deaths there "tragic".  Thirty-four people were killed when police opened fire on striking platinum miners on Thursday. At least 78 people were injured in the confrontation.

Imagine working deep underneath one of the biggest cities in the world http://bbc.in/Pkmyaq   Tom Petrizzo is a Sandhog, a New York City urban miner. He has been working underground for 13 years. Currently, he is tunnelling the East Side Access, a public works project that will connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central station. Tom took the BBC down to the tunnels and into the "hog-house", explaining the dangers, the mud and the heat, but also the camaraderie that develops among sandhogs.   Get to know Tom in a special weekend edition of our First Person series.   Could you work with Tom?

Squid-like movements? Surfing shark-trackers?  These new innovations may just change the way we look at robots.   http://bbc.in/PjKTgx Researchers at Harvard University have designed a soft and bendy robot that can also change colour to either blend in with or stand out from its surroundings. The machine was inspired by the camouflage skills of sea creatures such as octopuses, cuttlefish and squid.  http://bbc.in/PjKTgz A surfing robot is being used to track great white sharks off the coast of California, US, by marine scientists. Shark fans are able to follow the animals' movements via a free app for smartphones and tablet computers.

In this week's edition of First Person we meet Esther Miller, a mother of six from the US state of Ohio http://bbc.in/PjB1TL   She is also a cowgirl and professional rodeo rider. Esther was raised in a traditional Amish family, a Christian community whose members generally shun modern conveniences such as electricity, televisions and cars.  When Esther grew up she left the Amish community and started on the path to become a champion barrel racer.

Link Title: Costa Rica’s surf and yoga heaven
Message: This week, BBC Travel dives into Costa Rica’s surf and yoga heaven. Have you been to Costa Rica?

Link Title: India's millennium city a 'slum for the rich'?
Message: The BBC's Shalu Yadav looks at why Gurgaon, India's Millennium City, has turned out to be a failure in planning.

Ethiopia has become the second country after Japan to take delivery of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner.  Ethiopian Airlines has bought 10 of Boeing's flagship aircraft, which are built from lightweight material, rather than aluminium, to save fuel.

Link Title: Organisers of first Syria protest - where are they now?
Message: On 31st January 2011, inspired by the protests in Cairo's Tahrir Square, six young Damascus residents organised the first major demonstration of the Syrian uprising.  They prepared placards, modest in their message, calling on the Egyptian army not to kill Egypt's young people and adding "Yes to freedom!", and they posted an invitation on Facebook urging people to show their support by demonstrating outside the Egyptian embassy.  Now, Newsnight has tracked down three of those protesters to find out what has happened to them since.

Three members of Russian punk band Pussy Riot have been convicted of hooliganism motivated by religious hatred, over a protest in a cathedral.
