Judge Marina Syrova said the women had "crudely undermined social order" during their action in February.  The women say their "punk prayer" was a political act in protest against the Russian Orthodox Church leader's support of President Vladimir Putin.  Prosecutors are seeking a three-year jail sentence.

People are dying in large numbers in a refugee camp in South Sudan, a medical charity says, describing the situation as a humanitarian disaster.  Medecins Sans Frontieres says as many as four young children die at the Batil camp every day - twice the established emergency threshold.  The rainy season makes it impossible to bring food in by road, and the only way to deliver aid is by air.  Some 170,000 refugees have fled to camps in South Sudan from Sudan following fighting north of the border.

On GMT with Komla Dumor at 1100GMT - We'll have the latest from Marikana in South Africa where more than 30 people are known to have been killed when police opened fire on a crowd of several thousand striking miners on Thursday.  The incident is one of the worst of its kind since the end of apartheid.  The violence has caused widespread concern, and President Jacob Zuma said he was alarmed and deeply saddened by the loss of life.

In less than one hour's time, members of the Russian punk protest group Pussy Riot will hear the verdict in their case. They're charged with hooliganism and inciting religious hatred, after performing a song against Vadimir Putin in Moscow's central cathedral in February. Protests around the world are expected in their support.   Are members of the band being treated too harshly?  Or is this  "hooliganism motivated by religious hatred" as prosecutors are arguing?  The band stormed the altar of Moscow's Christ the Saviour Cathedral in February wearing bright ski masks, tights and short skirts to hold a "punk prayer" for Russia to get rid of Putin.

Link Title: Yetis in the lab: The search for mythical beasts
Message: Do you believe in Yetis? How about Bigfoot? Or the Yowie? A controversial project could decide once and for all whether these mythical beasts really do exist.

The head of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, Abune Paulos, dies aged 76, an official tells the BBC.   The foreign ministry said he had been receiving treatment over the past week for an undisclosed illness.  The patriarch's office is due to hold an emergency meeting on Friday to finalise arrangements for what is expected to be a state funeral.  Abune Paulos led Ethiopia's 40 million Orthodox Christians - half the population - since 1992.

The largest Muslim area in the Burmese city of Sittwe was razed to the ground in recent communal violence, a UK broadcaster has reported.  A team from the UK's Channel 4 News gained access to Sittwe, which has been off limits to reporters for months.  They filmed an area once home to 10,000 that had been reduced to rubble.  Days of violence in Rakhine state began in late May when a Buddhist woman was raped and murdered by three Muslims. A mob later killed 10 Muslims.

Peru is a major source of fake dollars, according to the US authorities,  but despite increased seizures of counterfeit bills, Peruvian forgers are unlikely to be out of business any time soon, reports the BBC's Mattia Cabitza.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-19240999

While President Bashar al-Assad of Syria is fighting rebels in Damascus and Aleppo, he has given up control in parts of the Kurdish north east.    Kurdish leaders say they now control about 50% of the territory there, and warn they will fight the regime if it tries to retake power.     Our Correspondent Orla Guerin has spent 5 days under cover in Syria's Kurdish region and sent this report.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19279590

Coming up on Impact: Ecuador grants asylum to Wikileaks founder Julian Assange.  Do you agree with the decision? What do you believe should happen to him? What are the political implications of the decision?  Do let us know and we'll use some of your comments in our programme at 1300GMT

Prominent Bahraini activist Nabeel Rajab is jailed for three years for taking part in "illegal gatherings".  He is already serving a three-month sentence he received in July over comments on social networking websites.  Mr Rajab, president of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights, had previously been detained several times.  He was one of the organisers of pro-democracy protests which have rocked the Gulf kingdom since last February.

First the Argentinians accused Britain of behaving like a colonial power over the Falkland Islands – now it’s Ecuador’s turn.  It follows what the Ecuadorian foreign minister described as a British threat to enter its London embassy to arrest the Wikileaks founder Julian Assange who’s trying to avoid extradition to Sweden on sexual assault allegations.  Is Britain behaving badly?  Join me, George Alagiah, on GMT

The UK has issued a "threat" to enter the Ecuadorian embassy in London to arrest Wikileaks' Julian Assange, Ecuador's foreign minister says.  If Assange has not yet been charged over the sex allegations does the British government has the right to invoke a little known law which would allow them to enter Ecuador's embassy?  Is this in accordance to international law?  What impact will any such action have on international diplomacy as whole?  Is Assange justified in fearing further extradition to the US to be tried on espionage charges?

Gunmen have attacked a Pakistani military air base triggering a fierce firefight with security forces that lasted several hours.  Several militants wearing military uniforms and suicide belts stormed Minhas air base at Kamra, near the capital Islamabad, just before dawn.  Eight militants were killed, one soldier also died and the base commander was seriously injured.  All of Pakistan's air bases were placed on high alert following the attack.

Ecuador has accused the UK of making a "threat" to enter its embassy in London to arrest Wikileaks' Julian Assange.  Mr Assange took refuge at the embassy in June to avoid extradition to Sweden, where he faces questioning over assault and rape claims, which he denies.  Ecuador foreign minister Ricardo Patino also said a decision on the 41-year-old's bid for political asylum had been made and would be revealed on Thursday.

Link Title: BBC WORLD NEWS - BEHIND THE SCENES - LONDON 2012
Message: We wanted to share with you this collection of images taken during our coverage of the London 2012 Olympic Games.  You will see some familiar faces and also some of those who mostly work behind the scenes.  We hope you enjoyed our coverage.

Brazil's government is set to launch the first in a series of measures that could inject up to $50bn (£32bn) into the economy over the next five years.  The first part of the plan, to be announced on Wednesday, includes privatising about 14,000 kilometres of railways and roads.  The privatisation of ports, lower energy costs and incentives for industry will soon follow.  The package is designed to boost what have been disappointing growth levels.

Link Title: UN blames Syria for Houla deaths
Message: Syrian troops and militia were behind the massacre of 108 people in the town of Houla on 25 May, UN investigators have found.  The massacre was considered one of the worst attacks on civilians since the start of the uprising in March 2011.  It alleges that systematic violations have been authorised at the highest levels of the Syrian government.

Four men are arrested in Germany on suspicion of illegally supplying Iran with parts needed to build a nuclear reactor.  They are accused of using front companies in Turkey and Azerbaijan to supply the parts in deals worth millions of euros.  Germany has an embargo on nuclear-related trade with Iran.

Global survey conducted by The Economist Intelligence Unit has ranked Melbourne in Australia as the most liveable city in the world, while Bangaldesh's capital Dhaka came bottom of the table.  The survey ranked 140 cities using factors such as political and social stability, crime, education and access to health care.   How would you rate the place where you're living?  How accurate and relevant are such surveys?  We'll be using some of your comments on Impact with Karin Giannone

Emerging economies in Asia, including India and the Philippines, face the greatest financial risk from natural disaster, analysis suggests.    The authors based their rankings on nations' economic activity and exposure to natural hazards, such as floods, droughts, earthquakes and cyclones.    The nations' limited ability to recover from disasters left them exposed to severe disruption, they added.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19254685

An Australian court has upheld the government's new law on mandatory plain packaging for cigarettes in the country.   The law requires cigarettes to be sold in olive green packets, with graphic images warning of the consequences of smoking.  Will this ruling lead to a domino effect in other countries?  If tobacco companies are no longer able to compete in branding what does the future look like for them?  Will illicit trade rise as a result of such legislation being passed?  What are kinds of regulations on tobacco are there where you live?  Let us know and we'll use some of the comments on our GMT programme with George Alagiah.

Link Title: From China to Albania, via Guantanamo
Message: Abu Bakker Qassim is a pizza chef like no other. Born in China, jailed in Guantanamo, now cooking halal Italian food in Albania.  It is an extraordinary journey, and one which has left Qassim an exile, separated permanently from his family in China.

VIDEO: It is just over three years since the Sri Lankan army decisively crushed the Tamil Tiger militants, ending a 26-year civil war.  Hundreds of thousands of people were left displaced, and parts of the island were devastated.  The BBC's Charles Haviland has been given access to the area of Putumattalan which hosted the final days of fighting.

Imagine if you could travel from London to New York in about an hour http://bbc.in/OhgD49 The hypersonic jet WaveRider might just be the first step in making that possible - the craft, funded by the Pentagon and Nasa, is set to undergo a test flight today above the Pacific Ocean, aiming to reach Mach 6.  Do you think this technology will ever be put to use in commercial airliners?

Do employers have the right to know your social media passwords? http://bbc.in/OgB01k  Robert Collins took a leave of absence from his job as a correctional officer to grieve after his mother passed away. When he returned, his employer forced him to reapply for his position and demanded the username and password to his Facebook account.  Take a look at our conversation with Robert and tell us what you think.

Link Title: London 2012 Olympics:  The wonderful and weird
Message: With London 2012 now finished it's time to look at some amazing feats of human achievement as well as the surprising images and numbers from the Olympics.
Syria's regime is collapsing "morally, financially and militarily" and controls just 30% of the country, says former PM Riad Hijab who defected to Jordan.

Thousands of Tunisians have protested in the capital against moves by the Islamist-led government which they fear will reduce women's rights.  The government has unveiled a draft constitution which refers to women as "complementary to men".  The mostly women protesters held up placards which read: "Rise up women for your rights."  Tunisia was one of the most secular Arab states before the Islamist Ennahda party won elections last year.

Link Title: Youths riot in north France city
Message: Buildings and cars are torched and police officers injured in clashes overnight with angry youths in a deprived district of Amiens in France.  Sixteen police officers were injured in the clashes with up to 100 youths, some of whom threw fireworks, large-sized shot and projectiles, say police.  Reports suggest the unrest may have been triggered after police arrested a man for dangerous driving.

The whistle-blowing website Wikileaks is back online after being disrupted by a denial of service (DDoS) attack for more than a week.  The website said it had been flooded with 10 gigabits per second of traffic, making it slow and unresponsive.  Wikileaks noted that a group calling itself Anti Leaks had said it was behind the attack

A couple from English county of Suffolk have won $232 million in the Euromillions Lottery.  They are shortly due to announce what they plan to do with their winnings. So cue to obvious questions...  If you had just won the same amount what would you spend it on?  Would you be a good Samaritan and donate to good causes some of the winnings?  Would you spoil yourself rotten and buy luxurious items? Would you take care of your family and friends?  Let us know and we will read out some of the comments on GMT with Komla Dumor at 1100 GMT.

Link Title: China hosts aide to Syria's Assad
Message: China is preparing to host an envoy from Syria's President Bashar al-Assad and says it's prepared to receive members of the opposition.   This diplomatic development comes as the fighting in Syria appears to have reached a new level of intensity. Rebels say they can now fight attacks from the air after shooting down a jet and capturing the pilot - a claim the government denies.
Australian MPs are set to consider proposals to restart offshore processing of asylum seekers, as fears mount for 67 migrants missing at sea.
Norway is to hear official conclusions on the response by police and other agencies to Anders Behring Breivik's attacks last year.

The Hub is back on your screens with Nik Gowing at 1600GMT.  Today's topics:   How to sustain Britain’s "happy and glorious" Olympic spirit? Goodbye London, what about Rio in four years?  Also, the Pope's butler to face trial: what will be revealed?  And: why have anti-corruption marchers been arrested on their way to India's parliament?

A fighter jet has crashed in eastern Syria owing to "technical problems", according to state media.  The rebel Free Syrian Army (FSA) say they shot a military aircraft down in the same area.  Experts who examined footage from the FSA of the downed plane say its camouflage and markings are consistent with those of a Syrian air force plane.  The pilot ejected and a search is now under way to find him, according to state media.

The former butler to Pope Benedict XVI will stand trial for stealing confidential papers and leaking them to the press, a magistrate has ruled.  Paolo Gabriele was arrested in May after police found confidential documents at his Vatican flat.  He has been charged with aggravated theft while another Vatican employee, a computer analyst, faces complicity charges.

Over 70000 of them worked tirelessly for two weeks helping to make the Games.  But their enthusiasm, wit, knowledge and good humour they brought to long days performing often menial tasks was all their own.  So how has it been for them, to give up a minimum of 10 days with no pay, no expenses, no accommodation, for some, sleeping in a bunk at a makeshift campsite?

Police in the Indian capital Delhi have stopped prominent anti-corruption campaigner Baba Ramdev from marching to parliament to stage a protest.  Baba Ramdev and his supporters have been detained for allegedly "violating prohibitory laws".  Known as the yoga guru, Baba Ramdev says he is campaigning for the recovery of bribe money allegedly held overseas.
Firefighters battle a forest fire on La Gomera in Spain's Canary Islands which forced the evacuation of nearly 1,000 people by ferry overnight.

Link Title: In pictures: Olympic Games closing ceremony
Message: As London Olympic Games drew to a close yesterday we wanted to share some of the images from the closing ceremony.  Did you watch it? What did you make of it? Did you prefer it to the opening ceremony?

A vast "raft" of buoyant volcanic rock covering 26,000 sq km of the Pacific Ocean is spotted by a New Zealand military aircraft.  A naval ship was forced to change course in order to avoid the cluster of buoyant rocks, located 1,600 km off the New Zealand coast.  The unusual phenomenon was probably the result of pumice being released from an underwater volcano, experts said.

Link Title: DIZZEE RASCAL - LONDON 2012 - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO : When British rapper Dizzee Rascal performed at the opening ceremony of London 2012, it's thought a BILLION people were watching.   Dizzee grew up in East London, not far from where we are sitting now. Karin Giannone spoke to him about what it has been like to be a part of these games.

Syrian civilians are fleeing the city of Aleppo in increasing numbers, the UN says, amid a lull in fighting between rebels and government forces.  The UN refugee agency says it has now registered almost 150,000 refugees in four neighbouring countries.  It said 6,000 had crossed into Turkey in the past week, many of them from the Aleppo area.

Link Title: Olympics: Dispelling doubts about exceptional feats
Message: It started with a splash, but the ripples continue to be felt. When 16-year-old Chinese swimmer Ye Shiwen touched home to win a gold medal in the 400m individual medley, accusations began to fly. But could the fledgling field of performance profiling reveal the truth about Olympian achievements that defy expectation? BBC Future finds out. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120810-dispelling-olympian-doubts

As Brazil celebrates the centenary of his birth, Amado is remembered as one of the country's most important, and best-loved writers, famous not only at home but internationally.  His vivid portrayal of his fellow countrymen and women struck a chord, and he created characters who captured the popular imagination.  Translated into 49 languages and published in 55 countries, his books reflect Brazil's culture, inequalities and contradictions.  "I'm under no illusions about the importance of my work," the writer Jorge Amado once said. "But if it has any worth, it is that it truly reflects the Brazilian people."

Tens of thousands of people have gathered in the Ghanaian capital Accra for the funeral of President John Atta Mills, who died suddenly in July.  Some 18 African heads of state and visiting US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton are also attending.  Mills, who had long suffered from throat cancer, died only five months before he was set to seek re-election.

South Korea's president is visiting islands also claimed by Japan, in a move set to raise diplomatic tensions.  Lee Myung-bak flew to the islands, which are known as Dokdo in South Korea and as Takeshima in Japan.  A Kyodo news agency report said Japan had recalled its ambassador from South Korea.

They have volunteered to give up a minimum of 10 days with no pay, no expenses, no accommodation, and some have been sleeping in a bunk at a makeshift campsite.  So as two weeks of helping to make the Games and herding the crowds come to a close, how has life been for Olympics volunteers?

A minister in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh has told officials that they could "steal a little", but should not be "robbing" public funds.  Public works minister Shivpal Yadav made the remarks while speaking to officials at Etah district.  Mr Yadav later said he was against corruption and that news channels had shown an edited version of his remarks.  The remarks have caused an uproar in a country which is witnessing a mounting campaign against corruption.

Nasa's new Mars rover has returned its first 360-degree colour panorama from the surface of the Red Planet http://bbc.in/OTDYKy  The Curiosity robot used its wideangle science camera placed high up on a mast to acquire the frames. What are you hoping the Curiosity rover will teach us about the Red Planet?

The UN estimates there are around half a million chronic heroin users in Pakistan, with many living in the country's biggest city Karachi.   But help for addicts is in short supply, and locking them up is one of the only forms of treatment.

World food prices have risen substantially in recent months, hitting record levels, and the price of oil is also rising. We explain what's pushing up the cost of these crucial commodities.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18857765

Does the US have a legitimate right to intervene in the behaviour of companies and individuals, indeed of countries, operating beyond its own borders?    The question is pertinent and timely, given that Standard Chartered, a UK bank, was accused this week of violating US law.      http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/19172065
Take a look at this picture gallery which illustrates why London 2012 has turned into the "crying Games".  Would you cry if you were an Olympic medal winner ?
Efforts are under way to help hundreds of thousands of people displaced by deadly floods in the Philippine capital, Manila, and nearby areas.

In China a court case with huge political implications has ended after just 1 day.   Gu Kailai, the wife of the former senior politician, Bo Xilai, is accused of murdering the British businessman Neil Heywood in a case that has grabbed international headlines and helped topple her husband from the top ranks of the Communist party.    It's not known when the verdict will be delivered.

Could you live in a ghost town?  http://bbc.in/OPmXBg  Half a century ago, a landfill fire in the Pennsylvanian town of Centralia spread underground to an abandoned coal mine. The blaze has been burning beneath the community ever since.  Fears about toxic gases and dangerous sinkholes led the authorities to evacuate more than 1,000 people from the town in the 1980s. The BBC's Matthew Danzico went to Centralia to meet the few Centralia residents who have refused to leave, claiming that their part of town is not threatened by the fire.

Syrian state media say government forces have taken full control of a strategic district in the biggest city, Aleppo, after fierce fighting.   However, rebel commanders denied they had retreated from the Salah al-Din district, amid reports of a push by army tanks and armoured vehicles.

Link Title: Battle for the heart of Georgia
Message: Georgia's parliamentary elections will be held on 1 October, pitting the country's richest man against a popular president, and putting the volatility back into Georgian politics.

Link Title: Antarctica to Mars: The loneliest job in the world
Message: Think you have had a tough day at work? BBC Future talks to the man who lives in the coldest, remotest part of the world - all in the name of science. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120807-the-loneliest-job-in-the-world

Link Title: Scars of separation as Kashmir insurgency winds down
Message: Years of insurgency appear to be ending but thousands of Kashmiris remain refugees, separated from their loved ones and former lives, reports the BBC's M Ilyas Khan in the Neelum valley.

Flooding caused by torrential rain has brought parts of the Philippine capital, Manila, to a stand-still.   Schools and offices are closed, and at least 8 people have been killed in a landslide.   Many of the people living in areas affected by floods have been getting in touch with us describing the situation.  If you have been caught up by floods we want to hear from you. Do get in touch with us and let us know how the floods have impacted you.

Egypt carries out air strikes against suspected Islamist militants in the Sinai peninsula, with reports of 20 people killed.  The strikes came after security checkpoints were allegedly attacked by gunmen in the town of al-Arish, leaving a number of people injured.  On Sunday, militants killed 16 Egyptian border guards in the area.

We asked you to send us your versions of the famous Usain Bolt pose, which has been seen a lot during the Olympic Games. Here are the photos from a few of you. To see more of our best Bolt models, visit us at  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19162357

"Touchdown confirmed."  A spectacular image of the Curiosity rover descending to the surface of Mars on its parachute has been obtained by an overflying satellite http://bbc.in/OV0i64  The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter played a key role in Monday's (GMT) historic landing by recording telemetry from the robot as it approached the ground. But Nasa also tasked it with trying to get a picture of the new arrival.  Will Curiosity spark a renewed interest in space exploration?   Check out the first photos from Curiosity by following the link above.

Link Title: CHAD LE CLOS INTERVIEW BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: It's nearly a week since Chad le Clos won the men's 200 metres butterfly in dramatic style - and unwittingly introduced his father, Bert, to world-wide notoriety.   South African swimmer powered through in the final stretch to win his first Olympic medal - snatching victory from the man who's since become the all-time greatest Olympian in terms of medals won - Michael Phelps.  Chad Le Clos joined us today on BBC World News to tell us about his Olympic experience

Link Title: The first man to wear a sanitary towel
Message: Arunachalam Muruganantham is a man on a very unusual mission.  He wants to change the way that poor women in developing countries cope with their monthly periods.  And in the heat of this obsessive quest, the 49-year-old Indian entrepreneur did something extraordinary to test the sanitary towels he invented.

Link Title: Sikh shock at US temple shootings
Message: Sikhs living in the United States have expressed their shock and fear after a shooting at a temple in Wisconsin on Sunday which left seven people dead.  A gunman entered the Sikh temple on Sunday morning and opened fire, killing six people and injuring a policeman.  The suspect has been named as Wade Michael Page, a 40-year-old army veteran, in US media reports.
Senior Chinese leaders are reported to be gathering at the Beidaihe resort for private meetings ahead of the leadership change later this year.

Link Title: Life for Uganda's Asians, 40 years on
Message: 40 after the expulsion of Asians from Uganda by then leader Idi Amin, Rupal Rajani revisits the land of her birth, to find out how far things have changed, and meets Asian families who have returned to Uganda in the hope that a new life awaits.

Link Title: JAMAICA CELEBRATES USAIN BOLT'S 100M WIN - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: As Jamaica celebrates 50 years of independence, Usain Bolt continues to be the focus of attention after his victory in the 100 metres.   He defended his title in stunning style, setting an Olympic record time of 9.63 seconds and finishing ahead of compatriot Yohan Blake and American Justin Gatlin.   In Jamaica, they're been celebrating through the night. The BBC's Nick Davies reports from the capital, Kingston

Japan marks the 67th anniversary of the atomic bomb attack on Hiroshima.  Tens of thousands of people attended the annual ceremony, amid growing anti-nuclear sentiment and protests in the country.  A bell marked the start of a one-minute silence at 08:15 local time (23:15 GMT) when the US bomber Enola Gay dropped the bomb that killed 140,000 people.

Are you curious?  http://bbc.in/OSUgTB  In the next few hours Nasa will attempt to land its one-tonne Curiosity rover on Mars to study the possibility that the Red Planet may once have hosted microbial life. Curiosity is currently hurtling through space, close to the end of a 570 million km journey from Earth.

The US is in the grips of its worst drought in more than half a century. Soaring temperatures and a lack of rain across much of the country's agricultural heartland have created an increasingly dire situation for farmers and ranchers alike.   Some ranchers must sell off cattle at auction because they can't afford to keep them, and farmers struggle to irrigate all of their crops.  The BBC travelled to western Nebraska and met some of those on the front line of a desperate standoff with mother nature.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19121807

Now that the US space shuttle fleet is spread out across the country as they prepare to become museum exhibits - we take a look at the three launch systems finalists to carry the next generation of astronauts. http://bbc.in/OOQ4UG  Nasa's intention is to eventually outsource its crew launch requirements to the private sector. Do you agree with this move?

Earlier today, BBC News correspondent Ian Pannell answered your questions about the situation in Syria and what it's like to report in such demanding conditions in a live Twitter Q&A produced by our UGC team in London.   In case you missed it, here's a summary of the session -  http://bbc.in/PMqa0F  Thank you to all of you who followed along and contributed questions.

Niger rower Hamadou Djibo Issaka only 6 months was a gardener working in the capital Niamey.   He only took up rowing 3 months ago and trained for his Olympic debut in an old fishing boat.   Nevertheless he is now vowing crowds at the London Olympics.

Link Title: Brazil set for big bribery trial
Message: One of the biggest corruption trials in Brazil's history is due to start over a corruption scandal that rocked ex-president Lula's  government.   The defendants are accused of involvement in a scheme that used public funds to pay coalition partners to support the government's agenda.  Among those accused are former leading members of Lula's Workers' Party (PT). All reject the charges.
David Eades reporting live on BBC World News

The United Nations says North Korea has requested immediate food aid after floods last month that killed more than 100 people.  UN officials in Pyongyang said the need for aid was urgent after visiting flood-hit parts of the country to assess damage.  Damage to infrastructure and farmland has affected the country's already dire food shortage problem.

British cyclist Philip Hindes admitted to crashing deliberately to force a restart.     In light of recent controversy of using unsporting tactics by the Chinese badminton players, can this be seen as cheating?    Let us know and we may use some of your comments on our programme at 1200GMT

In the second episode of the series Mishal Husain in joined by Sana Mir, a female Pakistani cricketer and captain of the Pakistani women’s team.  Currently the only Pakistani cricketer in the top 20 ICC Player Rankings, Mir began playing the sport at a young age before the initial fun of playing in the streets became an electrifying passion for the game, later deciding to enrol herself at the Zaheer Abbas Cricket Academy for Women (ZACA).  Tune in this Saturday at 1:30 and 8:30 GMT and on Sunday at 14:30 and 20:30 GMT

A truth commission set up after last year's election violence in Ivory Coast is unable to work properly due to a lack of funds, a spokesman says.  The BBC's John James in Abidjan says that a year after the Truth, Reconciliation and Dialogue Commission was set up, many Ivorians complain that it has achieved little.  The panel includes football star Didier Drogba, representing Ivorians abroad.

After his recent reporting trip to the frontline in Syria, BBC News correspondent Ian Pannell will answer your questions about the situation there and what it's like to report in such demanding conditions in a live Twitter Q&A on Friday 3 August.  Ian will be answering questions directly via his Twitter account: https://twitter.com/BBCiPannell between 16:00 GMT and 17:00 GMT  Tweet your questions to @BBC_HaveYourSay using the hashtag #ask BBC Ian or Text your question, beginning '#Ask BBC Ian' to +44 7624 800 100

Great Britain has won gold medals today in cycling, canoeing and shooting as well as silver medals in canoeing, rowing and judo - making today one of the greatest days in British Olympic history. http://bbc.in/OLUDPx  Tonight US swimmers Ryan Lochte and Michael Phelps will compete against each other for what will likely be the last time.   Athletics competition begins at Olympic Stadium tomorrow morning with the Men's Shot Put and Women's Heptathlon.  What is your Olympic highlight of the day?  What event are you most looking forward to watching?

Link Title: Annan resigns as UN Syria envoy
Message: The UN-Arab League special envoy to Syria, Kofi Annan, is leaving his post, the UN says, as violence in the country continues.  In a news conference, he said the Syrian people "desperately need action" but criticised the UN Security Council for "finger pointing and name calling".  He said: "As an envoy, I can't want peace more than the protagonists, more than Security Council or the international community, for that matter,"  Where does this leave the peace process?

Link Title: Mutilated Pakistani woman rebuilds her life
Message: The BBC's Orla Guerin in Pakistan meets a woman who has rebuilt her life after being brutally attacked by her husband.
Egypt's military chief, Field Marshal Hussein Tantawi, is to keep his post as defence minister in the country's new cabinet, Prime Minister-designate Hisham Qandil has confirmed.

Badminton suffered a huge blow when four pairs were disqualified for throwing matches on Tuesday in an attempt to get an easier fixture in the next round.     Tactical has always played a part of sport but what happens when it doesn't follow the Olympic code?     Is it ever within the spirit of sportsmanship to apply such tactics?    If such tactics have been used in the past why is there such an outrage over the way the badminton players acted?    Let us know what you think and we'll use some of your comments on our programme at 1330GMT with Lucy Hockings.

Link Title: Audio slideshow: A surgeon in Somalia
Message: AUDIO SLIDESHOW: Dr Omar Saleh, a surgeon working for the World Health Organization in Somalia, addresses some of the issues facing working in a country which has seen two decades of conflict.
A spokesman for Palestinian militant movement Hamas condemns a visit by a Palestinian official to the site of the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz.

Chinese badminton star, Yu Yang, has announced she's quitting the sport after she - and seven other players - were disqualified from the women's doubles competition at the London Olympics. She was accused of deliberately trying to lose her match.  Is her decision to quit the sport justified?  Should the trainer be also blamed for negative tactics?  How far a new regulations in the sport to blame?

Link Title: Understanding the animal mind... through music
Message: Do animals respond to music? And, if so, what could it tell us about their personalities? Laurel Braitman, a science historian and author, has taken the slightly surreal step of organising live music in zoos to try to help answer those questions. How would you try to understand animals' minds?

Link Title: The 90-year-old world record holder in pole vault
Message: London and Beijing might be some of the biggest cities in the world - but many of the athletes that come to the Olympic Games are small town folks.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19069206  The BBC's Franz Strasser traveled to Jonesboro in the US state of Arkansas to take a look at how pole vaulting has found a home in this rural landscape.   While in Jonesboro - Franz witnessed 90-year old Dr William Bell,  father of former Olympic silver medalist Earl Bell, attempt to set an age group world record for the event. Take a look at the clip below to see if he cleared the bar.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pX9h5PVNGaY

Link Title: Superstitious Fund: Too mystic to fail
Message: Would you invest in a new fund that trades on superstition - for example, not buying anything on Friday the 13th, or not trading on a new moon? BBC Future's David Wolman has done just that, but as he explains it's not that far removed from the irrational ways in which we regularly treat and handle money. The question is would you put your money in the superstitious fund?
Lucy, Vincent Hancock (US gold medallist in shooting), and our man in charge Antony
The boom in China's social media is forcing the country to open up, but critics argue it is a poor replacement for real change.

Government forces are continuing to persecute Muslims in Burma's Rakhine state after failing to protect them during deadly clashes in June, Human Rights Watch has said in a report.  Security forces had killed and raped members of the Rohingya group and arrested hundreds of others, it said.

The earliest unambiguous evidence for modern human behaviour is discovered by an international team of researchers in a South African cave.  The finds provide early evidence for the origin of modern human behaviour 44,000 years ago, over 20,000 years before other findings.  The artefacts are near identical to modern-day tools of the indigenous African San bush people.

Link Title: Fate of Syria at stake - Assad
Message: With no let up in the fighting for Aleppo, President Assad says Syria faces battles that will determine the fate of its people.

Link Title: Fans jeer errors in doubles match
Message: The Badminton World Federation has charged eight women players with not using their best efforts to win their doubles matches at the Olympics.   They're said to have tried to lose so they would avoid tougher opponents in the subsequent rounds.  Have fans, who have paid a lot of money to see the world's best perform, been hard done by?  Would such strategy at any stage be in the spirit of the Games?     Should athletes always be expected to give their best?  Let us know what you think and we may use some of your comments during our programme.

Trains have come to a standstill and hospitals are running on backup generators as more than half of India is hit with power cuts after three grids have collapsed. http://bbc.in/OHELh7  Power Minister Sushil Kumar Shinde is blaming the problems on states overdrawing from the grid.  Will India's ageing power infrastructure  slow down their economic growth?

Images released by Nasa show that the American flags planted on the Moon by Apollo astronauts are mostly still standing. http://bbc.in/ODlwFo  The notable exception is the flag from the Apollo 11 mission, the first to bring mankind to the Moon, matching Buzz Aldrin's account of the flag being knocked over by engine exhaust as they departed the surface.   Do you think future space missions should return to the moon?

Link Title: Olympic cheats: The cat-and-mouse game to catch dopers
Message: Sports doping is back in the news after a US coach cast doubt on Chinese swimmer Ye Shiwen's record-breaking win. One Olympic chief hit back by saying that the World Doping Agency have passed her as clean. The Agency has brought in new measures at London 2012 to keep on top of unscrupulous sportspeople - to find out more, see this BBC Future article published before the Games began.

INTERACTIVE: We have put together a series of maps showing the extent of fighting in Syria's main cities of Damascus and Aleppo and where refugees are gathering.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-19049388
INTERACTIVE: Here is your opportunity to find out which London 2012 Olympian you most resemble  Which Olympic athlete is closest to your own body size and shape?
Dar es Salaam is one of the world's fastest growing cities, but the Tanzanian authorities are struggling to harness its potential, reports the BBC's Joe Boyle.
A US man pleads guilty in a court in Chicago to trying to provide support for hardline Islamist group al-Shabab in Somalia.

Link Title: Second huge power cut hits India
Message: Hundreds of millions of people have been left without electricity in northern and eastern India after a massive power breakdown.  More than half the country has been left without power after three grids collapsed - one of them for the second day running.  Hundreds of trains have come to a standstill and hospitals are running on backup generators.

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney visits Poland, after a visit to Israel that prompted criticism from a senior Palestinian official.  The Republican candidate is due to lay a wreath on Tuesday, to mark the Nazi invasion of Poland in September 1939.  But trade union movement Solidarity has distanced itself from the visit.

Link Title: China swimmer: Netizens leap to Ye's defence
Message: China's 16-year-old swimming prodigy Ye Shiwen has denied taking performance-enhancing drugs, after smashing a world record at the London Olympics.  Ye won gold in the 400m individual medley after breaking her personal best by at least five seconds.  There is strong reaction in China to questions over the performance of Olympic swimming champion Ye Shiwen, with internet users leaping to her defence.

Link Title: Why the fax thrives in Japan
Message: The Japanese are regarded as a hi-tech nation, the country that gave the world huge electronics companies.   Why, then, are faxes so popular there?
Images from the markets and mosques in Gaza's old quarter as Palestinians mark the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

VIDEO: Syrian government forces have been continuing their assault with artillery, ground forces and helicopter gunships on rebel-held areas Aleppo. The BBC's Ian Pannell and cameraman Darren Conway were trapped by fighting in Aleppo, from where they sent this report (contains graphic material)

Do you remember the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles?   While names like Carl Lewis, Daley Thompson, Greg Louganis, Mary Lou Retton and Sebastian Coe dominated the headlines - there was one other 'star' of those games.      Join us as we visit William Suitor to learn how he became the 'Rocketman."  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-19003777

Link Title: Q&A: Why Olympic seats are empty
Message: Despite huge demand for Olympic tickets prior to the games, areas of empty seats have been spotted at a number of events over the first few days of the competitions.  The London 2012 Olympics organisers have now attempted to defuse the empty seat row by clawing back 3,000 seats from sporting officials who have failed to turn up to events.  What could have been done to prevent this happening in the first place?  Should more tickets be made available to ordinary fans?  Has there been a fair distribution of tickets across the board?
Advances in technology mean African women can play a far greater role in the region's businesses, writes Barbara Birungi.

Link Title: Ancient pilgrim festival draws modern crowd
Message: When thousands are attending a festival in Norway to remember Scandinavia's most famous saint BBC's Maddy Savage is trying to find out why Trondheim is one of Europe's fastest growing pilgrim destinations.
How about this for Olympic spirit?  A man has offered his spare Olympic seats to a couple who travelled from Australia to watch the boxing but found their original tickets were fakes.

A massive power cut has caused disruption across northern India, including in the capital, Delhi.  The power cut affected more than 300 million people in Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, Himachal Pradesh and Rajasthan states.  It is unclear why the supply collapsed but reports say some states may have been using more power than authorised.

Link Title: STARS OF THE OLYMPIC OPENING CEREMONY BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Meet some of the stars of the Olympic opening ceremony.  Gary Connery is the stuntman who played the Queen during that breathtaking skydive during the ceremony.  AND  Desiree Henry was one of the chosen young athletes to who lit the Olympic cauldron.  Both of them joined us today on BBC World News to tell us about their experiences.

Link Title: What will we be eating in 20 years' time?
Message: Insect burgers could soon replace the hamburger on dinner plates as volatile food prices and a growing population mean we have to rethink what we eat.   So what might we be serving up in 20 years' time?

Link Title: Syria: Fear and hunger amid battle for Aleppo
Message: The BBC's Ian Pannell reports from the Syrian city of Aleppo where government forces have launched an all-out attack to drive rebel fighters from their strongholds.

Meet Pakistan's hockey team.    They are the country's only real chance of a medal, and they start their Olympic campaign when they take on Spain on Monday.  Out of a total of 10 Olympic medals Pakistan has won in its history, eight have been in field hockey.  But London 2012 comes after a period of turmoil for the team and at a difficult time for the country.  Aleem Maqbool reports...

Link Title: Romney to vow closer Israel ties
Message: Mitt Romney: US has moral duty to block Iran nuclear plans  US Republican presidential candidate said his country has a "moral imperative" to stop Iran from developing nuclear weapons.  Mr Romney said Iran was the most destabilising country in the world.  He said the US recognised Israel's right to defend itself and that it was right for the US to stand with Israel.

Link Title: Salmassi: The teacher who won Iran's first Olympic medal
Message: Video: The story of Ja'afar Salmassi, the teacher who won Iran's first Olympic medal
Images from Aleppo, where government forces have attacked rebels seeking to make Syria's biggest city their base of operations.
Deadly clashes between two communities in southern Ethiopia cause 20,000 people to flee across the border into Kenya, the Red Cross says.

The BBC's Ian Pannell is in Aleppo as government forces and rebels fight for control of Syria's largest city. Pannell says that rebels he had spoken to were "very upbeat" but that many civilians were very scared and trying to leave the city.    Watch Ian's report by following the link below http://bbc.in/P1AMbI

Link Title: Ian Pannell: Army moves in on Aleppo
Message: The BBC's Ian Pannell in Aleppo witnesses civilians fleeing as rebels try to resist a government offensive on the city.
Spain is in an "unprecedented" double-dip recession and the outlook for the country remains "very difficult", says the International Monetary Fund.

The former head of the UN mission in Syria says President Assad's fall is "only a matter of time", as Syrian forces renew an assault on Aleppo.   But Norwegian Maj Gen Robert Mood, who left Syria last week, said Mr Assad's fall would not necessarily mean an end to the 16-month-old conflict.

Microsoft's online message, phone and video chat service Skype, which has 600 million users worldwide, has denied making changes to its system "in order to provide law officers greater access" to its members' conversations.

Link Title: 'Hit and run' idea in Moon origin
Message: Moon formation: Was it a 'hit and run' accident?  A computer simulation shows the Moon's birth may not have been through the impact of a slow, Mars-sized object, but rather something much bigger and faster.
The body of Giuseppe Garibaldi, the 19th Century military leader who played a key role in the unification of Italy, is to be exhumed, in response to doubts about its true location.

Link Title: Who will light the Olympic flame?
Message: By the time the Olympic flame reaches the Olympic stadium tonight it would've have been carried by 8000 people.  However, we still don't know who will have the honour of lighting the flame in the opening ceremony.   Many names have been mentioned already like  Sir Roger Banister Sir Steve Redgrave Daley Thompson Prince William David Beckham Dame Kelly Holmes  Who do you think WILL be the person to light the Olympic flame?   AND   Who do you think SHOULD be the person to light the Olympic flame?  Let us know and we'll use some of your comments on air.

The mastermind of a white supremacist plot to kill Nelson Mandela, South Africa's first black president, has been convicted of treason.   A Pretoria court ruled that Boeremag group leader Mike du Toit was involved in nine bombings in Johannesburg's Soweto township in 2002.  He is the first person to be convicted of treason in South Africa since white minority rule ended in 1994.

WATCH: Breaking up old ships is a billion dollar industry in Bangladesh and it's been roaring ahead since restrictions were eased last year.    The BBC's Anbarasan Ethirajan has been given rare access to one of the ship breaking yards, near the port city of Chittagong, in the south of the country.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18993585
Babita and Mary Pilon with fireworks in the background.

Olympic officials in London say they are to blame for a flag row which jeopardised a women's football game at Hampden Stadium in Glasgow.  The North Korean women's team walked off after a video introducing their players showed the South Korean flag. They later returned to play the match.

Despite having protected status, the biodiversity in a large number of tropical forests is still continuing to decline according to a study covering 36 nations across the tropics in Africa, Asia and South America.    Habitat disruption, hunting and timber exploitation have been seen as signs of future decline.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-18970076

Link Title: Big brands on the rise in Nigeria
Message: Some African economies have experienced growth, even during the global downturn, but long before then Nigeria has been noted for its love of luxury goods.
Syrian rebels are reinforcing in preparation for a major battle in Aleppo, a BBC reporter says, as government forces reportedly head to the city.

North Korean state media have confirmed for the first time that the country's leader Kim Jong-un is married. Reports referred to him attending the opening of an amusement park with his wife, "Comrade Ri Sol-ju".  There had been much speculation about Mr Kim's private life in recent weeks when an unidentified woman was pictured attending events with him.  Kim Jong-un took over as leader of the country after the death of his father Kim Jong-il in December last year.

Link Title: WOMEN'S BOXING - LONDON 2012 - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: One innovation at these London Games is that for the first time - women are going to be competing in the boxing - hitherto it was a men only Olympic event.   Over the years many famous boxing names have come to the Games including Muhammad Ali.   This year, with women boxers making their debut, we thought it was a good idea to send the BBC's Karin Giannone to try and punch her way to a medal. Take a look at this video.

Link Title: More press freedom for Burma's media
Message: Cautious reforms being introduced by Burma's President Thein Sein are freeing up the rigid controls on the media.  Although repressive laws remain technically in force, practical guidelines have given print, television and internet journalists considerable leeway to report on everything including controversial political questions.

Greek triple jumper Voula Papachristou has been expelled from her national team after posting comments on Twitter which were deemed racist.  The Hellenic Olympic Committee said in a statement today she's been dropped from the Olympic team "for statements contrary to the values and ideas of the Olympic movement."  Voula Papachristou has since issued an apology on Facebook.  Should Olympic competitors be allowed to continue using social media during the competition?

On an East Jerusalem hillside, the firing of cannon marking the end of the daily Ramadan fast has been the job of one family for the past 120 years.    The ancient tradition is thought to have taken place in the Arab world for hundreds of years.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18958266

VIDEO: Women have come a long way at the Olympics and one competitor is about to go even further at London 2012.    Malaysia's Nur Suriya Mohamed Taibi will compete in the ten metre air rifle the twist is that she's 8 months pregnant.  Do you think her pregnancy will make her more determined or will it have an adverse effect on her performance?

The surface of Greenland's massive ice sheet has melted this month over an unusually large area according to NASA.  Scientists said the "unprecedented" melting took place over a larger area than has been detected in three decades of satellite observation.

Battles for control of the Syrian capital, Damascus, and the second largest city of Aleppo have reached their second week. Syrians in Aleppo have been speaking to the BBC about the continued fighting.

Link Title: OLYMPIC TORCH - STUART HUGHES - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: We wanted to share with you this video of our colleague BBC's Stuart Hughes who was among the 144 torchbearers carrying the Olympic flame across London today.  He lost part of his right leg after stepping on a landmine while covering the Iraq War in 2003.   Stuart is now a patron of the Manchester-based charity, the Mines Advisory Group.

BBC Future has reports on "Generation HIV" - the pioneering young adults who have battled the infection since birth. As these children survived infection and are now adults, they are giving scientists the first ever chance to understand what growing up with the virus really means both at the medical and the social level: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120723-generation-hiv

PHOTOS: Back in 1989, as the Berlin Wall fell, Gunther Holtorf and his wife Christine set out on what was meant to be an 18-month tour of Africa in their Mercedes Benz G Wagen.   Now, with more than 800,000km  on the clock, Gunther is still going.

Fighter jets have bombed eastern areas of Syria's second city Aleppo as fighting intensifies.  The attack is seen as a significant escalation in the conflict.  It is thought to be the first time that warplanes have been used in Aleppo.

Link Title: S Korea's Lee in national apology
Message: South Korean President Lee Myung-bak has apologised to the nation over corruption investigations involving his brother and former aides.   It's the latest incident in a series of corruption scandals among people close to the president.   Lee Sang-deuk was arrested earlier this month, following allegations that he took bribes from two troubled savings banks.

At least 39 people have been killed in flooding in central Nigeria's Plateau state after heavy rainfall caused a dam to overflow near the city of Jos.    A Red Cross spokesman said that about 200 homes, many of them made from mud, had been submerged or destroyed.     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18966160

VIDEO: The BBC's Ian Pannell has travelled to Syria's second city of Aleppo with "hundreds, maybe a thousand" rebels, as the battle for control of the city intensifies.   He said that the rebels "feel that they have the initiative, but the truth is they are overwhelmed".

"To live through it twice... it's not fair."    Samuel Granillo was a junior at Columbine High School when he survived the mass shooting there in 1999. Now he faces the tragedy of another mass shooting - this time at the movie theatre in Aurora, Colorado where one of his friends was killed.    The BBC's David Botti travelled to Colorado to learn how Mr Granillo balances helping friends mourn with the rush of memories the killings bring back.    http://bbc.in/MhVbtE    The suspect in last Friday’s shooting in Aurora appeared in court for the first time today. http://bbc.in/MD6PQQ

Today, we've started broadcasting from the studio that will be our home for the next 3 weeks during the Olympic Games.    The studio itself is overlooking the Olympic stadium.     What do you think of the stadium itself?   How does it compare to Beijing's 'Birds Nest' Olympic stadium?
London 2012 - BBC World News Studio

A string of bomb attacks and shootings in Baghdad and north of the capital has killed at least 91 people, say security and medical officials.    At least 172 people were wounded on one of the bloodiest days of the year.    Some 13 Iraqi towns and cities were hit in the spate of apparently co-ordinated attacks.
VIDEO: A Turkish designer has developed a prayer mat with a built-in navigation system, which lights up as soon as it finds the direction towards Mecca.

Link Title: Arab League calls on Assad to go
Message: Arab League foreign ministers call on Syria's President Assad to step down, as rebels tell the BBC they are encouraged by last week's assassinations.   Our correspondent says Islamist rebels where he is are receiving weapons and money from outside.

Link Title: Evita's life and legacy 60 years on
Message: Eva Peron, the flamboyant Argentine First Lady, died 60 years ago. But her influence lives on as an inspiration to some and as a celebrity icon. It is a divisive legacy.
A global super-rich elite has at least $21 trillion hidden in secret tax havens, according to a major study.  The figure is equivalent to the size of the US and Japanese economies combined.
Has Norway changed in the year since Anders Behring Breivik's terrorist attacks on Oslo and Utoeya? The BBC's Richard Galpin reports from Oslo.

Link Title: Profile: Aurora cinema shooting suspect James Holmes
Message: Before he allegedly shot 12 people dead at a cinema in Aurora, Colorado, on Friday, James Holmes was considered a quiet young man, introverted but pleasant.

Link Title: Leaving Cuba: The difficult task of exiting the island
Message: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford reports on Cuba's claustrophobic emigration laws, and fresh hopes that the restrictive policies might change.

Link Title: Syria crisis: Iraqis flee 'sectarian violence' in Damascus
Message: Iraqis who fled conflict in their home country and settled in Syria are now returning in droves, saying they are targeted by armed opposition groups.

One year after the United Nations declared a famine in parts of Somalia, there is plenty to praise and even more to fret about in a country still grappling with conflict, drought, and the muddled politics of international aid.  Why do aid agencies wait for disasters, not prevent them?

The US has begun mourning after 12 people were killed and 59 wounded in a shooting at a midnight showing of the new Batman film, the Dark Knight Rises.  US President Barack Obama ordered flags flown at half mast and said the day was "for prayer and reflection".  A man wearing a gas mask and body armour threw tear gas canisters at movie-goers in Aurora, Colorado, then fired on the crowd, witnesses said.

“It’s scary – You’re suspended in the air by another person who has your life in their hands.” http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes Nick Delpopolo was born in the former Yugoslavia. Nick’s American parents adopted him from an orphanage in Montenegro when he was a toddler. He started doing judo at age five in the same gym where his father took karate. Today, Nick is ranked number 1 in US and number 16 internationally in Judo. The BBC visited Nick in New York as he prepared to take on his first Olympics as one of America’s adopted athletes. Meet more US immigrant athletes in our video series running all this week. http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes
Nigeria's Saheed Adepoju is a young man with big dreams. He is the inventor of the Inye, a tablet computer designed for the African market which aims to compete with Apple's iPad.

Link Title: The madness of net scare stories
Message: “Is the web driving us mad?” So asked Newsweek magazine, in a cover story that fuelled some frantic global debate on technology and mental health. In response, BBC Future's Tom Chatfield argues that scare stories like this do little to enhance the debate regarding new technologies. What we should do is understand people's experiences with new technologies, and then ask how we can create happier, richer human experiences through these tools. Do you agree? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120719-the-madness-of-net-scare-stories

A court in Beijing has rejected an appeal by the dissident artist Ai Weiwei against a fine of more than 2 million dollars for alleged tax evasion.   He says police prevented him from attending the court today and has described the tax case as part of a Government campaign of intimidation.

Syrian rebels have captured a number of positions on the country's borders with Turkey and Iraq.  The push came a day after a bomb claimed the lives of three senior defence officials in Damascus.  The first images of President Assad since the attack have appeared, largely ending rumours he might have been hurt.

“My arms were way too long for the size of my body, my butt was too big, my feet were too flat... but the one thing I needed was heart.” http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes Danell Leyva was born in Cuba and came to the US as a toddler. Both his parents had been gymnasts when they were younger. Danell started the sport himself at the age of three. Now he competes for an Olympic medal. If he succeeds, it would be the first time a US man took home the gold for an individual gymnastics event in 20 years. The BBC’s David Botti went to Danell’s hometown of Miami, Florida, as he prepared to take on his first Olympics as one of America’s adopted athletes. Meet more US immigrant athletes in our video series running all this week. http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes

Link Title: How a movie changed one man’s vision forever
Message: Can you imagine life in 2D? That was how neuroscientist Bruce Bridgeman saw the world, until a trip to the cinema unexpectedly rewired his brain to see the world in 3D. As BBC Future reports, scientists are trying to understand what happened. www.bbc.com/future/story/20120719-awoken-from-a-2d-world

An iceberg twice the size of Manhattan has broken away from the Petermann Glacier in northern Greenland.    Images from a Nasa satellite show the island breaking off a tongue of ice that extends at the end of the glacier.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18896770

Today on Impact with Karin Giannone we will be talking about the latest developments is Syria.  The White House has said that the killing of three top figures at the heart of Syria's defence establishment shows President Bashar al-Assad is losing control. Do you agree?  Do you think that these are signs that President Assad's grip on the situation is loosening?   Do you think that the conflict in Syria has reached a "tipping point"?  Are we likely to see greater violence and greater chaos in the country as a result?  Let us know what you think and we may use some of your comments in a programme at 1300GMT.

Link Title: Viewpoints: Is it time to intervene in Syria?
Message: Coming up on GMT with Tim Wilcox:  With the suspension of the UN observer mission from Syria, and as fighting escalates and begins to envelope the capital, questions about whether, how or when the international community should intervene persist.  In this article five leading analysts tell the BBC what they think.  Do you think that the conflict in Syria has reached a "tipping point"? Can possible foreign intervention is now justified?  Join us at 1100GMT
Voting is underway in India to elect a new president with Pranab Mukherjee widely tipped to win the poll.

A bomb explosion has killed at least seven people on a bus carrying Israeli tourists in the eastern Bulgarian city of Burgas, Israeli officials say.  About 30 people were also injured when the bus exploded at Burgas airport, by the Black Sea.  Witnesses told Israeli TV that someone boarded the bus and a huge explosion immediately followed.

Link Title: SCHOOL OF 2012 - LONDON OLYMPICS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: The Olympics are just days away and lots of schools in Britain have had Olympic-themed sports days - including Colegrave Primary, our chosen School of 2012. The kids can see the Olympic Park from their playground but as the BBC's Lucy Hockings discovered, some exciting news means they're going to be doing a lot more than just watching the Games.

“Badminton is in my blood. Cannot live without badminton.” http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes Tony Gunawan was born and raised in Indonesia. In 2000, he won the gold medal in badminton for his home country. Ten years ago, Tony came to the US intending to spend the rest of his career coaching. But things changed when he was granted American citizenship last summer. Tony will again compete for badminton gold at the London Olympics, this time for Team USA. The BBC’s Franz Strasser visited Tony in Covina, California to see how he prepares to be one of America’s Adopted Athletes. Meet more US immigrant athletes in our video series running all this week http://bbc.in/adoptedathletes

Link Title: Blast on Israeli bus in Bulgaria
Message: At least 3 people have been killed in an explosion on a bus carrying Israeli tourists in Bulgaria. The incident happened at the airport of the city of Burgas on the Black Sea. Witnesses told Israeli TV that someone boarded the bus and a huge explosion immediately followed.
WATCH: Images from Colombia where members of an indigenous group who say they are tired of being in the crossfire of the long-running civil conflict drive some 100 soldiers from a local base.

In the Hub with Nik Gowing:   We'll have the views in Washington and Moscow on developments in Syria after the reported deaths of senior regime figures in an explosion, and gun battles in Damascus.   Also we'll take a look at the new permits to drink alcohol in Mumbai.   And as Bollywood's first Superstar Rajesh Khanna dies we'll take a look at his career. Join us at 1600GMT

It's already been discussed how some people feel there is now too much weight given to commercial priorities.  But some big-name brands, such as Coca-Cola, have been linked to the Olympics for nearly 100 years.   Here, take a look at how sponsorship first started, and how it has changed the Games.

Link Title: Robot swarms aim to bring buildings to life
Message: BBC Future has launched another column today - Nature's Tricks by Christopher Mims, which looks at the scientists, architects and engineers taking lessons from nature’s ingenuity to create a better blueprint for our world. First up: Meet the man who wants to create buildings that understand everything about us. Creepy or cool? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120717-bringing-buildings-to-life

The Indian actor widely recognised as Bollywood's first superstar, Rajesh Khanna has died at the age of 69. His family says he had been ill for some time.   Mr Khanna made his name playing the romantic lead in a string of films which were massive hits in the 1960s and 1970s.   He starred in more than 160 movies and was also elected to parliament in the 1990s.

Worldwide 1 in 10 deaths from heart disease, diabetes and breast and bowel cancer are the result of inactivity.   According to new research published to coincide with the Olympics - lack of exercise is causing 5 million deaths a year globally. That's as many deaths around the world as cigarettes.  How important is exercise to you?  Do you find time to exercise?  Which form of exercise to you enjoy?  How often do you exercise?  Let us know and we'll use your comments on our GMT programme with George Alagiah.

Link Title: Mandela: 'He charms bees out of the hive'
Message: Nelson Mandela's 94th birthday is being marked by people across the world. His granddaughter Ndileka spoke to BBC reporter Milton Nkosi at an exhibition of photographs in Johannesburg, celebrating Mandela's life. Send us your birthday wishes for the elder statesman of South African politics.
Bruce Lee's daughter produces a documentary on her martial artist father's life, portraying him as film star, fighter and philosopher.

Link Title: PHORIA - CULTURAL OLYMPIAD - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: In the English seaside town of Brighton, thousands gathered to see the Olympic torch and to send it on its way through its tour of south east England.   But the Olympics are not only about the torch or the sport, there is also a cultural Olympiad taking place. BBC World's Lucy Hockings went along to meet some of the musicians that were taking part.

“It looks so light and easy but under water it’s extremely hard work and you feel like you’re dying.” http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18821583 Mariya Koroleva was born in Russia and came to the US at the age of 9. When she was 14, Mariya made the “A team” and competed with girls almost twice her age. Mariya’s coach told her father if she worked hard, she would be good enough to compete in the Olympics. Mariya says synchro was crucial for her adjusting to life in America. Today, she makes up one part of an Olympic synchronised swimming duet, competing for the US at the London games. The BBC’s Franz Strasser went underwater with Mariya in her hometown of Walnut Creek, California, as she prepared to take on the Olympics as one of America’s Adopted Athletes. Meet more US immigrant athletes in our video series running all this week http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18821583

Israel's centre-right Kadima party has decided to leave PMr Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition in a dispute over military conscription for ultra-Orthodox Jews. According to reports a vast majority of the party led by Shaul Mofaz was in favour of leaving the coalition after only joining it in May. It reduces the governing coalition by 28 members but still leaves it in place with a majority.

Link Title: SCHOOL OF 2012 - LONDON OLYMPICS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: VIDEO: Here is another episode from our School of 2012 series.  You might think that having the Olympics in the heart of your community would be a dream come true for most children. But not every pupil at Colegrave Primary, the school closest to the Olympic Park is impressed as BBC's Lucy Hockings discovered.

"I've taken 20 years of an artist's early career and I've shrunken it into 2."     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18839324         Can a young artist find success outside of the gallery system?      In this week's edition of Living Online we meet Paul Zepeda and Borbay, two New York based painters that are taking an open source approach to the creative process. They show the BBC's Matt Danzico how using the internet to promote, share and sell their work is changing the business of art.          http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18839324
Nigeria's authorities start knocking down the famous slum dwellings built on water in its biggest city Lagos.

Hello, on Impact today we are intrigued by the debut of the first HIV prevention drug in the US. It's a daily pill that could be used if your partner is HIV positive or if you are at high risk of infection.   So in your view, is this a breakthrough or could it encourage people to take more risks? Mishal

On Newsday with Babita Sharma in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore, we hear from the man who until recently was Syria's Ambassador to Iraq. Nawef-al-Fares tells the BBC that all the major high casualty bombings in Syrian cities have been carried out by the authorities themselves, using al-Qaeda operatives.  A Damascus resident and opposition activist tells us she believes the fighting in the capital means it is only a matter of time before President Assad is swept from power. All that and more on Newsday at 2300 and 2400 GMT.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18864629

The new Batman movie - The Dark Knight Rises - will premier tonight in New York. It's expected to become the biggest blockbuster of the summer. But where is Batman without the Batmobile?   Ever wondered what the vehicle looks like in real life?   Here’s BBC’s Suzanna Reid meeting the man behind the special effects and Batman’s toys.   http://youtu.be/dikk0MkfUbU

North Korea's top military chief Ri Yong-ho has been removed from his job, state media say, seven months after Kim Jong-un came to power.  Is this, as some analysts suggest, a start of possible political purge in order to cement Kim Jong-un's grip on the military?

“Running didn’t mean anything. You run because the soldiers are coming to get you.” http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18821583   Meb Keflezghi was born in Eritrea and came to the US at the age of 12. He first discovered running as a sport in a primary school physical education class – little did he know that it would one day take him all the way to an Olympic silver medal performance in Athens in 2004.   Today, he is preparing to compete in his second Olympic marathon for the US. The BBC’s Franz Strasser travelled to Mammoth Lakes, California to get a look at how he trains and ask about his experience as one of America’s Adopted Athletes.   Meet more US immigrant athletes in our video series running all this week http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18821583

Link Title: BBC London 2012 Olympic Games advert (full length)
Message: As athletes begin arriving in London for the Olympic Games we wanted to share our promotional video with you.  In the video the UK is seen as a giant stadium with Olympic athletes preparing and competing in a range of landscapes.  Let us know what you think of it?

Muslims in South Asia can now buy a new device which recites the Koran in as many as 28 languages, including Urdu, Bengali and Malayalam.  Iqra-e-Koran was launched to "help Muslims of the sub-continent in practicing their religion".  The Chinese-made "talking Koran" can also recite from Islam's holy text in English, French, Spanish and Pashto.

The attack on the Syrian village of Tremseh mainly targeted the homes of rebels and activists, the UN mission in the country has said. A UN spokeswoman issued a statement after experts visited the scene of Thursday's attack, 25km north-west of the city of Hama.

US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has suggested the Syrian army "deliberately murdered civilians" in the village of Tremseh.  Up to 200 people are reported to have died in an army attack on the village, which would make it the bloodiest single event in the Syrian conflict. However, reports suggest that a large number of the casualties were rebel fighters.  The Syrian army admitted killing a "big number of terrorists" but no civilians.  UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said the attack casts "serious doubt" on President Assad's commitment to a peace plan.

Coming next week to BBCNews.com  Meet America’s Adopted Athletes, the immigrant Olympians born elsewhere, but hoping to bring gold home to the US.   Check out our trailer for the video series below & visit our BBC Sport Olympic page here http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/2012/  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mPh2JJRGVco&feature=youtu.be

Link Title: SCHOOL OF 2012 - LONDON OLYMPICS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: The closest school to the Olympic Park is Colegrave Primary school.   In the next instalment of our 'School of 2012' series Lucy Hockings visits its pupils and finds everyone trying to make the area looking fantastic before it's at the centre of the world's attention.
Thousands of illegal gold miners are operating in the Peruvian Amazon, one of the most bio-diverse places on earth, but can the government succeed in regulating their activities?

INTERACTIVE: Check out our new body-fat calculator which tells you if you are a healthy weight for your height and how you rank against others globally.      Using the values that you input into the calculator, it works out your Body Mass Index as well as where you are in relation to the rest of the population in your country and the world for your gender and age.       http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-18770328
The Olympics was once about amateurism. But have the modern Games become too much about sponsorship and commerciality?

Link Title: Responding to lucky and unlucky numbers
Message: Now some of you may be all too aware but today is Friday 13th. It's a date that, largely thanks to Hollywood, many have come to associate with bad luck and misfortune.  What do you think about Friday the 13th - does it fill you with dread, do you use superstition to try and ward off bad things happening, or do you think it's just a load of nonsense?   Send us your comments and we'll use some of them on our GMT programme with George Alagiah at 1100GMT

At least 200 people are reported to have been killed in the Syrian village of Tremseh, in Hama province. Opposition activists quoted residents as saying the village was attacked with helicopter gunships and tanks. Pro-government Shabiha militia later went in on foot and carried out execution-style killings, they said.  State media said "terrorist groups" had carried out a massacre to raise tensions ahead of a UN Security Council meeting on the Syria observer mission

Link Title: BBC Picture This - Jeff Ragsdale: The man who gave the world his number
Message: Call me?  What happens when you post ads around town seeking human contact?     http://bbc.in/LcoH2o  Jeff Ragsdale went through a difficult break-up last year. Finding himself alone and isolated in New York City he posted a flier that read: "If anyone wants to talk about anything, call me."  See a small sample of how the world responded to this "lonely guy" below and visit  http://bbc.in/LcoH2o to meet Jeff for yourself.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OI2NuadDG6Y&feature=youtu.be

Link Title: Nigerians die in fuel tanker fire
Message: More than 100 people have died in southern Nigeria after a tanker carrying petrol crashed.  The authorities say the vehicle did not immediately burst into flames, so nearby villagers rushed to collect the fuel.  But the tanker then exploded, burning many of them to death.

It's a historic day for the Olympics and for Saudi women.   Two Saudi athletes will be the centre of attention when they turn out for their events - why? Because they're female.   It's the first time women will compete for the Saudi Olympic team.

Jewish and Muslim organisations across Europe have joined together in a backlash against a ruling by a court in Germany outlawing the practice of circumcising young boys.   A district court in Cologne ruled at the end of June that circumcision of infants on religious grounds amounted to grievous bodily harm. But several European Jewish and Islamic groups released a joint statement on Wednesday, saying circumcision is fundamental to their faiths and should be legally protected.   Do you agree with the court's ruling or do you think that circumcision should be under legal protection?

On GMT with George Alagiah we'll be live from Bush House as BBC World Service broadcasts for the last time from its iconic HQ.   From there it has fulfilled its historic mission, highlighted in its motto - nation shall speak unto nation.   Join us at 1100GMT

Details of an additional 3,500 troops expected to be provided to help with 2012 London Olympics security are set to be announced by ministers later.  It comes after it emerged that UK armed forces are on standby to provide more troops in addition to 13,500 already agreed amid fears private contractor G4S may not have enough trained staff.  G4S said it had "some issues in relation to workforce supply".

Syria's ambassador to Iraq says he has defected to the opposition. Nawaf Fares is the first senior Syrian diplomat to abandon the government of President Bashar al-Assad. The move comes just a week after a Syrian general from a powerful family close to President Assad also defected.

With age comes wisdom, the saying goes, but at Public School 124 in New York's Chinatown, the pupils are wise beyond their years when it comes to chess. The BBC's Franz Strasser visited the 'Panda Pawns' - the name for the school chess club - and followed the students to this year's National Championships in Nashville, Tennessee to see what it takes to raise a chess champion. See our video report by visiting  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18636078

What do you think has been the biggest breakthrough in technology in recent years? Peter Diamandis is on a mission to create fundamental change. Here, he tells BBC Future how how grand challenges and cash prizes can bring about radical breakthroughs in science and technology. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120710-the-x-prize-incentive
