PHOTOGRAPHS: The pictures that tell the story of a lost China - how photographs like these are in demand to recapture snapshots of the past.    Historical photographs are exceptionally rare in China. A turbulent 20th century of war and invasion in the country meant many archives were destroyed.     Today there's a new craze for old photographs sweeping China and a major effort is underway to bring the remaining photographs together.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18784990

Link Title: SCHOOL OF 2012 - LONDON OLYMPICS - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: WATCH: Over the next several days BBC's Lucy Hockings will visiting the school closest to the Olympic Park to try and see the Olympics through the pupils eyes.  The motto for the games is "inspire a generation". So, is it working? We decided to follow the kids at Colgrave Primary School in East London which is our School of 2012.

Link Title: Law and order: Blame it on the brain
Message: Is "my brain made me do it" a plausible defence in court? Advances in neuroscience are transforming our criminal justice systems, but as BBC Future reports the jury is out on just how far it should go: http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120710-blame-it-on-the-brain

What do you think of the new effort on family planning centred on a summit today in London?     Melinda Gates believes that contraception should not be controversial, and has been unnecessarily linked to the debate on abortion. Is she right?     On Impact we'll hear live from the talks and a campaigning politician in the Philippines. Mishal

On GMT with George Alagiah we will have the latest from Spain as Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy announces a rise in taxes and a cuts to local government budgets.     This is the government's recipe for dealing with its bloated debt but will it work?    Join us at 1100GMT

Hi it's Babita here preparing to go on-air for Newsday.   Coming up on the programme we have the latest from Egypt where thousands have returned to Tahrir Square to protest against the ongoing turmoil in Egyptian politics. We're also speaking to an expert in North Korea to find out if he knows who the mystery woman is pictured alongside Kim Jong Un. Any ideas?   Join us for Newday with myself Babita Sharma in London & Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore from 06SSGT/22GMT

The Washington Monument, the towering obelisk at the centre of the capital city of the US, is expected to stay closed to the public until 2014 as crews work to repair damage from an earthquake last year. The BBC News Washington bureau went down to The National Mall to take a closer look at DC's tallest structure. See our story on the planned repairs by visiting http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18786990

Today's weather prognosis for London is as follows: Rather cool and cloudy, with rain or showers for many.    The UK has just gone through what was the wettest June on record.    July has not started that promisingly either and with the Olympic Games only around the corner many fear that the Summer Olympics may not be that summery.    How will bad weather affect you enjoyment of the Games?     Do you think, in case bad weather continues, that London will be able to cope?

Link Title: Africa's journey to space takes off
Message: As the US space programme loses momentum with the retirement of the space shuttle, those of Ghana and Nigeria are just taking off. Here we explore impact of these technologies on wider issues.

Link Title: In pictures: Beijing's Olympic venue legacy
Message: WATCH: As London prepares for its Olympics, the fate of Beijing's venues after 2008 raises questions about future use.

More than 100 000 deaths could be prevented worldwide if contraception was distributed to all couples who asked for it.   That's according to a study published in The Lancet medical journal, ahead of a meeting of world health leaders in London tomorrow - which will focus on family planning.  Researchers say it would benefit women in developing countries who suffer complications from pregnancy and abortion.   What do you think is the single most important thing we could do to cut down on the number of women who die as a result of uncontrolled pregnancy?  We will use your comments on our 1200GMT bulletin with Ros Atkins.
Former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert is found guilty of corruption by a court in Jerusalem after a lengthy trial.

Join Babita Sharma in London and Sharanit Leyl in Singapore for Newsday. Coming up on the programme we have more of the harrowing evidence given by the first prosecution witness in the genocide trial of the former Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic. And a six year marriage over in just two weeks - Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes finalise their speedy divorce. All that and more on Newsday from 06SGT/22GMT.

"Just an old sweet song - keeps Georgia on my mind." Were you expecting peach trees and Southern hospitality?   Meet an American artist with the other Georgia on his mind.  http://bbc.in/L4nk5E  John H Wurdeman first visited the nation of Georgia in 1996 - today he is dedicated to preserving Georgian wine culture.

Egyptian President Mohammed Mursi's order to reconvene parliament has been rejected by the highest court, which says its ruling that led to the assembly's dissolution is binding.  Is Mohammed Mursi heading for a new confrontation with the country's powerful military council, over the dissolved parliament?
TAKE A LOOK: A zoomable spectacular image of Mars taken by the panoramic camera on the Exploration Rover.

India's PM, Manmohan Singh, has been dubbed an "underachiever" by the US based Time magazine, which says he appears "unwilling to stick his neck out" on reforms that will put the country back on the growth path.     Do you think that this is a fair criticism or do you think it's, as some have suggested, distasteful and incorrect?     Mr. Singh has long been praised for his pivotal role in liberalising the Indian economy but has he been successful in dealing with the slowdown in economic growth?    How has he dealt with corruption in the country?      Let us know what you think and we may use your comments on the Hub programme with Nik Gowing at 1600GMT
In an interview with German television, broadcast on Sunday, President Assad was asked if he would be prepared to step down if it brought peace to Syria.

Join Babita Sharma in London and Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore for Newsday. We'll have the latest on Egypt where the military and the new president seem to be on a collision course. We're live in Taipei for a look at what's making the news. And we hear how truck drivers in Pakistan are trying to make ends meet after the supply route to Afghanistan was disrupted.

President Barack Obama is campaigning in Ohio today and his landmark healthcare reform act is sure to be a topic of conversation in this critical battleground state.  http://bbc.in/MP2koG  The BBC visited Parma Community General Hospital in Ohio to hear the opinions of local residents.   Where do you stand on the issue of healthcare?

What is there to live for when you are waiting to die?  http://bbc.in/NbcBq8  The BBC's Paul Adams recently travelled to Livingston, Texas to meet Ivan Abner Cantu, a convicted murderer living in a maximum security death row facility.  Last year, he came within a month of being executed, but was granted a stay. The convicted murderer maintains that he is innocent and looks forward to being released one day.

Conflict in the DRC. Rebel soldiers have routed Congolese government troops. Thousands of civilians are fleeing the fighting.It is our top story on Focus on Africa TV tonight at 1730GMT on BBC World News. Share your thoughts on this story.Our great lakes expert Kassim Kayira will join me in the studio to provide context and analysis.We will feature some of your comments on the show. Komla

Chinese police say they have broken up two major child trafficking gangs and freed 181 children across the country. Greater freedom of movement as a result of China's economic reforms is thought to have also made it easier for trafficking gangs to operate.

Link Title: FACEBOOK BBC WORLD NEWS - 2 MILLION LIKES
Message: WATCH: BBC WORLD NEWS - 2 MILLION 'LIKES'   There are exciting times on the BBC World News Facebook page. We've hit 2 million likes which we're thrilled about.   We started the page in 2009 and we hoped to create a place where we can give you information, but where you can talk about the news too.   So 2 million of you have taken us up on the offer - but who are you? Take a look at this.

For more than half a century, the Australian girl guides have pledged allegiance to God and Queen Elizabeth - but that's about to change.  The organisation says its members will now promise to serve the community. The re-wording is designed to attract new recruits from all faiths and cultures but will it work?

Join me Kasia Madera in London and Sharanjit Leyl in Singapore for NEWSDAY. We will have the latest on a UN mandate for Syria and the jailing of Argentina's military leaders over the theft of the babies of political prisoners. That's NEWSDAY, broadcast from 0600-0830 Singapore time; 2300-0130 bst

It used to be that authoritarian regimes could get away with cracking down on their populations because their actions went largely unseen. http://bbc.in/MMbJNN  But times have changed - digital cameras, smartphones and easy access to the internet have all made it harder for today's autocrats to combat their own people.   Author William Dobson's new book, "The Dictator's Learning Curve," takes a look at the evolution of authoritarian tactics.

Two young women in Dubai have started a Twitter campaign urging foreigners to dress modestly when in public.   One tweet suggested setting up a police department where you could complain about inappropriate clothing.  The famous saying goes 'When in Rome, do as the Romans do' but in Rome, the Romans are the majority whereas in the UAE, Emiratis make up less than 20% of the population's estimated 8 million people.

BBC Future has launched a new column called Code Red on science, technology and security. First up: the technology that taps into a soldier’s thought patterns - is it a cool advance or a chilling insight into the future of warfare? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120704-mind-control-moves-into-battle
Wikileaks begins releasing more than two million emails it dubs the "Syria files", promising embarrassment for both Syria and its opponents.

Link Title: Goal-line system set for go ahead
Message: Goal-line technology is set to get the go-ahead today but the debate about is not slowing down.   Does the game need it or should human error remain to play a part in football? How will it affect the game? Will we soon see the same technology applied to the off-side rule? Is the decision long overdue?  Other sports like tennis, cricket and rugby have all embraced technology to assist officials in making the right decisions.  But in football, the powers-that-be have always been reluctant. Fifa's outspoken president Sepp Blatter said he didn't want to slow the game down or make it less exciting.   Let us know where you stand? Are you for it or against it? Why?  Your comments may be used during the Impact programme at 1300 GMT

On GMT with George Alagiah we'll be discussing South Korea's proposal to resume whaling as part of scientific research programmes similar to Japan's. The move has been widely criticized.   What do you make of it? Is it in effect, as some countries are suggesting, an excuse for a return to commercial whaling?   Your comments will be used on our programme at 1100GMT so let us know what you think.
The mistreatment of female athlete Pinki Pramanik betrays the insensitivity of the state and sections of the media.
Nearly one million Americans are marking 4 July without power as utility firms scramble to restore service five days after severe storms in the east.

History will be made at the upcoming London Olympics when South Africa's Oscar Pistorius competes in the 400m race. It means he'll be the first amputee track athlete ever to compete at the Olympics. He runs with carbon fibre prosthetic blades and will be in the Paralympic Games too. Some, however, argue that he should compete ONLY in the Paralympic Games. What do you think?

Link Title: HIGGS BOSON 'GOD PARTICLE' - WHAT IS IT? BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Today you've been hearing a lot about the Higgs Boson, or the 'God Particle'. But what is it?   Here is BBC's science correspondent Jonathan Amos who used some props to try and explain it in a different way.   Watch the video and let us know if you understand it better now.

The Turkish army says the bodies of two pilots whose jet was shot down by Syria have been found at the bottom of  the eastern Mediterranean sea. The jet was shot down over the waters last month and Syria insists the plane had strayed into its airspace. A US deep-sea exploration vessel located the remains about a thousand metres underwater.

Scientists at the Large Hadron Collider claim the discovery of a particle believed to be the long-sought Higgs boson. The world of science is excited but why does it matter for ordinary people? Do you find this discovery to be inspirational? Let us know and we may use your comments on Impact with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT

Link Title: Ecuador's mix of folk and modern medicine
Message: Is there space for traditional medicine in today's hospitals? Well one clinic in Ecuador is using traditional indigenous treatments alongside modern medicine.

The US has announced that Pakistan is to re-open crucial supply routes to Nato-led forces in Afghanistan after Washington apologised for killing 24 of its soldiers in November.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18691691    US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said Islamabad would not charge any transit fees when the lines re-open.    Pakistan has not yet commented on the US statement.    How will Nato exit from Afghanistan?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-17999603

Have we created online ghettos that mirror our real world?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18680485  Hispanic and African-American audiences now claim about 30% of Twitter's user base.  Meanwhile, white users claim 90% of US traffic on Pinterest.com And Tumblr.com has seen an over-representation of Asian Americans as of late.  What do our digital communities say about us?

Link Title: WIMBLEDON - BILLIE JEAN KING INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: WATCH: Billie Jean King, a legend of tennis, joined us today in our London studios. She won a total of 39 Grand Slams including a record 20 Wimbledon titles, in a glittering career spanning three decades. After leaving the game she's continued her fight against prejudice by campaigning for women's rights, and she even found a way back to the tennis court after recovering from a knee injury. She began by talking about the stunning victory of Germany's Sabine Lisicki over top seed Maria Sharapova at Wimbledon yesterday.

Link Title: Aamir Khan: Bollywood star on new TV show
Message: WATCH: An estimated 400 million people, that's about 1 in 3 Indians, have tuned in to watch a new show on Indian TV. It doesn't have a prime-time slot and it's not light entertainment. Presented by Bollywood superstar, Aamir Khan looks at hard-hitting social issues. And it's even prompted politicians in some states to change the law. Rajini Vaidyanathan went to meet the actor behind one of India's most successful shows.

As the interest rate scandal in London deepens after Barclays' chief executive resigns we want to hear from you how universal is this banking culture? How will it impact as a financial centre? Will Bob Diamond's departure solve anything? We'll use some of your comments on Impact with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT
Barclays chief executive Bob Diamond resigns with immediate effect.

Can you imagine being married alongside two thousand other couples?  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18655836    John and Cathy Williams were paired at random three years before their marriage by Unification Church founder Sun Myong Moon and took part in a very large group wedding. Thirty years later we visit the Williams to see how they have fared since then.

Amelia Earhart and her navigator Fred Noonan took off from Papua New Guinea aboard an Electra 10E aircraft 75 years ago today.      They were never seen again.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18670292     An expedition to the uninhabited Pacific island of Nikumaroro is setting out today from Hawaii  looking for clues to her disappearance.     Will these efforts help solve one of the great mysteries in aviation history?

Hi it's Babita here. Coming up on Newsday we have the latest from Mali where islamist militants have attacked mosques in the historic city of Timbuktu. Plus a million people are displaced from their homes after severe flooding in Assam. Will the Indian Prime Minister's pledge of aid help those affected? And we have a special report into how high levels of smog is affecting Hong Kong's skyline. Join myself and Sharanjit Leyl for Newsday from 0600HKT/SGT/2200GMT.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-18668783 Mexico's old ruling party, the PRI, is set to return to power as early official results indicate its candidate Enrique Pena Nieto has won the presidential election. Here are a few candid shots from our staff that covered yesterday's events from Mexico City. What is your reaction to the apparent victory of Enrique Pena Nieto? What should be the priorities of the new president?
The 2012 Olympic Games present a rare opportunity for Palestinian athletes, whose sports have suffered from the conflict with Israel.

Link Title: BAHRAIN BOMB INVESTIGATION - FRANK GARDNER INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: For more than a year there have been ongoing clashes between the pro democracy protestors and the police in Bahrain. Now the British police are in Bahrain to support an international investigation into a huge find of sophisticated bomb-making materials. Last month, the authorities in Bahrain seized more than 100kg of high explosives. BBC's Security correspondent Frank Gardner joined us on BBC World News to explain the significance and the implications of the recent developments.

Link Title: Are Spain the best team of all time?
Message: The day after the night before...After hammering Italy 4-0 in the Euro 2012 final, is the Spain we saw in action the best national team of all time? They were, after all, playing without a striker for most of the time, and had been criticised by some early in the tournament for being 'boring'. If you're Italian, could you have imagined a worse night? Where does this leave Italian football and the existing squad? I'd love to have your thoughts for our Impact debate at 13GMT on BBC World News. Karin Giannone

Link Title: Mexico election: Full in-tray for new president
Message: Mexico's new president will not take office until December, but there are plenty of issues mounting up to be tackled - above all security, says the BBC's Will Grant in Mexico City.
Images from Mexico where people are going to the polls in a presidential election dominated by the economy and war on drugs.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18662555

Link Title: In pictures: HK celebrations and protests
Message: Pictures from Hong Kong, where protesters have tried to disrupt the lavish events to celebrate the 15th anniversary of the territory's return to Chinese control. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18662974
South American foreign ministers of the Mercosur bloc gather in Argentina to discuss measures against Paraguay over President Lugo's impeachment.

Link Title: Bolt shocked by Blake in 100m win
Message: Jamaica is in a state of a shock as national hero Usain Bolt is defeated in the 100m final at the Jamaican Olympic trials by Yohan Blake. Blake's time of 9.75 seconds is the fastest time in the world this year and a personal best. Bolt and Blake will be joined by former world record holder Asafa Powell representing the island nation at the 2012 London Olympic Games that begin next month.    Who do you think will win the title of world's fastest man?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/18649280

US President Barack Obama has toured neighbourhoods ravaged by a wildfire which drove tens of thousands of people from their homes in Colorado's Waldo Canyon. The visit comes after Mr Obama issued a disaster declaration, allowing federal funds to be used to combat the blaze.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18639894    The family of Susan Solich in the city of Colorado Springs posted this picture yesterday on Facebook showing the before and after of their family home. The family has told the BBC that Susan and her four grandsons have lost everything that wasn't taken with them when they were evacuated - only the fireplace and foundations currently remain of the home.    Photo credit: Hanna Solich

Ciudad Juarez has had many labels in recent years. One that stuck firmly was given at the height of Mexico's crackdown on drug gangs: the world's deadliest city.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-18637470    As Mexicans prepare to elect a new president on Sunday, the BBC's Ian Sherwood visits Ciudad Juarez to see how the city, which has been the scene of brutal drug gang killings, is faring.    Have things started to change?

It takes two hours to ride New York City's A-line subway train from end to end - along the way you'll pass through Harlem, upper Manhattan, Brooklyn and then reach the beach in Queens.    Join us on a ride through NYC's history on the line that is the inspiration for one of jazz's best known tunes.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-18623559    125th St image below appears courtesy of Melanie Burford

Link Title: SAUDI WOMEN DRIVERS - SARA AL KHALIDI INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: INTERVIEW: In Saudi Arabia a group of activists are today flouting the Saudi ban on female drivers by getting behind the wheel. They're marking the first anniversary of a women's protest drive which attracted attention around the world last year. We were joined on our Impact programme by Sara Al Khalidi whose mother is one of the women taking part in the protest. Why do you think driving has been so sensitive in Saudi Arabia?

Hi there. It's Lucy on Impact today. We want your comments on the new first lady of Egypt, Naglaa Ali Mahmoud. She's being discussed on social networking sites and compared to Suzanne Mubarak and Jehan Sadat. Some are attacking her appearance, others are hotly defending her and say she fairly represents the average Egyptian woman. What do you think? And what about the role of "First Lady" - is it important or necessary? We're joined by commentator Nabila Ramdani and I'll put your questions to her. See you soon.

Link Title: In pictures: China's Shenzhou-9 returns to Earth
Message: WATCH: Stunning images of China's Shenzhou-9 manned spacecraft returning to Earth after a 13-day mission.

Coming up on Newsday with Kasia Madera and Sharanjit Leyl more on the fallout of the banking scandal. And we'll be watching as China's Shenzhou-9 spacecraft as it returns to earth after the country's first manual docking in orbit.

Hundreds of homes in Colorado Springs have already been destroyed by the Waldo Canyon fire. Shifting winds today have made it even more difficult for the 800 firefighters in the area to tackle the 29 sq mile (75sq km) blaze.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18632545    BBCNews.com user Meghan Blanton sent us this photo from just outside Colorado Springs    "The atmosphere is very very hot and smoky. I have asthma so at times it gets hard to breathe. Public health has been telling citizens to stay inside with the windows closed and to keep cool, so that's what we're trying to do. We're expecting a thunderstorm here soon, so it's probably going to get windy quickly, which is just going to bury us in smoke.”

Do you know this murdered teenager?   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18529368    In part three of our video series we reveal the faces of the two victims in a 33-year-old cold case. The boy and girl have never been identified - but now a forensic artist using digital technology is giving the investigators new hope of finding a killer.

It's one of the flagship achievements of the Obama administration. The US Supreme Court has upheld Barack Obama's healthcare reform bill. Stacy Hilliard (Republican commentator) and Rob Carolina (chair of the UK branch of Democrats Abroad)  joined Karin Giannone on our Impact programme to discuss its implications.
Palestinian Islamist militant group Hamas says one of its members has been assassinated in the Syrian capital Damascus.

We are at the US Supreme Court waiting to hear their decision on the 2010 Obama healthcare legislation.    Follow along on our live event page by visiting  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18582607
Hundreds of people have been protesting in Mumbai against police raids on high profile bars and clubs
More banks are under investigation after Barclays was fined £290m for trying to manipulate the interest rates at which banks lend to each other.

Link Title: BALBIR SINGH OLYMPIC GOLD MEDAL WINNER LONDON 1948
Message: Only one month remains until the start of the London 2012 Olympics. To mark the occasion we were visited today in our London studios by a very special guest. Balbir Singh was a gold medal winner the last time the Games came to town in 1948. Furthermore he also won Olympic gold with the Indian men's hockey team in Helsinki 1952 and Melbourne 1956. Mr Singh spoke about his experience to Karin Giannone on the Hub.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P66mKMDaBtM&feature=youtu.be

We asked for your photos from the fires raging in Colorado - check out the shots below from BBC friends and followers just like you. If you have photos from the fires that you would like to share, please email yourpics@bbc.co.uk or submit at http://bbcnewsupload.streamuk.com/

Link Title: Brian Greene: Exploring the unknown universe
Message: BBC Future's new series - Future Thinking - kicks off today with renowned scientists, inventors and futurologists revealing the one big idea that they want to solve. First up is physicist Brian Greene who wants answers to perhaps the biggest question of all. What idea would you like to solve? http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120626-exploring-the-unknown-universe

Link Title: Could Mohenjo Daro be lost forever?
Message: Archaeologists in Pakistan are struggling to save one of the most important historic sites in south Asia. Mohenjo Daro , in the southern Pakistani province of Sindh, was one of the first planned cities to have been built anywhere in the world.  But the Bronze Age site has been rapidly deteriorating, leading some experts to fear it could soon be lost.

Link Title: PREGNANCY REPORT - LYNSEY POLLARD INTV - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: WATCH: According to a new report by the British-based charity Save The Children. Pregnancy is the biggest killer of teenage girls worldwide.   It says that 1 million teenage girls die or suffer serious injury, infection or disease every year because of pregnancy or childbirth.   In many countries girls marry too young and become pregnant before their bodies are ready to bear children.   And it stresses that urgent action should be taken to make contraception more available with more advice on the health benefits of later pregnancies.   Lynsey Pollard from Save the Children just got back from Ethiopia and she joined George Alagiah on the GMT programme.
Mexicans go to the polls on 1 July to elect a new president. BBC Mundo spoke to several people in different parts of the country to see which issues matter most to them.

We have an update today on the late abortion case that's gripped China. It's sparked a discussion on Impact about the one child policy - joining us on the programme will be artist Aowen Jin, whose work has reflected the debate. So do you believe the one child policy has had its day? Mishal

Link Title: In Pictures: Finding work in Burkina Faso
Message: Take a look at these photographs of young women in a rural village in Burkina Faso. They face the choice of travelling to other regions to do domestic work or trying to find work at home.
An official is sacked and others punished over the case of a woman forced to have a late-term abortion, Chinese state-run media report.

Link Title: Syria in state of war, says Assad
Message: Join Babita Sharma and Rico Hizon for all the latest international news on NEWSDAY, broadcast live from London and Singapore. That's NEWSDAY, on the air from 2200-0030 gmt.

"You see things you didn't expect to be able to see."   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18529371    A poll by the Pew Research Center says that for the first time more than half of Americans aged over 65 are now using the internet. And one in three online seniors uses social networking sites like Facebook and LinkedIn.    The BBC's Rozalia Hristova visited the "gerontechnology program" at Pace University in New York City to see how young students are working with senior citizens to learn about email, Skype and instant messaging.    Talk about this story on Twitter #SilverSurfers

Link Title: SYRIA DEFECTIONS - AKIL HASHEM INTV BBC WORLD
Message: WATCH: According to reports in the Turkish media several high-ranking Syrian military figures have defected to Turkey. We spoke to a former Brigadier-General from the Syrian army about how significant such defections are. Take a look at the clip and let us know what you think.

We wanted to alert you about our new 7 part online series called 'Collaboration Culture'. We have paired up 14 creative people from around the world to work on an arts project. Click on the provided link to see how they get on. Of course we will have more on BBC World News TV.

Hi, it's Lucy today on Impact. What do you think of this photo of a young woman on the Shanghai metro? The subway authorities think this will attract perverts and is telling girls to "cherish themselves”. It’s caused outrage on Weibo from women who say it's an attempt to blame them for the problem. We'd like your thoughts. Also, what will a doubling of sales tax mean to the average Japanese consumer? That's coming up on Impact at 1300GMT. See you soon.
Two policemen are reported to have been shot and killed at Mexico City's main airport.

Link Title: Cyprus to ask for bailout help
Message: What will the Asian markets make of the latest Eurozone bailout request? Find out on NEWSDAY, with Kasia Madera in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore. That's NEWSDAY, broadcast live between 2200 and 0030 gmt.

Is the “American dream still attainable”?    That’s what the BBC asked residents of Levittown, Pennsylvania on the community’s 60th anniversary.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18560867    Levittown was built with the “American dream” in mind – cheap, decent homes in the post-WWII boom.  It’s still a solid place to raise a family, but times have changed and some think the “American dream” will never be the same.    To check out more of the BBC’s series on Levittown visit here  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16283802

"There's no romance for me to sing to you about an iPod."    The BBC recently caught up with Jack White at the legendary Ryman Auditorium in his adopted hometown of Nashville, Tennessee, to find out about his first tour as a solo artist and his commitment to pressing his work to vinyl records.      Check out our video feature  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18545530    And our commentary from North America editor, Mark Mardell  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18525200

Link Title: OLYMPIC TORCH - SHEFFIELD- BBC WORLD NEWS BEHIND THE SCENES
Message: WATCH: Mishal Husain is in Sheffield reporting on the arrival of the Olympic torch. We have asked her to go behind the scenes and speak to some of the key members of BBC's production team you never get to see on camera.
NEWSDAY will have the latest reaction to Mohammed Mursi winning the Egyptian presidency. Join Kasia Madera in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore for NEWSDAY, broadcast from 2200-0030 gmt.

Turkey's decision to call on Nato to discuss the shooting down of its warplane by Syria suggests it is looking for a concerted diplomatic response rather than taking unilateral military action, the BBC's Jonathan Marcus says.
Egyptians await the imminent announcement of results of the presidential run-off election, in which both candidates have claimed victory.
Governments in Latin America react angrily to the impeachment of Paraguayan president Fernando Lugo.

Watch the BBC Focus on Africa TV team do Azonto . Yes Alex teaches Komla, Sophie, Peter, Chaku,Mariam, Bilkisu and the entire team how to Azonto. So don't be shy!!!! Send us your videos of you doing the Azonto and we'll play some of them on BBC Focus on Africa TV. Email africa@bbc.co.uk or post them on our facebook page. Come on!!! If we can do it SO CAN YOU!!!!! — with Komla Dumor.
Turkey's President, Abdullah Gul, says the Turkish fighter jet shot down by Syria's air defence forces on Friday may have violated Syrian airspace.
The authorities in Mexico admit their claim to have captured the son of the country's most-wanted drugs lord, Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, was a case of mistaken identity.

Link Title: Blade Runner: What has come true?
Message: It's been 30 years since the release of cult film Blade Runner, and it's 10 since Minority Report. But what elements of the films have come to pass?

Along the highway linking the luxury hotels of Copacabana and the conference halls of the Rio+20 summit, the darkened windows of the VIP limousines will not have offered a clear view of the crowded hillside known as Rocinha.

Link Title: Mutuna Chanda 'Focus On Africa' BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: It's time to introduce another member of our 'Focus On Africa' team. Today we take you to Zambia from where Mutuna Chanda will be reporting. We're back on air in just over 45min time.

Link Title: Greece v Germany, the bailout game
Message: Sports writers are dubbing it the "bailout battle". Germany and Greece face each other later in the quarter finals of Euro 2012.  Germany produces 27% of the GDP in the 17-nation Eurozone, compared to 3% for Greece.  In 2011, Germany saw growth of 3%.  Greece's economy shrunk by 5.5%.  And Germany's also the footballing powerhouse - winning 6 international tournaments - Greece were the surprise champions in 2004 for the first time.  Who will win tonight?

Here's the short version of the film BBC's Ros Atkins made about the end of the Breivik trial. He met some survivors of the attacks who are now looking for closure and a more positive focus in Norway. The long version of the film will run on World Have Your Say at 1500 GMT

The New Yorker magazine is known around the world for the clever and sometimes controversial cartoons that grace its front cover.    Join us as we meet Francoise Mouly, art director for the New Yorker, who has the tough task of picking each week's iconic image. In her new book, Blown Covers, she takes us on a journey through the drawings that didn't quite make it to the front page and explains why not.   http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18511053    What's your favourite New Yorker cover?

Link Title: Group B winner v Group A runner-up
Message: Are you Greek or German football fan who in Gdansk for the 1/4 finals of Euro 2012? Do write to us and let us know who do you think will win? We want to hear about the atmosphere in the city. Does Greece, who will have to face Germany without their captain Giorgios Karagounis, stand a fighting chance? Can Greece repeat its heroics from 2004?  Let us know what you think.

Link Title: Nomsa Maseko 'Focus On Africa' - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: Today we want to introduce to you another member of the 'Focus on Africa' team. Nomsa Maseko will be reporting for from South Africa's capital Johannesburg. What do you think of our new programme? What have been your favourite stories? Is there something you didn't enjoy? How can we improve? Who is your favourite reporter? Let us know

Link Title: The Hub Promo BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: WATCH: Karin Giannone will be on air at 1600 GMT with the Hub programme. Take a look at the video to see what we will be discussing.

We're not lost - really we're not. Just keep the Nile in view and we'll find our way to the destination soon enough... Busy returning various bits of equipment to their proper places, after a week of constant relocation.
The mother of all detours. One wrong turn, 30 more minutes negotiating the usual Cairo snarl-ups. This should have been a journey of a few minutes. Whoops.
A few dozen tents have appeared in Tahrir square since Wednesday. This is the response so far to the Muslim Brotherhood's call for a sit-in.
IMAGES: Mountains high and valleys low - stunning award-winning travel images from around the world.

Link Title: London 2012 Olympics from the BBC: Latest news, sports and programmes - Home
Message: Should the Olympic Games celebrate more than just sporting achievements? That is what we will be discussing on today's Impact programme with Lucy Hockings at 1300GMT. Let us know what you think and we may use some of your comments during the programme.

As we approach 2 million likes on our page we wanted to ask what you like about our page and what you would change and like to see more of. Do you like features and analysis stories? Or are pictures and videos more interesting? Are there stories which you think we are not covering enough? Your input will help us improve the experience of our page so please let us know what you think. All of us at BBC World News would like to thank you for the contribution you make on daily basis with your comments.
I spoke too soon. A couple of hours after seeing my first car crash in Egypt, along comes another. A nasty pile-up on the road from the east bank of the Nile onto Zamalek.
Lyse Doucet enjoying the excitement. The thousands below us are having a party. The fireworks are deafening.
Our colleague from Swiss public TV Pascal Weber (@srfpascalweber) interviews Lyse on our balcony.
Tens of thousands fill Tahrir Square. A noisy demonstration of the Brotherhood's ability to mobilise their support.
Negotiating exit from parking space with traffic warden/car minder. Inscription on hat reads "Kill Teacher".
Who's filming who? Having finished a live for BBC World, we're filmed by Swiss Public TV for a documentary.
Look straight down from the live position in Tahrir square and this is what you see. Vertigo sufferers: look away now.
Battling through the huge crowds, from one side of Tahrir Square to the other. A celebration by the Brotherhood.
A small corner of Sweden in Tahrir Square. Watching wires, making calls, eating meatballs in a chilled Swedish restaurant.

Ska, a type of music that originated in Jamaica, has come to southern California - but with a specifically Latin American sound.    The BBC caught up with some of Los Angeles' local bands to find out how the music made its way north and what ska sounds like in SoCal.    http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18516342

Link Title: Kevin Mwachiro 'Focus on Africa' - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: It's DAY 3 and we are back with our new programme 'Focus On Africa'. Today we introduce Kevin Mwachiro who will be reporting from Nairobi in Kenya. For more 'Focus on Africa' visit and like the Facebook page at www.facebook.com/bbcafrica

Link Title: In pictures: Has South Sudan been a success?
Message: PICTURES: As it celebrates its first birthday, Africa Debate asks whether South Sudan has lived up to its expectations?
There are conflicting reports about the health of ousted Egyptian leader Hosni Mubarak, who has suffered a stroke.

Link Title: Offline jobseekers reach for the web
Message: WATCH: Can living without the web increase the social divide?The BBC takes a trip into a disconnected US, to see whether it is possible to escape poverty without the internet.

Link Title: Stress and illness: The decades-long search for a link
Message: Common sense tells us that constant stress makes us prone to illness. While most people outside medicine happily accept this view, it has been viewed with a much greater degree of scepticism within science. There are plenty of ideas and intuitive hunches, but rather less incontestable evidence. BBC Future reports on how the 30-year quest of one scientist has finally revealed the best evidence so far for how stress operates at the biological level. And, more importantly, other scientists think this could finally provide a plausible connection between stress and illness. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120619-how-stress-could-cause-illness

Link Title: Laeila Adjovi 'Focus On Africa' - BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: 'Focus on Africa' launched yesterday on BBC World News TV. Did you enjoy it? Would you change anything? During this week we are introducing some of the journalists who will be contributing to the programme. Today it's our reporter from Dakar, Senegal, Laeila Adjovi.

Link Title: Man walks up mountain on his hands
Message: WATCH: Climbing Mount Kilimanjaro would be a challenge for anyone but an American man has proved anything is possible, reaching the summit without legs. Spencer West lost both his legs due to a genetic disorder when he was five. His climb up Africa's tallest mountain has raised over half a million dollars for charity.

Link Title: In pictures: Unseen Muammar Gaddafi-era archive in Libya
Message: Pictures from a unique archive from Libya spanning the reign of King Idris and the North African country’s late leader Muammar Gaddafi which is going on show in London.

The Rio+20 Earth summit begins this week, and the world hopes it will help steer the global economy towards a more sustainable path. We are stretching many of our natural resources to their limits, and the assumption is that human ingenuity and market forces will save the day. But if the unthinkable happens, when can we expect our most valuable resources to run out? The latest infographic from BBC Future illustrates the sobering outlook for our dwindling natural supplies. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120618-global-resources-stock-check

Link Title: Komla Dumor 'Focus on Africa' BBC WORLD NEWS
Message: It's only a couple of hours before we launch our new programme 'Focus on Africa' on BBC World News TV (1730 GMT). During this week we'll introduce some of our journalists who will be reporting from across the continent. Today, it's time for the main presenter himself, Komla Dumor.

Link Title: India's growing problem of food wastage
Message: Hello - on Impact today we have a special report on food waste in India - especially grain languishing in warehouses because the distribution system isn't good enough to get it swiftly from farmer to consumer. Do you have your own examples of waste to share? Mishal
If you want to recapture Shanghai's era of glamour in the 1930s, you could begin by dancing a waltz in the Paramount, the city's Art Deco dance hall, says Fuchsia Dunlop.
The Wayuu tribe in Colombia celebrates its cultural festival.
Reminder to everyone that our new programme BBC Focus on Africa starts on Monday, 18th of June. Do join Komla Dumor at 1730gmt

Link Title: Why are the Beatles so popular 50 years on?
Message: Are you a Beatles fan? What does their music mean to you?
The International Olympic Committee launches a probe into allegations that Olympic officials and agents breached regulations on ticket sales.

Link Title: LA riots figure Rodney King dead
Message: Rodney King, the figure at the centre of the 1992 LA riots, is found dead at the bottom of a swimming pool aged 47, US media say.
WATCH: An exhibition has opened in Paris to mark the 50th anniversary of Algerian independence from France.
Images of voters going to the polls for a second day in Egypt's presidential election amid a bitter row over the dissolution of parliament.
WATCH: In Mexico'a drug war a sheet of glass can be the difference between life and death. As more people look to protect themselves from the violence, the demand for bullet proof cars has soared.

IMAGES: From Greece, where voters are going to the polls for the second time in six weeks amid fears for their country's future in the eurozone. Will they choose to press on with austerity measures or to go towards the exit from the euro?

Link Title: BBC News - Impact - South Korea blind news presenter reads Braille on air
Message: WATCH: A blind man has been given the job of reading the news on South Korea's state broadcasting channel. Lee Chang-hoon was one of 500 people who applied for the job, after KBS advertised for a disabled presenter.

WATCH: Go behind the scenes with BBC's Lee James and take a look at how BBC World News has been keeping you up to date with all the latest news from the Euro 2012. For more sporting updates and features make sure you visit our colleagues at 'Sportsworld BBC WORLD SERVICE'

On the Hub with Katya Adler - The UN pleas with Bangladesh to stop turning away people fleeing the sectarian violence in Burma where up to 30.000 people have been displaced by the rioting. Also, she's an Indian gold medalist, who's been detained on charges of rape - amid questions over whether she might actually be a "he". Join us at 1600GMT

WATCH: Here is a promo for our new programme Focus On Africa on BBC World News. It will be presented daily by Komla Dumor and Sophie Ikenye. The first edition will air on the 18th June at 1730 GMT. We hope you can join us!
BBC World News returns to Cairo for the second round of voting.  Commentary by producer Jonathan Twigg.

Link Title: BBC News - Impact - Boxing controversy grows over Pacquiao defeat to Bradley
Message: WATCH: Manny Pacquiao's defeat to Timothy Bradley has been causing a lot of controversy. The famous boxing commentator and journalist Ronnie Nathanielsz joined Lucy Hockings on the Impact programme to discuss the outcome of the fight and the implications of the decisions made.
Police detain a man believed to be the last fugitive of the Aum Shinrikyo cult wanted for a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway, Japan media says.

Something new is taking root in a small and dusty corner of western Niger. The unremarkable looking moringa tree has become a frontline weapon to fight the recurring droughts that have hit the West African nation.

Link Title: Russian, Chinese media justify Syrian support
Message: Russia and China have been steadfast in their refusal to back the UN resolutions on Syria, with their media presenting a distinct narrative of the Syrian struggle. We take a look at media coverage of the Syria conflict in both countries and whether broadcasters tend to justify this stance.
Henry Hill, a former mobster-turned-FBI informant whose life became the basis for Martin Scorsese's 1990 movie Goodfellas, died in Los Angeles aged 69.

Link Title: My Business: Pizza delivery in Kabul
Message: 41 year-old Muhammad Ismael Aarefi speaks to the BBC about discovering a niche in the food market in Kabul - a western-style pizza delivery service.

Link Title: Folding cars offer solution to urban transport problems
Message: How can we convince commuters who don't live near stations to leave their cars at home and use public transport? Car-pooling and bike-sharing systems, and shuttle bus services have all been tested and failed to get enough commuters out of their cars. But as BBC Future discovers, there is another option that looks set to zip around European roads as early as this summer: foldable electric cars.  http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120613-folding-cars-offer-city-solution

Link Title: Syria in civil war - UN official
Message: Syria is in civil war, warns the UN's head of peacekeeping, as the US accuses Russia of supplying the Syrian government with attack helicopters.
Join Chris Rogers in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore for NEWSDAY, broadcast live from 0000-0330 gmt.

The Times-Picayune - currently the only daily newspaper in New Orleans - is set to abandon its daily print edition. Their website will be supplemented in print form on only Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays.    We visit New Orleans to see how people are reacting to the loss of their 175-year-old award-winning daily news source.     How will the city change when the presses slow down?     http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-18346130

Link Title: BBC announces new focus on Africa
Message: We have some news for our African fans: The BBC will be launching its first-ever dedicated daily TV news programme in English for African audiences. 'BBC Focus On Africa' will air daily on BBC World News TV and will be presented by Komla Dumor and Sophie Ikenye. The news programme will draw on the pool of BBC African talent on the continent and in London to report on Africa's rising economies, entrepreneurs, innovators, culture, entertainment and sport. The first edition will air on the 18th June at 1730 GMT. We hope you can join us!

Link Title: BBC News - Dingo death ruling delights Azaria Chamberlain's mother
Message: If you have missed our interview on GMT programme with the mother of the baby girl who was taken by a dingo 32 years ago click on the attached link. Lindy Chamberlain-Creighton spoke to BBC World News about her relief and delight that the truth was finally about the death of her daughter Azaria.

Link Title: Verdict due in dingo baby case
Message: The final ruling in the dingo baby case is due in the next few hours. Join Babita Sharma in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore for full coverage on NEWSDAY, broadcast from 0000 until 0330 gmt.

PICTURES: View this amazing discovery of more terracotta warriors at the 2,200 year-old tombs of Emperor Qin Shihuang - unveiled for the first time by China after 3 years of excavation.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18391197

COMMENT: Football players from teams in the 2012 European Championship tournament recently visited the former Auschwitz-Birkenau Nazi death camps. What compels people to visit sites of mass death like these camps and like the 9/11 memorial? What do you think?

Link Title: How easy is it to forget your children?
Message: UK's Prime Minister admitted he accidentally left behind his young daughter at a pub when the family and their friends went for a Sunday lunch a few months ago. Something most busy parents could easily do, let alone a leader of a country? What do you think?
WATCH: From the Emperor of France to a nation of shopkeepers: the letter that shows off Napoleon's English language skills sells for $400,000.

Our top stories today: World markets react to Spain's bailout, Somalia sanctions threat and UK politicians giving evidence at Leveson enquiry. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18391824 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17116237 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18392576
Spain's banks get their bailout - how will the markets react? Join Babita Sharma in London and Rico Hizon in Singapore for NEWSDAY, broadcast from 0000-0330 gmt.

Link Title: Ray Bradbury: The day I read to a legend
Message: BBC Future's columnist Matt Novak was one of the last people to interview science fiction legend Ray Bradbury, who died this week. Here is his account of that meeting ...and how he ended up reading to the writer who inspired him. http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120608-meeting-the-master-ray-bradbury

WATCH: Funeral of Bee Gees singer Robin Gibb was held in his home town in Oxfordshire, Britain. Horse-drawn carriage carried his coffin as hundreds of fans lined the streets of Thame. A bagpiper led the procession.

WATCH: France prepares for parliamentary elections - the first of two rounds is on Sunday. President Francois Hollande hopes he'll get a slender majority but the main focus is the renewed battle between the far right and the far left.
WATCH/LISTEN: BBC's Paul Danahar gives his first account of what he can see in Qubair. WARNING - his account is graphic.

Link Title: The fight for a Chinese university place
Message: WATCH: In China, over nine million students compete for fewer than seven million university places. Many push themselves to the limit, or indeed are pushed by their parents, as they take the notorious Gaokao exams.
Paul Danahar in Syrian village Qubeir tweets "The largest of the two houses on the hill top in Qubeir has been gutted by fire. The stench of burnt flesh is still strong."

WATCH/LISTEN: BBC's Paul Danahar reaches the village in Syria's Hama - he's travelling with a team of UN monitors. He describes the scene as "an idyllic spot, if it wasn't for the misery that we are told awaits us at the bottom of the hill".

Top stories today: SYRIA, FORCED MARRIAGES IN UK, 2012 EUROPEAN CHAMPIONSHIPS  As international frustration increases over the lack of progress of Kofi Annan's peace plan in Syria, how else can the country avoid a civil war? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18303989  The British government proposes a law to ban forced marriages. It means parents who force their children to marry could be jailed. How prepared are victims to see that happen? http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-18356117  The issue of racism stalks 2012 European championship tournament -- the Dutch football team was a victim during training in Poland. Referees will have the power to stop games if there's racist abuse from the stands. Is this the best way to deal with the issue? http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18363736

2012 European football championships: UK government ministers will boycott England's group games in the European football championships in Ukraine. The move's in protest at the "selective justice" meted out to jailed opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko. Attendance at later matches to be kept "under review". Germany, Holland and Austria threatening a boycott. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-18351326
WATCH: Greece's problems get ugly on a live TV election debate. A far-right MP faces arrest after assaulting other guests. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18350017

Message: Nuclear is back in the news, but what does it take to build a bomb? And why do few countries bother? Link Title: Woman with learning difficulties 'trains her brain'
Message: A woman who was born with severe learning difficulties has told BBC World News that she "built herself a better brain". Barbara Arrowsmith-Young's brain training program has now helped thousands of others to do the same.

www.bbc.co.uk/news/world/  It's Kirsty Lang presenting the Hub today. She'll be looking the Nigerian president's pledge to improve air safety after the plane crash in a built-up area of Lagos that killed everyone on board and many on the ground. She also talks to an Indian MP on Sachin Tendulkar becoming the first cricketer to take a seat in the upper house of India's parliament - just how much time will he devote to political life? And the latest from Berlin on the arrest of the Canadian psycho
The Queen salutes a 1,000-boat flotilla at the Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant, as organisers say more than one million spectators defied the London rain to see it.

Huge crowds have gathered in Cairo's Tahrir Square to protest against the verdicts on Egypt's ex-President Hosni Mubarak and his co-defendants. Although Mubarak got life in prison for complicity in the killing of protesters in last year's uprising, the acquittal of key security officials sparked fury.
The US plans to move the majority of its warships to the Asia-Pacific region by 2020, Defence Secretary Leon Panetta says.

Link Title: Judge to rule in Mubarak trial
Message: A Cairo court is due to decide whether former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak is guilty of conspiracy in the killing of protesters during last year's uprising.

Link Title: Weak US jobs figures hit markets
Message: Stock markets fall following news that the US economy added considerably fewer jobs than had been expected in May.

Link Title: Pakistan flood victims face fresh misery
Message: Pakistan's disaster management chief has admitted to the BBC that floods are likely again in a matter of weeks because of a lack of proper prevention measures.   Millions of Pakistanis were affected following monsoon rains in both 2010 and 2011 prompting huge international aid mobilisation efforts.

On GMT with David Eades – Burma's opposition leader warns the world against complacency over her country's reform process. Also, we'll be live at Buckingham Palace as Britain prepares to celebrate Queen Elizabeth's diamond jubilee. Join us at 1100 GMT.
